review_text: I played 7 Days to Die and enjoyed it immensely, especially the mix of survival, crafting, and exploration. The game kept me hooked with its intense nights and rewarding progression. review_text: Bought this game a few years back and I always seem to return to it. Developers never gave up even if the cash flow has probably dwindled considerably since there's no cash shop / dlc until recently and it's been out for YEARS.  There's also great mods out there for it.  IMHO not only was it worth the money I spent on it, but I'd gladly pay for cash shops / dlc items (as long as it's cosmetic and not P2W) to help the developers out.

Ok, so review time. I have played this game for over 700 hours now and i must say it is one of the best zombie survival ames out there in my oppinion there is nothing out there that has the same feel as this game, the progressio is great and the building aspect is wonderfull. It has a steep learning curve when you start the game fresh and don't know what you are doing, but give it time and it will grow on you.
It's a voxel game so everything is a block that can be destroyed but can also be exploited.
This game is so much fun, but the devs have been going into a strange direction with the game ever since 1.0
but i still have faith they will make the game even better.

i highly reccomend this game it  is a must play.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text:
7 Days to Die is the lovechild of Minecraft and a zombie apocalypse… if that child also came with a serious performance problem. Gathering, crafting, and building feels great, especially when you’re fortifying your base for the dreaded horde night. The sandbox survival is deep and addictive, and there’s nothing like blasting zombies with a DIY shotgun you just crafted.

But optimization is rough — even mid-range PCs can struggle, and the UI feels like it was designed by someone who hates clarity. Horde nights are thrilling, but sometimes you spend more time fighting the game than the zombies.

6/10 — fun moments, but your PC might file a complaint.

review_text: I have a lot of hours in this game, but when I say that it has gotten worse with every update I mean it, the music is worse, the visuals, the game play, everything is much worse. For one, you used to be able to wear up to ten or so items on your character, now you get four FOUR! The game is not a survival game, it plays like an adventure game built on top of a survival game with a lot of features very commonly being removed to the point where I'm longing to play older versions of the game for the game play instead of wanting to remove the bulk. It's bad, but maybe still the best considering the quality of other games but it used to be great not the best of X type. Furthermore your saves will be deleted every update. Very nice.

review_text: What happened? This game is nothing like it once was - a true gem of a survival game. These days it feels bloated, laggy, and sad.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text:
Pros

- Large, interesting world with lots of towns, POIs, and places to explore.
- Combat and gunplay feel much better than the older alphas.
- Graphics and lighting are noticeably improved, especially in newer versions.
- Quests give structured gameplay for people who prefer constant action and looting.
- Multiplayer groups progress quickly through missions, loot, and XP.
- Plenty of content for looter-focused players, including weapons, mods, and POI variety.

Cons

- Base building lost most of its creativity:
   - zombie go straight for the weakest block. 
   - removed tons of building options.
   - more below.
- Skill system replaced active progression with a perk system and magazine RNG that feels generic and punishes base building.
- Game heavily favors quest grinding, leaving builders and slow-paced players under-leveled.
- Zombie pathing targets weak blocks like a laser, removing fun or experimental base layouts.
- Farming and water systems feel downgraded, slower, and more annoying than older versions.
- Long-standing bugs (hitbox issues, zombie spawns in sealed areas, vehicles glitching out) remain decade-old problems.
- Shift away from survival and building toward a faster, looter-shooter loop that many older fans don’t enjoy.

Overall: it's probably a fun game for new players.  I'm sure if I played this now without ever having experienced how good the old game was, I'd love it.  Now, it's just a generic looter-shooter to get the largest audience.  It's sad how the devs tinkering took tons of the greatest parts out of the game. 

Longer and more descriptive review:

I've been playing this game on and off since 2016.  It used to be my absolute favorite game with great building, a pretty good balance between exploration and base building, interesting mechanics with biomes, good crafting, and most importantly a very exciting and terrifying experience.  

The #1 downfall to this game and the worst part of it is that the developers CONSTANTLY change the game. Since I've been playing they've had 9 major updates that completely reworked dozens of parts of the game, usually for the worse.  If you like base building don't bother with this game anymore, they've taken out 90% of the creativity and 100% punishes you for building a base now.  

I LOVE base building and this game used to be amazing for it, the skill system actually rewarded you with a skills-based progression system but they changed that to the most generic and useless attribute/perk system with RNG books and magazines you need to find to unlock skills and traits. The old system was the type of active-use progression where if you dig, you improve your digging skill, you craft, you increase crafting skill.  

The game actively punishes you now for being a base builder.  If you play with people who do the generic trader missions or explore, they level up ten times as fast, find all the magazines and books, and then can put attributes into everything whether they use it or not.  It's so disappointing because good and fun base building takes time but now you're funneled into a looter shooter type game and punished if you build. 

They've also taken out tons of building options and changed the way hordes attack. There used to be a lot more variation in building options, building styles, and general base development.  Now the AI is pathed to the weakest points, they dig directly to the weakest tile like guided missiles, farming and other collectors like water have been replaced with poor mechanics that don't really work but still attract zombies like nothing else.  

It's all clearly to shift the game from a base building survival game to the generic skins-purchasing looter shooter, generic zombie game which can reach the broadest audiences, which has obviously worked so good for them.  

This isn't even getting into all the other bugs and problems they've never fixed or added in their constant reworks of the game.  They still have random zombie spawns in places they shouldn't be able to spawn, vehicles are a wild ride, there is still a weird lag on melee and zombie hit boxes that they've never bothered dealing with in over 10 years (one of the reasons why I prefer base building).

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: I played this first on xbox back when telltale was involved and then I got on here till my old pc couldn't run it, Then I got a new one and played it again and I can say after every update the game felt worse and worse and worse. I came back hearing somethings that were pretty much all bad. I had some hope. That was crushed very fast. Tutorial sets you up for failure. Rewards for quests aren't balanced. XP grind is not adjusted properly. Don't get me wrong it's called a grind for a reason but when almost full week passes and I'm still level 3 on default settings after killing A new yorks city worth of zombies that's just bull. Quest locations if they are a zombie filled building all the zombies just sit there till I hit a trigger and if I get a new quest in the same building they all respawn even if it was only 3 minutes since I was there. The only thing that is still around that I like (and doesn't feel pointless now) is zombies are still somewhat tanky early game but aren't going to rip your face off if your careful while also still being easy to kill. I know you can mod this game but if you have to mod a game to make it fun the game is screwed up.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text: I have been playing this game for about 10 or so years now on and off. What they have done to progression is just awful. Remember when crafting an item made you better at crafting it? Remember when doing an action like running, jumping, looting , ect. Made your skill for that level up? I sure do. Now most of your progression is pretty much 100% RNG dependent. They keep making changes that force you into a certain playstyle instead of you know... The sandbox survival game that it used to be. Making farming harder, zombies don't drop loot like they used to, constantly changing zombie AI to nerf base designs they don't like people using, removing clothing for some reason, removing getting jars back after drinking water, making leveling traders harder, and just so many more obnoxious and useless changes that horrible. Its like they hate their players I really do not get it. It is honestly just so sad to see what the game has become. I really cannot recommend this game anymore especially for $45.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text:
I have honestly yet to play a game as unstable as this.
Even on the latest build, native linux or proton with a half-million different settings tweaked, it remains horribly unstable.

At any random time, atleast once per hour, the game will either freeze my system, or spike the memory usage 30gb, and THEN crash after OOMing my system.

Its a... slow game when its not crashing, with progression made difficult by the instability since at any moment it could crash forcing you to remain in places that are as safe as possible.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text:
I've put over 300 hours into this game because it was one me and my sisters would play together, but since its official 1.0 release, the game has not improved in any considerable way, and the price hike to $45 is wildly stupid because it's not worth more than $30 for the content that's available. Not to mention, there's no actual purpose to the game other than 24/7 survival. There's no story, and the "quests" that are in the game do nothing but help you level up to unlock perks. The base building aspect is lacking and extremely mediocre, the combat mechanics are still crap and the graphics are still ugly to look at.

If you are still interested in it, buy it when it goes on a steep sale. Otherwise, avoid it.

One of the best city builder/kingdom makers i,ve played in a bit and graphically beautiful

Farthest Frontier is a fantastic city builder. The visuals are beautiful, the atmosphere feels alive, and it’s genuinely rewarding to see your small settlement grow into a thriving town. The survival mechanics add just the right amount of challenge, keeping things engaging without being frustrating. Every run feels different, and I keep coming back for more. Easily one of the best games in the genre.
In-depth medieval city sim. Combat is trash, but can be disabled

Great game. UI is a bit peculiar and the game has performance issues, when you reach higher population numbers, but overall you can sink many hours into this, do micromanaging, fight against animals and raiders and so on. It's a mix of Anno, Frostpunk and Cities Skylines with it's own touch.

One of the best examples of early access done right. Been there from the beginning and the developer communcated their goals well, took enough time to implement everything and there weren't even too many bugs involved! 
Great chill but also demanding survival city building with an emphasis on forward planning, resource production, population management and trade. Also big thumps up for no use of AI!
This is a great game. Realistic and challenging. love getting as far as I can and then rerolling and trying out something else.
Chilling and relaxing game with a lovely characteristic
One of your villagers died. ☠️
Way better than Manor Lords

Mix of city builder and RTS. There's some depth to the production chains and tech tree but the military gameplay loop is pretty basic. Early game food production is a bottleneck. Late game the raiders are overpowered.

Overall it's a decent game with both easy and challenging map biomes and gameplay modes. There's some flexibility to city layout but there's certain production chains that work better when placed in a more formulaic structure, so the city building part is kind of repetitive after a couple of play throughs. The strategic combat portion of the game is very basic and repetitive after the first five raids.

The devs have hinted at future updates and possibly DLCs if the game sells well so hopefully they continue to expand on the core gameplay loops like they did during early access.

It's like a more polished version of banished with basic RTS combat added. There's at least 30-50 hours of play here minimum. More if you enjoy city building with some environmental interruptions and the occasional raider incursion.

Definitely a good city builder sandbox game with some shallow military and RTS components.

Exceptional before release, exceptional at release. This game will suck you in for hours, even when you've finished it repeatedly. There's something really satisfying about it. Can't wait to see how it develops.

FInally into V1.0 and great to see the game become what most of us thought it would be. 

Highly recommended and now its in V1.0 its time tog et right into the gameplay and enjoy the completed features.
Its a really well made game. The first learning curve is a bit step due to having to set limits in your storages inventory. But otherwise all good and fun.
solid city builder and very addicting
One of the best city manegment/builder game on steam. Looks both beautiful and feels easy too learn/understand.
Rich and cool game mechanics.

Surprisingly deep, especially on the economic side. Its city-building system is stable and well-designed, and the realistic crop-rotation mechanics make it an excellent survival city-builder — even if the combat elements are not the most exciting part of the experience. I can only recommend it to every city-builder fan.
I enjoy this one. Easy to start and fun to deep dive into. Late game gets slow and a little grindy but is still fun. Its only a month old and I'm at 220+ hrs already. That speaks for itself.
Simple but a crafty gameplay design.
This is my favorite of the colony city builders. Great farming, lots of depth
A certified cozy banger for the years to come. It's both challenging and merciful for a very satisfying result that's going to make you crave for "One more year" over and over.

A worthy successor to the classic Banished. Very pretty art style that is mostly grounded with a slight fantasy flair to it. The changing seasons are beautiful to look at, and the survival mechanics are a solid challenge and very tweakable. Combat is a welcome addition as well!
Really fun time sink that I often play while listening to podcasts. Continues to see regular improvements.

After 97 hours, I think I can confidently say that it feels incomplete. The tech tree doesn't seem to flow well, there aren't clear explanations as to what things mean, I don't have a hotkey (or at least one that I could find easily) to select all of my laborers at once and have them do a task (like excavation). I enjoyed the game, but there are so many issues and missing quality of life mechanics. It feels like its still early access.

Promising at the start, but very slow and little in the way of goals/progression/difficulty as you get further.  Can't be bothered to complete the first play through and it's just more bleh.  Badly thought out tech tree, raids do not work well and are not particularly challenging.  I could go on.

8 hours of game play, gunna recommend the game but it needs polish. The production chains are difficult to navigate (ie viewing recources, how much iron do i have? do i have enough workers, great i have way to much now, feeling)

Plus the production chains arnt all that fleshed out, as well.  No logisitcs ect (remote work camps but no low priority depot)

Combat sucks, trade hub no auto trade or Search.   basically the menus need work.  As a gamer, im not going to lean into trade, until im self seficient,  and if you wanna support the town, you need to do this, till like tier 3.

Farming sucks, interesting idea, but too much micro management, Still aint figured out what sand and clay do..

Speaking of, No tutorial. No clear idea what does what. Its a over production mindset with this game. Could use a que from captain of industry in this regard... Graphs are cool, but whats the demand for an item? (am i producing to much of this?  Oh it spoiled.. oh there is rats now, well gotta pay the rat catcher, is that worth doing?) 

So problems aside, Kill the hostile stuff, and forget the military, this a laid back city builder.. Otherwise, similar to banished.  

Fun, time killer, but def DEF needs some 1.0 polish.........Thats why recommend no, even though it is actually pretty good.

***EDITED FOR MASSIVE LOSS & DISAPPOINTMENT***

***My 70 hour city where I unlocked everything, maxed out the tech tree, and was basically just constantly taunting raiders, was magically erased from my "saved games"... started 1 new city after writing my initial review which was overwhelmingly positive; put about 35 hours into it, & my son asked me to see my previous, well-developed city, and to my surprise when I went to load it, it simply didn't exist anymore. Only a slew of auto-saves of my current city. It had its own name, I never interacted with or deleted anything at all. But my 70 hour investment doesn't exist anymore & I now have absolutely zero desire to play this game again. For those that do, please be careful with your save files. Absolutely crushing loss, as silly as it seems...***

I started a fresh new settlement about 5 times back to back before feeling like I had a decent enough foot-hold & understanding of the game & its mechanics to progress into the later tiers of the game. Now 66 hours in, with probably 58-60 of those hours dedicated to a single settlement; I would say, this game is amazing, & consistently leaves me wanting more. After building all 3 civic monuments(you "win" after building just one), I am only left wanting more, & feeling like I've only scratched the surface of what the game has to offer.

**Key points**

- The economy management & trading is, for me, supremely enjoyable. As your settlement & population scales up, it becomes more challenging to continue "out-producing" the demand of your buildings & settlers in order to have surplus goods available for trading with the traveling merchants at your trading post; requiring attentive oversight of how much labor you invest into producing whatever goods you want to produce. Some items/goods come very easily, others take tremendous time. For example, platemail armor seems to be the most valuable individual item that a settlement can generate, typically valued between 800-1000 gold for a single unit. But the time it takes to generate even a single platemail is literal in-game years. And if you have heavy soldiers, they will automatically seek/equip them from storage. So generating a surplus to cash in on is very difficult & time consuming. However, you can also grow grain to your hearts desire to either stockpile, or mill into flour; with a huge host of options in between. The game has a long list of goods/items that are ALL used by your settlers & buildings as you play, & trackable in-game by you as the goods move from person to person/building to building. 

- The time investment relative to progress. I read several other reviews that criticize the game speed & the fact that "max speed" is a 3x multiplier of normal in game speed which is admittedly slow, but revealed itself necessary. While in the very early to early/mid-game(tier 1/tier 2), the game can feel like a crawl, & like you WISH there is a 5x or 10x option to build resources. But as I progressed & as the settlement became much more complex, I found myself slowing down to 1x speed, if not pausing outright, to micro individual things, especially trading and inventory management AT the trading post. Also, when a combat alert happens, you want to slow down to properly arrange your troops to defend. Enemies can approach rather quickly at 3x. I initially found myself wanting more of a fast-forward function, but rapidly outgrew that thought & found the 3x speed option to be more than sufficient as my settlement grew, & as I invested more of my time into a settlement. My time investment ultimately had me appreciate the fact that the game caps at 3x.

- Aesthetics. The game & specifically the architecture evolution look outstanding. Each & every time I built something new, or watched a building upgrade to its next tier, I was pleased & proud.

- Difficulty. My main settlement is played on whatever normal/default is. & while there are minor tips & tutorials that pop up to assist you, the game leaves much to be discovered through trial and error, & i am the type of gamer to very much appreciate that. I don't want my hand held on how to be successful in a game like this, & i've found the difficulty curve to be very rewarding. Figuring out why production is off, or why you're running short on a particular good, or short on labor/builders & rectifying that problem is challenging & fulfilling.

66 hours in, I cant say I have individual complaints. The game has been overwhelmingly enjoyable, & whatever problems/complaints I "thought" I had at individual points in the early game, revealed themselves to be manageable, & merely requiring experience.

All that said, this game has a moderately low floor for entry, but an absolutely Massive ceiling of potential that will take hundreds if not thousands of hours to master. Huge shout out to the devs for creating this GEM of a game.

I had been watching this game for a long while waiting for the release.  And well.  It's not done.

Town defense is garbage.  You can't place archers on walls, so they just try to fire through gates until they get over run, or worse try to fight close quarters.  The towers do less damage than a hunter, they're really just more of a distraction until other troops get there.

A lot of the industry and resource gathering needs pretty severe reworking.  Getting industry to the point that you can either turn a profit or even maintain demand is nearly impossible.

You are constantly out of food.  The amount of people needed to make food grows to the point that it's the only thing you can do.  

I really would like this game if it got ironed out but it's just moderately frustrating at the moment.

It's very slow progress and if playing with raiders they are OP'd in the early game and just slow down progress even more. Hours of playing leads to not much advancement. Feels like a bit of a waste of time.

I hate the tech tree. I do not understand how a group of aspiring settlers have absolutely no experience in farming, mining and animal husbandry. Why the F would they try to start a town (starving or not) if they cannot sustain it? They brought people who can do the complicated process of the tannery and soap making but no one who deals with food provision?

"right hans we have everyone here to start a new town, soap makers, basket makers and shoe makers" 

"Ok stuart, what about food though? should we take people who know how to do animal husbandry"

"Na hans, we will suss that out through a ridiculously slow process of building research points so while we make mountains of soap bars and shoes we can all slowly starve to death"

For me it would have made more sense to have these capabilities already unlocked as a foundation and your research points can be spent on skill levels of the specific task. Not sure what has happened to the growth mechanic as barely any new settlers come. TBH its no wonder no one new arrives as the first lot that left to start a new town haven't got a clue what they are doing and are probably presumed dead.
On the early access by year 10 in the game a flourishing town has emerged that is progressing at the leisure of the player but instead now by like year 40 they are only "discovering what a goat is" by "they" i mean the last 3 villagers left that haven't died by eating soap or baskets.

I like the city building in this game, but they have had more than a year i think in early access and do nothing about the unit controls. Worst unit controls I have ever played. You have to manually select every citizen that isn´t a soldier if you want to use them and then there is nothing more to control them. Just put them in a place and then repeatedly keep them in place while trying to make them attack. I hate to give this a thumbs down because this is the only problem with the game, but this is unplayable for me.

This game is fine, but there's a caveat there based on what you want out of it. 

So far as city building and citizen management goes this game is decent. Nothing exceptional but everything more or less works the way you think it should and it's not too much hassle. There is a decent tech tree but it takes an absurd amount of time to get all of the perks if you want them, despite the fact that It has a very Banished feel to it and you can make extremely nice/authentic looking villages if that's your jam. 8/10. 

The thing I was most excited about, which most city builders do not incorporate, is RTS mechanics. Every few years bandits will raid your city and you have to defend it. You have an okay amount of troop options and walls/towers to use. Again, nothing special, but the RTS mechanics also very clearly not the focus of this game. Which is the problem. The difficulty in defending your base isn't actually the invading forces, the difficulty is in micromanaging your troops/villagers. This game has beyond abysmal micro. Getting your archers to stand still and shoot is borderline impossible unless you're willing to individually tell each archer exactly which enemy to shoot and when. Infantry spend most of their time getting stuck on each other. When they're not stuck on each other they're following enemies around instead of attacking. The attack move command doesn't work the way you would expect attack move to work if you've ever played an RTS before. Your archers are going to run into melee range and your infantry are going to run past enemies. Not sure what kind of clown programmed the RTS mechanics into this game but they're beyond infuriating to use. 0/10. 

I played this game for 20-something hours years ago when I bought it on early access. The game has come a long way since then with it's official release. But the military side of the game is almost unplayable for me. 

Got my Desert Jewel Achievement and then uninstalled the game immediately. I don't mind hard games. In fact I like hard games. But the game should give you challenges to overcome, not be a challenge to use.
Great game, but it keeps crashing when i'm through year 4. I will recommend this game if that gets fixed.

Game is okay. Probably worth the money on sale, but to be honest lacks a bit of depth towards the latter part of the game.

The pacing could be a bit faster, lacks a bit of QoL (it's tedious to re-arrange a base), doesn't really discuss mechanics (not even in their website), there are some strange quirks (farmers from far away keep travelling between crop lots), lacks options in logistics management and clarity of which goes where and how does inventory flow across the town, doesn't discuss the production rate of buildings, bugs (flag doesn't re-appear when a barracks is destroyed). Trading becomes stagnant after awhile, you just wait for the rng and check what the merchant buys or sells. Economy mechanics where there is no true way to make a sustainable economy with large surpluses passively. No passive trading functionality (you have to micromanage every sale and re-stock?)

The list goes on..

Simply put, the game has a decent base but lacks polish for a full release game. Happy to revisit the review maybe a year from now after improvements.

I expected this game to have a stronger historical accuracy but it's disappointing. For some unexplainable reason Christian churches have been left out, even though they were a prominent feature in every medieval town. Also, meat plays a disproportionately large role in the residents' diet, even if in reality meat was more of a luxury item among the common people in the Middle Ages. If you don't mind things like this, the game is fairly good.

I love Banished, so I'd love to love this game. Actually, I'd love to be able to play this game. I can't though, because despite the UI scaling the fonts remain ridiculously small and unreadable on a 4K monitor and a 4K TV.

Sadly, this is a "no" for me.  I  bought the game a couple years ago thought it had promise but needed a better tutorial/encyclopedia as well as more polish.  I checked in here and there and found the picture to be largely the same.  The full release looks pretty much identical to what we had a few weeks ago.  There clearly are a lot of systems.  There are many resource types.   Village development looks promising.   But, stuff is hard to see and some of the mechanics are obscure; it is easy to sink an hour only to find there would have been only one way to proceed in the beginning lest your folks stave or die of cold.  So, perhaps less freedom and a bit more hand holding in the beginning?  Given that I have a life and a family and don't game every day, a disappointing evening is enough to turn me off for months.  10 years ago, when there were not many games in the genre (I also had not reproduced and had a much less demanding job), I would have felt compelled to figure it all out.  Now, I can think of at least 5 similar games off the top of my head and they are not the same of course but are infinitely easier to get into for playing a couple hours here and there.  

As a side note, games take a long time to develop and FF did look incredibly good when it came out in EA.  Now, the visuals are better than average but not by any means jaw dropping.  Furthermore, there are now a few gridless games with organic road placement and going back to square grids and deliberately building dirt roads does not feel good; grids are an artifact of game coding, not medieval village development.  Dirt roads just happen over time.  I want messy and organic, not neatly tied to a square grid with 90-deg turns.  I did not expect the devs to change their whole game to come up to speed on this so it did not figure into the yea or nay decision.  

I do hope that documentation or a tutorial will make barrier of entry lower because there seems to be a lot there past that point.

Well this game do has a nice style to it but it is not particularly fun. There really is no motivation going forward, no mini quests or challenges, citizens don't come with new needs, you just build for the sake of it. The scaling is also off in the tech tree on my 4K monitor and the font is horrible. Foundation for example is much more fun.

Trash. Villager AI is fundamentally broken, not just in response to hostiles which is well documented but even farmers and so on will mill around the field uselessly for entire seasons without doing anything. You can manually select villagers and move them around but there's no option to tell them to go back onto the AI, so they mill around for weeks before they're polled again. Scaled UI actively gets in the way.

The game is actually pretty dang good. The interface, controls/hotkeys (or lack thereof), and quality of life: ABYSMAL. 

After quite a few hours of enjoyment, I'm frustrated and feel insulted by the developer's lack of interest in implementing more/better hotkeys (it's not much work) or the ability to even select all villagers or control them as a group, etc. They built in these controls for military but expect you to slowly drag-select the many groups of villagers across your very large town and manually click them into place. Then, they'll roam back off into raiders to die. Nonsense.

I don't get the hype.
Played quite a while, but never felt any connection to the game.

IMHO the game lacks soul. Yes, there are a few interesting mechanics, but they don't really go anywhere.
Micromanaging your gatherers in the first few years - nice. Doing it in year 20 (or... not doing it) - why?
Same with farms - it's a nice idea to have crop rotation, but the way it is done feels like a minipuzzle game.
Techtree is completly random - it's just after some time: "here's a techpoint"-> click something -> something is 10% better or "here is a new building" -> "yeah, i have a new building, because i clicked on someting"

And while you might say: at least some new mechanics -> the rest is nothing new and you have all seen it better done. None of the buildings/workcycles are animated. The buildings have some moving parts and people stand around and do the same movement the whole time - the only thing that visually changes is the amount of produce in the storage. This has been done better 20 years ago. Not even the transports are visible - people just go around empty handed and ... 10 wood delivered to building site (there is some hint of it with the baskets and carts, but it just doesn't come to life for me).

You could say, that's not important, as long as the gameplay is good - but there is none. Building a busy town is the game - that town looks busy but taking a closer look, it's just people walking or standing around doing unconnected animations.

(For clarification: take the brickyard: you see the forms for the bricks, you see bricks layed out for drying, you see the ovens and the pile of done bricks - nobody ever moves anything. nobody uses the forms for the bricks, nobody lays them out to dry, noone puts them in the oven or takes them out - all they do is sit in front of the oven with some stick and then the pile behind them gets bigger.)

Music is good but very repetitive.
Menues are bad .... it is a city builder - why is the build menue full of submenues? instead of beeing spread on the bottom of the screen, like every(!) other city builder does it (ok - do it differently, but why do it worse? - feels like "building is just a small part of the gameplay" ... well... then where is the rest?)

That's basically how I feel about it - either there are major parts missing or - if what is there should be all - it's by far not good enough (because it has been done better over and over by others and the devs should and could have done their research).

Game takes forever to load and sometimes wont load. If it loads, crashes constantly and you go through the whole process again. Steam said no refund because I played more than 2 hours (14 hrs) but over 90% of that was either waiting to load or trying to recuperate after crashing. 2 hrs is Steams policy. My policy is when I pay for a game and it wont play and you wont refund, I dont buy any more games from you and I give you a lousy review. Sorry, thats my policy.
optimized like shit for higher population settlements

I reached 1000 population and the game felt... Done.

I guess the replayability felt bit low for me, but maybe it's just my gaming style.

The threat is always external (invading barbarians, barbarian camps, wild animals) - there are no other kingdoms to worry about or to do some diplomacy with.

It felt like some medieval life elements were missing in order to give this game a bit more... Flair. Such as the ability to have a monarch, a castle, guards with the house colors, maybe some crime as the population is unhappy or hungry... You know, mechanics to enhance the medieval-inspired gameplay. But this is just my opinion, it may not be this game's ultimate goal to do any of that, and that's okay.

Not recommending it, however, due to the limited replayability vs current price.

This game was in early access for over 3 years and whilst they made significant improvements to the game, one of the biggest complaints was the terrain tool. They ignored all feedback and criticism regarding this for over 3 years and released the game to 1.0 with the tool in the same state as it was when they released to early access. Why is the terrain tool such a big issue you may wonder resulting in my negative review and inability to enjoy the game?

Buildings and paths follow the terrain so if you place a building on uneven terrain, it is wonky. This is especially noticeable for the larger buildings. The last time I played the game on a mountain map, my mind broke as I realised my entire Town was completely wonky made worse and more noticeable with the larger buildings and upgrades to housing.

The other issue is that any ranged buildings and units get a bonus to their damage depending on the terrain height relative to their target. This means that to create proper defences, you have this incredibly tedious, unintuitive and somewhat broken tool to try and adjust the terrain heights. It's abysmal and ruins the entire game to the point that most people don't even bother playing on maps that have hills or mountains because they do not want to have to deal with this issue.

I thought these devs would be good because they made Grim Dawn, but I was so wrong. How can you ignore so many complaints about the terrain tool and not do anything to rectify it? It's the worst implementation of a terrain tool I've ever seen in a game in my 3 decades of gaming.

I want to like this game but I find it so slow and the tech tree to be a disappointment. 

Want your villagers to be better at defending? Click a button. No experience based skill system. 

Raiders don't make sense. Raiders: Let's attack that village of 50 people and hope they don't attack us back! 5 vs 50.. smart.

Resources don't matter, they're abundant and now matter how many trees you chop down, you'll always run out of logs but forestry is a tier 2 technology.. cause planting trees like planting crops is just a no no.

I'll give this game a pass for another year I think.

Farthest Frontier began Early Access with a strong core and beautiful aesthetic, but the 1.0 release disappointingly failed to evolve beyond its "basic foundation status." The game quickly becomes dull and repetitive due to a fundamental lack of meaningful progression. The core mechanics are sound, but they do not deepen over time. Maps feel monotonous, and the raiding mechanic is less of a strategic challenge and more of an annoying disruption. Ultimately, the game offers a competent but shallow city-builder experience that gets boring quickly for veterans of the genre.

I appreciate the time and effort it takes to make games as I have personally invested dozens of hours attempting project after project. It's no small feat that the game works as it does at all and you should always be proud of that. However as a capitalist "Product" not a free program you are distributing, I reserve the right to harshly judge and attempt to warn others off. 0/10 no innovation or genre-defining mechanics just another pile to the slop inspired by those who came before it and actually innovated.

It's just so slow to progress through the knowledge part, even with everything upgraded. 

The upcost pricing is terrible. I want to get an army but i'll get taxed into oblivion and have to trade off with risking getting my shit plundered because I can't afford an army.

All in all, needs work and balancing.

Update 23 November 2025:
You know what, I know when to eat my words.  Like a week after I wrote my "this is abandonware" review, they released a major update.  I guess all the people who said "negative reviewers are morons, everything is fine" are probably feeling pretty vindicated right now.  But I'm not taking back what I said about 16 months of crickets being "not normal," even if the people who called us morons were right.  A lot of EA games get quietly ditched in less than 16 months, so it's not like there wasn't some precedent here.

That being said, I put in 56 hours on the previous version and had fun.  I haven't played the new update yet, but the last version (16 months ago) was pretty fun and I enjoyed it, so I imagine the update only made it better.  For $30, it's not a bad value - I've paid way more for AAA games that I finished playing in way less time, so this is a pretty good value for the amount of game time you get.  I changed my review to positive, since it's still an active game.

***************

I really enjoyed this game while it lasted. Exhibit A: I put 56 hours of played time into it, because it was fun, until you basically ran out of things to do.  For the $30 or so that I paid, I got a decent amount of play time.  I've paid way more for AAA games that I finished playing in way less time, so the value isn't bad.  And New Cycle isn't even that buggy for an EA game.

If you're okay with putting down $30 for a few dozen fun hours of a well thought-out game, have at it.  But if you're expecting the rest of the roadmap to be completed sometime this century... don't hold your breath - you might suffocate.

The last substantive update (aka something that changed the playable code) was in July of 2024.  Everything since then has just been puff pieces and pretty posters of "things that are being worked on." And even the last of those was about 9 months ago.

And for those people who say "negative reviewers are morons, everything is fine"... I refer you to Kerbal Space Program 2, which went through this exact cycle (no pun intended).  The developer stopped updating the game.  Then marketing took over and tried to hide that.  They even posted a "thanks for hanging out, look at everything we accomplished so far!" right before the game got abandoned.  Then the publisher fired the entire studio and refused to ever confirm or deny that it had been abandoned - they just quietly walked away even as the community cried about it.

I enjoyed the game while it lasted, I really did.  I'm honestly more mad at people who are still defending the nothing that's happened for the last 16 months and thinking this is normal.  Look at any normal job - if you keep telling your boss that you're working for 16 months, eventually he's going to find out that you haven't actually done anything for 16 months.

It's up to you - if you close your eyes and pretend you're buying a finished game, it's not a bad value.  But you can't ever really "win" because that part never got written in.  I can't recommend a game that'll never finish its roadmap.

/shrug

Normally I wait until I finish a game before posting a review but in this case it seemed necessary to counter some of the negative reviews spreading misinformation that have been posted lately.

Also, if the negative reviewers bothered to check the discord discussions, they would learn that the game has not been abandoned. Having said that, the only way any Developer stays in business is by generating enough revenue to keep the lights on so I genuinely hope this game succeeds because even as the negative reviewers admit, the Developers have created a solid foundation for a great game.   

To give some context, I purchased this game last year on the same day that I purchased Manor Lords. After testing both games, I refunded Manor Lords and kept New Cycle, not because Manor Lords was a bad game, but because New Cycle was the more polished game - it looked better, sounded better, and had far fewer bugs and mechanical problems. I plan to get Manor Lords once it is in better shape but people need to show patience for early access games like Manor Lords AND New Cycle that have small development teams. 

New Cycle is already a good game with lots of potential. As such, it is certainly worth trying out and supporting if you like this genre.

As of today 11-20-25, the developers have breathed life back into this game with an overdue but outstanding update, so with that, I have updated my recommendation for the game.

This game is not for the faint of heart. It is a punishing, deeply challenging survival builder that will test your patience and resolve. If you're looking for a gentle, hand-holding experience, this isn't it. But if you're a fan of games like Frostpunk or Rimworld and crave a truly brutal, unforgiving challenge, then you've found your next obsession.

The core gameplay loop is incredibly tough. You are thrown into an apocalyptic world with very little guidance, and the early game is a constant struggle. The first few cycles are a desperate scramble for resources, and you will fail. A lot. But every failure is a lesson. And when you finally manage to survive and thrive, the sense of accomplishment is unlike anything else.

The game's music and art style are fantastic and perfectly capture the bleak atmosphere. However, the background music can become repetitive, and the menu audio cues are sometimes inconsistent, which can break the immersion.


Final Verdict: This game is a raw, compelling, and incredibly rewarding survival experience. It's harsh, but that's the point. It's a game about enduring against all odds, and if you're willing to embrace the challenge, you'll find a truly special game here.

Just spent 6 hours in New Cycle and I’ve officially gone from 'just one more building' to 'how did it get 3AM again?' 😩🔥

Game’s got that classic city builder addiction loop, but with survival stress sprinkled in. Imagine Banished had a love child with Frostpunk, and then it watched Mad Max for parenting tips. Yeah, it’s kinda like that.

The good:
✅ Building from sticks and stones to smokestacks and steel feels chef’s kiss
✅ The post-apocalyptic vibe actually makes sense and adds pressure
✅ Managing resources and trying not to starve your entire population = true strategy gamer moment™

The mid:
⚖️ UI’s doing its job but not winning any awards
⚖️ Tutorial? Nah, figure it out like the rest of us, champ 💀
⚖️ Sometimes you stare at your screen for 10 minutes thinking “what now?” but in a good existential way

The not-so-good:
❌ Game stutters a bit once your city turns into a spaghetti mess
❌ Some features feel half-baked (early access vibes, y’know)
❌ Still no mod support so we can't replace citizens with anime characters yet smh

Final thoughts?
It’s not perfect, but it’s got that “one more hour” energy. If you're into city builders with a side of chaos and a sprinkle of solar apocalypse, give it a shot. I’m definitely keeping my eye on future updates.

Jumping into New Cycle on normal difficulty feels both familiar and different if you have played other survival city-builders. The setup is classic, with humanity clawing back from collapse and you taking responsibility for organizing the first sparks of civilization, where every decision matters.

The opening focuses on survival by securing food, wood, and housing while constantly juggling limited workers between gathering and construction. On normal mode, the difficulty feels fair because mistakes such as expanding housing too quickly before stabilizing food supplies are noticeable but not devastating.

The atmosphere stands out as one of the strongest elements. The bleak post-apocalyptic setting and detailed visuals make it rewarding to watch a small camp slowly grow into a functioning village. Some mechanics feel unclear at first, and the resource loop can become repetitive as you shift workers around to keep production moving.

Unexpected events also keep things interesting, like when a worker at the soup kitchen died in a fire, forcing you to adapt quickly. Compared to easy mode, normal is far more engaging. On easy, resources are abundant, setbacks are mild, and events rarely disrupt your plans, so the challenge and tension are almost absent. I would recommend playing on normal since it strikes a better balance between survival pressure and steady progress, making victories feel earned rather than handed to you.

Still, the game would feel smoother if the population were not so demanding. Right now, everyone seems to want something different at the same time: one person asks for a shack, another demands better health care, and someone else expects improved worker morale. Meeting all of these requests in the same time frame feels overwhelming and at times unrealistic, which makes progression more frustrating than it needs to be.

Overall, New Cycle already delivers a solid foundation with its atmosphere, resource management, and survival tension. With future updates and development, it has the potential to become something even more polished and enjoyable

When playing New Cycle in campaign easy mode, the game feels much more relaxed and forgiving. Resources are easier to manage, people stay healthier, and disasters are less punishing, which gives you time to focus on building and exploring instead of constantly putting out fires. It feels more like a calm city-builder than a survival challenge, and I even managed to survive four in-game years without losing anyone, with the only deaths coming from old age rather than sickness or disaster.

The only drawback is the camera movement, which feels a bit locked since you can’t rotate it with a simple right click like in most city-building games, making navigation feel clunky at times. Overall it is enjoyable in this mode, but the game still has room to improve, especially in controls and adding more meaningful depth to keep players engaged longer.

I enjoyed learning how to play and the concept is really solid. I really like the world map and Explorer building, it feels like a throwback to one of my favourite parts of Frostpunk. However, there are major game breaking bugs that emerge when specific circumstances are met. For example, one of the maps available to play on (there are two currently) has a river, and you can build a bridge across the river to exploit resources on the other side. However, the bridge will never connect to your village's main road which has a major effect on the resource's productivity values. You can also build multiple bridges overtop of that bridge -- it's like the game doesn't detect it. The Tier 3 kitchen is less efficient than the Tier 2 kitchen. With multiple users noting a recent lack of engagement from the devs in the community discussion forums (some claiming abandonware), there is no telling when, or even if, these issues might be fixed. 

That said, this game does have the potential to be something really great. I hope they don't give up on it.

There might be a curse on city builder games, for whatever reason most of them that I tried lately aren’t really good, especially with those that try to mix two existing ideas in one, like a clear banished/frostpunk combo here. 
[list]
    [*] No updates. At the time of writing the game is in EA and the last patch was 13 months ago. Sure, there was a patch on an experimental branch - but it lacks both in quality and quantity, and there was no word from the devs, so the game might not even hit 1.0.
    [*] Horrible visual style. Not in a way that it looks ugly, but in an entirely different way: the buildings not only look so similar that you can barely distinguish them from each other, they somehow manage to blend in with the terrain too, as everything has the exact same dirt brown palette. The fact that minimap does not, for whatever reason, show anything but the terrain makes finding scattered gathering huts basically impossible.
    [*] Poor stat/feedback/UI. Yes, there are a bunch of graphs, but some show useless stuff, some useful stuff is nowhere to be found, most of the menus go for “style over QOL”. There isn’t even a classical Banished work menu for fast job switching - and considering that people here die often and training them for higher tier buildings is completely manual - you will be doing it a lot, manually for every building, wasting time to find where exactly did your worker die.
    [*] Horrible morale/workload system. How it is supposed to work: you make people happy so you can force them to work harder or get other benefits. How it works here: you try to make them work harder - and they are tired in 5 minutes, so you either micromanage like mad for pathetically low bonuses or simply stop interacting with the system as there are no other benefits you can get from it. But wait, that’s not all - for whatever reason every single workload/productivity decision you make uses absolute values instead of percentage. Example: you have an event to give your workers one day off in 10 days and get -20 productivity, so you expect that your worker who contributed 10 points (building has 10 workers max) will now give only 8, right? Wrong, it just means that 3 workers will do the same job as 1. How does one day off in 10 days lead to 66% loss of productivity? I have no clue.
    [*] The whole “story” thing. In Frostpunk you have a steady buildup, you are shown how dangerous the cold is and are told about the big event that will be much, much worse - so you, the player, have a clear goal that you FEEL you need to achieve. In this game though you have a few lines of text about how bad it will be and… Welp, nothing. There are some bad events that are more annoying than threatening or dangerous, and the finale does not feel like a big event you are preparing to - it is just a “welp, the run ended” screen. To put it simply - the survival story is not working due to being poorly written and having no impact on gameplay.
    [*] World map. On paper you can build outposts on the world map to get resources. In practice it comes a bit late in the run and the whole thing feels extremely basic and underdeveloped.
    [*] Technology tree. It is weird - instead of having branches it has tiers, and upgrading a tier does not need the technologies from a lower tier - but it needs several buildings and a certain population number. Yes, I know that the buildings needed do require technologies from that tier - but I had enough cases where I unlocked a building without having its prerequisite in the production chain. So this whole tier system feels like a forced tutorial for every tech level - very weird and inorganic. And at higher levels the prices for each building become so high that it completely kills the pacing as you have to wait way too long to get enough resources to build anything.
    [*] End game techs. To put it simply: when you get to the last tech level upgrading your building gets you zero benefits for insane resource costs. That’s because those buildings are supposed to be hooked to conveyors and highways to work at full efficiency. Sure, when you do that - those buildings will give you really good bonuses. The problem - you will never do that, because up to this point you were building your whole city trying to make it as tight as possible to minimize travel times (even though logistics doesn’t seem to work right now) and get into the radius of service buildings - so you simply do not have any free space to build a surprisingly wide highway or conveyor belts. In theory you can rebuild your whole production, but here comes the next problem:
    [*] Clash of survival and sandbox ideas. Currently most of the gameplay is just a Banished clone - free build sandbox. In that type of game you can switch your laws (btw, apart from events there aren’t even simple laws like population control), rebuild your whole city if it no longer is good enough for you. But at the same time you are playing by survival rules: decisions that you can never change, not having enough time to rebuild even a part of your city - let alone your whole production facility - because you have a ticking timer, strict requirements for resources and efficiency. Sadly those two aspects of the game instead of working together mostly play against each other, that clearly shows that the game needed more time in the oven to decide what it wants to be.
[/list]
So is the game bad? In its current version - yes, it simply isn’t ready - not even for early access. With some mechanics on the lowest functional level and without interaction between systems the game simply has nothing to offer. Survival strategy? Frostpunk. Post-apoc city builder? Endzone. Factory builder? Factorio. Playing 3 of those will give you better experience in their respective field. The game does have good bits (like alternative craft recipes), but they aren’t enough, and considering how slow the development goes - there will be a lot more city builder games before that game is finished, potentially making it obsolete on release date.

[b]New Cycle[/b] is the typical game with an interesting core concept but poorly executed. It presents itself as a mix between a survival game and a city builder (the factory planning part is negligible, and I’ll explain why later), like the excellent Frostpunk. However, unlike Frostpunk, it fails in both genres, the game puts you in charge of a small group of survivors after a nuclear apocalypse. The world is a nearly barren wasteland and civilization must be rebuilt from scratch or at least that’s how it starts. I won’t spoil anything, but the objective shifts after a few hours, borrowing several mechanics from Frostpunk and throwing them into this big melting pot we call New Cycle.

The events in game, which are clearly trying to imitate Frostpunk’s, have no real catastrophic impact, they apply some negative modifiers, but nothing too dangerous, so most of them can be easily ignored by simply clicking the first choice often without even reading the description.

The game loop is simple and typical of factory builders: most resources are immediately available or at least their locations are making map planning very straightforward, but this is where the factory building elements end. The game allows for building conveyor belts and train lines, but these are not necessary even in the late game, since they’re optional, there’s no real need to carefully plan your industrial layout to boost efficiency, this leaves a lot of freedom, which personally I didn’t enjoy.

Graphically, the game is nice to look at, but many buildings especially in the early stages are made up of tents and tarps, and are hard to tell apart, there is also a system that lets you assign icons to buildings for visibility on the minimap, but annoyingly, every time you select a building to assign an icon, the menu closes itself making the process tedious.

Labor management is also tedious population often dies off and isn’t replaced, but there’s no way to highlight which buildings don’t have 100% staffing, so unless you want to risk (as I did, multiple times) discovering that some production chain has halted due to unfilled jobs, you’ll have to check buildings one by one. Additionally the surplus/deficit UI is unclear and it’s very difficult to figure out what consumes a specific resource and how big the deficit is.

[h2]Let me share two more “highlights”[/h2]:

[b]Lightning[/b]: The game has weather events like sandstorms, hurricanes, and droughts, these just apply production or morale penalties. But lightning? Lightning strikes out of nowhere - even on a clear day - and instantly destroys any building, from early-game tents to late-game mines. The only protection is the lightning rod, but it’s only unlocked deep into the midgame, making it almost pointless. It’s obvious lightning was added as a material sink, but it usually ends up one-shotting your freshly built structures.

[b]Water[/b]: A real masterpiece. Water is essential for everything and is consumed in massive amounts, however water amount on the map is finite (renew itself each year). I assumed that advancing technology would unlock deeper wells with larger reserves… nope. Better pumps just drain the existing water sources faster, so instead of upgrading pumps, it’s better to spam the basic ones everywhere (since they don’t require workers, roads, or electricity to function).

You’ve probably gotten a sense of the game’s issues by now. Personally, I like it, but I don’t think it’s a good purchase at the moment especially considering its high price. On top of that, after a year of development, only two out of four maps are available, and updates are slow and largely uninteresting from a gameplay standpoint.

Another uninteresting post-apocolyptic city builder that doesn't provide entertainment or responsive joy.

Placing buildings is a chore - having to switch between grid build and free build to rotate. Building roads is not fun at all. Have to find roads in the logistics tab, click on the road, then select where to begin and end... but this isn't simple because roads must be built in at least 3 square at a time, and linking buildings to roads provides no visual or audio confirmation that it worked and actually linked the roads.

The music is dreary and on a short loop. Music does not change to suit the events happening, pop ups or actions or seasons or anything.

When workers idle such as run out of resource to collect or there is storage is full, there is no visual or audio cue, or pop up. I have to manually check. Same for scouts - no sound or cute the scouts are idle. No cue someone died or joined workforce - If you don't manually monitor the chat log on left side, its all missed.

The game visuals are nothing special. Maybe these will improve as this "Early Access" game develops. Maybe other things will improve with quality of life and enjoyment of playing... but right now it is not fun to play.

I much more enjoyed FrostPunk, and even the old Caeser 3 city builder games. Glad I got this game on sale, would want a refund if paid full price.

One positive is the artwork on the static drawings of the survivors - these are well done, and some of the story dilemmas are thoughtful, but all really lack impact, context or emotional engagement.

New Cycle (Early Access) - Preliminary Analysis and Constructive Feedback

New Cycle presents an intriguing proposition within the city-building and survival genre, placing the player in a post-apocalyptic setting with a dieselpunk aesthetic. Currently in Early Access on Steam, the game shows potential, but certain aspects of its current implementation warrant discussion and, potentially, refinement by the developers.

The premise of rebuilding society after solar cataclysms is captivating, and visually the game successfully creates an atmosphere consistent with its arid and challenging theme. The basic systems of construction and management of the population's needs are present and form a functional foundation for the gameplay.

However, two points stood out during my experience and, in my opinion, significantly impact the game's flow and player satisfaction:

Map Density and Resource Distribution: The size of the map and the dispersion of natural resources seem excessive in the current state. While scarcity and the need to explore are central elements of a post-apocalyptic survival game, the large distance between primary resource nodes and the initial settlement can make the early phases of the game slow and the central area of the map appears underutilized for long periods. This dispersion, without efficient long-distance transport mechanisms or more robust early-game exploration incentives, can create a feeling of "emptiness" in the world and focus the challenge more on resource collection logistics than on other aspects of colony management. A rebalancing of resource density, especially in the starting areas, or the introduction of mechanics that facilitate or incentivize exploration in a more dynamic way could mitigate this point.

Pace of Technological Progression and Learning Curve: The speed at which new technologies are unlocked in the research tree is remarkably fast. While access to new buildings and processes is exciting, the current pace does not allow the player sufficient time to implement, optimize, and fully understand the ramifications of newly acquired technologies before the next batch of unlocks is available. This not only diminishes the sense of achievement associated with each technological leap but can also lead to information overload and, consequently, confusion. The rapid transition between different technological "eras" prevents the mastery of specific mechanics for each phase, hindering the strategic depth that could be explored if the pace were more gradual. Adjusting the speed of technology unlocks to allow for a smoother learning curve, where the player has time to experiment with and consolidate the use of new tools before advancing, would be beneficial.

Concluding Remarks:

New Cycle has a promising foundation and an engaging theme. The points mentioned above seem to be, for the most part, issues of balance and pacing inherent in an Early Access title. I believe that addressing map density/resource distribution and, crucially, the pace of technological progression and how new mechanics are introduced, could significantly elevate the gameplay experience, making it more cohesive, challenging, and rewarding in the long run.

I recommend New Cycle to players who enjoy the city builder/survival genre and are willing to participate in the Early Access process by providing feedback. The game has the potential to become an excellent title in its category with proper polish.

I thank the developers for their work so far and eagerly await future updates.


New Cycle (Early Access) - Análise Preliminar e Feedback Construtivo

New Cycle apresenta uma proposta intrigante dentro do gênero de construção de cidades e sobrevivência, situando o jogador em um cenário pós-apocalíptico com uma estética dieselpunk. Atualmente em Acesso Antecipado na Steam, o jogo demonstra potencial, mas alguns aspectos da sua implementação atual merecem discussão e, potencialmente, refinamento por parte dos desenvolvedores.

A premissa de reconstruir a sociedade após cataclismos solares é cativante, e visualmente o jogo consegue criar uma atmosfera condizente com seu tema árido e desafiador. Os sistemas básicos de construção e gestão de necessidades da população estão presentes e formam uma base funcional para a jogabilidade.

Entretanto, dois pontos se destacaram durante a experiência e, em minha opinião, impactam significativamente o fluxo do jogo e a satisfação do jogador:

Densidade do Mapa e Distribuição de Recursos: O tamanho do mapa e a dispersão dos recursos naturais parecem excessivos no estado atual. Embora a escassez e a necessidade de explorar sejam elementos centrais de um jogo de sobrevivência pós-apocalíptico, a grande distância entre os nós de recursos primários e o assentamento inicial pode tornar as fases iniciais do jogo morosas e a área central do mapa parece subutilizada por longos períodos. Essa dispersão, sem mecanismos de transporte de longa distância eficientes ou incentivos de exploração mais robustos no early game, pode gerar uma sensação de "vazio" no mundo e focar o desafio mais na logística de coleta do que em outros aspectos da gestão da colônia. Um rebalanceamento na densidade de recursos, especialmente nas áreas iniciais, ou a introdução de mecânicas que facilitem ou incentivem a exploração de forma mais dinâmica poderiam mitigar este ponto.

Ritmo da Progressão Tecnológica e Curva de Aprendizado: A velocidade com que novas tecnologias são desbloqueadas na árvore de pesquisa é notavelmente rápida. Embora o acesso a novas construções e processos seja excitante, a cadência atual não permite ao jogador tempo suficiente para implementar, otimizar e compreender plenamente as ramificações das tecnologias recém-adquiridas antes que a próxima leva de desbloqueios esteja disponível. Isso não apenas diminui a sensação de conquista associada a cada avanço tecnológico, mas também pode levar a uma sobrecarga de informações e, consequentemente, à confusão. A transição rápida entre diferentes "eras" tecnológicas impede o domínio de mecânicas específicas de cada fase, prejudicando a profundidade estratégica que poderia ser explorada se o ritmo fosse mais gradual. Ajustar a velocidade do desbloqueio de tecnologias para permitir uma curva de aprendizado mais suave, onde o jogador tenha tempo para experimentar e consolidar o uso de novas ferramentas antes de avançar, seria benéfico.

Considerações Finais:

New Cycle possui uma fundação promissora e uma temática envolvente. Os pontos mencionados acima parecem ser, em grande parte, questões de balanceamento e pacing inerentes a um título em Acesso Antecipado. Acredito que abordar a densidade do mapa/distribuição de recursos e, crucialmente, o ritmo da progressão tecnológica e a forma como novas mecânicas são introduzidas, poderia elevar significativamente a experiência de jogo, tornando-a mais coesa, desafiadora e gratificante a longo prazo.

Recomendo New Cycle para jogadores que apreciam o gênero de city builder/sobrevivência e estão dispostos a participar do processo de Acesso Anteciado, fornecendo feedback. O jogo tem potencial para se tornar um excelente título em sua categoria com o devido polimento.

Agradeço aos desenvolvedores por seu trabalho até o momento e aguardo ansiosamente as futuras atualizações.

[b]KAMGUSTA's MINI REVIEW[/b]

The card rogue-lite everyone talks about. I understand why it's so popular, as almost everybody knows how to play cards and make a "double", a "three of a kind" or a "flush". Runs are also quite short and the high randomness makes all of them quite different. As a roguelike and/or deck-building game, it has big flaws: you aren't in full control of your deck (uncertainty and randomness are unavoidable) and the stacking of bonuses ([b]+[/b]chip, [b]+[/b]multi, [b]x[/b]multi) should have been clearer and better balanced. You can get to the point where a single card (a "high") scores more than a "royal flush", erasing all the fun of a card game. Game also lacks meta-progression, you just unlock more bonuses to be find on your runs. Runs are too short to build your deck or create long-term strategies - you are forced to just hope for good cards and push your luck. Best strategies focus only on gaining a lot of money to be able to reroll and trying to get (pray the RNG God) that couple uber bonuses.
For all those reasons, it's not the masterpiece some people talks about and I only recommend it for casual players (in that case, add +2 to the score). It is what it is: a casual, short-lenght, mobile game.

When I started playing Balatro I was presented with the choice of playing a poker-like hand or exchanging cards. Trying to figure out how to balance these could be a fun learning curve. Looking at a screen full of numbers I tried mousing over them to see if there was a tool tip explaining when they meant or maybe some in-game help. No such luck. Playing hands blindly for a while I eventually "won"? I was presented with a screen with an option to "cash out". Actually there was no other option. So cashing out is a good thing? Not sure. Next I'm presented with a joker that changes the rules of the game in many different ways, and a different joker-like card that is not a joker that also changes the rules of the game in many ways, and a store where I can buy cards for cash including, for my sins, a loot box. Then I'm presented with three different game modes with no explanation of why I would want to play one over the other. That is a lot of complexity to dump on the player all at once.

Lacking any help or more tutorials I wade into the game without understanding. I play some hands. Some numbers go up. Others go down. I'm not really sure what I should pay attention to. After a while it dawns on me. I have no idea what the goal is. Trying to figure out the byzantine rules and how they combine is slightly fun, but I have no sense of progress and no sense of purpose. The only thing I can tell for sure is when I win a round  I assume eventually I'll reach some sort of major win state, but frankly I lack the patience for it.

This might be a good game, but it needs more comprehensive tutorials and/or in-game help system to help players up the learning curve.

it's a very hard title to really put a thumb on...

At the very core of the game play, this is nearly perfect and too naked at the same time that Balatro felt so brutally straightforward. 

It is almost hypocritical to say that you actually miss some extra fluff eg: more animation/mini-games because the game was designed so that you would just get right into it without having to deal with anything else but the bulk of the gameplay which is the strategy, yet, because you literally just grind it out the minute you boot the game up made it felt so much like your 9-5 job that I just can't continue play for too long each session.

Much like my issues with Cloverpit and other luck based games it stops being fun when the game stops allowing you to win. In Cloverpit I gave up after 65 losses in a row. Here it took less because the frustration points are more egregious. Delay between selecting things and the game actually allowing you to play have given me more than enough time to say: I don't recommend this game. I will actively tell people to avoid this game. I actually hope that people making games like this lose their jobs.

It's fun on the first set of difficulties, but eventually it just becomes a tedious exercise of what feels like the game developers actively taunting you with how close you get to the next band before rug-pulling.

Eventually EVERYTHING hinges on you being just lucky enough with just the right set of jokers at just the right stages and it just stops being fun. Especially when what counts for the conditions of a card, i.e. what is considered an enhanced card, seems horribly arbitrary.

Furthermore - the conditions that cause deterioration are badly designed - losing points on Ramen, a multiplying joker that loses .01 of its multiplyer per card discarded, when the Boss Blind is Hook, a joker that discards 2 per hand played - this is ridiculous! The Arm, which takes away a level of a hand played - an utterly unfair Boss Blind that just makes your efforts feel wasted. 

The Wall and later Violet Vessel, especially on higher difficulties, are just cruel. Especially as the cards which have a 1 in however much chance of popping clearly don't work properly and need to be fixed. Even when you have the joker which doubles their chances of activating they don't work unless the base chance is a 1 in 2.

I want to like this game, but there are so many aspects that just make me go to the devs "what do you expect me to do when I'm not being given anything to work with?"

What can I say? I want to like it. I really do. There are parts of it I do actually enjoy. But overall, this is very much not the game for me.

Act 2 had me slightly annoyed.

The camera is a fucking nightmare, the combat feels like a slog through molasses, the RNG definetly favors the enemies. The fact I had to do almost two hours of prep work and research to make it through one large combat encounter, on Explorer mode, broke me.

I played D&D 5e for awhile before I started BG3, and while I do enjoy the world building and the roleplaying aspects for the most part, the combat is honestly the worst part of this game. Theres literally no justifiable reason my entire beefed up squad with meta gear and stats should struggle with a group of lizard people, on the games easiest difficulty.

The only workaround Ive found that takes the combat from nearly an hour per conflict (obviously dependant on size of enemy group) is to cheese the shit out of items and set up a trap guantlet before starting the combat. Which, if I was playing on hard or above, I could respect. But I wasnt.

Overall, BG3 had great potential for being one of the better games Ive played, but quality of life and combat/balancing issues abound doesnt make me want to play this game ever again. Finishing it felt like a chore and frankly thats just not fun.

As a lover of turn-based strategy and tabletop D&D I really don't see the appeal of this game. What is hyped and praised as a thrilling action-packed campaign in reality is a boring, horrible-paced slog with zero replayability and variation. After act one the quality drops off a cliff and just feels bloated.

It's all window-dressing, every choice eventually leads to the same outcome. No, really. Try and avoid Shadowheart at the start of the game, see how often they thrust her into your path before the game just gives up and drops her magical macguffin into your bag with zero explanation. Want to be evil? You'll still fight the same enemies and go to the same places just with less help. 

The dice rolls outside of combat only feel like they exist to decide if you'll be inconvenienced or not, and these become worse on subsequent playthroughs when you know what you'll lose should you fail. 

This game is a perfect example of why I don't listen to public opinion on what a good game is, as they'd rather insist that you SHOULD like it when in fact a lot of the time you might only like it because it's popular.

negatives now, this game has a terrible early game (theres a reason people like starting at level 3-5 in tabletop) that feels directionless and causes the pacing to have significant issues that persist through the entire game. i tried my absolute hardest to stay invested in this games narrative but its just genuinely not very good.
