4/10
I really liked the game at the beginning, but the further I progressed through the quests and locations, the worse my overall feeling became.
What I liked: I enjoyed the gameplay; I was really looking forward to the tactical combat, and it’s done well. There are issues with how certain skills work and how items and weapons interact, but it’s not critical and doesn’t ruin the experience. The spells with their variety of effects are well implemented, but the main thing is that the developers gave the option to complete a world full of magic without using magic at all. That’s real flexibility. That’s very good.

And now what annoys me: the complete lack of the feeling that I’m in the Forgotten Realms. The most important thing that distinguished the first two games in the series was that special feeling — the atmosphere of a familiar and beloved fantasy world of the Forgotten Realms. What do we have here? No atmosphere. Just some references and fantasy-world attributes like castles and dragons that don’t fit together at all. The ridiculous bosses from the second chapter — what even are they? Why are they here? You came up with them and shoved them into the game because… what? They feel more suited to some random Asian game where weapons are twice the size of a person.

The biggest disappointment is the characters. All the characters are awful, absolutely all of them. It feels like they took a modern person, dressed them up, put makeup on them, and dropped them into a fantasy world. And because of that, all the characters feel out of place, like mannequins or functions. “Let’s let the player be a vampire! How original! But we’ll also let them walk around in broad daylight — because magic.” Rubbish! But even worse is that they have zero motivation. And not just zero — their motivations are completely uninteresting. There’s nothing to empathize with; all they provoke is irritation.

The only character who felt coherent and adequate was Sarevok, but he was taken from the first game and somehow managed not to be mangled by the writers.
It would have been good if i didn't crash incessantly.

I had high expectations based on the universally positive reviews both online and from friends and family. I wanted to like it and share this experience with friends who are deeply into it, and I just can't. 

Game play is straight out of the 1990s and hasn't advanced once bit since BG1. They even added a very intrusive dice roll animation just to make sure any immersion in the game is impossible. This isn't a computer game, it's a tabletop game simulator. Dice rolls and turn based combat are limitations of table top games, not features. Simulating them is bad game design. 

The writing is just awful, no taste at all. Dialogs are menu choices with only stupid cliche options. Because the protagonist's lines are not voice acted, dialogs never feel like conversations, but more like overhearing someone talking on the phone. Party members are one-dimensional and incredibly annoying. It's like a D&D campaign written by a 12 year old. Turn based combat is incredibly tedious. This was fine 25 years ago, but it's just not acceptable in the 21st century. It's completely impossible to care about the plot, if there is one, because all the characters are so fundamentally unrealistic and un-likeable that it's just impossible to care about them. I want them to suffer and die. I wonder if this game was written to appeal to nostalgic memories of playing table top games in high school. I don't have such nostalgia so it falls completely flat. 

The graphics look plastic and cartoonish and the artwork is just standard fantasy cliches. The music is incredibly twee, repetitive and annoying. It just looks cheap, cartoonish and lacking any kind of taste, almost like it's AI generated. 

Unfortunately this is the worst game I've ever played by a very large margin. I really wanted to like this. I was expecting something like Oblivion or Skyrim - other fantasy based RPGs, that offered vastly better game play, art work, writing and even graphics almost 2 decades ago. 

The disconnect between my expectations and reality was so vast that I had to double check if I hadn't downloaded a parody game by mistake.

I'm only 2.5 hours in but this is not matching the hype. I liked Original Sin. This seems, strangely worse than that game. The dice rolling was fun at first, but that thrill wares off quickly. I really don't know what the story is beyond just trying to get a bug out of my head and the heads of others. The combat with the spell slots, I assume is a DnD thing, is a bad mechanic. The graphics look like Dragon Age Inquisition but zoomed out and the camera is only one step up form a poor 2000s platformer. Why  is this game so popular?

Edit: So I gave it another 5 hours but the story and the characters are just not hooking me. For a game that I feel relies on its story, pretty heavily, I can't say its a good fit, at least not for me. The combat, Original Sin had its share of problems, with the DnD stuff and all the environmental shit you don't know until it happens, its a save scumming marathon.

Age of Empires II is one of the best strategy games I have ever played. The game lets you build your own medieval kingdom, manage resources, and lead armies into battle. You can play in many different ways: relax and focus on building, enjoy story campaigns that teach real history, or play fast and competitive matches against other players or the AI.

The game has many unique civilizations, each with its own units and bonuses. The balance is very good, so every strategy can work if you plan well. It always feels exciting to grow your economy, train your army, and fight for victory.

Even after many years, the game is still active and always improving. I keep coming back to it because every match feels different. If you like strategy and thinking ahead, I can strongly recommend this game.

A true classic that still shines today.

One of those rare games that never gets old. Age of Empires II is truly timeless, and it feels like we’ll keep coming back to it for many years. The Definitive Edition only makes it smoother, prettier, and even more addictive.

This game is hands down one of the best RTSs in existence. It's hard to really express how well throughout and built this game is. This game being 26 years old at the time of this review and still being extremely playable is a huge accomplishment. In some ways this game is even better than Age of Empires 4 which I have played more(via steam anyway). The campaign section of this game is one of the best of any RTS ever. The historical accuracy and the breath of historical eras covered is phenomenal. The fact that this game still gets DLCs today is incredible. This will be one of the very few games I will continue to play throughout my life. You don't have to be perfect or super skilled to enjoy this game (you may want to avoid multiplayer until you've done some hard campaign missions..). There are many ways to have fun with AOE2 and once you're hooked you'll be back again and again. I 100% recommend this game its in the top 5 of my favorite games ever.

What is there to review? Age of Empires 2 is among the reasons the RTS genre exists. It is a hallmark of video game history, and this is truly the definitive edition of it.

It's immaculately balanced, it looks gorgeous and it just feels nice to play. There's content for people who play it casually, as well as professionally, and I doubt that its popularity will fade in the next 100 years.
It takes you down the history lane

One of the greatest, if not the greatest RTS game of all time. After 25 years this game still consistently has active player counts between 10k-20k, thanks to the incredible work done by the devs on this definitive edition and the timeless gameplay (build a base and an army and destroy the enemy's base), which is intuitive yet deeply rich and replayable. Of course, there are countless RTS games that have the same gameplay loop but none execute them quite as well as AoE 2.

The community is also great and pro tournaments are very fun to watch. This game deserves more players and more money.

Gaming should be a relaxing experience. Not being able to run the game is, of course, not entertaining.

[b]The problem[/b]
Once every few months, a major update comes out, adding new game contents. Sadly, each update has a chance to prevent the game from running on random computers.

[b]New libraries required[/b]
The issue lies in new requirements in regard to dll libraries. Unfortunately the developer studio doesn't care to list these changes in the changelog, so users can only guess which dll files are required to run the game.

At first, the game started to require the library [i]xinput1_4.dll[/i], and this is [b]outrageous[/b] because one can simply rename the [i]xinput1_3.dll[/i] into the new one and the game works...
So what's been really added to the game apart from a hidden requirement? What does the [i]xinput1_4.dll[/i] add over the [i]xinput1_3.dll[/i] if the game works by simply renaming the older version of the library into the new one?
Nothing.

Then they started to require [i]api-ms-win-core-winrt-error-l1-1-0.dll[/i] and [i]api-ms-win-core-winrt-error-l1-1-1.dll[/i], and I'm going to skip the part about how I learned about this... Regardless, was it so hard to put it in the changelog?

[b]The current situation[/b]
Last update broke the game, again, and some people are already complaining.
This situation makes Age Of Empires II Definitive Edition too unstable for being considered entertaining, because now users would be supposed to learn by themselves which new dll are required to run the game, all of this because developers didn't spend two seconds to write down these changes in the changelog.

Finally, the game hasn't changed much, apart from new civilizations, since the beginning. So, what's the point of adding new core dll requirements? Why do Age Of Empires I & III Definitive Edition continue to work flawlessy?

Just buy an RTS that's more stable and whose developers don't plague their costumers with new dll requirements every now.
I have 30min to spend in the evening. Yet I am sitting here waiting for update. What a total garbage modern gaming has become....

What kills this game is how utterly broken the AI is in skirmish, not because it's complex, but because it follows a micro perfect build order that follows only the highest of skilled players. The ai is not fun to fight, always beating you to every age and instantly producing units based on counter the split second it sees your units. This isn't good AI, it's near inhuman cheating. Is this how we are with games ai now? Lazy and just train it off competitive multiplayer? The AI knows nothing but to rush castle/imperial and just spam out units that they counter you with. They aren't even coded to build walls, completely incapable of doing anything surprising.

You can say skill issue all you want, but if you have to follow a competitive multiplayer build order just to beat the basic standard AI then it was never good to begin with.

The devs claim the AI doesn't cheat on the DE but I'm somewhat convinced they broke it and gave the AI cheats for the sake of "difficulty." At the minimum it does have fog of war cheats...

The only people left in this game are the ones who take it so unbelievably seriously that it squashes any level of fun left.  This is no longer a game.  If you're not here for PURE competition and willing to researching timings for the literal dozens of civilizations, each with numerous of their own build orders unique to the civilization, this is not for you.  It will take any new players NUMEROUS YEARS to become even remotely intermediate.

Age of Empires 2 is great if you enjoy competitive micro-optimization and memorizing timings like a robot… but if you want something with substance, where “thinking like a general” actually matters and has some historical consistency, it’s a disappointment.

Also, “Definitive Editions” should actually be definitive — not a base for endless DLCs designed to squeeze as much money as possible with minimal effort.

As someone without nostalgia goggles, I deeply regret this purchase.

New pathfinding problems that didn't exist in the original, poor squad mechanics, lack of cinematics that existed in the original, removed/modified difficulties and maps, and an AI with higher APM than the best Starcraft players with precision and screenreading tactics. 

This version was not meant to help players new to the series get into it, it was made to skip over the engine they couldn't build on with a new one presented in a graphically impressive way while adding loads of artifical time-based gotchas to every map that rely on map memory rather than any kind of information processing in the moment, to disguise how cheaply built it actually is and the illusion of replayability

It's a slap in the face to RTS players and it promotes negative RTS multiplayer trends shifting towards high blood pressure APM and individual unit tactics that the ritalin addicted masses can't get enough of, but ultimately will not help you to improve anything other than remembering a build order and cutting years off of your life trying to keep up with cracked out AI or stimulant abusers in multiplayer. 

Still waiting for an RTS that returns the genre to quality instead of what sells an illusion of it with enough decoration to be convincing to most.

Isaac and his mother lived alone in a small house on a hill. Isaac kept to himself - drawing pictures and playing with his toys as his mom watched Christian broadcasts on the television. Life was simple and they were both happy. That was, until the day Isaac's mom heard a voice from above. "Your son has become corrupted by sin. He needs to be saved." "I will do my best to save him, my Lord," Isaac's mother replied, rushing into Isaac's room, removing all that was evil from his life. Again, the voice called to her. "Isaac's soul is still corrupt. He needs to be cut off from all that is evil in this world and confess his sins." "I will follow your instructions, Lord. I have faith in Thee," Isaac's mother replied, as she locked Isaac in his room away from the evils of the world. One last time, Isaac's mom heard the voice of God calling to her. "You've done as I've asked, but I still question your devotion to Me. To prove your faith, I will ask one more thing of you." "Yes, Lord. Anything," Isaac's mother begged. "To prove your love and devotion, I require a sacrifice. Your son, Isaac, will be this sacrifice. Go into his room and end his life, as an offering to Me to prove you love Me above all else." "Yes, Lord," she replied, grabbing a butcher's knife from the kitchen. Isaac, watching through a crack in his door, trembled in fear. Scrambling around his room to find a hiding place, he noticed a trapdoor to the basement, hidden under his rug. Without hesitation, he flung open the hatch, just as his mother burst through his door, and threw himself down into the unknown depths below.

I was going to wait until I 100%ed this game to review, as I often do, but I just cannot. This game has been one of my favorites for so long. It is what introduced me to one of my favorite genres of games, all that stuff. That is when I was bad at complex thought. This game is not good. This game seems to be almost entirely luck based, and unlike so many other games in the genre, there is no way to mitigate that fact. There is no way to increase the quantity or quality of items and quite literally nothing is reliable in this game. I can excuse that, to an extent, but what I cannot excuse is the genuine fucking torture that is the tainted characters. The tainted characters are fun a lot of the time, yes. They are also genuinely awful to deal with. Tainted lost is one of the worst gaming experiences I have ever had the displeasure of dealing with. I love risk vs reward characters, and this is a character that expands upon that from one of my favorite characters, base lost. Unlike base lost, however, this one is bullshit. You get one hit per run a lot of the time. Which yes, is the ultimate skill check, but also, in a game that is so built on the leniency of getting hit, considering the bullshit spawning mechanics, tainted lost is so dreadful to play with. There should not be a skill check character in a game that so heavily relies on luck for anything to get done. And on the topic of luck, one of the ONLY ways in which you can mitigate it is by minmaxing every single floor. Which is fine, I enjoy minmaxing because of something that is wrong with me. But of course, there are speedrun achievements, So that is just more luck. And that is compounded when you are playing the other most dreadful character, tainted cain. I like tainted cain in concept. He is just so unfun to play with. Any run with him will take about 3 times as long as a different characters, and you still need speedrun achievements while playing him, which either entails getting the singular crafting recipe that allows you to skip said time requirement, or just not have basically any items. Genuinely fucking dreadful. There are numerous other things I could mention, like a couple of the challenges, which McMillen has gone on record stating that one of them is straight up not fun. but one thing is the fucking price oh my god. If you want the "full" experience, you need to pay for so much dlc. The base game is fine, more enjoyable even, but attempting to move from console to pc or something like that costs so much money. Oh my god and the curses. The fucking curse. On hard mode, which is the main mode you will be using if you want to beat the game, you have a 1 in 3 chance to have a curse on each floor, and they are frankly just not fun. Curses affect information and movement, and only one is even remotely entertaining, the other are just a nuisance, especially curse of the blind. It isn't fun to have less information, all it does is take up more of your time in this timesink of a game. Finally, before i write another essay length review, I just do not like how many achievements there are. I love achievements, but there is an achievement for every single unlock. It feels cheap. I understand the reasoning, but having a game with 644 achievements skews my stats in a way that is simply not that fun. So even outside of the game it causes issues. But for the good, the atmosphere and music is great, as well as the fact that when you do get a good run, it is genuinely very fun (provided you don't get tapped by a random little guy as tainted lost and lose 3 hours of progress without any fault of your own). This is not a very unbiased review. Im just mad. I sure the game is slightly better than I have portrayed it, but none of my critiques have been even close to nitpicks (other than the amount of achievements). Overall, it is a fine game, fun even. Is it a good enough game to actually play? No.

I played the game long enough that I 100%ed it for all the achievements, which isn't something I do often so it must be doing something right! It's certainly addictive, with great style and gameplay. I like the strategic side of it and there's decent enemy variety (although I'd like more). 

The game hides far too much information. If my stats are changing throughout a round, why can't I see them as they change? My damage increases in line with the dragon but I have no idea how much damage the dragon does and how much it increases my damage. Why can't I look at the synergies screen or my current abilities while choosing new abilities? It makes it very frustrating to optimise my build and understand which abilities are good or bad.

There is good fun gameplay variety with the number of weapons, characters and abilities. I was surprised how much I enjoyed the different weapons and how much they could change your strategy. I do think there is a huge balance issue. Some guns and abilities are incredibly powerful, must picks on every run while others are really weak. The three different builds are essentially guns, summons or elements, but elements is pretty bad on its own and fire is especially weak. You're better off going guns or summons and supplementing with frost (or some lightning). Going full damage is far more sensible than going defensive, especially in higher difficulties where enemies hit harder.

A good way to pass the time, and ideal for short play sessions. I'd rank it as better than Vampire Survivors but it falls far short of the lofty heights of Brotato.

This game is really dope. After a couple of play throughs, where you get to grips with the mechanics, the small tricks you can do (like baiting the large exploding enemies into bombing everyone by running close then backing up as a method of crowd control), the game isn't too tough to master. But I appreciate the fact that it puts the power fantasy first and makes it more accessible and less reliant on rng.

It also helps that the game encourages experimenting with builds by having 15 unlockable difficulty levels and a huge cast of unlockable characters and weapons that become absolutely busted when you take advantage of their perks through the upgrades you choose. Each weapon is distinct; the SMG rocks for elemental builds, while the shotgun is great for crowd control and skills based around reloading. Meanwhile the Batgun benefits from being buffed by both regular and summon attack buffs, so you can create an army of summons that decimate everything. There are several key skills to buff, like base attack, health, movement speed, as well as bonuses to your guns like elemental damage and other effects. So even if you can't get a skill you want to mainline, there's still pretty much always going to be something you can pick that will help you in the long run.

And all the fun is from breaking the game. There are infinite ammo builds, summon builds, multiple elemental combination builds (like one where, when lightning strikes a flaming enemy, they explode), and more based around the individual skills of the characters. Played properly, your screen will be a crazy mess by the end and you will have transcended mortality into a crazy kind of Godhood. It's a total blast to mess around with.

For $7.50AUD this is a really comfy game. I managed to get a solid 20ish hours of enjoyment out of it, and as of writing this review have 100%'d the achievements.

What I liked:
- Immaculate vibes.
- I loved the sprite work of the characters, enemies, and summons.
- Once you've gotten the hang of the game most runs feel unloseable, you'll find a way to build your character within the first five level-ups.
- A varied roster of 12 characters with their own unique upgrades following boss-kills.
- A standard winning run takes around 25 minutes including time spent paused choosing upgrades, making it a good wind-down game if you're time-poor like me.
- Meta-progression in the form of runes, which provide upgrades to your stats, and character and weapon unlocks.

What I disliked:
- The runs can feel very samey after a while, as you're heavily encouraged to lean into your characters 'class'.
- This is especially prevalent with the Summoner classes, which can honestly be played by standing still for 80% of the game with some minor dodging required when bosses appear.
- Some rune choices have what is obviously the best-in-slot, and there's nothing encouraging you from changing the runes between runs.
- Some characters are definitely stronger than others. As an example Dasher spends approximately half of your run in their invulnerable deer form which scales with summon damage, which is already the strongest build in the game in my opinion.

Overall I recommend this game. If you're a fan of Vampire Survivors or Brotato this will slot neatly into your library, and at its current price you'll find that it has great value for money.

It's a decently fun little time killer of a game, 5 dollar price tag feels a bit iffy to me personally though, plus the dev has been radio silent on this game for almost a year at this point, with the last bit of information being about their new game they're working on. I've seen this story before: [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/671860/BattleBit_Remastered]BattleBit[/url], [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/767810/Tiny_Rails/]Tiny
 Rails[/url], and, ironically, [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2488510/FatalZone]FatalZone[/url] [i](this one is survivors clone as well, got randomly released as 1.0 and threw away all the good will with crappy (lack of) updates)[/i] a small game goes viral, catches lightning in a bottle, then moves on (usually to a more “profitable” mobile version). Can’t blame devs for chasing success, but you can still feel disappointed when the original gets left behind.

[b]20 Minutes Till Dawn[/b] is one of those cases. It’s stylish, it’s fun, the pixel-art gun-girls blasting Lovecraftian horrors still hit that dopamine spot — but it’s also unfinished, buggy, and clearly abandoned. You can almost see the potential it once had (there is literal roadmap or dev plans in the main menu xd).

If you want a polished [b]Bullet Heaven[/b](?), grab the OG [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1794680/Vampire_Survivors]Vampire
 Survivors[/url].
If you’ve beaten that, try [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2218750/Halls_of_Torment]Halls
 of Torment[/url].
And if you’re after something niche and full of promise, like 20MTD once was, check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2283940/Ancient_Guardians_The_Dragon]Ancient
 Guardians: The Dragon[/url].

It's fun but lacks the "wow" factor to keep me playing. It also has a large handful of problems in my opinion. Maybe it's just not suited to my tastes for some things, but objectively I think there are other problems that can't be excused by preference.

Lots of stuff feels unfinished, including missing or convoluted UI elements. I found it very tricky to understand the upgrade paths, the language for abilities, and so on. Some things are unintuitive or incomplete in how they're written, and there are simple typos that show a lack of attention to detail.

There's little enemy variety, character builds are not that versatile and the characters don't feel sufficiently different to warrant unlocking all of them. Honestly some of the playstyles for weapons can feel more impactful than some characters. I think it would have been beneficial to give each character an active ability to further set them apart and allow for a bit more skill expression.

And then, I have quite a few complaints about the balance of the Rune system for persistent upgrades, and the actual in-game perks. Quite a few feel minimally impactful or downright useless. When you're presented with 5 choices and 3 of them aren't helping you, now you're choosing between 2 and that really limits the exploratory factor and variety run to run. After a while I knew which perks I was hunting for, and assuming I didn't get hosed my RNG my builds ended up looking 90% identical.

All that said it's reasonably fun for a few hours and worth $5, but it has a lot of problems I just can't get over. Art style is cool if a bit dark and muddy. Gameplay loop is pretty standard but the manual aiming adds a bit more to keep you involved. There's a decent amount of stuff to unlock so you feel like you're meta progressing, even if some of the stuff is not the most noticeable. It's OK, but I'd recommend spending your time and money on other things unless something about this really captivates you.

One of the best precision platformers i have ever played! You are playing a character that is having a physical and emotional journey while climbing the Celeste mountain. It is trying to give you interesting and meaningful concepts while climbing (e.g anxiety, mental health, self-doubt, self acceptance, depression etc) and the character is trying to face/accept/embrace them. The music was sooo beautiful and its difficulty was solid if you want to finish it casually. HOWEVER, the game gives you  the opportunity to play optional stages where their difficulty skyrockets a little bit because it focuses more on precision AND consistency. One last thing..... a lot of stages will be challenging but none of them are speedrunning/frame perfect ones. In other words, no matter the deaths, keep trying and you will make it. This is what celeste is all about.

Was enjoying the game, until I realized the game tries to force feed gender ideology and politics into its story. Was interested in a story about the main character climbing the mountain with awesome pixel art and pixel effects but nope, the devs had to interject political divisive nonsense in their game.

What does divisive mean? "tending to cause disagreement or hostility between people." I think the majority will agree the game is a good game about climbing the mountain and overcoming personal struggles. But nope, the devs had to add themes in their games that alienates a lot of their player-base and adds division.  Why add themes in the game that causes "disagreement or hostility" between players? Video game are suppose to be fantasy worlds where players can escape the real world problems of life not dens where these divisive ideologies are idolized and shoveled into players faces. JUST STOP ALREADY. Also the devs did this AFTER the game was released, it was added in a very cheap way. Almost like they just wanted to be apart of the ban wagon/put a check mark on the checkbox. If they were truly sincere they would have had this originally apart of the game on release. Its a very CHEAP way to add this in and they are not doing that community any favors. 

Also having the game capped at 60 FPS on PC in 2025 is diabolical. refunded.

I simply cannot understand the consensus around Celeste. It’s hailed as a modern platforming masterpiece, a game that masterfully blends challenging mechanics with a deep emotional narrative. To me, it felt like a punishing, repetitive slog wrapped in the guise of therapy, all served up with visuals that were "retro" in the most tedious way possible.

Let's start with the gameplay: the controls are supposedly "tight," which is reviewer speak for "there are only two buttons." You jump and you dash. That’s it. For 20+ hours, you do these two things. The level design then simply becomes an exercise in chaining these two actions together in increasingly arbitrary and frustrating combinations. The game doesn't feel challenging in a fun, clever way; it feels cheap, like a series of instant-death puzzle boxes designed solely to inflate the death counter on the screen - a counter that the game tries to tell you is a badge of honor, rather than a monument to its poor difficulty scaling.

The core loop is relentless: die, respawn instantly, and repeat the same two-second sequence until your muscle memory snaps the joystick the right way. This isn't flow; it’s exhaustion.

And then there’s the story. This is where Celeste truly loses its way. The emotional narrative about protagonist Madeline dealing with anxiety and depression feels less like genuine introspection and more like a heavy-handed lecture constantly interrupting the action. Every time I finally started to get into a rhythm, the game would pause for another sequence of pixelated characters discussing their feelings with the subtlety of a sledgehammer. The whole "Badeline" concept is so on-the-nose it's embarrassing.

Finally, the aesthetics. The pixel art is functional, I suppose, but it adds nothing of visual distinction. It feels like a deliberate choice to save on development resources while hiding behind the shield of "nostalgia." When every element on the screen is an extreme close-up of a few chunky squares, it just highlights the visual monotony of climbing the same mountain, just with slightly different colored rocks and spikes.

If you enjoy paying full price to feel frustrated while being told to "be kind to yourself," then Celeste is for you. For everyone else, it’s an over-sentimentalized, repetitive platformer that should have stayed at the bottom of the pile.

Genuine dogshit. One of the worst games I've ever played.

Game is okay but not anything super special, it focuses too much on the precision part of precision platformer, which makes most of its challenges blur together in terms of feel despite there being a lot of variety in level design on paper. 

The progression of the game is also quite bizarre, where a large swathe of the level challenges are made purely optional to collect strawberries, a collectable that is there absolutely for bragging rights. I am all for intrinsic motivation in games, but what this ended up leading too is a lack of forward progression in levels. You either go for most collectables, in which case you will be stuck going to alternate rooms to do many of these mini challenges, dragging the pace to a halt, or just ignore them all, and get super short levels that don't feel as though they fully flesh out their respective level gimmicks. 

This isn't like New Super Mario Bros, where star coins are used to unlock content in the overworld and are placed mostly en route to your objective, which lead to them being useful to collect, without repercussing the pace of the game, yet not making the levels feel hollow if you decide to ignore them. Thus the inclusion of these collectables and their impact on the level design ended up taking a lot of the bite out of the progression in the game.

Aside from that the story is poorly integrated into the game with middling dialogue quality and I found the soundtrack to be the typical retro ost you hear in these kinds of games without much in it to separate it from what you hear elsewhere.

Also the game will sometimes heavily lag-spike on steam deck, and that sucks.

it's a good game overall, but i can't recommend it in good faith since only the main game feels like it rewards you in any way. 5/10.

Easily one of the best games of the last decade, if not the best overall.

Soundtrack is incredible, storytelling is incredible, art direction and world design are incredible, characters are lovable, enemies are interesting, gameplay is engaging.

It never felt too repetitive and there's plenty of tools at your disposal to keep the gameplay fresh, and each playable character has a very unique and charming playstyle that suits their personality and design.

If you haven't played this yet you're missing out. If you have played this, the bar for all games in the future has been set extremely high, considering a small AA studio created something that is essentially a masterpiece. 

There are a few areas where you could tell they wanted to do more but ran out of funding or time, but the game still feels complete regardless and I look forward to any future content (the upcoming "bonus" update) and any future games in the Clair Obscur universe.

I 100% this game and wouldn't hesitate to do it again.

"Omg so much hype and glaze about the game... Is it actually that good???"

Better.

Amazing turned based game with great story and music. Need more games like this from Sandfall. Plays a lot like paper mario ttyd with being able to add badges to characters and change up their playstyle. My GOTY for 2025.

Legititmately one of the best pieces of media I have ever consumed. 

Gameplay: 10/10- turn based with a parry/dodge mechanic along with a really cool picto/lumina system to create a really cool build. The movement can be clunky at times but there are minigames that actually buy into the clunkiness as well. You wont have any issues navigating the world, compared to other open world games, the movement can feel clunky at times but to me it absolutely felt just fine and never once took away from the combat. Once you get the timings down, parrying isnt too hard at all. The builds in the game are awesome and are sort of endless in a way. You'll enjoy it. Gameplay feels like FromSoftware and Final Fantasy had a love child that got the best aspects of those games, while being better than both in every aspect. 

Story: Absolute Cinema/10: I mean, you played the game, and if you havent, you just need to witness this masterpiece, I honestly cant come up with words to describe it. Just be in the moment and enjoy it, cry with it, and let your heart be shattered into a million pieces. 

Soundtrack/Audio: ABSOLUTE LUMINA/10 - The entire soundtrack is unbelieveable. I have added some of these songs into my spotify rotation and i have no idea what the lyrics mean but theyre incredible

Visuals/Graphics: 10/10: The game looks incredible. All of the scenery is top notch, even the prerendered stuff looked IMMACULATE. Then world in this game is so stunning.

Performance: 10/10: Since alot of the backgrounds are prerendered I have no issues with a 4060ti, i7-14700f and 32GB of RAM at 1440p on high. I never ran into any performance snags at all. I of course tweaked settings but never did i have crashes, stutters, or anything while playing the game. It ran buttery smooth(which is not always the case for AAA titles yet here we are)

Voice Acting: Better Than alot of hollywood movies/10: Ben Starr, Charlie Cox, Andy Serkis is already beyond stacked for a cast. Every single member of the cast put on the performance of a lifetime. Im pretty sure they had rent due because every character has their emotional moment to shine, and they shine bright!

I dont need to keep categorizing you get my point. If you think its over hyped, glazed too much, or anything, just witness this masterpiece and youll change your mind. This game is legitimately one of the best games to come out in recent memory and I hope that Sandfall continues to make games with similar styles and gameplay to E33, because I will buy every game even if i have to pay double.

Great game but giving negative review for lousy PC implementation:

I'm really enjoying this game, actually. Good acting, beautiful designs, interesting story, satisfying combat, and more. However, I'm giving it a thumbs down because of the lack of a map. I cannot believe this game, inspired by so many digital role-playing games, doesn't include any sort of map, which has existed in this genre forever. It even fits the theme and story. I'm pretty sure these expeditioners would take notes and make maps as they go through these labyrinths, no?

If the game were strictly linear, I wouldn’t have minded, but a good portion of it is about exploration, and you never know if you're going the way that will progress the story and trigger a cutscene, or if you're finding a side path with optional enemies and items, or if you're just circling around aimlessly. The exploration right now is honestly so excruciating, and it feels even worse because I genuinely want to find everything, but without a map I'm having so much difficulty. Sometimes I just prefer to move forward because I have no idea if I've missed anything or not.

Weird graphical issues everywhere (grainy/ant shadows, black artifacts in hair, inconsistent fog), black cutscenes with just music, clipping in every dialogue interaction, wooden dialogue line transitions, horrible audio mixing, combat and cutscene music is about twice as loud as everything else, some cutscenes seem to be 720p stretched to my resolution...
And all this in an hour of gameplay.

I don't really like it. It's decent but it's kind of boring. This game tries to be a JRPG but with souls like dodge, parry mechanics and it kind of falls flat.

Lore wise it looks interesting but in general story, not that much. It has a serious tone but with JRPG cringe dialogs which I don't like at least for this game. It starts interesting at first and tries to make you feel bad with characters which you don't know nothing about. You have to feel bad, yeah? I felt nothing in prologue whatsoever. Characters are OK, I guess. I like the some interactions between them apart from the cringe worthy dialogs. They have some chemistry between them but I don't really form a connection with characters.

GAMEPLAY
In short, I don't like it. I'm not a big fan of turn based combat but I have my fair share of them. I don't really like the idea of QTE rhythm type of dodge and parry mechanics. I think it's alright to have some of kind QTE for combat but in this, it's the main mechanic. I don't think it's working for a turn-based game. You only care for DPS, not about healing and defence because you can dodge and parry. So, you're making a build for DPS only.

Bit of a nitpick but some of the enemies have animation and audio sync problem. Sometimes audio plays too early which makes me press the dodge or parry button instinctively only to get me wrecked by it until I get used to it.

I don't really like the level design. I think it's a bit confusing with all the colours and stuff but world looks gorgeous. One of the prettiest worlds I have ever seen and has a NIER vibe which I like.

This game is OK but not for me. I got bored because of the easy gameplay and story. If you don't like rhythm type of games, souls like dodge/parry mechanics or If you are looking for a turn-based game with strategic gameplay it's a pass.

I've had it with this game after years of repetitive gameplay. I find myself playing the same campaign with a slightly different coat time and time again. Both wide and tall playthroughs I find myself ending the game within a generation or two of achieving the main goal of my campaign. The occasional decent dlc paradox drops usually adds only few hours of decent content before I feel I'm playing my average Cornwall or Bohemia playthrough with a new coat. It's been five years and paradox is still filling the void that is crusader kings 3 with overpriced dlc's. This game offers little to no late game content other than fighting the mongol empire or forming a hegemony. The release of various new governments has resulted in the five base game governments to be forgotten and never expanded upon. Maybe Paradox will one day finish this game, but it will likely take several years of extra dlc before they finally retire this game and release another empty Crusader Kings entry. I personally don't see myself playing this game again even when that day comes, because it is has already been way too long since this game's release for it not to be finished.

This was my first CK and I found it honestly terrible: the war mechanics are way too simple as well as the economy. The activities are boring, unrealistic and pointless. The whole relationship with vassals is very weird, and I am pretty sure not historically accurate.

I tried really hard (52 hours) to learn the game, and I kept failing at it. It was a constant barrage of new rules. I found playing with gemini on the side was necessary for me to understand how to get out of tricky situations. And even with this extra help it didn't work out for me. 

Sometimes I felt in control, to find out 20 minutes later that my lineage was gone and I had no way to carry on. Other times I went through what felt like a never ending war, not winning nor losing for hours (playing at standard speed). I lost some battles that were predicted as guaranteed wins, and vice versa. Still no idea why.

It feels appealing when one finally understands a bit of the game mecanics. But too many times the game  smashed my face into the ground and I didn't have a clue why.

Sorry, not for me!

On 7950x3d, 4070 ti super, 64 gb ram you do will experience slideshow, 5 fps, input lag, because this awesome game is written in a way that can't handle more than 1 cpu core and everything is binded in a single thread, so unless you have quantum cpu - stay away from it.

Don't get me wrong, CK3 has its fun moments, but it has one massive, underlying issue: It's a combination grand strategy game and life sim. Because of this, it never really is able to be a good version of either. It's strategy components are puddle deep and easily exploitable. Warfare amounts to building centralized military in the 800s, and because the AI can't think strategically, you just steamroll everything that hasn't been over-buffed by the devs (Like the mongols).
  The roleplaying elements have a shelf life because everything is handled through events, you play through menus so you can only be given character moments through text, and because its all random events that have been pre-written there`s a distinct lack of character for your characters. 
  Several of the game's systems have also just been left to rot completely. I don't even need to list them here because almost every game system has just been neglected. Devs are focused on adding new content, which is fine, but surely you can hire a new team to update and upkeep the old content? Stellaris is actually a great example of this working. (Despite that game's current issues.)
  Unfortunately I just don't think you should play CK3. If you want a good Grand Strategy game, play EU4 or HOI4 or even VIC3. Heck, go play Imperator: Rome. Crusader Kings 3 is otherwise an incredible game, but a severe, long-standing bug tied to succession and cultural reformation makes it impossible to recommend.
This bug has been known since 2022 and is still active.
The Problem: When your ruler dies, and the Culture Head title briefly transfers to an AI, that AI instantly uses the chance to cancel and change your ongoing cultural reformation.
The Consequence: This arbitrarily wastes 20-30 years of development time, gold, and prestige and is an unfair punishment for a core game event (succession). The AI is operating under rules that the player does not have (players cannot cancel their own ongoing reforms). Do not buy this game until Paradox addresses this critical inconsistency. The core mechanic of shaping your culture is currently too vulnerable to random AI interference.
This is a widely reported issue, confirmed by the community:
Confirmed - NPC's switching your Cultural Tradition mid-establishing
CK III - AI cancels the current reform culture type while my emperor is a child
CK III - New culture head changes a reform in progress, but I can't do the same!
Game breaking issue, AI randomly changes culture reformation in progress

[h1]“Supergiant Game’s take when you mix a sports game/visual novel game and great world building to package it all together. Does the Pyre burn or does it snuff it out?”[/h1]

[hr][/hr]
[h2]Presentation and Narrative[/h2]
- Deep and very expansive Lore, Supergiant Games’ never miss when creating a world from scratch.
- Gorgeous Art and Music. Supergiant Games aways are top notch with their art and music.
- Gobsmackingly great World building. Supergiant Games can just whiff up worlds and stories that all cohese into one big story.

[hr][/hr]
[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
- This is basically NBA Jam if it was 3 VS 3 with ofc more gameplay elements mixed in.
- I switched playing on a controller and it felt better.
- Only played the campaign, and over all it’s a mix of visual novel, rpg, sports game.
- Going around challenging other parties to the rites while also exploring the world at a whole.

[hr][/hr]
[h2]Technicality and Value[/h2]
- From the makers of Bastion and Transistor, Supergiant Games’ 3rd Game
- Goes very cheap on sale.
- Versus Mode that you can play with Bots or Friends, via Couch or Remote Play Together
- Would see this as a good couch play with friends, but you’ll need patient friends as the game itself takes some time to get used to.
- I played this for the Campaign alone and judging only by that, the game is still worth it’s price.

[h1]FINAL SCORE: [b]7/10[/b][/h1]

2025年10月19日中午 4h首通 算是首次通关了这个游戏其实这个游戏我当时在晶体馆之后就一直很关注美术实在太棒了 但是20年以前,当时打的开投就没有再打了主要感觉就是节奏还是稍微有点慢而且我对他这个抢球、夺球的玩法不是特别感冒……
目前玩到的部分就是把郝德文算是第一次送出了下界，当时游戏刚刚开始的时候就是他对玩家展示出了最大的善意所以也是首先选择送他出去 （而且他不强）
【美术5/5】这游戏的美术是绝对没得说的是我觉得简直可以称为艺术品的感觉 尤其是把郝德文送走了之后,车子就解锁了飞天功能,然后在各个世界穿梭的时候会有一种在翻书的感觉,每一个世界都是重叠在另外一个世界之下或者之上的。 而且 Supergiant 这家公司很强的地方就是配色都非常鲜艳,但是却一点都不让你觉得杂乱,就真的很好看。像插画一样,每一幅画面都像插画一样。 
【音乐4/5】这个游戏的音乐也很好听。特别是中间有几个段落。比如说翻越海洋的时候要走向最终的北极的时候。都会有一段人声的歌唱然后我当时还停下来听了不少时间。还有一开始序章的时候三个人把玩家捡到的似乎后，背景音乐就有那种荒野的感觉 相比很多其他玩完了都没有任何音乐感觉的游戏来说这个游戏的音乐真的算很不错 
【游戏性2/5】不得不说,这个游戏真的不是我特别喜欢的那种。就是纯粹为了看剧情换画面才勉强玩了玩它的这个抢球的游戏。 操作非常不舒服因为能控制的角色只有一个然后另外两个角色是处于完全没有任何防御的状态的就很容易被敌人打死 反正我不喜欢而且打完了初次通关之后也没什么动力继续玩下去了先就这样吧

in the best ways, this felt like a video game version of my favorite fantasy novel. I can see how pyre built from transistor, and to hades, but everything I love about supergiant is still here: beautifully-rendered art, compelling narrative choices, and innovative gameplay. 

also, a bunch of little guys, one being mostly an eyeball snake. 10/10 unionize your workplace.
Crazy innovative, beautiful and surprisingly deep
This is an oft-overlooked game by SGG, but I highly recommend it. It has gorgeous art, beautifully written characters, and the gameplay is engaging and deceptively deep.
An innovative game with astounding artwork and great SFX. The gameplay is unique, as is the ability to fail forward.

Pyre is a game i didn't think much of when i first bought it, but the moment i stepped foot into the game's world i knew i was in for something special. And i had that confirmed when i realised that Supergiant developed this game. They managed to weave the seemingly impossible and combine two genres i'm usually not a fan of (visual novels and sports like games) and create one of the most unique, finely crafted, GORGEOUS and fun experiences i've had in a long time.

I love so many ranges of indie games but this has become easily one of my top 5 favorite games of all time. The story and characters i adore, the soundtrack is INCREDIBLE (and Darren Korb has the voice of an angel), this is one of the most jaw droppingly beautiful games i've ever seen. There is truly so so much i could go on about but i'll save the gushing and just say please try this game out. Especially for the price. It's a crying shame that this game got so little attention compared to their other work. And i will continue to sing this game's praises for as long as i can (along with their other works) and i will continue to support them in any way i can.

This game is not for everyone in terms of gameplay but that's ok, i'm happy as long as more people get to try an absolutely incredible experience. 

And if anyone at Supergiant reads this, thank you for your work. Your art and music is always something i and many more eagerly look forward to. You've been an artistic inspiration for so many people and your passion for what you do is so inspiring to all, As an aspiring game dev, artist and hopefully someday composer, there's so much i can learn from you. This may be just gushing but that's because i have nothing but positive things to say and this game along with Hades have become so special to me.

TLDR: Please try this game out, it knocks it out of the park on so many fronts and it's very affordable. And if you haven't yet, please do try out Super Giants other works and support them. I cannot recommend it enough.

Pyre, developed and published by Supergiant Games, stands as one of the most daring and unconventional narrative experiences in modern gaming. Known for their emotionally resonant and stylistically distinct titles like Bastion and Transistor, Supergiant took a risk with Pyre, merging the structure of a visual novel with the mechanics of a fantastical sports competition. The result is an experience that feels unlike anything else—a fusion of story-driven role-playing, tactical action, and moral choice, all wrapped in a richly imagined world of exile and redemption. Pyre is not content to simply tell a story; it asks players to participate in the creation of that story through their choices, triumphs, and failures.

The game takes place in a world divided between the Commonwealth, a rigid society that banishes anyone who breaks its laws, and the Downside, a vast, mystical wasteland where exiles are sent to live out their days. You play as the Reader, a literate outcast in a world where reading is forbidden. Rescued by a small band of exiles, you quickly become their guide and strategist, using your ability to interpret the Book of Rites—a sacred text that details the mystical competitions that grant freedom from exile. These contests, known as the Rites, form the heart of the game’s structure and symbolize the hope of redemption. Each victory brings one of your companions closer to liberation, but also closer to departure, as those who win are granted freedom and must leave the group behind. This mechanic transforms what might have been a simple victory condition into an emotional choice—winning means losing someone important.

The Rites themselves are a fascinating blend of tactical sport and magical ritual. Two teams of three face off in mystical arenas, each attempting to extinguish the other’s pyre by delivering a celestial orb into it. The rules are simple but layered with nuance. Each character on your team has unique abilities, movement styles, and aura sizes, which affect both offense and defense. Some are fast and agile, capable of darting across the field to score quickly, while others are slower but powerful, able to banish opponents from play with bursts of energy. The challenge comes from learning how to balance these traits, chain passes, and outmaneuver the opposition. The pace of the Rites sits somewhere between a real-time strategy match and a competitive sports game, emphasizing positioning, timing, and coordination. The sense of tension in each match is amplified by the fact that no defeat is final; losing a Rite does not end your journey but instead reshapes it, influencing character relationships and the ultimate direction of the story.

Pyre’s decision to let the story continue regardless of success or failure is one of its most inspired design choices. Rather than enforcing perfection, it allows the narrative to adapt dynamically, emphasizing the weight of choice and consequence. Every victory and every loss becomes part of the journey, shaping how your companions perceive themselves and you. It’s a design philosophy that challenges the typical game structure where failure means repetition. In Pyre, failure carries meaning. Losing a match may alter who gains freedom, who remains trapped, and how your group evolves emotionally. These narrative ripples make each playthrough personal and distinctive, encouraging you to accept the story as your own rather than chasing an ideal outcome.

Outside the arenas, much of the game unfolds through richly written narrative segments aboard your caravan, the Blackwagon, as your band of exiles travels across the Downside. Here, Pyre resembles an interactive novel, filled with branching dialogue, world-building lore, and moments of quiet reflection. You converse with your companions, learn their histories, and make decisions that affect morale, resources, and relationships. The characters themselves are among Supergiant’s finest creations—each distinct, complex, and layered with humanity despite their fantastical forms. There’s Hedwyn, the optimistic warrior who seeks peace for everyone; Jodariel, the stoic demon whose loyalty masks deep vulnerability; Rukey, the scrappy cur who hides his insecurities behind humor; and countless others who join along the way. As you journey together, bonds form and break, and the group’s dynamic evolves in ways that feel organic and emotionally authentic. When the time comes to choose who earns their freedom, these relationships give the decisions a poignant gravity—every liberation feels like both a triumph and a loss.

Visually, Pyre is a masterpiece of color and design. The Downside is depicted as a dreamlike wilderness, filled with desolate deserts, haunted ruins, and glowing celestial fields. The hand-painted art style is lush and vivid, each scene glowing with painterly detail. Supergiant’s artistic direction is unmistakable—fluid animation, bold use of color, and striking character portraits make every frame feel alive. Complementing the visuals is the extraordinary sound design. Darren Korb’s soundtrack is both haunting and uplifting, seamlessly weaving folk, choral, and atmospheric elements that evoke the game’s emotional and spiritual themes. The narration, delivered by Logan Cunningham, adds depth and presence, his gravelly voice acting as both chronicler and conscience throughout your journey. Together, the art and music create an otherworldly atmosphere that lingers long after the game is over.

While Pyre’s ambition is undeniable, it’s not without its shortcomings. Some players may find the abundance of text and lore overwhelming, especially early on when the world’s terminology and politics are introduced at length. The pacing can occasionally feel uneven, as stretches of introspective narrative are followed by bursts of frenetic gameplay. Additionally, while the Rites are mechanically unique, they can begin to feel repetitive after dozens of matches, especially if players find themselves favoring certain strategies or team compositions. The lack of an online multiplayer mode also limits the long-term replayability of its competitive component, though a local versus option provides a glimpse of its potential as a standalone sports experience. Still, for most players, these issues are minor compared to the richness of the overall experience.

At its core, Pyre is a game about redemption, sacrifice, and the nature of freedom. It asks what it means to lead, to forgive, and to let go. Every decision you make reflects not only your tactical skill but your moral compass. The story’s multiple endings depend on the choices you make, the Rites you win or lose, and the companions you choose to liberate. Few games so elegantly integrate narrative consequence with gameplay mechanics, and fewer still make you feel the emotional weight of those consequences so profoundly. Pyre rewards empathy and introspection as much as strategic thinking, making it as much a moral journey as a mechanical one.

In the end, Pyre is more than just a game—it’s a work of art that defies easy categorization. It combines the heart of a novel, the soul of a myth, and the structure of a sport into a single, cohesive experience. Its willingness to subvert expectations and trust the player to accept imperfection is what makes it special. Every match, every dialogue choice, and every sacrifice builds toward a personal story of struggle and redemption that feels entirely your own. Supergiant Games has crafted something rare with Pyre—a game that not only entertains but invites reflection, one that lingers in the mind like an unfinished song, echoing long after the final Rite has been won or lost.

It's my favorite of Supergiant's work, easy. 
Practical terms - the game part is rugby with ranged weaponry, but surrounding it is this vivid fantasy world that is built on an in-universe astrology system but manages to escape that gravity to be so much more. Its snappy and tactical, then has linear exploration and dialogue between matches. Failure in a match is a canon event, and the game and narrative smoothly adjust for your success in your matchups to a degree reminiscent to Disco Elysium. It might click with you or it might not, but you gotta try it.
It's just such a fascinating object, so familiar as to be understandable and easy to grasp yet so unique in so many ways. It really flaunted Supergiant's ability to craft an interesting world and unique game structure in a way that is both accessible and wonderfully strange. I love it a lot, and it's a shame they've lost this kind of wonder.

The game is largely fine, a sports game of passing a ball (An orb) down to a goal, but is ruined by trials that are very obviously completely impossible without the computer essentially just giving you a break.
You _can not_ win in a 1 vs 3 AI firing on all cylinders, its not physically possible, so making that a part of the game is objectively garbage design. There is no satisfaction to it even when you do pull it off because you know the computer just let you do it. You can even see when you pull too far ahead of the computer and itll rubber band itself back up by playing normally and scoring a goal almost instantly with zero hope of stopping it. 

Obviously a computer can beat humans in a lot of tasks, but when you lay it so completely bare for the player, that no, you can not win, the only time you will is because its deigned to let you this time around is frustrating trash games creation, and by a huge margin the worst thing Ive seen in any this studios games.

Edit: I want to flesh this out a bit cause the trials are just one small part of the game, so what about the rest.
Well, as others have pointed out its actually more visual novel than it is game, given much of the game play doesnt even really have much bearing on things. There are some neat characters, but the story is quite scatter shot and didnt have the same impact on me as Bastion, Hades, and certainly not Transistor.

The game play more broadly is... fine, I think you might get the impression from my main complaint that my issue is with the difficulty, that I just need to git gud, but no, in fact I played it on Nightwing difficulty (cause Im a filthy completionist.) and actually found it to be a better experience than my first play through. The issue isnt difficulty, its how very apparent the AI is, Im just very aware Im playing against a computer and it doesnt feel good, it isnt satisfying: I won almost all my games on normal, and the majority on Nightwing, and it still never felt like the game play had really clicked with me, while the computer always made me feel like it was just letting me win half the time. (The corollary of this is that it also often feels unfair when you dont win.)

The trials are where this is most egregious, because as I say, its essentially impossible to win 1 vs 3 without the AI deliberately sabotaging itself and there is nothing good about winning like that, I genuinely dont understand the decision to put that in the game. Regardless, it is a problem the whole way through, and when Im not that married to the story (or many of the characters for that matter), there really isnt much here for me outside of some good music as always, and the world which Id kinda like to see more of... but in a different game.

Big fan of Supergiant Games, but this fell flat for me. Very cool visuals and concept, but the world building had me lost. The game consists of 90% dialogue and 10% actual game play. I couldn't really find myself caring about any of the characters or the story in general. Game play can be difficult, but once you catch on to the mechanics, it gets easier. I'd say the best thing about the game is that when you turn the difficulty up, it becomes quite the challenge. Probably won't revisit this game anytime soon, but with this game completed...I can move on to Hades (finally)!
