Bastion is an action game, Transistor is a turn-based strategy game and Pyre is a sports game. Supergiant Games has a range and that’s great, a lot of people like their games, but I just can't get into their games. I like them at first, very artistic, but then quickly grow tired. I want to enjoy their games, but after like 2 hours, I'm bored. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3241522266 https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3146023515 Unlocked all achievements!

Supergiant is a good developer and I see what they were going for with Pyre, but I just don't think it's engaging or interesting enough to play for very long. I loved Bastion, Hades is fantastic and I see why people like Transistor (though personally, the battle system ruined the game for me), but Pyre doesn't really have much to offer.

The game is half visual novel, half sports game. In the visual novel portion, you learn more of the residents and exiled of the Downside who try to make their way back up to the Commonwealth, travel around with a band of misfits and companions as the reader, and challenge other exiled to the "rites". Those "rites", the other half of the game, are essentially a mix of soccer and rugby. In these 3v3 matches, the goal is to pick up a ball and deliver it to the enemy's Pyre. Every exile has their own playstyle, some are really fast, others can fly shortly, others are really big and block a large part of the area. Every exile also has a field around them, which you can touch enemies with to banish them shortly, or send it forth in a wave as a ranged attack.

It's an interesting concept, but as a game, Pyre doesn't have much to offer. The visual novel portion, while set in gorgeous landscapes with Supergiant's usual style, and accentuated by a good soundtrack, is unnecessarily wordy. New terms are thrown at you constantly, with many different names and circumstances you are expected to become familiar with (or not, as many terms are bolded so you can instantly hover over them to know what they mean). The different exiles are somewhat interesting in their personalities and most of them are likeable, but you don't really get much time to interact with them due to the game's pacing.

The game works as follows: click on a star in the sky to guide you, then travel to that areain a series of cutscenes. Sometimes you can choose one of two or three paths where you can find items like talismans to equip or to sell, and sometimes you can do vocations which grant bonuses, but generally, there isn't really a "wrong" choice. After a few minutes, you are at the next rite, and then it starts all over up to the liberation rite, which decides who of your exiles go free. Then, you do it all over again - 6 times, as I've understood, before the game is officially over.

There isn't much more to the game than travel, rite, travel, rite, travel, rite. The rites themselves are fun at first, but get boring and very repetitive very quickly. After one liberation rite, I had enough and can not imagine doing this another 5 or so times. The worst part is that nothing you do really matters - the story continues, whether you win or lose. As I understand, it does affect the ending somewhat, but it feels like there is nothing at stake and so, overall, I felt like I had seen enough after liberating one exile.

In my opinion, Pyre is definitely the weakest title of Supergiant, because unlike most of their other offerings, the gameplay isn't deep or interesting enough to be entertaining longterm, and the world and story, while interesting at first, are too fragmented and cryptic to really care about after the initial few hours. Good characters and a good soundtrack / artstyle can't save Pyre from being a mediocre game and I think even Transistor, which I personally didn't like all that much, was more fun to me.
Having basic mechanics as a stat is beyond stupid. Having your units to be animation locked is supreme travesty.

This studio makes great games, but this isn't one of them. The storytelling is great, but the gameplay isn't very fun. I do like that they've tried something new and original, but this time it just didn't work out well.
I really wanted to like this game, but the gameplay just threw me for a loop. It's basically basketball.

I can describe this game in 1 word:

Tedious

The "gameplay" is a 3v3 sports game, which isn't horrible if you know what your doing, but it isn't fun either.

The game tries to claim RPG status by giving the illusion of choice constantly.  But the choices all end up exactly the same, thus making this a Visual Novel...  not an RPG.

2.5 of the 3 hours i played of the game is Visual Novel and it's just boring...
Characters the game didn't get me invested in, going from place to place in a world the game didn't get me invested in.

There are a whole lot of better novels out there.  And there are a whole lot of better games out there.
This is bad enough I would rather listen to an audiobook while playing solitaire...
Characters are interesting but the story, world, and ritual game are lame. Never to return. Music is good.
The gameplay is very repetitive it gets boring quickly. The only props I gave it is the art style everything else is just mid.

"The two old friends have evidently managed their way past certain tensions in their long-standing relationship. They rather seem to draw a certain strength from one another."

This is the text that appears after a dialogue between two characters of your party. This happens near the end of the campaign. The dialogue preceding this was moderately long and establishes with no subtlety that they are friends who have disagreed in the past. There were no choices to be made and new information was not revealed. The line about drawing strength from one another has no effect, to the character or gameplay wise if you put the two characters on a team. It is well written filler text, and it exemplary of why I do not recommend this game.

You will spend a vast majority of the campaign reading filler text. The text will ask nothing of you - no mysteries to deduce, no characters to unravel, no choices to be made except for flavor text. You'll solve mysteries when the text is programmed to reveal the answers. You'll get character bonuses when the text declares it's time to get bonuses. You'll get resolutions when the script decides it's the right battle to resolve an arc. You can skip the text and you won't miss any opportunities to better your team.

For being primarily a visual novel, Pyre is deeply disappointing in using text as if it was a static script written external to the game. It should have been an easy recommendation considering how strong it is mechanically and visually. Much love was poured into this project. This just needed to follow the formula that the Persona series established and just... didn't.
It's another Supergiant game in which the gameplay, despite being innovative, gets boring after a few hours. The art and story are nice, but could not keep me playing until the end.

I really wanted to like this game. I've been a fan of Supergiant games.
It's visually stunning. The music is immersive.
But I found the gameplay itself boring. It's more like a repetitive minigame, lacking in depth.
The story itself was intriguing but the game part felt so much like a chore that I didn't finish it and probably won't.
Nice Graphics/Story/Voice but as a game it's not for me (I fell that it's not fun & difficult to understand)

Its a visual novel meets sports mini-game. The characters are ambiguous over deep and the lore about characters and world building is presented through tool tips rather than actual developments in the story. An air of mystery is fine but without feeling motivated to experience the stories of these characters its a bit shallow. 

The mini-game part is pretty decent but its very fast paced and for me that kind of game play just promotes frustration. Soundtrack is nice but not as initially memorable as other Supergiant Games titles. They have produced something really unique and it is not for me.

I must preface this by saying that my expectations of this game were unreasonably high going into it, since Pyre is made by Supergaint Games and I highly enjoyed Hades. Even still, this game was a disappointment. The environment's, characters, and tiny details in the story are all incredible. Every environment is packed with charm and details and could easily be a screen savor or hung up on a wall. All the characters have a great amount of depth from what I have seen and feel like real people, interesting real people at that. Finally, the music is incredible and I will need to go listen to the full soundtrack later. Every part of the game outside of the core game-play, the "rites", is incredible. The only problems are with the "rites". The idea of three versus three basketball for the core game-play is unusual for an rpg, but the idea in and of itself is really interesting. However, the execution fails. You can only control one team member at a time, and to switch team members, you need to be looking at the team member and hold down the space bar. On top of that, while you have the ball, you must throw the ball before you can switch team members. You throw the ball by holding down the space bar, which slowly increases the distance you will throw the ball, something that feels very clunky. Additionally, teammates do nothing while you aren't controlling them. Finally, the A.I opponents can switch between teammates instantly and throw the ball instantly. This all incentives you to only play as the fastest character in your party, since they can easily avoid the A.I on normal difficulty. The only reason your other party members aren't useless is that after you score with a teammate, you temporarily can't use them. You can only use them again after another teammate scores. This way of forcing the player to use more than one team member quickly turns the game into a two versus three game and just makes me wish the game allowed you to have other players control the other team members or was one versus one. The final problem with Pyre is the speed of game-play. The game feels like it wants to require complex strategy and quick reflexes. The game fails to give players opportunities for either, as the game-play is too slow to require good reflexes and too fast to allow for complex strategy. All these problems combine to create a game that feels like its trying to do too many things and is only succeeding with the story.

TLDR; Great story, amazing visuals, and incredible music, 4/10 game-play.

In essence, I think that the gameplay itself isn't all that great.
In it's core it's a sports game of sorts. If you know M.U.D.S. (Mean Ugly Dirty Sports) from the early nineties, it might be the closest thing to this game. I suspect it seems fun on paper, but feels slow and clunky.
I tried various controller layouts as well as a PS4 controller. I never felt much in control of the characters. Maybe I lack the strategic teamplay aspect, I don't know.

Everything else is a different story.
There is a world that looks gorgeous, the character designs are great as well. The animations are charming and wonderful, I can only praise what I see. It's unique and very enjoyable. I would have put this game away much faster if it wasn't for it's design.

Part of the design is the sound as well. The voices (although unintelligible glib) are well done, every hit, flame and movement make the right noises. The music is unique and just a joy to fall into it's thick atmosphere. Atmosphere in general is a really strong point of this game. It's well-crafted and something that welcomes you to stay.

The story itself is less of a drawing point. It's deliberately obfuscating. There is no mystery because you're constantly confused. It even goes so far as to have keywords that you can hover over to give some sort of context. It's hermetic and hard to get through. There is an argument to be had to have a very unfamiliar world, but at some point it's becoming heavy handed as you constantly need to relearn vocabulary to understand what's going on. Final Fantasy 13 had a similar approach where the world would make sense if you read long articles that were supposed to be optional. This game expects you to read a lot. So it sort of falls into a kind of visual novel. While it's written well, it never managed to draw me in. I understand that they are in some sort of underworld where they want to get out of. On the other hand, the world above doesn't seem to be a much better place with probably an even worse way of living. So the goal is muddy at best.

So that's what I got: 
Characters that are amazing artworks and quite unique - but lacking interesting personalities. Sure, everyone has their kind of tragic backstory, but there isn't much more to it.
The atmosphere and the world design are visually outstanding and I'm glad to have seen it in all it's glory. The animations are so smooth and charming that I don't know if I'd have anything that could match it - again, in a very unique style and done by true artisans. Same goes for the music that really strengthens the atmosphere. That part is absolutely fantastic.
Then there is sort of a visual novel that I don't find interesting.
Lastly there is a sports game that I never got the hang of and is more frustrating than interesting. Sure, SuperGiant always was on the experimental side of things and I usually search for experiences that differ from the norm. Transistor was brilliant and offered great gameplay. Pyre just wasn't fun to play for me.

If old sports games are your thing, you might enjoy it. It might be that I could put in some more hours to get the hang of it and it probably could transform into a fun game. But after 5 hours and the first round of rites I'd have hoped to have an idea of how to play, but I don't.

Sandwiched between early gems Basition and Transistor, and absolute masterpiece Hades, Pyre is a complicated middle child. It has lots of elements that Supergiant has polished to a gleam by this point - wonderful characters, graphics, voice overs and music, and Supergiant fans should probably check it out, if just for those.

Unfortunately, at its core, the game revolves around the 'Rites', a sporting event where your team of three tries to get its orb to the other side. There's more to it than that, with unique characters, powers, and a, in theory, impressive plethora of combos and strategies that you could devise and employ. Unfortunately it just isn't fun. Too fast to let you focus on strategy, but with movement and controls too clunky to focus on reflexes and intuition.

The story and characters will leave a lasting impression on me, but the truth is that I persisted with the game just to experience the story. Held hostage by great character building. There is lots to admire here, but at the end of the day you should go play Hades. All the successes of Pyre are firmly embedded in that game, as well as every lesson learned. Onwards and upwards Supergiant Games!
Die Geschichte ist nett aber die Steuerung für die Kämpfe ist so garnicht meins. Das Balanceing ist einfach net da.

Alright I've tried to beat this multiple times (general playthrough) and I gave up this final time.

It's still pretty buggy, I had to revert to a checkpoint multiple times because the "exit out of menu" button randomly disappears so you can't leave the vendor.

The game is basically basketball with magic, and it's very awkward to control.  You can only control/move one character at a time so passing leads you to toss the ball backwards.  The only strat is to grab the ball with a fast hero and run straight into the fire, which is pretty silly.

Likely Supergiant's worst game.

I wanted to like this game, but man I can't recommend it. 
First issue I had it took almost 4 hours until the game opened up so I can choose who to fight.  
I heard it was mostly visual novel with little combat and because of that I thought game would be more open ended, choosing what characters to speak to, learning more about them and having some open ended options about their stories based on your dialog, but so far it was mostly listening to them speak and other than who to liberate I didn't feel like I had input in their stories or that even who I liberated mattered.

But my biggest reason for giving it thumbs down is combat. It feels so clunky and most of the time enemy scored was because I wasn't able to switch my character in time or misclicked on them.
If combat felt good or I felt like I had more influence on the characters I would finished it.

Lore is interesting, characters have nice designs, visuals are polished so if you like linear stories then I can see you enjoying the game but it's just not for me.

I love Supergiant’s Bastion. And I kinda like Transistor as well. I absolutely love the artistic touch the studio has, and that’s why I thought Pyre would be a good game for me. But it isn’t. It has good art, good story, good soundtrack, but I felt that the gameplay is lackluster. I am probably halfway through the game, and it feels ever like a drag. I will probably finish it, but out of sheer will… I respect the game, but it’s not for me.

review_text:
[h1]A cute but extremely short and at times frustrating adventure puzzle game.[/h1]

So after initially attempting to play this with a friend using Remote Play Together and getting absolutely nowhere, we gave up and I ended up playing this with my girlfriend using 360 and PS4 controllers respectively.

While the game is extremely short, it was quite fun from the puzzle aspect of things. However the camera is atrocious, this is my main gripe, as well as being an overall glitchy mess. The music can get annoying too with it being a never ending loop. Aside from these minor frustrations though, we had fun playing for the short amount of time that the game lasts and all achievements triggered without any issue.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2313402852

With that being said, I'll happily give this a positive rating. Especially considering it's Free to Play.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Free To Play, Indie
review_text: I am not the one who owns this game but I was playing it with my friend who does. We both really like it, we both find it really cute, simple, and has a lot of potential for something more! However, we ran into some issues and we just wanted you and future players to be aware of. Seeing how we can't get together right now, we were playing via remote play. This led to some issues that seem to be mostly remote play's fault but not the game. The game crashed multiple times right after starting remote play until we finally got it to work. Then, connection was rather choppy, and when in other games it it usually is less so, but it could be an internet issue. My friend was also using the keyboard, and was having issues. They would click full screen but it would only stay in windowed. They hit maximize to make it fill the screen, but since it was still windowed, they would click out of the screen when using the mouse. Other than that, we really like the game and just wanted people to be aware. We both highly recommend the game, but it is truly best played locally.

review_text:
I played this with my brother, after initial confusion because I forgot to configure the controls before playing. We laughed a lot.

Pros:
- Pee was a viable mechanic.
- Daigo can poop off ledges, though poop has yet to be a viable mechanic.
- I can troll my fellow player.
- Wholesome content.
- Teamwork mechanic is smooth.
- Puzzles are clear.
- Chill music.

Cons:
- Daigo can't pee all his problems away.
- Camera too close to Daigo's butt.
- Some things are hard to see due to camera angles.

8/10.

review_text:
I was asked to try this game out by two friends that helped make this game so here I am. I had seen some stuff they made during development and I have to say the models are pretty well made. The game uses vibrant colors and easy to understand concepts to reach out to a younger audiance. 
There are still some things that could be improved, like the lag during cutscenes (I think this is due to the loading of the next level) and the jump animation is a little odd. Also it was really quiet in the last level, which could be by choice, but I'd like some music better. 
Apart from that it's a cute game you should try out to support the hardworking people that made this game.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Free To Play, Indie
review_text:
A cute, little game for two players, but I played it alone, keyboard and controller simultaneously.
You play Kika (player 1), the granddaughter of a private detective and she has clearly inherited his passion for solving mysteries.
Together with her corgi Daigo (player 2) she tries to find her grandfather back.

The 3D models are simple yet cute (the fork-lift truck <3), same for the cutscenes. There are some surprisingly witty interactions with the world.

Hopefully they will add more levels and make the camera a bit smoother, but apart from that it's fun to play for an hour with a friend or alone (you don't have to move both Kika and Corgi at the same time, with a few doable exceptions). Achievements can be obtained within one playthrough. Congratulations on releasing this game, BFCS!

review_text:
Love the concept, and the style is very cute. Gameplay completely kills the experience however. 

Controller controls have been implemented well, but the camera is absolute hell when playing either character on keyboard. Most the time one player is the eyes and the other just moves in the directions given, without any real clue where they're headed. 

I've also never seen cutscenes lag as much! On my current computer, or even my old crappy laptop. How does that even happen?

The gameplay doesn't need to be ground breaking, but it should atleast not feel like a chore just to move your character. I really hope this will be fixed later, since as I said, the concept is cute and charming!

This game will make you feel pain like you've never felt. Like worse than Naruto Pain

We start off with what looks like an 80s style cartoon show. The plot is written and now your soul is suddenly owned by the devil himself. And of course the only way to clear the debt is to play the game and win it. Sounds easy right?

Wrong. Playing this game with another person will drive you both mad. It's not enough to play perfectly but you both have to play perfectly. Due to the share screen nature both players have to stay in sync or risk slipping or stalling the screen from progressing whiles enemies and projectiles continue their trajectory towards your little bodies with big cup heads as easy targets.

Pain aside, this game is genuinely fun when you can finally clear a stage. It takes hours and hours, sometimes days to finally reach the next level. But when you do that feeling is unforgetable. Its the kind of game that exemplifies the value of perseverance. For young kids this game can potentially be a good teacher in that aspect.

I still have only cleared like 5 levels so far at the time of this writing so theres very much left to play. Replay value is great. Enemy variety and boss fights are top notch. This is a game you can play forever and keep coming back to

A masterpiece of style and substance. Cuphead is a visually stunning, audibly perfect, and relentlessly challenging run-and-gun boss rush that demands perfection and rewards it with pure, unadulterated joy.

Cuphead defines a genre, it is incredibly beautiful and just as challenging. I have completed many games, but few have felt as entertaining as Cuphead: in most games, overcoming an obstacle is often a mere relief, but this game makes you feel like a champion.
Every section of this game is unforgettable. The gameplay is very fast-paced and dynamic, the arsenal is wide and the player is encouraged to come up with different builds.
The music perfectly accompanies the player throughout the various sections of the game almost in a cinematic way, the fights being presented like episodes of old cartoons. The animation is just as impressive and it truly feels timeless, the drawings are so beautiful and stunningly hand drawn.
Overall, this game is a pleasure for all the senses and, when I play it, I often admire it in astonishment and feel nostalgic for a distant but incredibly familiar time.
If you have patience and perseverance, do yourself a favour and play this work of art: you will not regret it.

[h1]Only Play If You Get A Hard-On For Boss Gauntlets[/h1]

Yeah, I didn't play much of this before requesting a refund, and I will admit that this game does not suit my taste. I bought it with only the knowledge that it's difficult, but when I began playing it, I realized that there is zero exploration and 100% boss rush/gauntlet.

Don't get me wrong. I'm not saying the game itself is bad. It's just not my taste, but I didn't know that when I bought it. 

I adore the aesthetic of Cuphead. The art and design just drip with love and care from the developers. But I just don't like the idea of playing a game just to immediately jump into a boss level. I enjoy games that have difficult bosses but with interesting level exploration for reprieve.

I will say that this game resembles an arcade approach to gameplay, so if you're into that, then enjoy. Otherwise, stay away and save your money at all costs.

This game is just not fun for me. it'snot that it's too hard, i love challenge, but i feel like every single time i go into a boss, i don't feel in control of the outcome in the slightest. half the time, it feels like the game will just decide that i lose because a projectile was in the wrong place at the wrong time, or i'll be unable to hit a boss because of the way shooting works. forcing me to move in the direction i want to shoot feels incredibly counterintuitive, especially when the only other way to aim forces you to stay still for it to work. Chaser was my best friend, but it just isn't good enough to fix that for me.

and if you couldn't guess: i also hate Metroid games. same exact shooting mechanics, and i don't like them there either. 

not my game. and i'm willing to admit that. the controls just don't feel natural or even fair to me most of the time. 4/10, but that's entirely personal.

from an objective standpoint, it's at least a 7/10.

[h2] F in CUPHEAD stands for Fun [/h2]
Finished the game.

I'm baffled. So much effort went into making all those bosses with their animations. Visually game is very creative. Literally epic. But that's that.

Game's is not that hard since i played many NES games. But that's actually real problem. 1980s called -  they want their gameplay back. The thing is that back then we had nothing else and all that "memorize patterns" stuff was relevant. But when you see this approach in modern games like Dark Souls, Cuphead and whatsoever, it's really sad. The only thing that was changed here is that boss timings (attacks, moves) are slightly randomized with shifted delays. And this is not challenging. I wish studio would focus on gameplay as they did with 1930s style. Gameplay is designed to waste your time with random timings, broken hitboxes and things on foreground that disctract you.

Levels and bosses are "one-offs": you try 10-20 times, beat it, forget it, time to move on. Playing game feels like having a second job. It's just not fun. Upgrades are nominal, you can easily beat the game with peashooter. Parrying is useless mostly.
When you die you have to watch that intro animation and listen to narartor which breaks the flow. In Super Meat Boy after dying you instanlty begin from start and ready to try again.

Here's zero variation on how to beat enemies: no combos, no nothing. Just hold attack button and move on. It worked in games like Contra since they were short and you beat games within 15-30 minute time range. Here whole game consists of Sonic, Chip & Dale and other games' bosses and it's really exhausting. Whats worse - it's not rewarding at all.

So the only people who would like this game are ego driven 20-year-olds who think they "ain't no punk b1tch", i guess. I'm too old to be motivated by being annoyed or wanting to show off.

茶杯头核心双人模式下只有一人能选的圣杯小姐，并且圣杯小姐自带四个护符：双跳，冲刺触碰即招架，无敌翻滚，+1 生命，而茶杯头/马克杯仍需在单护符槽里做痛苦取舍，甚至王堡图强制禁用这唯一护符而选择圣杯小姐的护符却不受到影响。这等同于把原作围绕“跳跃-冲刺-招架-定位”的三键协同难度，压低一个档次，改写了许多Boss对位节奏与处理窗口，比如说当粉色格挡物平行于玩家时，原本不可能触发有效格挡现在却变得可行，并且有些关卡大量的粉色格挡物只能在平行时被格挡。

DLC显然把“只靠招架取胜”的王堡明显按圣杯小姐的冲刺招架去适配，当用原配茶杯头/马克杯尝试时，玩家需要把向上弹跳的抛物轨迹、落点后摇与空中身位暴露一并管理，而圣杯小姐可以贴地或低空平移完成招架，风险更小、节奏更稳，难度曲线直接分岔。

还有在双人模式里，如果茶杯头带上圣杯小姐护符并产生遮挡，另一名玩家在同屏密集弹幕与平台处理下更容易吃亏。在旧关卡回刷与评级挑战中，角色选择本身就改变了Boss设计原本的意图，让“学会读招/位移换血的爽点”被“更强动作模组的省心效率”取代。圣杯小姐拥有更安全的招架与翻滚，在需要频繁“跳台+招架+还位”的节奏里，另一位仍用茶杯头/马克杯的玩家更容易掉节奏，更多挨打。

并且双人本就有“弹幕密集、队友身体/亡魂遮挡、复活粉心判定挤占视野”的老问题。在dlc里，投射物与背景的低对比度，boss花里胡哨复杂重复化的动作以及圣杯小姐的大招I和新武器的攻击模组更加对第二人带来分心与遮挡，特别是对Boss细微起手的读取和对投掷物位置的把控，前者的身位与射线、EX特效、击中特效、倒地亡魂的粉心复活动画，都会在特定弹幕密度下遮住关键像素，复杂的呈现效果导致人脑对多处动作图像的处理更加费劲，部分Boss阶段存在投射物、地形机关、背景动画、屏幕滤镜同步堆叠的情况，有效信息与装饰信息难以一眼分层，击中反馈/受伤反馈相对略显温柔，血量/进度严重缺乏直观条形提示。

总之，MDHR在没有优化前有缺陷的基础上，不断创造新的缺陷，将dlc双人模式下的整体体验感极大的降低，垃圾茶杯头。

In Cuphead’s core two-player mode, only one player can choose Ms. Chalice, and she comes with four built-in charms: double jump, dash-parry, invincible roll, and +1 HP. Meanwhile, Cuphead/Mugman are still forced to make a painful choice in a single charm slot. Even worse, in the King’s Leap (King’s Castle) stages, the one unique charm they can normally rely on is disabled, but Ms. Chalice’s built-in charm abilities remain unaffected. This effectively lowers by a full tier the original three-button synergy challenge built around “jump–dash–parry–positioning,” fundamentally changing the pacing and counterplay windows for many bosses. For example, when pink parryable objects move parallel to the player, parrying was originally impossible; with Ms. Chalice, it becomes doable. In some stages, large numbers of pink objects can only be parried in parallel motion.

The DLC clearly designs the “parry-only” King’s Leap fights around Ms. Chalice’s dash-parry. When attempting them with the original Cuphead/Mugman, players must manage an upward parabolic jump trajectory, landing recovery, and aerial hitbox exposure all at once; Ms. Chalice can perform low or ground-level parries with far less risk and a steadier rhythm, splitting the difficulty curve entirely.

In two-player mode, if Cuphead equips Ms. Chalice’s charm and causes visual obstruction, the other player, under dense on-screen bullet hell and platforming demands, is at a significant disadvantage. In revisiting old stages or going for high-rank challenges, the choice of character itself changes the boss’s original design intent—turning the satisfaction of “reading patterns/trading hits through skill” into the easy efficiency of a stronger movement kit. Ms. Chalice’s safer parry and roll mean that in sequences requiring frequent “platform–parry–reposition,” the Cuphead/Mugman player is more likely to lose rhythm and take more hits.

Two-player mode already suffered from the long-standing problems of “dense bullet patterns, teammate body/ghost heart revival blocking view.” In the DLC, the low contrast between projectiles and backgrounds, the bosses’ flashy, overly complex and repetitive animations, along with Ms. Chalice’s Super I and new weapon attack modules, further distract and obscure the second player—especially in reading a boss’s subtle startup frames and tracking projectile positions. The lead player’s body and shots, EX effects, hit effects, and ghost heart revival animation can, at certain projectile densities, hide key pixels. The complex visual presentation forces the brain to work harder to process multiple moving images at once. Some boss phases stack projectiles, environmental hazards, background animation, and screen filters simultaneously, making it hard to visually separate meaningful cues from decorative noise. Hit feedback and damage feedback feel relatively soft, and health/progress is seriously lacking in any straightforward bar display.

In short, on top of pre-existing flaws they never fixed, MDHR has kept creating new problems, massively degrading the overall co-op experience in the DLC. Cuphead DLC essentially is nothing more than garbage.

The most heartbreaking game I've ever played. I'm a sucker for redemption arcs and Johnny's is one of my absolute favorites. Doesn't mash it in your face that he's sorry but makes it very clear you matter more to him than anything else. The game had me bawling my eyes out more than I care to admit, and it's easy to understand why when you see and recognize the immense love and care that CDPR has put into making 2077 truly special. Every major character feels like an actual living person with goals, aspirations, and personalities, with their own unique interests and responses to how you choose to talk and act with them. You can try your best to help people but after all is said and done, Cyberpunk leaves you realizing just how bleak and punishing Night City, as well as our seemingly destined future is. Even the "happy" endings will leave you with a pit in your stomach, but at least some of them were caused by you choosing your own fate. Though, in the end, you'll wind up affecting others' lives as well as their own fates no matter how hard you try to distance yourself, because you never realize just how many people care for you. There truly are no happy endings in Night City.

Preordered Cyberpunk and still enjoyed it on the launch version. I was fortunate enough to not run into game breaking bugs on the launch version, just minor problems. Couple years have passed since then and my computer has gone through extensive upgrades so i decided to reimmerse myself in the world of cyberpunk once more to witness the major updates, the new DLC, and to test my new specs, and i have fallen in love with the game once again. Even though i enjoyed the game at launch I applaud CDPR for bouncing back from launch day and im excited to experience Orion.

HOP IN CHOOM, WE'RE GOING TO SKLOUNCE SOME GONKS! A genuinely awesome, powerful experience--blasting chromed out murder hobos who lost their minds to the metal while slowing down time just enough to line up a 2077 double-barrel sounds as fun as it is. When I ran into the "you're approaching the end of the storyline. Please finish up any side missions before continuing," message, I almost crawled under my desk for a cry.

Cyberpunk 2077 — 10/10 | Chrome-Grade Excellence

Cyberpunk 2077 hits like a Sandevistan to the skull—fast, stylish, and impossibly smooth. Night City isn’t just a map; it’s a living, neon-soaked predator that dares you to keep up. Combat slaps, characters feel like emotional cyberware, and the story burrows straight into your neural socket.

Compact verdict:
A chrome-plated masterpiece that voids your warranty in the best way. 10/10.

One of my favorite games ever, It has a great story, great voice acting, compelling DLC, etc. I bought the game and beat it shortly after launch and even then with the performance issues that plagued the game at the time I found the game to be amazing. Absolute masterpiece.

Got this game LONG after the initial broken release and absolutely love it.
Story writing is cut above the rest of AAA open world RPG games and makes you feel like your choices actually matter. 
NPCs also acknowledge previous quests you've completed giving them some credibility as opposed to Skyrim's hard coded interactions.
Movement feels smooth and fluid (admittedly I did go for double jump & dash every playthrough XD) and the gun play is solid with a variety of playstyles made to support multiple playthroughs (on my 6th so far).

If you like open world RPG I highly recommend this game, though you will need a pretty beefy PC to get the most out of it.

[h1]Finally, Neuromancer - The Game[/h1]

[Table]
     [tr]
         [th] [b] Category [/b] [/th]
         [th] [b] Ranking 1-5 [/b] [/th]
         [th] [b] Summary [/b] [/th]
     [/tr]
     [tr]
         [td]Gameplay[/td]
         [td]3[/td]
         [td]The gameplay is fine for a first-person shooter. It is uninspiring and, based on your preferences, is either the run-of-the-mill cover-shooter or infiltration-style with basic sneak elements. Likely because Red is excellent at third-person combat, this did not come naturally to them. Considering that this is their first run at it, it is decent enough. [/td]
     [/tr]
     [tr]
         [td]Story[/td]
         [td]5[/td]
         [td]Whew. V and Jackie Welles, man … If you know you know. I rarely see Keanu Reeves as anything but Keanu Reeves, as if his characters are all literally just him, but this time it was all Johnny Silverhand. He rocker-boy’ed the ever-living cyberpsycho out of that character. Endings are all superb, and left my gut hollowed out. [/td]
     [/tr]
     [tr]
         [td]Interaction[/td]
         [td]3[/td]
         [td]Just about everything is interactable, which does wonders for the immersion. Not much more to say, though. It does not immerse you in the way for instance Kingdom Come: Deliverance would, but it is still great[/td]
     [/tr]
     [tr]
         [td]Visuals[/td]
         [td]5[/td]
         [td]Yeah, they’re amazing, and I even played it on a Steam Deck. I can’t even imagine how stunning this game would look on proper hardware – the OLED does wonders, though. [/td]
     [/tr]
     [tr]
         [td]World Design[/td]
         [td]3[/td]
         [td]I loved driving around in the game, as I could finally scratch that Bladerunner itch I have had for years. There are different biomes and areas in the game, but ultimately, they all have the same flavour to them. The Badlands are dusty, Night City is neon and grime, and that’s it. There’s nothing wrong with it, as I loved it myself, but there is a relentless one-ness to all of the world that almost defeats the immersion. It can be a lot. [/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
         [td]Music Score[/td]
         [td]2[/td]
         [td]I must rate this based on how much I have been humming the soundtrack post-playing, but I am loathe to admit I cannot remember a single track off of this game. I love the cinematic, swelling music, but this rarely comes out as there are plenty more scenes with heavy fighting pairing equally heavy music with it. [/td]
     [/tr]
  [tr]
         [td]Had-fun-ness[/td]
         [td]4[/td]
         [td]I was not bored for a second playing this game. It was a JOY from start to finish in terms of the story. Doing all of the cyberpsycho missions and all the other side-quests for smaller characters rarely felt like it was worth it, though. The “main” side-characters are brilliant, but otherwise the quests felt like a “meh”, after which I could move on to the next big thing. Still lots of fun. [/td]
     [/tr]
     [tr]
         [td]All in all[/td]
         [td]3.5 / 5[/td]
         [td] I rarely experience a game that so completely absorbs me into its world, and I do believe this is [i]Cyberpunk[/i]’s main strength. I cannot remember the last time the only thing I could think about was a game. It literally affected my job in that I called in sick just to finish it in one go – absolutely no regrets there. The story is simply one of the best campaigns I have ever had the joy of experiencing: gut-wrenching, funny, intriguing and compelling. Themes of transience, belonging to the world for a brief moment, and pondering what is left behind in the wake of one’s death. These are questions that affect us all, and for better or for worse, we must come to terms with our answer to them at some point. This game feels like an offering to do just that in a world that might actually be our own at some point. Gameplay-wise, the games does leave something to be desired. Still, I liked the means and nature of the traversal through Night City, the content of the quests, and even the somewhat janky combat. Johnny Silverhand and V are incredibly well-written characters, and I could finally live out my fantasy of living in a world as Rick Deckard or in the Night City of [i]Neuromancer[/i] [/td]
     [/tr]
[/table]

⭐ Cyberpunk 2077 – A Masterpiece Reborn (100% Achievements Completed)

After fully completing Cyberpunk 2077—and I mean 100% achievements on Steam, every last one—I can confidently say this game has evolved into something truly special. What started as a rough, ambitious dream has transformed into one of the most immersive and emotionally powerful RPG experiences I’ve ever played.

Night City isn’t just a backdrop; it’s a living, breathing beast. Every street corner feels handcrafted, every shard adds to the lore, and every gig has its own flavor. The world rewards exploration in a way few open-world games do.

The storytelling? Absolutely top-tier. V’s journey, whether played cool, chaotic, or compassionate, hits hard. The writing, the branching choices, and the weight of consequences make every decision feel meaningful. And after finishing Phantom Liberty, I genuinely felt like I’d lived through a cyberpunk thriller.

Gameplay-wise, the overhaul patches and 2.31 update turned the combat into a fluid blend of gunplay, hacking, and cyberware insanity. Maxing out builds and chasing achievements kept me hooked long after the main story.

And earning that “all achievements completed” badge was a satisfying ride—some were challenging, some were hilarious, and some made me explore corners of Night City I would've otherwise missed. But together, they proved how much depth and detail the game truly holds.

If anyone still wonders whether Cyberpunk 2077 is worth playing in 2025:
Yes. Absolutely. This is one of the best modern RPGs—rich, emotional, stylish, and unforgettable

This game is a perplexing mix of great story moments and awkward dialogue. A very satisfying game play loop and cookie cutter side missions. An incredible hand crafted world and immersion shattering bugs. 

It has come a long way from its disastrous launch with all of the game breaking bugs ironed out. I haven't experienced anything on the level of the T-Posing, game crashing, or random nudity that made headlines in the first months of this game's release but there's still an extreme lack of polish in many areas. The prime example is the driving. AI drivers will randomly stop in the middle of the street. Pedestrians will walk out in front of your car like a new hybrid of oblivious humans and suicidal deer. Any time you come to an intersection is a coin flip on whether you will pass through unharmed or be struck with a wanted level as you T Bone someone whose green light went straight to red as the game detected a player character approaching a stop light. Auto drive only compounds these issues as your car struggles to navigate the incredibly complex problem of a car being next to you when you need to make a left hand turn. I wish I could see my character's wanted level from the NCPD, as the amount of traffic violations and vehicular manslaughter that have been committed on the altar of trying to refill my drink while autopilot takes me on a two minute drive have turned me into the automotive equivalent of the night stalker. Truly this is a world where the forces of Big Sobriety have lost the war on drunk driving, as a DUI is far less dangerous than trusting your life to the hands of Tesla's Thalidomide baby. 

The story is the game's shining achievement. In true Cyberpunk fashion it is a tragedy written on chrome leaf paper. V races against the clock as an experimental new chip is rewiring their brain. And this macguffin comes with a jaded rockstar/terrorist in the skin of Keanu Reaves, who delivers a compelling performance as Johnny Silverhand. As you progress along the path of the world's first voluntary lobotomy, the supporting cast become entangled in your plight and vice versa. Unfortunately, while the side characters can be quite compelling during their missions, everyone you meet that isn't directly related to the main story drop off after finishing their quests. In most games this is expected but in Cyberpunk all of the side characters' lives are dramatically influenced by V (for better and worse) with most of them coming just shy of declaring their love for V as the person who brought them from the edge of their individual despairs to the turning point of getting their lives back on track. But once the last mission of their side plot is complete, you won't hear from the characters organically until the end of the game. I would suggest saving some of these missions for later in the game for a more cohesive story that doesn't abandon the best parts of the story in the second act.

While the characters are well written and a highlight of the story, the dialogue system leaves a lot to be desired. Anyone familiar with Bethesda games will recognize the dialogue tree, helpfully separated into blue options that add more detail and yellow options that will affect the conversation, but the style of dialogue system isn't the only genetics that the games share. Characters awkwardly walk to their stage positions before continuing conversations and speak with their hands/bodies in a way that would make disney animatronics embarrassed. Maybe it's a statement on the way cybernetics push humanity into a cold, robotic existence or maybe rigging is more complicated than the developers were given time for after multiple launch delays, who can say? But even if you can overlook the inorganic posing and positioning of characters in scripted dialogue scenes, it is much harder to ignore the game stuttering to load the next string of dialogue options once character's stop talking. You can almost hear the gears grinding like a 16 year old learning to drive stick as the characters sit in awkward silence until the game jolts awake and finally brings the dialogue menu back up so V can respond. The fact that so much of the gaming community were outraged by Fallout 4's dialogue wheel of "yes, sarcastic yes, more details, and no" but haven't mentioned Cyberpunk's wheel of "yes, yes but pay me, yes but in the tone of V's background, and no" is either the result of CD Projekt's otherwise well written story winning players over or the original release being such an unmitigated disaster that players have succumbed to the same logic as abuse victims rationalizing their partners constant gaslighting and emotional abuse by saying "well at least they don't hit me anymore." On a second play through the mask falls even further as it becomes clear that many of the dialogue options elicit a response that is generated from the following formula: [Player's Chosen Dialogue]=[Brief Acknowledgment of Chosen Dialogue] + [Statement the NPC will say regardless of Choice of Dialogue]. This is especially apparent if you select a different background in a new play through as NPCs pay lip service to the idea of addressing your unique perspective before moving on to what they would have said should you have just selected the "yes" option. These issues combine to dialogue that feels as stiff and inhuman as a David Lynch film but without the shield of auteur sensibilities to hide behind.

The gameplay loop is simple but extremely satisfying. It has the same bones as Far Cry 3/4 and Fallout 3/4. Go to a place, have an unexpected and often slightly absurd new variable added to the problem, kill everyone in sight and loot their corpses. But it's the way the game allows you to end the lives of your fellow man that scratches the homicidal itch in my lizard brain that keeps me coming back. My first V was a quick hacker that only entered rooms after melting someone's cyberware and exploding a nearby radio from the safety of a CCTV feed. And while the game starts you with fairly innocuous quick hacks like "reboot optics" or "overheat," eventually you unlock such war crimes as "Cyberpsychosis" or "Suicide." My second V is a close range shotgun/katana wielder with a military grade Sandevistan and Optical Camouflage allowing me to shotgun a room full of scavs and reach the other side before their grey matter does without raising an alarm. And each build has enough unique weapons to guarantee a unique overpowered build is always available. In that way it succeeds in the way Far Cry 3/4 did; with the first half of the game being spent leveling up to be an unstoppable killing machine and the second half of the game just being an unstoppable killing machine. It adds an incredible layer of satisfaction in picking a dialogue option that equates to "I will instantly kill you" and being able to immediately back that threat up by turning the person V is threatening into a pink mist before they can utter the first syllable of their witty comeback. 

Overall, the game is difficult to recommend. There is an amazing game here buried inside a considerably clunkier one. It's death by a thousand cuts, starting out with the naive optimism that the bug or awkward dialogue was a one off issue or just an unlucky glitch most people won't experience. But eventually that gives way to the understanding that these are larger problems stemming from the shaky foundation that game was built on. The knowledge that however you customize your V, there won't be enough character there for NPCs to react to. An understanding that for a game about leaving your mark on Night City and dying a legend, that the legend was rigged from the start; and for as often as the game comments on V's growing notoriety and status as one of Night City's most infamous edgerunners, you will always be overshadowed by the exploits of your drugged out imaginary friend. 

My dissonance is ludonarrative, and my immersion is ruined.

Truly one of the most remarkable games I have ever played. Dark Souls III is the culmination of everything great about the first two combined into a seamless and unforgettable gaming experience. Rediscovering the world, visiting old locations, and fighting new bosses made Dark Souls III feel like a journey that you can only live once. It is a challenging experience not for the faint of heart, but if you have played Dark Souls I, you are sure to love this game.

52.4 hours, every achievement unlocked, all DLC completed—and honestly, every minute was worth it. Dark Souls 3 was the second Souls game I played, and it delivered exactly what I wanted from the series. The boss fights were intense and memorable, the world design felt interconnected and atmospheric, and the combat struck a perfect balance between classic Souls weight and faster, more aggressive action.
Out of all the Souls and Souls-like games I’ve played so far, DS3 lands as my 3rd favorite, but that still puts it in incredible company. It’s polished, challenging in all the right ways, and consistently rewarding. If you enjoy difficult but fair combat, amazing DLC content, and that signature FromSoftware sense of progression, this game is absolutely worth diving into—especially if you’re the type who loves fully completing a game.

​👑 Dark Souls III: A Worthy End to a Trilogy ​Overall Score: 10/10 (Considering the Genre) ​Dark Souls III is not just a superb action RPG; it is a glorious and fitting conclusion to the trilogy that redefined challenge and storytelling in video games. ​🔥 Strengths (The Good) ​Flawless, Faster Combat: The combat, influenced by Bloodborne, is quicker and more aggressive, yet the core essence of the Souls series—focusing on patience, timing, and stamina management—is perfectly preserved. The addition of Weapon Arts adds immense variety to weapon movesets. ​Boss Design: Epic, highly challenging, and featuring compelling multi-phase mechanics. Many boss fights in this game are among the most memorable in the entire Souls series. The "Phase 2" moment in many of these encounters is pure adrenaline. ​Lore & Atmosphere: The world of Lothric is a masterful blend of grandeur and decay. The environments are visually stunning and, through the deep, hidden lore, perfectly convey the feeling of a world facing extinction. ​Exploration and Level Design: Though the world lacks the seamless interconnectedness of Dark Souls 1, each separate area is designed like an intricate labyrinth, full of shortcuts, secrets, and appealing optional locations. ​💀 Weaknesses (The Bad) ​Visual Repetition: Some areas and enemies feel overly similar to previous installments or even Bloodborne, slightly diminishing the sense of visual innovation. ​Relative Linearity: The structure of the game early on is a bit more linear than its predecessors, which might offer less freedom of exploration at the very beginning. ​✨ Conclusion ​Dark Souls III is an essential action RPG. If you are looking for a brutally hard but incredibly rewarding challenge, deep and ambiguous lore, and combat where every victory feels truly earned, this game is the best option. It might be a tough starting point for newcomers, but for veterans, it is the ultimate homage to the series. ​May the flames guide thee, Ashen One.

Dark Souls 3 is not my first souls like however it has become one of my favorites. The atmosphere created by the visuals, audio, and story for you as the main character are unique to the souls like genre. The gameplay is incredibly challenging for those that do not normally play, or are unfamiliar with souls like games. But it is worth all of the frustration and struggling to be able to claim and learn from this game and the rest of the series.

The story teaches you, the ashen one, to not dare go hollow in your pursuit of rekindling the first flame. The constant struggles of relentless fighting throughout the story create a sort of suffering that you as the player learn to persevere through. The most important lesson I have found in my journey wasn't patience, precision in rolling, or controlling my own anger. The most important lesson was the suffering from this game. After my first playthrough I realized that it's okay to find meaning in the constant torment and suffering of dying, but it's not okay to find purpose in it. Dark Souls teaches you as the player to constantly persevere for your own reasons. Suffering does not make you stronger on it's own, but the growth that follows does.

Creative Bankruptcy: The Game
They fixed and unfixed many of the issues with Dark Souls II.
They kept power stancing, because it obviously makes sense to include that. They also added weapons which were made specifically to be used with both hands, like the Sellsword Twinblades and the Drang Hammers. But obviously, the coolest one is the Farron Greatsword. Its name doesn't make much sense considering that it's a dagger and an actual sword, but hey, cool, regardless.
Which is why it's so dumb that they made the player character mainly right handed, just like in the first Dark Souls. For example, holding an axe in your left hand makes you block, and you can only do a heavy attack with it. Meanwhile, if you have a shield in your right hand, you start punching with it. In Dark Souls II, your character is ambidextrous, however, sometimes you deal less damage with the left hand.
As for the story, areas, and story, the game tries its hardest to emulate Dark Souls 1, from the main quest to the ending, the boss designs, and the levels.
Crystal Sage is just Pinwheel that's not too easy. Old Demon King is just Demon Firesage from DS1. Wolnir is basically Gravelord Nito, again, from DS1. Yhorm the Giant has to be defeated with the Stormruler, a weapon from Demon's Souls, used specifically to defeat the Storm King, a boss fight, that is actually really fun with a cool setting. Dragonslayer Armour is basically the Penetrator from Demon's Souls. Champion Gundyr could be a different version of Iudex Gundyr that the developers thought would be cool, but couldn't decide on which one to put in the game. Soul of Cinder is literally the the Burnt Ivory King from Dark Souls II's Crown of the Ivory King DLC. Same moveset, almost the same attacks. As for the DLCs, Halflight is, again, literally just the Old Monk from Demon's Souls with the same invasion gimmick (which is quite cool). Then Slave Knight Gael, who is a red Artorias.
Areas: Firelink Shrine, same name and function as DS1, but a different setting. I like this version more. Farron Keep => Blighttown. Catacombs of Carthus => Catacombs from DS1. Irithyll + Anor Londo => Anor Londo. Grand Archives => The Duke's Archives. Untended Graves is funny because there's an extremely difficult out of bounds glitch where you can climb up backwards from Cemetery of Ash to reach the illusory wall to reach Untended Graves, but I think you'd get stuck as you probably can't enter the fog wall from the other side (at least in DS2 you couldn't do that), but if you drop back down you'd arrive in Untended Graves. Archdragon Peak is great, especially the Nameless King, I'd say he's my favourite boss. Kiln of the First Flame, same name as in DS1. Painted World of Ariandel => Painted World from DS1. So the pattern here is to evoke an emotion from the better designed game, DS1, by copying everything they can, but making them much smaller, and making them look just as terrible as they were in DS1, because of technical limitations.
More about the bosses (and the enemies), oh dear. It seems like they just tried to make them difficult for the sake of it. They all aggressively ambush you in hordes, as if this was Left 4 Dead or something. Two perfect examples of creative bankruptcy are the Deacons of the Deep and High Lord Wolnir. The deacons are just enemies spawning infinitely without giving you any room for movement at all, and the first stage of the fight is just some collective soul that you can only deal an exact amount of damage to. Then the second stage which is just a crowd crush simulator. Then there's Wolnir, a hard to reach boss with incredibly high defence, whose weakness are his bracelets. He may or may not spawn skeletons just to make things harder for you. Then there's the mist around him, which can make reaching the bracelet on his right hand challenging, because it pretty much instantly kills you. If he starts moving upwards, you're basically dead. Dragonslayer Armour can be pretty difficult by itself, especially because you're fighting on a bridge, and then for some reason the level designers also decided to put some monster in the sky to shoot at you during the second phase. Why? The rest are fine, I guess. It'd be silly to complain about attacks with weird timing. They're annoying, but they're fine.
Magic works the same way as it did in Demon's Souls, meaning you have a mana bar, that you can refill with items (here, mainly the Ashen Estus Flask). I like this one more than the system in DS1 and 2.
As for armour, this is the only game in the series where you can't upgrade armour. Which is sad for cosplay builds, as now you have to choose between high defence or fashion. Meh.
Weapon infusion also works the same way as it does in DS2, which I'm quite fond of.
As for PvP, there aren't really any OP builds like in DS1, but it's still just as unforgiving. Parrying is more difficult (with regular shields?) and rolling i-frames are longer. Parrying would be fine with latency, but dodging with server delay just makes fighting a nightmare. At least you can FINALLY invade without being embered/in human form. Thank GOD.
Overall, this game is a bit of a disappointment for me.

FromSoftware: Fix DSIII stuttering 

Frame drops were not a problem during my first playthrough in 2018. I have since upgraded to a 9800X3D. After numerous patches, performance declined. How? That makes no sense

I’ve tried to:
-Enable VSYNC/Shader Cache - unlimited in Nvidea control panel
-Set affinity in Task Manager (uncheck CPU 0; I also followed a suggestion to disable all even-numbered CPU cores, to no avail).
-Disable “Device Association Root Emulator” under “Devices By Connection” in Device Manager
-Disconnect bluetooth devices, plug in directly via USB
-Set graphics settings to low/medium/high
-Update drivers 
-Set Screen Mode to Windowed
-Run DarkSoulsIII.exe in Windows 8 Compatibility Mode
-Rollback on older patch
-Disable/stop Windows Management Instrumentation
-Disc usage under 50% (storage capacity at ~30% usage)
-Install Proper PC Experience from Nexus

FPS [i]still[/i] drops to 27 or 57 - usually in double intervals, seemingly at random (even while leveling up character, in menus or mid battle) 

CPU never exceeds 50°c or 20% utilization
This is the [i]only[/i] title i experience this sort of issue w/. How FromSoftware managed to make DSIII perform [i]worse[/i] over time is beyond me. No stuttering in Sekiro or Elden Ring so they clearly have [i]some[/i] idea how to program. This specific performance bug wasn’t a problem 6 years ago.. Now, there are numerous crash reports & similar performance related posts sited online 2023+

EDIT: I found Nvidia driver 537.58, wired peripherals, disconnect bluetooth devices to reduce stutters

[u]Specs[/u]
9800X3D
4070 
32GB DDR5 Memory
Samsung Evo 870 2TB SSD
Windows 11 

Side Note: Port Bloodborne. Hop off Sony’s wang - sales would do numbers

After playing more than 100 hours, it became clear to me why this game has rightfully EARNED its Negative review. First of all, The "difficulty" is Artificial and in no way shape or form skill-based. All it did was slap Higher HP bars on enemies and programmed them to do higher damage values to the PC.

That's it! I'm serious! Want proof? Look up the mod on nexus "Easy Souls" and by just understanding how it works, you'll get what I mean.

Secondly, this game is HIGHLY Telegraphed. By which I mean that there's no way for you to "fix" any prompt or input you make unless the action resolves; You press to attack> You lift your arm to complete the animation and that's it. Same as the enemy!

You can't stop it
You can't dodge midway
You're FORCED to bait out the enemy's animation to finish as well

Some even string together a 9-attack combo and they can't really let you do anything. Not a single cast or a move. And they call THAT difficulty...

It's almost as if FROM doesn't know some of us are nimble minded enough to actually dodge danger by the millisecond. OR they claim this game is difficult by rigging it with stringent coding.

Anyway, Latter is what turned the game Garbage and thus earns its bad review.

If you still insist on playing this, I urge you to download either Easy Souls or Honest Merchant. Thank God that if not for the latter one, I'd have wasted my money on this game.

I came to Dead Cells as a long-time fan of metroidvanias, and it did not disappoint. Usually, I'm not a fan of heavy metaprogression mechanics, but the core gameplay here is so engaging that it did not matter to me.

This is hands-down the "flowiest" action roguelite. The movement is precise, and the combat is responsive and dynamic. Even more, there is variety in regions, enemies, items, and secrets to find. This makes it my favorite Action roguelite (so far).
Fantastic game that holds up even after many hours of play.

Once you get going, its a non-stop intense action packed platformer with an incredible skill ceiling. Very satisfying to conquer, and its DLC have been incredible so far, especially for the price.

It become satisfying after several runs when you start feel the game mechanics and start understand how it works. Well fast-paced, but doesn't punish you too much for playing slow. I would say your gameplay actually accelerates at some point.

On a Metroidvanias kick I tested out Dead Cells by Motion Twin. A very Castlevania in theme type, with similar feel in action and gameplay, 2-d rogue like procedural slash fest, sounded good and was overwhelmingly positive in reviews on Steam so I went in. You play some type of goo that animates a dead body and returning from death is a thing, a thing I was very used to from playing Hades, and yes dying is quite common. Art style wasn't really my cup of tea but it IS creative and it wasn't the pixelation I didn't enjoy it was something about the control scheme... something felt a little jank to me... I cant say I could quite put my thumb on it (no pun intended), but it didn't take long for me to realize I wasn't going to enjoy this one. I'm clearly outside the box on this one as it was so well received, but to be fair I was always MUCH more of a Metroid over Castlevania player anyways. Ill continue on my path, not regretting a stop over at Dead Cells, but not regretting moving on either.

Dead Cells is fun, but I don't understand the hype. Base game is extremely bare bones. There is a whooping total of 4 bosses, 2 of which you will see every run. There are no random powerups which would introduce any kind of fun rng or broken synergies. Instead the only thing that's somewhat random are the weapons and 90% of them play nearly the same. This makes it so each run feels exactly the same as the previous run. It also makes shops kinda useless and not exciting. In Hades each shop brings excitement, because you know that you will get something good. Meanwhile here shops will at best slightly improve your weapons stat-wise.

I'm sure the game gets at least slightly more varied with the DLCs, but that should be the base experience. Even less known roguelikes like Skul provide more variety.

Don't get me wrong, the game is fun. Bosses are well designed and combat is addictive. The semi metroidvania aspect is an interesting choice and I had fun for a few runs, but if a roguelike gets stale after 5 runs then maybe it shouldn't have been a roguelike. 

[h1] Steam Deck [/h1]
Dead Cells runs very well on deck. Keeps stable 60fps, fans are quiet and battery lasts long. In short, it's one of the perfect Steam Deck games.

From a general perspective it's actually a good game, but really wasn't for me. The gameplay felt too arcade-like and it's most likely my fault for not knowing that when I bought the game. Also the multiple DLCs aren't my thing, especially when the game still shows you the doors to it but is like "Oh no you have to buy this btw"

Masterful game. It's simple enough to not require a tutorial, but the level design provides enough difficulty and depth for it to feel whole. There is no randomness to blame, no enemy to insult, only you, your actions, and the game.

The "Psychological Horror" tag feels at home. This game will feel like torture until you become numb to it all. You will go from anger, to boiling rage, then depression, followed by apathy, and eventually, happiness.

What awaits you once you reach the Babe as spoken of in legend? The end of your journey, hardly something from which one can derive enjoyement. It will make you feel hollow, as though the game had plucked one of your organs and won't give it back, as though a part of you had left forever.

The true reward lies in the mindset. Your "MOTHERFUCKER!!" turning into a simple "Welp.", the tightening of your grip on the controller becoming weaker and weaker, the smirk that replaces the deadpan expression you had upon hearing "Schlap!". It's the embrace of failure as a just another step taken to get through this pilgrimage, with "forwards" and "backwards" melding together, bearing the name "towards".

You can only bet on yourself in this game. Win, and you will walk away from the experience with a tangible reward. Lose, and will leave 13€ poorer than you were prior.

The odds are not just in your favor. They are in your hands. Do as you will.

So the main difference between this and other "rage" games is that when you fail it's your own fault and not because of janky controls.

Everything is learnable and you understand what went wrong unlike foddy games.

In a lot of ways, this is similar to Getting Over It with Bennett Foddy. However, Jump King fixes many of the core flaws of GOI, leading to a far more enjoyable experience overall.

- The controls are perfectly consistent. If you stand on the same part of a platform and make the same button inputs, your character will always perform the same action, 100% of the time. This is far, far better than the shit show that is GOI, where performing the same action can give vastly different results. It also means that once you learn what you need to do to beat an area, it's fairly easy to recreate what you did and get back to where you were.

- There are no physics bugs. You don't need to worry about your sledgehammer getting stuck in a wall, or being thrown across the map at high speeds without meaning to.

- The map design isn't deliberately cruel. In fact, I'd argue the design is quite generous. In most cases, a failed jump will just knock you back to whatever platform you jumped from, letting you try again immediately. In other cases, there are additional platforms added specifically to stop you falling too far. Sure, if you fail consistently or in a big way then you'll lose progress, but it's often not too much. Again, this is a lot better than GOI where most areas are designed with the sole intent of sending you back to the start of the game and stripping you of as much progress as possible.

- You don't have to listen to Foddy's pseudo-intellectual comments about how failure and overcoming challenges helps you grow as a person. Shockingly, making a game specifically to piss people off and waste their time doesn't make for a great learning experience, and it doesn't make you a revolutionary philosopher. Jump King has an old man at the bottom who makes small jokes about the lore of the game, occasionally mocks you, and sometimes gives words of encouragement. It's funny, fits the game, and once you get past the starting area you don't even need to deal with it anymore.

- It's half the price. Not a gameplay change, but still a bonus.

Do you remember playing your first platformer as a kid? There was a disconnect between what you wanted to do and what your character was doing, every step was a small victory, a challenging jump would make your heart race. You would fall, fall, and fall again until eventually, like an angel, your dad or your older sibling or your friend's dad or your friend's older sibling would beat it on their first attempt—and all of that, just the first level. And finally, hours, days, or even years later, you would beat it yourself. 

For me, that game was[i] Scooby Doo! Who's Watching Who [/i]on the Nintendo DS. Now if I was to go back and replay SDWWW I would probably slam through the game and beat it in a couple hours. I wouldn't even think twice about the first stage. I have become the older sibling, the dad, the angel. 

But isn't that a little sad? Don't you miss that adrenaline-dopamine cocktail coursing through your little veins you used to know so well? When every corner you turned you would pray for a checkpoint, only to be met with—in absolute horror—a section that looked meticulously designed to ruin your day?

Jump King manages to gamify the experience of improvement. It feels like when you first fell in love with going to the gym. Or when you picked up your favorite instrument for the the first time. Or like you're five years old again, playing Scooby Doo on the sticker-laden, family DS. Only it doesn't take years to build your fine motor skills, it takes a few hours.

TLDR: if you're tired of being good at platformers, and want to be bad at them again, play Jump King.

You will most likely hear about this game from friends challenging each other to try and beat it, or some internet personality raging at its challenging jumps and punishing level design, and assume that its another cheap RAGE GAME, made to only be played for internet clout. I'm here to tell you that it is so much more.

The game's controls are simple, you can only jump left, right or straight up, as well as walk left and right. You must use these tools to get from screen to screen to the top of the world and find yourself a smokin' hot babe. As soon as you start to play, you will realise just how this game can go from simple to nail-bitingly hard. 

Counter to all modern platformers, there is no air control, and jumps are determined by holding the button down to charge its power, increasing its range and velocity. once you have leapt into the air, you are at the game's mercy, and your punishment for a poor jump can send you back multiple screens worth of progress if you aren't careful. However, I never found the challenges to be unfair. Towards the second half they start adding some environmental hazards, from strong winds that push and pull to icy slopes that will shoot you right back down from whence you came, and these hazards are always introduced in a fairly easy to grasp manner, before pushing it to its limits by the end, never lasting longer than about 5 screens. 

Where Jump King stands tall (or rather, jumps high) above other contemporary games of unforgiving challenge is, well, it is forgiving. there are no checkpoints to save your progress, but there's also no lives, and no hazards that instantly kill you to send you back to the beginning or enemies to get in your way. The controls are strange by modern standards, but not poorly made, they feel buttery smooth to control, and you only get more adept at them the longer you play. the only one to blame for your mistakes is yourself, and falling down the tower has but one recourse; climb back up.

Combine this with its beautiful art and sound design, and this game is closer to a gentle, almost ethereal learning experience. Jump King will teach you patience, humility, and above all an enjoyment of the little things. You just landed a tough jump and made it further than ever, and you deserve to feel good about it. Conversely, there's nothing to worry about by falling. You made it up there once before, you can certainly do it again.

As of this review, I've only beaten the Main Story. That's right, there were two extra sets of levels added after release, much harder than the main scenario, as well as a huge plethora of fan-made content through the workshop, from levels to new looks for your little character. I don't think I can recommend this game enough for people looking to challenge themselves as well as a gentle game for people like me, who love to have something to play while they listen to video essays online. 

Please buy this game.

Jump King is an awfully lazy display of game design and artificially inflated with difficulty. This game only gets the credit it deserves by being ridiculously hard by removing core functions within platforming. If it wasn't it just comes across as a lazy platformer game. The game obviously makes you angry, but after a point you just become apathetic to the game and just bored. The game constantly deprives of you of content and has you constantly retry levels (that you've completed hundreds if not thousands of times).

If this wasn't the case then Nexile (the developers) would actually try to make another game but have instead shilled more Jump King content for the past 5 years. Creating artificial difficulty bottlenecks doesn't create good design nor is a good business decision to keep repackaging. Best of luck to them otherwise.

tl;dr the main game only gets good at the end

[h3]the bad part[/h3]

before [spoiler]the chapel[/spoiler] the game is just boring, not even frustrating
the difficulty balance is non existent and the level design is really bs (random chokepoints in an otherwise easy area, forcing you to do the same thing over and over because the levels are designed to make you fall as low as possible, the game punishing you just for not knowing what to do the first time so you don't even get the satisfaction of getting somewhere new)

[h3]the good part[/h3]

after you get to [spoiler]the chapel[/spoiler] the game is actually really fun
the difficulty is actually balanced, you don't get singular near-frame perfect jumps after 5 free screens, you actually have a chance to save your fall, and even if you don't the game doesn't waste your time by making you fall all the way down, it's a completely different experience

[h3]the dlc[/h3]

This game is an exercise on patience, stress and muscle memory. Its all about learning the timings for jumps and the distances. Committing them to memory and persevering when you fall. Then jumping to the top of a fiendish and merciless jump puzzle tower. You will fall a lot. I fell a lot. This game has the worst jumping mechanic I've ever had the displeasure of enduring.

I can see the appeal and I understand the sense of accomplishment when you progress. But its just not for me, I feel my rage boiling up inside of me every time I fall. And by Odins majestic beard you will fall a lot and so so so far. You can undo tons of stress inducing hard work with a moments mistake or worse a random stutter in the game. It is crushing to see your little helmeted man plummet through several screens worth of climbing. Then you climb back up and fall anew.

I fancy myself as rather good at platforming games and jump puzzles, but this jumping endurance trial on my patience is too much. I like a good challenge but I'm not a masochist and I cant submit myself to anymore punishment. I did not enjoy my time with this. I know plenty of people will, but not this individual.

Destiny 2 is basically an abusive relationship where the abuse is inconsistent balancing and the apology gift is a cool dungeon. It’s a hate–hate relationship with tiny love sprinkles thrown on top just often enough to keep me hooked. I don’t trust Bungie, but I also refuse to leave. Guardians don’t quit. We just complain loudly and keep grinding.

Destiny as a whole has been my favorite game series of all time.  Yes it has had it's ups and downs but it truly is one of a kind and although there are other games out there that try to mirror the success of destiny, none have been able to replicate what Bungie has created.  I can only hope that this game can pick up momentum again and be around for many more years to come.
