Say what you will but Destiny 2 does what hardly any other games can do. PvP weapon gameplay controller/mouse feels amazing. No other games for me has this feel. The exotics, the weapons, trials of osiris, Xur, is all so special. They care more for the PvE obviously and the raids are epic. The game is over 6 years old and now people are saying it sucks. They have done a lot of good things and bad things. But at the end of the day for me....this game is home. Star Wars crossover coming next is freaking sweet. People hating just to hate. Pick this up for free and enjoy the content. If you fall in love with the game support it and buy the expansions

There is probably too much to really write in what would actually be an interesting and informative review for D2, but the short of it is that the game is currently going through one of its worst states of being yet i still can't find anything on the market place that can be enjoyed anywhere near as much as the fun i've had in this game. 

If you're completely new it has a difficult learning curve that isn't helped too much by the developers. It is recommened that you join a friend who has experience to guide you early. It's also currently trying to keep alive both new and old systems of the game to appeal to both veteran and new players alike but neither playerbase are feeling satisfied.

Microtransactions (in the form of cosmetics) are honestly very fair in this game. You can absolutely earn yourself a lot of Brightdust from casually playing the game consistently, but playing as a free player is not the recommended experience, You will be locked out of certain activities, loot, and full world experiences due to paywalls however the DLC regularly goes on sale for around 50% off and at that price is worth it, especially if you dabble in end game activities like raids and dungeons (some dungeons are on a seperate paywall that requires silver and are only purchased in game). I would say the pay-to-win experience is limited but it is there in the form of the paid season pass tree. Previously it minimally impactful the game before Edge of Fate. I personally don't consider owning additional expansion pay-to-win (barring New Land Beyond and its ties to Year of Prophecy)

I still recommend this game to everyone because the Raids and Dungeons blind is some of the best gaming experiences out (3 raids and 1 dungeon are free). The problems are glaring and are hard to ignore but the people i've met in and out of the server and the experiences shared can't be match anywhere.

Destiny 2 is more than just a game—it’s a living universe. Every sunrise on a distant planet feels like poetry painted across the stars, every battle a symphony of light and shadow. The gunplay is crisp and satisfying, the worlds are breathtakingly crafted, and the soundtrack carries you through triumphs and heartbreak alike. Whether you’re standing shoulder to shoulder with friends against impossible odds or wandering alone through forgotten ruins, Destiny 2 makes you feel like a legend in the making. It’s not just about loot or levels—it’s about stories etched into the cosmos, and the unforgettable memories forged along the way.
Good game but has absolutely turned into a PAY TO PLAY game which is unfortunate... (was not compensated for this review)

Massive mistake don't play this shit.

Reason for thumbs up (conditional):

This is a free to TRY game, not a free to PLAY game. You are locked out of roughly 85% of the content if you dont spend money. However, I was able to grab the legacy collection bundle for 90% off (~$8 and change) about a year ago and at that price it is definitely worth it. The graphics are good, sound and music are good and the moment to moment gameplay is fun. I got a couple hundred hours of enjoyment out of it before I stopped playing. You can make this game as sweaty or as casual as you want to make it. In conclusion, if you can get the legacy bundle on the super cheap (epic store has this bundle listed for $11 right now) it is worth it. However....

Reasons for thumbs down:

DO NOT PAY FULL PRICE FOR ANY DESTINY 2 CONTENT. Bungie is arguably one of the worst developers on the planet and these days there's a long list of terrible gaming companies and it takes effort to be at the top of that list. They are most known for:
1) Deleting paid content from customers. They call it "sunsetting", most call it theft and false advertising. 
2) Plagiarism multiple times. Most recently for marathon art and a huge settlement on "sunsetted" content.
3) Ridiculous corporate greed with predatory MTs, predatory in game currency structures and pay to win bs.
4) In game advertisements and pay walled content.

Negatives for the actual game include the most disorganized "story", if you can even call it that anymore, I have ever seen as the first chapters of said story were deleted from existence with the whole sunsetting robbery. They literally have a timeline section in the game, that is buried in menus, to explain the actual sequence of events. 99% of players will not see this and play the different campaigns out of order so none of it makes sense. I thought I was doing it in the right order and I very much did not. The new player experience has to be one of the worst in gaming. Tutorial pop ups at every turn that explain how to shoot your gun, that never go away and will still pop up hundreds of hours into the game but no detail what so ever about incredibly important in game systems like weapon and gear moding. It contains what has to be the worst "journal/quest list" in gaming. There will be times where you are completely confused about what the game wants you to experience. Sometimes you will even know what you want to experience and have absolutely no clue how to access it. At times it feels like a menu simulator and the in game group finder is a disaster to the point were the community has all resolved to using 3rd party apps for it.

So, the thumbs up is conditional. If you can get most of the content for under $15 total, get it and enjoy it. Its fun. If you cant get a deal, try out the free nibble of a game until you get irritated with all the pay walls and ads and be done with it. Rob them like they robbed their customers. Hit it and quit it for free.

After thousands of hours and thousands more on console, I can tell you this is the best first person shooter ever made. The gameplay is so snappy and polished unliked any other game made. The loot and builds and guns are just so good. Then the raids, man the raids. Getting together with a team of 6 people to beat a very challenging mechanics and combat raid that takes 6-10 hours to beat to finally get the best guns in the game, the best experience out of any game I have ever played. Truly, special. 

That being said, Destiny 2 is dead. That is why I gave it up. I literally built a $4K gaming PC just to play Destiny 2. It kills to me to say it but it is dead. Management decided to dwindle away their money and waste it on random projects and CEO car salaries instead of investing into developing Destiny 3. Then the bugs, man oh man the bugs. The biggest one by far was "WE DO NOT WEIGHT ANY WEAPON DROPS. IT IS PURE RNG, WE PROMISE". 6 years later, a scientist discovers with a math formula that the weapon drops are actually weighted and have been for YEARS. That is right, for YEARS people were grinding for thousands of hours and often times the drop they were trying to get was bugged at a 0.00000001% of dropping. Bungie FINALLY admits the math is correct from this scientist and their was a bug messing up the drops for the last 6 years. Oops. 

I know first hand, I took a week off of work trying to get an adept palendrome with Rampage Outlaw and spent over 204 grandmaster completions with a buddy and NEITHER of us got a single drop. We literally played 10 hours a day for 6 days straight and not one drop. I knew something was wrong with RNG but people just told me "stop crying, it is RNG". Turns out, it actually was a HUGE bug in the RNG that wasted all my time. Haha

However, Sony just paid 3 BILLION dollars for Bungie, they aren't just going to let Destiny die for good. They want to make their money back. They will put D2 on life support and force bungie to develop D3 which will take 3-6 years. Then one day they will come back with D3 to recapture all fans and new ones and that will be the day I jump back in. But until then, it is done. I realized it one day when I was trying to do the newest raid, I waited for hours and couldn't find a team of 6 people to run it. Then it dawned on me that the game was actually dying. The numbers don't lie, people like me have thrown in the towel. 

RIP the GOAT D2.

Beautiful, awe inspiring, and soul crushing. A magnum opus the likes of which we'll never see again. The beauty dwells in hope in the face of despair, in the imagined world that reaches so far beyond the melancholy of Revachol. We see so little of Disco Elysium's world, and it left me with a yearning for a place that I never knew. Discover what there is to live for in a shrinking world scarred by failure and defeat. Play the anthem of a future that will never come. Hurt, long, and dance to disco music.

The message exists to be burned.

/Disco Elysium – 4 Hours In and I Already Feel Smarter Than I Actually Am/

Only four hours into Disco Elysium and I’m convinced this game is secretly an IQ test… and I’m failing beautifully.
This is the most intellectual detective experience I’ve ever had where half the time I’m solving a murder, and the other half I’m arguing with my own brain about philosophy, communism, and whether or not I should apologize to a mailbox. Every dialogue choice feels like a college exam written by a drunk poet.
The writing is insanely good — like reading a brilliant novel, except the novel occasionally tells you you’re a disgrace and then gives you +1 XP for admitting it.
I have no idea what I’m doing, but I’m fascinated, entertained, and feeling weirdly introspective about my life choices.
If the rest of the game is anything like the first 4 hours, then I’m ready to become the most confused genius detective Revachol has ever seen.

10/10 would debate my own thoughts again.

Disco Elysium is a highly ambitious RPG celebrated for its deep narrative and complex writing. However, its immense focus on dialogue, internal monologue, and philosophical exploration means it is not a game for every player. For those seeking traditional gameplay loops or faster progression, the experience can feel incredibly slow, tedious, and overly dense. While critically acclaimed, its heavy, text-based nature makes it a difficult and lengthy commitment for players who prefer action or lighter fare.

Well... What to make of this game?

It starts of very slow. Frustratingly slow. Then it got rolling a little bit, and I wanted to get through it and know how the story finishes....  I can't ever remember looking up how long a game takes to finish... Because I just wanted it to be over.

Then by the end of it. Being more familiar with all the mechanics (Getting time to advance) I was even contemplating a second play through.
BUT then... Just as the referendum was about to start... My game freezes. (The coppernado is back)  And I can't advance even after looking up solutions on the web. The biggest anti-climax in my gaming life.

So after 50 hours it leaves a bitter taste in my mouth.
Any tips to resolve the freeze are welcome though. I really want to get to the end.
Cool aesthetic, kinda cool rpg elements but BORING overall

I gave this game so many tries because I truly do love the premise of it. But holy moly I've never read so much text in bulk before and it turns the game in a snooze-fest. I love RPGS, I adore books and reading as a whole but for me this game didn't stick the landing. 

If you're capable of reading huge swathes of paragraphs, alongside a well crafted game, then you should definitely play this. I'm not exaggerating when I say that there's a METRIC TON of text.

I'd say it's very close to graphomania. It's hard to remember the last time I skipped so much dialogue in an RPG. Walls and bastions of text unrelated to anything other than the author's desire to create "art." If you enjoy immersing yourself in a wealth of fictional pseudo-knowledge, this game is for you.

Its a good game coming from one of the best developer in the market.

That until I learn what happened to ZA/UM and their original Devs. Holy wowza, to think greed could be this devastating on such a beloved game.

DO NOT PURCHASE

Incredible art direction, strong writing, great music, interesting concepts, a compelling world, and unbelievably boring gameplay and dialogue. I won't lie, my brain's been melted by the internet, so I could see someone else getting a lot out of this. A great deal of love and talent went into it, it really shows. I generally go for pretentious or conceptual stuff, and I can have a lot of patience if the story can hold my attention. But the characters in this game do not behave like people, and as funny or as interesting as that can be, I'd rather have some kind of emotional core to keep me engaged. It's too impersonal and cold, and the rest of the game is incredibly slow. Still though, I think if you don't demand as much moment-to-moment stimulation you could vibe with it. Not for me though. Also, the communism stuff feels incredibly forced in the beginning. I hate the U.S. healthcare system as much as the next guy, but the messaging feels quite desperate at its inception. It probably gets better later on, I wouldn't know.

The game's story is amazing, from what I've seen so far. The visuals are incredible. The voice acting is some of the best I've ever seen. The sound design and music is quote nice.

BUT

The gameplay is ass. It's just pure luck, especially for your first playthrough where you don't know which if the 25 skills are useful (many are VITAL and many are USELESS, at least early on, but the game doesn't tell you this). Often times a failed check will mean you are softlocked unless you want to have your character do truly awful things (like accept that racism is correct or violently bully a nice person). In real life, there would obviously be other options, including the option to just give up. But in the game, if you don't want to just give up and uninstall, failed checks can lead to you being forced to play a truly horrible person doing truly evil things. And that's not really a game I'm interested in playing nor one I can recommend.

I plan to revisit this game at some point, but I will be making EXTREMELY heavy use of a walkthough and save-scumming, as I feel this is the only way possible to play the game without being forced into taking actions that I wouldn't take even in a video game.

So yeah, if you're the sort that can still enjoy a game with heavy spoilers (cause you're going to need them) and who doesn't mind save-scumming or a person who just has no morals and is fine with being truly evil in a video game, there is a lot to like here. But I absolutely could not recommend this to anyone.

This is probably one of the best games of all time and you should experience it, nevertheless, the company, ZA/UM did the creative minds behind this project so dirty I cannot in good mind recomend you buy it. So sail the high seas or whatever, but treat yourself into the brainrot cleanser that is Disco Elysium

Divinity: Original Sin (Classic) is an amazing turn-based RPG with deep combat and clever writing. It’s even better with a friend — the co-op makes the experience unforgettable

The interactivity of the world keeps you coming back. It uses real world that is not at all common to games, at least not that I've played. The music is fantastic. The tone of the game is a little odd. Strange humor, dark quests and sometimes silly voice acting all at the same time can sometimes take you out a bit. The combat is layered, environments are interactive almost to the point of malleability. You can't change the lay of the land, but you can do a lot on the surface. 

The only gripe I really have is about the combat. Its incredibly long. There's no speed up button. At times I've sat through upwards of 8 enemy activations, and sometimes it takes a while between turns.

Recommended. There's a newer one which I hear has more VA & updated visuals, which you should probably grab instead. Unless you're on an older system.

[h1]Divinity: Original Sin (Classic) – 100% Completion Review[/h1]
[i]All achievements earned, every side quest completed, every secret, companion arc, and dungeon explored[/i]

[b]Divinity: Original Sin is where Larian found its voice, and it still holds up as one of the most reactive RPGs of its time.[/b]
It is rougher than the Enhanced Edition, but completing the Classic version reveals the blueprint for what would become the studio’s signature design philosophy.

You control two Source Hunters investigating a murder that spirals into a metaphysical crisis. The writing is quirky and full of charm, though tone can shift abruptly between absurdism and apocalypse. Dialogue choices, companion opinions, and even arguments between your two main characters can affect how quests unfold.

[b]Combat is the standout system.[/b]
Turn-based, tactical, and heavily reliant on environmental interaction. Fire spreads, poison explodes, and surfaces chain-react with elemental effects. It rewards experimentation, punishes poor positioning, and scales in difficulty quickly. A 100 percent run demands full mastery of the combat system, especially on higher difficulties.

Exploration is densely packed. Side quests are often multi-layered and easy to miss. Solving everything requires awareness, patience, and sometimes trial-and-error. Inventory management and UI are clunky, but the sense of discovery more than compensates.

[hr]

[b]Divinity: Original Sin (Classic) is imperfect but brilliant.[/b]
It is a slower, stranger game than its sequel, but seeing all of it through reveals just how ambitious it already was.
A great game, and a massive success for DND style RPG's. but at this point I recommend playing the Enhanced Edition.

Some RPGs make you feel godly by battling big bosses or making heady choices. In Divinity: Original Sin, it's about discovering how you affect the world. I realized the power at my disposal when I used my mage's rain spell to douse the flames afflicting a boat in the starting town of Cyseal. Piff, down went the flames and up went the cheering arms of the rescued sailors. No yellow question marks or blathering NPCs bid me do it; it simply seemed like a good idea at the time. And praise the sun, it was. That's the kind of rewarding experimentation that lies at the heart of Divinity: Original Sin. Discovering how its many complex pieces interact with each other and how its complex and amazing spell system can be used to your advantage is what keeps it going for the majority of its outstanding 60-ish hours of questing.

This game has some of the strangest and some of the funniest steam reviews I've seen but before I get into that, yes I'd recommend this title. Both my gf and myself have loved this game for years. We played and completed this years ago on 2 player and recently started to play our own solo campaigns. This game has literally hundreds of hours of fun to be had.

Important things to note is that:

* it's turn-based combat
* the devs poured humour throughout the game
* the tone of the game changes very often i.e. way more so than other titles of this genre

I mention this as it's easy to see gameplay or read reviews for this however these three things will kill the game for you or sell it to you.

Okay back to the steam reviews! I strongly suggest if you haven't played this before to ONLY check out the reviews that have 100 plus hours of game play on record because offft a LOT of peoples negative reviews is literally based on things that are figments of their imagination or nothing to do with the game.

So a lot of people down vote because, "this game is different from another game" i.e. Divinity 2. Surprising eh? two different games are... different.

Another thing people comment on is the games aesthetics and how they believe it's too "cartoony" > why did you buy it then? Surely you didn't just buy something without looking at it?

I've seen reviews that the writers has stated that they, "understand what I'm supposed to do" however clearly don't have a clue at all. Sometimes, it's because the thing they are trying to do literally doesn't exist in the game. One example of this is that a reviewer literally wanted to talk to a character that isn't in this game and moaned when they couldn't find him.

Lots of people saying it's too hard or they have no idea what they are supposed to do > pro tip, listen to dialogue and read text. Most of the time - if not all of the time - you are point blank told what to do and where to do it. There is player agency duh but progression is never hidden like these players allude/inform. I mean if someone was curious about something particular or was needing help, the fandom wiki is a fantastic resource > use it.

I've never read such delusions before.

Don't get me wrong everything is subjective when it comes to the question of "is this game good enough for you to recommend?" > I get that. I've just never seen so much dishonesty and/or irrelevance before in reviews. The same could be said about what I'm typing sure, that's cool. I'd disagree - obviously - as I'am typing this as a warning to new comers > skip reviews that have less than 100 hours of play time.

BTW the steam mods are awful for this game.

The first time I ever tried this game was on a bad day. Shortly after beginning I got a call from my brother, our mother was in the hospital and I should go see her. He failed to tell me it was a massive stroke and I only found out while standing at the foot of her bed that my mom wouldn't be waking up. That was last year, and every time since then I sat down to play this game I cried. Recently I was able to give it some attention and I'm not sure if this is a case of me being too jaded or if I just had a bad series of sessions because as it stands I do not like this game at all.

I tried to enjoy this game for 35 hours, and for 35 hours the game did not let me enjoy it. I have never in my life played a game that is so full of text that has no meaning whatsoever, from recipe books that have no reason for existing to journal entries that provide zero helpful hints or knowledge, Divinity: Original Sin feels like a game that was meant to be played by people who already know the story, have spent hours reading wiki pages and know what all of the traits/talents/skills do in order to exploit the game's systems.

Obviously there are a number of players out there that have no problem scouring various database pages looking for usable information but to me it feels wrong, like I paid to browse wiki instead of play a game. But if you try to just play the game using the information provided ingame, you'll get absolutely nowhere. Every time I felt like I was making progress the way forward was blocked arbitrarily by a horde of monsters that are far stronger than my entire party. Trying to fight them doesn't work, going around them doesn't work, baking them a cake doesn't work either. My only question is, why? Why give the illusion of an open world and player choice when the game is set up so that the only way to progress is to do it exactly how the developers designed anyway? All of the paths forward except for one are blocked from the very beginning.

All that really needs to be done to get ahead is to follow the main questline, which is easily done by following along on the wiki. You can't follow along ingame because it doesn't differentiate between quest types, so unless you know the quest names or have them written down sequentially you have no way of knowing how far along or if you've even made any real progress on the storyline. Usually the text provided with journal entries could help but Larian decided to be as vague as possible and refuses to mention anything beyond basic ideas, names of some places and people, but never how to go from point A to B. There are misleading directions to neighboring settlements, to the point where one is better off not trying to use the signs provided ingame at all. It is truly astounding to me that a company would develop something like this, where the markers that are meant to assist players are wrong and things like recipe lists contain only flavor text and nothing about ingredients. Adding to this the fact that sometimes you need to repeat conversations with the same NPC before your journal updates and we've got a big hot mess with vaguely written directions.

Combat is the main draw of the game so it does that right at least? Nah, not really. You can cast spells and skills whenever you want but outside of battle field effects do not trigger and there's no way to start a fight pre-emptively, enemies ALWAYS go first. Add to that the fact that field effects will sometimes simply not trigger no matter what, and due to an arbitrary wait time that forces attack animations to "finish" well after damage is actually calculated you could find yourself accidentally skipping turns with no confirmation popup. Also expect enemies to always vastly outnumber you, be higher level than your party, and have some way of completely neutralizing your damage output through self heals, buffs, spell immunities and the like. The enemies also have way more AP and can self buff, move, and attack multiple targets with different skills in one turn. When combat goes awry (and it will) there is an option to flee combat, which teleports the character and nobody else to a random waypoint, leaving the other party members to attempt a confusing retreat or die trying. The camera only travels one way when you do this by the way, have fun being disoriented and trying to figure out where your party is while the camera does the best job at not helping I've ever seen.

Speaking of cameras, it seems designed to get in the way of exploring and was often detrimental to my ability to see anything and negatively impacted my interactions with the world throughout my time playing. The only thing I could do to fix it was to zoom in as far as possible during fights so that the camera couldn't possibly impact the action. I ran into several fun glitches where I was unable to target enemies due to the camera angle, and in these scenarios clicking the enemy portrait to target didn't work. I ran into multiple situations in which my straight unobstructed line of sight to my target was somehow broken by an object nearby and the attack fizzled. It wouldn't be an issue but it happens more often than it doesn't, to the point where ranged attacks feel useless. The issue was mostly resolved when switching to melee but still pops up when using skills like Battering Ram unless they're used on a completely flat plane.

At this point I'm 35 hours in and I feel like I know too much about it now to stop playing. Maybe I'm missing something here, maybe it is a good game and I'm mistaking its charms for flaws. I'm going to try and finish it and I hope there's something in here that will make me change my mind but so far I've been trying to find the proper way to thread the needle and even with the help of multiple wikis and random anonymous individuals that have already solved this riddle I'm coming up with nothing but blanks.

Another hard to review game. I was playing this multiplayer with the SO and mostly the turns took forever and it ended up very boring by the end. When I was actively playing it was fun, I enjoyed the old school feel and exploring etc. If you already like old school RPGs then you'll probably like this, but if not do not spend your time on these, even with all of its awards.

This game design appears to go all-out for careful combat tactical planning and analysis of strategy. What elements work best against this enemy group? You can (and will) die quite often unless you plan for each combat carefully. Some players will find this rewarding, and that's fine. Unfortunately, I guess I don't fit into that demographic.

From what I can tell of the plot it features mystery solving and some fun quests, but in my first runthrough eventually the TPK rate was too high and I gave up. Oddly enough, the breaking point was at a completely insignificant combat with some zombie animals at a river. It had devolved into a pattern of the gameplay slowing to a crawl as I would stagger through a fight, having lost most of my consumables. I would be reduced to save scumming, not even to win a fight, but to actually win it without having to use up too many of my expendables, so I'd have a few left over for the next Incredibly Difficult Combat. 

A very minor quirk that could have been avoided with more lenient design: in a TBS game, it is not cool to have enemy sprites that move just as you're about to click on them, resulting in a misclick that messes up your entire combat command. At least make it Undo-able if you think the unit animations are so essential to the gamer experience. The only real feedback I've heard even from people who like the game is "yeah, just be careful when clicking". Meaning the designer messed up, fans are defending them, and it's now our responsibility to work around the designer's oversight.

Years later, they released an Enhanced Edition where the combat was simplified, and I was able to enjoy that much more, although I gave up on that too near the end, due to a "you cannot pass unless you have this many MacGuffins" gate challenge. I realized I'd have to open up a walkthrough and retrace all my steps to find a load of Soul Stones. 

I'm not going to do that.

I found I didn't care much about the plot and I wasn't really enjoying myself in the course of normal play anyway. I was really looking forward to finishing the game and crossing it off my list. And if that's the only pleasure I'm getting, I can do without having to watch a Youtube walkthrough just to experience it. I could have just watched a Youtube walkthrough of the whole game and saved myself the cost of purchase.

Verdict: If you enjoy analysis for its own sake, and a tough combat gives you feelings of achievement for figuring out the right way to survive it, this game is probably going to be enjoyable for you. If not, then consider the Enhanced Edition, which allows you to set the combat to Easy and to focus on the plot instead.

Near the end of the game, there will still be some puzzle type level design that may force you to consult a walkthrough, as they're quite obscure. There is also a "go back and collect all these hidden things in the previous levels" gate at the end which caused me to uninstall the game and just watch it on Youtube. You may want to consider doing the same if the rest of the game doesn't interest you, and save the cost of purchase.

This is one of those great games where you think, "Why didn't I play this sooner?". Divinity Original Sin 2 (DOS2) is the sequel to the already acclaimed DOS by Larian, who are also responsible for Baldur's Gate 3 and all Divinity games. And it felt so good to play this game right after playing the first one; everything here is better: more lore, more exploration, more skills, and more fun and challenging battles.

The lore is excellent and everything in the game fits together; it's incredible how even the side quests offer more depth. The graphics are better, more detailed; every piece of equipment is more beautiful than the last, and each item adapts to the race—the same helmet, for example, will have a different look for each character when equipped.

Exploration is rewarding. There's no grind here, but it will help you reach the recommended level for the tougher battles, besides opening up alternatives to solve the main quests.

The soundtrack is incredibly good. I recommend choosing Lohse as a companion for a wonderful surprise at the end of her personal quest.

In short, it was more than 200 hours well spent, and I'm rooting for Larian to release the third game with the improvements made in BG3.

Esse é daqueles jogos bons que pensamos, "por que não joguei isso antes?". Divinity Original Sin 2, é a sequência do já aclamado DOS da Larian, responsáveis também por Baldurs Gate 3 e todos os jogos Divinity. E como fez bem jogar esse jogo logo depois de jogar o primeiro, tudo aqui é melhor, mais lore, mais exploração, mais skills, batalhas mais divertidas e desafiadoras. A lore é excelente e tudo no jogo se encaixa, é incrível que até as quests secundárias se aprofundam mais. Os gráficos estão melhores, mais detalhados, cada equipamento é um mais bonito que o outro, e cada item se adapta a raça, o mesmo capacete por exemplo, vai ter um visual para cada personagem ao ser equipado. A exploração é recompensadora, não tem grind aqui, mas vai te fazer chegar no level recomendado para as batalhas mais difíceis, além de abrir alternativas para resolver as quests principais. A trilha sonora é absurda de boa, recomendo escolher a Lohse como companheira, para uma supresa maravilhosa no fim da quest pessoal dela. Enfim, mais de 200 hrs bem gasta e torcendo pra Larian lançar o terceiro jogo com as evoluções feitas no BG3.

As opposed to Baldur's Gate 3, this game has an original onset in its world and storytelling, it has Larian's quirky, goofy handwriting and fantasy style. All things that should not have been in Baldur's Gate 3. This is what Larian used to be before they made the mistake to tap into an old and outstanding franchise set in a dark fantasy realm. Better enjoy DOS2 than BG3. DOS2 includes a brilliant combat/skill-system and likeable characters and story. All this, because they were free when designing it and didn't have to try to include a foreign ruleset. I think as a native Larian game this is the pinnacle. Enjoy (Coming from someone who is not a Larian fan, but played all their games back in the days starting with Divine Divinity)

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is an amazing RPG and a perfect choice for fans of Baldur’s Gate 3. It’s clear that many ideas later seen in BG3 started here. The story is well written and the characters are interesting. The story is strong, but most of it is told through dialogue and text, so it doesn’t feel as cinematic as BG3. Combat is turn-based, fun, and challenging. The game makes great use of combining elements and surfaces, so there’s always something to experiment with. Most situations can be solved in different ways. The world is full of side quests, hidden spots, and interesting situations. Exploring is genuinely rewarding. The whole game was played in Honour mode in co-op, and it was an incredible experience. Encounters were great and every mistake could be fatal. This game is a great option that is worth playing. It does not have modern cutscenes, but the story is great, fun combat, and co-op mode more than make up for it. Highly recommended for anyone who enjoys BG3 or turn-based RPGs in general.

- Wonderful music
- High replayability
- Freedom in solving quests

[h2] Cons: [/h2]

This is the game that revitalized my love of gaming. This is a close-to-perfect western RPG. It has flaws but the rest of the game is so immaculate and unique I do not care. This game is fun and its even better with friends. It is impossible to not recommend this game to anyone who loves RPGs. It also completely revived the love for strategic turn based combat for the industry and thank god for that.

This is a game that if I meet a new friend, I always suggest we do a play through.

Overall it is a great game with a really deep and engaging story and gameplay. It does have a bit of a learning curve though; and some bits can get slightly tedious. But beyond that I do not regret buying this game and playing through it fully.

Ways you can build your character are diverse, and you can really go nuts- no holding back. The story is excellent, and when you’re done with the game you feel like you’ve had a great adventure. I recommend playing with an origin character, but that’s not necessary. If you’re coming from Baldur’s Gate 3, this game’s combat is a bit more “sticky.” Even so, I consider this game the better of the two. The narrator and music are 10/10.

I really hate this game.

I didn't want to hate it, I bought it when it was in beta, played it a lot. 

But I hate it.

The combat is awful (people teleport everywhere, positioning means NOTHING, anyone I talk to who likes it just used exploits to avoid it and lies to themselves about it, etc.). The story is really bad, especially if you have no personal ties to the divinity franchise before this installment (and even then you probably won't care for the truly stupid reveals, references, and twists). I like CRPGs. I've always liked CRPGs. Since I've played this game game came out I bought Larian's own BG3 as well, and I believe that to be one of the best games ever. In part, that's because it has 0 of the weaknesses found in this game.

I hope Larian's future endeavours look nothing like this game.

Also the floor effects are constant and miserable. That and the constant teleportation are maybe the worst mechanics implemented in any CRPG to date.

The first Original Sin game was excellent, one of my favorite rpgs. I cannot recommend DOS2 though. It has many flaws and lack of improvements that persist even in Baldurs Gate 3 in a certain extent. 

The combat looks like a chore, the split between physical and magical armor is very underwhelming since it restricts party compositions. Enemies on tactician have like x3 your defenses on same level and you need to kite them, split them, use surface barrels etc to slow them before engaging all at once. The AI is rubbish! They know they have better defense stats so they yolo rushing close to the party without considering their survivability. There are also constant issues with the plane of the game since it has issues with space. Meaning you can be on line of sight of an enemy with just a stair in front of you and game thinks something blocks your path. Same issues with verticality, you cannot aim enemies in many instances from above but they can from below.

Secondly the thieving and QOL hasn't been improved since the previous installment. Thieving is a chore to make money and the UI with so many items has not been improved with a universal inventory tab for all crafting materials. I will finish the game but is nowhere near as fun. 

Lastly half the characters are not likeable in particular Prince, Fane and Sebille are extremely arrogant.

Lemme focus on the good first :

-Graphics fully hold up
-Good voice acting
-Deep buildcrafting and lots of ways to approach encounters
-Large and packed open world

The bad :
-The world almost feels too big and not structured at all. You are not told where to go and can just go anywhere, which sounds good but doesnt work since areas arent scaled. You will have a tough but managable fight at one house, then you turn the corner and all of the sudden there are enemies that are 7 levels above you. There is just no rhyme or reason to what enemies you encounter and what magic gear they suddenly pull out of their bag and oneshot you with.

- The game barely saves. I get that I can save myself but I dont want to constantly have to worry and savescum because I dont know if the area or person infront of me will turn out to be a unbeatable shitshow or just some friendly trader.

- The amount of items and buffs and passives are too much. Giving us the option for a lot of build customasation is nice but if I need to make a spreadsheet to keep track of what trader sells what item with what buffs just to compare all of them for 2 hours to then decide to buy an item just for it to become useless because a random rat in a basement has a way better ring stashed for some reason is just dumb. It really just feels like loot-slop.

- Maybe I just missed them but the lack of quick travel points at key points of interest feels off

If you dont have a friend that can somewhat guide you as to where to go and what to look out for you are gonna suffer on your first blind playthrough. It's like the devs made this large and great world for you to explore but just threw darts with encounters linked to them at the map and placed them where they landed instead of giving you a natural progression where you level along the encounters you are presented with.
GAME DELETED MY SAVINGS WITHOUT ANY WARNING. 97 PLAYTIME GONE! SO NO DON'T BUY.

Possibly one of the most frustrating games I've ever played. I did a full two player run with a friend on Classic difficulty, start to finish. After having played through BG3 twice and enjoying it, I expected this game to feel similar. Do not make that mistake.
This game has major balancing issues, but not combat wise, but knowledge wise. If you go into this game knowing and looking up everything, you'll probably clear it all no problem, but going into this game blind will result in you getting your ass handed to you. Surprise encounters out the wazoo, enemy immunities that can screw up a majority of builds, the physical/magical split. Oh and some of the puzzles are absolutely idiotic. Then there's the add-ons, fantastic additions if you don't care about achievements, but if you do, you gotta keep em off, which really sucks given they're all QoL things that exist to make this boring game significantly less frustrating. Want to be able to see ghosts without clicking a button? Tough luck, no achievements for you. Want to replenish a resource that isn't hard to get but takes like 20 seconds at the end of each fight to replenish at the click of a button? No achievements allowed.
Also lets talk about build variety. And how it sucks. Do you want a hybrid magic/physical guy? Enjoy gimping yourself. Heck, do you want half mage half physical team members? Enjoy gimping your team. You pretty much have to go all in on one type by the end of the game because of the game's magic/physical armour health system. Oh and you better hope you get good levelled gear on level, or your armor will be too low and this game becomes CC hell, because almost every ability has an unavoidable CC once your armor is gone.
Also by the end of the game, you better have at least 5 points in polymorph if you want to do anything, cause if you don't, good luck with your builds.
Also civil skills are stupid. Maybe if you got more points it wouldn't be as dumb, but lockpicking eats lockpicks success or failure, same with identifying, so you better have a mask of the shapeshifter or an undead in the party if you don't want to deal with that crap.
Finally, ignoring balancing issues, enemies regularly jumping out of nowhere to fight you, the fact that the game has levelled randomized loot, the weirdly rushed ending to many story arcs and the fact that the game tells you nothing, the game is broken. Numerous times, dialogues that were supposed to happen didn't, things that didn't seem like they were supposed to happen did happen, and my friend and I literally skipped the final boss because the game bugged out, and we just... didn't fight it.
All in all, this is probably one of the most frustrating games I have ever played, that punishes you with disabling achievements for trying to make the game not even easier, but a smoother experience. Also you're locked into your companions for the whole game, so you better like em once you pick em. Honestly, just play BG3 again, that game despite having some similar issues is a million times better, and doesn't have that stupid magic/physical armor mechanic.

While it might be a "me" issue, the random, near endless loading times make this game a chore to play. One time out of 10 it will load quickly and nicely, the rest of the time it seems to just end up blocked, or taking longer than 10 minutes. And even with the advice of stopping cloud saves, or trying a new game the issue persists. 
I'd review the rest of the game, but so far I have spent more time loading than playing.
Crashes on start on macOS Sequoia.

It's an excellent game that I'd give a neutral review if possible but I wanted to voice my opinion on just how confusing I found the UI because it literally broke my brain on how weird some things were:
-You can add things to wares by right clicking the item before picking it up, or right clicking it in your inventory, but can't add it to wares when holding alt to see nearby items, since in this state you cannot right click items. Why? Cause screw you that's why. You also cannot right click add to wares on an item that is inside some sort of container like a backpack in your inventory.
-You can't sell items that are inside a container/backpack in your bag to merchants without first removing it from the bag for some inane reason
-You can add an item to wares by shift-clicking it in your inventory, but cannot do this by shift-clicking an item in the overworld, in a container within your bag, or in the buy/sell menu
-You can send an item to another player from your inventory menu by right clicking it, but you cannot do this by right clicking in the overworld, you cannot do this from the merchant buy/sell menu, and you cannot do this from a container within your bag.
-You have to press a button for a merchant to pay you the gold worth of an item / multiple items since it defaults to the player just handing the item to the merchant for free for some inane reason. 90% of the time your are selling crap you picked up to merchants for pure gold so the concept of a balancing offer button isn't needed in those 90% of times.
-There is a search feature to search through your combining recipes which you only sometimes need, but there is no search feature for your inventory, which is INFINITELY more useful with a game that pumps your inventory full of crap constantly. You can only do basic category filtering on your inventory. Why?
-Game's UI confusingly shows you your damage values for equipment BEFORE applying any of your stat buffs if you look at the equipment's stats. The ONLY way to know your basic attack power is to view your character sheet, even during battle. Why would I ever look at my character sheet to see what damage i will do during battle after my stat buffs? YOU ARE HEARING ME RIGHT IT DOESNT SHOW YOU THE DAMAGE RANGE YOUR NORMAL ATTACK WILL HAVE WHEN YOU HIGHLIGHT AN ENEMY TO ATTACK THEM, DESPITE DOING THIS FOR EVERY OTHER SKILL IN THE GAME, JUST WHY
-Selecting an enemy to attack during battle is INCREDIBLY specific to each skill and INCREDIBLY finicky, you will constantly misclick and often feel like you can't even click the enemy you want to click because of their janky click detection. Massive example: literally every single time i use Battering Ram skill it is a struggle to get the game to actually attack a specific opponent rather than try to go beside them, every time i try to use an AOE projectile it jumps my cursor around like a friggin madman to avoid centering on multiple enemies which is always what I would want to do.
-You MUST, MUST combine items by slowly dragging them or double clicking them into some combine UI, waiting for a sound to play, and waiting for 1 item to be made as a result, instead of dragging one over the other and them instantly combining or having a bulk combine feature. Yeah why would i ever want to drag the horn of poisonation (dont care what the actual name is) onto a potion to turn it into a poison flask instead of slowly waiting for a sound effect to play as they combine for the millionth time? I avoided combining things just because the UI was so slow to use.
-Why the HELL can't i drag runes onto armor pieces with empty slots. Instead I must use another UI that adds more clicks to slot things into the equipment. 99% of the game you only have 1 rune slot on armor pieces so it would be braindead simple to implement.
-Why the hell do I have to slowly hover across the overworld to click where i want to go instead of clicking on a spot on the map and let autopilot kick in? I literally can do that anyway by hovering for long enough, you just want to waste my time intentionally or something?

Most of these complaints just add an insane amount of extra clicks for the player and make managing your inventory a complete nightmare even with an automatic sorting function.

other gripes I have are
-Game gives you a talent for talking to animals, 90% of the animals do nothing other than say some stupid crap or tell you to stop talking to them angrily in some way. What a waste of a talent point. You can get a decent shield near the end of the game but it's massively outclassed by other available ones 2 moments later.
-When you enter caves, rather than clicking on the cave entrance itself, you have to click on the rock formation that surrounds the cave entrance. Dunno who could even come up with something that strangely different other than that they were too lazy to do it the way that makes sense.
-Why the hell are some of the battles the most confusing jank shit ever? Your party member was posessed, but you killed them, now they're not possessed, but someone else is, but now they're not, but now they are, but you killed them, now they're not, now their summon is but they're not, but now their summon is but they aren't, WTF IS GOING ON IN THIS FIGHT IT MAKES NO SENSE DEVS
-Constant unexplainable events in battle triggered by jank. Big enemy summons henchmen because we took too long, HENCHMEN ARE NOT CONSIDERED IN THE BATTLE AND CAN WALK AROUND FREELY AND HEAL ANY DAMAGE WE DID TO THEM EVEN THOUGH THEY ARE RIGHT NEXT TO US, AND THEN STAND THERE AND DO NOT EVEN PARTICIPATE IN THE BATTLE, THEN DIE WHEN WE DEFEAT THE BIG ENEMY. This is half broken. 
-Fighting in the arena in co-op mode with my friend. One of my characters die during the battle. They announce since we defeated all enemies we must defeat each other next. Friend kicks my ass. Both my characters are now dead. BATTLE ISNT CONSIDERED DONE BECAUSE HE MUST KILL BOTH OF US MEANING HE HAD TO MANUALLY REVIVE MY ALREADY DEAD CHARACTER AND KILL HIM AGAIN. Straight up untested battle situations?!???
-Doing well while fighting Lucian punishes the player by Braccus having full force against them. I love when playing well makes you lose more. Great design that. Dont worry we half-assed it the next try and easily won. Felt "rewarding"

This is a good game, but hear me out. 

This is a negative review because the game has insanely high review scores BUT it has some glaring issues. 

There's a bit of a catch though. It's the fact that I've only become frustrated enough to leave a negative review after multiple playthrough's. This is because I was so pleased with my initial experience that I was willing to overlook the issues back then. I am not willing now. 

The worst issue here is the simple fact that many fights in this game feel borderline unwinnable unless you already know how the fight will go before going into it and take steps to give yourself as much advantage as possible. This doesn't feel like "tactical" gameplay and is very frustrating, probably the most of any of the issues this game has. 

The second biggest issue is that you can really easily screw yourself over just because you talked to someone with the wrong character, which btw can be very hard to avoid in certain situations where npc's approach and initiate dialogue after a fight or something. They just go for the nearest npc and you can't well control that. If you are playing with friends, this mostly manifests as the player with the character who has persuasion having to be the one who goes first everywhere to talk to all npc's and see all new areas, otherwise you might fail some essential dialogue option. Feels like it punishes the other players for exploring.  

The rest of the issues have mostly to do with jank or bugs, like quest entries and markers not updating properly (this happens ALOT, but thankfully actual quest progression rarely breaks). But one of my biggest personal issues is the fact that many near-essential game changes that come bundled with the game and were made by the devs are treated as mods and disable your achievements. Like, really? Almost all of them are quality of life improvements that should have just been part of the base game, don't get me wrong it's extra nice to have the option, but not if it punishes you for using them. 

It's a good game, and you probably owe it to yourself to play it if you are a fan of crpg's, BUT it still has issues which may not be conveyed to you by the high review score. That's why I decided to write this.

Ah yes one final thing. Traps in this game are on a limited, short timer, which counts independent of the combat turns. They are fucking useless. Absolute garbage and waste, baffling design decision that I still struggle to comprehend. Normally I love a good use of traps in games like this (Underrail is the absolute king of this plus also stealth) but in this game it is awful. But that may be just me, cause I'm a traps enjoyer.

It's inevitable that this is going to be compared to Baldur's Gate 3, so I might as well frame my entire opinion around that comparison. 

The combat in this game is much more interesting than in BG3 - the action point system gives you a lot more freedom and cultivates interesting choices almost constantly. A big advantage over the very rigid actions offered in BG3. 

The writing in this game is severely inferior than BG3. Many characters are just grating to interact with, and will routinely harass or otherwise disrespect your character/party and there's never any options to tell them off, let alone start a fight over it. These NPC are just annoying to interact with and the game forces you to roll over and take it so you can complete the main quest. What a joke. Whoever replaced the head writer for BG3 made the right choice.

I would love to give this game a very positive review. The actual content in the game is wonderfully built and very fun to play. But it won't work for me. I crash constantly, either loading into the front menu or into the game itself. If I save, I crash. I have tried everything under the sun to fix this because I really enjoy the experience when I get to play. I have: verified game files, put it in windowed mode, run the .exe as administrator and put it in compatibility mode, taken all overlays off of the game, disabled 3D settings, deleted all save files, deleted config files (for re-downloading), fully wiped all data from the game and re-downloaded, updated my graphics driver, turned auto-save off, have nothing running in the background while playing, disabled cloud saves. Nothing has worked. It is so disappointing, especially coming from the relatively stable BG3. I hope that it is fixed but I doubt it will be.

Not enjoying the combat system. It's doable but I don't enjoy how it creates challenge. For example pre-positioning enemies in good positions and clumping up the party (when the fight happens on a new map), setting them them up to get blasted before they can do anything. Or, just making enemies far stronger than the party members, forcing you to figure out what areas to avoid by dying and reloading. The game does a poor job explaining how things work. You get a lot of options and variables without context, and you need to pick wisely or suck. It all results in having to google how things work, and meta-gaming before fights, which is detrimental to the immersion.
Also, the game world is supremely bleak and depressing; I don't need a game for that.

I essentially had to force myself to get to the end of this game, after owning it for years and restarting it repeatedly. It's gorgeous, D:OS1 is one of my favorite games, and I was so excited to play the hero characters and experience their storylines, but playing this game was [b]tedious[/b]. Several puzzles were so nonsensical and presented so blankly that I (like many other players, it seems) kept having to go online just to figure out what I was supposed to do... which ended up making the puzzles boring. Same with a lot of the combat (one of my favorite parts of D:OS1) - there's giving players a satisfying challenge, and then there's forcing the player to slog through endless tedium. This was unfortunately the latter.

The ending...oof. I chose the option I thought was best, and it ended up being cynical and depressing. Looking online, it sounds like the other endings aren't any better. The epilogue was dull as dirt and droned on for way too long.

I can't even say "well, I'm glad I finished it at least". It just wasn't fun. Huge bummer. Guess I'll go replay D:OS1 again.

A French themed souls-like with pretty fun fighting mechanics and an interesting setting. This game is [i]extremely[/i] my jam. Supernatural alt-history silliness featuring a gorgeous clockwork automaton doll who uses graceful, elegant maneuvers and weaponry in a fast-paced, mobility-oriented Soulslike combat system to strike back against nasty little men in power for the sake of a revolutionary cause? [b]Sign me the fuck up![/b]

That said, despite managing to maintain my hyperfixation through two pretty thorough playthroughs, I would have to say that I can only [b]barely[/b] recommend it. The game is full of technical and design jank that ranges from "haha, whoopsie!" to "[b]oh NO, WHY!?[/b]".

The lighter, more amusing end of the spectrum includes things like a specific enemy that reliably disappears and deactivates only when you're in its room, the variety of weird issues with item pickup interactions, item and equipment descriptions being unhelpful or sometimes outright wrong, or enemy/boss AI sometimes just deciding to entirely nod off on the job.

On the more frustrating end, we have stuff like the squandered potential of the special boss abilities and vertical maneuvering, the frustrating inscrutability of some of the level design, or the very jarring in-dialogue "this is the point of no return, turn back if you have other business to attend to" notice that only actually applies for the duration of a single mission before you can return to the world and do side quests.

Chief among my frustrations, though, would be some of the narrative choices made, especially regarding the nature of our dancer doll protagonist. I am a huge sucker for robots, automatons, and androids and a huge fan of narratives involving the intersection of identity and synthetic life, this game does [i]not[/i] deliver on that front. Instead of anything thoughtful, we get an anticlimactic and predictable reveal, a bunch of Important Men denying the stated identity of our character on multiple occasions, and an outcome that felt emotionally unearned and left me more bitter than moved.

All that said, though, I [b]did[/b] overall enjoy a substantial amount of time with Steelrising. I felt that the core combat and exploration remained generally solid throughout, and the design and animation of Aegis and all of the clockwork Automat enemies alone was enough to make me want to keep existing in that space, as that character, for as long as possible. I just feel like there's a lot of potential that wasn't realized, and my love for the concept makes it all the more frustrating that it wasn't quite able to deliver on all of it.

Decent soulslike, easier than most though, pretty repetitive, some glitches that just freeze the game and force quit due to janky interactions with boxes or other various geography as you dash over/through them. Overall, not bad but not a ng+ contender. Deep sale purchase and blow through it.

not the brightest bulb on stage, but a needed refresh from the usual american based ideas

[h3]Souls-lite with clockwork-steampunk aesthetics.[/h3]

An interesting, but mostly linear story, with beautiful graphics and fun combat mechanics.
Personally, I didn't find it as hard as any Dark Souls game, as the mobs, bosses and runbacks are much more forgiving. While playing an entire game without healing is usually a privilege of expert challenge-runners, it is quite feasible in this game to get this rare achievement.

There is a good variety of weapons, ranging from fast and evasive to slow and devastating. With freely configurable augmentations, you can create any build you want, from an enemy-shredding glass cannon to an immovable tank. The ice, fire and electric elemental attacks and defences are a nice addition, too. I've found managing your stamina quite delightful in this game - you can refresh your stamina bar by cooling yourself down at any time, as long as you don't freeze yourself in the process.

[u]Recommended if:[/u] You like skeleton-watches so much that you could imagine a whole world built around them. Or you liked Lies of P, but wanted to play a female character. Joking aside, it's a nice Souls-lite, give it a try!
[u]Not recommended if:[/u] You hate souls-like games, parry mechanics, gimmick bosses, and the French in general. :D

A solid soulslike set during the French Revolution, taking you on a journey from the storming of the Bastille to Versailles. The game incorporates Metroidvania-style progression, with new abilities unlocking as you go, encouraging backtracking and exploration of earlier areas.

Later sections can be quite challenging, as the distance between "bonfires" increases and healing options remain limited, making each run feel tense and demanding.

The game’s main drawbacks are the underwhelming boss fights, even some regular enemies pose more of a threat as well as the general lack of enemy variety. Still, it’s a well-paced experience that doesn’t drag on too much.

It's Dark Soul style, with hard battles and where death is harsh. However, I really appreciate that the game designers knew not everyone would want to play that style and gave the player the choice. You can enable assist that allow you to adjust the game to your style. The game is beautiful by the way. I also loved that even though you're following a pathways, there plenty of exploration to do. My one negative about this game is the map. They needed better maps of the cities. The compass is helpful but when going back for breakable doors and secrets, not so much.

It´s like lies of P, on a budget and not as difficult. 

It was cool, the bosses could´ve been better - a strong 7

Great game.
Although it falls under the soulslike genre, this title is one of the more accessible options - making it a good starting point for newcomers.

The storytelling leans heavily into psychological thriller territory. There are no jump scares, but certain moments - and the eventual realization of what’s really happening - can be genuinely unsettling, even goosebump-inducing, due to how disturbing the narrative becomes.

There is a known optimization issue related specifically to vertical synchronization; simply disabling V-Sync resolves the problem.

The visuals are stunning - I played with a mix of High and Epic settings.

Overall, it's well worth picking up, especially on sale. I had a great time, and achieving 100% completion felt rewarding rather than tedious.
Absolutely amazing game, highly recommended. The fighting is fluid and dancelike if you use a lighter weapon. The story is great and the graphics are amazing. 10/10

*Steel rising* isn’t revolutionary, but it’s a solid improvement on the action-RPG formula. The story is fine (3 endings + a DLC that feels more like a side quest), but the real highlight is the **world-building and map design**. The 7 regions are interconnected and layered in a way that makes exploration rewarding and atmospheric.

Gameplay is fun enough — good weapon variety, decent armor sets (though less important than in other games), plus grenades and elemental resistances for combat variety. I personally liked the anima farming armor since leveling past 40 becomes a grind. Graphics are beautiful, but note that full textures at 1440p require **10GB for High** and **13GB for Ultra**.

**Critics/bugs:**

* After finishing the game, you *cannot return to your save*, which means no DLC access unless you start NG+.
* NG+ gives you duplicate weapons/armors instead of replacing old ones — clutter and pointless selling.
* Store bug: oil burette can’t be upgraded past 5 doses / ~340 HP. Materials for upgrades in NG+ are a trap and waste anima. Store also sells items you already own.

**Overall:** With bugs and flaws → **5/10**.
Fixed/patched → easily **8/10**.

Only 1 Problem With The Game Is The FPS Performance Is Too Bad To Get 90 fps On Max Settings For My PC It Should Be 200+ FPS Is Okay I Still Love The Game Is Very Nice Souls like Game And For All Hunters Is a Easy Game To 100% <3

ONLY RECOMMENDED IF YOU ENJOY THE GENRE..... I mean the genre has to be your favorite for you to get through this.

Pros: 2H heavy mace with special attack that might as well be a shotgun was a lot of fun. Aesthetic of the game is pretty good. once you get the air dash and grapple hook that's pretty sleek too.

Cons: story suggests something more but turns out pretty shallow. game is janky, runs poorly, overly convoluted map layouts, why am I constantly circling where I want to go with simple metal gates or barriers barring my way with arbitrary 'locked from the other side.'  I can jump but many invisible walls above walls that you could easily find a way to parkour over.

Also.... light attacks (R1) and running attacks (R1 or R2) with a heavy weapon all suck. They don't seem to do any posture damage, so even the scrawniest trash mob will hit you in the face if you try to start a fight with a running attack. As a heavy weapon user, this game was all positioning and timing for standing R2 and charged R2 attacks... plus special attack. maybe other weapon types favor more light/running stuff.

Bosses are pretty darn easy. I barely used items. You could spam a boss with frost grenades and just hit when stunned if you wanted to. I stopped using grenades after it made an easy fight even easier.

As far as indie soulslike games go... Thymesia had far less production (no voice acting) and was a better overall game.

super con: ending is dumb as hell. 

spoiler::::: without giving away too much... the bad guys in the game could defeat you at any time if they wanted to and there's no explanation for why they didn't when they clearly want to defeat you... completely not the mechanic, but imagine lex luthor has kryptonite and never uses it against superman. the kryptonite has been THE MOST OBVIOUS solution for the villains the whole time and they didn't use it? what? the? hell?

whoever allowed such a total buzzkill of an ending is a total clown. made zero sense.

C’est un good game. L’histoire est intéressante et innovante, mais honnêtement, elle n’est pas très profonde. Le personnage est assez maladroit, voire robotique… :p ce qui me rappelle DS2. En fait, tous les boss m’ont rappelé les boss du début de DS2. J’en ai tué la plupart au premier ou au deuxième essai. Le moveset des boss est manjado (simple) et pas très élaboré. Je n’ai rencontré aucune difficulté dans ce jeu, mais peut-être que le build de force correspond au easy mode ; je suis sûr que cela aurait été plus difficile avec un build d’agilité ou de tireur.

La plus grande difficulté que certains pourraient rencontrer, ce serait de gérer les différents combats contre les mobs ennemis, des ennemis qui ont comme un spider-sense, voient à travers les murs et te détectent même sans t’apercevoir. Autre chose : la limite d’aggro des ennemis est beaucoup trop courte, ridicule ; ils se retournent simplement sur toi. L’IA est vraiment trop stupide.

J’ai apprécié le temps de soin presque instantané (à l’opposé de DS2). C’est bien que le moveset change avec chaque type d’arme, mais il y a trop d’animations ajoutées, ce qui ralentit le combat et le rend vite répétitif. J’ai trouvé le level design problématique, avec TELLEMENT d’arbres, de rochers et d’objets bloquant la vue et ralentissant le personnage. Mon personnage restait souvent coincé ou buggé par des débris, racines ou objets, visibles ou invisibles, au sol du niveau. Il y a aussi quelques bugs agaçants, où il faut appuyer plusieurs fois ou se positionner différemment pour ramasser un objet ou verrouiller un ennemi.

Une chose que j’ai vraiment aimée, c’est l’ambiance d’enquête et de mystère dans le gameplay.
Malgré ses défauts, il faut se rappeler que ce n’est pas un jeu AAA, et qu’il est de meilleure qualité que BEAUCOUP de AAA et même de AAAA qui existent. C’est un GOOD game, et je l’ai apprécié.

7.5/10

I think this game is a good entry point for someone who likes the Souls formula, but finds it too unforgiving and punishing. It's definitely on the easier side of souls-like spectrum. 

The game actually allows pausing. The items and equipment menus are still live, but there is a pause menu where you can adjust basic settings. Pausing the game also auto-saves, so you don't need to make it to a vestal (bonfire) before quitting out. You can just quit at any point and continue from there.

The game is pretty generous with vestals, so runbacks arent really a thing. There are either a lot of them, or there are several shortcuts back to a particular one, so runbacks aren't as common or as grueling. There's almost always a vestal near the boss.

One common complaint I saw that I just don't agree with is the level design. It's not labyrinthian or hard to navigate at all. Most areas are straightforward. There aren't a ton of branching paths to get lost on. The levels all tend to loop around and give you shortcuts back to where you started. There's a compass you can buy that points you toward various objectives. 

The story is decent. I thought VA was pretty good. Enemy variety is a bit meh, basically everything bipedal and humanoid, which come in flavors of grunt, warrior, elite, and heavy architypes. Some quadrupeds. And stealthy guys. Character customization and weapon variety is good IMO. Overall pretty fun souls-like. Better than LotF, not as good as LoP.
Really nice game! Really recommend for those who appreciate Souls like.

I only recommend the game since I paid $5 for it, which it is certainly worth.

The setting in french cities is really nice, although I would prefer a little bit more variety. Graphics are a bit outdated, but serviceable. My biggest gripe (and the reason why I would not pay more than $10 for it) is the combat. It is imprecise and not very fun. Most enemies and bosses can easily be stunlocked by spamming heavy attacks. Hence, it is not very challenging. 

I would recommend Lies of P instead, which is a much better game.

Here's the short and simple part you want to hear: Yes it's like Dark Souls, Yes its good, Yes it will keep you busy for a dozen or more hours. Buy it on sale.

Here's the long version: All of the above + the game is super easy and the story is mostly nonsense you can ignore. Maybe it's just me but I could not care less about the story when every single main character in the story (save 3 out of like 10+ important characters) are just old white guys in powdered wigs who all want to take over France for they're own gains. Play it for the unique take on souls like combat, the cool looking automatons and the incredibly easy difficulty. Your character is a nuclear bomb with a charging heavy attack button and all the common enemies and bosses are basically newborn babies you can and will stun lock to death once you put a couple points into your prefered damage type.

If your looking for babies first souls like game, SteelRising is the way to go.

A Mild Soulslike — Fun for a Weekend, but Lacks Challenge

I picked up Steelrising on sale, and for that price, it was worth it. It’s a short and relatively easy game compared to most Soulslikes, but it does have its charm.

The story is simple, easy to follow, and a bit predictable—but still enjoyable enough to keep you moving forward.

The gameplay starts off fine, and once you unlock the main abilities, it becomes very easy to clear levels. Combat feels smooth, but it doesn’t take long before you’ve mastered it and stop needing most of the items the game throws at you.

Bosses are not challenging at all. I beat most of them on my first attempt, which was a bit of a letdown given the genre. The game also holds your hand quite a lot—something I personally didn’t enjoy since I prefer a tougher challenge.

Exploration is also on the weaker side. Most of the time, your “reward” is just a consumable you’ll probably never need. There isn’t much incentive to go off the main path.

That said, it’s not a bad game. It runs well, looks good, and the setting is interesting. It’s just not on the same level as the heavier hitters in the genre.

Bottom line: Steelrising is a mid-tier Soulslike. Worth picking up on sale if you want something light to play over a weekend, but don’t expect a big challenge.

Game is kinda fun, unique and intresting, and ALWAYS on sale. If you get it on sale, its worth it, but i'll be honest, its no Lies of P.

Its a much more janky and indie version of that, you can see the inspiration of it throughout this game, but after 4/5 hours of the game i think i got a good grasp of it.

Exploration is fun, and with all indie game it is well thought out. Ways to get from point a to b have like 2 or 3 solutions if you know how to work around the weird mechanics, which is cool, but speaking of mechanics, they're bad. And i dont mean, im complaining bad, but they're bad. The jump is weird and the pause at the top of the arc is a little too long, especially when you're in battle. The weapon and the attacks are slow, even when using a fast weapon. And there's this weird startup when you run which makes it unusable in battle because you pause for a split-second, then run, and if you know game mechanics you'll know what im talking about.

Its fun, but after a couple hours, the gameplay is the main turn off for me. Story was awesome though.

A bit clunky and not always super-balanced, pretty easy to beat, but overall a humble yet good AA game.
Solid souls game. Reminds me of Lies of P and DS

I'm having a lot of fun with this game. It's refreshing to play a souls game that gives you that little bit of feeling on edge whether you should venture a little further or retreat to safety and level up without being frustratingly difficult. There are constantly little side hallways to venture into and I love that the direction that is the side hallway and the main path are not always clear so your mind is constantly working to make sure that you don't miss out on the very rewarding chests that could be in any little nook.

Update: 9 hours in and having a blast. The build options are pretty robust and all of them can essentially become broken good if you invest in them enough and play to their strength.

This game is a mixed bag for me. I wish I could give it a mixed review but negative it has to be.

Pros:

-Every weapon class is unique and some of the designs a bonkers crazy but they dont feel out of place in this clockwork automaton world.
-The game is beginners friendly so if you want to play soulslike games but hate the high difficulties. This one is for you.
-For me the game ran really good. I only play on 1980p and had no technical issues like I read in many of the other reviews.
-The game doesnt overstay its welcome and doesnt feel like a grind and NG+ is worth a shot.

Cons:
Some of the sidequest storylines irritated the hell out of me. Cause they broke immersion of this beautiful fantasy world with current day-isms and its the main reason for my negative recommendation. You dont break immersion for political messaging and virtue signaling. The same would be true if the main character suddenly pulls out a coca cola can out of her cogs and slurps it down while telling us how its smears her gears in the right spot. Allow me to explain these "woke" questlines.
- A black slave owner of the colonies yaps about muh racism in 18th century Paris and how he wants freedom for all the slaves in the colonies. I would say thats quite hypocritical. And the funny thing is that another npc calls him out on it and asks him why he didnt set his own slave free. But the discussion and the slaver arguments ends in the way of stfu white boy and check your privilege (not in these words but thats the jist of it). But they keep bringing up the muh racism thing way to much. Black guy speaks during main storyquest plotlines "but what about muh racism thingie" is present in one form or another.
- Another "woke" storyline is tied to the DLC mission. And its about a female bodyguard who takes every opportunity she has to insult men. Yap about muh womens rights and down with the patriarchy. And that whole conversation felt so out of place. Even your main character suddenly has a more combative voice when its about the current day feminism.

These 2 storylines were so out of place i mean come on. A tyrannical Despot and his lackey build an army of killer automatons to keep power over the people. And they kill as many people as they can to harvest the souls to keep the automatons fueled so that the army can keep on existing. And then we have diversity hire and feminist here yapping about muh racism and female rights. Really? Entire cityblocks are eradicated and covered in corpses and thats your priority?

I presume some of the devs are activists and they had to insert their agenda in the game. Or perhaps some EU or ESG money was rewarded if they made the game more DEI. Nonetheless. That grinded my gears the wrong way and i call it out. Im sick and tired of this crap creeping into our entertainment. Entertain me and stfu. 

And its so sad really cause the rest of the game i really enjoyed and had a great time with. But never give your money to people/companies who hate you and want you gone. A great man once said "Everything woke turns to Shit". And he is not wrong.

4/10
Steelrising is, in many ways, a clear imitation of Dark Souls—from its combat mechanics to its overall gameplay structure. While it captures some of that familiar challenge and atmosphere, it struggles to offer anything truly unique. The map design and story simply didn’t grab my attention enough to keep me invested, and I found myself losing interest before long. It’s not a bad game by any means, but it’s not particularly memorable either. There are plenty of stronger Soulslike titles out there that do more to innovate and engage. Steelrising feels like one to play only if you’ve already exhausted the rest and are looking for something similar to fill the gap.

After finishing it, i am strongly disappointed. A few hours into it the combat and story completely fall appart. I was just button smashing, since doding was barely needed, even for bosses. There were also no new game mechanics and enemies barely changed. All side quests force you to run multiple times through the same areas just to pick up letters. Game would be better if it was ~6h, rest is really boring padding.
