After my first 4 hours:

Looks great, plays great and performance is also great. Setting is interesting, writting and voice actors are good.

Hit boxes are tight, visuals for attacks are clear and patterns are fun to learn. Weapon variety is there.

Levels are fun to explore. Locations loop back to the bonfire and are quite detailed, so orientation is not a problem.

Encountered only one visual bug.

This game is a mediocre soulslike, fine if you want to grab it on deep sale and give it a play.

The main critique of the game is variety. There are a total of 11 base enemy designs, half getting used as early bosses. Most variation is a new attack or different elemental effect.

Similarly, weapon variety is limited to 9 classes with 4-5 variants using the same special ability pool (block, parry, flurry, ranged attack, and elemental buff).

The gameplay itself is fine if easy. you get to active reload your stamina bar in exchange for a partial freeze buildup. Play hyper aggressive to stagger and crit.  Most bosses went down on the first try.

All the sidequests pop up near the point of no return after you're maxed out, so you can go back and do them all, or just speedrun past the 0 new enemies in the last 3 areas.
This game wish it was Lies of P. And it fails gloriously at it lol

The CLOWN:

The Conclusion:
Loved the concept, Hated the clown performance. Game’s good, but the clown side is stronger. Negative it is 🤡🤡🤡

El juego NO es bueno.

Combate super repetitvo con animaciones burdas y toscas. Aunque las armas son interesantes, rápidamente te das cuenta de lo que REALMENTE vale la pena tener.

El parry es DEMASIADO bueno. Es tan bueno y fácil de hacer que puedes hacer parries constantes a los jefes, lo cual lo facilita muchísimo los combates. Se vuelve más fácil cuando te colocas el módulo para curarte cuando haces parries, y si lo combinas con el módulo para curarte cuando stageas a un enemigo, casi nunca tendrás que curarte.

El juego es totalmente mediocre, la historia es MALÍSIMA y te ponen una custscene larguísima incluso antes de conocer a tu personaje, la actuación de voz mala, y yo estoy jugando con una RTX 4080 y en muchos lugares le cuesta el juego cargar. 

Los enemigos son LOS MISMOS, y para empeorar: los jefes NUNCA se sienten como jefes. Sólo se siente como enemigos básicos que tienen un poco más de vida. Básicamente, la primera hora del juego ya viste todo lo que tiene que ofrecer.

Lo único bueno es que tiene niveles estilo metroidvania: poco a poco los vas desbloqueando a medida que vas progresando pero resto... realmente no lo recomiendo, en lo más mínimo. Incluso The Surge / The surge 2, que ya de por sí no son tan buenos, son muchísimos mejores que este juego porque ofrecen algo distinto.

Imagínate que te compraste Lies of P a través de shein/temu, pero en vez de LoP te llega este juego. Eso es Steelrising.

I did my best to try and like this game, but the terrible camera that would get stuck in walls or alter the direction of your dashes, controls that felt like they both slipped around and were unbearably stiff at the same time, and invisible terrain in the ground that is apparently able to stop you from moving (example, a single step either up or down is a solid wall when dashing, walking and sometimes when jumping), I could not find a way to enjoy playing this game.

For the most part It is a good game with a very good story line. I liked the combat style, it changed up the characters and bosses enough that you don't necessarily feel like you are combating the same thing over and over again. Nice weapon and armor selections as you progress through the game. Great graphic style and have no issue with the voice over and dialog. A good game.

What is a pain in the ass, is sometimes in the game in order to west you have go east instead. Or, to go north you first have to go south, etc, etc, etc...... For me this becomes very laborious an almost endless, mindless grind! When you finally make to the main objective, you then sometimes have to re-fight your way back out. Similar for side quest even though you have already fought your way through and area to get to the quest objective.  You still have to fight your way back out. This just gets boring at times, taking the fun out of the game.

However, this is not why I gave it a thumbs down, I likely would have given the game a 6 or 7 out of 10, if not for the following.

At about 3/4's of the through the game, whether it was me, or a one off glich, or bug? I was distracted by a bright shiny thing on the ground, and I clicked on it!    POOF!!!!!!!!    The screen went black and at first I thought the game froze, dead. But it returned, and there my character was standing on the beach when you first enter Paris for the first time in the game. All the found armor and weapons found, story progression everything done  was gone, removed.  I knew where the save files were, but all of it gone! ALL gone!!!!!!! No way to return to were I was. While the game is not a bad game, it is not worth replaying to get back to where I was. So for that, to my forever uninstall, delete pile never to be played again. Should you play it, just know there is a bright shiny thing some where that when clicked on you will return to the very beginning of Paris to start it all over again! Naked and alone!

The End

In my quest to play as many souls-like games as possible, I stumbled upon this mess called Steelrising. On Steam it’s listed for 50€, but honestly, it’s worth maybe 10 at best. I’m glad I only paid 3€ for a key, because if I had spent full price, I’d be furious.

The game has nothing of value to offer. The cutscenes are boring and badly done, the mechanics feel clunky and unpolished, and bugs are everywhere — from enemies glitching out to broken hitboxes. The combat is stiff, the level design is uninspired, and overall it feels like an unfinished project that was rushed out the door.

If you’re looking for a solid souls-like experience, this isn’t it. There are countless better alternatives out there for the same (or even cheaper) price. Save your time and money.

Wow, the artstyle is beautiful and the setting is interesting and the concept is intriguing and the protagonist has potential and the historical side characters have a rich background to draw stories from.

So, how come this game is SUCH a borefest? It's aggressively trying to put me to sleep! I don't understand.

I couldn't get into it.

I personally don't find the combat to be strong enough to trudge through, and find a gameplay style suited for me. I was unable to find a weapon that particularly stood out as fun to use. When switching from a light, and fast weapon to a heavy, and slow weapon I fully expected to see a response from the enemies when being hit, but I was disappointed. The animations are much too slow to feel rewarding when you don't get feedback from scoring a hit. The frost batons in particular were truly awful to use.

In level design, I think there were some strong points, but the heavy use of groups so early on with enemies whose main difficulty is interrupting your actions made the initial experience more frustrating than I could tolerate. 

Maybe it gets better. Maybe there is a playstyle that I would love later. Maybe the enemies become more fun, but I couldn't push through. 

I think the company has a strong start, and I will look forward to seeing what they make in the future, but I bounced off of this one because of the feeling of the core gameplay.

The game crashes way too much, about every few minutes. I did everything the internet suggested. This is a problem for several years from what the forums tell me. I liked the premise of automatons taking over in France right before the revolution. But I cannot play a game that crashes every few minutes, even if the auto saves prevent you from losing a lot of time. 15/100

Overall, I'd give this game like a 4/10.  
Art style: Incredible, 10/10
Story: Tough to follow, I feel like the focus was on getting French aspects and getting the translations all sprinkled in that the story had a few holes. I feel like there were some choices to make that would have lead to different outcomes like the gunpowder, but I feel like there wasn't enough of an indication of what they actually meant. I filled the gunpowder with water before I even saw the gunpowder. Also how the heck was there so much water to just fill that place? That doesn't make sense. 
The main villain also wasn't super interactive; I feel like he had 2 one-liners to me and then was gone. No resolution with him kind of annoyed me because it hints to another game, that I won't be playing. 
Animation: Enemy styles were predictable and really easy. I shouldn't have been able to walk into any boss battle, including the last one, and beat it first try.  I'm good at souls-like, but I wanted a challenge.  There were a few bugs that caused for unnecessary damage to be taken/ npcs to walk through tables/ glitch.  Also I could run through water for some reason in some places but die from a toe going in in others.  The memory in the orange area near the end did not show the customized Ludia, but rather a default puppet/ machine that threw the story off a bit.
Weapons:  There was a bit of variety which I loved, but realistically, some of them were so weak that it didn't make sense to switch  and buff something up.  
Items: The items were alright, the ones that caused stagger were OP but the rest were just sold. Also, the item locations were BS; why the heck were some of them so hard to get and then they were just a small heal and then the weapons and unique items were right in the open in big glowing chests. 
Equipment: why wasn't there a backstory for the new skills? Like why the heck did I get a dash and a kick out of no where? It made the item less meaningful and didn't really tie into the backstory. It could have been an amazing portion of the story as to how she built her body with add-ons from the creator.
After finishing this game I can say: Don't.
Runs really quite badly. Lies of P is a much better game - play that instead.

One of the worst "soulslikes" (and that word is doing some heavy lifting) I've ever played. Awful mechanics and gameplay. The first boss is turned into a normal enemy less than 5 minutes after you beat it. When they are recycling assets that quickly you know you're in for some lazy game design. 

The story seemed cool but this game isn't worth your time. Spiders games never are.

Steelrising really makes me wish we had an option in between a positive and negative review. I don't think it's bad I just don't think it's good either, but if asked by a friend if I'd recommend buying it I'd have to go with no. As of writing this review I haven't actually completed the game yet though I am somewhat close, despite the negatives it's not bad enough to drive me away from finishing it; I just wanted to get my main thoughts down while they're still fresh.

The combat in Steelrising is underwhelming. The Overheat and Rapid Cooling mechanics that allow you to nearly have unlimited stamina in succession is quite fun and really allows you to keep up the pressure on enemies; the only issue is that the enemies just are not built to handle this. This game uses the stance break mechanic similar to games like Sekiro and Elden Ring where keeping up pressure on the enemy fills up a meter that will eventually stun them and leave them vulnerable to a critical attack, but the non-stop pressure you have from Rapid Cooling constantly refilling your stamina makes it so just spamming fast attacks will quickly knock enemies and bosses alike over. Enemy AI isn't great either which compounds this issue, I've had several bosses lose interest in fighting me and just stand there, I don't know if this is caused by having so much pressure on them or if it's just like that normally. The game also reuses a lot of regular enemies as bosses, which isn't uncommon in soulslikes but when it's the majority of bosses in the game it gets old fast. Oh, and unlike Elden Ring where you're incentivized with more pressure damage for sneaking in a few charged attacks, the charge attacks suck in this game and are both incredibly slow to charge and not very impactful once you do, so just spam R1 instead.

Aegis is pretty cool being a French robot woman and the setting is neat, though the character building for Aegis lacks any real depth. You pick the one stat for the type of weapon you want to use and crank it, maybe put a few points into extra health or stamina but the game isn't really hard enough to require you to do more than pump damage. Similar to a Metroidvania Aegis gets some upgrades as the story progresses that allows her to go back to older areas and access new locations, though they all really amount to "press button in predetermined spot to open door with new power," and while these abilities can be used in combat, they're all pretty weak and underwhelming to actually use. I'm not a Souls Must Be Soul-Crushingly Difficult elitist but this game is way too easy in the opposite direction, the only times I died was to the environment.

Speaking of the environment, the level design here is... Ambitious? Quite unlike any soulslike I've played. There's a lot of verticality and platforming which I'm actually not against I think it could be cool if done well but I don't think this is it. The levels want to be in that Metroidvania/Dark Souls interconnected style but have so many twists and turns and pathways that you'd never find where to go naturally like you do in those games, which is why Steelrising gives you a compass item that puts a giant waypoint on your screen to guide you; which turns most levels into just sprinting towards a waypoint, running past all the enemies. Of course you don't need to use the compass, but the levels are too confusing to navigate naturally and would take frustratingly long to find out where to go, and it's not like you'll be well rewarded for exploring anyway since most of what you'll find is some consumable you'll never actually use. Even when using the compass it's easy to get lost, like this one area where you need to get across a canal and the compass guides you to a spot where you can jump across, but it doesn't really look close enough that you can make the jump so you may look for another way over, only to eventually realize you just barely can make that jump...

The setting is cool but the presentation of the story is not. You're constantly watching cutscenes of samey looking French aristocrats yapping and none of it is fun or interesting to watch. The cutscenes all have this amateurish jank that makes even the boss cutscenes look kinda awkward.

I got this game from a Humble Bundle with a handful of other soulslike games for $20-ish bucks or something around there, and outside of getting Steelrising a similar way I would not really recommend buying it. Like I said in my opening I don't think this game is bad or anything it's just not... good either. If you really have an itch to play a soulslike as a robot who needs to save Europe from other robots, play Lies of P.

Steelrising started off strong for me, but the deeper I got into it, the more the fun wore off. The enemy design quickly became repetitive, the same basic types reused over and over, just with different elements like fire or frost to make them “unique.” After a while, it stopped being exciting and just felt like a chore.

Once I realized I had essentially hit the cap on weapon upgrades and certain specs, the sense of progression disappeared. That’s when the game really lost me. By the second-to-last area, I found myself just running past enemies instead of fighting them, not because I couldn’t handle them, but because I was simply bored.

Looting also felt unrewarding. Gear upgrades were expensive enough that I never really switched weapons or outfits, so there wasn’t much incentive to experiment. The whole system made exploration feel pointless.

In the end, I didn’t finish the game, not because it was too hard, but because it got less and less fun the further I went. It’s a shame, because the opening hours showed promise, but for me, Steelrising ran out of steam halfway through.

I’ve spent some time with this game and honestly, it surprised me in a way I didn’t fully expect. I don’t want to sound dramatic, but there’s something oddly satisfying about how everything fits together — not in some perfect, polished “advertisement” way, but more like a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and just… goes for it.

The first thing I noticed is the atmosphere. Every part of the game — the visuals, the sound, the pacing — kind of blends into this feeling that you’re actually inside its world, even if you’re just casually playing. I know that sounds a bit cliché, but it’s true. Sometimes it’s chaotic, sometimes slow, sometimes you’re just wandering around thinking “ok, what now?” but that’s honestly part of the charm. The game doesn’t try to rush you unless it actually needs to.

Gameplay-wise, it has this mix of familiar elements and small twists that keep things from feeling stale. Nothing groundbreaking, maybe, but it all works together in a way that feels natural. There were moments when I thought “yeah, I’ve seen this in other games,” but then the game throws in tiny details or unexpected interactions that make it stand out just enough. It’s the kind of thing you only notice after a few hours, when you start connecting the dots.

Performance has been mostly fine. A little rough spot here and there, but honestly, show me a game these days that doesn’t have something weird happening once in a while. Nothing game-breaking on my end, at least. You can clearly tell the developers put effort into this, even if a few edges are still a bit sharp. Again — part of the charm.

What I really appreciate is that the game gives you space to play the way you want. Some people will rush through every objective, others will take their time exploring or messing around, and both approaches actually feel valid. I like games that don’t punish you for not following some “correct” path.

Overall, I’d say this is one of those titles that grows on you the longer you play. It doesn’t try too hard to impress in the first five minutes — instead it slowly builds its identity, layer by layer, until you suddenly realize you’ve been playing way longer than you planned. If you’re looking for something that balances comfort with challenge, familiar mechanics with fresh touches, and a world that’s just fun to be in, then I genuinely think this one is worth giving a shot.

Would I recommend it?
Yeah, I would — maybe not to everyone, because no game is for everyone, but definitely to anyone who likes getting lost in a game for a bit and discovering things at their own pace.

Don't Starve is one of the grown up survival games that has it place in my heart since the very beginning more then ten years ago.

You can choose between several characters that have their individual advantages and disadvantages while playing the game. The main goal is to reach Maxwell's Door and go through the story.
Or just survive as long as you can and fight the different Giants that might appear in the seasons the game has.

I most played offline, so the hours I spent are much more than shown in steam (I would say about 500hrs?). 
The game is still unique and very special. I like it most, because it is not mainstream and has its own style and feeling.
Nothing is explained and the player needs to figure out everything by themselves.

Interesting to mention is, that you can create your own rules for the world that is created and define what you want to have appeared less or more like certain giants or certain resources.

There are some basic mechanics the game has, which the player needs to understand:

Hunger - your character needs to eat from time to time

Sanity - you need to do something for the brain of your character to get not insane, otherwise the shadow hands and shadow creatures will appear that attack the character

Health - the environment, the creatures, some consumable and too hot or too cold circumstances can heart the character

Light - the light is the protection against the shadow creatures and the player needs to stay in light to prevent beeing attacked by them and losing sanity

Temperature - not visible directly, but it can be too hot or too cold and the player needs to do something to protect against heat and cold by wearing certain clothes or hats or by staying near a fire

Crafting - one base mechanic is to craft things and structures out of the resources (not all are renewable) one found in the environment

Research - you can upgrade your gear and your base buildings by finding the right resources for it and you will need to to survive over time

The fun part is the challenge the game offers to the player. You have a lot of stress the first runs to survive the harsh environment and to understand the game mechanics.
After meeting the first giants you will get a more deep understanding, what survival means, when the burning sun in summer or the shadow creatures that appear when you lost sanity in spring because the frequent rain depleted your sanity didn't kill you until then.

And this is only tip of the iceberg.
There is Adventure Mode in the Story Mode which gives you different gameplay compared to the bare survival
There are different Giants that appear in different seasons
There are the caves you can jump in
There are the add-ons that give almost a completely different gameplay:
 - Shipwrecked with islands to hop over
 - Hamlet with Pig Villages
 - Reign Of Giants with a lot of extra resources and stuff to encounter
And much more

If you like unique survival games with well balanced game mechanics and crafting, you might like this game and I recommend it to you.
If you do not want to learn a lot and you really don't like to start over and over again at the beginning, you might avoid this game.

At the end, Klei Entertainment made it to stay to their uniqe style of games and this counts a lot nowadays in my humble opinion.

In short yes, the game is super fun. If you like difficult games and don't mind sinking a lot of hours in, reading the wiki or watching Youtube tutorials, then this is the game for you. You can get it on sale for super cheap and I've played this game along with the together version and will continue to do so.

The problem is that the game doesn't tell you how to do anything. Don't get me wrong, it's fun to figure stuff out on your own. But how am I supposed to know that giving meat to a bird in a bird cage enables me to make amazing new food or that bunnymen will attack you just because of you holding meat items, causing me to die 15+ hours into my run. I know dying, learning from your mistakes and starting over is the whole point of the game, but it can get frustrating and repetitive.

Also certain parts of the game like the adventure/story mode are poorly designed in my opinion. It's running around searching for random items on your map for 4 levels, just for you to die on level 5 because you didn't know the final level was in total darkness.

Reading the wiki, watching Youtube tutorial and using mods like display food values, geometric placement, craft pot and minimap feel like necessities for me to enjoy this game.

This game really sucks, it's just kind of backwards and inconsitently confusing. You wander around and you'll die, you stay still you'll die. The basic items for your character could spawn right next to you or 3 miles away and soft lock your progress for 2 weeks. It's random in all the wrong ways. 

It's keen on pushing you to explore the world but then punishes you for doing so, you have a tiny hunger bar and very few ways to respawn or regain health. Even eating only gives you 1-5 health, the later game foods at least the ones I've tried give you zero health at all. Despite the massive amount of effort put into them. 

It wants you to explore but every ten minutes the lights shut off and you're forced to either a slow crawl with nearly no light or a complete stand still. 

Pretty much any plan or strategy you make is pointless because the items you need for it could be fiften miles away or spawn right next to you. 

Travel is dreadfully slow even with worm holes (random chance to go where you're trying to get.) and paths (double your speed.) 

Every world is stupidly massive, but its hardcore mode no respawns. And with enemies that can easiely one shot you. Why would you ever take the risk to leave your comfy base? Because the devs said so, they'll send as many enemies to pester and kill you as needed to force you to do what they want.

Pretty much the whole game is just random chance, the devs decided to leave it to random chance to enjoy the game. Except the things that ruin your game, its not random when enemies will spawn to come and kill you. It's not random to starve to death. Only things that are enjoyable are random, only progression is random. 

Imagine if every time you took a dump you had a 1 in 5 chance of exploding and dying. That's what this game feels like, a random tedious chore where you die at the end.

For reasons I can no longer recall, I bought [url=store.steampowered.com/app/322330/Dont_Starve_Together/]Don't Starve Together[/url] shortly after buying this game, so I didn't end up playing this game all that much, as I chose to play with friends instead. However, I decided to revisit this game again recently to see how they compare, and after playing it a bit, I just can't recommend this game when the multiplayer version exists.

This game is very similar in many ways to the multiplayer version. Much like the multiplayer version, the game simply dumps you out into a world and lets you try to figure out how to survive without explaining anything. The world is fairly unique and interesting, but like the multiplayer version, this game also has permadeath, and unlike the multiplayer version, there's no settings to make this easier, so the game basically expects you to repeatedly die to things you had no way to see coming to slowly learn over time. This may be a fun gameplay loop for some, but I unfortunately just found this tedious and frustrating. It's even more frustrating when things you've learned in the multiplayer version don't apply quite the same, as you're never quite sure if the things you've learned in one game will apply in the other, and this game is also missing some quality of life features that have made the multiplayer version more approachable as well (such as the compendium). This game also doesn't really seem to be getting updated anymore either, while the multiplayer version is still getting frequent updates.

The only thing this game seems to have over the multiplayer version is the existence of story content, which is pretty cool, as I've always missed this when playing the multiplayer version. Unfortunately, the story content in this game still seems pretty sparse, and it appears to primarily found in something called Adventure Mode, where you're tasked with entering five separate brand new worlds that are modified to be even more challenging. This was pretty disappointing for me, as I was looking forwards to getting lore which was missing from the multiplayer version, but starting over in a brand new (and harder) world five times in a row without dying once was just too much to ask when I was already having a hard time justifying spending time in this game when the multiplayer version exists.

The game does still have the extremely good, iconic art style that the series is known for, and I didn't encounter any bugs while playing this game.

[b]TL;DR[/b] This survival game has a great art style, runs well, and has a unique world to explore. However, the multiplayer version of this game Don't Starve Together is simply better, as it allows you to play with friends, has quality of life features that are missing from this game, and is still getting updates, which doesn't appear to be the case for this game. The story content is the only thing this game has that the multiplayer version doesn't, but it's far too sparse and the game requires a lot of work to reach it, so if you're really interested in this game, I'd highly recommend looking at [url=store.steampowered.com/app/322330/Dont_Starve_Together/]Don't Starve Together[/url] instead.

Don't Starve, according to its overwhelmingly positive reviews, is a great game. If you think you'd like it, you probably will.

Unfortunately, I didn't.

Don't Starve is a survival crafter with no tutorial and no explanation. This fits the other-world horror theme of how you suddenly found yourself in this strange and confusing universe. I can appreciate the lack of handholding. Is that red or green mushroom going to heal you or hurt you? One way to find out!

When I say no explanation, I mean [b]no explanation[/b]. You do not see how much damage your axe does, or how effective your armor is. I found multiple headgears. What do they do? Who knows! Just pay attention and maybe you'll find out!

When you die, you start over completely. The only progress you make is the knowledge you take with you.
(Hopefully that mushroom didn't finish you off!)

While it's a rare take on crafter games to be so unforgiving, I can get behind it. I enjoy a good challenge and mystery.

Except... man, oh man, is it going to feel repetitive going through your lessons.

If your game is going to force players to go through the same motions over and over and over again, you better make sure that experience feels smooth. And [u][i]that[/i][/u] is really the sin of the game. Everything feels clunky.

Combat? Clunky. You'll have to "kite" all your enemies. Stab, run back, stab, run back, stab, run back. Very rote.

Inventory management? Clunky.

It all just feels like... "What's the point?"

The theme did not sufficiently carry the day.

Great game with fantastic art and rich survival mechanics. I'm likely just bad nowadays, but I found the gameplay rather routine—it's still good though.

I don't like games where I feel like I'm forced to do bad things. The humanoid pigs in the game are neutral and can speak. There's really not justification to kill them, but many crafting recipes require items obtained by killing the pig people or destroying their houses.

My other complaint about the game is that it is extremely unforgiving when learning. I feel like several of my deaths were just because it was the first time I encountered a new monster, event, food, etc. I know I could brute force my way through by playing and dying lots of times, but I would have to invest far too much time learning that way. One way to address this issue at least with foods would be to clearly explain whether or not a food is going to hurt the character (e.g., +10 hunger, -10 health).

My third issue is that it's not clear how much damage weapons are doing. It's hard to tell if one item is better or worse than another. 

Inventory management is a pain. If I'm in my base I should have access to all my items in all nearby chests for crafting rather than constantly digging through different chests.

DOTA 2 remains one of the most strategically complex and competitively balanced multiplayer games available, offering near-endless depth through its vast hero pool and dynamic itemization. The game’s constant updates and meta shifts keep both casual players and professionals engaged, ensuring that no strategy remains dominant for long. Its matchmaking system, while occasionally criticized, generally succeeds in creating challenging and rewarding games that test mechanical skill and strategic thinking. The esports scene surrounding DOTA 2 is exceptionally rich, featuring high-stakes tournaments like The International that showcase world-class talent and innovation. Overall, DOTA 2 stands out as a demanding yet deeply satisfying experience for players who appreciate mastery, teamwork, and ever-evolving tactical gameplay.

Management sims, and especially sports management sims, have always been my bag. I've won National Championships in the old EA NCAA games, started a expansion team in 2K, and even had CM Punk retire due to a drug addiction in one of my many fake wrestling promotions. But nothing compares to the stories that have come from the various iterations of Football Manager. 

Part of it is simply how complex soccer is. There are hundreds of leagues and thousands of players. And the game itself can be very complicated. A player who is amazing in one scheme can be dogshit in another. Even egos and personality types come into play -- I distinctly remember one Liverpool save where I bought Harry Kane and it caused my whole team to mutiny. 

Sports games all come with management modes now, but compared to the depth of Football Manager it's like the difference between swimming in the deep end and wading in a kiddie pool. It's not for everyone but if this is your type of game it doesn't get better than this.
Difficult to master but can create real tension hoping for that late equalizer or winner.  Fun to play in any division.

Football Manager (FM) isn't just about numbers and text to those who understand its magic. It's a realm where dreams take shape, where the fervor for football finds its digital haven.

Within this simulated universe, every notion and hope a fan harbors for their beloved club can materialize. Whether orchestrating the rise of a prestigious club to triple-crown glory or navigating the challenges of a lower-tier team, each stride forward is a personal conquest. You might assume the guise of a savvy dealmaker, wheeling and dealing for profit, or opt for unorthodox methods, nurturing a squad of homegrown talent like your own progeny. The game allows for hands-on involvement in every facet or the luxury of delegating tasks, assuming the role of a contented overseer.

My journey with FM spans numerous years—just me, my trusty computer, a flask of coffee, and a journal. No breaks, no shortcuts. Ahead of every match, I meticulously analyze opponents, fine-tune tactics, and maintain an extensive library of football literature for insights. The highs of nail-biting victories and the lows of gut-wrenching defeats are etched in my memory. I can still vividly recall the heartbreak of losing a Champions League final on penalties to Atletico Madrid, feeling the weight of defeat akin to Mourinho himself. Yet, there are those indelible moments, like Ruben Neves' last-minute heroics against Liverpool, clinching the Premier League title for my team. At the final whistle, I pumped my fist in triumph, wanting to shout from the rooftops, "I reign supreme!"

Years of leadership have witnessed resignation in the face of board disagreements, accompanied by the poignant departure of loyal staff. Witnessing homegrown talents blossom fills me with paternal pride, while lackluster performances stir frustration, sometimes prompting me to pound the table, yearning for halftime substitutions. These genuine emotions of elation, fury, anguish, and mirth distinguish FM—it's not just a game; it's a slice of life.

This iteration of FM stands as a testament to its predecessors, boasting refinement and depth. Despite its flaws—the missed opportunities, the erratic crossing of wingers—its allure remains irresistible. Launching Football Manager, you can envision yourself on the pitch, amid the scent of freshly mown grass, with players by your side. As you bask in the adulation of fans, their chants echoing, their anthems composed for you, there's nothing quite like it.

For those uninitiated into this fantastical realm, ensure you have your player face packs, team logos, 2D and 3D kit packs, and authentic trophy images at the ready. And for aspiring coaches seeking these enhancements, don't hesitate to reach out.

Football Manager 2020 isn't just a game; it's a deep dive into the world of football management. The level of detail in this game is astounding – from player transfers to tactical decisions, it encapsulates the essence of being at the helm of a football club. What really stands out is the game's realistic transfer market and the dynamic nature of player interactions. You feel the weight of every decision, whether it's in training sessions or crucial matches. The 3D match engine brings your tactical choices to life, adding a visually engaging layer to your strategies. The learning curve is steep, but once you get the hang of it, it's incredibly rewarding. Whether you're a seasoned veteran of the series or a newcomer with a passion for football, Football Manager 2020 offers an immersive experience that’s hard to put down. A must-play for anyone who fantasizes about managing a top-tier football club.

FM20 is the first FM game I really sank my teeth into after becoming legitimately interested in the sport, albeit I didn't start playing it in earnest until 2022. The series as a whole is a monumental achievement in simulation, even with its flaws, and there are many. If you're playing FM, you're not playing it for great graphics or sound, or even necessarily amazing gameplay, but for the sheer depth and detail of the simulated world, with thousands upon thousands of real players and teams meticulously coded in in a way that FIFA could only dream of.

FM is also amazing at giving you moments of pure emotion as you watch a game unfold. It really does feel like a mixture of actually having the game be in your hands, while still watching it as a spectator or fan. One of the most memorable FM20 moments for me was when my Arsenal side came back from 4-0 down to Manchester City at halftime to draw 4-4 with the last action of the game in an absolute masterclass of a second half. The sheer joy when Bastoni scored that header was one of the highest highs I've ever had from a video game, and that includes much bigger achievements in that same save. That was the moment that launched the most successful Premier League season that Arsenal have ever had. But not just joy, but sadness, and anger also. A football season is long and arduous and you will always have failures, and they hurt. But FM is great for all of those moments; it feels like you're really going through a season, with all the highs and lows, and that's what FM is best for.

What I like about this game, over FM 22 and 23, which I've also played, is the interaction interface. In more recent games they've made this terrible change where most of the screen is empty except for a single dialogue bit from your player, and then all of your options crammed at the bottom of the screen. This is awful for my poor eyesight. In this game things are more centered and obvious. Also, the change they made in later games to hide the energy level numbers in favor of hearts? Also not a fan, both because I'd prefer things to be less obtuse, even if it's less realistic, and again for vision purposes.

Of course this version missing things I've grown to quite like, like the date hub and more agent interactions, and players deteriorate in quality too quickly in this game, while in later entries they age a bit more gracefully, which is more realistic. FM23 also has the UEFA licenses, which is nice, though I suspect pretty much anyone who plays this mods in such things anyway.

Overall FM20 is still worth revisiting if you have it, to play out certain kinds of games, even if you have later entries.

I have to give my due to one of the venerable pillars of the simulation genre, which is still going strong today. It quickly became one of my most played franchises of all time, and I don't anticipate that changing anytime soon.

I've played Football Manager since the very beginning when it was called Championship Manager. I have watched how it has slowly grown and became so much more realistic over the years. Unfortunately is is now going backwards. The database and game itself is second to none. The tactics of the game is awful. Managers do not need to change their tactics and tweak every 10 or so games because the opposition figure them out. The best managers in the world have used the same tactics for a decade. Altering it to change the flow now and again. They let the opposition worry about them and not changing a tactic because they might get beat. They change the system within the game. FM20 is the worst ever for this. Just when you get a decent tactic you have to start all over again. This is just not realistic. Because of this FM20 will be my last addition. The game is now dead. I think eventually everyone will get sick of having to create a new tactic 3 times a season. Its just isn't a Football sim anymore where you pit your strategy against other managers, even if they are AI they should all still have their own character and styles. Instead, you are playing against the same AI regardless of what team your playing against.  Goodbye FM. Thanks for the years of entertainment. RIP.

As an avid fan of the fm series stretching back to CM 04 - the year I started I woudl consider myself a veteran. The last version I played was FM 2017. Decided to pick the 2020 version curious as to what AI modifications and improvements had been made. I have been left dissapointed
- It seems som of the underlying algorithms have changed. It is much harder to scores goals to the point that you need 10 chances on target pr goal.  There are matches that have generated 2 clear cut chances and up to 20 shots on target that have ended 0-0.  The fun factor and gravitational pull for me has definately been removed because goals are now at a premium.
- The game crashes - I have never experienced FM crashes in any of the  previous versions. Yet on this version 2020 and playing on a laptop with a core I7 processor - I encounter occasional "freezes" in particular after having been awarded a penalty meaning you have to shut down and start afresh.  Despite following the youtube guides on how to resolve this issues - the crashes still happen from time to time.
- The beauty of the FM series was that over time you sensed that your imprint on the team would be more  and more discernable - your style of pay and so on. The interaction between you as a player and your team was what provided the incredible gravitational pull to this game. I don't feel that in this version. I think I will revert back to FM2017 which is everything that 2020 is not.

I can remember over the years looking forward to the next fm being introduced but sadly that is no longer the case. FM 16 or 17 were about the last decent games in he series but since then FM has been bogged down with far too much detail. Pages and pages of useless information to wade through before you even get close to a game of football. Not for me I certainly won,t be buying FM2021.

The game has become unplayable and it's irritatingly gotten worse each year so unless FM21 is a vast improvement I won't be spending my money or time on it.  I loved the concept of being able to Manage football teams and bring them up through the leagues and win trophy's etc. but you can only enjoy this game if you skip over the live matches which unfortunately (for the logic of the game itself) is what makes real Football exciting. Why skip the matches?  Because the AI has a script that influences the outcome of games.  For example, you have Defensive players that hoof the ball forward for no reason, while under no pressure.  Guess what happens most times?  The other team gathers the ball, counterattacks and scores and this happens despite the fact that players traits or tactics were changed to avoid long kicks forward.  You have players directed to mark opponents closely under a defensive tactic and you end up with opponent players unmarked for 20-30 meters.  Guess how that ends up? Defenders under no pressure heading back balls to opponents distanced 10-20 meters away.  Players getting outrun or outpaced by opponents with lower Attribute abilities.  I could list dozen and dozen more little 'tricks' that the AI uses to decide the outcome of games.  All of which takes away from the purpose of the game which is your ability to Manage a Football team.  Penalties, send offs are all heavily unbalanced against your team.  The game also lacks comeback scores (unless it's the AI's team).  If you go down 2-0, forget about trying to draw or even worse, to win.  In honesty it not something that happens often in real games but it's almost impossible in FM20. Bottom Line: Make the game more exciting like real football games can be and get rid of the scripts!

[b]TL;DR - If you've basically been playing football manager in your head and are looking for a game that will let you move from your head and onto the screen; maybe this game is for you.

If you're a fan of management / simulation games, looking for something to get stuck into, but don't live, eat, and breathe football then stay [i]well[/i] clear of Football Manager 2020.[/b]

So, this probably goes without saying, but don't pick up this game unless you're already, like, [i]really[/i] into football; I received a key as part of a humble bundle, so figured I would give it a go and...yeah, nah.

The game makes a lot of assumptions before you begin:

[list]
[*] You already know a lot of technical information about football
[*] You already know what you want to do in the game before you play
[*] You already know how you would go about achieving those goals IRL
[/list]

The process of starting the game for the first time is absurdly long; I assumed I was still in an installer for a long time before I realised that all of the setup I'd been doing was actually just part of the game.

The weirdest part of it all as well, is that it does all of this [b]in absolute silence[/b] - there is no music at all, and the UI is completely silent; no clicks on buttons, no confirmations, no hover sounds. I spoke with my flatmate and apparently this isn't a bug, it's just how the game works.  The effect is eerie as heck.

In terms of onboarding - nope. Afraid not. There's no gradual introduction of variables and features to ease you into the game, it just throws everything at you at once! The tutorial consists of, I kid you not, an inescapable sequence of tooltips that explains how to use the UI without explaining what any of the player stats do, or explaining what you should do.

To put the strangeness into perspective: I don't need a degree in civil engineering or an all-consuming occupation with town-planning in order to find the fun in a city-building game - unfortunately that's not the case with Football Manager 2020.

A World That Pulls You In...
Hours Played: 21.4 hrs (at time of review)
Recommended? 👍 Yes

After 21.4 hours, I can confidently say Elden Ring is one of the most immersive experiences I’ve had in gaming. The world feels alive — every corner hides something worth discovering, whether it’s a new boss, a hidden dungeon, or just breathtaking scenery. The combat is punishing but fair, and every victory feels earned.
What really stands out is the freedom: you’re never forced down a single path. I’ve spent hours just exploring, finding my own way, and still feel like I’ve only scratched the surface. The sense of scale and mystery keeps me hooked, and I’m loving every moment.
If you enjoy challenging combat, deep lore, and a world that rewards curiosity, Elden Ring is absolutely worth it.

[h1] Elden Ring: The Triumph and Agony of an Open World in the Spirit of FromSoftware [/h1] 

Elden Ring is not just another RPG from the creators of Dark Souls, but a bold experiment at the intersection of genres. The game combines hardcore «souls‑like» action, a vast open world, and a deep character customization system. For fans of the series, it is both a long‑awaited evolution of ideas and a challenge: there are no easy breaks here, but there is plenty of room for creativity. Immersion into the world of the Lands Between turns into a marathon where every victory is a small personal revolution.

[h2] Strengths: Why the Game Became a Cult Classic [/h2]
First and foremost, [i] Elden Ring [/i] is three games in one: a classic «souls» title with punishing bosses, a sandbox with boundless exploration opportunities, and an RPG with near‑infinite character customization. The meticulously crafted gameplay keeps players on edge — every battle demands full concentration, and death serves as a lesson rather than a failure. A wide array of combat mechanics (melee combat, magic, ranged attacks, spirit summoning) encourages tactical experimentation.
The character progression variety is truly impressive: the attribute system ([i] Vigor, Mind, Endurance, etc. [/i]) and the [i] Ashes of War [/i] mechanic grant players the freedom to create unique builds — from a stealthy sorcerer to a mighty greathammer warrior. The diverse roster of bosses (from colossal dragons to nimble assassins) ensures constant engagement, with their distinct attack patterns demanding careful study of every move.
The authentic dark fantasy aesthetic crafts an atmosphere of both despair and grandeur: crumbling castles, eerie forests, and desolate plains resemble sets for an epic tragedy. The deliberate, hint‑based storytelling rewards exploration — every nook and cranny might conceal a treasure. The locations are distinct from one another: from snow‑capped peaks to poisonous swamps, each zone boasts its own visual style and gameplay mechanics.

[h2] Weaknesses: Where the Game Falls Short [/h2]
The main drawback is the vast open world, which sometimes feels empty. Long journeys between key points can become tedious, and certain areas fail to meet players’ expectations. The initial story zones are not sufficiently engaging: the early bosses and locations don’t deliver the adrenaline rush that series fans are accustomed to.
An overabundance of quests creates chaos: many side missions are disconnected from one another, and their objectives often contradict each other. The plot remains obscure even after many hours of play — it’s nearly impossible to grasp without diving deep into the lore. The world is extremely uninformative: there are no hints, marked maps, or NPC guides, which might discourage new players.
The repetitive patterns of some bosses are a trade‑off for the game’s scale: giant creatures often boil down to “dodge sweeping attacks”, while mages usually follow the “wait out the cast” pattern. This diminishes the sense of uniqueness, especially in the later stages of the game.

[h2] Conclusion: A Masterpiece with Rough Edges [/h2]
[i] Elden Ring [/i] is an ambitious project that redefines the genre. Its strengths — versatility, atmosphere, and combat system — outweigh its flaws, though the latter are certainly noticeable. The game demands time, patience, and a love for exploration; for those willing to immerse themselves in its world, it offers unforgettable experiences.
This is not just «another souls game» — it’s a statement: an open world can be challenging, beautiful, and endlessly engaging. If you’re ready for the challenges and crave the freedom of choice, the Lands Between await.

[h3] [i] Score: 9/10 [/i] [/h3]
[i] For its boldness, scale, and that very «souls‑like» magic that keeps bringing players back time and time again. [/i]

This review is a bunch of nitpicking but the more I go back and play the older From games the more I'm disappointed with this game:

The open world itself is forgettable since it poses zero challenge to the player.  You can just turn your brain off and run past every enemy with zero punishment. People still reminisce about their first time in Blight Town or facing those two guys down the well in Bloodborne. There is literally nothing of sort in Elden Ring.

The small dungeons spread out in the open world sometimes have interesting gimmicks but usually end with you killing a reused boss and being rewarded something you'll never end up using. Bloodborne chalices had random layouts, a decent amount of  enemies/bosses not in the regular game and gave you a reason to do them in Blood gems. All that and most people still skipped them. Ubisoft level bloat for people who don't realize more playtime doesn't make a game better. 

Legacy dungeons, you don't even want to explore because after doing a few you realize the only decent content the game has are the bosses. DS1 was praised for the inteconnected world, DS2 and 3 still had shortcuts you could discover by exploring.  The level design once again devolved with ER, with a grace around every corner the shortcuts and the relief from finally finding one are mostly gone. 

Bosses, I've died to Malenia, Messmer and Radahn dozens of times yet none of them gave me the same dopamine hit from killing Gael or Orphan in maybe one fifth of the tries. It feels like 90% of the challenge with all these big bad bosses are their one or two crazy moves. You'll die over and over to Waterfowl or the big snake combo Messmer has until you figure out when and which way to roll or run. You'll never get that adrenaline rush from getting a boss to 5-10% your first try because these moves solely exist to make older players not whine about everything else by giving the illusion of difficulty while still letting the new "broader audience" tank half the combos with their summon. This contrast in difficulty between the world and the bosses also makes the game feel like a boss rush rather than an adventure like the older games.

Narrative, they don't leave things to imagination much compared to the older games. Ranni probably blogs more about the story than the entirety of DS1 dialogue. Around the same amount of NPC questlines in a much bigger world makes the world feel even more barren. Through 3 playthroughs I haven't noticed a Solaire, Lucatiel or Anri. Someone on a similar journey, living their own life you come across multiple times. Maybe they exist but the world isn't interesting enough for me to go find them.

Multiplayer, covenants are gone, invasions are opt-in. All the fun sucked out of it because god forbid the people who already look up everything online would have to look up how to turn invasions off too.

It's still an okay game but I'm worried where FromSoft is heading. I don't care if some guy who didn't have the dedication to beat the older games now gets to have fun beating bosses with spells/summons/weapon arts as long as it doesn't end up making the game a worse experience but the multiple steps backwards taken in level/world design, narrative, multiplayer are clearly an attempt to make the game more appealing to them, and it affects everyone.
Even the content people create has gone downhill, from meme videos, challenges and invasions to weapon/spell/x rankings, how to cheese x boss and loreslop (FUCK VAATI)

And what's up with the "Open World"-formula? It's empty and shallow, and sometimes even reminiscent of a Bethesda game like Oblivion, SkyRim, Fallout 3 or 4. There is a lot to love if you like these types of games, especially the DLC which excluding the final boss is my favorite part of the game.

Enter the Gungeon is an absolute triumph of a game and a must-play for anyone who enjoys challenging, rewarding action. From the moment you pick it up, it’s clear that this is a game crafted with a profound love for its genre and a meticulous attention to detail.

The core gameplay loop is incredibly addictive. It's a top-down, bullet-hell rogue-lite that perfectly blends precise shooting mechanics with the thrill of randomized dungeon crawling. Each run feels fresh and exciting, thanks to the vast array of weapons and items you can discover. And "vast" is an understatement—the sheer creativity on display is staggering. You’ll find everything from a gun that shoots bees to one that fires t-shirts, all contributing to a uniquely chaotic and charming experience.

Dodge Roll, the developers, have infused the game with a personality that shines through every pixelated corner. The art style is gorgeous, the humor is spot-on (the "Gundead" enemies are a particular highlight), and the subtle references hidden throughout the Gungeon are a joy to uncover.

Yes, the game is difficult. It’s a bullet-hell, after all. You will die. A lot. But the beauty of Enter the Gungeon lies in its progression system. You constantly unlock new weapons, items, and characters, ensuring that every failure feels like a step toward a deeper understanding of the game’s mechanics. The learning curve is steep but incredibly satisfying to master. Executing a perfect dodge roll through a storm of bullets and clearing a room of enemies feels incredibly rewarding.

Ultimately, Enter the Gungeon is a masterclass in game design. It's challenging, charming, replayable, and a genuinely joyous experience. It's a game that respects your time and rewards your skill, making it an easy recommendation for anyone looking for a new obsession. Lock and load; you won't regret entering this Gungeon!

I can’t quite see the appeal of this game. As a roguelike, its RNG design feels off. There’s a large pool of weapons, but in practice they barely differ beyond DPS. Meanwhile, the maps, enemy encounters, and bosses vary so little that runs feel like pre-designed stages rather than true roguelike experiences. Character building also feels shallow: you rarely get meaningful choices at chests or shops—most of the time you’re stuck with a simple take-it-or-leave-it decision.

The reloading mechanics are a terrible idea for this kind of game, and after each run you feel like you’ve accomplished nothing.

I played this game right as it released so that should be taken into consideration if you read this review.

That said ... I hate this game, lmao.  The RNG was unbelievably obnoxious.  I can appreciate a difficult game, but when your success relies on a certain amount of RNG in order to reliably handle the more difficult content yet the RNG is absolutely horrendous and the item pool isn't all that great ... well, let's just say my experiences overall sucked pretty hard thanks to that.

I managed to beat the game a few times which for sure was great the first time I managed to do it ... but the time it took between runs in order to actually have a powerful enough setup to reliably complete the game completely killed all of my motivation and drive to keep playing this game for years to come.

I don't know how it is now.  I never gave the updates a chance because my experiences were such a pain in the ass, even when people told me "Oh it's so much better now, they did x y z" too little too late, man, I was already sick of this game.

It was almost good ... but really ... it was just another copy of BoI in the end.

Also, with news of Enter the Gungeon 2 coming out, I'm removing this game from my account and putting both on ignore.  If EtG 2 is anything like what I experienced with the first game, then there's absolutely no FOMO for me and I'm better off pretending it doesn't exist.

This game has failed multiple times to care for my time - it is not worth playing for runs where one simply cannot get a new gun even after clearing everything and my index finger can only click so many times before it goes numb shooting at the Ammoconda with the starter pistol.

Was I supposed to involuntarily participate in a challenge where the starter weapon is the only weapon? Was I supposed to shoot only by holding the mouse, making me have to care about when to reload? I was not given guns in a game called "Enter the Gungeon" ... more like "Enter the geon", if you ask me. Unbalanced and annoying.

A good run will take an hour in both games, but in NT that hour is full of action whereas here you spend a lot of time walking through empty rooms looking for treasure chests. It's not good.

Before I start an important disclaimer:

If you are prone to epileptic seizures or in any way sensitive to strobe lights, DO NOT ABSOLUTELY DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. This game spams strobe lights like it's Christmas, from beginning of the game to finish. If you play this game and you're an epileptic, you will be as dead as this game's protagonist, before even the intro ends.

But yeah, this game. It's pretty flawed.

As I said before, this game spams strobe lights. It also has it's hard to pronounce name, as well as this 3d pixel style that to be perfectly honest, looks kinda ugly. 

The gameplay is the weakest part of Continue, because you are so reliant on rng to not screw you over it's ridiculous. See, in each stage, with gc stages being the only exceptions, your goal is to escape the stage with lightning, while building shelters for gc stages with your prayers. However, lightning strikes at random, so it's entirely possible to have your run ruined all because lightning struck the same already cleared location three times. This is tolerable on large in length levels, but if you get bad lightning strikes on somewhere like the Riverbanks, your run is pretty much over, because you cannot escape in time.

The plot? This game does seem to have a story, but it's a jumbled unconnected mess. Each stage has its own story, its own history, but its all disconnected from the protagonist, which are shuffled everytime you restart the game anyway. The only thing we know for sure is what's on the cover.

And yet, despite all that, despite all these problems, I still love this game. A lot.

The music and the atmosphere are some of the places where this game shines. I don't remember the last time I felt so peaceful when playing a video game. I would download the whole OST if I could. The filters and the sound effects, give the game a weird broken console dream simulator quality that I can't really explain. That, combined with some really touching scenes and you have yourself a game that made me cry at several times.

There's also the message itself. As someone who had troubles accepting the idea of dying herself, I was completely repelled by this game when I first saw it. It seemed to me like just as a game so dark and so obsessed with its own darkness, that it would be completely unenjoyable. It wasn't. It was a journey, complete with thoughts and feelings people may have when they confront their own mortality. And it ended up being one of the most serene games I have ever played in my entire life. I haven't expected to be so pleasantly surprised at all.

So final verdict? I dunno. I can see why people can be turned off by the message and the gameplay and other things. The dev himself said that he made this game this way SPECIFICALLY to repel CoD brogamer dudes. From the name itself, to pretty generic gameplay, I get it. Still, I'd say give it a chance.

If you love these cerebral, borderline-walking simulator type games that are very emotional and sad, maybe this game will give you something. If you are like me and are struggling with accepting your own demise, maybe this game will help you not worry about your own mortality as much and even accept it like it did for me. If you are looking for some neat gameplay or a story heavy game, pass. This game will not satisfy you. And if you're prone to epileptic seizures, dear god stay away.

I don't really know what this game is about. I feel like the message underneath the game is a serious one, and certainly existential at that, but it's honestly lost on me. I want to like it for being different and interesting, but I'm having a hard time doing just that in the face of obscurity. 

At the end of the day...I like it? I guess?

Far from being worth 10 dollar obviously, but not a bad game / experience AT ALL! (imo)

I got it for a small price on humble so i am happy i have this game.

Maybe i'd be pissed if i did pay 10 bucks tho...
This game is not for the "average" game player. I love this game, however!!!
A very thought provoking game. Even better if you know about computers. A little sad.

Continue?9876543210 is an interesting game with some potential for frustration. It's somewhat mysterious and pretty good at creating tension while aiming to bring about its philosophical conclusion. We see deliberately low-poly 3D graphics which nevertheless are easily translated into "the world".
The game expects the player to go for several, slightly changing run-throughs, not all of which let the player get to the end. The player is mostly playing on limited time but can sort of recover in mostly unskippable cut-scenes. Will you find the strength to go on or will you find the strength to rest?

+ Nice low-poly design
+ Good music and good atmosphere
+ Special exits
+ Live stories
+ Restarting areas
0 "On the clock"
0 A tad short
- Bad restart method - "Have you tried turning it off and on again?"
- Camera is sort far-sighted
- Fade-ins waste time and make it harder to react
- Controls somewhat lacking
- Incomplete menu with and ambiguous option

The game features a number of modes. There is investigation mode where you run around an area or level, talk to people and gather knowledge which is needed to find an exit from the area and build up shelters, all within a time limit (except for the first level which has slightly different rules). That mode already shows how the camera is sort of far-sighted when giving a perspective view. Enemies will randomly and with increasing ferocity and frequency spawn around you. While the perspective view shows enemies or people in the background pretty well, it's hard to see things in the foreground. This is coupled with the foreground also often going down. So it is possible that you run the avatar towards the foreground/player, run over an edge, be in the air and without control over the avatar while unknowingly steering into an enemy. You have a sword to fight of enemies but to use it effectively you still need to know where enemies are.

Running into an enemy brings you into an action mode of always the same type where you have to fight of a number of enemies approaching you from the air while you play in a 2D brawler fashion, think minimalistic smash brothers. Those fights are easy but time-consuming at first but grow challenging and fast over the levels/investigation areas.
Hint: When jumping and attacking in the air go into the direction the avatar is not looking to make an overhead swing.

Each investigation areas also features up to three other action modes where you are thrown in one of a number of, let's say, mini-games. There are some where you have to find an exit, there are some where you have kill objectives and there is even one where you simply go right.
Action modes mostly offer treasure and performance-based rewards, but failing them results in harsh consequences.

The third mode is a shelter mode where you need to hide from impending doom. It's paramount to have gathered enough shelters or this is where the avatar gets GC'ed.

While cut-scenes offer time for recovery and breaks - they prompt the player before continuing - they are mostly unskippable and it may take you upwards from 30 seconds to get into an investigative area. This is unnerving in connection with the restart feature. You can restart the current investigative area if you feel like you didn't get enough out of it - the game autosaves at the beginning of an investigative area. While the game tells you restarting is an option it doesn't tell you how to realise that option. Instead of clicking the button "Start Over" in the menu and confirming the reset you have to kill the application and restart it, then you are loaded back into the area.
The reset instead means starting the whole run over and losing all progress, not just that of the last area. Imagine my happiness when I found out.

Apart from the "far-sighted camera" problem there is another one with visuals. While investigating you are required to enter houses. When you subsequently leave them the main area fades in, i.e. the world is turned back on before you can see clearly. While you can remember positions of enemies or people and interact with them blindly you are more likely to run into a problematic situation all while running out of time.

Action modes have a number of control problems. First off, navigation is sometimes hard because you don't always know which things you can pass over and which things present an obstacle.
Then, I often felt like I couldn't turn fast enough with incoming enemies. When trying to stab enemies you sometimes only hit when your sword is at or near full extension. So despite facing the enemy and presenting good points they will hit you anyway, reduce your performance and hinder progress in the meta-game.
Specifically the last and fix action mode where you need to turn and jump had me failing jumps multiple times because "up" is somehow not available  when being pressed while changing directions. And yes, I specifically bought a keyboard where ghosting doesn't happen when only two keys are pressed.

I found the gathering of knowledge surprisingly fun, the random life stories are effective towards the game's philosophical goal and I enjoyed the special exits you can find. Even though I played through the game with "full points" I have yet to see some parts of the game.
If you're not immediately put off by its graphical style, I'd say give this a go. With all the little short-comings listed above, I, maybe not highly but securely, recommend Continue?9876543210. Even with its relative shortness of six captivating hours its price tag compares well against the average movie.

"Oh little town
shelter me"

I don't know why people haven't tagged it this way, but its obvious that this game is a roguelite behind the messages and themes that it contains. Jason Oda covers the whole story aspect pretty well in the about section of the store page, so I will focus my review on the game beneath the facade.

The game mentions that you take on 6 out of 11 levels each playthrough, but these 11 levels appear to be split into two different types where there arent any major differences other than the graphics/map layout for levels of the same type.  The first type being a tag/hide and seek with npcs and the second, more frequent kind, is an open town where you talk with the npcs and try to gather keys,resources, and information. This repetition would be boring if it wasn't for the short minigames in between.

There are at least 5 different types of minigames ranging from platforming to Galaga to zelda dungeons and these different types can come in varying difficulties. If you succeed at the minigames, there is much to gain, especially if you play them perfectly, but they can also be rather dangerous

First off of the roguelite checklist, randomness. Random characters, random levels, random npcs, random minigames, randumb... The first two don't really make a difference, but the random npcs are what make the game. You'll have to get clues and keys from these npcs, but not all are to be trusted.  The npcs never seem to lie about information, so aside from getting some nonsense one liner that wastes your time talking to the npc, the worst they will do is sell you a trapped room. However, since you can get free, safe rooms from the rounds, the npcs really are the least of your problems. The information from the npcs will make otherwise random choices definite, but if you are really desperate for time or resources you can guess questions, although you don't really need to do that to beat the game.

The worst of all randomness is the lightning. The first kind of lightning is used to pave the way to an exit, but there are several exits and its possible that your lightning will hit an empty space, so it is easy for the lighting to be spread out and still not have an exit. These rolls will make or break your runs, they are the difference between having to focus all of your resources just to make it to the next level and being able to safely farm resources with impunity. Then there is the matter of having to find shelter in the storms. The randomness here has the potential to be more punishing when you have few buildings. Some buildings can take 1 or 2 lightning bolts and still stand for the next storm, but too few buildings and these tankier buildings are likelier to be destroyed. Despite all of the possible ways you can get fucked by the dice, you do have a decent bit of leeway to messup. Even if you get a few bad dice rolls, you should be able to make those up with resources from playing the minigames well.

Then there is the matter of death. You can use your various resources to get second chances once you 'die', but when you run out of those, you must start from the beginning.  Additionally, the penalty when using buildings to revive gets increasingly severe, while using money to revive, while a static cost, will prevent you from getting more buildings/lightning.

What do you get for replaying this game? Mostly you just get to see different specs of story/dialogue; however, actually seeking out the in game diaries will be detrimental to progressing to the end, but I suppose that's just part of the message with this kind of game. You'll see the different level art styles and see some different minigames, but thats about it. Some roguelites require you to play the game over and over to get direct benefits or crucial knowledge, but any useful knowledge is rerolled with each new game aside from knowing how to play a specific minigame.

In the end, its not close to being the hardest game of the genre since you dont need a truly perfect run to beat the game, but it isn't too simple either. Players have the option of playing the way the developer would, but you could also speedrun it too if you wanted to. I recommend both playing to win and playing to explore in order to get the most out of this game. Finally, for your own sanity, do not play this game in full screen mode unless you want to make it even harder, perhaps impossible.
Sometimes in this game, you know the game over on the next screen is inevitable no matter what you do. And that's pretty much the point.
