Blasphemous is a brutally beautiful Metroidvania that blends dark gothic-religious lore with tight hack‑and‑slash combat. You play as the Penitent One, exploring a twisted land called Cvstodia, fighting grotesque monsters, and uncovering deep, sorrow‑laden secrets.

Pros:

Stunning pixel art and a haunting, atmospheric world.

Hard-hitting, rewarding boss fights and combat.

Lots of build variety through relics, prayers, and abilities.

Rich, dark lore that feels unique and deeply unsettling.

Cons:

Platforming can feel finicky and punishing at times.

Some instant-death traps and cheap spike placements frustrate players.

Backtracking is often required, and fast-travel isn’t super generous.

The learning curve is steep; not super forgiving for newcomers.

Realistic Score: ~8.5/10 — It’s not perfect, but for fans of challenging action-metroidvanias with incredible style and atmosphere, Blasphemous is a deeply satisfying journey. Most players are very positive about it, but be ready for a dark, demanding ride.

Blasphemous is a Metroidvania developed by Spanish studio The Game Kitchen, a game that was successfully kick-started and a game I had my eye on since it was announced. 

I originally played this back on my switch but have picked it up again after many years. I remember really liking this game but remember seeing some reactions being a bit more lukewarm at the time, I do feel reception is certainly more positive and since replaying it on steam it's probably one of my favourites in the genre. It's a bit dark souls, a bit castlevania and a lot of Spanish Catholicism. 

I think the first thing that needs to be mentioned is the striking visual style, it's pixel art but it's absolutely gorgeous with incredible detail and design. The real star is the incredible art design, as mentioned above it's heavily inspired by Spanish Catholic iconography and this really helps create a unique and disturbing world. It's sin meets penitence in which the whole world seems to be in state of forgiveness whilst also undergoing bizarre and cruel punishments to atone for their sins. This point is really driven in when you discover you're playing as the The Penitent one, a mysterious silent figure that's looking for atonement. 

Gameplay is quite a rudimentary Metroidvania but this isn't a negative, it's the refinement of the formula that puts this game in high regards, the map is incredibly well designed, there are loads of secrets and quests with lots of interwoven paths. I genuinely enjoyed every biome in this game as they are deeply intriguing and fun to explore. It does have the typical health, magic and damage upgrades but thankfully you aren't hunting down heart fragments. You just get the upgrade when you find them which is nice. 

Combat is fun but does feel simplistic, it has a wide variety of moves you can unlock which are all basically useless and a magic system which is fairly simple. It's again not a bad thing and the extra tools are nice but don't seems necessarily useless to get through the game, the real fun comes from mastering the parry system and knowing when to strike, it has that slow deliberate dark souls style combat with you losing out on your magic meter if you die. It's not salt and sanctuary levels of 2d dark souls (god I hope these comparisons are making sense) but it does have that dark souls dna. 

Platforming is very basic and I see some discourse still exists around the clunky movement, I don't think this is an issue personally but the lack of mobility upgrades does mean you won't be double jumping around the map any time soon, there are a small handful of mobility upgrades but they come so late and they are optional meaning you can miss out on a lot of game. Also the one hit kill spikes are the worst. 

With all that said this is a fantastic metroidvania and one I think anyone who seriously enjoys the genre need to play. One of my favourites and I it's not a sin to admit it.

Blasphemous is not just a game, but a haunting and unforgettable religious experience delivered through gothic horror and stunning pixel art. It is a brutal, beautiful, and essential masterpiece for fans of dark fantasy.

Graphics and Visuals: At the peak of modern pixel art. The world of Cvstodia is a breathtaking nightmare of baroque architecture, grotesque monsters, and meticulous detail. The animations are fluid, impactful, and intensely visceral and stunning.

Music and Sound: World-class. The soundtrack features mournful pieces with Spanish and religious undertones, creating a heavy atmosphere filled with dread. The combat sound effects make the sword strikes feel weighty and responsive.

Mechanics and Gameplay: A perfect blend of Metroidvania and Souls-like. The combat system is precise and unforgiving, emphasizing parrying, dodging, and correct timing. The use of the Fervour meter for powerful abilities adds a strategic layer.

Exploration and Narrative: The map design is clever and full of secrets. Discovering shortcuts and new items is highly rewarding. The game's lore, conveyed through environmental details and item descriptions, possesses a terrifying depth and allure.

Conclusion: Blasphemous is a triumph of artistic vision and uncompromising game design. It is a challenging but fair experience that is highly recommended.

From the first trailer I knew that Blasphemous would be a masterpiece of artistic merit and expression. Even though I'd bounced off it the first time playing it, I recently came back to finally experience it fully. Is it a perfect experience? No. But there's a lot here to make it perfectly memorable.
First off, the story. Wow. Inherently tied to its design, Blasphemous tells a story about guilt and its twisted power, using Catholic mythology and aesthetics, but transforming that into its own thing. The world, characters and lore are simply phenomenal and very original. It's a joy to explore this world and uncover its secrets and twisting pathways. There's a giant cathedral, a buried enormous bell, and many many decrepit churches, either underground or atop frozen peaks with sculpted faces. Everything is so gothic and so beautiful to just look at and every location fits very well into the world of Cvstodia. The Penitent One is also a great protagonist, silent for a reason and deadly for another. He feels really good to control and move around, and every swing of the blade or step you make is beautifully enriched by excellent sound design. To this I'll point you to the OST by Carlos Viola, which is incredibly good. It fits the mood perfectly.
There's lots of secrets and collectibles to find too, and while I've had my fun backtracking to explore everything, I felt that by the end it was becoming tedious and there's stuff hidden behind a DLC which can only be experienced in NG+. This means one playthrough isn't enough to experience everything, which is made worse by the incredibly cryptic quest design. If you don't know where to go, what to get and who to speak to, you'll never get the actual true ending to this tale, so I recommend you use a guide. This is similar to Dark Souls nonsense and I was never a big fan of this approach, but I forgive it because artistically I just find it all so inspiring.
Ultimately this truly felt like a pilgrimage inside a world ruled by pain. The lore and setting here are unforgettable, even if the gameplay style isn't your thing. It's a really fun time too, but I felt it overstayed its welcome slightly by the end.

*I think it's also a Thumbs down for this game.*

I just reached the last boss's second phase a few minuets ago... and I was done. I quit the game and uninstalled it on the spot.

I wasted so much time dumping Tears of Atonement (Souls) into every move in the Combo Tree, Charged Tree, Vertical Tree, and Lunge Tree.
But against the final boss?
All I could really use were Ranged Tree shots, single upward hits, and if I got lucky, maybe two horizontal swipes from those appearing-and-disappearing platforms.
This isn't fun. It's not even hard. It's just tedious AF, with luck dictating where and when those platforms spawn. It doesn't test skill or give me any real choice in how I want to beat the boss. And god damn, what's with this creatively bankrupt move of slapping a boss with a bazillion, and I mean a qazillion, health points? 

The game was enjoyable once I unlocked some abilities. I don't care much about the story, but the world design is really cool, even if it's nothing new. It's basically Dark Souls with a fresh Halloween theme. I'm not big into platforming, but it was all decent enough.

What fascinates me about souls-likes is the world-building and exploration, plus how satisfying experience (Souls) collection and farming feels. I love grabbing new abilities and blasting through bosses as quickly as possible.

Getting stuck on one absolutely kills the game for me. In my opinion, bosses should just be a bit tougher than the regular mobs, and the final boss a notch stronger than the rest... that's it. I couldn't care less about these brain-dead World of Warcraft-style encounters where you battle some god-like creator for two or three hours straight.

At the end of the day, having fun is the number one priority in games. And the beginning and ending of this games hasn't much of fun in it, but great middle.

5/10

"Blasphemous is a brutal action-platformer with skilled hack’n slash combat set in the nightmare world of Cvstodia. Explore, upgrade your abilities, and perform savage executions on the hordes of enemies that stand between you and your quest to break eternal damnation." 

It's not skilled, is not hack and slash, there are no hordes, the movement it's extremely slow, there are no cancels, no efficient way to transverse the map, parrying overlaps the basic attacks.

If you guys want to market this game as a Soulslike go ahead. But I purchased this game under the premise of being skilled and engaging. Very misleading description.

This one pains me to vote down because it does so much right! I am a fan of metroidvanias, from the old to the new, and it is important to establish that this most definitely is one, contrary to any claims of being a souls-like that some may make, so don't go in with false expectations. As a metroidvania though, it leaves a lot to be desired, as those moments of both character and exploration progression are few and far between. 

As for character progression, there are no levels and so most improvements come as upgrades. Not unusual, but man, these upgrades do nothing. Every enemy takes half a dozen hits, and the many items you get don't make you any stronger or make any appreciable difference, especially since the flavor text muddles what everything does. That is especially odd since the items also have a lore section you can switch to, so the verisimilitude feels like a poor choice. It was said in another review, but there really is no difference in your gameplay as the game progresses, and that sucks because this gameplay just ain't it. 

Inputs feel clunky and slow, and there is so much input bleed, especially in moves with combined inputs like dash-stabbing. That move is especially heinous, as I died countless times because my character just stopped and slowly slashed in place, whilst the dodge refused to cancel anything or even come out. Even the four hit combo I unlocked rarely makes an appearance despite the requirement being to hit 'K' four times. The dodge is also just awful, since its ability to pass through enemies and projectiles is often unclear, and after a dodge it acts like it has a 1 second cooldown before you can even use it again, so any bullet hell elements or crowds of enemies just stink to get through. There is a parry, but it feels like a band aid, and again it is unclear what it is and isn't fair game to parry. Mobility in general isn't great, and the game is not forthcoming in fast ways to get across the map. Instead you have to trudge through enemies aplenty.

The enemies are a mixed bag. They are okay in terms of mechanical design, though some such as the shield enemies feel they exist entirely to slow you down further and waste more time. I never thought any were really challenging except for maybe the teleporting wax ghost that shoots high damage lasers. Awful, just awful to face, and gimmicky to deal with. Bosses are a tad dull, or in the case of the second boss, set up to be annoying and tanky. That entire fight is just running back and forth before hopping around jump slashing. Jump slashing is not fun by the way, and you can't help but feel like you are doing something wrong. As mentioned, having to pass through these guys over and over is such a chore, especially given how many of these rooms are designed like puzzles, so you have to dodge your way through every single time just to get to the other side.

A quick note about traversal: it isn't rewarding, and unlocking new areas isn't usually because of the application of a particular item, but instead because you went around. That's fine on its own, but with the amount of items I am picking up, it would be nice if at least one let me glide or double dodge or something.

On a positive note the game truly is gorgeous. The animations, especially on the nun with the giant incense flail, are amazing and really impressive use of pixel animation. The choice to lean into the late medieval Christian obsession with saintly body parts, penance, and ordained suffering makes the world feel unique and yet darkly familiar. In real life those body parts are still held by the Catholic Church, and it makes this world feel both macabre in a way that only human inflicted suffering can bring about, and alive with a history and culture that everyone participates in. I think the devs get an A+ for bringing something incredible to life here.

Would I prefer that the game had not been made, or at least, that another was made instead? No, I think this game is invaluable as a piece of art and expression through game design. Clearly a lot of people do not share my concerns or feel that these issues are notable enough. I just wanted more from this game. I got it on a very generous sale, though the price tends to be quite high for what it is. Maybe that is a sensibility from an older era when metroidvanias were considered less equivocal to other game genres, even on platforms like steam, and were priced around the $10-15 range digitally. If the gameplay was tighter, I think this game is worth full price, but for those who aren't going to be satisfied with a game that just looks cool, a sale of any kind brings it to a more justified cost.

As someone with limited platformer experience, but nigh 1000 hours of Souls and Souls-like games, I started playing expecting to have to learn the ways of an unfamiliar genre, but with the theme and twist of a familiar set of games in the Souls-like genre that I find fun due to their challening nature. However, rather than being engaged by it's difficulty, the combat felt very clunky and monotonous. Getting damaged because your pixel touched a peasant's cloak, and spending ages running through hallways with the same peasants and ghosts didn't at all grip me. It's hard to even blame the game, it's just doing what it seems like every platformer since the original Super Mario's have been doing, but to me it just feels extremely odd to play a genre that seems to refuse to innovate and question why certain senseless, unintuitive and dated mechanics are in these games, without critically thinking on whether it actually serves to guide the player into a fun playstyle. Considering this game is so well reviewed, I am obviously in the minority, but to those who don't play a lot of platformers be aware. The game, likely unsurprisingly, feels very dated and slow. Hopefully the second game, or some other platformer, attempts to make fluid, fast and engaging combat, with enemies that push the player to take on a fun playstyle, and without the mind-numbing miles of corridors filled with chaff and random doorways that lead to more winding hallways and bogs that loop and lead off from each other, making you realise once you open the map you will be going through the entire route again to go to the other random doorway that you only pray is short and not littered with ghosts throwing projectiles and peasants that dare you to touch a single of their pixels with your own, lest you die from the agony of the mistake. I don't know why I expected something intuitive, engaging and fun, but every time i touch this genre something in me finds myself repelled by what I find to be very out-dated and poorly chosen gameplay mechanics that holds back the potential that such simple and straight-forward games could achieve.

I spent more time searching where to go than actually playing. Tabbing out every second to look up guides, wandering in circles, and wasting time not knowing what the next step was just completely killed the experience for me. I wanted to love it but I just couldn’t go on anymore.
What made it worse was the map. Every time I opened it, it looked like a scribbled piece of shit paper drawn by a 7 year old Arkham Asylum patient. It’s genuinely one of the most confusing and unusable maps I’ve ever seen in a game.
It’s a shame really, because the art, music, and atmosphere are all incredible. But when you spend the majority of your time lost and confused, It’s hard to appreciate the game.

Плюси: гарний візуал, деякі боси непогані, є ряд прикольних ідей в кімнатах, ворогах та предметах, дуже прикольний сюжет

Мінуси: дуже багато кривих моментів в механіках, які разраби фіксили костилями (цікаво чи спеціально, щоб люди бачили прогрес в наступних іграх) або не фіксили взагалі. З того, що не фіксили взагалі, це переважно проблеми пов'язанні з ворогами, типу ось цих привидів, що крізь стіни літають і які мають дивні хітбокси, чи жіночки з вазою з руками. Тіпа, ну платформінг не так бісить тепер, як він бісив на релізі, але от всі інші криві моменти як були, так і лишились. Також ніяк не мінялись просто погані геймдизайнерські рішення, типу непотрібного ліміту на одночасне носіння предметів для переміщення, предмети з лором, які однаково виглядають як інші предмети і теж вимагають від вас додаткові челленджи проходити чи взагалі бектречити до них, повільність ГГ який годинами переміщується по карті, бо в грі 0 покращень для швидкості переміщень. 

Це все штуки очевидні, про них пише будь-який негативний відгук. Хотілось би ще додати від себе чогось. От що мені точно в Бласфемус не подобається, що гра недопускає ніякої оригінальності з боку гравця. В грі відсутнє саме поняття білдів, які б кардинально відрізнялись одне від одного, тому незалежно від того, який набір апгрейдів ви візьмете, боси вбиватимуться +- однаково. Окрім того, оскільки в грі вкрай примітивні апгрейди того, як ГГ переміщується, і вони всі опціональні, то навіть в цьому плані у вас одна стабільність в грі. Локація з початку гри під кінець грається і відчувається ідентично тому, якою вона відчувалась на початку гри. Більше того, відсутня оригінальність навіть в битві з ворогами, оскільки в усіх них дуже примітивний ШІ та мувсет. Піком цього є ці привиди, які б'ють вас якоюсь магією і переміщуються між 2-3 точками. Коли ви доходите до них, на їх вбивство треба 4-5 ударів по ним і тому ви просто стаєте на одне місце і вичікуєте їх спавн з цих 2-3 точок. І так ви будете їх вбивати завжди, ви можете 10-20 разів проходити цей коридор і варіант того, як пройти цих привидів без дамагу по вам буде один і той самий, а саме стояти на тому місці, інші варіанти просто відсутні. І це комплексна проблема, причиною якої є як відсутність цікавих апгрейдів, відсутність в багатьох ворогів якогось спектру атак. Через це гра відчувається набагато довшою, ніж є насправді, бо вона душна капець, бо ну за 10 годин гра не дала мені інструментів на хоча якусь оригінальність. Ні тобі підтягнутих під себе тактик проти босів, тактик проти ворогів, цього всього нема. Пєчалька, сподіваюсь друга частина ліпше

The movement feels so slow and clunky. It's like I'm operating a WW1 era tank instead of a warrior. The platforming is dreadful as well. I want to like this game, the atmosphere is damn cool, and the enemy designs are wicked. But I just can't recommend it. 2/5 stars

Blasphemous is one of the most visually striking yet mechanically shallow and braindead Metroidvanias I’ve ever played. It feels like Game Kitchen took cues from WayForward. Both studios excel at crafting beautiful worlds but consistently fail to deliver engaging gameplay beyond that.

As for the controls, keyboard and mouse are generally fine during gameplay, but navigating menus is awful. Unfortunately, you’ll also be in them often. Swapping beads, browsing collectibles, and changing prayers all feel clunky and unintuitive.

Gameplay starts with promise but quickly stagnates. The combat at hour 1 is virtually identical to hour 10, and the lack of mechanical depth makes the game’s length feel unjustified. It’s one of those games that throws a million pieces of gear at you, most of which are either useless or so niche that you’ll forget they even exist. Most of them exist solely to justify a platforming puzzle or enemy gauntlet, padding the runtime without adding meaningful variety. The bosses are also laughably easy. I ignored every pattern and still brute-forced my way through. Aside from the second boss, I first-tried all the others.

Metroidvanias are an oversaturated genre, and you can afford to be picky. You won't miss anything by skipping this one.

The first half was one of the best games i've played, but in order to increase difficulty unsatisfying cheap tricks are added, and one ultra tuff unfun area i was trying to get through turns out to be dlc, i would have found that purchase to be a big slap to the face.

Just spam the attack button and you will melt the bosses hp. I literally never used any combat ability, I never needed to. Hopefully the second game will be more challenging and satisfying because, to me, this one almost seemed like a big pretentious waste of time.
Despite this, I think the art is absolutely stunning. One of the best pixel art direction I've ever seen.

Story is nice, visuals are great but the gameplay itself is kinda bad in some areas.

1. No i-frames on dodge, so the game compensates by making the bosses easier
2. Traveling on the map is horrendous until the very late-game, moving from one end to another just to spend more time in the game. Now don't get me wrong, I like going back to the first levels and rediscovering stuff, but this game just makes you go from one end to another for almost nothing
3. No hints on how to unlock fast travel between respawn points
4. No way to know if you completed a room or even a zone
5. Hardest zone is made overly difficult for no real reason and it feels kinda weird to be ready to fight the last boss but some random mob can 2 shot you, while the boss needs ~4-5 hits, without you needing to parkour around him
6. Making a platformer time-based speed-run puzzle part of the progression but having janky controls (at least on the steam deck) is a big no-no from me:
- for attacking to latch onto platforms, you can only do it in the exact location of the dedicated area. It doesn't matter if you are in the attack animation while in the zone or if you spam attack in the zone
- regarding latching onto edges, you can't latch to all of them and it's not obvious which ones are latch-able. Even when trying to latch, if you're in a different animation, you won't latch
- death zone hit box is bigger than the graphical description (the spikes) and not consistent

I'd only recommend for the story and visuals but NOT for the gameplay

I've been playing since the start of the game and it used to be incredibly fun. I was apart of every major battle in the game's history and have seen every "it's so over" and "were so back" moments of the community, and despite how much I love this game I cannot in good conscience give this game a good review. 

This isn't because of the games fault, but rather the dev team who have time and time again proven their incompetent, and sometimes malicious approach at maintaining this game. Some things can be forgiven like: using an engine that would soon be discontinued, minor bugs on an updates release, balance being slightly off on new content, etc. However, due to what I can only assume is their ego they dev's have: completely ravaged the game with content that is not play-tested making balance and bug fixing a nightmare, lying to community about actual balance changes and notable nerfs they claim to be buffs, creating enemies that spit in the face of the games original design philosophy, and letting performance get so bad to the point that people, who paid for this game mind you, have had their computer's hard crash multiple times due to the amount of tech debt they seemingly refuse to meaningfully chip at. 

They also have seemingly no respect for the community for anything other than content. People have been begging the devs to fix bouncing strategems and revert the hellpod maneuverability for ages, and despite it being a literal toggleable option in the code they refuse to do so, but they need to listen to the community and add caves that barely function, with enemies that barely function, on a world designed to frustrate the player, because that was what the players wanted. Then you have the fact the treat their content creators horribly with creators being kicked from their program because they criticized the game in a way the devs didn't like, or lead one on for months only to tell him to fuck off later on. 

If they actually listened to the community in any meaningful way, and stop trying to force the game into being a "grunt fantasy" with shitty weapons, overpowered enemies, and bad game design, they wouldn't have lost like 200k players in the span of a few months. 

All in all I would not recommend this game until Arrowhead get's it shit together, and actually delivers on their promises of fixing this game.

I've had this game for 2 years and it's now become beyond playable. Every time there's a new patch issued to "fix" the game, it becomes more unstable everytime I attempt to boot the game. I've attempted game file verification, Clean reinstall/uninstall, and completely shut off all background programs, adjusted BIOS settings, and yet it still yields zero results.

I’m running a Ryzen 7 7800X3D RTX 4070 super with 64 GB of ram, and Helldivers 2 is the only game that completely freezes my system — no keyboard, no mouse, GPU stops, and the only way out is to hard restart.

I'll echo the previous sentiment shared: This is not a “performance issue,” it’s a critical system-level failure caused by the game or its GameGuard anti-cheat.

For a AAA-priced title, this level of instability is unacceptable and beyond disappointing. 

I strongly advise others not to buy it.

Helldivers is an incredibly fun game, few other games scratches the same itch of coop pve.

However, long story short, it's often a crapshoot whether the devs wanna make the game fun for the players, or follow their vision of the helldivers being grunts more than heroes. 

I love the game, but I hate the intentions behind some of these changes over these last two years.

The bugs are, to this day, game breaking. Especially in the cities, tileset issues cause you to clip through and under terrain, where you get stuck, Hitboxes desync from the enemies, Damage done to the player feels wildly inconsistent, you can do the same action or face the same attack and take wildly different damage values. Explosions are far wider in radius than their visuals would indicate. Everything ragdolls you. Weapons feel inconsistent and weak. Enemy spawns seem capricious, spawning on top of you constantly.

Until and if they get their shit together, I cannot in good conscience recommend this game.

The game is good. The publisher is not. 

After finally bailing on PlayStation brand due to Sony's progressive, insufferable incompetence and fully switching to Steam, I decided to buy Helldivers 2 again, since as I said, the game is good. However, Sony managed to screw me over here as well.

Despite having the whole "Link PlayStation account" thing set up, which was unnecessary and caused huge controversy and backlash back in the day, there is no form of cross-progression at all. The only things this linking accounts was mean to do. These fools can't get one thing right. 

After 200 hrs on PS5, I refuse to start from scratch, because of Sony's incompetence. Unacceptable.

Extremely fun game; immersive, epic, and with tongue-in-cheek humour. Gameplay loop is engaging and the battle pass system in the game is generous and free-to-play friendly. Some say the balance is off-whack, but I think it adds to the more casual nature of the game. I have little qualms about the game itself; it is amazing and I applaud the devs for the years of development that went into this modern live-service masterpiece.

With that said...

The optimization is extremely subpar; game literally shuts down my PC with no BSOD. Helldivers 2 is the only game that does this on my setup. The game literally screws with the HARDWARE of my computer, which mind you, is fairly beefy and was built a year or so ago as of writing this review. The anti-cheat in the game might also have something to do with this.

Also, 130GB+ storage space is appalling when on consoles it is less than half of that. Its not worth saving 130GB of space on a game that has the potential to kill your computer without warning.

I absolutely adore this game, but I cannot in good faith recommend it in its current state; not until the devs polish up the game. If you do buy this game, play with caution.

I loved this game in the beginning, even with its flukes, but now; I think one of my favorite studios has fallen to the power of Capitalism when I thought it was for consumer Fascism. Shame on you, shame on your family, and shame on your cow!

Not a fully negative review, but the grind needs discussing...

I beat the run for the first time after 20 hours. After another 10 hours I saved an important character.

After that? 35 hours later I am still hunting for fucking stupidly padded and grindy achievements that require absurds amounts of items to do. ABSURDS I TELL YOU! And all the events, randomized. While the game requires like 5 of those random random random events that happen once per run randomly, or maybe not. Because is random... Soo annoying.

I don’t understand all the positive reviews. Graphics are good and it’s a Cool concept but it’s repetitive. You die, you don’t progress, only to get stronger, and then replay everything. Rinse and repeat.  Stuff like this gets boring fast.

Boons do too little and don't synergize nearly often enough. You are entirely at the mercy of RNG for a viable build or not.
Hitboxes are way too generous when you're being hit but way too precise when it comes to landing an attack.
Visually beautiful but good f***ing luck deceiphering what's happening behind 13,459 projectiles, AOEs, and 20 different enemies with attack patterns all out of sync with each other. When the dust settles you will be a red smear on the floor and  back to the beginning.

No to mention all the times enemies move to a spot that cannot be reached or which makes them invisible thanks to the isometric view.

In summary, it's a visually stunning mechanical nightmare. Take your money to a casino if you want to gamble. At least in the casino you can win money. All you're going to get playing this game is high blood pressure.
The fact you need to romance everyone to progress (i.e. getting Companions) takes away all the fun for me. If I knew it was such game I wouldn't have bought it in the first place. Disappointing.
esta mierda de juego, me tiro dos horas hacviendo una run, me cierra el juego y tengo que volver a empezar la pertida que mas fuerte he ido me cago en el developer y en su puta madre

Don't have a history of playing hack and slash roguelites but gave it a go due to reviews and I liked the artwork. First ten hours were very exciting, but eventually the game turned into grind. 
A combination of things that I really disliked are:
1. It takes time to get to bosses that kick your ass and every attempt takes time and further you go, more I feel like I am wasting my time clearing first levels.
2. The game beats you by throwing a lot of SFX which makes it extremely difficult at times to see what's going on and react. Combined with importance of life preservation it makes for a frustrating experience.
3. The deepest runs happen when I use weapons I am lukewarm to. Combined with random boons that force gameplay style I don't enjoy a significant chunk of playtime turns into a chore.

As they say in French, "un pas en avant, 2 pas en arriere" (one step forward, two steps backwards). HADES will punish you for getting better and stronger for no valid reason other than to strech its very short playtime. 

Don't get me wrong, it's super addictive once you get the hang of it and it's fun to make and test various builds, boon crafting is a rewarding process. It's just that the game seems to have little frustrations implemented here and there for the sake of frustrating you. They're not narratively engaging or interesting. Without spoiling much, after the grind when you finally feel like you have conquered a certain realm or biome, and you clear it up more consistently, it just suddently gets tougher for no reason and all your progression is thrown out the window, and you have to work your way up again, I suppose they did this because otherwise the game will be super short, like it would have 5 hours of content max, but with their little trolling system thy can squeeze 20 or 30+ hours of your time. 

So yeah, very fun and addictive gameloop, but I wouldn't recommend if you don't like unecessary hard difficulty. After 20 hours, I'm starting to feel a serious fatigue for this game that up until now was very engaging and exciting. After a 3rd or a 4th step down, I'm tired to go back up again cause what's the point? how long is this going to take... I may or may not continue. We'll see.

I grew up on Halo. I've enjoyed its highs, loathed its lows; Explored the many levels for skulls, terminals, super bounces, and everything in between. I appreciate what Infinite has done for both its multiplayer and campaign after the massive departure from everything I loved in Halo 5. Its not easy in the current world to backtrack the direction you've been headed, accept the loss, and return to your roots. Infinite does that in alot of ways while still trying to maintain some momentum and freshness it sought to bring to the more recent titles. Honestly the game has alot going for it, but it really lacked Forge on launch when player count was at its peak. Community is what made this game memorable for so many of us, and  not capturing that community by initially delivering a half baked product really hurt this game overall. Enjoying it none the less.

now i've been a big fan of halo ever since it was introduced to me when i was a kid. halo 3 being a personal favorite of mine despite playing reach before 3. it's home to some of my warmest memories, the times that got me through the stress and struggles of the time i had as a kid and the things i had to put up with, it was halo that got me through that all.

but for the life of me, i can't say i like this game and could reccomend it when it had became the unfinished mess it is now, full of too much ambition and broken promises, and a terrible multiplayer model for a system not needed on a game meant to be a flagship title for a launching console.

we were promised many things, and many things later. they insisted to us it's the most halo they've made for halo.
hmmmm, what did they all do?

some halo fans didnt like that the classic shotgun got replaced overall in the sandbox with a new shotgun. then they said they'll just add it in an update. we never got the classic shotgun, but we did get some stupid fucking brute shotgun that belongs in doom. it's cool, but it honestly doesnt feel like a halo weapon, if im holding it im playing fucking doom.

support for the coop campaign got cut. they added it, but they didnt give us the other features campaign should have had. no replayable missions, no story dlc to continue the story after the cool cliffhangar we got, campaign support being cut also means no new sandbox weapons are being added to the campaign, and that's kind of stupid; it kills the replay value. i would have liked to see the weapon sandbox fit and update with the multiplayer, and even some followups for the jokes of 'seasons' they had. they eventually said fuck that and went to 'operations' because they thought fomo works or some dumb shit like that.

our store was just a place of overpriced bundles and by the time we got free currency, they make any decent items too fucking grindy to get, and also made promo items grindy, and offered you to buy the free currency to get them, but im not going to fall for that shitty marketing tactic.

now i understand that some people feel like this is the best halo campaign but it really isnt to be honest.

there's some neat emotional tugging moments, yes, but it's done so much 343 fanfic for the story i just cant say the campaign was good. i personally fucking felt it could have been better. we could have had better battles, a better setting, but they didnt want to offend anyone from what it looks like. you scooby doo chase a villain through his various BIG IMPORTANT FORTRESS WITH ALOT OF BAD GUYS and then hear about 10 glazing atriox speeches and hear a banished bad guy go "hello master chief i am going to fight you now, i tortured alot of the good guys"
i honestly would have loved an introductory mission where you're aboard the infinity, chief is geared up, and he is getting ready to approach the new halo ring. then the infinity gets into this cool space battle, but its also brought a small fleet with them as well, so a cool space battle ensues, as the banished is fighting with their ragtag group of upgraded ships, before chief then flies into a banished ship carrying atriox and starts running a crazy assault on the banished flagship, eventually destroying it from the inside and getting into a cool beefy fight with atriox before their fight goes unfinished and they separate from the ship tearing itself apart as it crashes onto the halo ring, before they eventually separate on different paths to spiral into some events like chief going to retrieve the weapon, then he's racing to get to cortana while also trying to chase the banished, chief gets support from some fellow marines but as chief retrieves the weapon, the infinity crashes, and now the spartans (and maybe some mp spartans like yours) need to defend the infinity, establish themselves on the ring fight the banished and finish the fight. idk i wanted a story to be very much halo feeling and have it come full circle where chief fights atriox, then has to deal with cortana and get her to stop oppressing the galaxy in some cool epic finale where chief has to stop her and eventually put her in some ai lockup or something. 

instead, 343 fanfic comes in, and does it's ritual of mollywhopping chief yet again by space kratos who is all like "i am atriox im the new bad guy, now im going to disappear from the rest of the game because im not actually in this game at all." and throws chief into space which magically freezes him for 6 months. chief wakes up and the big bad guy he fought 'died' apparently which then just gets retconned at the end. all the spartans that were with you have been reduced to setpieces, so you cant live the cool fantasy of chief leading in fellow spartans on a cool assault against the bad guys in a new fresh coat of not halo 5 paint. oh yeah, funny how our boy fernando withstood the same shit and was just a little sore for a few minutes. after a little bit of far cry spiderman gear rising revengance, you get thrown a new 343 fanfic trope, which is introducing a new bad guy, and they're called the e n d l e s s (wow) and they're fucking stupid because theyre just some aliens that withstood a halo blast and now suddenly the forerunners just dont like them because they're enabling the flood i guess. instead of that; they could have played it safe and just gave us the flood to fight again, and say we need to make sure a proto gravemind isnt made, and this thing happens again because we dont have the arbiter and the swords with us because they're stuck on sanghelios until we can deal with cortana or some plot reason until we can get some of the swords of sanghelios to help out on the ring. oh, and since we get nothing cool, mught as well get myself some special variant rockets, hand them to every marine possible, get myself a razorback, and let every rocket marine on, and just let the banished feel all the frustration i feel on what's been honestly missing from the whole game.

they held off on adding forge until it was a year and a half late. that really choked the life out of this game. they also made the forge ui just as complicated as halo 5's forge, which without the prefab structure setpieces, are absolutely useless to me. some of those prefab structures in halo reach and h2a forge were pretty integral in map making, but it also offered familiarity to where people could create interesting ideas. cant build a cool spaceship no more.

Marvel's Spider Man was amazing, the game is heavily inspired by Batman Arkham and i feel that, however, having an original new Spider Man game again with such a high level of quality was such an amazing thing for me man, i love spider man, he's one of my favorite heroes and i've read a lot of HQs of him

Now, going for the game, Story is excellent, it has some not so good moments but it's common for a game with this amount of hours, story is about 20 hours, the DLCs felt boring in the majority of the time, however atleast it's a DLC with new story, so even though i got bored in the middle, it was good

Gameplay is essentially Batman Arkham, it's great and feels smooth, web swinging is amazing and fun, had a lot of fun seeing the villains in the game and seeing the development of the story, even though at some point it started to get a bit rushed, that's something i didn't find that bad because at the start there was just nothing happening at all lol

Now for some flaws, i think the game should have had a bit more of a variety in boss fights styles, i liked them, but they're all literally do webs at boss > dash and hit him > webs at boss > dash and hit him, with the amount of gadgets the game gives you, i expected more of them to be used, it was still cool tho, boss fights aren't the main point in this game but yeah alright

Also, i feel like this game shouldn't have had some of the stealth parts, or they could have just gone better, they were actually enjoyable but it was an awkward sudden change in the gameplay

Well, the game is amazingly fun, i liked it a lot, nice game, i'd recommend it for anyone

Great game. Lots of attention paid to movement as it should be.

Brilliant and relaxing traversal (web-swinging is amazingly fluid and fun), decently fun combat (albeit a bit easy and overpowered (even on the highest difficulty), but it's much more flashy and fun than the Arkham combat), and a great last bit of story. The beginning of the game with Fisk and the lack of a good showcasing of everything is a massive turnoff, though, and the sections where you essentially just run around and hide as Miles or MJ are very, very boring, to the point where I began to dread them arising. I also had some weird performance issues and bugs, at times.

Otherwise, this is surprisingly a very good game, and the end of the story allowed me to now somewhat like the character of Spider-Man (the final fight was also just very graphically beautiful, even if not very in-depth, engaging, or difficult).

Swinging around the city is fun, but there’s some crazy stuff going on all the time. A lone civilian gets mugged in broad daylight by ten masked guys with crowbars and assault rifles. You fight enemies who randomly yell “sweep the area!” right in the middle of a brawl. Drug dealers in balaclavas hang out on rooftops for no reason. And so on. I get it — game logic — but it’s a bit too much nonsense.

As for the game itself, the story’s average, missions repeat, and there’s not much to do in the city besides photographing landmarks and collecting 55 backpacks — not exactly exciting.

Marvel's The Amazing Spider-man remaster is full of subliminal messages.
Here and there you can literally spot graffiti of a pyramid with an eye - which symbolises the corrupt elite that control society through manipulation and crime. This ties with the following points.

The story with Otto Octavius and Mayor Osborne seems to suggest and follow the narrative that corrupt business men get away with stealing credit and reap the rewards from the real innovators and people who want to make a positive influence in the world. This reminded me of other real world cases such as Nikola Tesla and Martin Fleischmann.

Before becoming Dr. Octopus, Otto is at risk of personality changes/ psychosis? when plugging in to the 4 armed machine to ensue vengeance against Osbourne which implies that anyone that feels motives to target a corrupt person in power suffers from mental illness. This nonsense can be seen in numerous real life cases such as Luigi Mangione and Charlie Manson.
To me, the game subtly hints at the idea that the powerful stay on top and people who raid their ivory tower are silenced and your job as Spiderman is to enforce that. Peter's motives at the end of the game are questionable and the game gives you no choice in the matter.

PS. New York is unsettling. The whole play-through it felt like The Devil's Advocate. New York Satanic

I've played the game for over 100 hours so you can take it that I can give an honest review on this game!

Hollow Knight takes you through the difficulty curve pretty well and for me it was an amazing challenge. I've played Cuphead before coming into this and the Early Game was easy comparatively. The late game bosses especially the DLC comprising of Grim Troupe & Godhome was an exceptional challenge which I was looking for.

There is a huge story behind the game and it's interesting, engaging and spikes your curiosity. The art style is beautiful and the music (BGMs & OST) is amazing given the scenario at hand, There are many areas to explore which is amazing but can lead to finding specific stuff being a tedious chore (But you have plenty of guides online if you aren't into finding them yourself).

Overall the game is not for the faint hearted if you aren't used to dying a lot for the late game optional challenges (but that's what makes it fun!) but the base game is well rounded for most people. I'd recommend this to everyone who wants a challenge and an amazing story/lore unravelled about the world our little Knight treads in.

I want to like it, but I just can't so many deaths feel cheap and out of place it's insane, it makes me rage quit every time. In most metroidvanias you feel powerful while remaining vulnerable and this game you just lose for the sake of losing. 

For how difficult the bosses are (<- that's good) benches are extremely far away (<-that's bad) you lose half your HP before you even reach them. And you can't even practice them in anyway before that. Half of the journey is travelling to the boss rooms.

The nail arts are so inapplicable in an actual combat scenario it's basically just there for show. You can hit them once per hard fight if your pre-prep it before you get there and that's.. that's it...

Backtracking is INSANE, and the fast travel is *extremely* limited. It is also extremely unclear where you should go in this game, one wrong step and poof enemies just delete you or you're in a boss room without even knowing. It reminds me of the SNES times where you needed a booklet with a guide to backseat you the entire game.

If you play aimlessly, like I did you backtrack and retrace steps way more than you actually play the game, it gets boring.

Playing with with a guide to backseat you also gets boring, but there is no other way to play.

I really wanted to like this game, but this is probably the most overglazed and overhyped game of all time. It is regularly called the "Souls-like Metroidvania," but a better comparison would be to call it the Fortnite of Metroidvanias becuase it's not really that deep, but appeals to mainstream gamers who aren't really that deep into the Metroidvania genre, or gaming as a whole. And don't get me wrong, this game is fun at times, but it excels at nothing and is rather bland as a whole. If you are looking for a visually striking, creative and innovative Metroidvania with challenging or even souls-like combat, play Blasphemous or Symphony of the Night instead. This game is not that, contrary to what others say.

As a Metroidvania, it is probably the most shallow and uninteresting Metroidvania I have ever played. The level design is extremely repetitive and bland, The exploration appears open yet lacks any vision and ends up being largely linear and involves you often walking in circles until you find a hidden door you missed. There is very little movement growth, really only getting a dash, wall jump and double jump. Back tracking is not rewarding because by the time you get anything out of it you've already run through the same area 10 times already. The environments also lack visual clarity and often look more or less the same screen from screen. While some Metroidvania's make more use of the map than others, A large portion of this game's upgrades are just adding rudimentary features to the map like showing your cursor on the map or marking merchants on it. This really isn't much of a Metroidvania as much as it is a walking simulator because the movement is so slow and you spend so much time trudging through the same areas over and over.

As a Souls-like, the Combat is extremely shallow and a complete letdown. Combat in it's entirety really just boils down to just mashing a single button and has virtually zero depth. Parry timing is extremely tight and while it does nullify a single instance of damage, it's ultimately better just to button mash and deal damage than it is to strategically bait out a parry. Dodging provides zero Iframes and is purely a traversal tool here, further limiting combat to this passive game of chicken where you run in, mash, run away, repeat. Even among Metroidvanias, which to be frank, usually have lackluster Combat: Hollow Knight stands out as exceptionally repetitive and bland in virtually every aspect. The only reason this game gets called a souls-like is because it has corpse running (IE: Death = you must recover your body or all your currency is lost) and because it has a parry button. Controls are sluggish and the opposite of tight. Frankly, calling it a Souls-like is an insult to Soulslikes.

The Art style and Lore seems to carry this game in the eyes of many, but to be honest, that is also rather basic and shallow. Character sprites are minimalistic, bland and even when they are distinct from one another, there isn't much interest to them. The NPC's also have virtually zero dimension to them, so there's not really any reason to be invested in them or their (non-existent) stories. Assets and Backgrounds don't really match in terms of style or level of detail. Characters have thick, blocky lines and no shading or detail whatsoever, while backgrounds are highly detailed, shaded and static.

If I didn't get this game for under $5, I would probably really disappointed. It's not a terrible game, but there are flash games of equal or superior quality from like 2008 both graphically and mechanically.

My 1st and probs my last metroidvania game I just didn't like it, I had no clue where i was going like 70% of the time and just kept going around in circles trying to figure out where i am suppose to go just made me go insane.

Like many others say, the game is good enough until you realize how unforgiving the checkpoint system is. Most reviews I see talk about this. You reach the first really tough boss, end up losing over and over again and are reset to a checkpoint that is miles away to walk all the way back and try again.

This is a souls like game that instead of offering you retries, punishes you for dying. Oh you lost? Now walk all the way back from beginning. Also you lose all your upgrades until you reach the point where you last lost. Then HOPE you don't die again to waste more time traveling back to the fight AGAIN.

IT's a cute game, good music, good graphics, fun game play. AWFULLY unforgiving checkpoint system with no retry option for tough battles. Quality of life is VERY low on this game. I may not play again for a long time if ever. I've wasted my money.

Later on you can buy markers to put on your map. Great! just mark where I've already been or where I want to come back, right? NOPE, you get a max of 6 markers (for each color) for whatever reason.

Ok I'll just remember where I've been, right? Well, what happens when I don't play for a few weeks then come back? already forgot everything.

Then during boss fights, or I guess in general, if you die, instead of respawning nearby, you respawn at the last bench you saved at. It's not fun and frustrating dying and then having to walk all the way back while taking damage along the way.

Then there's also the fact that, for whatever fucking reason, in order to see where you are on the map you need to sacrifice a slot which could be used for other upgrades. Same thing for automatically picking up dropped coins from monsters, like why aren't they just permanent upgrades?

I'll probably still finish the game, but I wanted to share my frustrating experience for a supposedly top rated game.

Came back to leave a review after completing Silksong. I found Hollow Knight really hard to stick with and dropped it multiple times before finally finishing it prior to playing Silksong. 

My biggest complaint is that the storytelling is super vague and expects the player to pick up a big chunk of even the main storyline from environmental clues that aren't necessarily easy to make sense of. I can see how this method of storytelling appeals to people, but it's definitely not my cup of tea, and I struggled to maintain interest. I powered through the game and even after getting the "true" ending, still felt like I didn't really understand what is going on at all until I watched a video explaining everything which, looking back, I would never have been able to pick up myself.

Storytelling aside, the combat felt really one-dimensional. Having played Nine Sols before and Silksong after, I can't help but find Hollow Knight's combat system and boss fights lacking and boring, mostly relying on positioning and avoiding enemy attacks with a jump and a simple dash. While I understand that HK's combat is designed and balanced around enemies inflicting touch damage, I'm not a big fan of it, and found that bosses who rely on killing the player with them accidentally running into it are generally just less fun than bosses with more complex skill/movesets. And while Silksong has the same exact system, the combat just feels more fun and rewarding because of how fluid Hornet moves, and the addition of some movement abilities, with the biggest gamechanger being Clawline as a gap-closer or a way to deal with aerial enemies. I understand that Nine Sols has a completely different combat system and it's not fair to compare the combat of the two, but Nine Sols' parry-focused combat is perfect and just feels way way more rewarding than HK's and if you haven't played Nine Sols you should!

I won’t waste any fucking words sugarcoating this absolute dogshit excuse of a game. Yeah, maybe it’s late as hell to write this review, but I can’t fucking stay silent anymore. I still can’t wrap my head around how the fuck this game managed to get a Very Positive rating, it’s a goddamn joke. Horizon Zero Dawn is nothing more than a worthless pile of overhyped shit. Before writing this, I gave it 7 hours to impress me, and every single minute was boring as fuck.

Aloy? Don’t make me fucking laugh. She’s a bland-ass, cardboard ‘chosen one’ with zero depth, zero growth, and zero soul. The writers shoved her down our throats like she was some iconic badass, but in reality, she’s flat, forced, and fake as fuck. Stack her up against a real protagonist like Arthur Morgan from RDR2, and Aloy looks like a pathetic piece of shit cosplay.

And the gameplay? Christ, it’s the same repetitive ass cycle on loop: scan, shoot, tear off parts, repeat. That’s it. Over and over and over again. The robot dinosaur concept sounds badass, but when every fight boils down to the same formula, it turns into a fucking chore. The side quests are even worse, uninspired, fetch-quest garbage that only pad the playtime.

This whole game stinks of fanservice, overhype, and fake praise. It was marketed as some revolutionary open-world RPG, but what I got was a shallow, lifeless, boring-ass 72GB pile of trash. Horizon Zero Dawn isn’t a masterpiece, it’s one of the most overrated, disappointing, and flat-out shitty games I’ve ever wasted time on. Fuck this game.
P/S: If you’re bored and looking for a good game to play, don’t fucking waste your money on this piece of shit. Honestly, anyone who gave this game a positive review has taste that’s fucking below standard, seriously pathetic.

This game is pure garbage. The voice acting of the protagonist and several other characters sounds like it was literally made by AI. I don't know if the gameplay starts to improve later on, because I don't even have the energy to continue. A game should engage the player within the first few hours, not just hope they won't leave to see the better parts. Even the story, which should theoretically be great in such games, is cheap here. Simply put, it's a narrative action game with RPG elements, but with poorly executed action and a cheap plot.

I had this game on the PS4 and I hated aiming with a controller. Yes, there's auto-aim (or aim assist or whatever you want to call it), but it just never felt good.

Revisiting it on PC after buying it on a deep sale... it's aged very poorly.

Pros:
[list]
[*] Graphics are really good imo, even for a game this age, even though it was a console exclusive. The art style has held up and looks good. Lighting is good, shadows are good, textures are good.

[*] Combat is... serviceable. You never feel "strong", but with good aim you can cripple machines and make them into glorified robot vacuum cleaners with anger issues.

[*] Decent array of weapons and armour options, with decent customisation (non-visual though... never got why that's a thing, kinda sucks imo).
[/list] 

And that's basically it for the Pros.

Cons:
[list]
[*] Aloy's face is squarer than some of my Minecraft skins, truly. If you want cute female (and male) protagonists, look East, cuz the West ain't gonna deliver. Thank you mod makers for saving the day (again).

[*] Outfits are decent, but apart from the Nora Brave they're kinda meh. They try to make Aloy look tough and competent, but never deliver. They sure as heck don't make her look any better, that's for sure. Thank you mod makers for saving the day (again again).

[*] Writing ranges from "meh" to "alright, stop, ffs". Aloy is bratty and wooden. Other characters are equally so. Very little emotion. Some quests are alright, other quests are boring garbage. Game's also back-loaded with lore, it's super tiring and it hits you like a truck filled with encyclopedias driven by a drugged-up librarian screaming "LORE! HISTORY! REVELATIONS! PLOOOOT TWIIIIIST!". My god, learn to pace this stuff!

[*] Animations and cut-scenes are... bad. Really, really bad. Jank everywhere. You can see this in one of the intro cut-scenes as the Proving aspirants light their floaty lanterns, after they're lit, at least 8 NPCs do a synchronised "get up and look around" animation. Other NPCs nearby clap in perfect sync, no emotion or lower-body movement to be had.
Additionally, all NPCs suffer from "wave my stiff hands around like a lunatic mannequin" syndrome. It's both hilarious and bad. You'd think they'd put a bit more effort but nah.

[*] Game suffers from problems rampant in that era, such as "climb ONLY this clearly, colourfully marked stuff" and "badass chick with a bow vs. the world" (but she's Lara Croft from Temu lol) and "there's collectables, here's a map with all of them clearly marked" and "there are puzzles, but the protagonist will spell out the solution to each puzzle in <10sec of you seeing the puzzle, sometimes even before you get to see it".

[*] Game also suffers from "here's a bunch of loot but 90% of it is filler and garbage lmao, fill those bags!". Seriously, you do a quest and all you get are sticks, 4 traps, 1 health pot and some metal scrap. What the sh*t?
You collect the clearly marked collectables, turn them in for a prize, and you get extremely underwhelming boxes of basic materials you can also farm in about 5min. Absolutely abysmal loot system.

[*] You'd think they'd make this game's controls respect the fact it's now on PC... they really didn't.
Listen, bozos, I got a keyboard with 104 freakin keys. A controller has like 14. LET ME USE MORE KEYS. I've counted them, and without moving my left hand, I have 28 available keys (no SHIFT modifiers needed) to press. Not counting Caps Lock or Win key, not counting F1-F5.

Why do I have to awkwardly press Z and X to cycle through consumables??? Why not, here's a genius idea, let me map some of those to my 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 keys? Why not G? Why not T, R, B, H, Y, N or ~? Why do you only let me use Q, Z, X, C, V, W, A, S, D, F, CTRL and SHIFT?

No, I'm not counting M for Map, or J for Quests, or K for skills, as those affect gameplay as much as a wet rag on a pigeon. I'm counting the complete lack of buttons that made me have a gaming PC in the first place.
[/list]

ok so i’ve tried to get into Horizon: Zero Dawn like 3 different times now and after dumping 21 hours into it i just can’t do it anymore, every time i encountered the same exact wall. i feel like it’s time wasted but at least ain’t nobody gonna tell me now that i didn’t give it a fair run with a straight face, i finished probably a bit over half of the game before i decided to let it go. i think i gotta accept that i’m done with this game for good.

the annoying thing is i really want to like it. the whole mystery of “where did the machines come from” and “what happened to the world” is actually fascinating to me. but the act of playing this thing is just so mind-numbingly boring. exploration is literally the same checklist open world garbage i’ve seen in a million other games: cluttered map, repetitive activities, boring side quests. combat is fun, cauldrons are fun, sure. but everything around those moments is just pure boredom. and around the 10 hour mark you’ve already seen every challenge the game has to offer, so then you’re just repeating the same set of challenges over and over again. i was actually pounding caffeinated drinks just so i wouldn’t fall asleep mid-game. not even kidding.

dialogue is another huge problem. i don’t usually mind games with tons of talking. some games make dialogue one of the best parts. but here it’s just so bland. like, 80% of the conversations don’t hold my interest at all. but if you skip them, you immediately feel like you’re missing key story beats. so you either slog through it half-asleep or skip it and get confused. people kept telling me “don’t worry, the game gets good once you reach X” but once i got way past that point, i still didn't feel it.

and i know i’m in the minority here. tons of people LOVE this game. i see how fans obsess over the lore and the characters and just soak it all in. and i get it, it clicks with a lot of people. but to me the lore itself is boring. not just the dialogue, not just the quests, but the actual worldbuilding is boring. the mystery of the machines is cool, but the tribes, the politics, the everyday struggles of the people in this world… none of it grabbed me. it all just feels like post-apocalypse boilerplate with a tribal paint job. i never cared about which settlement was fighting which, who was struggling, or why i should be invested in all these little conflicts. so if the world is supposed to be the main selling point, and that doesn’t hit, then there’s nothing left for me to latch onto.

so yeah, 21 hours in and i’m done. Horizon: Zero Dawn clearly has its fans and i respect that, but i can’t recommend it if you:

- get bored easily with repetitive open world checklist stuff

- need dialogue to be sharp and interesting to stay awake

- don’t care about tribal/political worldbuilding

if you’re the kind of player who loves digging through every codex entry, listening to tons of lore dumps, and doesn’t mind repetitive side content as long as the world hooks you, then yeah you’ll probably love it. wish i could say the same, but nah, i’m out.

"Boring and Repetitive"

I won't recommend Horizon Zero Dawn because I didn't really like it, but I don't think it's a bad game in itself. Let's start with the positives. The game is very very good looking visually. You can stop and look at the view pretty much anytime and be like : waw that's beautiful. The combat against the robots are also very good because they aren't just an HP bar : you can break things, make some components explode, and even use their own weapons against them. This kind of interaction is very cool and well thought, making the combats feel less repetitive . The musics are also really great and I enjoyed the setting of the game. Some characters are also pretty nicely done even if it's not the case for every single one of them. 

Now, it seems great but, what did I dislike ? First of all, the game is beautiful but there is very little rewards for exploration. Yes of course you'll find components here and there, but it's far from what I've saw in other open world games like Elden Ring which was the last one I played. And I truly think it's a shame because you don't really get rewarded to explore such a beautiful world. My review is mostly subjective but I think this particular criticism is objective, and one of the biggest complaints you can have while playing Horizon Zero Dawn. I usually like exploring everything, but I quickly found myself just going to point A to point B without exploring anything in order to follow the story. You can still do it at the end of the day I guess but, yeah not a whole lot of rewards for that. Talking about the story, maybe it's not commmon but even if Aloy is a good character, I didn't really liked the story that much. It's far from bad don't get me wrong but the plot of the game didn't manage to captivate my attention. I didn't finish the game so it might be better later on, but where I'm at it's not bad nor incredible and I dropped the game because I just didn't enjoy my time that much. But maybe it'll be an incredible story for you that's just my very own opinion on it. Following that, bugs. I didn't really crash, maybe once, but I had a few game breaking bugs that forced me to restart a mission, such as NPCs not reacting despite being needed for the quests, or me being stuck in terrains which happened a few times and was extremely annoying. I'm fine with bugs, but not when it ruins the experience and has any impact on your gameplay/playthrough. I also have a bug making a notification appear in my inventory even if I checked everything that I had. This notification is permanent,  I played hours with it, and it's really personal but I despise having unchecked notifications... but I can't remove it so yeah. On the fighting side, using melee doesn't feel great at all but you'll play the game 95% at range so it's not really a valid point to make. Lastly, the facial expressions in cutscenes are really poorly done, which unfortunately happens to be a reoccuring problem in gaming.

To sum up, no Horizon Zero Dawn is not a bad game in itself. I just found myself quickly losing interest because of everything that I mentionned above. Should you buy it/can you enjoy it ? Maybe, you'll enjoy it more than me yes. But I can't recommend a game I didn't really enjoy. At the end of the day, gaming is still subjective.

Horizon Zero Dawn is a strange game to me - it has so much potential and it can be really hard to pin-point why I don't like it or want to play it. The gameplay isn't terrible, the graphics are obviously pretty decent and the concept behind the story is great. 

However, when all is said and done, I find the game non-engaging, the story too bland to care about and the protagonist stuck somewhere between unlikable and shallow. 

Horizon ZD is like playing a Young Adult novel in a way. It's the same sort of characters, a fairly bland protagonist that the reader/player can transpose their own traits unto, a dystopian world where teenagers are the only hope against a corrupted, lost society and pretty weak character arcs based on predestined properties like a prophecy or in this case, special genes that are humanity's only hope. 

And I guess that's what turns me off. I don't really care that much about anyone in the story, including Aloy herself, and then the game has to be carried by the mechanics and even though they're sort of fine, they never manage to rise above that. It's... fine. You'd think that hunting huge, robot dinosaurs would be epic and exciting but oddly it isn't. Maybe it's also because our protagonist doesn't really act like it is, I'm not sure. It's all so... indifferent. Fighting the dinos is more about solving a maths problems sometimes, even though the fights are or can be pretty difficult. I don't know. I guess the gameplay could be ok if the story or characters were engaging, but for me they aren't. Now this might be because I'm not a young adult, but this review are meant for other potential players who may also not be young adults and may not want to play through a story meant for them. 

I'm sad the game isn't better, because it has a lot of potential and a pretty solid idea. But there you go.

Deliberate Deception (minor spoiler)

    GRAPHICS
    At first glance, the visuals seem impressive — environments, effects, and overall style look solid.
    But after a while, the plastic look of the characters becomes hard to ignore. Even main characters lack believable facial expressions. Scars look like someone sliced dough with a knife. On the surface, it’s fine — but look closer, and it feels cheap and rushed.

    DIALOGUES
    Flat, dull, and often silly. Emotional delivery feels like high school theater.
    Dialogue choices (fist, brain, heart) exist, but they only affect one or two lines of NPC response. After a few hours, you’ll probably start skipping everything but the last reply. Shallow and empty.

    STORY
    There’s no real intrigue — it plays out like a stitched-together collection of clichés.
    The game literally starts like The Lion King — the girl is held up before the tribe. Then, she runs off crying and “accidentally” falls into a giant underground facility… that she somehow never discovered despite living right next to it for years.
    The pacing is erratic: time jumps without context, followed by long, boring treks. Fast travel is available, but costs in-game resources — the game punishes you for trying to save time.
    Tribal logic is laughable: a girl clearly linked to their gods appears, and they exile her. It’s explained as “tradition,” but it’s clearly just lazy writing. There’s no depth to the religion, culture, or morality — everything exists just to push the story forward.

    COMBAT
    This is where the game shines. Fighting mechanical beasts is tactical, satisfying, and fun. Weaknesses, traps, and weapon choice actually matter. It’s the one truly fresh and well-executed part of the game.

    OVERALL
    Horizon Zero Dawn tries to present itself as a massive, ambitious project — but underneath it’s a shallow, derivative experience.
    The visual wow-effect and robot fights grab attention early, but after 4–6 hours the lack of depth becomes impossible to ignore. It feels like a stitched-together set of borrowed ideas: Ubisoft-style map structure, generic sci-fi setting, and cheap storytelling.

Not a disaster — just a hollow shell with a pretty face. There are far better and more meaningful RPG/open world games out there.

I recommend this game as an adventure game, I do not recommend it as a card battler. However, I bought this game because I love card battlers, so it gets a negative review.

This game starts out pretty good. It's a decent card battler and the graphics are cool. Then, the game starts incorporating different mechanics and it turns into more of an adventure game. This is cool at first too. Then you start to realize the game is taking itself way too seriously. The actual card battle matches start to feel more and more shallow and tacked on. It becomes more about exploration and the story is trying its best at 4th wall breaks.

It's unfortunate that the game starts out seeming like a promising card battler, because that's the best part of the game. After the first several hours, the game changes and only for the worse.

act 1 is the highlight, though with the card augments it becomes inevitable to win. the "puzzles" are thinly veiled stopping blocks and most the game just gives you the solution. act 2 was fine, though i felt like i just autowon any battle without really using my brain after a certain point. Act 3 is a rehash of act 1 but pushes a painfully slogged, incremental-improvement mechanic that slowly pushes the player over the edge of a game that has light strategy, that can feel deep but the decision choices are few and lacks punch when the game checkpoints so frequently.

This game is actually much deeper than it first seems. I only got through the first act of the game then stopped. I found myself very frustrated by the RNG, especially because the final fight is basically impossible without one or two boons you get right before, but you don't know the metrics you need to achieve to get those boons beforehand, and they're different each run.
Propably the most overrated game I've ever played. Act 1 was awesome, but the next two were nowhere near as good.

The game has a unique style. The music is atmospheric and can be a little boring. After playing this and slay the spire, I just don't like roguelike deck builders. If you like them , you'll like this game most likely. But, if you have played other roguelike games with permadeath and starting the game from the beginning, you probably won't like this game.

I DO think this game is worth the price and was overall fun. I am leaving this negative so people who are actually looking to buy the game have a warning about something I wish I had known before I bought it.

The game you see in the trailer is only about a third of the actual game. Partway through your playthrough the game fundamentally changes. I won't say anything else, because I don't want to spoil anything. But just be aware that the game you are paying for might be a lot different than you expect. If you are willing to give it a chance, this is one of the weirdest, yet coolest, games I have played in awhile. But during my first run through I was pretty frustrated with how the game pulled the rug out from under me, and I think prospective buyers deserve to know that going in.

Unfortunately, I'm gonna have to go with a "do not necesarily recommend" on this one. Very much the Family Guy joke about The Godfather "insisting upon itself" -- this game does exactly that. Folks seem so convinced of its genius, but I found the "twists" and "turns" to be insufferable, the meta-textual nature of it boring and more than a little tryhard, and despite truly enjoying much of the core gameplay loops of Act I and Act II, Act III and the "ending" require researching an ARG to fully get there. Even then, the juice is not worth the squeeze! There's a lot of promise here, I thought my time with this game was going a different way for most of it, but... man, I just cannot get past how wack it ended up being. Even if it started SO STRONG. Also, I have no idea what people in other reviews are talking about with 'endlessly replayable" because mf no it is absolutely not lmao

A balance of linear progression while keeping a open world experience choosing to crouch around enemies, row around them, run by them or fight them, theres a lot of similar experiences like that. The gun customization, different guns, the inworld map and having to pull out your backpack to craft limited items create an immersion like no other game.

An Unforgettable Post-Apocalyptic Journey 

Metro Exodus is not just a game; it’s an emotional journey through a ruined world filled with danger, hope, and breathtaking moments. From the very beginning, it feels like you’re living inside a real story. The characters are incredibly well-written, and every choice you make feels meaningful.

The visuals are stunning. The open areas are rich with detail, each region having its own atmosphere—from frozen wastelands to dry deserts. The lighting and shadows are phenomenal, especially in dark tunnels or during sunsets over destroyed landscapes.

Gameplay is perfectly balanced:

Deep weapon customization

Limited resources that make every encounter intense

A smooth blend of stealth and action

Atmospheric music that enhances every scene

But the heart of the game is its story. It's emotional, human, and makes you feel truly connected to the crew of the Aurora. Even the quiet moments around the campfire are memorable and meaningful.

Metro Exodus masterfully combines open-world exploration, a dark and immersive atmosphere, emotional storytelling, and exceptional artistic detail. It’s one of the best post-apocalyptic experiences you can have.
