Pros:
• Good gameplay
• Large maps
• High-quality graphics
• Addition of new game mechanics

Cons:
• Change in Miller’s appearance
• Reworked mutant graphics appear already in Moscow; the explanation of a “different type of mutation” feels illogical since we are still in Moscow
• Save system – the game does save, but when loading it sometimes places you elsewhere or up to 20 minutes back, even though the save timestamp shows only 5 minutes ago (I'll probably get a bad ending because I don't have the patience to do it correctly five times in a row.")
• Miller has prosthetics from the start; it would be more interesting to first see him in a wheelchair and gradually show him getting back on his feet (could include 1–2 extra missions)

Metro Exodus is easily the biggest and best game of the series; all the hard work and development 4A Games built up since 2010 culminates in an expansive and poignant adventure with just a few small stumbles along the way.

Some time after Metro Last Light, Artyom clings to the hope that a better life exists beyond the underground tunnels. By chance, him and his wife Anna discover a fully functioning train and a long-buried truth that has been hidden for decades. A long journey begins as Artyom, Anna, Colonel Miller and the rest of the Order set out to find a new home. The story is certainly the best yet with a genuinely likeable and charismatic group of characters. From a writing standpoint, Anna has been vastly improved from the last entry and there is a greater sense of hope that compels you onward.

But the developer didn't stop there; they drastically expanded the scale and scope of the levels, taking some inspiration from Metal Gear Solid 5 and other open-world titles. The Volga River and Caspian Desert chapters are both brilliant showcases of building landscapes that feel real. There are no tickbox objectives, tedious busywork or pointless collectables. Everything has been hand-crafted from bandit camps to the main missions. It all blends so well with the franchise's deep immersion and completionists will gladly explore every nook and cranny.

The gameplay remains as visceral and engaging as ever with a few important tweaks. The bullet economy is gone, replaced by a handy crafting system. With tons of different weapons, attachments, repairs and upgrades, you have more free rein over your chosen armaments. The stealthy approach is also much more viable with the day/night cycle feeding right into your infiltration. There's a good balance between humans and monsters in combat and the title still packs plenty of tension with Artyom's fragile health pool.

It has some issues here and there, namely some ocassionally clunky movement and a lacklustre boss fight or two, but Metro Exodus is a must-own for all fans of shooters, horror and atmospheric immersion. There's no doubt that 4A are at the top of their game and I'm looking forward to what they put out next. The Two Colonels and Sam's Story DLC packs are also worth getting to expand things further.

[h1] Metro Exodus: A Metro game that doesn't belong [/h1]
[h2] Intro [/h2]
I am a long time fan of the entire Metro franchise, playing all the games it has to offer and reading plenty of the books as well. As a long time fan, I need to say that this game doesn't feel like Metro at all, it doesn't have that same vibe that the original metro or metro last light games had.

The game itself can be very clunky at times, especially with vehicles and the bunch of glitches they have. There are soft-lock issues, movement glitches and generally just bad level design at times.

[h2] Game Design [/h2]
The game design itself is very lacking, and to me, pretty disappointing. The partial open world levels get very stale, very quick. Every level is the same, you get some more of the story, you get random quests and need to roam the map often repeating similar actions etc. It is just not very interesting and it is very, very repetitive.

[h2] Morale [/h2]
The morale system is very bad, I went on every "side quest" that was morale related, like bringing back a guitar or teddy bear etc. expecting that it would be enough for a good ending, but I was SHOCKED when I finished the game and got one of the worse endings. Ends up, you need to use this games awful stealth mechanics at any time you can in order to get the good ending, which is quite absurd, considering you aren't exactly going around and killing a bunch of good people.

[h2] Conclusion [/h2]
All in all, I can see how some people might enjoy this game, especially those that aren't necessarily long time Metro fans, but to me this game is disappointing and I cannot recommend it. For a Metro game, it should either be full open world or fully linear like usual, a semi open world level game is too hard to pull off good with a universe such as Metro.

The game is a plain ok for me, followed by a couple of technical problems with it. First of all, it runs on a separate window instead of through Steam which results in various crashes, when alt+tabbing for example. Secondly, I couldn't roam the Caspian level because the vehicle was stuck between desert particles; I was unable to move it and roamed through the level on foot. 

Story-wise, there were a few enganging moments but nothing too serious nor it had the crisp of the other two installments in the franchise. Side-stories, additionally, felt too detached and quite "empty". Combat is mediocre with some erratic movements from the enemies. Point-blank range can fail and for long-range there were no distinct physics that would result in avoiding the target (or maybe I couldn't identify them)

The reason I uninstalled, and thankfully I played Two Colonels DLC first, is the autosaves that did not happen for half an hour in the Sam's Story DLC. That resulted in a huge loss of progress. However, that issue was not present in the main game and the flow was fine,

Overall, I would rate this as 3/5 and 2.5 with decimals allowed.

As much as I want to give this game a positive review, I just can't due to a few big issues. Keep in mind that I played on Ranger mode which I have also done so in previous Metro games.

Positives:

-The graphics are decent and the game doesn't rely on upscaling to run well.
-Animations are great (meaty shooting sounds and satisfying reloading etc).
-SFX is mostly great.
-The game's world/setting is enjoyable.
-I still really like the classic Metro ideas of having to charge your flashlight / pressure gun pumping mechanic and the mask oxygen filters. Simple but makes the general gameplay loop more satisfying (and it isn't really possible to run out of oxygen in this game unlike previous Metro games as you are able to craft them).


Negatives:

-AI - This is the biggest and most glaring issue at least when playing on Ranger mode. The AI has 2 different difficulties they will switch between... 1) Being completely braindead and easily manipulated... to... 2) Having godlike aim and will insta 1 pop your head the millisecond you enter their sight AT ANY RANGE. Now you might be thinking "OK well just go around and flank them then, it is an open world game!", sure for general exploration... but there are several story focused missions where you are forced to walk down a linear pathway and the enemies are just waiting for you or you have just a couple of seconds to shoot them before they get into position and insta aimbot you. You often die in 1 hit on Ranger mode and rarely 2 hits. Some of these scripted fight areas completely ruin the game on Ranger mode as you will be reloading the game several times in order to try and kill many enemies in a row without a single mistake. It turns these scripted fights from an apparent challenge to a memory game of "oh yeah, this bot will spawn here after I've killed these other ones". A couple of these sections are just so ridiculous that I wonder if anyone on their team even tested how outrageous the 1 shot AIs are. In the very first mission they have an enemy behind a smoke cloud that you can't see through, but the bot can sure see you. Fun.

I quit the game at the crane in the desert area. Why? Because I get to the top and a scripted enemy attack happens from the bottom of the crane from the other side of the huge bridge that you have just came from. My first thought is to hide behind the cover and look through a gap that is *literally* just a couple of pixels wide. "No way they can shoot me through this wall when they're about 200m away, surely?". Yes, they can. These bandits did a perfect 1 shot on me over 200m away, through a tiny pixel gap on metal cover with their scrap shotguns and pistols. Why bother continue to play after that. When the bots have this scripted attack mode on you are completely screwed. The general world exploration you are able to stealth kill a lot of them and even if you pull aggro you can hide in stealth areas, distract them away etc which gives a lot of options to deal with them... but you have none of that in these scripted action sequences, you just have to shoot them before they can get in position to aim.

-The setting of the game is great but the dialogue and general storytelling is generic and boring. I'm not a story skipper in games but I sure wanted to skip past a lot of this dialogue. I never got that with the previous Metro games though. I played with English voice acting and that is also pretty bad (yeah I know I probably should have played with Russian). The enemies in particular are often very goofy and stupid.

-The open world is boring. Perhaps I have too high expectations as I've played many other open world games with two examples being Xenoblade and Genshin but the open world in this game is pretty bad. There is barely anything to do and exploration is actively not encouraged as you are often just wasting bullets on monsters just to get less bullets back as your exploration "reward". I get that it is an apocalypse so you can't be having a dopamine spree with opening loot every minute but still... Why bother with an open world game if you put such little content in it. Feels like they just wanted another linear game but slightly different just for a change of pace.


TL;DR. The shooting is fun and satisfying (I love the bolt action stealth pistol especially) but you are either just shooting target dummies or getting 1 shot from any range INSTANTLY on Ranger mode in sections where stealth is scripted to not be possible. The open world and the dialogues are boring. The game is likely a lot more fun on non-Ranger modes but I honestly cannot be bothered to continue, unfortunately.

[h2]Let me just start by saying that it's such a shame that, should you choose to spend no money on the game, you are still matched up with players who buy their way into a winning position.[/h2]

More often than not, my opponents either have way more hours under their belt (fair enough, I joined late - I have no issue with this) or they’ve bought their way into a completely stacked deck. And honestly? That’s fine. If someone wants to drop half their rent to lose to someone with a starter deck, I’m not going to stop them. To be fair, I [b]do[/b] get why the matchmaking works this way - it keeps queues fast and the player pool healthy. And yes, every card can technically be earned through play - it’ll just take a lot of hours and patience to get there. At the end of the day, it’s still not as fair a system as it could be, and whales do have a clear edge early on.

Aside from the unfair matchmaking in the previous regard, when I [b]am[/b] playing against people my own level or economic situation, it is an incredibly fun experience. It certainly feels rewarding to overcome your opponent with a supreme strategy, which are, most of the time, dynamically changing as the game goes on. This keeps me on the edge of my seat and has me constantly thinking ahead as to what the opponent might do and how I might react - it's great!

On another note, the graphics & animations are very pleasing, the variety of cards is impressive, and despite my earlier complaint about people essentially paying to win, you do indeed get a great amount of content and opportunities to build a formidable deck without spending any money. To date, I have won most of my games, and again, that's without spending a cent. Also, there is a draft game-mode where you and your opponent both build a deck from scratch by choosing from randomly presented card packages - which is a neat break in between things.

Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who falls into the following groups:
- You enjoyed playing Gwent in The Witcher 3
- You're a fan of strategy OR tabletop games and like to flex your strategic superiority
- You have some money to burn and enjoy having the upper hand on lower level players as a result
- Are a fan of The Witcher in general

So yeah, ultimately, it’s a very fun game - especially when a whale drops a small fortune on cards and still gets wiped by someone who spent $0. [i]At this point, they’re basically just paying to boost my ego, so who am I to complain?[/i]

My Review of Gwent

When I sit down with Gwent, it doesn’t feel like a game meant to pass time or bait quick dopamine hits—it feels like stepping into a world that understands where I’m at in life. The Witcher universe has always carried weight, but Gwent translates that maturity into something more than flavor. The card art alone tells stories of hardship, struggle, and consequence. It’s not childish spectacle; it’s grit and realism wrapped in folklore, politics, and war.

What sets Gwent apart for me isn’t just the atmosphere, but the way it rewards patience, calculation, and composure. It doesn’t beg me to play flashy for the sake of it; it demands foresight, resource management, and the ability to read not just my hand, but my opponent’s mind. This resonates with my own approach to competition: I don’t play games to stumble into victories, I play to dissect, outthink, and sharpen myself through the process.

Unlike games that thrive on chaos or gimmicks, Gwent makes me feel like my victories carry meaning. Every round I win comes from strategy, timing, and restraint. Even in defeat, there’s value, because I can trace back exactly what I misread, what I wasted, or what I should have held onto longer. That kind of clarity isn’t common in games—and I appreciate it because it mirrors how I live: owning my mistakes, learning, and using them to rise stronger.

In short, Gwent doesn’t try to be for everyone, and that’s why it works for me. It’s a mature card game built for players who think deeply, who want to win with their mind rather than noise. It feels like a conversation with people closer to my age, not a playground of kids chasing thrills. And that makes every match, win or lose, feel like time well spent.

Kind of a shame what happened to Gwent. Just to preface this, I have probably 1k hours in the mobile and/or GOG version. This **WAS** one of my favorite games in the TCG genre. Until the devs cut support.

The core gameplay of this is very unlike other card games. You draw all of your cards at once (with addtl draws in between rounds) and take turns playing cards until you or your opponent pass. Games follow a best of three round system where typically only cards in-hand are retained between rounds (although there are some units with carryover effects). Cards don't have a mana value during a match, instead the "mana" value is accounted for during deckbuilding by forcing an upper limit of total mana across all cards in the deck. Cards are either units with point totals or are spells which impact other units's point totals in some way. Whoever has the most points on board at the end of a round wins that round. Decks building has 2 simple rules: the deck must have more than x number of cards and the deck must not go over a certain "provision" total (where each card has a provision amount which indicates the card's relative power).

Because of the Bo3 format, there are a lot of interesting strategies that come up. Do you go all in to win in round 1+2? Do you try to get your opponent to waste resources in round 1 and you go for the win in 2+3? Do you win big in round 1 then try to force an over-commitment from your opponent in round 2 so you have an advantage in round 3? There are lots of ways of think about strategy here. 

Unfortunately, the devs were too generous with players earning in-game currency, so the game didn't earn enough money. Due to this poor monetization structure, eventually CDPR cut support for the game and now there is no chance of there ever being new cards. Before they dropped support, they did implement a community voting system. This mixes up the meta every month, but the community tends to overreact to over- or under-performing cards, so it feels very chaotic.

A well known survival loot game, this platform is able to deliver a multitude of fun for up to 4 players as they scramble around various maps to find 'scrap', avoid monsters, and sell them to the entity for profit. Despite being an indie game with laughably low graphics quality (think Minecraft), this platform is able to turn these disadvantages around by advertising itself as a VERY light-weight and rapid-loading game with minimal computer and temperature stresses. 

Up to 4 players are placed on particular 'moon' maps of one's choosing, and all have access to proximity voice and text chat. Clearly distinct and important items are brightly colored to contrast with the surrounding background, and more valuable loot are usually smaller or darker colored in nature. A variety of different monsters all require different strategies for management, adding to the tension, with some being able to more punish solo players than others. Tools become paramount in managing one's playthrough and can be picked up from dead players to prevent permanent loss. All of these aspects combine together as players eagerly or terrifyingly shout at their teammates for instructions or assistance as they strive to gather enough scrap and survive their moon maps. 

As mentioned earlier, graphics are ridiculously low quality, but it is clear that the game was deliberately designed as such. Still however, this may prove unattractive to some players who seek visual beauty and details. As players progress through more and more moons and scrap selling, they will eventually hit near impossible scrap goals, guarenteeing their inevitable game-over and restart, which may prove discouraging to some. Having a mic is almost a requirement, as most hosts often kick players who do not have any. The learning curve is quite sharp, as this game provides minimal hand holding and instead kicks their baby chick players out of the nest to die and learn anew. 

At the end of the day, this light-weight and computer friendly game provides an easy-to-pick up platformer with simple and straightforward goals. Even the most veteran players remain vulnerable to death, as the focus revolves not around combat, but survival and looting. Highly recommend with friends with mics, and for its relatively low price and computer stress, this game is a must-try for even the most casual players.

Steam Review:  

Lethal Company stands out as one of the most unexpectedly amusing and genuinely thrilling co-op experiences I’ve encountered in quite some time. It strikes an ideal balance between horror and humor — one moment, you find yourself stealthily navigating a dimly lit corridor, listening for any signs of movement, and the next, you’re shrieking as your friend inadvertently opens the wrong door at the absolute worst moment. The game’s lo-fi visual style surprisingly enhances the eerie ambiance without detracting from the enjoyment. The diverse enemy types keep each mission engaging, while the sound design is exceptional; if you notice something breathing behind you, it’s probably too late. 

What truly sets this game apart is its player-driven chaos. Every session unfolds like a unique narrative: 

- There’s always that one person who gets overly ambitious for “just one more piece of scrap.” 
- Someone inevitably forgets to secure the bunker door. 
- And there’s always a player left behind during takeoff.

The replayability factor is immense, as even after numerous runs, I still find myself both laughing and feeling frantic simultaneously. If you enjoy cooperative gameplay, light survival elements, or shouting at friends while hurrying towards an extraction ship, this title is definitely worth purchasing. **10 out of 10  Would willingly sacrifice my coworker again.

I will try to be very objective in this review. This game has brought me many hours of fun and enjoyment with my friends. However, I can’t turn a blind eye to the current state of things. The game, as it stands right now, is very lacking—no significant updates, extremely basic “changes,” and a complete lack of effort to keep players engaged. Sadly, it seems to be heading down the same path as many other indie games. What I mean by that is it appears to be stuck in Early Access hell forever.

It wouldn’t really be an issue if the game were free-to-play or sold as a complete product. My biggest gripe with all of this is that this is no longer a small project. The game has sold well and even had a collaboration with Epic Games. The means were there to continue developing the project and not leave players in the dark for so long. However, the predictable choice was to almost fully abandon the game and focus on other things while the game you paid for rots in Early Access limbo.

In conclusion, as of right now, I cannot recommend the game unless it somehow gets back on track.

Amored Core is the 6th game in an entry where the last game was over a decade ago made by the people who made a game franchise that still gets used as an inspiration to this day. With that preface, do you like violence? 

Do you like guns? Do you like the feeling of cold hard cash after slaughtering anyone who gets in your way? Do you enjoy a game where you can freely craft the perfect combat automaton to counter anything that gets in your way without commiting to a specific style? Do you want a easy to follow yet deep story which is the polar opposite of how FromSoft handles all of their storytelling and lore in the Souls series? Do you enjoy making your Gundam look like a Ferrari? If you answered yes to at least 2 of the ones above, this game is for you. If not, go watch the Keanu Reeves vid, then come back to this.

This game has some of the best characterization via voiceacting ive ever seen in a game.

The mechs are really fun, and the game is gorgeous, but the writing and fact they can make a character loved, pitied, or hated solely via nothing but comms chatter - that is the truly great thing about ac6. 

To put it simply - the characters in this game feel like actual people, that could actually exist, 
It has one of the most genuinely hateable antagonists ive seen in a game, a cowardly, selfish, arrogant man without a good bone in his body, but somehow, he isnt boring, or annoying, or over the top. He is just that - a man. The same could be said for the characters I love, who are like people that I would want to be friends with in real life.

Also, if you were like me, and prefer mechs like battletech/mechwarrior over more anime-ish mechs akin to gundam - still give this game a try. Playing a slow lumbering mech is totally viable, and a ton of fun. Nothing feels better just eating an enemy's strongest attack and watching your utter brick wall of a mech shrug it off, and then deleting them from existence.

Would reccommend for the writing alone, and doubly so if you like giant robots of any type.

I've been gaming for over 30 years and this is one of the rare games that I honestly can't find a flaw with. In terms of  what it is trying to do in its genre, I would give it a 10/10.  To give some context, I think I have only ever rated Crono Trigger, Metal Gear Solid, and Breath of the Wild a 10/10 off the top of my head. That puts this game in rare company.

That being said, I don't think it necessarily is one of the best games of all time, I just think it is a flawless game. Everything from gameplay, the missions, layout and story are awesome. And honestly I think this is the literal best instance of how to do new game + correctly. It gives you a reason to replay the game while also dolling out tiny bits of new content while doing this. Armored Core: Fires of Rubicon – Review 8

Armored Core: Fires of Rubicon feels like a time capsule from the golden age of gaming—a reminder of when titles were tough, gameplay-first, and unburdened by fluff. Its lineage goes all the way back to the late ’90s PSX era, and that heritage shows: this is a game that knows exactly what it wants to be, and it delivers with confidence.

Visually, the game isn’t a powerhouse. Graphics: 8 —nothing spectacular, but clean, stylish, and perfectly functional for the speed and clarity a mech game demands. The real star is the combat. Gameplay: 8.5 —high-paced armored-mecha action at its finest. Like the classic entries, it expects you to adjust your build for each encounter rather than brute-force with pure skill, and that philosophy is still part of its charm.

The presentation hits solid notes across the board: Sound: 8, with industrial beats and sharp effects that fit the world, and Story: 7.5, a simple but compelling narrative that does more with restraint than many modern blockbusters do with endless cutscenes.

If you’re tired of bloated open worlds and checklist design, Fires of Rubicon is a breath of fresh air. It’s focused, challenging, stylish—and the kind of game that can make you fall in love with the medium all over again.

Honestly, I really liked this game, but after further play I realize I can't really recommend it. After going back and playing through other Armored Core games as well as other giant robot games both retro and modern, the fact that this is the game that is now the flag ship of the mecha genre is disappointing. Not because its worse than any of the other Armored Core games nor any other mecha game, but its disappointing that this is the best the genre has to offer. This is very easily one of the best if not the best Armored Core game out there. The game is extremely well polished, worked perfect on launch, and has no micro transactions or any major hickups, and the game can be extremely fun.
However, I just don't think this modernization of Armored Core works well. The Armored Cores of the past admittedly are not great. Many missions are just you destroying waves of clueless MT's that have no chance of beating you, until you come to a mission where you get absolutely destroyed by fighting 3 AC's at once. This game is far better than the Armored Cores of the past (don't take armored core fans word for it, actually go and play them and see for yourself if you don't believe me). But AC6 doesn't know what it wants to be. A big part of the Armored Cores of the past was that there was no healing. All the health you had was given at the start of the mission, this would turn certain missions into a game of learning how to navigate to the end while taking as little damage as possible for the boss. It also made your mechs feel more unique and specialized making you choose between just beefing up, or trying to be nimble and skilled enough to just avoid the damage all together. With the healing items and resupply mechanic in AC6, navigating through the map feels extremely trivial, almost like a waste of time. The combat is flashy and satisfying enough to where, on your first playthrough, you wont even notice how little they put up a fight. If somehow you manage to get through all your medkits fighting MT's, it doesn't even matter since you will autosave before you get to whatever boss you are going to fight. This mechanic in a weird way makes the game more frustrating, because if your build isn't cutting it for the boss, since you are mid mission you can't buy and sell parts to fit the job. So instead of just having the mission be the boss, you have to quit the mission, make your new mech, go fight your way back to the checkpoint, and then try your new build against the boss. This disincentivizes experimentation because the dark souls mentality (lets be honest that's why we ALL played this game) just tells you to keep fighting rather than back out, which while this can be satisfying, isn't what the Armored Core series has been about.
Speaking of the buy and sell system, while in the beginning this does lead to an interesting 4th dimension to mech building where you have to factor in the cost of parts, at a certain point in the game no matter what mech you want to build, if you just sell everything you can always make it (you get all your money back when selling parts). This just adds more friction to mech building requiring you to back out of the buy menu, go to the sell menu, sell all the parts you aren't currently using, then buy the ones you do. Even worse if it's a core in which you need to first buy the core you want, then swap, then sell. 
There are some really awesome missions in this game, but the majority of them just feel like the equivalent of orange waypoint AAA slop, just something to do because you have to do something. You don't really feel like the legendary Raven pilot, you feel like a fly swatter.
Like other AC games, you aren't necessarily getting attached to characters the same you would in a Baldurs Gate or a Tale Tale game or something. You just like them cause they are cool but nothing really beyond that. The ending quality varies WILDLY. The first ending I got absolutely blew me away and made me think about the game for weeks after I beat it, but after getting another ending, the ending most people probably would have gotten, I was extremely disappointed and felt completely unfulfilled after having going through the entire game again, which leads me to my last point.
This game isn't very replayable, but it very much tries to be. The mission replay system encourages you to replay missions to try and "S-Rank" them by beating them faster, taking less damage, ect, but doesn't present itself in a way that makes that satisfying. Maybe if there was an extra UI showing the time needed to S or the damage you can still take before going past the threshold while you are doing the mission it would feel better but you get nothing, once you are in the mission you are in the dark so it just feels unsatisfying. And most missions aren't interesting enough for you to even want to replay them, and you have to if you want to get all the endings, one of which requires you to get all other endings. 
But there still is a reason I have so much time in the game, and was my favorite game of 2023. The environments are beautiful and dreary. The sound design, particle effects, movement, and mech design are incredibly immersive and really give off this awesome feeling of dealing with truly extraordinary weapons and armor of the future. The aesthetic is raw and incredibly unique. The voice acting is, okay well the voice acting is really rough, but some characters like Handler Walter, Carla, Ayre, and Rusty, while not being fleshed out or honestly even really characters, are still presented in such a way that make them unforgettable (in certain endings). Where this game shines is what all AC games shine in, the customization, and this game turns it up to 11, letting you choose what type of weathering you want, how much weathering, differing finishes between matte and glossy, colors, your boosters, targeting systems, weapons, swap-able weapons. The cosmetic customization and the build variety is something I haven't been able to find in any other pilot game. This game showcases what is now exceedingly rare in the gaming industry, truly showing off things that can only be done by a AAA studio, and using that power to bring to reality something that fans of mecha or just gaming in general could only dream of a decade ago. It truly is an unforgettable game with spectacle I've never seen before. 
If you are truly passionate about the mecha genre, this is an absolute no brainer purchase, its the most important thing we have gotten in gaming, but Armored Core isn't yet at a point where I can truly recommend it to everyone, and I'm incredibly excited for when we get to that point.

Not sure if I don’t like the game or if I don’t like that this is not what Armored Core used to be back in the day. So take my review as a failed attempt to manage my own expectations.

Unlike in the older AC titles where strategic planning and resource management were still a thing, AC6 focuses more on mechanical execution of combat maneuvers, dodge timings and overall button pressing technique. The stagger mechanic rewards ultra-aggressive combat style over any type of cautious approach, meaning that the action is extremely frantic all the time. You can spam all your weapons simultaneously and most of the time an effective combat approach is just to mash all four weapon triggers without thinking. Failing a mission is not usually caused by your build or miscalculated strategic approach but more often just a consequence of wrongly timed button presses and badly executed combos.

Mech parts you regret having bought get fully refunded when sold and the only penalty of failing a mission is the annoyance of having to replay the mission again. This is underlined even more with the very forgiving checkpoint system, which on the other hand is really mandatory due to the overtuned boss encounters. Having no consequences for bad decisions means that there is also no incentive of getting invested in planning.

The linear story is expressed through brief and meaningless radio chatter that supposedly tries to be cool and serious but ends up being deeply embarrassing to mature audience.

If you want to have another action game influenced by the new generation From Software games but this time with a mech reskin, go for it. If you are looking for the classic Armored Core experience, there is a high chance that you will be disappointed.

Top 3 Things I Liked:

Solid Gameplay – Moving your character around, shooting stuff—it's fun and engaging.
Great Graphics – Looks fantastic; AAA quality all the way.
Mech Building – They simplified the process nicely,  a little bare-bones but, the customization system isn't overly tedious.
Top 3 Things I Think the Game Fails At:

Control Scheme – The mech doesn't move like a real mech. Nothing about the movement feels mechanical—you're just controlling a person, not an Armored Core.
Plus, the controls are awkward. I keep boosting in the wrong direction, and it doesn't feel like a skill issue; the mech gets hung up on terrain or dashes in the wrong way. It’s as if the game expects you to fight its controls rather than letting you explore and use the commands freely. I’ve never written a critique quite like this before; movement just feels off.

Mechanics and UI – on the mech customization, it's not tedious but, there's limited parts- so the builds all feel rock, paper, scissors. The UI is basic and lacks what I think is important feedback, making customization less satisfying.

Franchise Expectations – AC has never been known for its story or music, and I thought this one might improve on that, but it didn’t. It seems like many of the combat mechanic issues from AC 2 are still present, but masked with fancy dash mechanics for faster paced combat, unfortunately this introduces some goofy control issues. (I'll try again with a controller and a joystick, Maybe this is a keyboard mouse thing.) 
Was disappointing to see the mech-building aspect take a backseat to try and appeal to a broader audience. However, it's really not a bad system - I just thought it wasn't as good as some of it's predecessors. (nothing was as bad as AC 3).
While it’s not a bad game, the control issues and the reduction in depth in key areas really ruin the experience for me.

This is a very conflicting review cause the game is fun but has so many short sighted issues that all in all it just isn't worth the full price. The game has shifted the franchise to a very "speedball" style of play almost like Doom. Everything is constant motion yet the system doesn't even make sense. You can walk with your legs, but spend 90% sliding around yet despite of this there's no way to permanently toggle it on or off. You have to activate sliding every single time you start walking, god forbid you DO stop. Sliding also doesn't use you're energy meter despite using your boosters constantly which feels like a way to forceably enable the fast paced mechanics without worrying about balancing. On top of that, most bosses you'll fight have unlimited energy supplies and will simply fly around the entire time. You'll likely spend most of the match just turning around trying to find them. But there's still more issues..

-Despite being a core dynamic the auto targeting is incredibly sloppy at times. When going against multiple opponents the tracking system till often turn and begin targeting a different enemy then the one you're trying to or have been attacking. On the boss fight of the 3rd ending alone I missed the fatal shot on the first stage and got killed because when the enemy was staggered my Core turned to fire on an enemy OFF SCREEN that got too close behind me and triggered the targeting to swap.

-enemy and boss stats will often be skewed against your favor in other ways then limitless flight, such as stagger bars that massively drop almost instantly after you land a shot and fade to zero faster then it takes to reload

-While there's a lot of guns and weapons, so many of them are incredibly redundant making most of them virtually useless, being out classed by something virtually identical but slightly better. Most of the active player base seems to mostly stick to a sold 12 or so weapons over all. 

-mech builds also feel fairly limited. Even if you wanna go full speedball and make a high speed glass canon you likely wont be able to meet the energy requirements for about half of the more interesting guns. Heavy builds tend to be too slow for the enemies that can constantly fly around and are more like being on the wrong side of target practice

-You have an INSANE amount of customization, able to make or download decals and apply them limitlessly, however there is no mirroring option meaning left and right symmetry must be painstakingly done by hand. As well, there is no option to save customized patterns for individual parts, you have to save the entire robot design. God forbid you need to change JUST the legs or something for a single mission and forget to, all you work is gone.

-the story was honestly a lil mid and the whole play it 3 times to unlock 4 different missions each play through for a different ending thing is pretty lame. All of the endings are basically just "FromSofts usual Existential Nihilism"  packed with slightly different flavors

-Many of the stats and effects aren't directly listed or are poorly labeled with small pictographs that you need to pull up the help screen for to get a explanation of. One Stat, Stagger damage modifier, doesn't seem to be listed at all. Some Melee weapons do more damage to staggered enemies and actually makes them better for certain builds, but you have to go to reddit or a 3rd party site to find that out.

-no melee only builds, you cant equip them to your right hand at all and they wouldn't be viable with the face paced ranged style of combat loop that makes up the game. 

-Missions for the most part are very short. Dying and repeating boss fights pads gameplay time, as does the multi play throughs for all endings

While on the whole I did very much enjoy playing this, at times it felt more like a chore to slog through. it has a lot or potential and I hope they make a sequel with more refined combat loop, but all in all I can't in good faith reccommend this as a full price game because it feels unfinished in terms of actual game play.

Kind of got ruined by some very asinine boss fights. The rules of that your mech is constrained to is often just not applied to the boss, which is like 90% of the difficulty in this game. You're fighting mechs are are supposedly and equivalent of yours, but like, they will just outright cheat by ignoring the rules that apply to you.

For example, one of the rules that you're subjected to is your thruster energy. Quick boosts consumes your thrusters, and so is flying. Then you have enemy mech bosses that will just be in perpetual flight 90% of the fight while also dodging with quick boosts, completely disregarding the thruster energy component of the game. It's like fighting bosses that have infinite stamina in a souls game, where if you get unlucky, they will just unleash a series of combo that lasts forever.

Another is the stagger. When you get staggered, it's always a fixed time depending on your mech build. Bosses however, will just get staggered for almost random amounts of time. They can get staggered a full 5 seconds, or they can get staggered for a full 0.5 seconds. I'd almost call this a bug, but the game is 2 years old and happened so often that I will just call it a feature

And then there's the range. Enemies will just ignore the range limit on weapons. For example, you and an enemy both use a sniper, you both do a charged shot and you both land a hit, all at the same very far distance. You will take 600 damage while the enemy takes 27. Because you are "out of weapon's effective range". But the enemies will just ignore this rule. Game tells you you're a sucker and you take full damage.

EDIT : Finished the game and got all 3 endings. My opinion remains the same.

Armored Core as a franchise has gone through distinct eras with numerous changes/differences between them. Just because you liked the games from one era, it doesn't mean you will like the games in other eras. I liked the original era and had mixed feelings with the two eras that followed. I hated the fourth and fifth eras. This game is another new era. It has borrowed mostly from the fourth and fifth eras with some compromise with other eras and chunks inspired by systems from other FromSoft titles. I found it to be a miserable, ugly experience. Movement felt bad, combat felt bad, and every aspect of the game's visual and audio design was unpleasant. I need to accept that this franchise has long been done with me, and I need to be done with it.

Most missions have you face a lot of cannon fodder foes that pose zero threat to you, going down in a single hit. In many ways, the work of a critic is easy. We risk very little, yet enjoy a position over those who offer up their work and their selves to our judgment. We thrive on negative criticism, which is fun to write and to read. But the bitter truth we critics must face, is that in the grand scheme of things, the average piece of junk is probably more meaningful than our criticism designating it so. But there are times when a critic truly risks something, and that is in the discovery and defense of the new. The world is often unkind to new talent, new creations. The new needs friends. Last night, I experienced something new: an extraordinary game from a singularly unexpected source. To say that both the action and its consequences have challenged my preconceptions about fine decisions is a gross understatement. They have rocked me to my core. In the past, I have made no secret of my disdain for Life is Strange's famous motto, "This Action Will Have Consequences." But I realize, only now do I truly understand what it meant. Not everyone can become a great artist; but a great artist can come from anywhere. It is difficult to imagine more humble origins than those of the genius now working at Life is Strange, who is, in this critic's opinion, nothing less than the finest developer on Steam. I will be returning to Life is Strange soon, hungry for more.

ABSOLUTE MASTERPIECE. if you are thinking about giving this a try, DO IT. The story is well built, the characters are well developed, the game is full of plot twists that keep you on your toes. Sobbed multiple times throughout the game, and I will definitely replay this till the day I die

The thing that stood out so much in this game was its atmosphere. It's idylic, I really loved the music breaking in throughout the story while the backdrops remain amazing to see and work through. The dialogue doesnt always work for me but I think it being a bit awkward is okay as well. Story-wise the game does a really good job at making the character's motivations worth the time you spend with them. The mechanics of rewinding to see other outcomes are really well implemented and definetly make it worth a play if you haven't had the chance.

I liked the soundtrack of this game which really supports the ambiance for the game. The story is pretty good too which is framed / portrayed somewhat uniquely around the theme of photography and time travel. The time rewind ability adds a level of complexity for choices along with puzzle solving. There are some deeper meanings / philosophical ideas to be explored as well. When exploring, the main character does have plenty of commentary, but these can be somewhat basic at times.

Overall, would recommend as the story gets pretty emotional and more impactful as you progress through each episode / chapter.

After an hour I was bored because the story did not draw me in. The pace was so slow even when I was avoiding interacting with random objects and skipping repeated sequences wherever possible. This is largely down to the rewind mechanism that really slows down the flow of the story.

If you like games that take away your agency / control frequently and for long periods of time (multiple minute) with cut-scenes that you can't skip even on 2nd play-thrus and feel VERY disruptive to your gameplay so that the developers can better tell a story, then you might enjoy this. if you like having "GUNS BAD" and similar ideology subtly pushed at you, you might enjoy this. If you like having characters that (when you can actually control them) move at the pace of a elderly, disabled snail travelling uphill in the dead of winter, then you may enjoy this.

Otherwise, it'll be a matter of how much you can tolerate those things compared to the quality of the story experience. Story was ok - I tend to be a big fan of time-travel themes, the rest was so-so. That said, the frequent, slow, and long cinemas that kept taking away my agency for extended periods really soured the overall experience for me.

Also, just to be clear there ARE bits of dialog that you CAN skip, but ONLY after you have listened to the slow version once and then rewound time (and that's per play-thru so if you start over, then you STILL need to listen to the slow clip once before you can skip it). Also, while that applies to most dialog, it seemed like there were a few lines here and there that you couldn't skip and you definitely could not skip the cinemas that played at the beginning and end of each chapter as well as during whatever random story point they felt like.

Game is strange, Not my story. 

Graphics is not good enough, sometimes it can not keep up with the emotion behind those great voice acting at all. For a game focusing on story and released in 2015, the character modeling could use more work. The music is fine as the story itself doesn't require too much.

The gameplay is unique, it feels like loading last choice in Visual Novel, but it does have some clever designs involving time reverse rather than simple save and load. But There are some flaws in terms of gameplay as well, irrelevant interactions like checking photos, opening drawers, Max's reaction can't be skipped, for important events, we have to wait for voice to end. And the last choice, I can not fast forward either after getting one ending. Max keeps saying "should have", it could be a hint for using rewind, but also annoying as it sounds like Max has no stand at all.

And the biggest problem, story. It starts with a fantasy disaster, which is not important until the end. Not a problem, let's work on the main plots, the crime and suspense, I have to say it does hide those clues well, when the truth is disclosed, those small but unusual points all make sense. But I also have to say the suspense is successful because the story is filled with a lot of common teenage problems and emotions, too much trivia that I gradually lost interest in tracking the murderer. And for the characters, they talk a lot to build their own background, but when it comes to key events, they quickly changed their opinion because our Max is totally persuasive if she insists. A simple rewind power is not good enough to put all this together.

The ending is a coin choice besides the game keeps telling our choices has impact, maybe just like Max's rewind, yeah, she can rewind, but in a short term, or even worse, her choices are meaningless after all. The superpower is given to Max, she could either sacrifice a lot of people to make a difference, make the changes constant, or she could give up her choice, and make all her nightmare experience in vain. I don't feel the bond between Max and Chloe, because it is Max who lives her choice again and again, and Chloe is not even there at the end, one week happy and horror experience is not enough for me to be touched.

The concept is good and there are some genuinely captivating moments, but they are drowned in a sea of absolute mediocrity. From the abuse of trite and obnoxious teen drama tropes to straight up bad writing, there is enough to fill up a whole course about how [b]not[/b] to write fiction here. I get that I'm not exactly the target audience and a certain degree of cringeness is to be expected due to the characters being teenagers and all, but that does not excuse the profound lack of logic and coherence of certain scenes and dialogues, not to mention the forced lingo that gives everything a sour "40 year old trying to sound like a highschooler" aftertaste.

A lot of people were left disappointed by the ending, particularly due to the fact that the only choice that truly matters in the end is the one you make in the last minute of gameplay. I honestly didn't mind that too much. True, the whole "choices matter" thing is little more than a marketing trick and very few and often minor details change from picking a dialogue choice instead of another ([spoiler]even Kate's death is eventually brushed off when Max changes all past events[/spoiler]) but in a story that is fundamentally about how tragedies happen and learning to make do with the hand you've dealt in life, that is honestly acceptable. What angered me is the fact that the writers wasted a lot of time dwelling in absolutely pointless sub-plots and school dramas, changing pace all of a sudden once they got to the last episode, which honestly is the best part of the whole game but it feels rushed, hamfisted and cheap. They really pulled a Shyamalan move trying to stage a big plot twist that just came out as a goofy asspull, which is sad since most of the last hours of the game are really intense and would've otherwise been really compelling.

I will spend a couple more words on the main characters, because I just feel like I have to: Chloe is an insufferable idiot. Like, seriously. There is no amount of daddy issues or teenage rebellion that can excuse being THIS stupid, and that seriously impacts the whole story in a negative way, since you're supposed to care for her. Max in turn is the epitome of "basic yet pretentious white girl", which also makes really hard to relate to her, at least for anyone who has a bare minimum of personality. The other characters range from "functional to the plot" to completely unremarkable so there's really not much to say about them. Except for Kate, maybe, which is the character I found more likeable - ironic, since she's supposed to be a Catholic bible-basher.

In short: lots and lots of wasted potential. I cannot recommend this to anyone except maybe to people who thoroughly enjoy cheesy braindead teen drama. Which, apparently, is quite a large audience.

The honest & candid comment from me is Life Is Strange 2 is an absolutely breathtaking narrative experience that blends powerful storytelling, heartfelt character development, emotional depth, and beautifully crafted choices into a journey that stays with you long after the credits roll! Additionally, the choices in this game carry weight unlike anything I’ve experienced in other narrative titles, with every action shaping not only the story but the very person Daniel becomes, creating a truly powerful sense of responsibility & connection. Furthermore, every episode feels like a meaningful chapter in a beautifully told story, filled with real emotion, relatable struggles, moral complexity & a heartfelt exploration of family that elevates this game far beyond a typical choice-based adventure.

How do you follow up a beloved, critically acclaimed game that is based around a novel mechanic?

Instead of just settling for more of the same with some technical improvements, developer DONTNOD gives us a completely new story, new characters and, in a risky but brave move, complete drops the first game's signature time-rewind mechanic.

Despite this, the game still has the soul of Life Is Strange - The indie soundtrack and the sad-but-not-necessarily-depressing vibe, as well as a refreshingly realistic portrayal of American teenagers who swear, drink, smoke weed and have sex (all of which makes them come across as relatable, rather than extreme or even particularly cool).

Being a fan of the first game, I thought I was going to miss Max Caulfield's time-rewinding powers but it turns out the story is all the stronger for it because the stakes are higher when you can't save people's lives by rewinding time.

Unlike the first game (which kicked off the story with the murder of a stranger and then instantly brought them back to life) this game really packs some emotional punches by letting you spend time with the characters before tragedy strikes (spoiler: there are some character deaths throughout the game that you can't prevent and instead, all you can do is choose how to react to them).

Just like the first game's story was often concerned with sexism and the treatment of women, this game's story is often cornerned with racism (police brutality against minorities is a major plot point). A major difference though, is how much more vulnerable the new protaginsts are. 
Not only because they lack Max's power but also because they spend most of the game on the road and unlike Max, they don't have a choice.

A common criticism against this type of game is that your choices don't really matter because the main story is the same anyway. While it would have been nice to be able to visit some new locations and meet some new characters on a 2nd playthrough (pretty much my only complaint), your choices often DO influence your relationship towards other characters and character development is such a big part of the game that it even becomes a mechanic - Your little brother WILL pick up bad habits from you if you're not a good role model and unlike the first game, which simply let you choose between two endings once you reached the conclusion, this game has up to four endings (plus some minor variations) that depends on your actions throughout the story.

There's also a particularly heart-breaking scenario early in the game where players who choose to treat a character poorly may end up feeling guilty when they realize how pointless those choices actually were from a practical standpoint.


If you're a fan of the first Life Is Strange, this one does not disappoint and actually improves on its' predecessor, despite lacking that game's most notable gimmick.

[h3] Spoilers ahead - you've been warned. [/h3]

Read the complete story here: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3606445552

[hr][/hr]

[h1] It wasn't just about two brothers. It was about our everyday life. [/h1]

[hr][/hr]

Life is Strange 2 shows how one day can change your whole life. One day you go back home from school, laugh, and prepare for an upcoming party. The next day your life turns upside down. You don’t have a house or even a trust fund. Life is strange indeed, and the game makes you face that reality from the first episode.

I also love how the developers show the main characters as wolves, because wolves are free, independent, and loyal, just like people want to be. This idea connects to something bigger, and yeah, it gets political, because everything is politics nowadays. Everyone in the world has the right to speak, rebel, and do whatever they want (without breaking the laws, though). And some countries don’t let you do that, like North Korea, even though people pretend it’s the only one. That’s a myth. This whole theme of freedom ties directly back into the wolves, who represent the life Sean and Daniel want but can’t fully have.

Anyways, politics is trash. I played this game and got all the endings two years ago, which means I’ve had a lot of time to sit with it and think. That’s why I’m even writing something this long.

The main message of the game, at least for me, is that you can’t escape reality, even if you literally run into the desert. Karen tried to do that when she left Sean and Daniel for the life she wanted, but she couldn’t escape the problems she carried inside herself. And honestly, that’s something we all do. We think changing jobs or moving somewhere new will magically reset us, but most of the time we’re just trying to find ourselves without even realizing it.

This connects to the road trip the boys take. It’s something I’ve wanted to do for a long time, and I still want to. Just without the constant fear they dealt with. Brody Holloway became my inspiration here. He’s the perfect example of someone who doesn’t pretend to have life figured out. He just keeps moving, keeps observing, and lives with the basics: gas money, food, and cheap motels. He writes about life and the places he’s been, and that simplicity is honestly the point of traveling. 

Even stumbling from failure to failure helps you find yourself. This is Karen’s painting, by the way. It was behind her trailer. She was the perfect example of this idea. Going to New York was her first failure, not her last, but eventually she found peace. Not a glamorous peace, but a real one. In the desert, surrounded by people who understood her.

And when you think about Episode 5, climbing all those rocks to reach the top of the canyon, it ties everything together. You start to understand how small we are in this world, how little control we have, and how the journey changes us more than the destination ever could.

Everyone in the game pushes you to think about the future. At least that’s how it felt to me. Even characters like Stanley and Arthur, who are just living peacefully in the desert. They show that there’s nothing wrong with choosing a life outside society’s expectations. Karen talks about how society forces rules on us, but the truth is simple: everyone’s different. You should do what feels right, make the choices that matter to you, and live by your own rules.

Daniel’s situation in Episode 4 also fits into this pattern. It’s a perfect example of how not to live your life. Don’t let people manipulate you, no matter how convincing they sound. And yeah, it starts to sound like a political campaign, but it’s not meant to be one.

The game doesn’t avoid loss either. Three deaths hit you: Esteban, then Mushroom, and then Finn. Everything changes so fast you barely have time to process it. That’s life too.

One thing the game repeats over and over is the importance of family. Even when it’s really freaking bad. They’re the people who raised you, and that alone is a reason for respect. Brody hated his family and tried to run from them, but eventually his mom got cancer, and he had to come back. Family pulls you in whether you like it or not. Sean hated Karen for leaving, but once they reunited, he understood her reasons and forgave her. Forgiveness is one of the hardest things humans can do.

Even Episode 3, which wasn’t as exciting for me, fits into this whole theme of freedom and connection. Sitting at the campfire, talking with people who want the same thing you want, feels real and wholesome. Everyone there just wants to see the world. And honestly, the world is small when you think about people. You’ll meet the same person twice in your life with a 50 percent chance.

Road trips only add to that. Being on the road gives you unforgettable experiences with people who share their stories. Everyone you meet has a story, and traveling is really just learning from them. Some people are open to new connections, even strangers like truckers. And Brody, again, is the perfect example. He’s in the A++ tier in my imaginary tier list for a reason. He helped Sean and Daniel with his last bit of money just so they could keep going.

I can’t say exactly which episode was the best, because each one has its own lesson and vibe. But Episodes One, Two, and Four hit me the hardest. They felt the most emotional and relatable.

Pursue your dreams, boys and girls. See ya.

[h1] АУФ ГОЛОВНОГО МОЗГА ИЛИ УСПЕТЬ ЧЕРЕЗ ВСЮ АМЕРИКУ ЗА 5 ЭПИЗОДОВ [/h1]

Life is Strange 2 разочаровал многих фанатов серии, и это не без оснований. Несмотря на хорошую идею и потенциал для глубокого сюжета (хотя кого я обманываю, ВСЕ РУШИТСЯ ЕЩЕ С ПЕРВОГО ЭПИЗОДА), игра страдает от множества проблем, которые затмевают положительные моменты.

Первое, что бросается в глаза, это перенасыщенность повесткой, которая, на первый взгляд, должна была добавить реализма и актуальности. Однако вместо этом она выглядит навязчиво и искусственно, теряя свою естественность. Создается ощущение, что разработчики сделали ставку на социальные вопросы, забыв про ключевые аспекты — интересный сюжет и развитых персонажей. И логику, потому что добро и зло тут как в Hellaverse - диаметрально, и без какого либо высмеивания и сатиры, нелогично противоположны.

Герои игры - отбросы общества. Что один что второй братья Диасы представлены как типичные мигранты-мудаки учиняющие беспредел "без мести", (но даже если это ради другой главной завязки сюжета - то почему?! И это относится к логике поступков окружающих их персонажей), что делает сопереживание за их судьбы невозможным, если вы не феменистка из твитера. В моменте, да не в одном я не то что усомнялся в адекватности их действий - а в адекватности при создании этой игры вообще.

Постановка и режиссура оставляют желать лучшего. В игре часто встречаются затянутые и скучные сцены, которые только отвлекают от главной линии. Это снижает общее восприятие, и игроки начинают терять интерес к происходящему. Вместо эмоционального погружения мы получаем долгие диалоги и общение, которое утомляет, и уж тем более не заставляет задуматься или СОПЕРЕЖИВАТЬ.

Life is Strange 2 — это не сиквел, а отдельный, политизированный и наивный выкидыш во всей серии LiS. Обилие повестки, бездарная постановка и персонажи, делают этот проект ужасным. Возможно, лучше было бы оставить историю первой части незавершенной, чем пытаться развивать её в таком ключе.

[h1] BRAIN FEVER OR MAKE IT ACROSS AMERICA IN 5 EPISODES [/h1]

Life is Strange 2 disappointed many fans of the series, and with good reason. Despite the good idea and the potential for a deep plot (although who am I kidding, EVERYTHING COLLAPSES FROM THE VERY FIRST EPISODE), the game suffers from many problems that overshadow the positive aspects.

The first thing that catches your eye is the oversaturation of the agenda, which, at first glance, was supposed to add realism and relevance. However, instead it looks intrusive and artificial, losing its naturalness. It seems that the developers have relied on social issues, forgetting about the key aspects — an interesting plot and developed characters. And logic, because good and evil here, as in Hellaverse, are diametrically opposed, and without any ridicule or satire, illogically opposed.

The heroes of the game are the dregs of society. That one or the other Diaz brothers are presented as typical migrant assholes who commit lawlessness "without revenge", (but even if it's for the sake of another main plot plot, then why?! And this applies to the logic of the actions of the characters around them), which makes empathy for their fates impossible if you are not a Twitter feminist. At the moment, and not just in one thing, I did not doubt the adequacy of their actions - but in the adequacy of creating this game in general.

The production and direction leave much to be desired. The game often has drawn-out and boring scenes that only distract from the main line. This reduces the overall perception, and players begin to lose interest in what is happening. Instead of emotional immersion, we get long dialogues and communication, which is exhausting, and even more so does not make us think or EMPATHIZE.

Life is Strange 2 is not a sequel, but a separate, politicized and naive miscarriage in the entire LiS series. The abundance of the agenda, the mediocre staging and the characters make this project terrible. Perhaps it would be better to leave the story of the first part unfinished than to try to develop it in this way.

I’ve played through all the previous parts. Compared to them, this game feels so much worse when it comes to story and emotions. It could still be decent, but it’s stuffed with in-your-face woke propaganda. You can see it most clearly in the way the characters are written. It’s full of old, worn-out clichés.

Almost everything here is black-and-white. People opposing mass migration are shown as xenophobes and fascists, or at best just rude and nasty to others. On the other hand, anarchists, hippies, gay people, and those living in communes are always nice, smiling, and cool.

Anyone tied to the church has to be a villain, or at least a brainwashed lunatic with no will of their own. In the end, of course, the church has to burn.

Migrants and minorities are always portrayed as good guys and victims. People protecting their country or opposing migration are painted as thugs. The border fence is “evil” and must be torn down to save the heroes.

There are also layers of symbolic references placed throughout the game. For instance, the main character bears a symbol of Baphomet on their sleeve.

Overall, the impression is that the game is designed less as a story-driven experience and more as a vehicle for conveying progressive ideas. After a while, it becomes difficult to ignore the sense that this message takes precedence over the narrative itself.

It’s disappointing, especially given the studio’s earlier achievements.

Sad. Dontnod, enjoy yourselves without me.

This game got a lot of undeserved flak for not being linked for no Max and Chloe, but as it's own game it's just not good.
They tried some new ideas for the formula but for me it just doesn't work.

-The plot feels contrived the characters jumping from location to location doing stupid stuff for very stupid reasons. I get the MC is a kid but still. There are a few high points like the church which are legitimately cool and interesting. At points it feels like a slog to get through, a tighter story would've helped massively. The game doesn't draw you in like the first game did probably because rather than solving a mystery you're just running away.
-The 5 episode structure doesn't help, some episodes massively overstay their welcome and some parts feel like padding, if maybe 30% of the game was cut it would probably be much less of a chore to play through. I've played through LiS and Before the Storm multiple times but this game is too much of a slog to ever replay.
-The player doesn't get powers, instead it's his little brother, which is an interesting change but makes the game play much less fun.
-The characters aren't particularly memorable and you spend very little time with each group before the plot moves on. You get to influence Daniel but half the interactions are hidden behind weird dialogue triggers you'd need a guide to find. Even if you've been a great brother he still turns against you at points because "the plot needs a conflict" and Daniel being dumb/manipulated is most of the game's conflict.
-The choices in this game do matter but many are opaque and a few make no sense, if you don't phone a character in the first hour it changes the ending and she stops being your friend forever? but you never try to phone her at any other point in the game (even with a payphone lmao).
-The game also beats you over the head politically, I'm not even American but I can tell how much the writing got affected by the 2016 election. Plot starts from a racist bully and police brutality. You get beaten and detained by a "build that wall" guy who won't shut up about how evil Mexicans are. Racist rednecks beat you up (again). Civil border patrol try to murder you. The church is full of evil sociopaths who beat children for fun. The cops and justice system manhunt you for stuff you didn't do.

To be honest I'm dissapointed by this game. It gives you the delusion of choice, but forces you to "do the right thing" by all the narrative around. I'm not happy only how poor power of the Daniel was but how it's all been developed. No one cares about Sean except some of the later events in the dessert. Only repeating how he have to be the adult one and protect brother and such. The game forces you to put priority of Daniel's happy first no matter what. That's stupid. Game of choice without a choice to be honest.

To more technical stuff - damn, this game bugged more than I expected, just because I moved a bit too quickly from the place, cause I didn't hear the next dialogues starts... like wtf, I had to reload checkpoints few times, that was annoying. Anyway, for me this game is kinda 5/10. 
It touches tough topics and they're showed without feeling that they're forced too hard, but overall the story wasn't that great for me. It had some good moments, but a lot of choices were forced to get it Daniel's way and I don't get it how people love his character. He was such annoying brat, that I would leave behind if it was an option in early stage of the game and just run away alone if I was at Sean's place. I'm surprised that I forced myself to go through all episodes.
Max and Chloe solo I'm afraid.

I don't recommend this. It's my first experience with this franchise, and since there's very little fun in the gameplay, it's all down to the story. And overall, that gives me more negative feelings than positive. Even the ending can't make up for that.

First game I decided to play in 2025. Given that LIS 1 was an ok game I gave it a go. Damn it was a rough one. The writing just doesn't make sense, the characters are borderline sociopaths or in Daniels case a narcissistic sociopath, the voice acting is terrible and the story has way too many holes. Overall the game felt like a drag since episode 1. Even if the game is free I would suggest you to do something better with your time. Only play this game is you are paid to do so. 0/10 and definitely in the top 5 worst games I've ever played in my life.

There's something missing in this game when compared to it's predecessor. The first one was amazing, the main character, most characters, intriguing story, cool power mechanic... plot twists... But in this one I got bored and annoyed.

Even True colors, that was a bit woke, was much better and intriguing. 

I just don't feel invested like in the others.
This game didn't grab me as much as previous Life is Strange games. After finishing the first episode, I had mixed feelings. I honestly don't think it's worth the time.

I wanted to recommend this game so much. While there were moments I really enjoyed, overall I feel it’s a step down from the first game. Despite Sean and Daniel’s story seeming like it should have more emotional impact than Sam’s in the first game, it just didn’t connect with me. The game ends in one of two ways, neither of which feels particularly satisfying: Sean’s life is either ruined by surrendering and going to prison, or he escapes to Mexico by forcing his way across the border (at least, those were the options presented to me). While reaching Mexico is the goal of the game, there isn’t enough shown of their arrival to make it meaningful. The brothers deal with some gang trouble, then have a beer and look at the ocean. There’s no real follow-up on Lyla or other supporting characters like Jacob or Brody, who helped the brothers along the way. It feels like there should have been an epilogue to show more of their new life, but instead we get maybe two minutes at most at the end, and that’s it. A bit of a let-down, considering how much I liked the first game. I’ll probably give the next game a go, but I doubt I’ll replay this one, and I don’t think it’s a title you need to rush out and buy.

its not a bad game. but it is quite frustrating at times and i can't recommend it. most choices dont really matter, each episode we meet quite cool characters but we go to a new location in the next episode and don't see those characters again, so your choices with them dont really matter. this game is god awfully slow most of the time and i wish cutscenes weren't so long and dragged out. tbh, i was bored alot of the time. but, overall the story is good, its just not implemented well and struggles with pacing issues. the characters are mostly good but they don't have that much impact on the story.

Bioware created something that, despite a tempest of setbacks and obstacles during development, is truly a work of art. Even if you think this game does reflect those issues I truly think that the passion, love and talent poured onto it overshadows and compensates anything that could've been improved given more time and freedom. The writing is just stellar, with characters that have been developed to a point that they can rival any others in traditional literature or art cinema. 

No game can be perfect and there's so many more standards to be met when something isn't the first in a franchise, but when we speak of a game's quality there needs to be an aknowledgement of how almost 100% of time capitalism maims talent and intention to varying degrees. This game is something beautiful that speaks through that noise. One of my favorite games of all time.

Dragon Age Inquisition is arguably the best out of the four Dragon Age games in 2025. Although, Origins come very close. The latter only losing out for me because of technical improvements in Inquisition (and these happen to be important for me).

That being said, this game has several flaws, though most of these are only 'optional' in the sense that they don't affect progressing through the main story.

The good:
[list]
    [*]Story
    [*]Dialogue
    [*]Voice acting
    [*]Controller support (of course this is only important for those who prefer to sit back and use a controller)
    [*]Some of the supporting characters
[/list]

The bad:
[list]
    [*]Side quests are often pointless and for the sake of being there
    [*]Navigating the world can feel tedious and a waste of time (esp. Hissing Waves, Forbidden Oasis, the Deep Roads)
    [*]Personally, I feel like the combat is mostly a matter of stats (gear) rather than tactics
    [*]Way too much elements of grinding that become super tedious and repetitive (with crafting materials, gold, and prestige)
[/list]

In summary, this game has an extremely well written story, with believable dialogues and character interactions. There are also a LOT of tedious pain-in-the-arse game-design choices that can make you feel like you're grinding half the time, rather than enjoying whatever the game has to offer. There are some very nice immersive moments with the taverns and towns, but most of the world feels barren and somewhat nonsensical.

Dragon Age: Inquisition is BioWare’s third entry in the Dragon Age series and one of its most ambitious RPGs. Built on the Frostbite engine, it expands the world dramatically—combining open-area exploration, political intrigue, and party-driven storytelling into one massive adventure. It’s both a continuation of the saga and a reinvention of its formula.

The story follows the Inquisitor, a survivor of a magical catastrophe who gains the power to seal dangerous rifts between worlds. As leader of the newly formed Inquisition, the player must unite factions, recruit allies, and face a growing demonic threat. The main narrative balances global stakes with personal choices, allowing players to shape political and moral outcomes through dialogue and decisions.

Gameplay blends exploration and tactical combat. The world is divided into large regions filled with quests, collectibles, and dynamic encounters. Players can switch between real-time action or top-down tactical view for precision control. Team composition, positioning, and ability synergy are key to surviving harder fights, keeping combat engaging across dozens of hours.

Companions remain the emotional core of the experience. Characters like Cassandra, Solas, Iron Bull, and Dorian each bring strong personalities, distinct motivations, and moral perspectives. Their interactions—through banter, loyalty missions, and romance—create some of BioWare’s best relationship writing. Every choice in dialogue strengthens or strains bonds within the party.

Visually, the game is stunning. The Frostbite engine delivers vast landscapes, from frozen mountains to deserts and ancient ruins. Lighting, weather effects, and detailed armor designs make exploration rewarding. Even a decade later, Inquisition still looks modern and cinematic.

The soundtrack by Trevor Morris enhances both scale and emotion. Orchestral and choral themes underscore the Inquisition’s rise, while quiet pieces support reflective moments in camp or dialogue. Voice acting across the cast is consistently strong, giving life to the game’s layered writing.

Overall, Dragon Age: Inquisition is a monumental RPG that successfully blends character-driven storytelling with grand world-building. Its scale can sometimes overwhelm, but its heart lies in choice, connection, and consequence. It stands as one of BioWare’s finest achievements—an epic about leadership, faith, and the power of unity in a fractured world.

this was my entry to the dragon age series back in 2016 and still i consider it one of my favorite games. i love the plot, environmental and costume design, and the companions are lively and wonderful. my favorite companions are solas, sera and cole, and i consider solas to be one of the best written character in videogames ever. many find the main antagonist lacking, and i can see their perspective, but i love evil old men and body horror so corypheus striked a chord with me. the locations are absolutely beautiful and mesmerizing and i found myself just taking a pause between quests and admiring the view. the fightings are quick and fun and the abilities are really satisfying, especially when playing a mage or a bow-and-arrow rogue. the politics part of the game is also really intriguing. the plot deals with religion, faith and personhood, and the toll it takes to be a chosen one (namely, the obliteration of personhood). the lore is beautifully woven into the plot, and it is so satisfying to uncover ancient mysteries, especially in the trespasser dlc. overall the game is a wonderful experience. also sera is my wife!
