[h2]Summary[/h2]
Back to the roots of Dragon Age

[h2]The Good[/h2]
- Deeper story lines
- Lore that is interesting
- Combat relatively smooth

[h2]The Bad[/h2]
- Still some bugs, including quest breaking ones
- Decisions are not as important as DAO

[h2]The Deets[/h2]
After the brain numbing slog of Dragon Age 2, this was such a treat. The developers realized what made DAO special and tried to bring back what was lost. Overall, I still think DAO is a better game. The decisions you make in it have far reaching effects and it feels like it matters. Characters are flushed out better and are more worth investing into. However, DAI shines in its combat that is smooth and fun to play around with to figure out new unique ways of playing. Hey, they must have done something right if I 100% this game and not DA2.

Dragon Age: Inquisition is just about as close to a masterpiece as a game can be for me and an excellent Dragon Age entry. I've put well over 1000 hours into it on PS4, PS5, and PC.

Pros: 
- Storytelling: A grand scale good vs evil fight much like it's predecessor Dragon Age Origins (DAO). The narrative is epic and the villain has presence. 

- Choices: As far as "choices matter" goes I think this game does fairly well though definitely not to the level of DAO. There are a few game changing choices that will give you entirely different questlines and loads of smaller ones that mostly effect companion approval and cutscenes as well as world flavour type outcomes. You can also see the relults of smaller choices in War Table quests.

- World building: DAI builds off established lore from the series and fleshes out a lot of cultures within the world. There is lots of world history related dialogue and codex entries for all you world-building nerds out there.

- Characters: perhaps the best thing about DAI (like it's predecessors) is it's companion characters and advisers. Each one is uniquely compelling and have fleshed out personalities. Everyone has reasons for what they believe and for being part of the cause. They will also agree/disagree both with the pc and other companions and can even leave if you clash enough. The companion questlines are also enjoyable and tailored well to each companion.

- Music: seriously the music in this game (and particularly the Trespasser DLC) is just unreasonably delicious
- Graphics: still hold up well 10 years later, it's wallpaper worthy in some areas
- Areas: There is a huge variety of environments to explore with their own unique vibes
- Combat: pretty good variety of options for builds and generally enjoyable combat. There are also difficulty settings that you can change during the game

Cons:
- Bloat: there are A LOT of "go-for/fetch" quests, and while I didn't mind them much I can see how they could be quite frustrating, particularly for the time-poor player. Some areas (looking at you Hinterlands) are also just too darn big and if i have to fight one more bear I'm going to cry

- Animations: be warned, ye who seek to play feminine characters or anything other than a brick outhouse. For whatever reason the devs decided that one style of animation would fit all possible characters you may create. You will be LOCKED IN to the most APE-ISH walking and sitting animations. Like MADAM YOU NEED TO SEE A CHIROPRACTOR. It is distractingly goofish on my petite elf Inquisitor but likely works well on heavy set lads. 
    - Another animation issue is that cutscenes often show items still in your hand from gameplay. This has resulted in my character STABBING herself in the face with her own weapons, gesturing wildly in peoples faces with blades, and trying to drink water with a LIT TORCH in her hand. 
    - There are also the classics, like characters standing on chairs instead of sitting or having items glued to their open hands but I find this endearing as I now view it through the rose-tinted lens of nostalgia.

- Player Character Dialogue: the dialogue options that you are offered are often very generic and make it difficult to give your character much of a personality, particularly when compared with the silent pc of Origins or the three personality options you could choose in Dragon Age 2. The Trespasser DLC gives you the chance to develop your pc more but the base game is lacking in this department.

- Sex: ew, but thankfully optional

Overall DAI is an absolute banger and truly my personal GOAT. If you enjoy anything open-world/fantasy/RPG this is a must play, even if you haven't/can't play the other Dragon Age games.

A genuinely great RPG with some minor pain points. A solid 9/10.

I loved the story, and I feel like they did justice to the characters both old and new. Overall the story has a much bigger scale than I expected, with some pretty epic twists that keep you engaged through the whole journey. 

Visually the game looks great, even in 2025. Frostbite engine was way ahead of its time and does a great job with the wide variety of environments and cool lighting setups. It helps that the art direction and tone is very coherent and fits the Dragon Age's gritty world. (unlike you know which game)

The combat is decent, but the controls are a bit clumsy and can take a while to get used to. I mainly played as a mage and a bit with a rogue. Rogue was surprisingly fun, having a parry mechanic is neat af! 

And I loved that the game doesn't hold your hand for most puzzles, the characters don't mumble the solutions to you if you're stuck for longer than 10 seconds, and a lot of the puzzles were very fun to solve! 

On the downsides, the open world bloat is a bit excessive. Especially the shards, massive amount of effort for a practically nonexistent payoff. I love my open world side content, but it needs to have more variety and a more balanced effort/reward ratio. 


The ending left me excited for what's to come, and hopefully one day we'll get a true and faithful sequel to this very cool game!

Maker's Breath, have I played this game a lot... I have hundred of hours on it on X-box. I bought it on PC to see how it fares with some mods, but unfortunately the EA app is quite spoiling the experience so I didn't get far. I know the opinions are divided and I cannot comment on how this one relates to the previous two games as I haven't played them, but as a stand-alone it is brilliant. I play for the story, the characters, the world and it delivers it all. The combat is just a get-through for me and this game allows me to easily complete it with just the minimum of strategic effort. The world is beautiful, the characters are rich and varied, the storyline is engaging and the lore is expansive. Some might say that this game tried to be a lot to a lot and it was its downfall, luckily for me it delivered just in the right places to make me fall in love with it. Yes, it's absolutely not perfect, but what is?

I didn't play this back when it first came out; it looked too different from Dragon Age Origins, which I loved. In hindsight, it was the best Dragon Age sequel we were ever going to get... Way better than Veilguard.

Here is my review of Dragon Age Inquisition and how it compares to previous titles in this series. Welcome, traveler - there are no spoilers ahead!

I am more than 10 years late in writing a review for this game - I skipped it when it was new, but I played DA1 and DA2 before that and now in 2025 I've had a replay of the trilogy, playing through all available DLCs as well.

I will be skipping Veilguard, at least for now. Bioware was wonderful with their RPGs, but their glory days have long passed. Thank you Bioware developers of old for the wonderful experiences you have created.

Times change, so the current king is Larian, as many would agree. 

Inquisition is a good game. It has traces of greatness, but it definitely pales in comparison to Origins. 

Origins has that perfect mix of joy and sorrow and continues to be my all-time favorite. Origins soundtrack is incredible and game characters are like your best friends and family.

DA2 is probably the weakest in the series, but it works well and should not be skipped.

The magic mix in Inquisition is more sour than before in my opinion - the story especially.

Inquisition offers better graphics and more action oriented gameplay while DA1 and DA2 excel in precise tactical combat.

Some players may not like all the characters in Inquisition. I skipped on 2 characters and focused on the rest of the party.

One thing that I must mention - Hawke in Inquisition looked nothing like my Hawke in DA2. Developers created a different face tattoo set which broke the immersion for me. Also Dragon Age Keep sucks pretty much - file import in DA2 worked better IMO.

Inquisition is somewhat glitchy, especially in Trespasser DLC where I had serous issues (black screen after Eluvian travel).

Side quests in Inquisition are numerous and as other reviewers have pointed out - are similar to the kill and fetch type quests used so often in MMOs.

These side quests prolong the game possibly too much, and they are typically inferior to the main quests. Main questline is not very long.

Bottom line: recommended!
Takes a minute to get interesting but it does. I like being able to take control of the different party members for added variety.

This review is 30 hours into the game. So I'm playing this  game for the first time in 2025 as I was looking for some open world fantasy RPGs that are not complete garbage. I haven't played Origins or DA2, so this is my first game in the series. The goods are the graphics are nice and still hold up, and the companions are interesting. The story being a political epic in a fantasy world is not bad either. But the gameplay, oh god. It is extremely boring and dull. It feels like you are playing World of Warcraft except it is single player and there way less spells and skill. It is literally and single player MMO where you run around the world collecting and gathering resources. The RPG is the choice to be a Tank, DPS with 2H or with 2 daggers or with a bow or with magic (cold, lightning, fire). That is it. Your choices barely affect anything. Again I've just played 30 hours, I don't know if it gets much different later on.  There armour and weapons are simple and boring. The crafting system is as basic as it can be.
So overall the game is not bad, but it is boring. 6.5/10.

I have tried and tried and tried to play this game but it is just *so* bad. 
The combat is the worst in the series. The game started as an MMO and you can tell.
The terrible fetch quests and pointlessly large maps were clearly an artifact of the Devs having to scrap their plans for an MMO and change it to singleplayer.
You get a horse to make the travel slightly faster, but it handles like it's drunk.

The system interface is awkward and uncomfortable.  Although there are brief tips on how to do things, key details, such as how to add your new skill to the number on your keyboard, are not included.  The movement keys on keyboard are awkward.  I was able to adjust the steps to WASD, but I have to turn the camera by using other keys (left or right only, not up or down) or by right-clicking and dragging with my mouse, which is exhausting after awhile.  I just want to move the camera with my mouse without clicking on anything and have my character move accordingly.  Using a first-person view would simplify matters even more.  Skyrim, which came out a few years before, has much better controls compared to this game, but the creators do not appear to have learned from their rivals.  This game gives the impression it was designed for controls other than the keyboard, and adjustments weren't made properly when modifying it for PC.

The layout could easily be adjusted to give players an easier time creating characters.  The options for darker skin all look terrible, even after adjusting the complexion.  Although the option for elves shows a card with blue-skinned characters and no nose bridge, those options are not available at all in the character creator, making them misleading.

The subtitles don't work, so I missed quite a bit of dialogue.

The game does win some points for animating the bow, which I've found to be rather rare bonus in games.

Some edits after 50+ hours:

Roughly 11 hours into my first real play through - have played about 10 hours a year or so ago as well.

After about 11 hours with Dragon Age: Inquisition, I’ve come away with mixed feelings. The game is undeniably pretty, with sweeping landscapes, a strong soundtrack, and the kind of lore rich world that is expected from a Dragonage IP. But beneath the surface, there are some rough edges that make the experience frustrating at times.

Skill Trees and Character Building:

The skill trees feel restrictive, almost as if the game is trying to force me down a predetermined path rather than letting my character grow into a multifaceted build. Instead of encouraging creative experimentation, I feel boxed into roles that don’t fully reflect how I’d like to play.

Combat and AI:

Combat is clunky. The lack of a robust tactics system is puzzling in a party-based RPG where multiple companions fight alongside you. I want to strategize, but instead I’m stuck wrangling poor companion AI. They often behave ineffectively, making fights more chaotic than they need to be. Even the pause-and-play tactical feature struggles - it frequently gets interrupted by the terrain, companion positioning, and enemy AI 'quirks' (or bugs), leaving it more awkward than empowering (or fun).

On top of that, the click-to-move/play feature from Dragon Age: Origins, Awakening, and Dragon Age II is gone even on the PC version. Without it, the game feels less like the tactical dungeon-crawler, party-based RPG that made the series distinct, and more like an open world action game in the vein of Horizon Zero Dawn but with companions. It’s a fundamental shift in design philosophy that left me feeling disconnected from the combat flow and party management that used to define Dragon Age.

Exploration and World Design:

The game world looks beautiful, but actually moving through it can be a chore. Too often I find myself tediously hopping over small rocks and uneven terrain that should feel trivial to cross. On top of that, enemy respawns feel relentless, more like an MMO mobile game than a living world. It kills immersion when areas repopulate too quickly, turning exploration into a grind rather than an adventure. (How many bears are in Storm Coast?!)

The minimap compounds the frustration by failing to show trails, which means I’m constantly flipping back to the full map just to navigate simple paths.

Quest and Search Mechanics:

Quests often lean on the “search” feature, but it only works about 70% of the time. I end up pressing the search button repeatedly before it actually points me to what I’m supposed to find. It’s another clunky design that slows the pace and adds unnecessary annoyance.

On top of that, having to constantly go back to The War Room for seemingly no good reason when I could just select quests from my journal and fast travel directly is as tedious as it is pointless. The only purpose it seems to serve is to add perks, which could simply be done when leveling up your characters and forcing you to wait on operations - operations that can take upwards of 20+ real life hours - or gather resources without having to go out into the overworld (and the amount of resources, whether its gold or herbs are handed out in tiny amounts, you may as well go into the overworld for resource aquisition). This mechanical essentially is there to seemingly make the player play through all the sloppy side quests while you wait for the main storyline to be opened up after hours of waiting on operations to be finished. The waiting, I believe, is there to make the game feel like there is more content than there really is. The side quests are mostly boring fetch quests that do nothing to further the plot. In the early game The War Room is presented as a hub where Inquisition agents hash out strategy, but in practice it’s nothing more than a glorified fast-travel screen with a dramatic title that forces the player to either wait real life hours in order to proceed or go off and finish boring side quests. The illusion of depth here makes the tedium sting even more.

Potions and Resource Management:

Yes, characters can craft potions - but only after unlocking the right quest line, and only at specific crafting tables. It’s never made obvious, and it certainly doesn’t allow the kind of flexibility Origins had, where you could brew potions mid-quest. But the bigger issue is this: mages can no longer heal! In a series where mages were the cornerstone of party survival, the absence of dedicated healing spells is baffling. Instead, the game leans heavily on its restrictive potion system, which forces constant micromanagement and frequent returns to camps. What should feel like tactical preparation ends up feeling like arbitrary limitation, stripping away both player freedom and the strategic weight of having a healer in the party.

Final Thoughts (So Far):

For all its beauty, atmosphere, and rich lore, Dragon Age: Inquisition is weighed down by awkward systems, clunky mechanics, and poor AI. The removal of staple features like click-to-play only highlights how far it’s drifted from its dungeon-crawler-esque roots.

If Dragon Age: Origins was an 8.5/10, I can’t imagine grading Inquisition higher than a 6/10 at this point. What astonishes me most are the overwhelmingly positive reviews this game has received since release. Either I’m missing something monumental, or a large swath of critics and players have mistaken sheer size for substance. It’s not the first time a bloated spectacle has been confused for greatness, but one does wish the bar were set a little higher.

I still recommend it for the story alone, though (so far). Do I recommend it for the game play? Absolutely not. Get it on sale, or just watch the cut-scenes on Youtube.

Combat is clunky and buggy, line level writing is meh, main plot is terrible (especially the main villain in a style of "Palpatine returned, again"), the WORST mount mechanics in history of games and a lot of padding content. Like 90% of the game is meaningless padding and war table shenanigans only makes immersion worse.
A did I forget to mention the atrocious loot system? 99% of the stuff you loot is basically useless, game economy is stale and you can barely find anything useful from vendors with money becoming meaningless very quick, so the only gear is worth wearing is either crafted one(crafting system was surprisingly not bad), boss drop or atrarium treasure(atrarium mini-games were somewhat enjoyable).
Companion cast is also disappointing with only worthy mention of duo of Cassandra and Varric, but even their chemistry is mostly the merit of Dragon Age 2 above all else.
The fact that choices from previous games are either ignored or Dragon Age Keep is not functioning properly anymore also added a grain of salt.
Into the depths DLC was okay, although other two felt like torture.
Glad it's finally over.

Imagine pouring countless hours into Dragon Age: Origins and Dragon Age II—crafting your own story, making tough choices, grinding through quests, tackling every DLC—only to discover that when you move on to the third game, none of that effort carries over. Instead of importing your hard-earned world state, you’re forced onto a webpage to manually recreate your past, with limited options that don’t even cover everything you actually did. And this isn’t years later when memories fade—this could be just weeks or months after finishing the first two games, and you still have to piece it all back together.

Then, to make things worse, you go to play what is mostly an offline single-player game, and if EA’s servers are down, you simply can’t.

It’s frustrating to see so much player investment treated as disposable, especially in a series praised for its choices and consequences.

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text:
It's my first, and probably only, MMO. I really like the gameplay, which is intuitive and dynamic compared to other MMOs I've seen online where you have a stationary character and attacks. Graphically speaking, it's extraordinary, with a great style (although it could do with some optimisation).

The story has really grabbed me even if its the classic "hero chosed by destiny" thing, everything builded around that idea is amazing. I don't miss a single piece of paper so I can find out every little detail, and when I can, I don't skip any cutscenes (And I don't do it in every game).

The progression system is a bit slow, it's true, but it's not as bad as everyone makes it out to be, especially with all the improvements they've made over time. Gatekeeping exists, but all you need to do is join any Discord dedicated to the game to organise yourself with other new players and learn the various raids. You just need patience in the game and you can do anything.

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text:
It must be fate that Chris Wilson's video about Dark Patterns in games was in my recommended feed on the last day before the big update of Act 4 & The Final Day raid. I'm getting off the hamster wheel.

This game's raid combat and different classes were the only saving grace for me. In the last few weeks, I found myself enjoying solo raids on my rat alts because playing them was a breath of fresh air compared to running the same 6 gold earners for the 9000th time. I enjoyed my time with the game playing with my friends and random people but if there's one sentence I can use to described this game is "It's as wide as the ocean and as deep as a puddle." Every older raids or activities they've introduced is abandoned because people only interact with the few latest content.

Almost every system in this game is debilitating and riddled with layers of RNG: it's by design to time gate slowing down progression. It uses so many predatory psychological manipulation like FOMO to keep to playing in the hopes that you get lucky: if you just get one good Frost/Flame Hell Key run, you'd save millions of gold from just getting a few Grudge, Keen Blunt, Cursed Doll, Raid Captain or Adrenaline books. But at the end of day, it's not going to happen. When you succeed, you don't feel good and want to do it again. You feel good that you never have to interact with that system ever again (like Transcendence or Elixirs). Designing progression systems like that makes it inevitable that your game with lose players. Old systems (Elixirs) get reworked to be easier to min-max because there's a new system that will make more money (Ark Grid). The game's reward system with the raids encourages gatekeeping by design because you want to finish your three gold earning raids ASAP so you can move on to the other 5 gold earning characters. The mokoko bootcamp event doesn't really help new players learn the raid, it only helps new players finish a raid by getting carried.

At the end of it, this game is just a predatory mobile game with a good combat/raid design. The game controls how much you get to play: everything is time-gated. It's heavily pay-to-win and has gotten worse with new content like Ark Grid and Paradise. The RNG is so egregious that it's impressive to say the least: one tapping/free tapping a weapon to +25 compared to the average cost is several millions of gold and compared to pity is probably in the tens of millions. When I found out about the Ark Grid system, I realized that this game isn't going to change. Smilegate will just nerf old systems (because it doesn't make a lot of money anymore) and introduce new systems to keep the hamsters on the wheel.

I, too, have seen the light; I've escaped and gotten off the hamster wheel. Stay away from this game and every predatory games like it. Remember that games are there for your enjoyment and played on your schedule. If you're playing on the game's schedule, it's just another job.

review_text: Game is mixed bag. It has good stuff like combat, raids, sounds and animations, but also tons of bad stuff like terrible progression systems, non existent gameplay outside of raids, p2w, nonstop fomo events and intentional time wasting in leveling. genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text:
This game had phenomenal potential as a raiding MMO, and I'm using the past tense because I'm done coping on the possibility that Smilegate will ever improve their systems. Combat is insanely fun, class fantasy is incredibly satisfying, but it's all buried under so many layers of garbage gambling systems that Smilegate has effectively turned a diamond back into coal.

Every single interaction with progression systems feels like it was designed with malicious intent to cause the player to swipe and avoid the headache, and the western playerbase could have taken a more casual approach were it not for the system-driven FOMO compelling even free to play gamers to invest insane amounts of time to try and keep up with the average dolphin, constantly pulling the bar higher and higher for what party finder considers "an acceptably geared character".

I understand that they wished to monetize progression as their business model to keep the game free to play, but it is done in such an obscenely hostile way that you'll never get good value for your money: if we compared with other MMO competitors like WoW or FFXIV where a 14-15 bucks monthly subscription will give you access to THE ENTIRETY of the game provided you just play, spending 200 dollars a year on Lost Ark gets you nowhere. It averages out to a drop in the bottomless bucket of resources you need to continue progressing your character depending on store pack releases and gold currency exchange. Cosmetics are generally low-value or mediocre at best, but that's a matter of personal taste, I am uninterested in the KR trend of suits or formal wear skins and would much rather have good fantasy armour.

I've played this game since launch, and even swiped on occasion, but it might be time to finally give it a rest and warn people who might be unaware of it just what kind of predatory cesspool awaits them, and it will remain that way because Smilegate simply does not care about making a good game, they are perfectly content milking their dwindling playerbase until it runs dry.

Overwatch 2 is a 5v5 hero shooter where Blizzard removed one tank, added a battle pass, and relied on the power of addiction to do the rest.

You queue for:

* **Tank** – Emotional punching bag
* **Damage** – Aim training with extra ego
* **Support** – Full-time babysitter with part-time healing beam

Then you load into a match and immediately realize:

> “Ah. No one here has ever seen the objective.”

---

### Pros

* When a fight pops off, it’s genuinely *incredible*:

  * Ults chaining
  * Pings flying
  * Abilities overlapping
  * You have no idea what’s happening but there are colors and numbers and someone is yelling “HUGE!”

* Wild hero variety:

  * Cyber ninja with a family problem
  * Grandma sniper with life advice and biotic bullets
  * Sentient hamster in a murder ball
  * Cowboy, sorcerer queen, traumatized bird archer, K-pop tank, angry Greek lightning lady…
    Every match is a crossover episode.

* 5v5 makes individual plays more impactful, so you can hard-carry a fight and then pretend it was “team effort” while quietly replaying it in your head for the next 3 hours.

* Game *feels* amazing to play: movement, shooting, animations, sound design—Blizzard polish is still there under the battle pass crumbs.

* With friends, it’s peak gaming:

  * One guy tilted
  * One guy cracked
  * One guy on Lucio “for fun” wall-riding nowhere near the teamfight

---

### Cons

* Solo queue is a social experiment that should be illegal.

  * Tank: flanks
  * DPS: snipes from spawn
  * Support: “group up” pings and quiet sobbing

* Ranked feels like this:

  * Win 5, rank stays same.
  * Lose 5, rank plummets 3 divisions and your will to live with it.

* Monetization went from “loot boxes are bad” to “$20 for this one skin, soldier.”

* People will actually type “diff” in chat unironically, as if that explains why they spent the entire game dueling the enemy Ana behind the point.

* New player experience:

  * Tutorial teaches you basics
  * First real match puts you against a Smurf Sojourn with 3000 hours and laser eyes

---

### Peak Overwatch 2 Moments

* Landing the most beautiful sleep dart of your life, saving the fight, and someone still types “heal diff.”

* Perfect team wipe with your ult, POTG secured… until the game gives it to Cassidy for pressing Q in a straight line.

* Joining voice chat:

  * *“Hey guys :)”*
  * Instant silence, then someone breathes into their mic and locks Hanzo.

* Saying “last game” after a bad loss and then chasing redemption for another two hours.

* Swapping heroes out of spite and suddenly playing 10x better, forcing you to accept your main might actually be the problem.

---

### Final Diagnosis

Overwatch 2 is:

* 30% amazing hero shooter
* 30% emotional rollercoaster
* 40% “I swear I’m uninstalling after this match”

**8.5/10**
When it’s bad, it will ruin your mood.
When it’s good, nothing else quite hits the same.

Would once again uninstall in a fit of rage, see a cool new skin on Twitter, and reinstall before the download bar even finished disappearing.

Mass Effect 1 is one of my top 10 favourite video games in my lifetime--maybe even #1--and the whole series is a standout, forever-favourite. 

The story is so phenomenally told, with characters that are unique, fascinating, and satisfyingly complex. Many of the cast of characters will forever possess a piece of my heart (especially Commander Shepard themself, Liara, Garrus, and Tali'Zorah, Joker, Jack, Miranda, EDI, Cortez)--though, ahem, we don't talk about Jacob.

The games also have a gorgeous soundtrack that draws you into the wardrum heartbeat of the series, though there are plenty of tracks suited to thoughtful character moments, and capturing the sheer majesty of setpieces (like seeing the Destiny Ascension and the Citadel for the first time--WOW!). 

The Legendary Edition updates a ton of textures, and consolidates everything into a clean menu of the three games that keeps it all feeling consistent and meaningful across the trilogy. 

Super highly recommend--fantastic for fans of the series, and perfect for people picking it up for the first time. I wish I could experience it all for the first time, but honestly, every time I play this immersive game is a joy. Mass Effect always evokes a kind of wonder, passion, and curiosity all braided together that makes this game unforgettable and genuinely life-changing (especially for being one of the first games to ever show same-sex relationships; Liara and Jane/female Shepard will forever mean so much to me for that).

Mass Effect Legendary Edition is one of the few games that made me feel genuinely attached to a fictional universe. It’s a rich, emotional journey that lets you build a story over dozens of hours and feel the weight of your choices. There’s a constant feeling that what you do matters, and that these characters are more than just NPCs. It's important that the story continues from one game to another and it's something that enhances your connection to the characters.

The game is full of quiet, human moments in between the big cinematic battles: talking to your squad in the ship. The world-building is rich (different species, cultures, politics) and it doesn't feel like a lore dump.

The Legendary Edition also makes the experience feel smoother and more cohesive. The game was never top of the line in terms of mechanics or gameplay or even graphics compared to respective competition. It is the feeling it leaves after completing the Trilogy. You feel like you've lived through an epic space story. So that makes it one of my favorite games and an unforgettable emotional experience in gaming.

It's been quite fun replaying the trilogy with updated graphics... but I feel like this was an incredibly low effort attempt at a Remaster.

For starters, the combat is every bit as tedious as the original trilogy-- especially ME2. All enemies act like bullet sponges, even on the easier difficulties. Combat isn't hard, it just gets frustrating having to empty a clip of 30-50 rounds into every single enemy. This is something that can literally be tweaked in a matter of seconds and wouldn't have taken more than a day to perfect. The devs just couldn't be bothered to do so. Squad powers and biotics (if you play adept) are extremely unreliable too, just like the originals. They fire off at weird angles and hardly ever behave as expected.

However, most people-- myself included-- play for the characters and the story... but even that didn't manage to see any reasonable improvement. In fact, I've actually had a couple of errors that I never experienced with the original 3 games: and those are problems with the relationship system. In ME1, I was friendly with Liara, told her there wasn't anything romantic between us, and romanced Ashley... but somehow I ended up getting the Liara ending. I thought maybe I made a mistake and carried on... then, in the second game, I romanced Tali (as always) but acted friendly with Jack and told her there was nothing romantic between us... I then somehow got thrown into the Jack romance, locked out of the Tali romance ("end things with Jack", which I couldn't do because Jack refused to talk to me), and then when I met with Liara she said she was "tossed aside for a tattooed woman with anger issues"-- again, I never even started the romance with Jack, I started it with Tali.

For me, this is by far the worst issue because it means you have to frequently reload the game and time each interaction carefully. It wasn't a problem in the originals, so I don't see why it is suddenly a problem in the remaster. It's clearly something to do with the relationship points behind the scenes.

Speaking of Tali... the replacement photo of Tali still feels like a massive cop-out. There's clearly been no thought put into it whatsoever, which feels incredibly frustrating when the rest of the world-building has been so masterfully done. It's not just about this one character, it's about an entire race of people who are central to the plot... it should have been a massive reveal, but instead it was just thrown in there without a care in the world. Honestly, I'd rather they just deleted that scene than to try and fix one bad photoshop job with another. Her mouth isn't even close to the filter on her mask, it just looks weird. You can find dozens of speculative fan art of the Quarians which do a much better job of imagining their look.

Lastly, all of these issues would have been much easier to fix if console commands or mods were easy to use. I have no idea why the devs went out of their way to put so many roadblocks in the way to prevent players from doing these things, but it's just another reason to find this game disappointing.

If you have the originals-- download some graphics mods. 

If you don't, wait until this game goes on at least 70% sale, and hopefully you won't be too disappointed. I, unfortunately, was.

[h1]Unlike Fine Wine[/h1]

Mass Effect did [i]not[/i] withstand the test of time.

I have no idea what they remastered, because the game is exactly as I remember it from 2 decades ago. The Legendary Edition includes all DLCs, but I didn't see anything beyond the vanilla game after playing ~75% of ME1 (that's where I finally stopped, because I was beyond bored. I didn't even bother starting ME2 and 3). 

I remembered ME as having one of the best stories I've ever seen in a video game. After playing it again, I think it's a rather simple one rather poorly told. 

You make some choices here and there, yes, but they are binary and you don't have to wonder about their consequences, because the game immediately tells you the moral outcome of your pick by awarding you Paragon or Renegade points. So, your options are always the same: to do what the game considers "good," or what it considers "bad."

Surveying planets is boring and pointless. Landing on them is much worse, because doing so takes you to a large empty area with a bumpy terrain that is quite annoying to navigate with your bouncy and weirdly-controlled 6-wheeler. If you bother exploring them thoroughly, all you'll find is money, a few sad items, and/or your worst nightmare: a copy-pasted location. And I'm not even talking about some nice, complex place; no, I'm talking about a few interconnected square rooms filled with nothing but boxes -- and always the same 5 or so different boxes, because these are pretty much all the props available in the game.

Combat is dull, consisting in your weapon overheating while you fire at bullet-sponges that move illogically. Having 2 squad mates joining you in battle is cool, but they act stupidly and frequently get in your way.

Your characters have skill trees, but these are boring and uninspired. Also, you get a ton of skill points, likely enough to get 100% of skills on everyone (no strategic building required whatsoever). 

Items are dull as well. Weapons' stats consist in variations of damage/heat-sink/accuracy, armors' in variations of defence/shield/biotic or tech defence. That's all. The only interesting thing about items is that weapons and armors have slots in which you can install some mods, adding bonuses to them. That's nice, but the mods themselves are nearly as uninspired as everything else in the game.

All maps are small, all spaces tight, everything linear. The game's level design is the worst and laziest I think I've ever seen.

To wrap it all in a paper bag and set it on fire on your porch, Mass Effect requires EA's platform to be installed on your computer, and for it to run every time you start the game. After it just refused to open twice in a row as I was about to force myself to play the game for a few more minutes, I finally gave up on it. 

In short, ME is terribly [i]dated[/i]. I thought it was a classic, but no -- it was just once good, in a time when there was simply nothing better. All the charm it had when initially released is gone. Now, it's just an embarrassing example of how awful [i]everything[/i] in games was 20 years ago. 

I loved this thing back in the day, and just gave the series a second, honest shot. But nostalgia alone can't save it. Mass Effect is now as boring as hell to old timers, and probably downright unplayable to newcomers. Even remastered, with all DLCs and a 90% discount, it's not worth playing -- not even for the story, which is what I personally went in for.

Wow this aged like doodoo dogwater. The mass effect trilogy is one of those classics that I finally decided to give a try but honestly it's baffling how anyone liked this in the first place. This came out after KOTOR, Halo CE, and Morrowind, and it's like a fusion of all of those games if someone blended them up into a smoothie, drank it, peed it out in the toilet, then dunked a ladle in there and went to town.

I really tried to give this game a fair shot, but 90% percent of my playtime was spent aimlessly wandering as a soldier with the worst cardio in the universe, wondering where tf to go. I've seen many people say "well this game doesn't hold your hand," but there's a difference between not holding my hand, and throwing me as a baby off a boat into the open ocean. I've played games where you're only given hints where to go and you have to figure the rest out on your own, but the difference is, those games actually give details and provide reasons to explore, while in mass effect, everything looks the same, around every corner there's jack squat, and as an added bonus commander shepherd is the worst note taker in human history. "Go to poopenfarten central," Cool, where's that? What do I do with this information?? Oh, it's marked on my map? Oh, but it's not on my current map, it's marked on the map of the area I need to go to. Sick. See you in 3 hours.

Also, the combat feels dreadful, which I could forgive if the story or any other aspect of the game had hooked me, but alas, this game is ultra poop from a butt.

Six Days in Fallujah isn’t just a game. It’s a lifestyle change.

I thought I was ready. I had snacks, a comfy chair, and a good mouse. Then the first door breached. The sound, the chaos, seeing my Marines taking hits, I haven’t been the same since.

Now I flinch when someone slams a door. My friends call me “Lieutenant Lag.” I can’t play other shooters anymore.

Uninstalled twice. Reinstalled thrice. OORAH! Just one more mission id tell myself.

10/10 Recommend if you’re ready to trade your sanity for immersion.

The development of this game originally started back in 2009. Then came bankruptcy, a long pause, and a change of developer in 2016. Early Access, if I’m not mistaken, began in 2023?
In those sixteen years, I’ve graduated from university and climbed to a high corporate position — yet the core game mechanics still feel stuck in the embryonic state of 2009...

I do like the fact that the gameplay is slow-paced. In fact, that slow pacing often helps the sluggish allied AI make fewer mistakes and avoid getting in the way.
But sometimes their behavior is just absurd… On the map with the amusement park, I was clearing an LZ full of heavily armed enemies, carefully peeking around the corner of a small building. AI “Fire” and “Assist” were covering the rear — everything was going great and felt very immersive. But “Ready,” who was originally behind me, decided to run all the way around the building toward the enemy side and almost took a bullet to the face from me as he appeared right in my line of fire. Pure nonsense.

The enemy AI would honestly fit much better in a zombie game. In the post-mission statistics, we often see numbers like 35–80 kills. With AI like this, that’s the only way to make the game challenging. But wouldn’t “quality over quantity” be better? Ten smart enemies are far more interesting than fifty zombies.

The random generation of buildings is great — it adds variety to repeated playthroughs. But the environments are completely empty. No civilians, no traffic, no security cordons or background activity that could make the world feel alive. Is it really that hard to add? Does it make sense that for an operation to clear an insurgents stronghold, only four men and an APC are deployed — and within a 500-meter radius, there’s not a single allied unit securing the perimeter or sweeping nearby streets outside the playable zone?

It’s truly sad that the development is progressing so slowly that I no longer believe in a bright future for this game.
The last time I managed to drag my buddy into a co-op session was eleven months ago — and he’s a big fan of “tacticool” stuff.

All in all Six Days leaves a lot to be desired, from general game play, Ai team mates, missions and progress. I bought the game when it launched, at launch there were only 4 missions, then they added 4 more and some of the Single Player missions which serve more as a tutorial then anything else, even though there is already a training mission in the menu. The gun play is very stale, the procedural generation is cool, but more of a gimmick then an actual factor to your game play. Once you see the same house 10 times, you understand the layouts and interiors which remove any "unknowing" factor when entering these structures. The devs stay radio silent, and this whole year 2025 they've talked about this big Autumn update, but no preview or any kinda teaser as to what it really is besides Dev Blogs with big flashy words that just fill me with more dispair then anything. Many in the community, myself included believe the devs have abandoned this game and just simply made off with the money. 

The Single-player campaign is nowhere near finished, the cut scenes feel rushed and half baked, as do almost all other sysyems in the game. This should game with a "buyer beware" tag, I hope that the devs finish the game and make it the shooter they set out to develop. But at this point in time I can't in good faith recommend it to anyone, when other games do it better, just not in the Middle East with a historical setting. Six Days is far from finished and until the devs start being a bit more transperant, I think you should just wait till its finished or they finally pull the plug

So I want to like this game because this era was all the pictures, propaganda, gear, and training standards when I joined the Marines. I came in shortly after Fallujah. But I just cannot like it, it is a poorly executed shooter, and the mechanics in game still leave so much to be desired. I bought it, hated it, gave it like a year to develop, still hate it.

Point shooting mechanic- I understand what they are going for, because when I first was trained in CQB, I was taught this exact thing. Look just over top of your rear sight, and put the target between the wings of the front sight, and out to about 50 yards, that's accurate enough to do the job. I shot probably thousands of rounds thru M16s at close range just like this before Acogs and Dots became the standard. But in the game the impact point is wayyyyyyy too high, Like several feet high at across the street distance. Theres no real predictability to it and even in rooms where you should be able to use your flashlight as a pointer, its way above that. Think about that logically, flashlight mounted maybe 2 inches on the right side of the barrels center line, and the impact hits like a torso distance above the center of the light beam at room distance. That don't make sense in any religion on any planet. 

The AI are dumber than actual Marines, and that's a feat. We eat crayons and marry strippers we meet right off base named Kandi. But the team mates in game are even worse. They will rush in directly front of you as you are shooting the enemy, get shot in the process, you stop shooting so you dont kill them, then you both get mowed down by the guy you weren't able to kill because Lance Corporal retard got in the way. They also get stuck on the simplest of obstacles and sometimes shoot you in the back of the head to try to kill the guy in front of you since you made entry into the room first but they want the kill I guess. 

The command system is also lackluster at best, you basically have go here, come here, suppress, watch over there, and a variety of object/instance specific tasks like breach a door or plant c4 right, but the go here command is capped at a very close distance. Like 25 yards. So you're trying to cover your team as they advance up the road since you got the acog and theres bad guys up the street, but you cant order them to a piece of cover because its 40 yards away and that's just too far away. That's not even in the distance we would start using our radios in combat. Theres also no combat formations whatsoever, they just kind of stumble bum around in whatever order they feel like, but usually in a straight line close enough to hold each others pockets, looking whatever direction they feel like, oblivious to the world around them until they get shot at, and if you tell them to go to a piece of cover, but then tell them to watch in a direction, they will leave that cover and stand in the open to watch that direction, getting shot and killed.

I have been playing single player with the "AI" bots. It feels like a well made game, but the AI gets in the way as much as it helps. From blocking doors to not healing me when injured.

I guess this will be great fun with human team mates, but I cannot recommend this game for a single player experience.

This game sucks now. I wish I could get a refund. 
As a concept, I love Six Days in Fallujah. It was pretty good before the addition of the campaign mode. I don't know what changed, but before, I was able to play on "High" graphics settings, now I have to play at the lowest settings to get a more playable experience.
As for the gameplay, the friendly AI can't hit a thing to save their life, or mine. I've been incapacitated by the door to the AAV after calling reinforcements. My whole fire team has been blown up by only God knows what less than 20 seconds into a mission. And the stupid tank escort mission, holy hell. The friendly AI is absolutely useless in shooting anything that is even remotely behind cover, the enemy AI is pixel peeking and blowing up the tank with RPGs, getting stuck, and appearing out of thin air, I have watched them spawn right in front of me. There is nothing more frustrating about a game than dying the same way or failing a mission the same way dozens of times. Call it a skill issue, but if there's no indication for what I'm supposed to do other than walk forward, mark IEDs, and shoot bad guys that I can't see, how the hell am I supposed to learn if I keep getting turned into a pink mist? This is one of maybe 3 times I've genuinely had such a bad time playing a game that I've rage quit. Death and failure loops are not fun, especially when you don't feel like your'e making any progress to a solution or victory. I don't mind throwing myself at a problem again and again and again as long as I feel like I'm accomplishing something. I'm not getting that feeling of progression in the tank escort mission, and it's also incredibly infuriating when you're dealt night and sandstorm conditions back to back when you're already struggling. 

2/5, would not play again without significant improvements

Not worth in the slightest.

Overall, it's very mediocre. Nothing really stands out, nothing really pushes you away or reels you in. 

The immersion is incredibly meh for the price point, especially considering it's in early access. The AI are not very smart at all, they'll follow you into rooms and run in front of your gun while you're shooting. They're just a pain to coordinate all around and I wish you could still play with them off. 

The visuals aren't great, some places are very dark and some places don't fit the overall atmosphere. 
It's incredibly difficult to tell where you're getting shot from as the background includes muzzle flash and tracers travelling towards you yet there are no enemies. 

The game features a point fire mechanic, which is heavily encouraged but makes the game feel incredibly arcade like, putting a crosshair on your screen. It honestly breaks the immersion, point firing itself is fine, but is the crosshair really necessary?

This wouldn't be an issue if it weren't for the incredibly zoomed in irons they give you. They take up half your screen and are virtually impossible to use in cqc. It just makes using irons completely irrelevant for the first few missions and you don't even get to choose which attachments you want to run for the first two missions at least. 

Did I mention the tips halfway through missions that feel more like cutscenes? Halfway through the first mission, the game slows down everything and tells you to place an order for your squadmates to watch a balcony, which seems fine at first considering its the starting mission. This wouldn't be an issue, except that it happens halfway through missions and DURING firefights. Getting randomly put in slow motion, and moving your characters gun barrel towards the floor since you apparently need to radio to command while you're being shot at just completely ruins the flow of the gameplay. I cannot speak for the entire game though, as I only played the first two missions before refunding, so I seriously hope there's a way to turn this off or that it becomes significantly less common as you progress. 

The game itself just feels incredibly arcade like for what it advertises itself as. It might get better with time seeing as it is in early access but I simply cannot recommend it in its current state considering its price point. 

I would heavily recommend waiting for future updates and the full release before purchasing, despite all the positive reviews. These issues seriously break the immersion and disrupt the flow of gameplay. I hope this game can find a way to become more immersive and more realistic while balancing the amount of guidance the player actually needs. There's lots of potential here, and I will revisit this game upon full release.

TL;DR: feels unfinished and incredibly arcade like for what it is, gameplay flow is frequently ruined.

Game has great potential but definitely not worth that $40 price tag. Too many bugs to justify it. However on sale for $25 its not a bad game to play with friends. With that said. Ive found guns to have random aim bloom that doesnt make sense even with first shots or crouching firing super slow. The acog is off zero and does not hit where you are aiming about 80% of the time. Additionally AI will just spawn and or appear in front of your or at your feet literally on defense missions. Friendly AI commanding on multiplayer are disabled this includes telling them to hold or move (horrible decision). So they will do nothing except revive and occasionally shoot at enemies while holding your hand and blocking your vision or movement whenever they possibly can with their bodies or their flashlight (AI flashlight bloom or blinding should be disabled). You cannot not command them to do anything other than close tunnels. To which are often bugged and will trap enemies inside of them preventing you from completing missions. Graphically speaking it looks like it was downgraded as of late. Still looks decent but definitely not as good as it is in the trailers. AI spawning needs to be adjusted quite a bit. They should run from areas close to the edge of the map away from where the player has cleared. Or just away from where the player is coming from/spawning from. To be clear when I got this today I expected a far more polished product (which is kind of on me). However, given how long it has been since early access I expected more. It makes me wonder what state the game was when it went into early access. As of right now I cannot recommend this game for the full price. At sale it can be fun with friends but if I paid full price I wouldnt be happy.

The game has a great concept and some genuinely intense and immersive moments that set it apart from most modern military shooters. You can tell the developers are aiming for something more meaningful and realistic, and I really respect that.

That said, the current state of the game has quite a few issues — bugs, crashes, and performance hiccups really hurt the experience. Sometimes the game breaks or gets stuck entirely, and it can be frustrating, especially during co-op sessions.

But I understand it's still in Early Access, and that comes with the territory. I truly hope the devs keep pushing forward, because this game has serious potential. I’ll definitely be picking it up again once the full version is released.

Wishing the team all the best — you’re onto something special here.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
Like any game in active development, there are some minor bugs here or there. That being said, I fully believe that the dev team here care about their game and the community they've built in it's playerbase. They're listening to feedback from us players and with every single patch it gets better.

Building in this game is easily the best I've encountered in any survival game. I have many hours spent in building our manor, the outlying farm, the gardens, its all been great fun. It's got something for everyone, with fun dungeons, interesting enemies, even NPCs you get to rescue and make part of your "village". 

I'd definitely recommend giving it a try. The minor bugs I've encountered haven't been bad enough to detour me from playing and I feel heard by the dev team working their tails off to make this game better and better.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
I went into it just looking for something to unwind with after work, and it ended up becoming one of the most chill and relaxing games I’ve played in a long time. The loop is simple: explore, loot, build, chill. There’s no crazy rush or punishment every 5 minutes. You can take your time, set up your base exactly how you like it, and just vibe.

The world has this calm atmosphere — even when you’re running into enemies or diving into the Shroud, it never feels stressful. Half my time has been spent just gathering materials, expanding my base, and trying out new builds. Co-op is even better; it feels like hanging out with friends, not grinding.

If you want a game that lets you relax, zone out, and still feel like you’re progressing, Enshrouded is absolutely worth it. I didn’t expect to sink 115 hours into it, but here I am.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
Early access review!
I played the game for about 70 hours in my first 2 months after the release.
I got somewhat bored after that and I now returned and there is so MUCH new stuff to do, new areas, new material to build and craft with.
New weapon types and all that jazz, I really like the game and I really do recommend it, no matter if you play solo or with friends.

Playing with friends is ofc a bit more fun for the most part and can make certain things easier.
Speaking of easier, there is ONE boss in the game that makes my blood boil. The mechanics and battle arena is just all bad and the only good thing about the boss is the design of the boss itself, not the mechanics or the battle. I cheezed the hell out of that fight by dropping the damage and health of the boss down to 20%, I love being able to customize my worlds with difficulties and resource yields and all that.

There are plenty of kinks and bugs to work out but the developers are working on the game and it shows. I hope the full realization of the game will come into fruition with the 1.0 update at some point.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
I wish I could give this a 'mixed' review. The game is fun, and the concept is good, but some areas seem to be extremely confused in the direction and there is a definite lack of review on how the additional content fits into the gameplay.

The new fishing for example, I kept breaking my line on rare fish and it wasn't until I searched *spoilers* did I find out you only get access to additional rods from the newest, lvl ~40ish area. The introduced fishing minigame, which is pushed very early through the villagers, and you can only get better at what is currently end game. Who reviewed this idea? It only takes thinking about this briefly from a new player perspective to recognise this is a terrible implementation, this game is still an 'in development' game and thus should be catering to a growing playerbase, why is something implemented and introduced to new players but the only development to this gameplay concept is brought about in the late game?

Being early access and a multi-platform game, some things such as excessively limited keybinds is understandable, but why am I still falling through the map on Blackmire? I had these issues when I first explored Blackmire maybe a month after it came out? A long time ago. And I am *still* falling through the map in that area, getting sent back all the way from the *spoilers* shroud root in SE Blackmire after going all the way through that horrible maze.

Meanwhile, as far as something that has also not improved during this process, lock on and hit registration, especially using the jump slam attack (which may be new I do not remember it) are still crap, I hit things behind me more consistently than what is directly in front, and any lunge attacks that I sidestep hit me similarly in the back, so at least it's consistent that in this universe it is easiest to hit that which you cannot see.

Game still has amazing feelings, vibe, music is great, world feels interesting to explore and loot feels rewarding, just really hope that we see more refinement instead of new content without considering how it interacts with new or returning players.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
I should like this game, it has all the things I look for.. but.. It just doesn't click with me.

From the lacklustre "Story" missions that don't do anything other than "Go Here, kill that"
To the world feeling both full of things but lifeless at the same time.
The boring level grind because most things you do don't give any XP, and that horrendously large skill tree just taking me completely out of the fun of Progression.
Building, which should be the thing I like the most, I just can't enjoy it here, the building system looks both really good and really convoluted at the same time. Too many buttons, no decent build camera and constantly having to break the flow to get decorations from one place or building blocks from another because I can't just use the resources I've gathered to build directly isn't fun or engaging.
Combat feels like a chore, it's not engaging or rewarding, more often than not the Lock-On is more problematic than it should, enemies have a weird difficulty scaling where one is a total pushover and the next will deck you instantly.

The thing I was more interested in, the Shroud and the Fact you're supposed to cleanse it, is totally insignificant, because nothing on the world is permanently changed, the Shroud you clear just gets back after a while and no terrain or structure stays permanently destroyed, it's totally pointless to engage with the one thing this game could have different from the rest.

Maybe the game picks up after a while, maybe the things showed on the Store videos and screenshots give more life to the game, but I'm honestly not committed to play any more of the game, which is a real shame to me because I wanna like it, it has some nice features here and there, but I can't force myself to enjoy something I'm still on the fence about after 15 hours.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
There is a lack of content in terms of combat. There is a lot to do for the creative people, so if you enjoy that aspect then this is a given buy. But if you came for the combat, the epic battles, the bosses, the character progression then you will probably as disappointed as i've been so far.

As far as i'm concerned there are maybe 1 or two bosses that aren't _just_ tank & spank (minor mechanics). The other enemies are extremely boring and repetitive. The same enemies repeated over and over, just different skins basically.

I really think this game has potential, but as it is today i am disappointed in the lack of content and the way the team seems to avoid adding more traditional content.

Also performance; the game is very beautiful but the performance even on a top tier PC is severely lacking.

Overall i don't regret buying the game, but i would not buy it again for the price knowing what i know.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: Don't get me wrong, the game is good. Exploring the world is fun, farming is effortless, and everything looks beautiful. But playing co-op is simply impossible; constant disconnects not only ruin the experience, they cause a very negative emotions. You just completed a dungeon and earned an epic weapon, and then you get kicked out of the game—you reappear God knows where with an empty inventory. You've simply been thrown back in time 10 minutes. Have fun playing this game in co-op.

From what I understand, the world is on a grid for building, so the direction in which you can place the walls is tied to that - meaning if there's a place you like that you want to build your house on, you can only build the walls in one specific direction, which is extremely limiting and frustrating. I would not recommend if building is important to you unless they eventually fix this. Unfortunately this game was a waste of $25 for me and I wish I could get it back.

review_text:
Absolute dogshit. Everything is janky. No one is ever going to fix the main mechanics. They built a foundation out of crap and are just slapping 'content' on top of it.

For example: the wolves. They will just damage you no matter what. Put up a block? Standing on level ground, facing the wolf? Damage goes through. People playing in zones at their own level might not notice this, but we wanted to venture out further. The result—getting our asses torn apart by these f*cking wolves. There is no actual combat system here. And it's like that with every aspect of the core mechanics.

People usually say a game is good depending on the price tag. Even for free—don't waste your time.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
A game that's balanced around groups, but better solo, making for an absolutely miserable experience when it comes to enemy quantity and scaling as a solo player. As a player in a group, you'll always have someone do something and now that gameplay experience does not exist for the rest of the players. Settings don't seem to properly afford the players the means to fix issues and equally contain such a bulk of settings that the player would rather just play another game.

The last update also added frequent rain. When it's raining, you are wet. When you are wet, your stamina is reduced and so is your stamina regen. This has genuinely caused some of the most miserable experiences I've had with this game. In a game that already heavily punishes you using the stamina system, every bad experience you had before is now exponentially worsened. The stamina system as-is creates too many moments where the player has to stand in place for 1-5 minutes.

Also terrible is the lighting. Specifically, for all the gorgeous scenery, you can't actually see the game more often than not. There's the shroud fog which reduces vision, underwater now that reduces vision, foliage which reduces vision. When it's night, light sources don't illuminate very far. You end up standing still for jumping portions for up to 12 minutes. Some darkness applied to ground is indistinguishable from open pits, likely resulting in falling.

Speaking of falling, the player will do it a lot because the game decided a flat surface is sloped just wrong. The player will fall because the glider read collision on terrain that doesn't exist. The player will land and forcibly roll off a surface. The player will fall because instead of double-jumping, the game decides to pull out the glider. And when the player falls, they often will die.

When the player dies, they have to run to the last solid surface they were on, which sometimes is why they died or makes them repeat the same exact actions that caused them to die in the first place.

The game has a lot of the right components, but the more I play, the more it feels like the devs resent the playerbase like they've been on the same project too long.

review_text:
I went back and forth if i would write a review for this game as i did not finish it but here i am typing. 

36 hours i made it, every night me and my duo got on was a night filled with why am i playing this,  surely it will get better but it just got worse over time.  

on the surface this game looks amazing, plays well enough and the world looks great but then you actually play the game and regret your choices.  

I really tried to like this game and i will start with its main positive which is the building system, you got terraforming and a lot of building pieces to pick from and can rebuild the broken down villages.  but that is the only positive i got.

The number one thing i noted playing this game was that it just hates the players... like dark souls but i love dark souls i have 300+ hours on dark souls 3.   this game actually just hates you... it wants you to get stuck, killed by hidden explosives, a swamp that insta kills you, monsters that hit for 500+ damage when you have a 480 health pool with the best armor you can get at the time and a vertical map that is cool at first but really is just a problem.  

I really hated this game the whole time i was playing it,  and im a survival craft player im not new to the genre.  i kept telling myself just give it more time but it just got worse the longer it went.  

This game sucked a lot and its a shame cause it looks good and obviously had good development dollars but this is a hard NO from me.

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing, Free To Play
review_text:
I’ve spent some time with this game and honestly, it surprised me in a way I didn’t fully expect. I don’t want to sound dramatic, but there’s something oddly satisfying about how everything fits together — not in some perfect, polished “advertisement” way, but more like a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and just… goes for it.

The first thing I noticed is the atmosphere. Every part of the game — the visuals, the sound, the pacing — kind of blends into this feeling that you’re actually inside its world, even if you’re just casually playing. I know that sounds a bit cliché, but it’s true. Sometimes it’s chaotic, sometimes slow, sometimes you’re just wandering around thinking “ok, what now?” but that’s honestly part of the charm. The game doesn’t try to rush you unless it actually needs to.

Gameplay-wise, it has this mix of familiar elements and small twists that keep things from feeling stale. Nothing groundbreaking, maybe, but it all works together in a way that feels natural. There were moments when I thought “yeah, I’ve seen this in other games,” but then the game throws in tiny details or unexpected interactions that make it stand out just enough. It’s the kind of thing you only notice after a few hours, when you start connecting the dots.

Performance has been mostly fine. A little rough spot here and there, but honestly, show me a game these days that doesn’t have something weird happening once in a while. Nothing game-breaking on my end, at least. You can clearly tell the developers put effort into this, even if a few edges are still a bit sharp. Again — part of the charm.

What I really appreciate is that the game gives you space to play the way you want. Some people will rush through every objective, others will take their time exploring or messing around, and both approaches actually feel valid. I like games that don’t punish you for not following some “correct” path.

Overall, I’d say this is one of those titles that grows on you the longer you play. It doesn’t try too hard to impress in the first five minutes — instead it slowly builds its identity, layer by layer, until you suddenly realize you’ve been playing way longer than you planned. If you’re looking for something that balances comfort with challenge, familiar mechanics with fresh touches, and a world that’s just fun to be in, then I genuinely think this one is worth giving a shot.

Would I recommend it?
Yeah, I would — maybe not to everyone, because no game is for everyone, but definitely to anyone who likes getting lost in a game for a bit and discovering things at their own pace.

review_text:
[b]# --- MY THOUGHTS:[/b]

I'd like to mention the fact that I have no issues with the core gameplay of this Fall Guys clone. It plays smoothly and its everything you expect it to be. No, my issues are of a different kind.

First of all, I hate the fact that [i]Stumble Guys[/i] is [i]all[/i] about micro-transactions. You could make the argument that many other games have micro-transactions, sure, but what really bothers me is that you are [i]required[/i] to spend money on these stupid micro-transactions in order to get some of the achievements this game has.

Second of all, there are many achievements related to maps that no longer show up [i]at all[/i], or have an astronomically low chance of ever showing up. This locks anyone who wishes to fully complete the game (achievement wise) out.

Lastly, the currency you would get in this game by taking part in the mentioned micro-transactions is [i]way[/i] too overpriced.

Due to the fact that 1. I am not made of money and 2. the game isn't [i]THAT[/i] fun to excuse the micro-transactions, I am abandoning my achievement hunting for [i]Stumble Guys[/i]. Too bad. I would have really liked to put in the hours to complete it.

[b]# --- RATING: 4.5/10[/b]

review_text:
Ich hab ja gedacht, Stumble Guys wär so ein nettes, kleines Partyspiel für zwischendurch. So was, was man mit Freunden lacht, ’ne Runde dreht, bisschen Spaß hat.

Spoiler: Der Spaß bleibt meistens auf der Strecke — zusammen mit meinem Charakter, der mal wieder von der Map geflogen ist, weil die Physik sich gedacht hat: „Heute nicht, Bruder.“

Erstmal das Offensichtliche: Das Spiel fühlt sich an, als wär’s auf Speed gebaut und dann dreimal zurückportiert worden. Alles wackelt, rutscht, buggt, und du hast permanent das Gefühl, die Steuerung ist aus Gummi. Präzision? Fehlanzeige. Dein Charakter läuft, als würde er auf Butter gleiten.

Dann der Ping – der eigentliche Endgegner in Stumble Guys. Egal wie gut du spielst, am Ende gewinnst du nicht, weil du skill hast, sondern weil der Server Gnade zeigt. Du springst perfekt – und wirst trotzdem nach hinten teleportiert. Du rutschst auf einer glatten Fläche aus, auf der eigentlich nichts ist. Und manchmal wirst du einfach so eliminiert, ohne dass du weißt, was du falsch gemacht hast.

Der Content? Wenn du drei Runden gespielt hast, hast du 90 % des Spiels gesehen. Immer dieselben Maps, dieselben Fallen, dieselben Zufallsmechaniken. Es ist nicht mal mehr frustrierend – nur noch ermüdend.

Klar, es gibt neue Skins. Jede Woche. Jede verdammte Woche. Und natürlich stecken sie hinter Paywalls, Season Pässen oder irgendwelchen Glücksspiel-Kisten.

Stumble Guys ist im Prinzip:

10 % Spaß

20 % Frust

70 % Werbung, Pop-ups und „Kauf jetzt dieses Ultra-Legendary-Rainbow-Kitty-Paket für nur 19,99 €“


Ich will gar nicht wissen, wie viele Stunden meines Lebens ich damit verbracht habe, in der Lobby auf „Start“ zu drücken, während das Spiel mir fünf Mal sagt, ich soll mir ein „besonderes Angebot“ anschauen.

Ach ja, und dann kommt noch das absolute Highlight: Mobile Port auf PC.
Alles fühlt sich an, als wäre es nie für Maus und Tastatur gedacht gewesen. Die Menüs sind ein Desaster, das UI schreit Handyspiel, und manchmal erkennt das Spiel deine Eingaben einfach gar nicht.

Ich hab’s ehrlich versucht. Ich hab’s mit Freunden gespielt, ich hab’s solo gespielt, ich hab mir eingeredet, dass es ja „für zwischendurch“ ist. Aber irgendwann merkst du: Es gibt kein „zwischendurch“ – es gibt nur „wieder rausfliegen, wieder genervt Alt + F4“.

Und das Matchmaking? Pure Magie. Du triffst auf Leute mit Skins, die aussehen, als hätten sie das Spiel studiert – und auf Bots, die gerade versuchen, überhaupt zu verstehen, was Schwerkraft ist.

Das Schlimmste ist aber, dass es trotzdem irgendwie süchtig macht. Du klickst auf „noch eine Runde“, weil du denkst, „diesmal gewinn ich’s“. Und dann stolperst du – wieder.

review_text: I'll start this by saying that I'm a completionist. I don't like being left out on unique unlocks and exclusive things. Anyway, me and my fiance both started playing this game at the same time. They have some trophy meter on the right to get special unlocks from a pinata. I don't have that option on my game. I also don't have a market section in my shop like they do. My friend joined yesterday and they too have these features that I don't have. I contacted support and said that it's part of a testing group before they release new features. I asked how I can join that because I'm the only one in my group who isn't a part of that, and they told me they can't. So I'm left behind while my friends and fiance get cool rewards and I'm the one actually winning the games.

"Everything that lives is designed to end, but Nier Automata..."

MASTERPIECE
my fav game forever <33

Even though I haven’t played a huge amount of NieR: Automata, it’s already one of my favorite games ever. It’s rare for a game to pull me in so quickly, but NieR: Automata does it effortlessly with its atmosphere, music, and emotional weight. From the very first hour, it feels like you’re stepping into a world that’s beautiful, broken, and strangely human.

What stands out the most is the vibe — that unique mix of melancholy and hope that Yoko Taro somehow makes feel comforting. The soundtrack alone could carry the entire experience; it’s haunting in a way that stays with you long after you stop playing. And even with the little I’ve seen of the story, it’s clear that it’s something deeper than just an action RPG. Every character, every mission, every small detail seems to mean something.

The gameplay shifts constantly — one moment you’re in fast-paced hack-and-slash combat, the next you’re in a top-down shooter or a side-scrolling platformer — and somehow it all works together seamlessly. Even as someone who hasn’t gone through all the routes yet, I already feel the emotional connection people talk about.

It’s a game I know I’ll keep coming back to, and the fact that I already love it this much with so little time played says everything. NieR: Automata isn’t just a game — it’s a feeling, and it’s one that stays with you.
It is truly a masterpiece.

Why this game?
The main reason I picked this game up was that I was sick of slow-ass combat and the pathetic dodge-rolls in souls like games. Why should I not take a hit just because I roll on the ground?
I wanted a fast paced game like Sekiro but not the ridicolusnes of 1000 kills in mousu genre games like Dynasty Warriors.

Pros:
→ Small 2D Gunship battles like arcade games: 1943 and more.
→ Small 3D Terminator/Armored Core battles which are also very cool.
→ Many 3D levels turn into 2.5D and it's much more fun to play that way and it keeps changing very quickly.
→ I am barely 30mins into the game and I have already figured out so many ways of combat without the game actually telling me so.
→ Giant boss battles which are pretty good.
→ Loved the quick dodge, still have to figure out the combat, a lot of things to go.

Quirks/Cons:
→  Game can be saved after around 45mins of gameplay. Will be around 1 hour if you keep dying.

I love the soundtrack and story, that can be experienced in full, as there is more new content with each successive playthrough that shows you the world from a different perspective. 
I appreciate that you keep your items, level and completed quests from the last playthrough, so you don't have to start over with all of the grinding and questing each time, even though this is inconsistent with the story.

I only had three negative experiences with the game (one of which was the fault of Windows), but thankfully these weren't game-ruining.
One was during a simple-seeming escort quest I started at level 23 and immediately regretted when level 50 enemies showed up (on my second attempt the enemies weren't so high level, so I suppose it was just bad luck).
The second was having to travel to a certain story-relevant location to progress a side-quest, but a short cutscene was automatically played that made the quest unavailable.
The third was losing a days worth of progress after eating a fish, because, as it turned out, WindowsDefender "protected" my save-files from being changed, making it impossible to save the game.
