This is the most grueling, unnerving and tedious JRPG i have ever played. I dont even care anymore how good the story might be, because the underlying "game" you have to play (or much rather endure) to experience the story is so absurdly frustrating.

The reasons are:
- no autosaves, saving only works at fast travel points which entices you to not travel through the map on foot but rather hug the fast travel points to not lose hours of playtime if you mess something up and want to restart at a save
- you have to find your corpse if you die to recover some of your items
- the map is terrible, questmarkers and points of interest are all in the same color and all of them are visible at all times. finding what you are looking for is almost impossible
- the camera sucks. there are tons of areas where the camera switches from regular third person to one fixed angle like in the first resident evil games from almost 30 years ago
- the music will grind your gears after a few hours, because its not an atmospheric backgrund track. Its really obtrusive and there are lots of repetitive vocals that get annoying really quick

And a gameplay-unrelated bonus point are the (for a 2017 released game) ugly, sometimes borderline pis*filter looking graphics with lod issues, pop in and flickering foilage.

I can not fully assess how good the story is, because i will most probably not finish this game as i had almost no fun playing it, but for the actual gameplay, id give it something like a 3/10

I expected so much more out of this series based on the hype and attention it gets, but man this was a let down. Visuals are drab, music is repetitive, combat is so-so, exploration is a slog, and worst of all are the performance issues are constant. That is also not mentioning the fact that the camera is absolutely broken in some areas from getting stuck in top down to not being able to keep up with the player during sprint.

It just does not feel like a modern game in a few areas and while that can possibly be overlooked, the crashes are inexcusable. IF I were able to finish this game, I would assume I would score it around a 5.5, but again, I quit after the myriad of issues.
its geniunely insane how you have to redo the tutorial from 0 if u die from the boss in the tutorial

I have no idea why this game gets the love that it does. It's annoying. The combat is, quite frankly, pathetic. There are button combinations that aren't explained at all. I have quest markers all over the map, in areas I can't get to. I have no clue which missions progress the story. The graphics are dull. People like the music which is fine at first, but it becomes repetitive. It's taken me way too long to figure out that exploration is not worth the time. At all.

The story is the selling point and I can agree with that. There's a side mission existentialist robot named Jean Paul and for those of us that have had Sartre thrust on us, well, that's damn funny!! You do connect with some of the characters, so I'll push through, but it feels like less of game and more of a really long, drawn out film.

If I didn't have a back injury, I'd not waste my time. But I'm stuck in this chair for a month so what the hell. I wouldn't recommend the game to anyone I know, however.

On paper, it looks like an amalgamation of everything I like: postapoc, androids, bots, greenery, heavy on philosophy plot, multiple endings, RPG, outstanding OST etc. But my Omnissiah, what a bore it is. The world is barren, combat is shallow, NPC-s could have been an email, side quests are a chore. I could go on, but if JRPG doesn't have neither a compelling story, characters nor gameplay, what else can it offer?

This game is famous for its story, yes, but I just couldn't force myself to slog through the gameplay to see it. If anything, it felt pretentious and shallow. Unfortunately, 2B's butt is not enough of a plot point for me to stick to the experience.

The only thing I liked about the game (long before I actually played it) is the soundtrack. Fortunately, that I can experience [i]without[/i] the game itself.
I have a motion sickness from this game...

I really wanted to like this game as I really loved the characters, setting and music of Nier Gestalt. But the gameplay is often grindy, stale and repetitive. The characters and story are ok and I appreciate the philosophical approach plus the excellent music. There are some very special emotional moments in this game that hit me hard and stayed with me. Unfortunately this wasn't enough for me to really enjoy the game. For the most part it felt more like a chore (especially the hacking) than actual enjoyment just to see what happens next. I know I am one of the few who cannot recommend the game, but I am pretty sure you can get some enjoyment out of this one especially if you love Japanese style games.
I don't get the hype. It just feels like fetch quest after fetch quest. Map is really annoying and confusing. You can't get to some areas with markers until later on, and that is not made very clear.

Play through the opening sequence before you get to the bunker and you'll know if you like it or not. 

For me, this was an absolute slog. I did not enjoy the combat at all, and the grindy, unnecessary levelling system exacerbated it. I played through to the C ending before I was done dealing with the shitty combat and being underlevelled. 

Frankly, I really don't get what people see in this game. Replaying through the same mediocre combat and missions as 2B and 9S is baffling. The quest design is bad, the map and level design is extremely uninspired, the VA is spotty, and the characters are very one note. 

The chip system wants to be something clever like Nine Souls or Hollow Knight's abilities, but then neglects to provide any interesting abilities, preferring instead to increase your melee damage by a literal 2%. We can do so much better than this.

If you want to experience the story, go watch it on youtube. This frankly fails on every metric I'd evaluate a game by.
Not my cup of tea. The combat is not very responsive, although I would point out a very interesting combination of gameplay mechanics.

Since the majority of the reviews for this game are old and positive, I think I'll be the minority report.

If this game is on sale, resist the urge to purchase it. If you buy it, and you play it, you'll know why I told you not to.

You've been warned.

The game is alright, but lacks QOL and polish. If you want to get it do yourself a favor and do so when it's on sale.

The save system is extremely bad and annoying. The music is extremely good. The gameplay is not smooth at all and most of the time I defeated the enemies with the robot 2B. The user interface of the game is boring. I continued the story of the game until the first ending, but after that the game had no traction at all and it bored me a lot. I was looking forward to experiencing this game but it was not worth the experience at all.

[b]Merits:[/b]
▪ A very intriguing premise (told in a terrible format)
▪ Dynamic switching between game genres
▪ Fantastic musical score
▪ 2B's assets & animations

[b]Flaws:[/b]
▪ PS2 level graphics
▪ Terrible UX, especially on the map
▪ Grindy and repetitive combat
▪ A ton of boring fetch quests
▪ Requires multiple playthroughs for the full story

[b]Verdict:[/b]
I have heard great things about this supposed masterpiece, however the reality did not meet the expectations. The switching between shoot 'em up/hack 'n' slash/platforming is novel but the pacing of the game is terrible. It absolutely does not respect your time, expects you to constantly backtrack and play the game multiple times. When it comes to the story or lore almost nothing is told to the player and you have to very slowly unravel things through tidbits in the world. 
My recommendation would be to watch the cutscenes on YouTube or better yet, watch the anime series that is based on the game, you will have infinitely better time.

[b]Rating:[/b]
★★☆☆☆ - Average

The game itself is a lot of fun, great combat and music hits hard. But the save system is one of the worst I’ve seen in gaming history and it ruins the whole experience; it constantly makes you worry about losing progress. I feel bad for not recommending it but this one thing ruined the fun for me.

I literally played the same thing twice, first time I exited after about 30 minutes without knowing there’s no Autosave and lost progress, and the second time I played ~50 minutes then died, instead of resuming I was sent back to the very beginning. That felt ridiculously frustrating. I refunded it for now, If they ever fix the save system I’d happily give it another shot.

I always thought this was a mindless action game with fan service.

The gun aiming in 3rd person is fine. In side scroll-er it's up OR left OR right. Nothing in between. Which is frustrating.
The melee combat is better. The heavy hits feel impactful.

I hit my first 'quit moment' 5 minutes into the game.
The game yanks the camera all over the place throwing you from 3rd person, side scroll-er, top down, and everything else with little to no warning.

The game is trying to be so many genres at once it's like being shoved in a barrel and tossed over Niagara falls.

I had a feeling this wouldn't be my type of game but I gave it a shot.
Turns out it was right.
What I expected from this game, I got from Signalis.

11 hours into the playthrough.
Gameplay: Terrible
Graphics: PS3-level
Difficulty: Unbalanced (Normal mode is too easy; Hard mode, you get one-shot—might as well play Very Hard mode)
Story: After 11 hours, nothing significant has happened. I know the story gets better, but how much longer do I have to play before it’s actually enjoyable?
Characters: Likeable
Also worst map navigation in history of games!

So basically, if you’re willing to spend at least 20 hours for the game to actually get good, I’d recommend it. Otherwise, you might want to just watch a YouTube video—preferably a 6-hour one—which covers everything and is free, saving you a lot of time.

you'd think a simple roguelike like this would be boring or frustrating after 40 hours or so. but unlike other games where you've figured everything out by then... in nuclear throne, the endgame is where the real fun starts.

i rarely write negative reviews, but nuclear throne is truly one of my favorites. it's like a zen state. every run is so intense yet *so* relaxing. the first 20 hours are an unforgiving learning process, but this is a necessary sacrifice in order to truly appreciate what comes afterwards.

nuclear throne avoids the problems of many other roguelikes, where you're doomed if your items aren't good enough or you get swarmed by enemies in the wrong way. this game is fine-tuned so that you can ALWAYS theoretically win a run, if you know what you're doing. it is the epitome of tough but fair. it should be frustrating but it isn't, because at the end of the day, *every single mistake* is your fault. (okay, that was a lie, a few of the achievements are just brutal. but it's about the journey, not the destination!)

true, sometimes the deaths feel like BS, and sometimes they even are. but it's a learning process. for example, getting suddenly blown up for all of your health is pretty funny -- and more importantly, it's a lesson to respect the power of grenade launchers (and stage props!). even the most explicitly unfair obstacles, like certain boss attacks, can be avoided with practice or planning. the end result of this mountain of failures, is a very satisfying flow state that tests your reflexes and tactical planning.  this is doubly true of the "endgame" system, which is a lot of fun if you can pay attention to all of the chaos. even now I am finding dumb ways to die, some really dumb ways to die.

overall, it's awesome for 15- or 30-minute study breaks. definitely a unique and interesting vibe, maybe slightly annoying at times, but it's grown on me. for example, i wasn't a huge fan of the soundtrack but you can easily go in the game files and swap it out with, say, the hotline miami music. great time, solid recommend. it should be even better when they release the epilogue update with custom difficulty & more character-specific achievements.

Unfortunately at this point in time this game's flaws are extremely apparent. The game is locked to 4:3 and 30fps unless you opt for a beta build (from 2023) in order to play widescreen and at over 60fps. The upgrades range from somewhat helpful if you even notice them working to down right useless. The teleporting door at the end of the stages can spawn directly under you automatically advancing you to the next stage even if you weren't ready and can potentially damage you if surrounded by hazards. The maps are too basic and claustrophobic and enemies take full advantage of this opting to shoot around corners and target the player from off the screen. I don't feel like this game is really worth the full price anymore, maybe at one point but not now. There are better more polished roguelikes that are more worthy of your time and energy.

Don't understand the hype around this rogue-like (yes, like, not lite, there's nothing to unlock apart from new characters).

While it does offer a decent variety of characters, weapons, enemies and levels, you'll probably have seen most of it within 2 hours.

I've pretty much found the same weapons every run. There's a variety of solid shot, energy and explosive weapons, like grenade launchers, rocket launchers, SMGs, laser pistols, crossbows, etc.

Characters are unlocked by just reaching certain levels it seems, and they're decently different, but I found that most of them are just "even harder mode". Not having access to the dodge roll or the even better block ability just doesn't seem particularly viable, unless you're so hardcore you're corehard.

Levels are always the same with minor variations. There's a specific set list you go through in each run, but there can be some differences at some points. Enemies are level-dependent, and every level is a sort of "maze" structure.

The mutations, aka level-ups, aren't interesting, either. They probably get a bit more complex, once you unlock more characters, since it seems the game is pulling them from each one of them, but I doubt that you'll deviate much from "this is the best I can have".

Now, my real issue (yeeeeah, git gud, scrub, I don't care) comes from the fact that the game is simply brutally unforgiving and unfair. Enemies do an absurd amount of damage to you, and your health pool is so small, I wonder why they even bothered with health pickups, since come level 3 or so all it takes is like 2 to 3 hits to go from full health to 0 health.
This is, obviously, exacerbated with each succeeding level, meaning you'll literally get one-shot, so health pickups worth 2 health are pointless if you simply die in 1 hit.

Of course, the game also evolves into a literal bullet hell, often dropping you into the middle of an unwinnable fire fight right from the start of a level, with enemies all around you shooting endlessly. Frantic doesn't even describe it.

All in all I can't find anything special about Nuclear Throne. Neither the setting, nor the weapons, nor the game mechanics are anything to write home about. It's simply a game for masochists, which is FINE ... it's just important that you know what you're getting yourself into, hence the "not recommended". It really is only for a VERY niche audience of which I am apparently not a part of.
If your idea of fun is to rerun the same 2 to 3 levels with basically the same setup over and over again in the vain hopes of maybe reaching level 4 or 5 at some point, without ever getting stronger or unlocking new equipment, and if you love twitch reaction top down shooters with very rough pixel art, then this game is for you. If you're not part of that specific audience, play literally any other rogue-like/lite.

Generally really like rogue-likes, and was a big fan of Gungeon. While the core gameplay is alright, the game has a lot of gotcha's that make it a fairly miserable experience. From cars that explode after a few seconds of no indication that they'll explode to enemies that if you melee (even at full health) will oneshot you. 

The cherry on top being once you finally figure out all the things that will instantly kill you and make it to the final boss. Guess what? It instantly kills you, no warning, no reaction time, the only way to avoid it, is to die to it and learn that you have to be standing in a certain spot. Really makes for an anti-climatic end of a good run that just leaves a bad taste in the mouth.

I've enjoyed plenty of difficult games, but when the biggest threat to the player is generally your own weapons or the environment, it just makes for a poor overall experience.

My biggest complaint is one particular boss later in the game.  The dude shoots like 5 bullets in a straight line at the speed of light.  And he can fire at you from off screen, so if you happen to be where he's aiming, unless you have superhuman reflexes, you're going to get hit by at least one of the the 5 bullets. 
Or if you get unlucky, you're gonna be eating 3, 4, or even god forbid all 5 shots  And since each bullet does 3 damage, even only 3 bullets is enough to kill your 8 health character.  Even if you get a health upgrade to 12 HP, you're still getting put down by 4 bullets.  

This enemy also summons other fairly strong minions, flies into the air and quickly lands right next to you emitting a ripple of fire that evaporates your health for every nanosecond you're in it, has tons of health, moves quickly, and is super tiny and hard to hit.  Not to mention he shows up only a few seconds after you get to his stage, so there will be tons of other normal enemies in the level ready to gang up and fuck you over.

WHILE I WANT TO reccomend this game, i simply cannot after 460 hrs of gameplay i find its gameplay loop too difficult and challenging for what should be an easy to slide into casual game that you can play for a few minutes. 
 There are a lot of good things to be said and a lot of bad.
                          The BAD
I find the RNG to be frustrating in the worst way possible
Say you get blood lust mutation, Youd expect it to heal you like it says it will but it doesnt
its like its up to the game to decide whether the hit you made is going to heal you, it doesnt seem like a percent chance but rather it feels like it actively chooses whether or not youll get hp, sometimes ill get 3 hp in a row, other times i will go through 3 levels and receive nothing at all,

Like a racing game where the better you race, the better your rivals race, instead of expecting consistency  expect it to be harder as you get better.

Lack of defined rules .
You learn in this game by failing, and in some cases it seems like its silly. one type of enemy hurts to touch while others you can walk into with no damage being taken, none of this is explained before hand but rather through experience.  i guess consulting the wiki is mandatory for knowing what to do in this game. Rats and maggots and crystal crawlers ( like rats) are the bane of my existence, small, slow or agile and jumping or racing all over the screen able to hit  and walk away or the pretending to be dead guys who can also race around and knock u half dead in one shot.  everything seems to be better than you or able to easily dish out more damage than you can to them.  some things die in one shot depending on your weapon. 

its frustrating to even get to the the throne, the quarters are tight for gunplay, areas are too narrow for it, and in most cases enemies cant be fought with melee weapons ( if you get one)  because they explode, have better melee range than you, are bullet hell producing gigantic healthbars or would burst you full of death before you could get in range. 

In short the enemies, The RNG, the environment and even the Game itself HATES you and does not want you to succeed in anyway Creating a frustrating end user experience only a machiavellian could love.

I feel like I got to this party a bit late. I'm an avid fan of the roguelike genre and Nuclear Throne does have a very solid minimalist design, but I can't help feeling it's a bit limited even by the standards of its day feeling more like something suited to the gameboy.

NT is one of the earlier twin stick roguelikes containing the skeleton of the genre. The gunplay is fast paced, tough, and simple. Upgrades come in the form of mutations which vary by character, and each level is a minimal, tiny, blocky arena that can be expanded via explosions.

Gameplay is centred around the guns and character specific gimmicks. Survival is achieved by learning how to wield the different weapons without killing yourself and familiarising yourself with the different enemies, how they react to being shot, and how to dodge their projectiles. The small resolution and tight spaces combined with large explosions and enemy attacks provide most of the difficulty here.

It has a lot of charm in it's simplicity but the gameplay lacks nuance so it becomes repetitive fast. I can see why people might grind this one for hours at a time but it's not substantial enough for my taste.

**Ori and the Will of the Wisps – A Near-Perfect Masterpiece (10/10)**

I just finished my second playthrough of *Ori and the Will of the Wisps* and I’m still in awe. Everything about this game feels like it was crafted with pure love.

From the very first moment, the visuals absolutely floor you. The hand-painted art style is breathtaking — every layer of parallax, every glowing particle, every blade of grass swaying in the wind looks like a living painting. When you sprint across the glowing sands of the Wellspring or glide through the midnight-blue depths of Luma Pools with the water effects rippling around Ori, it’s genuinely jaw-dropping. This is one of the most beautiful games ever made, period.

The soundtrack? Moon Studios somehow topped the already legendary *Blind Forest* score. Gareth Coker’s music swells and crashes with your emotions — gentle piano in quiet moments, thunderous orchestral bursts during escapes, heartbreaking strings when the story hits you right in the chest. I still get chills every single time “A Stirring from the Ruins” kicks in.

Gameplay is buttery smooth and endlessly satisfying. The movement upgrades feel amazing — triple jump, bash, dash, burrow, glide, grapple… everything flows together so naturally that by the end you’re chaining abilities like a speedrunner even if you’re just playing casually. Combat is weighty and fun (the new spirit weapons feel great), and the chase sequences are some of the most intense, perfectly paced moments in any platformer ever.

And the story… oh man. Without spoiling anything, *Will of the Wisps* takes the simple fairy-tale vibe of the first game and gives it real emotional weight. The new characters (especially Ku and the supporting cast) are so endearing, and the ending left me quietly crying in the best way possible. It’s rare for a game to make me care this much about little glowing forest spirits.

Yes, there were a few minor launch bugs back in 2020, but on modern hardware (Xbox Series X, PC, or Switch now) it runs flawlessly. If you love Metroidvanias, platformers, beautiful art, or just games that respect your emotions, you owe it to yourself to play *Ori and the Will of the Wisps*. It’s not just one of the best Xbox exclusives — it’s one of the best games of the entire generation.

Play it. Cry a little. Fall in love. Then immediately start it again on Hard mode like I did. ✨

As a long time D&D player, Solasta feels like a more faithful adaption of a tabletop RPG than the shadow-casting colossus that is BG3.

Like the forgotten older sibling whose more attractive and more successful younger brother receives all the love and praise, Solasta is the game that gives you everything its got, with all its heart. Sure, its not as polished, its voice cast is smaller, the scripting is rougher, and the graphics will look better at the end of the night after a few drinks, but it is D&D.

It has personality and quiet charm. Its scrappy, nerdy and enthusiastic like a Saturday morning DM doing their best to deliver you a fun game with whatever voices they can muster, half-baked stories, and last minute quest hooks.

Solasta is familiar, fun and delivers that all important authentic feel that only comes from a DM (or developer) with a true love for what they're doing.

pros: good game really close to 5e dnd tabletop experience... if graphics were a bit better and UI too, it would be really awesome :D
cons: a bit too easy in the standard difficulty. Also is a bit slow game but as I play story gets more engaging ;)

Einer der größten Vorteile dieses Spiels im Beriech der rundenbasierten RPG's ist, dass man nicht elendlange Dialoge lesen und beantworten muss. Ich mag die Pathfinder Serie und auch die Pillars Spiele, aber da hat es mich schon immer gestört, dass man eben teilweise extrem lange Dialoge lesen muss und das eigentlich Spiel darunter leidet. Das ist hier nicht der Fall. Knappe Dialoge, die sich auf das Wichtigste konzentrieren. Dazu eine (für RPG's) sehr gute Grafik, stimmige Atmosphäre und eine sehr gute Story. 

Also definiv eine Kaufempfehlung.

I feel like I owe the developers of this game an apology for being too quick to judge. Very impressive attention to detail regarding game mechanics related to dungeons/dragons adventuring, crafting, combat, terrain, strategy, storytelling, character creation and development. Vastly superior to baldurs gate 3, with the shallow exception of graphics - but these games when done well engage the imagination and graphics should never trump the rest (and the graphics aren't terrible). It reminds me of the first baldurs gate, and what I would imagine a proper continuation of that game to look like (updated to more current rule-sets). If this were ever to somehow marry Neverwinter Nights (the original with the toolset), I'd expect to be absorbed by it for years and years. I wish the money I wasted on the latest vampire bloodlines fail and expedition 33 or whatever that bad acid trip was called went instead to this developing team. Sometimes life gets busy and we walk right past treasures that we mistakenly assume are merely part of the surrounding drab terrain. I encourage you to dust this game off and take a close look and see it for the sparkling gem it is. Nice job, Solasta team.

This one is worth picking up on sale, if you need to scratch that D&D itch. We will not see the like of Baldur's Gate 3 for some time, but this one is serviceable. Solasta is more gritty. There is no multi-classing, and the main campaign is very stingy with loot. You have to make due without the more fantastical weapons and armor. A +1 item that you can actually use is considered good loot and will be used for a good part of the campaign. The best items are crafted in the main campaign and getting the recipe, correct faction requirements, and ingredients will take you half the game or more to put together.
The 2 DLCs that add new classes and races are straight up rip offs that should have been dropped for free. The full bundle is a good deal when on sale. You get all the races, classes, new dice, and 2 extra campaigns. I just finished the Palace of Ice DLC and it was great. Getting the loot thrown at you without worrying about factions and recipes was very satisfying after the main campaign.
I would recommend to pick this up mainly because the next Solasta coming out early '26 looks amazing. They are revamping the graphics, and making a slew of improvements. This one has minor issues like elevation is handled improperly, cover system is not great, crossbows are broken (in the players favor), graphics are meh, and few other minor things. All that aside I have put enough time in this one to endorse it, it'll do.

If you've finished playing Baldur's Gate 3 and are looking for a similar experience, whether single player or co-op, you are not going to find it here. The UI is very clunky, most classes/races are locked behind a paywall of DLCs. Your characters miss basically every attack. Ammo is required for bow/crossbow attacks. story seems very uninteresting. you become encumbered very quickly which can greatly affect how many spaces you can move. you can't move through characters, so corridors become a real problem when trying to move your team around. games seems pretty heavy on the crafting of potions and other materials. You have to stock up on food before you can travel between locations. fights take far too many turns to conclude.

I was shocked to see this game is only 5 years old, because it plays and feels like something from 2010.

Honestly even if you've never played BG3, I would still probably avoid this game. Hopefully Solasta 2 will be significantly better than this.

Solasta Crown of the Magister really made me question whether or not I actually enjoy D&D 5E combat. The campaign’s difficulty is all over the place. Sometimes we’d snooze our way through encounters. Other times, it took my party several attempts to prevail against a room full of foes that could all dish out and eat more damage than our little four-hero crew. Each time we finally got past a particularly sketchy battle, it felt like favorable dice rolls were more of a determining factor than our collaborative strategizing. A bit of randomness might be a fun way to add unpredictability to role-playing scenarios in a real-life D&D session, but luck as a primary mechanic in combat often leads to the dissatisfying disruption of your best-laid plans. Solasta at its worst really exemplifies this. It also just feels bad when you end up wasting multiple long-awaited turns because your professional archer can’t seem to hit a big, lumbering orc.

As for the rest of the game, it’s almost endearing how janky Solasta is. The muddy graphics, generic placeholder UI, “stanced-up” cutscenes that have a small reserve of animations, and awkwardly generic fantasy dialogue had me convinced that the game was from the early 2000s or something. As a co-op game, Solasta was only engaging for a short time, and it’s a shame that my party and I lost interest as we all enjoy CRPGs. It’s an unfair comparison given the obvious difference in scale/budget, but Solasta is no Baldur’s Gate 3. Solasta’s bland story and forgettable characters make for an experience with a tiny fraction of the personality that’s available in many other narrative-focused turn-based fantasy games. Maybe Solasta works well as a digital scenario builder of sorts for your own personal IRL D&D campaigns, but the adventure that the game itself provides is frankly underwhelming.

Summary: I give the game a passing grade, but I would not recommend it. 6/10. Only buy it if you absolutely love DnD 5e combat mechanics from 2014.

Do you like DnD 5, but wish it had less roleplay? This game might be for you. The story is barebone, the characters are shallow and you can't affect the world around you. As a combat simulator the game works fine. Even then it includes infuriating limitations and restrictions that ought to have been detected and removed in playtesting. Requiring an "open" hand for somatic components is frankly absurd. Being able to change equipped weapon only once per turn likewise. Sometimes spells disappear during casting without counterspell or other explanation. Many choices are locked as soon as they are pressed and require loading an earlier save or starting over. Mistake in leveling up? Get fcked! Attuned the wrong character to the item? Go back to bed or load up! Much of this I am willing to forgive. It is the first game for this studio. Atleast the game is functional. It is a good start, but the lack of experience is palpable.

Pros: Beautiful maps. Battlemaps have hazards and differences in elevation. Combat works pretty well once you learn to avoid the games autistic need to punish missclicks. Character creation allows for leveling up. Having a pool for created characters is cool overall. The story has few cool peaks like the theft of the crown. Crafting while traveling is cool.

Cons: Minimal story. Uninteresting characters. Few voice actors and some horrible performances. With only 2 male and female voices in character creation means one suffers having multiple characters with the same voice. Nobody likes counting rations, projectiles, weight limits etc. LET ME WALK THROUGH ALLIES, SWAP WEAPONS AND CAST SPELLS WHILE HOLDING A SHIELD FFS! Consider this: Enemy is far. I switch to using my bow. I am out of arrows. I can not refill my quiver, because I used my one free swap of gear to take out the bow. I also can not swap back to my melee weapon. 
Random encounters re-use the same 2-3 maps. Spell ares of effect are at times clunky and imprecise to place. Player is not afforded even the illusion of choice in the story. Many species and classes are locked behind DLC. Major gates for teleporting are at times hidden behind 3-4 layers of emptied battlemaps with no way to skip to the target.

It's bad.  Really bad.  It was "Campy" bad at first... Dialog, story, graphics are all scraping bottom of the barrel.  Rules are inconsistent with DnD and even inconsistent with itself.  Some fire creatures are immune to fire, others are not, some are *sometimes* immune... highly inconsistent.
Most *BASE* classes and races are hidden by DLC.  Very scammy.
There's a mod that helps with this, but it's not on Steam, so it's a PITA to get it installed.

***HOWEVER***    Once you install the mod, Multiplayer is ruined.  Constant Desync between host and client.  There's a "decent" fix, by hard setting your GPU to 60 FPS.  Which means, for WTF ever reason they connected network activity to the GPU.  And it still desyncs, but not *every* fight.

Even worse, once you install the DLC and experience the Desnc, you can't uninstall it... and after seeing all the classes/races left out by the orginal came in the mod, you can't enjoy going back.

Story is bad and get worse as you get to the end.

if you've already played Baldur's Gate 3, this will not scratch your itch. Clunky, non-interactive dialogue, a lack of variety in combat and character builds, constant backtracking to previous locations, crappy UI... it's only gonna make you wish the next Larian game was here so you wouldn't have to play this. Don't torment yourself.

Story 1/10. Role Play -5/10. Gameplay 3/10. Game Design 1/10

Why do they even have ironman mode anymore? I haven't been able to finish any game on ironman for years, maybe even a decade now, They all have bugs that need constant saving because,inevitably, it will crash or freeze or glitch out in some manner that requires a previous save to restore. Every fuc king game I play in ironman s hits the bed at some point and leaves completion impossible. This game is no different. It's simply unplayable in ironman mode.

I wish I could recommend this game. There are decent levels and the level design can be good. There is some hilarious voice acting moments. The game feels like it is on the verge of potential. But most of the game is formulaic, and a lot of the interaction with the levels feels like busy work rather than playing a game, or solving puzzles, or getting over combat. The game trudges along until these pivotal moments that on the serve feel significant, but then it dawns on you: the writing is actually really, really bad, with many plot points undeveloped, unexplained, etc. There may be some great potential in this game with its DLCs and its sandbox components, but the main campaign (co-op took 35 hours with numerous crash bugs, in 2025) was lacking, to put it mildly.

Lost will to play mid base campaign because of de-synchronization bug: 
- friend bought gear in a store, equipped it - other players couldn't see it in his inventory (he wasn't the host for the session)
- game restart revealed that his character actually has no mentioned gear, yet money he spent are also not available anymore (so, he did spend it and got nothing)
- we had to reload much older save and redo all the steps, all the dialogs and we did manage to buy everything the same and there was no issue that time
...and then it happened again further in a campaign

There are a lot of minor inconveniences as well, but this de-synch issue is way to much...especially if you have to redo dialog all over the city because you realized there is an issue right when everyone were done with their preparations / quests and ready to depart from the town

DLC scum: $4 for the game, $20 for the fun.

The basic version you get on a sale has only half races and classes available. In a D&D game!
Wanna play as a bard, monk, druid, warlock or barbarian? Pay 5x of the price. That makes the game more expensive than Baldur's Gate 3! 
Do you guys really think that your junk worth more than Larian's masterpiece?

 Even without sales, the full version of Solasta is 50% more expensive than BG3. If you want full experience, without "blocked by DLC" icons all over the clunky UI, you'd have to pay as much as an AAA game.

The game itself is just an indie with awful UI, boring story and clunky controls.

the general low budget vibe was fine. The bad graphics, the questionable OST, the hilariously bad dub, the basic plot, the generic UI that doesn't tell you much about your spells or enemies etc - 
All of this is literally OK, because having a coop DnD game with 3 other friends every weekend is great.

But I draw the line at losing a coop campaign of multiple months to a bug that prevents main quest progression. Unplayable, inacceptable and downright awful.

However. i can not .and will never suggest purchasing this for one reason. DLC. yes they have other stories that cost. that is reasonable but locking many basic classes behind a pay wall is just fucked up. like really? i purchased the game and to be able to play a druid i must pay again???? this is just a poor poor move in marketing. plenty of other things they could have charged for( tho i say there is bassically 0 good reason for microtransactions litterally ever,excluding high quaility f2p games)  but basic classes. thats just down right trickery. i bought it. expecting to play druid.nope.locked behind pay wall. considering the game is just acceptable . this was just some bullshit. like i feel generous purchasing the game . your not getting more out of me just so i can play the class i expected to be included in a DnD based game. i pray solasta 2 is not this way. cause it would no longer be poor marketing but rather greedy

Not only are common (Player's Manual) races locked behind DLC, but so too are common classes. I bought this on sale and am definitely getting a refund. I don't care how cheap it is, that's revolting.

The voice acting, close-up 3D model cutscenes and writing are all kinda atrocious. 
Characters are ugly which would be fine if they weren't in close-up focus all the time, and 5 out of 12 classes are locked behind DLC (warlock, bard, monk, barbarian and druid).
Gameplay and exploration seemed okay, and the tutorials are helpful, but I was rather put off by the previous points and wasn't enjoying myself.

mechanics are decent as well as the armor and weapon models. the character models are bad and they could not be bothered to fix the visible gaps and seem in the shoulders.  the dialogue is poor and the characters come off as bickering jerks to me. I also ran into a few annoying scenarios that threw  my plan right out the window. trying to fight a vampire in the day time but when the battle starts it instantly switches to night time. or planning to ambush a group of enemies with a fireballs but the fireball does no damage because I pointless scripted event were the party talks and bickers a moment did not trigger. there are some good things here but a lot of this stuff is to much for me to really want to recommend it to anyone.

OMORI is my favourite game of all time, and I doubt this'll change.

I found OMORI in 2022 before it was taken off of XBOX, initially glancing over it at first, I decided to play it later on into the year. OMORI has easily been the most impactful piece of media to grace my life.

The story is incredible, easily the meatiest part of this story is locked behind a HUGE spoiler wall, which I won't go into to allow people to really sink their teeth into something they equally should and shouldn't...

OMORI's artstyle and soundtrack are both brilliant, both of which influencing my artwork and music tastes in their own beautiful ways. After getting a PC in July of 2025 I wanted to see this game again the most, and it was nowhere near as lacklustre. I'd argue it was better. The story doesn't erode, it grows on you and hits you REALLY hard regardless of how many times you brush the dust off of it's cover.

OMORI is, and likely always will be my favourite game of all time.

I haven't played any other game with a story as well executed as Omori the story isn't afraid to explore some dark topics but it ends up paying off and creating one of the most beautiful bittersweet moments in any game. Everyone I knew was convinced that my play-through of Omori would turn into a masochistic hate-play almost immediately. They were so sure of it that they made me record a voice memo promising I’d quit before the two-hour mark if I ended up hating it that much. When I finally launched the game, I wasn’t even allowed to do it alone. I had two people sitting beside me on the couch, ready to shut it down the moment I started complaining. Honestly, I’m surprised I managed to stick with it as long as I did.

Gameplay: fantastic, engaging loop that I found fun

Characters: 11/10 I love every single one of them they all have such unique personalities that fit seamlessly with the gameplay mechanics. The artstyle is so creatively directed and it brings such a charm to every single NPC and enemy in the game.

Music: Heat. It's banger after banger, many of the songs went into playlists after finishing the game.

Story (For 95% of the game): Great, fantastic, engaging, heartwrenching, a story of loss, friendship, love, grief, pain, joy, and forgiveness. 

Story (For the final 5% of playtime): Makes me more annoyed/frustrated the more I think about it. I don't want to get too much into spoilers, but the writers made a creative decision that undercuts the entire pathos of the story, subverts the themes of depressive masking and emotional shutdowns in a completely negative way, and (in my opinion) completely ruins any and all attachment and emotional connection developed with three of the six main characters.

The final like, HOUR of this game makes me never want to play it again and it makes it impossible for me to recommend someone play in good faith, I think if the "Twist" in the story never happened, and instead the writers just played the story straight with what they already had going on, the game would've been so, so, SO much better. As it is, I'm not going to recommend you complete this game, reader. It is such a creatively beautiful and heartwrenching game that shoots itself in the foot trying to include a "shocking twist" that completely ruins the story in retrospect RIGHT as its about to cross the finish line. 

That fact ruins it all the more for me.

Final Score: Dissapointment / 10
I wanted to like this game and I really liked a lot of it, but I had to drop it because the combat was just DREADFULLY boring. Story is incredible though. Don't get unless you really hate fun combat.

[h1]A Test of Patience, Not Enjoyment[/h1]

[b]Contains Major Spoilers[/b]

This was actually my third time starting Omori from the beginning. This time, I pushed myself to finish it because, honestly, I never would have completed it if it were not for my dear friend [URL=https://steamcommunity.com/id/sudowesu] Sudowesu [/URL] ❤️. He recommended Omori to me and guided me through the whole game. We finished it in about 30 hours, but if I had played alone, it would have easily taken 40 or 50. He is also a legend for translating Omori into Turkish!

[h3]Story[/h3]

The story is mostly filler. About 90 percent of the game is filler, and only 10 percent is real story or lore. And most of that story is told at the very end, where it feels rushed and weak. Omori has a promising story and decent characters, but it screws up everything with endless fetch quests, villains that have nothing to do with the story, mindless puzzles and combat, and countless huge walls of text that have nothing to do with the main plot. Most of the dialogue is full of meaningless sentences; actually, it is safe to say they are pointless monologues since Omori never speaks.

I spent about 25 hours of my playtime with random villains and characters rather than with my actual friends, both in gameplay and story sections. The friends you travel with are very one-dimensional. In the real-world sections, there is a little more bonding, but those parts are small, and even there, the game gives filler quests. This made me completely disconnect from a story I was curious about and emotionally invested in at the beginning. I mean, how was I supposed to care about the plot twist at the end if we never knew about the victim or their relationship with us? Showing 20-30 photos is not how you bond players with a group of characters, or a certain very important one, as a matter of fact. The plot twist also makes no sense at all for two 12 year olds to pull off.

[h3]Gameplay[/h3]

The gameplay is repetitive and never changes. There is an emotion system that sounds interesting, but it is almost never used. Every fight feels exactly the same. I went through the entire game with the same combo and strategy, and it always worked. Battles become boring very quickly.

The game also feels like it tries to waste your time. It reaches a new level of evil in game design. Omocat does literally everything she can to extend the game's duration artificially. I wanted to experience a refined, high-quality story, with fun gameplay but Omocat does not respect the player's time. I have a life, Omocat! I cannot spend 25 hours with your meaningless filler quests that I already forgot. A story that could have been told in 5 hours is stretched into over 30 hours in Omori. Undertale, To the Moon, or Finding Paradise tell amazing stories in less time, creating quality and fun narrative experiences. Even Undertale lasts about 8-10 hours at most, and that's a game that reinvents itself almost every battle. Both the storytelling and gameplay are worse in Omori, yet it lasts about 4 to 5 times longer. Why could Omori not do the same?

[h3]Visuals and Music[/h3]

The game has a beautiful hand-drawn art style, but it makes up only about 10 percent of the visuals. The rest is just decent pixel art, which looks good, but nothing extraordinary. The game is in 4:3 for whatever reason, which feels more annoying than stylish. The music is good. There are a handful of great tracks, but that's it.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

The most important question when reviewing any game is: "Is it fun?" For me, the answer is an easy no! And when a game is not fun, it should at least have an amazing story to keep me interested for 30 hours, or a good story for 5 to 10 hours. Omori has neither. It is a filler quest simulator. The game does everything possible to waste your time in every way. If you have a life, do not play this game. If this were a visual novel, it definitely could have been better. But as a JRPG, it fails in gameplay, story, and game design. 

I checked positive reviews to see why people liked it, and I still stand by my opinion. I also checked negative reviews, and I was not alone. Omori just wasted my time, and I could have been playing another game instead. These guys called "i omor" and PeppermintBee mostly summarized what I think about the plot twists and the story details, so make sure to check their reviews as well if you are interested.

dont get this game expecting a scary horror game its not that and honestly really isnt much of a psych horror story either. So i was dumbfounded at the start of the game, what it really is is a story of 4 friends adventuring and later dealing with real life problems and emotions which isnt bad. Once i thought of it that way I started enjoying it more. BUt yeah definitely not a horror game in the slightest, the scariest it gets is like?? Idek how to describe it, like sonic.exe cursed game creepy, but nothing that would legitimately creep out anyone over the age of 10. The only genuinely "horror" part of the game is at the start when you anwer your door and open it a crack, that part was peak and actually gave me a jump without being a jumpscare. If the game blended that stuff with the other emotional stuff at the end of the game for all 20 hours it would probably be my favorite game ive ever played. Which like I said, wasted potential. But ALL IN ALL for an indie game they hit it out of the park for all its issues, I hope one day maybe they give this the full metal alchemist brotherhood treatment and revise the story to be more focused and fun to playthrough or turn it into a manga. AS a game tho, peak 1% of the time, mid 49% of the time and the last 50 is garbage. The foundational story is peak, but brought down by fluff filler and random bs and teasing the truth. ALso for reasons that are spoilers a few characters are hard to empathize with because of the nature of the story another con. Last;y. theres a bunch of missable content and some of it you need to do specific things to access. Which I might play through but idk these first 25 hours were filling enough and Idk if I wanna play through more of the same to get to like maybe another 5-10 hours of extra content that wont change the story much. not countting the other 7 or so endings, so yeah lotta bang for your buck but theres so much fluff it might be more bang than youre looking for.

I feel like i am losing my mind. Genuinely feeling crazy seeing how much praise this game received vs how genuienly bad it is. I loved the Lisa games, Undertale, Yume Nikki, etc, so its not like im just a hater for this kind of game. This is just bad.

Nigh unplayable, it has pokemon combat, including a completely pointless "emotion" rock paper scissors mechanic that mimics the way pokemon types work. It even has dozens upon dozens of random combat encounters, except this is not pokemon and you dont capture anything, so they're just filler meant to slow you down and force you to interface with a boring and poorly baked combat system that shouldnt be there in the first place. After my first attempt, i got so exhausted i stopped playing, and when i came back just to try to experience the plot, i enabled cheats, and still took 13h to complete this.
You could also call all the headspace sections of the story pointless filler as well, since they take forever, are not particularly well written or endearing and do not progress the plot in any way. Tho ig that is a blessing in disguise because the plot feels like its competing with itself to see what levels of edgy it can reach without following any coherent sort of thematic throughline. No idea flows into each other and the plot twist is so ridiculous that it makes me question my sanity. This game has deeply twisted ideas about what kinds of actions can be resolved and forgiven by just "overcoming internal guilt" and "talking to your friends".

Bizarre experience. Cannot believe ppl speak abt this in the same light as the Lisa games.

That ending makes the game go from a gentle, emotional dialogue on mental health and depression, to a hyper-specific tragedy that no one can relate to anymore. I lost my emotional connection the moment we had the reveal, and just completely checked out for the last hour or two of the game. [b]Don't get me wrong[/b], I kind of enjoyed the game, especially the story and [b]probably only the story.[/b]

Gameplay is just... [i]unpolished?[/i] I mean I see that developers had some idea behind and it is not totally awful, but all gameplay mechanics are kinda boring or get stale very quickly.

The only thing that carried me through 21 hours of gameplay is the story.

But to be honest, it also have some problems, especially when you start thinking about [b]the ending[/b] and some staff that were left over with [b]no proper explanation[/b].

I cannot go into details since I don't want to spoil the main twist, so I will point out a different problem - the way developers tell you a story is so [b]time-consuming[/b].

There are so many fillers with absolutely [b]ZERO value to the plot[/b], especially when you get closer to the end – devs just started making any excuses just so you will spend more time in it.

I got the feeling and really believe that devs could just cut [b]almost half of the game[/b] and it would only [b]benefit the game.[/b]

But despite that, I got emotional at the end and [b]teared up[/b], so I gotta give devs credit for that - [b]story definitely can get to you[/b].

Overall, I just don't get why it is [b]so appraised[/b] since it's just an [i]okay game[/i], with a pretty much [b]fine story[/b], but [b]absolutely terrible gameplay.[/b]

I'm sorry this game is way too hard I have played many JRPGs over the years and I found chrono trigger to be a rage inducing mess at times, but at least that game had some sense of progression or progress. 

In this game, the second you get out of tutorial you go from tutorial enemies so easy you could give your arthritic 80 year old grandmother the keyboard and she'd have a good time playing it, to immedately being thrown enemies that do 15 damage to you when you only have 50HP. 

So you think "oh I should use my items." The problem is that the enemies in the vast forest give you next to no money or gold what so ever. I shouldn't even have to explain this, but in a normal RPG or JRPG you get curb stomped a bit, get some money for your troubles and then you buy more health potions and keep grinding until your the one doing the curb stomping. 

In this game, you level up and you don't feel like you do any more damage, you don't gain any money. And pretty soon you just want to give up. Top this off with no save points or rest areas and pretty soon your burned out. By the time I got to the second area, I was at this bridge and I walked across it and there was a globe and the game is like "its the earth, do you want to distrub it?" And I'm like "sure we're only three hours into the game, how bad could this go?" It did 50 damage and one shotted my party over and over again and again until I died. At this point I closed the game and uninstalled. 

Why would anyone in their right mind review this game positively? This is easily the most overated experience I have ever seen in a turn based RPG. It feels like the developer has never played a videogame ever and fails to understand basic concepts of game design. 

And yeah, maybe I'm supposed to be messing around with emotions more. But heres the thing, if I was actually using my skills, they cost so much MP that its absurd. The most basic abilities will cost 5mp, while an expensive skill will cost 13. You have around 20 to 40mp and again, its not like I can use juice boxes to restore my MP because enemies drop no freaking money. 

This is the worse RPG I have ever played. I can't think of one turn based RPG that was this bad. I paid money, I actually sat down and paid money for this.

I can't really understand why people like this so much.

It's pretty atmospheric, and Niko achieves the bare minimum of being a generally likable character.
The fourth wall is also broken in a cute and fascinating way.

But nothing else really drew me in. By the end of my playthrough, I didn't feel any strong emotional investment to the world or characters. After looking up some more info on the game, I learned that I have to go into my files and tweak some things in order to play through it again. But honestly, I don't feel any desire to. This game heavily relies on the player being invested enough to want to try to play through a second time. It's why they hammer it home so frequently that you only have one chance, and can only make one choice for the ending. But if the characters and world are dull and uninteresting, It's only natural to not want to bother. 

The game's "mission" was to make me care, and it only had one shot.
If your pc run on Mac, you cannot finish the game. Too bad for such a good game

I was really enjoying this game, but the Linux port is broken and under Proton-GE I hit a point where I couldn't progress any further. It's a shame, because there are so many great things to say about this game but I wasn't able to finish it.

The game authors made poor technical choices that were all but guaranteed to cause problems down the line. Worse, they are not really necessary from a narrative perspective and come across as a bit gimmicky.

Anyway, I don't want to hate on the game too much because it is really nice in so many ways but I have to leave a negative review to warn people about potential technical issues. I have seen reports of these occurring on Windows as well. So just be aware.

So I know people in the Cult of Niko, and they may jump me for saying this. 
I have played the game about as blind as one can, only knowing it has Niko, a dead world, and fourth wall screwery where it messes with your computer.
This game is trying its best to be a great game, and it has a lot of passion put into it.
It's not that good.
No aspect of the game is nearly as good as it should be to get the following it has.
In order of best to worst, the art direction. It's pretty good, actually. The environments are all neat, and there's a lot of cute scenes. Every character is adorable. Not much else to say.
Next, the music. Some people really like it. It was kind of repetitive after awhile, and I wouldn't listen to it casually, but it was ok.
I'll put gameplay here, despite it being the worst element, because this is something you should go into knowing it's not about the gameplay. It says it's a puzzle game, but it should be treated more like a visual novel. Most of the time, gameplay is walking around, picking up stuff, and combining it. Nothing crazy, but it's also all you do. The only puzzles I remember, I remember because they have an achievement attached to them. If you're impatient, you will be bored out of your mind. If you're even reading this, that shouldn't be a problem.


Spoilers for the narrative. If you ignore this review and play the game, don't read it. Even minor spoilers massively hurt this game due to its narrative focus, and as I see it it's already lacking enough.
[spoiler]I was going to write a whole essay, multiple paragraphs worth, about how I didn't find the characters interesting and how the narrative hinges on the characters being treated as people, with a whole breakdown on each main character and how they have very little to them, but frankly I am not a good enough writer to properly summarize all of that, so you're getting a shortened version. Still decently long though.[/spoiler]
[spoiler]The story and characters aren't very good. At the very least, none of it stuck out to me. Maybe this is because I already engage with a lot of media that has similar narrative and meta-narrative themes and ideas (which I think execute them better), like Undertale, Deltarune, Homestuck, Metal Gear Solid, or hell even Toy Story (I'm serious) but it just didn't really resonate with me. There's a lot of characters introduced, and only two of them are given any significant development. Every other character feels like the same kind of "quirky pixel art indie rpg about depression" writing (wonder why), so while some moments got some emotion out of me, it was very minor at best. Niko's character is basically that they are in over their head, and really should not be here, but will strive to help the world regardless because they grew attached to it and the people in it. This sounds nice, but this brief summary isn't abridging much, and that's kind of their character the whole time, with wavering levels of commitment. I can't talk about the main antagonist without massive spoilers, but I can say that they have the only intended emotional moment I actually responded to. Every other character is one note and forgettable. The lore is also very empty, though I may think this because I'm spoiled by lore heavy games and media. Unfortunately I can't expound on that without game ruining spoilers.[/spoiler]


In summary, this game is really mediocre. I can only recommend it if you want to understand references made by the Cult of Niko. It's possible I just didn't understand the story and characters, or that I just don't vibe with the story, but considering that games with similar themes and ideas end up as some of my favorites (Deltrarune being the biggest example) I rather doubt that.

TL;DR:
❌ Not recommended, despite strong artistic intent.
✔️ Worth experiencing for indie fans and Niko enjoyers.
💔 Beautiful concept, lovable protagonist, but ultimately shallow gameplay and underdeveloped world.

Well, that will be a very painful negative review, that's for sure. 

If for every time I've played a game with a good concept but a bad game itself I had a dollar, I could probably afford a fancy cappuccino, but that's not the point. The point is, I, despite the negative review, would still recommend playing it for every indie enjoyer, just because it is already an established part of the modern «indie game as an art» paradigm, and I'm all in for it. First off, I absolutely adore Niko. I'm pretty sure that the entire game started from his art and a couple of concepts from the late game, just because they are the most striking parts. Second of all, you [i]can[/i] feel the developer's passion in it. And, sadly enough, that's about it.

Truth be told, I was pretty sure for, like, 85% of the playthrough that I would give this a thumbs up with several pages of «but»s. But (sorry for the «but» overload) it wasn't meant to be. After the playthrough and a thorough discussion with my wife that gave it the first oneshot™, I realized that I just can't. 

The main point is, as rough as it sounds, the developers fell short in almost every aspect of the game beyond the initial design document. 

The protagonist is adorable and sensitive, but he has no space for development. Yeah, he's a nice little boy, he loves his momma and her pancakes, and then… there's nothing. 

The world is pretty original, but it's just empty. About 80% of locations feel just incomplete, with the main gameplay loop feeling like wandering through the identical locations trying to identify which of the same ladders and passages were not explored yet. 

The NPCs are well-written, but their plots are disappointingly narrow and shallow. Come on, if I can't even interact a certain item with a certain NPC not for the purpose of progress but for the sheer lore, then how can I believe in the liveliness of the world? 

And the fourth-wall breaking? Yes, that’s what the game is all about, but it still manages to feel bland—Niko’s lines being the one clear exception. He’s the heart and soul of the experience.

The «point-and-click» aspect? This is a textbook example of «How to build a very easy "Find necessary items" game 101». Still, at the same time, it has some problems articulating the path to progress. This game is notably trying to be an easy game with a tough experience, but it somehow fails at both.

I'm aware that Oneshot is one of the first games to truly explore the «playing outside the game itself» concept, and it probably inspired a lot of great creators of such games. But aside from being a pioneer, Oneshot for me just can't find its place between just a good «digital fantasy» game and an experimental one and it is so sad. Because I can truly imagine the moment of revelation when developers had arts and concepts on their hands and were like «Okay, we are one step away from the masterpiece».

For me, the masterpiece never happened. But the game still earned a place in people’s hearts.

That wasn’t enough to make it great. But still—despite all of this—you’ve got another member of the Niko Enjoyers Club. I sincerely hope we do see the masterpiece one day.

just boring; terrible world design.

it's certainly cute and ahead of its time (remember the original was from 2014) but the gimmick is severely underused and simply won't work well on some computers. In my case, the ______,exe didn't work as intended so I had to start a new instance in every room. DDLC+ treatment is nice for accessability here, but also takes from the Experience. (not to mention the paths will change drastically from PC to PC, mine were hidden in three different folders - Documents (which I don't even use), %APPDATA% (which was a hunch) and the steamapp commons. Made me delete the wrong savefiles in different combinations for at least 30 minutes. 
The story itself is fine. It's very predictable, this also goes for the gameplay where you simply can do no wrong in the puzzle sections, and if you miss a part of the map you'll run around like a freak clicking tiles. 
The seed couldn't be picked up in my case which was kinda weird but I let it pass, later I read apparently it's quite important for an ending. Uh, cool?
There is little interaction with the player at all, you don't have many choices. There is no fail condition. The original had that going for it, that you basically have to clear it in one go so it had to be simple. At this point, write a sequel or a spin-off, seriously. 
All in all it's a neat little walking simulator (nothing more, really) but I won't recommend it because it was advertised to me by some crazy people saying it would be another Undertale or DDLC, which both of those it absolutely failed to deliver. 
Also, most of the goddamn lore in the game is ultimately useless. There is zero reason to learn about all the different phosphors and creatures, behind many items I suspected branching paths or different outcomes only to get nothing. Nothing is optional except the goddamn seed. So your one shot ultimately boils down to "do you trust the machine or not", with the rest of the game being fluff.

The game relies on having an emotional connection to the characters, and I'm one of 5 people who didn't really have an emotional connection with the playable character but was curious enough to complete the game's true ending. Though it was more one part curiosity with the plot, two parts sense of obligation to finish the games I pay for. 

As for the game itself, it's an RPGMaker game with puzzles that break the 4th wall. There were a few neat ideas with the puzzles, but the point of the game is more the story. If the writing doesn't click for you early on, I wouldn't recommend sticking with it.

I love this game i really do. But strongly go against buying this game if you are on Linux. The game was built for windows operating systems in mind. You can brute force your way through half the game using Wine and Bottles to open .exe files that can't be accessed on Linux but at some point those systems fail and you hit a brick wall that you can't bypass without changing the games code. This happened to me when I got to the tower and the game wanted me to open that clover file whilst playing the game, I ran the file through Wine and it opened but the game didn't recognise that it was open so it just closed again. I don't blame anyone expect the developers for this over sight. They could have just added a skip button that bypassed those scripted scenes but alas the game is unplayable on Linux.

I originally was interested in this game as I heard many great things about it and after playing well... I don't think it holds up. 

The main issue I have is the gameplay. Almost everything is region locked, ie you can only get certain achievements in certain areas and there is no way to go back. Also there is so much moving around that it becomes quite tedious with puzzles. Speaking of tedious lets talk about the endings. Now I haven't done solstice yet however I don't plan to. The issue is going out of the game into your files for important info. Also in order to restart at any time for a run you need to start from the very beginning, which is just mind numbing and a waste of time. And also, the tower was never explained (you have to exit the game and boot it up again) and if you need to look at a outside guide to beat a puzzle, then frankly it isn't inituive and not a good puzzle game. 

The final issue is the whole taking over your wallpaper and documents. Wow a fourth wall break how quirky. Oh look I hijacked your wallpaper, which can be invalidated by fullscreen or wallpaper engine forcing you to look up the puzzle, which isn't ideal for a puzzle game, they should be intuive. Also having to dig through my files just to find a password gets annoying. 

So overall, I just found this game tedious and also for a game called oneshot you can actually play as much as you want, not even oneshot.

The game and its idea are great, but it doesn't work on Linux properly. Unlike Windows, Linux environments can vary greatly. [spoiler]When it "cleverly" modifies files on your system, it should do so in a way that always works, for instance by using available system facilities.[/spoiler] On my machine, the ending, for instance, simply does not (cannot) work. [spoiler]I managed to find out what was supposed to happen in some cases that didn't work, and thus managed to arrive at the ending, but there, I'm stuck, b/c the program it tries to run fails with various errors. I fixed one of them (broken librt), but didn't bother with the remainder of the error messages.[/spoiler] Also, [spoiler]some of the puzzles aren't thought out properly, so you can get stuck in some situations, where you don't have the necessary items anymore.[/spoiler] So, to me, the game is partially broken. Don't play this on Linux.

Love how this game gets you to think about the way consciousness works, the value of life, and whether a situation is deemed to be better than death.
Spoilers for the themes and an integral twist in the game: [spoiler]"Native Americans used to think photographs would steal your soul." It's not a cut and paste, it's a copy and paste. Would I create a copy of myself to live a better life? Yes. Would it really fucking suck to continue being the doomed version? Very much so, but it would make me feel better that there's a version of me out there that's getting another chance. I've always been a big supporter of the idea of transferring one's consciousness to a mechanical or virtual form in order to evade death, I just usually think of it as a transfer rather than a copy. That might just be idealistic thinking though due to the disconnect between biology and what might be capable with technology.[/spoiler]
Love this game. Top tier story, walking simulator gameplay (I turned off the ability to die but the horror scenes felt just as tense, just less annoying. Hope this studio makes another game build on an idea with the same vibe as this, rather than another Amnesia sequel. 8.5/10

Ok, hear me out.

> This is, without a doubt, the best horror game I have ever experienced in my entire life. <

-I went in knowing absolutely nothing. My brother just told me, “You HAVE to play this one because it's a MUST.” (He already went through this one before me) So I thought, “Why not give it a try”

And oh dear Lord… I was left speechless.


-During the first hour I was simply curious — “Let’s see what this is about.” But somewhere around the second hour, I realized this wasn’t just a game and I had no idea what was coming for me.
Part of me wanted to stop, because I felt so uneasy… but the more I pushed forward, the more the world swallowed me whole. The level design, the atmosphere, the dialogues, the way the characters are build, and—OH GOD—the way that the story is written.... It isn’t just good. It’s a masterpiece.

>  (Honestly, I wish I could buy the entire story as a book. I’d read it a hundred times.)  <

-This is the kind of game where you don’t want to skip anything. I wanted answers—what happened to the characters, what happened to humanity, what happened to the world… and why I was at the bottom of the ocean. My mind was overflowing with questions I desperately needed answered.

-And the way the story reveals itself…
It gives you nothing at the beginning. It throws you, confused and helpless, into one of the biggest underwater facilities right after that brain scan, and you’re forced to piece everything together on your own.
When it all finally started to make sense… I genuinely had goosebumps.

-And then… The fact that you are able to see the other Simon… the shivers I felt down my spine…



-But that ending…



-The emptiness that washed over me… the hollow, sinking feeling in my chest…
It left me numb in a way I didn’t expect. I just sat there, staring at the screen, trying to process everything..


And Simon..

I hope you’ll be safe down there... alone...
