SOMA is the one of the most fascinating games I've ever played. [spoiler] The enemy A.I. is a giant step-up from Amnesia's with intricacies that one doesn't usually notice right away (Akers is attracted by sound, Yoshida doesn't see as well if you turn the lights in a room off) that enhances the fear factor and sense of paranoia immensely (some of the monsters being able to open doors is really novel design choice) with movement, sound design, and behavior of the Yoshida especially making it the scariest encounter within the entire game. The only real *thing* I would confidently say is a flaw with the encounter design is that the Proxy opening doors without any appendages doesn't make any sense. The gameplay in general is a more refined iteration of the gameplay style Frictional is known for but without Dark Descent's inventory management, but I think its exclusion here is more justified than A Machine for Pigs because a sanity system wouldn't make much sense within the context of the setting, and you shouldn't need to refill your light vessel when the flashlight is literally a part of your body whereas your lantern in Pigs can be just be on forever (as long as you don't flash it on enemies, but they sometimes see you regardless so shrug), which also made the detail of your light flashing when enemies are nearby made more sense as a design choice here compared to Pigs since it's not a 1800s lantern, it's a part of a 22nd century cyborg body. The only real annoyance I have with the gameplay is the scuba-diving sections (after K8's gone), where it can get pretty irritating to navigate through the map while your flashlight is too dim enough to be useful in many occasions. The epitome of this is the leviathan with it grabbing me having to require me to recalibrate where I was at. What the gameplay lacks in mechanical complexity, it makes up for with immersing you into Pathos-II and the stories within it, with the game also taking advantage of the interactivity of the medium in not only what choices you make and to what degree it changes particular scenes (which, along with it's length, boosts replayability value) but allows the player to piece together what happened with each and every area (seeing Brandon Wan's corpse right after I killed a brain scan of him particularly stands out to me). [/spoiler]

Similarly, the narrative is some of the most compelling I've come across, [spoiler] straight from the core premise alone (these thoughts aren't as organized). Having Simon using his blackbox to hear the last moments of most of the crew within Pathos-II is fucking harrowing and is disturbing for both the player and Simon, yet it only reinforces Simon's optimism in the ARK rather than driving him to doom-and-gloom until both after he kills a copy of himself and that heartbreaking last scene. Sarah Lindwall's last scene is really great with it being in one respect the hardest while also one of the easier choices to make in the game, with her *wanting* to die making killing her more poignant as the last breath of humans emphasizing their capacity of choice. The choice of to kill the Simon in Omicron is beautifully built up, and I lost my shit over making such a morally complex choice. Catherine's roof speech is a banger scene with it masterfully captures the beauty and comfortability of nostalgia and how to live on when everything you know is long gone, which I'd imagine will only resonant more with age, all the more complemented by the haunting score. The WAU is fascinating to think about in how it is functionally similar to the ARK, yet it's a machine's attempt at it rather than man's, but it *seems* for the WAU's victims involved, they can be living a good *version* of their past life, like we briefly saw with Simon with Amy, and that makes the decision at the end to either eliminate the WAU or leave a fascinating choice to think about. [/spoiler] I'm going to be thinking about this game for a *long* time to come and will definitely be replaying it in the near future.

[h1]What Makes Someone “Human”?[/h1]

[i]From the creators of Amnesia: The Dark Descent comes SOMA, a sci-fi horror game set below the waves of the Atlantic ocean. Struggle to survive a hostile world that will make you question your very existence.[/i]

[h2]Story[/h2]
In SOMA, you play as Simon Jarrett, who wakes up in a mysterious underwater research facility called PATHOS-II after a traumatic accident in his past. As Simon explores the decaying, abandoned facility, he discovers that an experiment to preserve human consciousness has gone horribly wrong, leaving the station populated by strange, hostile creatures and sentient machines. Simon gradually uncovers the fate of the facility’s staff and the ethical dilemmas surrounding identity, consciousness, and what it truly means to be human.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
SOMA is a first-person survival horror game. SOMA builds on the gameplay style of previous Frictional Games titles, like Amnesia: The Dark Descent, focusing on stealth, puzzle-solving, and immersion. Unlike earlier games, it downplays inventory management to put more emphasis on story and character development.

Players encounter a variety of creatures, each tied to the game’s themes, and must sneak, hide, or outrun them since there are no weapons to fight back. The game also provides a wealth of clues, such as notes and audio recordings, to build atmosphere and explain the story. Progress is made through exploration, puzzle-solving, and careful evasion, but failure to avoid monsters can lead to death.

[h2]Enemies & Bosses[/h2]
The enemies in SOMA include WAU-corrupted scientists and researchers, malfunctioning robots at PATHOS-II, and terrifying deep-sea creatures lurking in the Abyss. You’ll face a variety of foes, from slow or blind enemies to giant aquatic monsters. Unlike many games, SOMA doesn’t have traditional boss fights, keeping the focus on constant tension and survival rather than epic showdowns.

[h2]Environment & Scares[/h2]
The game is set in underwater research facility PATHOS-II in the late 21st century. The facility has fallen into disrepair after a catastrophic event. The stations are mostly linear, but occasionally you venture outside and traverse the ocean floor, which offers larger, more open areas. The environment is filled with computers and recordings that reveal a wealth of lore.

The horror is psychological and atmospheric rather than relying on constant jump scares. The setting—a decaying, flooded underwater facility—creates a sense of isolation and dread; it’s only you and the monsters. Encounters with enemies are tense because you are physically weak, and threats are often sudden or ambiguous.

[h2]Visual Design & Sound Design[/h2]
The game is undeniably beautiful. The underwater station’s design combines realistic industrial architecture—metal walkways, pipes, control panels—with derelict, decaying areas. Water damage, corrosion, and dim lighting make the environment feel abandoned and unsafe. Walking on the dark ocean floor amplifies the sense of isolation. Underwater, sounds are muffled, with the soft bubbling of water, and distant objects appear increasingly blurred, enhancing the eerie atmosphere.

Monsters are organic-mechanical hybrids with disturbing, asymmetrical forms that evoke both fear and pity. AI-controlled robots have humanoid shapes but uncanny movements, highlighting the game’s themes of consciousness and identity. The screen becomes distorted when you look at enemies, and the effect intensifies the closer they get.

[h2]Constructive Criticism[/h2]
I was a bit disappointed by the blind enemy’s AI. I tried throwing objects to lure it away, but it didn’t respond to the sounds at all.

While SOMA is a great game with clever puzzles, I couldn’t help but feel that there were perhaps too many of them, particularly those presented on computer screens.

I would have liked more gameplay mechanics, such as inventory management—similar to how Amnesia: The Dark Descent requires you to manage oil for your lantern.

[h2]The Verdict[/h2]
The best part about SOMA is the story, characters, and the philosophical questions it raises, like: What makes someone “human”? Can consciousness exist independently of the body? Are copies of a person’s mind still the same person? The narrative explores identity, consciousness, and what it means to be human. A central theme is whether consciousness can survive the death of the body, and the moral implications of transferring minds to machines. It’s a hell of a story, especially if you take your time, read the notes, listen to audio recordings, and just immerse yourself fully in the story and atmosphere. It’s so thought-provoking.

The horror and atmosphere are well-crafted, with disturbing monsters, but the environment, sense of isolation, and core themes of the game are often even more terrifying than the creatures themselves.

SOMA is an amazing game, no question, but the abundance of puzzles became a bit overwhelming for my taste. Combined with the occasional shortcomings of the enemy AI and the limited gameplay mechanics, these factors lowered the game’s rating for me.

[h2]Rating: 8/10[/h2]
One of the best narratives in horror gaming. Hard hitting, poignant and thought provoking in so many ways.
The deep sea is scary enough but this game gave me legitimate jumpscares plus an existential crisis. I also cried 11/10

one of the best horror walking sims whatever you call this genre. compared to the amnesia games its more story driven and fewer potential deadly encounters (except for a machine for pigs, which doesn't count as an amnesia game anyway and only has three enemies) but there are enough crucial moments where you need to quickly decide if you have to hide or run (or just immediately die so that you are not so skerred anymore) -  but the story elements are wonderful especially since so much is just experienced through game play rather than only being delivered by text dumps (but there's plenty of that in there to fill in the backstory), the themes and such in the story (identity, survival, etc.) were more real and visceral than what you usually get in horror games. i played with a friend (via streaming) and our incessesant speculation about what was going on and what would happen next (almost entirely wrong) made it much more engaging. also we thought the ending was presented badly then we decided no it was good actually, so there's that.

Best game ever, you won't regret it. I have anxiety when playing horror games when it's in first person, so I am so pleased to inform others there's a safe mode so you won't die by creatures making it a lot easier for me to play. I couldn't continue alien isolation because of my condition so I'm glad I was actually able to play through and enjoy the game. I wish there had been more direction, mostly like an objective in the corner because I could never remember what to do, otherwise this game was solid. If you love to be confused and enjoy a good story line, this is the game for you. I could never piece the game together fully until i got close to the end. It made me want to play all the more for a clear understanding. It was an amazing game and the details were awesome. The graphics and the story worked together wonderfully, making it more and more confusing, which was exciting for me. Loved it, took me 3 days to complete it kept me guessing and on my toes. Buy the game, it was worth every cent. Worth replaying just for the atmosphere alone, and of course I loved the story.

This time they overdid the puzzles in my opinion, was in a part where i had a hard time solving a puzzle on my own and it took a long time, when i finally solved it i walked for a while before reaching another puzzle, then i uninstalled.

Edit: After seeing the reaction some fans of the game gave to my review i decided to expand on my review.

First of all i tried to play and finish this game thrice, in my first try i went until our protagonist went into ocean floor and i got annoyed at how slow it made me move when i attempted to solve the underwater puzzle, while i was busy solving it i made a effort/reward calculation in my mind and decided to alt f4 since neither the plot, puzzles, characters, horror sections made it seem worth it.

After a few years i wondered if i was too harsh on the game and decided to give it a try once again restarting and deciding to be more patient this time, this time i lasted until another puzzle where i had to gain information from a guy stuck in a simulation, by changing enviorenments and voices. I got stuck in this puzzle got annoyed uninstalled, then decided to reinstall and decided to brute force it and i hated the solution.

After this part i said to myself 'Glad im done with this puzzle, now game will probably reward me with some horror sections or plot to reward me and i will be safe from puzzles for a while.' Well nope i walked less than a minute and there it is, another ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ puzzle without any meaningful reward for my time.

I didn't get this game on the promises of it being a walking sim with constant boring and annoying puzzles that makes your game longer, i got it for the promises of a revolutinary sci-fi horror story. Now i will continue why it didn't deliver for me starting with horror:

-They made the enviorenment of the game take place under the ocean where some sites are connected with each other and it takes place approximately one hundred years later and they somehow managed to not make it scary in a horror sense, no really imagine this i suffer from megalophobia, thalassophobia, Megalohydrothalassophobia so practically the whole package but only fear i felt was game forcing me to take another detour to reach my objective(A mistake Alien Isolation also did) or getting bombarded with another puzzle. Monsters/enemies aren't scary, they are very slow and annoying most of the time, acting as speed bumps.

Now lets compare them with amnesia the dark descent, outlast and alien isolation.

-In amnesia dark descent, enemies arent scary physically but the buildup to them(house shaking, noises they make) how they feel like an unstoppable force once they notice you and how they throw furniture away from the force of their charge once they notice you, the fact that you aren't supposed to look at them makes them scary.
-In outlast the soundtrack when you are getting hunted, heavy breathing of chris walker, his chains, his large frame and speed, Trager's speed and the fact that you can't escape him stealthily so getting chased by him is unavoidable, everything about Eddie Gluskin makes the game scary.
-In alien Isolation the fact that xenemorph has a skill tree, and adapts to your playstyle to hunt you down makes it scary.

Soma's enemies are not scary, just boring bland and unimaginative speed bumps attempting to slow your progress down nothing more.

Now 'revolutionary sci-fi story aspect'. This dissapointed me too, this is highly objective and depending on the person but personally i don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about the question of what is a human? Or what is conciousness? Is your amputated grandpa still human? What if we give him a plastic prosthetic? What if we make his whole arm cybernetic? What if we completely equip him with cybernetics and make him a cyborg? What if we upload his conciousness into a toaster or vacuum cleaner? Got bored with my questions? Good now you know how i feel towards philosophical questions like this. Will reaching a satisfactory answer about these questions give your life any more meaning? Will it make your life more benefical and enjoyable? Personally i don't think so. Continue working at your 9 to 5, flipping burgers, continue trying to find your soul mate despite the fact that you are pushing 40 or continue living under your parents until you reach there.

Another reason is sci-fi might be my most read genre in books and i read asimov, dan simmons, cixin liu, Expanse series, richard morgan, stanislaw lem etc. where concepts they came up with terrified me even more than this game despite them not trying at all.

For example: gradually noticing the planet you are on is alive like you, finding an abandoned spaceship on a never before explored planet during an emergency stop, humans colonizing different planets literally becoming aliens due to difference in their planets and their customs and laws, finding a planet inhabited by something completely different than humans and aliens we dreamed of, whole hyperion storyline, dark forest theory, richard morgan's sleeve concept and how hypothetically Putin, Epstein, Clintons, Trump etc. can become immortal by transferring their conciousness into other peoples bodies repeadetly and the fact that in the future capitalist world how the rich can even steal your body for themselves legally and illegally and how you are powerless to stop it etc.

I might have been amazed by soma's story if i didn't see stories similar to it and done better before, and it's not a bad story don't get me wrong, in fact i might have liked it more if they ramped up the horror aspect more and made playing the game more enjoyable, but they didn't so i didn't enjoy soma. It's fine if you enjoyed it, im not claiming my opinion is the objective truth like others, but claiming my review is funny or wrong because i didn't enjoy a game with mid plot with terrible gameplay revolutionary annoys me very much. You mfs remind me of kids who acted deep and mature because they blasted bohemian rhapsody and paint it black every chance they got in high school and felt superior because they didn't enjoy modern music like other normies.

Another complaint is Simon is very annoying and stupid (or maybe delusional not wanting to accept reality), probably intentionally since he is suffering from brain damage, not seeing what is in front of him the whole game. Or they made sure to hammer in the plot continously so that players can understand the story. Probably both.

And if i was in a situation like Simon i would be more focused on the fact that im completely stranded alone without any means of entertainment to pass the time rather than getting philosophical and argue with a person who suffers from the same problem as me.

The game asks some deep questions, such as "What does it mean if we interrupt game flow with constant search-your-way-in-the dark sections while providing zero clues on where to go?". Well actually the answer is pretty easy - it means you're ruining an interesting story with terrible level design.
Love getting stuck for over an hour in 1 spot unable to progress, great design

Boring. I am writing this 10 years after the game came out, with no prior expectations. Soma is a relic of its time; terrible writing, some sci fi themes that have been thoroughly explored in other media and severely lacking gameplay. There is no combat to speak off, and arguably worse no stealth tools. You can only really crouch or run to avoid enemies which just makes it supremely boring to play.

Hot garbage with a mandatory 60fps lock that can't be changed. The game says it's at 165hz but it simply isn't. Unacceptable, even for the time when the game came out. Renders the game unplayable on modern systems in 2025 unless you like looking at blurry smeary shit.

This game is very much  a mixed bag.
I'd say the strengths of this game are the atmosphere and design, the weaknesses navigation and, possibly controversial, the story. I have seen people praising this game for its story and saying they can't stop thinking about it and its ending. Well, for me, the idea is there but the story fell pretty flat and it didn't really impact me. Maybe also because I didn't find Simon enough of a convincing/interesting protagonist.
For me the game was picking up once you get to Theta and you encounter more enemies. But until then there was a lot of just walking around, not really knowing where to go and what to do and this was kind of frustrating and not very fun to play.  I guess it fits the theme of Simon waking up and being a bit lost but I almost quit the game because of it. That being said it is mainly a walking simulator with having to get random items and sections of hiding/running from/sneaking around monsters. One thing I liked about that is that you had to approach each monster with a different tactic.
Regarding the ending: [spoiler] I wish there was an option not to launch the ARK, just shut down the WAU and that's it because I'm not convinced it was the right decision. Sure, "humanity" lives on but actually you are just brain scans on a harddrive floating in space. I wouldn't call that living. I wish there was an option that if you stop the WAU and everything just shuts down. Roll the end credits [/spoiler]
7.8/10 too much water -IGN

I played this game checking every corner and interacting with everything possible to get the most out of the story. But it's just... weak? Like I get it, there is some interesting concepts down there but they aren't really used much. Am I supposed to enjoy spending ~8h walking a linear path and hiding from monsters due to couple interesting revelations in the story?

The game is advertised as a horror game but it has no horror elements. The most stressful part of the game was thinking how long it's going to take for some of walks to end so we could get to the next part of the game. The game is indeed atmospheric, the sounds and the environment gives you this deserted, scary place vibes but you have barely any agency against the monsters so that's kinda boring.

There are some enemies in the game that you can't interact with besides throwing things at them to gain their attention. They are just there for the atmosphere and horror but they were more frustrating than enjoyable because it did nothing but slow down the gameplay unnecessarily by forcing me to crawl, not run and WAIT for the monster to walk so I can go through where its blocking.

The *optional* lore bits you can access by interacting with data boxes or dead people slows down the game, forces you to stay close by (else they get canceled) and listen at the speed of them talking. You can't read or skip to next sentence at your own pace. You can do a lot of the unskippable dialogue while walking around and exploring but the game punishes you for daring to explore side content.

The core story concept is very cool and I would like to see a proper book or a movie around it. But this game isn't it. It's not worth the amount of walking. This game disrespects your time. I expected a powerful narrative from this game but I couldn't find it. The philosophical aspect of the game can be summed up into couple sentences and don't need all the 'backstory' bits the game throws at you. You don't really immerse into any of the characters, they are just another hook that are not explored enough. 

If you are into a walking simulator with scary elements and enough for the characters and the story to stay at the level of shallow plot hooks to connect areas and missions you move between and not expect real depth of story then you would enjoy it way more than me. If you expect a powerful story that will leave you awestruck after you finish the game, this isn't it.

The atmosphere is amazing, with great visuals and a truly excellent soundscape, the story is interesting but the gameplay just sucks at a few points which really brings this down.

Its a walking simulator where you have to spend ages waiting on the other side of a door as a monster goes past, to run out and grab some stupid component to solve a "puzzle", rinse and repeat.

The first few times are honestly very tense and scary....but then it just becomes dull.

When you stop being scared of the monster and wish it would just hurry up and move because you've got sh*t to do, the horror aspect is well and truly gone, and the game loses all interest.

What makes it worse is that the game makes no effort to explain what you're supposed to do or why, not even offering hints or enviromental cues as many games of this sort do - at one point I couldn't figure out why a vehicle wasn't moving given I'd gotten the power on, got the access codes, turned everything on and wanted to leave.

Turns out I had to sit in the command chair and that only then would a hidden screen pop down from the roof and allow me to leave.

This isn't a big deal on its own, but there's just so many of these annoying little issues that ruin the flow of the game and force you to waste 5 or 10 minutes being annoyed and trying to figure out how to progress and these completely trash the immersion, which is otherwise excellent, and really the best part of the game by far.

I feel like the developers should have just made a movie - it would have been a great horror film instead of a mediocre game.

Edit: I eventually used a walkthrough to help me skip the annoying 'wandering around figuring out what to do' problem, and then I had a much better time, and overall enjoyed the game (I'me leaving the review negative just because I feel I really shouldn't have needed to do this to enjoy the game).

⭐ Devour – The Best Co-Op Horror Experience Out There ⭐

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Devour is easily one of the best co-op horror games I’ve played. The tension, atmosphere, and unpredictable gameplay keep you on edge from start to finish. Every map feels unique, every run feels different, and the jump scares never get old — even when you think you’re ready.

The game rewards teamwork, communication, and strategy. When things go wrong (and they will), the chaos is actually the fun part. Whether you’re running from demons, collecting objectives, or reviving teammates in panic, the adrenaline rush is unmatched.

The developers keep the game fresh with updates, new maps, and challenges, making it a title you can return to again and again. Smooth performance, creepy sound design, and smart difficulty scaling make Devour stand out from other indie horror games.

If you enjoy horror, teamwork, and intense moments that make your heart race, Devour is absolutely the best co-op horror game to pick up.

Highly recommended.
Over the years I had many fun and exciting moments playing this game with friends, we're still getting together whenever a new map releases. Certainly recommend it if you have someone to play with.

Firstly, this game isn't the smoothest. Interact prompts can be weird, the map balance is off, and some animations are pretty cheesy and rigid. However I am surprised at the variety in this game. You look at this game and think, "So I do this one thing over and over with new coats of paint?" Well, no. Weirdly enough while the goal and basic, Find X and use on specific spot 10 times never changes, but the "how to" changes and it can get pretty enjoyable. 
The maps are really fun and different. The maps shift from open to tight hallways really well. There is also really fun spots to jump railings and evade the monster. The maps are also really well designed and I like how not one map looks or feels like another.
Solid multiplayer game, play it with your friends for a fun time.

Devour tries to present itself as a horror game, but in reality, it feels much more like a task-based challenge than a genuinely scary experience. The premise is intriguing: a group of players trying to stop a demonic cult while being hunted by a possessed entity, but the supposed horror quickly fades once you realize most of the game revolves around completing objectives and managing resources efficiently.

For the majority of the time, you’re not scared: you’re busy collecting items, burning or purifying objects, and coordinating with teammates. The gameplay focuses heavily on timing, organization, and communication rather than actual fear or atmosphere. Jump scares do happen, but they quickly lose impact once you understand that everything follows a predictable pattern.

After a few rounds, the game’s formula becomes painfully repetitive. The entity stops being terrifying and instead turns into an annoying obstacle disrupting your checklist. Devour might offer brief moments of tension or adrenaline, but it’s far from what you’d expect from a true horror experience. In the end, it’s a game that demands tryharding more than courage, and once the illusion of fear fades, what remains is a repetitive, mechanical loop with little to no genuine terror.

TL;DR
At the current state of the game, I would say it's a good game, but it's really not balanced at all..
(And the gameplay loop feels really repetitive after a short time.)

---

Maybe it's balanced for 4 player rounds, but like 2-player rounds are not fun as all after 6/7 sacrifices..

On "Normal", which should be the middle (but atm it feels like "hard"), there are way too many mobs spawning, which costs too much UV flashlight, so you often can't save yourself.
Also, the possessed person of the map is too "aggressive" on normal mode.
Like, after 2-3 sacrifices they already need to be flashed 2-3 times.. so its basically just running away, waiting for the red eyes to fade away, flashing them again and hoping to not run into several minions, which is nearly impossible after 6/7+ sacrifices.

The game needs to be tuned down in those terms to be fun for solo or duo play.

I really like the idea of the game, and that the gameplay is slightly different per map, but atm I can't recommend the game for solo players or if you plan on playing with one friend.
Not everyone plans on playing always with 2-3 other friends, so I hope the game will be more balanced for solo and duo rounds at some point and maybe the gameplay will be more unique too, so not every round/try feels the same, as it does at the current state of the game. Even if the description states "not every round feels the same" .. it pretty much does. If you don't switch between the maps, the only difference is - that the items/offering points are at slightly other spawnpoints, depending on the map. Which doesn't really change how the gameplay feels.

The game still has a lot of potential, if some stuff gets changed/added and if it would be more balanced.
Will change the review, if the game gets more diversity in gameplay and more casual-friendly in terms of the difficulty.

(Some last note in terms of difficulty and balancing, it also could be a great option and solution if the game would get some kind of difficulty sliders, so we as the players can change "every" aspect (which would influence how much XP we get too) to our liking. This way hardcore-players could also change the difficulty to how they wanna play. As some example, it could get inspired by how the game "Phasmophobia" handles this kind of stuff.)

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
I’ve spent some time with this game and honestly, it surprised me in a way I didn’t fully expect. I don’t want to sound dramatic, but there’s something oddly satisfying about how everything fits together — not in some perfect, polished “advertisement” way, but more like a game that knows exactly what it wants to be and just… goes for it.

The first thing I noticed is the atmosphere. Every part of the game — the visuals, the sound, the pacing — kind of blends into this feeling that you’re actually inside its world, even if you’re just casually playing. I know that sounds a bit cliché, but it’s true. Sometimes it’s chaotic, sometimes slow, sometimes you’re just wandering around thinking “ok, what now?” but that’s honestly part of the charm. The game doesn’t try to rush you unless it actually needs to.

Gameplay-wise, it has this mix of familiar elements and small twists that keep things from feeling stale. Nothing groundbreaking, maybe, but it all works together in a way that feels natural. There were moments when I thought “yeah, I’ve seen this in other games,” but then the game throws in tiny details or unexpected interactions that make it stand out just enough. It’s the kind of thing you only notice after a few hours, when you start connecting the dots.

Performance has been mostly fine. A little rough spot here and there, but honestly, show me a game these days that doesn’t have something weird happening once in a while. Nothing game-breaking on my end, at least. You can clearly tell the developers put effort into this, even if a few edges are still a bit sharp. Again — part of the charm.

What I really appreciate is that the game gives you space to play the way you want. Some people will rush through every objective, others will take their time exploring or messing around, and both approaches actually feel valid. I like games that don’t punish you for not following some “correct” path.

Overall, I’d say this is one of those titles that grows on you the longer you play. It doesn’t try too hard to impress in the first five minutes — instead it slowly builds its identity, layer by layer, until you suddenly realize you’ve been playing way longer than you planned. If you’re looking for something that balances comfort with challenge, familiar mechanics with fresh touches, and a world that’s just fun to be in, then I genuinely think this one is worth giving a shot.

Would I recommend it?
Yeah, I would — maybe not to everyone, because no game is for everyone, but definitely to anyone who likes getting lost in a game for a bit and discovering things at their own pace.

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
After sinking over 450 hours into Paladins, I can confidently say this is one of the most enjoyable hero shooters you can get—especially for free.

Is Paladins perfect? No. The matchmaking can be hit-or-miss, and balance patches sometimes feel like they were decided by throwing darts at a board. But when the gameplay clicks it’s genuinely some of the most fun I’ve had in a shooter.

For anyone wondering if Paladins is worth trying or returning to:
Yes. Absolutely.

It’s chaotic, stylish, surprisingly strategic, and still manages to be addictive after hundreds of hours. If you’re willing to embrace its quirks, you’ll find a game with a ton of depth and replayability.

450 hours later, and I’m still not done.

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
Been years since I last played. Apparently it's now winding down in activity. Seems like I never made a review for this. Better late than never.

All in all, I liked the gameplay. But disliked the "free-to-play" monetization. Every new character (non-free) they introduced was always OP, until they introduced a new character (again OP) and "re-balanced" the earlier one. You could usually pay for them with an exorbitant amount of in-game currency, or a fairly small sum of real-life money. So "free-to-play" became "pay-to-win".

I especially liked the character skill/attribute customization options, where you could build your character to your own play-style. There might not be overly many players online, anymore, but I would recommend trying this.

Skye FTW!

review_text:
Paladins is worth playing if you like hero-shooters and want a free-to-play option with a lot of customisation and fun. However — it is not flawless, and some of the longer-term support and ecosystem might feel weaker compared to more dominant titles in the genre.

Final call:
If you’re playing casually or with friends, you’ll likely enjoy it. If you want “the best” in 2025 for competitive hero-shooters, you might want to compare other options first.

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
A 5v5 team-based shooter like Paladins looked very promising on paper. It had a good variety of maps, a large roster of unique champions with different abilities, and even a shop system where you could buy extra perks to improve your stats. The gameplay felt fast and dynamic - fights were happening all the time, yet it never felt overwhelming or chaotic.

The balance and anti-cheat existed, though not always in their best shape. Still, for a while, the game managed to stay alive, build its own community, and even have an esports scene. But as time went on, it stopped evolving. Players began complaining that the only updates were new skins, while major improvements were nowhere to be seen. The game had squeezed out everything it could from its audience - and decline followed.

It's not a bad game by any means, but today it's simply not worth your attention anymore.

★ ★ ★ ★ ★ ☆ ☆ ☆ ☆ ☆ (5/10)

review_text:
I used to play this alot like 7 years ago. I came back after a year or two of not playing and was genuinely shocked at how bad everything has become. 
You no longer have drawn portraits of the characters/character skins when loading into a match (I don't know why it was removed??) the UI is now utter garbage to the point I can't tell what is what, they have some weird "tower defense" style mode in the works that you can't even play test despite it being on the menu.  And the game just overall. With the bugs, lack of updates, ect, just feels so much less fun than it used to. 

I want to hope Hi-Rez gets Paladins back on track but I doubt it. The game has been going downhill for like 5 years minimum due to their priority on battlepasses/skins over fixing any bugs.

genres: Action, Adventure, Massively Multiplayer, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
As a longtime Paladins player, the matchmaking and balance issues have really ruined the ranked experience for me lately. Way too often, my team gets paired against players who are obviously way more skilled or ranked much higher, turning matches into totally one sided stomps. It’s super demotivating when you realize that winning or losing feels out of your hands not because of how well you or your team plays, but simply because the matchmaking threw together teams of wildly different levels. Frankly, I want my effort and skill to matter, not just luck or who got stacked on my team.
Recent matchmaking changes have only made things worse. Matches feel even less fair than before, with the system regularly putting beginners against top-tier veterans, or grouping talent in ways that just don’t make sense. Sometimes I feel like the queue cares more about filling spots quickly than about actually creating competitive, fun games. All this randomness means I rarely enjoy ranked anymore, since I don’t get consistent, challenging matches with players on my level.
Honestly, unless the developers address the core of these matchmaking and balance problems pairing teams based on actual performance and skill rather than random chance I just don’t see myself having fun in ranked mode anymore. Competitive play needs to be fair, and right now, it’s just not

review_text: From someone that has played this game a ton over the year I unfortunately cannot recommend this game. I am finally uninstalling after years of frustration. You can not win a 4vs5 match in this game and reporting people does absolutely nothing. So you will basically have fun maybe 25% of the time because either your team leaves or the other team leaves and you are just playing against bots. You either steam roll them or get killed because of the bots on your team. If this game was actually popular and the developers took it seriously it would be one of my favorite games. After about 9 years of playing I am finally giving up on this game having any hope.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text:
Path of Exile completely changed the way I look at ARPGs. What started as a casual curiosity turned into one of the most immersive gaming experiences I’ve ever had. The depth of its skill system, the freedom to build your character in countless unique ways, and the constant introduction of new leagues make the game feel endlessly fresh.

What truly stands out is how rewarding it feels to grow your character. Every upgrade, every crafted item, every perfected build comes from your own effort and creativity. It’s a game that challenges you, but it also inspires you to think, experiment, and push your limits.

Path of Exile didn’t just raise my standards for ARPGs. It completely redefined them. If you love meaningful progression, complex systems, and worlds that pull you in and don’t let go, this game is a must-play.

review_text:
This game is now bordering the perfect ARPG. The addition of gold for respecing each and every skill point, is a great quality of life improvement, along with the Diablo 2-style gambling for items.

While the skill tree still looks intimidating, just knowing intelligence is at the top, strength is the bottom left, and dexterity in the bottom right for 3 classes, and additional 3 hybrid classes begin between each of the primary attributes str/int, dex/str, and int/dex, with a 7th class starting in the center of all three core attributes, the game doesn't keep you on rails, allowing you to build your character however you please.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text:
The game is extremely poorly optimized. The skills are all boring and because any character can use any skill gem, there is no atmosphere or aura to any character played. It's basically a game for chair gremlins who want to grind resources to make up for a small pp, which is what is confirmed when you look at these Twitch streamers they throw their moneybags at. 

The worst offense is how utterly BLOATED this game is with 'content'. PoE when I first played it was a crappy but interesting ARPG you could put a week or two into every few years and zone out on some maps and areas. Now, there are 15 different events that pop up on every single area. Yeah, you can ignore these 'pop ups', but now you are missing out on currency and possibly upgrades. 

These 'pop ups' basically ruin the game for anyone who is an adult and not some Twitch chair gremlin micropener. The game loses any atmosphere it had and just feels clunky, cheap, and FOMO'ey. But we live with this new generation of buffoons who can't go 1.2 seconds without a dopamine hit, so there needs to be special chests and events popping up literally every 5 seconds of speedfarming. It's horrible. 

Even Diablo 4 trashes this game. Stick to older ARPGs that aren't super bloated with boring currency mechanics designed to keep the user enslaved to the game.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text:
It just isn't fun.

PoE was the Diablo 3 people wanted back in the day: it was a passion project that filled the "no, we want more D2" gap left by Blizzard. And so for that, it was good.

But as it continued, the complexity and customization only increased. And now the world has moved on. Loot games have evolved. And this game is unapologetically complex because it believes THAT IS WHAT YOU SHOULD WANT.

I'm sure it gets amazing once you get deep into its systems, but Last Epoch is right there, folks. And even Diablo 4, Lost Ark, and a million others - including PoE 2. If you want unlimited customization which is only possible with unlimited complexity, then this game may do it for you. But otherwise, you can do better.

This game has a surprising amount of depth despite seeming like a simple RPG on the surface. The game's balance is impeccable, every new area and boss is challenging but not overwhelming and you are always rewarded for your curiosity and exploration. The post-launch support has been among the best that I've seen in any game, with mod support and even a built-in randomizer that makes the game insanely replayable. Absolute hidden gem!
This game is the best I've ever played.

ok this one was kind of cheating because i did finish most of it and then just went and learned the speedrun, so i technically didn't "beat" it casually, but whatever

this is just your standard turn-based rpg combat-wise, nothing too fancy here. you go around the world touching crystals, which unlock new classes, and then eventually beat The Final Boss, with all of your accumulated crystal knowledge. the special sauce it has is the entire world is open to movement, and if you're good at jumping or spotting the patterns you can get places waaaaaaaay before you're intended to.

this game is very interesting! it's plot-light, there are npc interactions you can find as you go around the world, but the main draw of this game is its HEAVY focus on builds. you can mix and match classes easily, and not only that, you can mix and match stat growths from classes. this doesn't affect tooooo much if you're just playing casually, but if you want to minmax this is absolutely the game for you. it felt like a slog for me a few times, but once i understood where to put my focus everything crystallized fairly well.

the movement in this game is very satisfying. there's a sprint mount, a swim mount, and a fly mount, among others, and all of them feel really good to use.

Crystal Project, at core, is effectively "What if you took FF5 and brought it to modern day with all the qol and streamlining that entailed, but also expanded upon it with some MMO-inspired features"
Those MMO-inspired features being literally seeing your enemy's intent and upcoming actions, as well as being able to access a list of all their possible attacks while fighting them
It's a bit impressive to me that they manage to provide a challenge even despite giving you such powerful tools
And makes it all the more fun when certain enemies deny you the privilege of those tools
It is just incredibly elegant and I heavily recommend trying out the demo for a feel of what I mean.

Where it truly shines though, funnily enough, isn't even the classic turn based gameplay
The exploration.
The most interesting part of Crystal Project that makes it fairly unique by JRPG standards is the fact it is a 3D Voxel Platformer
And the entire world is constantly loaded
And you can achieve some VERY impressive things with the platforming if you are curious/stubborn enough 
It's EXTREMELY hard for me to go further into this without further spoilers, but again, the Demo demonstrates it exceptionally well.
VERY mild spoiler ahead...

To me, it's hilariously fitting from a meta perspective that you can actually bypass some of the Demo's restrictions and delve further into the game than "intended" just by... exploring and platforming enough.

And a lot of the time it just makes me wonder
"What the fuck."
"Surely the dev didn't actually intend for you to do this, right?"
But yes, the Demo is literally the first 10-20% of the game assuming you do it as intended and saves carry over to the actual game so please go play it.
If you like JRPGs, FFV or even just exploration and finding secrets in video games at all, please give it a shot.

Also, shoutout to the dev for having some INCREDIBLE assist and challenge options, as well as decent modding tools,
The Final Fantasy Project Overhaul in particular outright skips the middle man and turns the game into a full-on FF gameplay-wise while adding various story elements and cameos that make it feel like a genuinely impressive fangame and love letter to the older FFs.
I heavily recommend it for a second or third playthrough.
Great gameplay. Can't wait for Crystal Project 2
There is a lot of exploring and very little story. IMO this is a positive because story usually gets in the way of freely exploring.

Very fun game! If you like to explore and find hidden secrets, this game really scratches that itch. The battle and class system is really good too.  There is a VERY generous demo available as well which you can transfer your progress over to the full game.  Definitely recommended!

Crystal Project has an amazing sense of adventure! easily one of the top 10 games of the decade for me. Its open world feels on par with titles like Breath of the Wild and Elden Ring, offering true freedom and discovery at every turn.

The class system is brilliantly designed, allowing for countless creative strategies and builds. The itemization is deep and rewarding, making exploration and experimentation feel meaningful. On top of that, the game is packed with thoughtful quality-of-life features that make the whole experience smooth and enjoyable.

Easly 10/10

This game is heavily inspired by old school JRPGs—to include punishing battles, grinding, and a complete lack of hand-holding. The game eschews traditional puzzle solving in favor of platforming and exploration, Metroidvania-style. The story is minimal, and the cinematics are non-existent. 

If that doesn't appeal to you, then don't buy the game because you won't like it.
If that does appeal to you, then buy the game, because it does all of those things at a really high level.

The two complaints I have are somewhat minor:
1. The difficulty settings are easy, normal, and hard when they really should be normal, hard, and "I hate myself". Under the description for normal, there is an explanation that there won't be much grinding. That's not even close to true. the game is still quite punishing on normal, and one of the most common complaints I've seen is that the difficulty spikes are ridiculous. If the developer had just renamed easy to normal and so on (sparing a lot of people's pride, myself included), they could have avoided this entirely.
2. The map system sucks. It should just track the area the player has explored. Instead, the game gate-keeps this function needlessly. This is easily the worst part of the game, and the other biggest complaint I've seen. Without looking things up online, you'll spend A LOT of time wandering.

Again though, if this is the kind of game you'd normally like, then you'll love this. For a cheap game made by a single developer, it's an absolute gem.
Great game if you love RPGs.

Hell of a beast! ❤️ Kudos to Andrew.


**WARNING BIT OF SPOILER**

While normally i'm a bit of a sucker for a story in my jrpg's., this one has none present, short, albeit funny dialogues here and there.

The gameplay of platforming and metroidvania as well as the jrpg with different classes / sub classes / wpns / gear / acc's / archive entry etc got me hooked!

Quintar breeding was a pain, but oh so worth for sequoia tree, got pretty close to the top with owl & salmon but wanted to die X.x, never again. Do not suggest unless you're into pain and rage, masochistic style.

Currently bulking for the 4 superboss in the depths, 1 down 3 to go.

There are assist options if you feel you need a bit of a break on certain aspects of the game.
Imo the 3 homepoints are a must. Others at your leisure, i find most stuff balanced as is.

The music is superb, really immersive.
The world is fun to uncover, and i know some of you, like me, will reach out for every corner of the map possible. 😁
Mini games are harsh at first, but becomes easier as it goes. Quintar breeding is money and time consuming.

There are ways to break and fast forward the games progression, as this is non-linear game.
Speedruns are out there on every crystals.

Workshop supported and lots of guides and videos online.

Def recommend, two thumbs & two big toes up. 👍🏻👍🏻🦶🏻🦶🏻

I'm surprised I haven't heard almost anyone talk about this game given how good it is. Excellent freeform exploration ripe with stuff to find and shortcuts that allow multiple ways of accessing almost every location, solid combat system (I disagree with some balancing decisions, but overall it keeps things appropriately difficult the whole game), very-very light on story. It's more or less exactly the game I wanted after finishing Octopath Traveler II
Pixels, rpg, exploration, classes, skils.... Perfect

Amazing game.
Doing what most JRPGs don't do anymore: having great gameplay

Dont feel like writing a long review. TLDR one of the best game worlds i have ever played trough, the design of the map itself gives the game so much character it is not comparable. The game was obiviously heavily play tested and it shows. Its 10 bucks, trying it wont hurt. And if you dont like the current job balance (i dont lol) there are rework mods that change that.

It's a great blend of the job system from FF5, a minecraft parkour map, and a metroidvania. If you like all of those, then this is a fantastic game, but you really have to be into all of them for the game to truly shine.

The combat is good, lots of different class combinations and interesting setups you can make. The game is very difficult by normal JRPG standards, but there are a plenty of ways to break the system. The game even has a preset system that lets you save specific setups so you can swap them easily.

The exploration is good, very open-ended and tons of little secrets to find. It can be a bit tedious to get around, as even with all of the teleport stones it can take a couple of minutes to get to where you need to go. None of the areas really stand out in terms of level design, but there are tons of skips and tricky jumps you can make to completely break the intended order of progression.

The platforming is, in my opinion, the weakest aspect. It's fine, for the most part, but there are way too many areas where one missed jump can set you back upwards of five minutes to get back and try again. Areas with platforms over spikes or water were the best, since there if you miss a jump at least it puts you back where fell from. Nothing stings worse than missing the final jump in a section and falling all the way back to the bottom.

Definitely worth it if you like all three of the genres it's blending. If any of those are a turn off for you, it's probably best to just skip this one.
owlbear is just fking stupid

A very well-made passion project. Super fun exploration, good combat, good progression, amazing class system (including multiclassing).

9/10
Great gameplay, great environments, great music, great class system. Would highly recommend to any rpg fan.

Perfect RPG for an RPG hater like myself. Specifically:

* I'm not interested in story or dialogue. The game has minimal both.
* I want combat to be interesting and not a grind. Here, it's similar to Slay the Spire in that it's almost a puzzle: The enemies broadcast their upcoming actions and you need to both plan and react accordingly, rather than just apply a broad strategy. (Sometimes the normal enemy encounters can feel a bit repetitive)
* Traversing the world is actually interesting, and only restricted by your movement/inventory rather than plot triggers.
* Skill trees and character customization are deep enough to be interesting, but simple enough to not warrant analysis paralysis.
* Effectively no decision is irreversible, and no missables. If you ever want to pivot to a different strategy it's always an option, and just requires light time and resources. And there's no sense of "don't miss stealing an item from this boss"
* You feel you can liberally use items. There's no sense of "save all your megalixers!"

I can't imagine an RPG that's more in line with what I want out of an RPG.

(Fully completed on Switch)

100% recommended, I'm enjoying this game a lot. Kind of like a mashup of old school Final Fantasy and Elden Ring

Huge world and the exploration is awesome, nice music, some challenge but not too difficult

Just finished my first playthrough and got all achievements at just under 50 hours of playtime.
Incredible game for the price.

What an absolute journey, this game really embodies the essence of adventures.

With an expansive world to explore and plenty treasure chests rewarding the curious.
Not to mention the many wonderful songs playing as you go (if i could, I'd buy it to listen to). 
The combat offers a deceptively interesting system, with a handful of classes to play around with.

I can highly recommend this to any rpg lovers

This game is a wonderful JRPG and definitely scratches a big itch for those looking for a meaningful turn-based RPG.  

The battle system and mechanics are definitely its highest selling point.  For many battles at your level (even mundane ones), it is very important to manage threat, apply buffs and debuffs, and review the turn order to see what attacks are coming out.  Every battle feels meaningful, and until you out-level enemies in the area, it can be very easy to screw up and have someone die or even wipe.  Status effects are VERY strong in this game, and they can effect bosses.  Sleeping or paralyzing a boss to set up for a series of attacks or buffs feels awesome, and applying debuffs that reduce physical or magical damage (or increase these types of damage against the boss) are paramount to success.  Battles feel like chess matches at times, and it is a very welcome change.

If you are a gamer that values the story above all, this game will not be the right fit for you.  While I find the story to be endearing, it is purposely left to feel very bare bones.  The game challenges the player to determine their experience, and interactions with NPCs generally reinforce that.

There are obvious parallels with the classes that are very similar to Final Fantasy, and tends to improve on those archetypes in unique ways.  The level of experimentation can be as simple as having a tank, a physical DPS, a magical DPS, and a healer.  OR you can really go down the rabbit hole and mix and match so many different things.  I have spent countless hours both in and outside of game theory-crafting party comps, and I have enjoyed every second of it.  In addition, there are also battles that  may require a specific skill or skills to either make a fight easier or completely negate certain mechanics, so definitely don't spend too much time attempting to completely master classes before swapping to a new one.

Stats are what you make of them, and are as involved as you want to be.  As you gain a level, the stat boosts you gain are determined by your current class.  While it is beneficial to have a party member adhere to a specific role, you really do not have to do this at all, and this can even be custom-tailored later on to suit your needs later on, so don't worry about it.

This game is very exploration heavy, with many jump puzzles and terrain puzzles.  If you get easily frustrated by this, you can help mitigate it by enabling the "Auto-Jump" option, which perfectly times a last second jump if you walk off any ledge.  I have found it to be very helpful in my new games, and definitely makes things a bit easier.  The game also really doesn't tell you where to go, but you are generally blocked from new areas through the addition of mounts, which allow you to clear gaps easier, jump higher, or swim.  

Money in the early and mid game is a little rough to come by, and maps suck away a lot of your extra cash as they tend to be pretty expensive.  Definitely be prepared to grind a bit if you need cash for better equipment or consumables.

And of course, if you're into mods, there are plenty for this game that improve the QoL if you don't enjoy the standard gameplay.

Overall, this game asks you a simple question:  do you want to go on an adventure?  And this game delivers, and gives you a great adventure.  If you love JRPGs, turn-based combat, and exploration, with an emphasis on gameplay over story, then this game is for you.
If you like Minecraft parkour or final fantasy 1 you will love this game.

I think the game i extremely solid but I do have a number of caveats
First, the combat is excellent. I feel like the rate at which you get new abilities, items and classes keeps things super fresh for most of the game. I recommend mastering as many classes as possible rather than trying to keep an optimal party all the time. There is a system where the levels you get in a class influence your characters stats, but you can respec that at any time (kind of makes me wonder why its a thing in the first place and they don't just let you choose what stats to level but this isn't really a problem). I guess my only other problem with the combat would be that some of the late game classes are pretty redundant like dervish or valkyrie, but thats a bit of a nitpick and probably adds variety in randomized runs.

Aside from great combat though, there's a few points of friction for me. I think the open world is mostly a missed opportunity. For most of the game its pretty cool climbing stuff where you can, but i felt less rewarded for exploring as my options expanded, I ended up going in the "wrong" direction a couple times, , thinking the game just had a massive difficulty spike, getting my ass kicked by random encounters, considered dropping the game entirely etc. I know this is a vastly different game but I would've loved if the world was more open and areas had scaling in order of when you entered them like in monster sanctuary, especially given the built in randomizer and seeming intent of challenge runs and replay value. Another massive point of frustration for me was the platforming. The isometric perspective makes it pretty tricky... at its best in the early game its a fun spacial puzzles figuring out what you can and cant reach, but later jump puzzles become a regular and irritating mainstay of areas and dungeons, culminating in the quintar side quest. the gist is its like chao garden but fast precise platforming (races) is mandatory to raising and breeding quintars. you need to win like at least a dozen races to breed the ultimate quintar needed to access a late game area. I really wouldnt mind something like this being tied to a minigame if it wasnt also super difficult. Its like if to catch mewtwo you had to perfect a song on guitar hero.
I think these things sound like nitpicks but combined with getting caught by random encounters sometimes It can be frustrating enough to make me need a break sometimes.

All in all, i would recommend this to fans of the team comp side of jrpg genre. Theres some really fantastic design put into the core gameplay, but decisions elsewhere can bring it down. I think anybody who loves that older generation of rpgs probably has patience for a bit of weird annoying bs in their games though, so fire away. oh and fair warning the game barely has a plot. fine by me but dont expect to fall in love with any characters

Definitely an interesting game that scratches a lot of little itches that no other game really has in a really long time. In short, if you're yearning for a complex job system and love finding secrets and unlockables in a classic RPG setting then this game is right up your alley and you should give it a shot.

[h3]Job system[/h3]
To get more into it this game has a complex, but not overwhelming, job system that adds a lot of customization for how you build your team. It's just robust enough to feel like you might be able to break the game with the right strategies and, in some cases, you kind of can. You begin the game with a party of four that you can level and gear up like any other good RPG. In this game you can choose each member's job and also a subjob. Jobs come with their own innate passives but when you choose a subjob you get access to that job's abilities and spells. You also level up the main job you have equipped and unlock more passives and abilities, making that job a more viable subjob for the future. An issue I have with this is how quickly some jobs get outclassed. Once one is mastered you'll never find a need to switch to that class ever again, forced to spend the rest of the game as a subjob. Classes like white mage are practically useless given their equipment limitations and underwhelming innate passive. If more classes had gameplay changing passives like the reaper then I feel like this could be mitigated. This is far from a deal breaker but it is a little disappointing once you get to the midgame point and start realizing your toolbox isn't as robust as initially thought.

[h3]Exploration[/h3]
This is a mixed bag because, for the most part, I very much enjoyed exploring the world and finding tons of secrets. There's hordes of hidden treasures and even jobs out there for you to find, making exploration feel very rewarding. The world is open to you and more of it becomes accessible as you're given new mounts to traverse the land with. Do yourself a favor and assign your mount's summoning item to the quick menu. Going through menus to use that item every single time you want to summon your mount feels exhausting even from the quick menu and it only gets worse as you unlock more. It wouldn't feel so bad if the parkour in this game wasn't so heinous which I'll get to in a second don't you worry. Some areas require you to switch between multiple mounts constantly and one slip and you have to do it all over again. Though your patience is almost always rewarded, it certainly does feel like a slog sometimes. If you're not thorough you can miss jobs entirely which I actually kind of like. It feels like a huge incentive to go out there and look around when the rewards are THAT good.

[h3]The Parkour[/h3]
I want to have a little chat with whatever Roblox or Minecraft kid convinced everyone that parkour is fun. I just wanna have a talk. Is it me? Am I just not the target audience? I play games like this because I love my menu-slop and I'm not afraid to admit that. I do NOT play these games to do jumping puzzles. They feel lazy, make the dungeons look god awful, and feel so out of place in an RPG. A few would've been fine but you're going to get to The Tree and think back to this review. I would've vastly preferred a far more simple [i]collect a key to open a door to collect a key[/i] type dungeon. The worst part is that some areas REQUIRE parkour to get to. Places you'll need to go back to multiple times meaning you'll need to do them all over again. A lot of them aren't particularly hard but, with no way to fast travel to these areas, they make the trek feel like a terrible slog as even a small slip up can set you back minutes of progress. I can bang my head against a difficult boss for hours no problem but with some of these jumping puzzles I've had to put the controller down and go for a walk.
A game so good I've bought it on multiple platforms.

One of the best classic turn-based RPG I have ever played.
Simple graphics, very fun to explore world with a variety of enemies, bosses and biomes.
You mix and match abilities from different classes to create your party of 4, lots of combos to optimize for different bosses.

I wish the steam review system had a 1 out of 5 stars system of some kind. This game is not perfect, it has glaring flaws, it also has outstanding highs and great traits that outshine those flaws, but I hope in this review the glaring flaws are at least acknowledged because they do hold this game back from greatness. The music, the goddamn music, man. What a hit. To everyone who knows about the LP farming method in this game.... just, what a soundtrack, right? I love the artstyle of this game, it's charming and cool at the same time. Wonderful setpieces, locations, creatures, and the classes for the most part (I will never understand why you made the Mimic look like *that*) look stunning. Mechanically, this is the best jrpg I have played. FF5 is one of if not my all time favorite game, a classic and cherished childhood memory with what used to be the best class system I have ever had the experience of using. This game's class system takes what FF5 did and runs all the way down to the touchdown line. You can turn on various options to increase replay value like mad. Randomize classes, items, monsters, even your skills. Make the game harder by changing the party size limit to whatever you like from one to four, for example. Being able to do most of the game in any order you want, at any time, works so wonderfully in this game’s favor. The mod workshop is packed with wonderful and meaningful mods, most are QoL improvements that I think should just be default to the game. The turn system is perfect, the best turn based system I have ever played. Bar none. Crystal Project is strong with how beautiful it all works.... mechanically. The way it is implemented? Holy. Fucking. Airball. 

This is what happens when you have one single developer having the full dominion over a project with no real voice or co-author to reign in ambition and self-understanding. While the mechanics of the game are all near-perfect, while the exploration remains it's strongest point, while the soundtrack and area design are impeccable and atmospheric (except for the final area), there are noticeable difficulty spikes littered throughout the game that then retract instantly afterwards for X amount of time. There are too many instances where certain overworld enemies are a tad too hard compared to what comes before and after their location, there are too many bosses (main and optional) that are way too overtuned for what comes before and after them, the puzzles range from absolute kindergarten level difficulty to "only the person who made this would know what to do without a guide" levels of asinine, the story (while admittedly not the focus of the game) is so laughably nothing and corny that it manages to not land with every player (I was fine with it, but a quick run on the forums and google will show you most people thought the story was lame and built up to a disappointment), and the final area..... without spoilering as much as I can, boils down to "walk down this path and encounter enemies where the gimmick is they blow up your whole party with full HP moves before you can act so I hope you equipped skills that let you survive on 1HP and just keep doing that until you reach the end." The absolute final stretch of this game was made in a single night, or at least that is how it feels. I'm not going to talk about the lore implications on the area and what that means for any previous statement, but mechanically and for US the player, it feels lazy and uninspired, and Andrew Willman should unironically strive to never again make a section of a game feel like that again. 

In defense of the game now, the developer put in systems to at least circumvent a lot of these problems. I’d rather the problems be solved before the final product, but these circumventions work. There are optional settings you can activate at any time, and I highly recommend you turn ALL of them on. The Enhanced Home Point should have just been how this game works, and the dev even acknowledges that most players will want to enable this option. The amount of not just backtracking but just platforming and parkour in general makes traversing to and from locations a CHORE depending on where you want to go at any given time, especially before well into the game where various fast travel shines are unlocked. Having one home point initially in the game where traveling takes so long without mounts and fast travel shrines always made no sense to me. The Healing Home Point seems like cheating at first until you realize that there comes a point where most people would just have the first save point in the game as their home point and fast travel to it for the insanely nothing priced inn. This just turns an already cheesed out mechanic into a time saver. I personally think the level limit could and should be level 99. Yes, the endgame is designed around level 60, but getting from 60+ to said 99 takes so much time that you might as well reward someone for grinding that out. Plus, unless you are minmaxing so hard you’re essentially powergaming (and if you did math and looked at graphs and charts to understand the endgame’s optimal growth rate reallocation), being level 60 will not be close enough to beating the endgame’s optional content. Easier Non-Bosses makes the  regular encounters in the world a lot less “mini-boss” feeling, as the dev wanted every encounter to feel engaging and not trash-mobby. This means almost EVERY fight in the entire game will want you to at least know optimally what buttons to push or what buffs/debuffs to be using. Yet again, another downside to the dev’s complete creative control with no outside opinion, as this leads to various regular and repeating encounters sometimes leaning towards the aforementioned difficulty spikes rearing their ugly heads. This option tones that down almost completely, and makes this game more playable and feel like an actual normal video game. Custom Difficulty lets you change the difficulty setting on the fly, as normally it is set at save creation. This lets you change the difficulty down to Easy during another difficulty spike moment, then change it back to Normal once you’ve gone past that stuff. Skip Minigames is honestly up to you, I actually have this one remain off myself, but it lets you get around really dumb rubberbanding npc races so bad they make Double Dash look fair and balanced (no, they’re actually very very bad. I just can stomach them I guess?) Extend Timers does not matter except for TWO dungeons in particular. The amount of time the game gives you to complete the mechanic in time requires you to basically be perfect with almost no margin of error. Ironically enough, the “Extend Timers” option makes the game feel actually well-tuned and balance, since the extra time it does give you is not a whole lot and makes it feel like this should have been the original setting. The Boost EXP/LXP/Gold just lets the game go by at a “I have a job” pace, so don’t be afraid to turn them on. 

But outside of all that yeah, great game. 4/5, and I mean that genuinely. Half a star is taken away by the random spikes in difficulty alone. The creator of this game clearly wanted to make their dream game, their idea of an ideal and perfect game. They set out to make this game for them, and I think they completely nailed it and hit it out of the park. They did indeed make the game they wanted to make for themselves. The problem comes when you realize not everyone wants to play their dream game, and most people are going to have the exact same issues with their dream game. It’s just not *our* dream game. And it doesn’t have to be, but I think a lot of people who are fans of this game online need to realize that it still means it ain’t our dream game. Pretty close though.
I love it so far.  It makes me feel honestly really nice to be playing it.  Although I do get confused at some points of the game.
