(I only have 12 minutes in the game because I played through it on console. However, since it is such a great game I look forward to playing through it again on Steam.)
amazing game, long and difficult. if you want good JRPG, pick this one up. worth the 14 dollars for sure.

Deceptively deep combat system and great exploration mechanics and rewards. Some of the endgame stuff has a bit more friction than I'd like (like the golden quintar process), but that didn't stop me from thoroughly enjoying this game.
Underrated gem. Open world rpg with amazing depth

I wanted to like Crystal Project. I really did. 

The Story. Barely worth a hoot. Doesn't really DO anything with its plot of "fuck around and find out", sorry, explore the world and find crystals. There's some crap about this world being built on top of an older one but it doesn't really matter in the grand scheme of things. This kind of vague storytelling might've been worked for Dark Souls and its contemporaries but the game doesn't make the effort to make the player CARE about such a reveal or its implications or anything. It tries to push this exploratory theme down the players throat but it just doesn't Work give all of the games other flaws. 

There just isn't much Reason to go explore beyond game progression. Sure, the mounts exist and getting more crystals unlocks more classes but it doesn't mesh well with the themes of exploration that the game preaches so highly. Combined with just how awful the platforming and bits of the level design are--it just feels bad to play. You'd think that some of these jumps were taken straight out of Super Meat Boy with the way you're forced to navigate them. And often when you're forced to perform them all for one stupid chest that only has healing potions that one barely uses--it's more frustrating than anything else.

Then there's combat and the equipment system. My god why the hell are you going to implement an elemental resistance system and then say that it basically doesn't matter for the majority of fights? The only reason you would choose to use a specific element against an opponent is when you're trying to cheese a boss or are trying to get past other elemental resistances. But eight times out of ten you'll just be trying to pile in more non elemental damage instead of specifically targeting one enemy's weakness. Even the elemental weapons you occasionally get are thrown to the wayside for weapons that simply deal more damage since having an elemental weapon is more often than not a detriment when fighting enemies and bosses that resist it--not to mention they often do less damage!

Then the endgame bosses exist. Some of them are genuinely some of the most godawful mechanically designed bosses that I've had the pleasure of facing in an RPG. Apply debuffs on them? Most of them cleanse it immediately and they don't even take a turn to do so! Some of them have mechanics that completely invalidate certain builds and force you to deal with conditions completely unique to their encounter. Sounds great in theory, but some of them are just too troublesome and unbalanced to be fun.

Combined with the hard level cap your choices are to completely rebuild your character to deal with the boss--which leaves a Very bad taste in my mouth since it punishes you for playing the way you like to play--or find a way to counter the horsecrap mechanics that each endgame boss throws at you. Sure, a party at level 99 and on the easiest difficulty might be able to cut through them but if you're playing on the default intended difficulty for the game you're going to have a bad time.

This game spits in the face of modern JRPG QoL. 

Everywhere is cumbersome to get to, there is no fast travel, you can't speed up or skip common battles, you can't even use items in battle, you can't even RUN from battles. There are very few Inns and getting back to them is a pain. Currency is scarce. 

Every single battle is a challenge - which at first is kinda cool, but after manual trudge back into zone X and having to fight every single common enemy that you don't literally outrun... it gets old FAST. Especially when you don't have a ton of time to sink into games. Even the most common enemies are extremely OP and getting one-shotted is all too common (and annoying). They introduce taunt which seems great in premise but, you have to taunt each enemy individually so your healer will get smacked.

Any game that copy/pastes FF5's job system gets major kudos from me, but it turned out to just be too much of a slog, especially when compared to its contemporaries. 

Ultimately, Crystal Project introduces unique gameplay mechanics, but fails to even get the basics right.

I'm sad to give this game a negative review because it has so much promise in the beginning. Exploring is fun, finding secrets or hard to reach treasures that give you an advantage feels rewarding, and the variety of classes hints at some fun mix and match experimentation ala FF5 or FFT.

Unfortunately, a lot of this falls apart as early as the mid game. Basic enemies can frequently kill party members in one or two hits, the jumps used for progress start to get ridiculous, areas are hidden behind terrain that you can't see, and bosses require specific setups rather than allowing for any party comps. The class you're playing when you level up affects your stat gains, but you can pay to reallocate the gains, which means grinding for money against enemies that can easily kill your party, or using specific attack patterns to make the fights trivial, but also a slough. The point of making generic enemies this difficult is to avoid the problem of "mash attack" that pops up in a lot of JRPGs, but instead becomes "cycle through menus for the same attack pattern," which is basically the same thing with extra steps. Add into that the expensive MP cost for abilities and relatively low MP pool of your characters, and everything becomes a tedious, plodding chore. 

I want to like this game. There's so much potential, but I just can't force myself to play anymore.

There are some parts of this game I like, but overall I can't recommend it as it copies too many of the bad parts of Final Fantasy too.

I really like the exploration, which reminds me of CrossCode, and it is very similar with the influences from Final Fantasy too.

However, unlike CrossCode, the slow battles make the grindy combat very tedious, especially when most fights require no tactics whatsoever, just repeatedly bonking the enemies until they die.

It reminds me of the bad parts of Final Fantasy: Mystic Quest - which is a shame as the exploration part is done very well.

The game is unnecessarily hardcore with mechanics which just don't bring any pleasure. Like unlocking classes, which apparently you need to CHANGE while playing... you can't develop love towards your character at this pace. The mine-craft block style map was something unusual for me to see, but in the end it's just depressing because the majority of secrets are hidden in between these blocks, with crazy jumping mechanics of 'press longer to jump a bit higher'... I did my best to really make myself play the game and at least understand what a hell I am actaully doing it. Until... you get a message on the message board that the ONLY SENSE OF ALL WHAT I AM DOING IS ... looking for crystals... which depresses me, because... crystals unlock classes... (which I would never transform into during playing because I created the characters as per my own understanding...) ... and serve as requirements to go further in game... To sum up - it's exceptionally boring, with great soundtracks, drugged monster sprites (which I liked), mana troubles and too much complication. Also, there is not a single thing about JRPG in it. Apart from Final Fantasy hero sprites... Wish I could refund these 6 hours back to my life.

hardcore grindfest with minimal mechanics or fun strategies, barely any depth outside of it having a great open world design. if you want a casual rpg look elsewhere. this one on the "no grinding" normal mode has unbearable amounts of grinding due to horrid game balance

the soundtracks, and artwork are nice but it has no story and there are hundreds of amazing rpgs you should play instead. this is a last resort one if you want to torture yourself with dull gameplay.
Expected 95% JRPG with 5% platforming, got 95% platforming with 5% JRPG

I played through most of the game up to endgame.  As expressed in a lengthy post, the developer strongly feels that your party should grow comparatively weaker to enemies as you progress, so the farther you get the more difficult fights are.  With endgame bosses being able to one shot your entire party even at max level with max gear, and being generally unbeatable without specific combinations of classes and strategies.  

The developer is also huge on status effects being the ultimate decider in whether you win or lose so endgame battle requires a precise combination of buffs/debuffs.  If you don't like that, you don't get to win.  There's 24 classes offered, many them are a waste of time when it comes to endgame.  You can waste hours leveling the "wrong" class, due to a mechanic that increases your stats inline with the class you are at the time of leveling up.  

For example if somebody levels up as a Wizard for 50 levels, and then switches to Samurai, their Strength will be super low for their level and not able to perform well.

To fix this there's a mechanic to delevel your characters, so you can relevel them with the right stats.  At the cost of spending many hours with each attempt.

Ultimately I got burned out and tired of dealing with it all, it's ridiculous and a waste of everyone's time.  What should be an amazing game has been turned into a tedious chore.

I want to recommend this game because it does a ton of things right. However, the end game is fair to frustrating and unbalanced to be something I would recommend . EVERYTHING one shots you. Every end game boss, every end game mob, its horrible. I have respecced and regeared so many times my head is spinning and I have made no progress. I am giving up and giving a thumbs down.
The encounter system ruins the platforming

Its kinda cute people enjoy this game so much. It honestly is one of the blandest RPGs i have ever played and i cant recommend it but the high rating clearly shows that im pretty alone with my judgement so maybe you will enjoy it.

I had a great time playing this game in the beginning but it did fall off for me.

Pros:
Character classes are fun and start out strong
Verticality of the levels is fun!  Feels great to find some secrets sometimes.
Auto jump is great!

Cons:
Getting lost a lot where to go.  I know the older JRPGs are like this and this can be a design choice.  
This further hinders my enjoyment  because I can't find new classes (you need to find certain areas to find new classes).  Even when I found new classes, my party feels "solved" and unlocking new classes doesn't seem to give me anything interesting.  Further more when a class is mastered and is in my current party build, I'm not gaining anything from playing and wandering around.  I'd just be grinding for money which isn't fun.

At first I really liked this game and had it stopped after the first 10 crystals id probably give it a positive review but the game starts to feel incredibly grindy once your in the north and the enemies get so strong its basically rocket tag only they dont have to keep going back to an inn to get their mana back

Honestly, I do like this game, it's a unique spin on an RPG. But it is completely ridiculous, certain enemies can just completely mop your party without any warning, and the leveling curve is absurd. Not to mention all the awkward platforming to get to certain places. Honestly, it's a good game, but it really needs some polishing.

The character development is fun.  Battles are ok.  The thing is this game should be listed as a fucking jump puzzle not a god damn rpg.  Just finding your fucking path take a miracle that the makes the bible seem boring.  Fuck this game.

There's some parts of this game that make me want to tear my hair out. The racing mechanics, the grinding, strange difficulty curves later in game, how vague the game progression/direction is. It has a lot to like, but at the end of the day it's a frustrating experience that I can't recommend.

Unfortunately the platforming aspect of this game is awful and just gets worse and worse as you play it. 

The Shoju ninja village is just oppressively awful as every missed jump is a minute plus walk back and you can't move the camera more than like 15 degrees in each direction to get a clear picture on the jumping.

Add to that a character that slides around and having to use multiple different types of mounts to make different jumps and it just completely falls apart.

Too bad as FFV like jobs system and combat and gear is overall pretty good. Better gear than FFV and tactics, but worse class combos (.... er.... what class combos really....).

Don't bother if you just wanted more FFV, FFVI or FFT. There are better games out there for this fix!
I was really enjoying the cloud, then when I opened the game my save wasn't there.  Steam Cloud save somehow overwrote everything.   I looked up guides and could not recover anything.

This game was pretty fun, right up until I realized that there is literally nothing to it to keep you coming back, unless you want to install mods.

Without mods, this game is a shell of an RPG.

More to the point, if you want to have any kind of actual "fun" in game, you basically have to learn to use Crystal Edit to improve the game and classes yourself, otherwise you'll always feel under-powered, under-leveled, and ill-equipped. I shouldn't need to go into the game files and make the game what I want myself.

I hate that I paid money for this. Don't buy this game. Seriously.

I play the game still, but only because I changed it to be what I wanted it to be, not because it was fun already.

I loved this game, but i don't know a single person i like that i would recomend it to. This game is a hard jrpg but a brutal platformer with some sadistic minigames. there are platform challenges that can take several minutes to re-attempt if you fall to a place that doesn't kill you and are frame/pixel perfect. this game doesn't respect you or your time.

A decent game absolutely ruined by the creator's sadistic and unnecessary approach to platforming. Massive sections where a single mistake will reset 10-15 minutes of progress await you in the end-game. Find another RPG with classes and play it instead.
99% jump puzzles, no real RPG interaction, the classes don't really interact in any meaningful way and the world is like half finished at best.

Lost interest due to traps set by designers, forcing the player to reset by ambushing them with over-leveled bosses feels like a time-waster, world also feels bland without any sort of narrative or world-building

4/10 Not impressed so far. It's a cheap, unoriginal ripoff of old school Final Fantasy... which I'd probably actually like except for 4 things that destroy the experience:

1 - Required platforming sections that require you do make difficult jumps, etc. Maybe wouldn't be so bad, except...

2 - You can't use the mouse for anything at all, not even camera rotation. Not even for "confirm" like you can in other similarly controlled games like Secrets of Grindea. You can't type in your character's name with the keyboard. Absolutely baffling, limiting, and infuriating controls if you're not using a controller, I guess. It's been out for years and you still can't bind a single mouse button?

3 - While the eventual class list is big, it's uninspired and the skill lists are very short and boring. There's nothing to look forward to.

4 - You can't undo options in the game's difficulty settings or assist options. I don't understand this at all... I use settings like this to adjust my game experience as I go, but making them one-way is horrible.

I really really want to give this a yes, and at currently 25 hours played it might still be a yes for a sale but this game has some serious issues.

Firstly, enemies over tuned to heck. I admittedly gave up about 15 hours in and turned on cheats so I could actually play the game without tears. I've played tons of RPG's, but rarely have a come across a game dev so insistent on preventing you from ever feeling strong. Enemies will spam aoe that either 1-shots you or close to it, on top of adding debuffs, and they will do this nearly every turn for nearly every enemy in the game.

Secondly, "exploring" is not "hardcore platforming". Someone with the ability REALLY needs to add the platforming tag to this game. I'm no stranger to platforming games. Celeste, Super Meat Boy, N Ninja, etc, etc, etc. Some of these platforming sections around what I assume is mid-end game are up there with the hardest stuff in those games. It's completely unreasonable, especially if you aren't expecting it. I haven't wanted to throw my controller in years until I unlocked "swimming" in this game and went into a certain tree. A platforming tag is necessary since you absolutely can't beat this game without killer platforming skills and an absurd amount of patience.

Buying maps should probably reveal the map. Important things on the map should be labelled automatically. Names of places should be shown on the map. None of these happen, I recommend a notebook on the side if you want to play this game seriously.

I'll probably try to play more because I hate myself, but I can't recommend anyone play this game. Do so at your own peril.

Ya know what? Some nandypandy complained about my review, so let me lambast this piece of shit game.

First, exploration is a chore; it really fucking is. Platforming mechanic is unforgiving and tedious garbage. The ways you can overshoot or undershoot jumps are just awful, and the amount of backtracking you have to do sometimes is just unacceptable when some jumps are just so easy to mess up. Then there's the animal companions, which completely overhaul exploration for the better, but only by mitigating the absolutely terrible horseshit problems of exploration.

Second, to say the puzzles and dungeons are bad is an understatement. The battles are tedious bullshit, exploration is at its worst in dungeons, and the puzzles, dear God the puzzles. Let's talk about this Goddamned pile of shit, and almost always involve very specific jumps that again force you to reset the puzzle because fuck this game. One of the worst examples isn't even a puzzle so much as you finding 10 people hidden throughout an underwater area and answer each of their multiple choice questions accurately, which all involve very specific obscure details from the game world.

Third, the story. "Master of games is disappearing heroes. You must stop them." isn't a story. There are only a bare minimum of characters, the reasons people do things are dumb, and the worldbuilding just sucks in general. This game's world lore comparable in complexity to Minecraft, and it's an RPG; meditate on this.

Fourth, let's talk about the combat. It's imbalanced. Nothing scales well, so everything feels like it sucks even in the rare instances when it doesn't suck and bringing suck to the suckless. Bosses are bullshit, most encounters are bullshit, random encounters in many places are too powerful.

Fifth, time to talk about the class system. Taking notes from better games does not make your game good; this game takes the style, but the substance was ruined. The classes in this game are all super simplistic versions of the conventional Final Fantasy classes. This is the first game I've ever played where these classes are shit, and here's a list of games that didn't fuck this up: Final Fantasy I, Final Fantasy III, Final Fantasy IV, Final Fantasy VI, Final Fantasy IX, Final Fantasy X, Final Fantasy XII, Bravely Default, Bravely Second, Bravely Default II, Final Fantasy Tactics. You notice how all of them understand how to make the class system fun and rewarding, but Crystal Project does not? How? Well, allow me to elaborate. This game gives every class very few abilities, makes them hyper specific to an intended build rather than a battle role, and then traps them into that role; in other words it defines a class not based on what a class can do, but what it is restricted to doing. For example, the Samurai in FF games is based on Zenigage or whatever, who would throw coins at his enemy, and is set up to be a heavily armored attacker similar to the Knight. However, in CP, of fuck its initials are CP.... damn. In Crystal Project, the Samurai is about building up the AP gauge to release a combo move, so this is what your Samurai will be doing IN EVERY GODDAMNED BATTLE. Even with interesting added features, they manage to wreck the simple design of the class by pigeonholing it into a preset purpose. Crystal Project simultaneously overcomplicated Samurai and caged it at the same time. This goes for literally every class, you might think. However, there are some exceptions that especially anger me, such as the Aegis being a really crappy version of the Knight, or the Warrior being a debuffer. These changes would be less of a problem if not for the fact that Crystal Project uses these as direct reference to classic RPGs I love, but even then they would still be crap.

Lastly, there's tons of dumb shit like their offbrand Chocobos. Yeah, they made a creature that is basically Chocobos, and they even made a racing game for them and the fish, which both suck because of how this game controls. I would gladly take the shitty Chocobo minigames of FFVII and FFX and all their terrible tedium over this, even the shitty Chocofinder minigame of FFVIII; this content in Crystal Project is just that bad.

Stop trying to be a Final Fantasy game. You suck at filling someone else's shoes. Do anything else, and maybe you will make a game that isn't flaming shit.

I'm disappointed I didn't manage to get into this game, seeing how positively it is generally regarded.

You really, really have to love platforming not to find the exploration part frustrating. It's just an endless series of jumping puzzles with little direction and plenty of nasty punishments if you mess up (long backtrack, unwelcome fights etc.).

The combat is good and the character building is a nice riff on the old ff system. But it's mainly the boss fights that are great. The regular fights feel a little overtuned. They're doable of course, but tax your attention and resources (potions to refill mana mainly) and the combat isn't quite interesting enough to make me want to do 10 semi-risky trash fights just to traverse some zone. You can avoid lots of fights, but that relies heavily on being good at the platforming parts.

Unfortunately, I can't really recommend this. A whole lot of the individual parts are actually pretty good, but they manage to come together to form a massive slog, something that's really far less than the sum of its parts.

For example, individual battles are mostly fun. However, every battle is a steady drain on your very limited resources, so you have the choice of avoiding fights, meaning you'll be underpowered and lacking abilities to fight mandatory fights, or you can grind. It's frustrating, because I chose normal difficulty specifically because it said you shouldn't need to grind. That was an absolute lie. You will need to grind for abilities, and grind for cash to afford better gear and maps, and grind for consumables to sustain your party, either as drops or more money grinding to buy them. You cannot get through this game without a decent amount of grinding, regardless of what the game may tell you.

As another example, the platforming. It's pretty neat in small bouts, and when it works properly it can really lead to an open, intricate feeling world. However, a lot of the jumping paths are long and require many, many precise jumps. And don't think you can savescum these, either. When you reload a save, you're sent back to your last home point, not the point where you saved, which is unspeakably frustrating considering how large some of the maps are. I eventually reached the point where I didn't want to explore anymore because there was just so damn much platforming and it took ages to get anywhere.

Third big example, the job system. Now, I like the jobs I experienced and some of the abilities are interesting. However, many abilities on several classes just felt completely useless. Additionally, because most physical abilities are tied to a specific weapon, you are sorely limited in what abilities you can mix and match. For example, if you level a rogue, most rogue abilities are tied to using a dagger. Switch to a monk, whose abilities use staves or unarmed. Equip trickery as your second ability from the rogue. Now, you can either wield a staff or be unarmed and be able to use all the monk abilities, or waste a passive making yourself able to equip daggers, equip a dagger and be able to use most of the rogue abilities. If you do the first, you have all the monk abilities, but only can only use steal from the rogue. And for the latter, you can use the rogue abilities, but only meditate for the monk. I have no idea why this was designed like this, but it feels awful, and massively incentivizes primarily using magic classes for secondaries, as magic isn't tied to weapons.

Overall, I just got worn out by the game. I set it down to take a break, and realized that I not only had no desire to come back to it, I was really dreading playing more. So no, I can't recommend this one.

I really really wanted to like this game. But there were a few mechanical choices that really brought it down in my opinion.

The first is build variety. Having so many classes implies the idea of having a lot of room to experiment with a character's growth and build. But many martial class skills are locked to a specific weapon, rendering them useless when used as a subclass. Magic does not have this issue. It feels bad to get a new class that fits the stat spread of one of your characters and simply be unable to combine it with anything else you have. 

Secondly, while the game boasts no random encounters, they are very hard to avoid on the map. Not only that, but they are rather punishing (at least on Hard mode, which I was playing on). They range between brutal to monotonous, where they are a puzzle that need to be solved and once you do, you simply repeat the same optimized process on them to victory. This isn't really an issue, but this leads into my next issue.

When you save and quit the game, you are returned to a save point check point rather than where you quit the game. Furthermore, these save points do not heal your party. Many times I found myself able to play for short session, I make it part way through a location and save and quit. Only to be ported back to the start with all of my used resources gone. I would replace them but..

Everything in the game is very very expensive. If you buy consumables, good luck getting gear upgrades. Without the gear good luck not getting trounced in fights. Even grinding for the money doesn't feel to be a viable option because the fights pay out so little compared to the costs.

The platforming is fun, but I rarely found the rewards for doing so worth it unless it was the core path to a dungeon or boss. The mount system is fun to add platforming abilities like a metroidvania, but you constantly need to swap between them and doing so through even the favorite menu is a pain.

Again, I really wanted to enjoy this game. but by the time I finished the desert it was just too much of a slog.

Cons: [b]#1.[/b] No mouse support (which makes overworld movement obtuse and menu navigation even more obtuse).
[b]#2.[/b] Huge lack of information provided to the player, like when creating your party at the start of the game, or when selecting the difficulty setting, there's almost no information provided.
[b]#3.[/b] No reliable fast travel to previously visited locations / towns.
[b]#4.[/b] A gigantic amount of platforming.
[b]#5.[/b] If you save at a savepoint, and load that save, you're taken back to your single 'home point' instead of spawning at the location where you saved. This makes no sense.

If a reliable form of fast travelling was implemented, then perhaps I could bring myself to shifting my overall opinion to slightly positive, but honestly, the lack of fast travel is going to waste hours and hours of your life in the game, and that's something I can't abide by (I'm not talking about the 11shrines in the game, those don't even take you to 10% of the places you'd want to go, like Nan's place or the fishing place, etc.)... I simply value my time too much to spend it backtracking for hours. I'd honestly rather replay Earthlock or FF9 than play this game anymore. I'll check back in a year or so to see if #1 & #3 was fixed atleast, perhaps then I'll give it another go

Ok... I really want to like the game, and find the openness very interesting... BUT (in my short time playing) literally 70% of all my time is just spent on jumping puzzles. It's cute having a couple secrets be tough to jump to, but literally progressing all my quests and areas is based on jumping puzzles (with a map that doesnt rotate). I just spent 45 minutes trying to get a final dog bone that I can see, but never figured out how to jump to it.
It had some clever ideas but ultimately it felt more and more like a slog to get through.

I like everything about this game except for the overworld. There's a job system! There are unlockable classes! There are no random encounters! Unfortunately, none of that matters when you're lost: you're just going to spend hours wandering around on an empty map. I don't have the patience for that. At least give us a hint of where to go, please.

2025-03-09 - I love almost everything about this game, so much so that I struggled through the parts that annoy me, or that I strongly dislike: The huge, empty world with no direction is tedious, but you can at least keep a guide open in another window. The platforming challenges are awful, especially when you can't see the xyz coordinates of where you're supposed to be jumping, so you just have to guess, die, and try again; but at least the Auto Jump option helps in some instances. But what I hate is how, at the very end of the game, in the final dungeon, there's an unskippable platforming/ice block challenge which is longer and more difficult than just about any other obstacle in the game. If you start this game, you might not be able to finish it, but you won't know until you've wasted dozens of hours.
It's to hard for beginner and casual game
Way too much platforming and going in circles tryin'a figure out which way to go.

I'm saying thumbs down. Because it calls itself a non-linear JRPG which sounds great. But really, it's a platforming metroidvania. The JRPG elements are great and I'm impressed when people can skip entire sections, but I just get lost easily in the game. And I wanted the blue mage's abilities to be shared across new blue mages!

Only rewarding to those with a jumping fetish. 

The zen appeal is quickly ruined by the serious lack of purpose in anything that you are doing. 

Great idea, and cool that the dev did it solo but..... should've hired some help for story content.

Despite all of the vertical endeavors available to engage in, this game is as flat as it gets.
I was enjoying the battle and job system, but my enjoyment was ruined by the platforming. Could have been something special. Truly a shame.

Though the review is listed as "not recommended", that's mainly because I have very high standards. You might like this if the things I mention aren't as negative for you.

Crystal Project was a game recommended to me as an RPG with Metroidvania elements, similar to Wine & Roses and Teenage Costume Squad. I've long thought a commercial-length version of those games would be the best thing ever, so I jumped at the chance to try this.

Unfortunately, the game is just a standard open-world RPG and not the kind of tactical-Metroidvania experience I was hoping for. It has Metroidvania elements, but they're entirely based on traditional Metroidvania principles of overcoming physical barriers, not tactical ones. I wasn't blindsided because the game's description was pretty clear about this, but it was still disappointing. It managed to be good for what it was, but falls into many of the usual problems with both jRPGs and open-world games.

So. The first thing you will notice is that the game looks like Minecraft, which is to say, butt-ugly. I'm told that this art style is called "voxel" (short for "volumetric pixel"). I presume the hideous block style of RPG Maker VX was either a precursor or attempted emulation of this. It's slightly better than RMVX on account of being actually 3D, but it's still hideous and I remain baffled why anyone would willingly make a game in this graphical style. (All those sharp edges, eugh.)

The second thing you will notice is that this game is also a platformer. There is a dedicated jump button and you are forced to use it constantly. Every area is absurdly vertical and demands platforming in order for you to get anywhere; and yes, you'd be correct in assuming this means every area is a minefield of one-way drops. If you fail a platforming challenge, you better hope you set a teleport point near where you started because otherwise you will be spending 5 minutes trekking back there. (The game even has a character joke about this, because it thinks joking about its terrible design decisions makes up for it.) This makes exploration -- you know, the key feature of any Metroidvania or open world -- an absolute chore constantly interrupted by resets instead of any kind of smooth, organic experience. Even the Mario RPGs don't have this much platforming; we did not need this.

Oh, and you can't freely warp between save points, so you'll have to do tons of backtracking regardless. There's an easy mode that magnanimously extends the number of warp points you can store from one to three, which barely helps. The only justification I could possibly see for this is to prevent you from warping to an inn and then back in the middle of a dungeon, except the shrine stones let you do that anyway so there is really no point to this other than wasting the player's time.

If you can get past all of this you can finally start playing the actual game, which is a class-changing jRPG a la Final Fantasy V. Each class has a unique set of abilities, and you can additionally assign the skillset of one other class. Winning battles as a class gets you class experience as well as regular experience, and you can spend class experience to learn new skills. In principle this is all well and good; in practice it's a grindfest because there are way, way too many classes, to the point that your starting classes outnumber your total party members. I really wish we were given a fifth party member to give you just a bit more wiggle room on this. It doesn't help that the class roles are very lopsided -- there are a bajillion offensive casters, several tanks and fighters, and like... two support casters.

The game is also a grindfest in the normal way, too, because as with all jRPGs each area has only 3 or 4 encounters copied dozens of times. To make matters worse, enemies have extremely rigid AI that almost always uses the exact same actions every time, so there are never any curveballs; if you beat an encounter once, the same series of actions will win that encounter again (barring random confounders like misses and crits). Battles quickly become tedious and frustrating due to all the repetition, which is a shame because a lot of enemies have genuinely clever behavior patterns that reward thoughtful counterplay; but, well, you only need to solve a puzzle once. And again as with all jRPGs, 90% of battle is determined on the equip screen, so even if you do know the correct solution to a fight you may not be able to execute it because you forgot to bring the right classes or equipment into the fight, so back to the last save point with you, sucker!

And now we get into the open world aspect, which has the exact same problem as [i]Pokemon Scarlet & Violet[/i]: There is no level scaling, so there is still a linear, intended route you're supposed to play in, just no indication of what that route is. To its credit the game is much better about nudging you towards the right path than S&V (and you can see before a battle how strong the enemies are in relation to you), but there were still multiple times when I slogged through a brutal dungeon only to find myself steamrolling everything in the next one because, oops, turns out I was supposed to do those in the opposite order. I think in principle it's good to give players the freedom to challenge themselves by doing things out of order, but it really shouldn't be possible to do that accidentally.

Of course, even when you do travel along the intended path you will be flattened into paste by the encounters because the game is also absurdly punishing. It's more reasonable in the early game, but once you're past the introductory section enemies will regularly two-shot your characters right at the start of battle, and by the endgame they will frequently oneshot them by doing more damage than they have max HP. This is made worse by an aggro system that ensures they will focus-fire on whoever did the most damage (i.e. your caster); the tank classes are supposed to control this, but enemies also love to spam defense-piercing attacks, so this usually amounts to your tank surviving a single hit at critical health instead of being instantly reduced to giblets, and that's it. Your healer has to be constantly spamming the heal-all spell when they're not desperately reviving people, which is just a deeply unfun way to play. I do not want one of my four characters locked into doing a single action the entire fight, thanks. Most of your strategy involves disabling enemies so that they can't attack you at all, because it's that or instant death with no middle ground.

Another common RPG element the game uses that I hate: Refusing to decouple quantitative and qualitative equipment bonuses. You like inflicting poison with your weapon attacks? Too bad, that weapon falls below the curve once you enter the midgame. There are so many interesting equipment effects and I especially liked how weapon skills retained the add-on effects of your weapons, but they're all rendered obsolete by the power curve far too quickly.

It's a shame, because I do feel there are good elements here. The diversity of the classes is impressive, and I particularly liked how they managed to make rogues feel mechanically distinct from fighters. Enemies will throw some pretty weird stuff at you and it's fun to think about how you're supposed to use your tools to counter them. Oh, and items are restricted to one class (Final Fantasy Tactics style), so in-battle MP management actually matters! I just wish those clever ideas didn't have to be chained to such tedious, repetitive, punishing gameplay. jRPGs need to break out of the genre conventions that have held them hostage for so long and realize that challenges need to be placed tactically, like in every other genre, not copy-pasted willy-nilly as if that's a substitute for real gameplay.

A fast, tactile VR FPS that channels a Counter-Strike-like energy: tight rounds, bomb plants/defuses, and clutch moments, translated into full-body presence. Manual mag handling, bolt pulls, and sight alignment make every reload and peek feel earned.

Gameplay & Mechanics — 8/10
Snappy gunfeel with satisfying manual reloading and clear hit feedback. Movement options cover stick locomotion and smooth turning; room-scale peeking around corners is a genuine edge. Occasional jank and the learning curve on weapon handling can spike early deaths, but mastery is rewarding.

Modes & Content — 8/10
Classic Search & Destroy sits alongside a grab bag of community favorites (TTT, Zombies, WW2, Gun Game). The workshop/custom servers are the secret sauce - maps and modes keep the playlist fresh, though quality varies server to server.

Presentation & Audio — 8/10
Clean visuals for quick reads under headset constraints; positional audio and proximity voice chat add tension (and hilarious chaos). Not a visual showpiece, but it prioritizes clarity where it counts.

Comfort & Accessibility — 7/10
Smooth locomotion can challenge VR newcomers; comfort tweaks help, but motion-sickness-prone players may need shorter sessions. Weapon manipulation is immersive but demands practice and decent controller tracking.

Conclusion
Pavlov VR is a fun, Counter-Strike-like arena shooter made better by VR’s hands-on gunplay and a thriving custom scene. It’s not the most polished or guided experience, but if you want competitive rounds with real-world reloading and endless community variety, it delivers.

Breaks my heart to not recommend this game, but it's just simply dead at this point.

The game thrived on mods with players making crazy custom modes and maps. You could easily lose yourself for hours in the variety. The devs made the decision to move everything to UE 5, and in the process essentially nullified all existing mods. The issue with doing that to a game that's been out for a while is that a lot of the modders aren't actively keeping things up to date, so we lost all the COD zombie maps and have only gotten 1 or two back a WHILE later after some dedicated modders revived them.

So in short, the devs attempt to shore up the game is the very thing that ended up breaking everything good about it, which has led to an exodus of the playerbase. At this point, its maybe one or two populated servers, and then a ton of private lobbies and empty lobbies. And sadly, I can't blame them. Keep in mind, this game made the move to UE 5 in summer of 2023. Plenty of time to fix it up for the modding community, so this is not just a matter of impatience but an active decision to stall / not consider it.

Since the update, i've installed the game twice in the last year to see where it's at, and sadly it seems mostly everything has stopped dead in Feb. No new mods really, no new dev updates, no new mod kit expansions to allow for the people still playing to save it. Save your money and just accept that you missed out on this title when it was king, and if you pick it up now it will be a shell of it's former self.

If you bought a VR headset to play on PC and are considering Pavlov as your first VR FPS, here’s my honest review. The game itself is very well-made, offering solid mechanics and immersive gunplay, but the experience you’ll actually have depends heavily on who you’re playing with and that’s where things start to fall apart.

First off, most of the PC servers are practically dead. The player base is much smaller compared to the Pavlov Shack version on Quest, which means finding active and populated lobbies can be a struggle. Even when you do find one, Pavlov isn’t beginner-friendly at all. The community tends to be impatient and impulsive in modes like TTT, players will often kill you for no reason, with little to no cooperation or understanding for newcomers.

If you’re new, you’ll likely find it frustrating trying to compete against experienced players who play daily and have the right equipment. It’s hard to have fun when the learning curve feels more punishing than engaging.

Because of that, I’d only recommend Pavlov if you plan to play with a group of your own friends. Playing with randoms from the community is rarely a pleasant or viable option. The game has great potential and craftsmanship, but without a stable, welcoming player base, it ends up feeling more isolating than enjoyable.

The player base is also dwindling in numbers. Not worth getting in 2025. I would recommend Contractors instead because it actually has lots of good mods and no performance issues.

Disappointing Performance and Accessibility Issues

I was really looking forward to trying Pavlov VR, but unfortunately the performance issues made it hard to enjoy.
Even with an RTX 3070 and a Ryzen 9 3950X, the game runs very poorly — with frequent stutters and inconsistent frame rates. It feels heavily unoptimized for what it offers.

The tutorial does an okay job at teaching the basics like movement and shooting, but it doesn’t go much deeper.
I also struggled to find a way back to the main menu — after several minutes of searching, the only solution I found was to close and restart the game.

Because of these problems, I didn’t even make it to the multiplayer part, which was the main reason I bought the game. Hopefully future updates will improve the performance and usability, because it seems like there’s potential underneath all the technical issues.

Pavlov [i] used [/i] to be a really good VR shooter. Fun gunplay and generally good vr mechanics, but most importantly, REALLY good mods. It had custom maps like Dust2, Rust, etc, along with my personal favorites, the CoDZ maps such as Origins with working staffs and BO2 weapons like the Hamr and Raygun Mark II.

Key word, [i] used [/i] to be. One day, the devs decided to update their game to allow crossplay, which changed the way modding worked, being that it wasn't supported on the workshop anymore on the newest version and instead moved to a different website. Normally, this would be fine, and it was since you could simply play on an older version of Pavlov to keep playing with the workshop mods you liked. People who wanted to play the vanilla game/could only play the vanilla game on PlayStation could play the newer, maintained version, and people who wanted to play with mods could play the older, unmaintained version, and not have to worry about old mods that are complete, or whose authors have stopped playing Pavlov disappearing.

But one day, the devs removed the older version from the Steam betas, essentially deleting all of the older mods that haven't been updated, and may never be updated. Some people kept playing the game for those mods, and some people bought the game for those mods, and now most of them are gone.

Instead of updating the legacy version to fix any game breaking issues or vulnerabilities or simply leaving it alone to let the community fix it, they essentially erased a lot of the game's history, and the reason for a good chunk of the playerbase's reason to keep playing along with it, and they didn't even remove the workshop from the community tab or add a warning that the game doesn't support the workshop anymore, which could lead to someone buying the game for something that doesn't exist anymore.

This game is a shadow of its former self, and they don't even give you the option to play the game in a version you enjoyed offline, let alone with friends or on a community server.

This game used to be amazing, but I just can't recommend it after the devs' decisions.

I purchased the game in 2020 and Post Scriptum quickly became one of my favorite games of all time. Superior to the laughable arcade mess that Hell Let Loose became near the end of its early access and beyond. 

Unfortunately, I really can't recommend the game in its current state. The new devs have made some irritating changes, especially to logistics, that killed the game for many players. The changes led to an exodus from what was once a great WW2 milsim. Many days, you'll be lucky to see 1 full server running.

It had a great run, but the devs seem determined to kill off the last few of us who were dedicated to the niche. I suppose a thumbs up for the great times over the years, but I cannot recommend this game to anyone unless the devs pull a 180 which is unlikely. The last of the community is hanging by a thread.

Squad 44 is generally a good game but it has a good amount of flaws, some good things are the graphics, it looks amazing, the gun play is pretty enjoyable and the maps layout is really fabulous in my opinion. There is more but that's just what came off the top of my head. The flaws though are numerous and really ruin the experience if you are not willing to look past it. Optimisation can get horrible as most Offworld games has shown numerous times, the game play is repetitive with it being constantly the same way of playing over and over, with barely anything new happening in that way also there are different game modes but they are to similar or just never used which brings me into my next point. The servers are abysmal, there is almost zero players on in weekdays, and weekends only have one or two with at most 50 players. These servers are also shit its always the same maps, France and operation market garden which can get so boring, I have not played the D-Day map which is the one that I wanted to play the most, also I have not played as the Australian's which I also want as a Aussie myself and the new pacific maps I have barely played but when i did i found them the most enjoyable. Battle of the bulge has seemed to disappear from the roster also there is a voting system setting in servers but only one of them has it that I have seen but hasn't had players in ages. All this is caused also by how you have to pay to make servers so only large communities can really make them. Offworld has also not made any official servers which would be better in my opinion as they could make a official server in each campaign so you don't have to wait for it to pop up, or just make servers free to make. But all this is useless if our community is so small. I would recommend this because if we had more people it would make it a better game in general but that's just me being selfish because I really want to like and enjoy this game. Any disagreement's feel free to comment.
fun game with a good community, not a lot of players but you can find a lobby that is pretty much always full and still gets updates so thats a plus

Squad 44 is a tactical WW2 shooter. As an avid enjoyer of first person shooters, this is really fun once you get into combat situations. Its not a spectacle like Call of Duty or Battlefield. Instead, its much closer to Hell Let Loose. 

Unfortunately, new players like me who are not experienced with realistic shooters struggle to properly engage in these battles. Another issue is that there aren't enough servers in asia which makes it hard for me to play the game at a smooth performance because of the high ping. The game's file size is also clearly large.

Still, I find that the gameplay is very engaging. Guns are responsive and close quarters combat is intense. The game also has a wide selection of weapons and vehicles to choose from, so the game is great for you if you're into tanks. The game doesn't look that good compared to modern AAA titles but it holds itself well. 
Buy this game when it discounts by 50% or more if you are into realistic shooters.

TLDR: HLL is the 'Rising Storm' of WW2 milsim while Squad 44 is like a hardcore version of regular Squad with better maps more realistic details and it takes place in WW2. Both are good games but HLL is more arcadey and sacrifices realism for console friendly gameplay

Squad 44 is an outstanding World War II tactical shooter that captures the chaos and camaraderie of large-scale warfare like few games can. Every match feels like stepping onto a living battlefield, with massive 50v50 fights where teamwork isn’t optional—it’s survival. The authenticity is incredible: weapons have weight, vehicles require coordination, and communication through proximity and squad chat pulls you right into the action. It’s not just about shooting; it’s about building defenses, holding lines, and pushing objectives as a unit. Playing with a well-organized squad is unforgettable—you feel the tension of storming trenches, the relief of repelling assaults, and the adrenaline of clutching a point in the last seconds. The sound design is chillingly real, from artillery barrages to the crack of rifles whizzing past. Squad 44 isn’t an arcade shooter; it’s immersive, tactical, and demands cooperation. For anyone who craves authenticity, teamwork, and large-scale WW2 combat, it’s absolutely amazing.

The fact that Offworld bought this game and changed the name just destroyed their own reputation. Putting the Squad44 title on the game the previous developers abandoned is not good for the studio. Like what was so wrong with the name Post Scriptum? Now when I see this game and the failure it has become I cant help but think negatively of Squad ( the actually halfway decent game). This game somehow does the class systems worse than in Squad, and it's already stupid in that game too. Maps are impossible to read and the icons/overlays are not easily discernible. No one ever knows what to do or where to go. That's to say IF you can even find a server with enough people to actually play. As soon as Hell Let Loose releases a Pacific Theater where we can play as Japs and US Marines, no one will care about this game. Offworld should've left this one alone and spent their resources on the Starship Troopers game. I am tired of seeing ads for this game, I already own it, I know it's a dead game, been this way for years. The fact that they're still pushing ads for it is downright slimey in my opinion. Anyone who buys the game will have nothing to do, no one to play with, and ultimately have their money stolen from them. Let this one go, move onto the next one. All this being said, it's truly sad to say. The game looks and sounds good when it's not bugging out. It's basically a slightly more hardcore version of Hell Let Loose but with the stupid squad role mechanics from their other Squad game. It just failed to maintain a community and keep people in it.  Hopefully they can recover from this one and make their next project better.

I once loved this game called Post Scriptum and used to play it a lot, hence the 1k hours I sank into it. But in the current State it is just unplayable. There is a multitude of Bugs like hearing Engine noises everywhere on the map as if they are right next to me or not hearing gunfire and explosions at all. Additionally, the performance dropped significantly to low fps and frequent stutters. The worst thing for me is that the severity and number of problems I ran into in a single match didn’t occur to me in hundreds of hours playing Post Scriptum.

To me it seems that the players with lots of experience and an interest in good high level teamplay have disappeared. I just recently had a match where the squad leader was a member of the Clan hosting the Server but still didn’t bother to lead or at least communicate with his Squad. This decline in the community is fatal for a game where teamplay and good leadership is the key of having fun. And instead of Offworld trying to get these people back they only use the old Squad strategy of making a free weekend which floods the Servers with guys having no idea what they are doing and giving the experienced players only the chance to lock themselves into private groups or quit playing until the flood has stopped. Adding to the bad shape of the community is that when someone dared to state this fact he got immediately attacked verbally by the loyal Zealots of Squad44.

Besides the Bugs, Offworld also managed, under the premise of fixing Spaghetti Code, to strip Post Scriptum of most of the things that made it unique. It had, other than Squad, a free building System making the logistic squads extremely capable in offense and defense, but they needed to fix that and implement the system from Squad. They also felt the need to implement the suppression system from Squad(which decides to work on the premise of how it could annoy you the most), removed the timer form the Rally Points (I know they are called Regroup Calls, but I have yet to find someone calling them by that name) making the Radioman nearly obsolete. And in general, they seemed to just Squadify the game wherever possible without thinking about the consequences. Like the time when they removed the MSPs or increased the player cap for Servers without them being able to handle it, which still results in bad hit registration for infantry weapons. They also kept introducing more uncommon vehicles like the Jagdtiger to the game, while the charm of Post Scriptum was that it felt like two regular units were fighting against each other with Shermans and Cromwells against Panzer 3 and 4s. I wouldn’t be surprised if they went ahead and added a Maus in the future.

I am shaken to say it, but this game is nothing like the game I once loved and with Offworld at the helm, I fear that they will only add new shiny ‘content’ instead of fixing the bugs, improving the performance and making the gameplay loop fun again. It seems to me that Post Scriptum is dead and Squad44 has killed it only to use its soulless husk to milk the WW2 enjoyers. So I can only say thank you Offworld for not just killing one but two games that I used to love.

If you're looking for something Rimworld-adjacent, this will do the trick. There's no world map or world travel, and the options for building and manufacturing are a bit more limited, but the addition of a Z-dimension (mining down and building up) is greatly appreciated.

Also, there's cannibalism, which is always a laugh.

Q. Why are the cannibals in this game so angry?
A. Because they're fed up with people.

This is my first step into the Rimworld esc game and I've really enjoyed it. I was stuck between the two but AC gives you a demo that entertained me and a few others for 7hrs. I can't compare this to Rimworld, but it explains most things, and others can be figured out along the way. It seeems to just be a perfect rendition of Rimworlds Early days, but with a sweet integrated Coop.

The coop: 
Each player starts with their own colony, but on the same Map. You can play solo or as allies, or you can Semi integrate your colonies and share resources with trades. (You can not control each others colonies / use each others resources etc.)

I REALLY like this Coop integration.

AColony is a good colony sim. Base defense, research, trading, meeting colonists needs, resource gathering, base building, etc., is all here and it runs well. A good 3D colony sim is hard to come by and even though it's in early access, this may be the best one on the market. The level of polish and attention to detail shows that this developer truly understands what makes the genre fun and engaging. 

But the name.... it's not doing this game any favors. A very basic lore primer and a name that shows even a bit of effort goes a very long way toward garnering attention in this genre. The developer is "ZeroTris". Off the top of my head "Zero Colony" or "Colony Zero" would be an insanely better name than "A Colony". The name makes it sound like a side project or a project that's only made to generate some quick cash before being abandoned.

Okay, I'm done ranting about the terrible name slapped onto a very good game. I have no opinion about co-op because I have no desire to play a colony sim in multiplayer after realizing it detracts from the experience for me after trying it in other games. I want to build my colony and play my way without someone interfering in my plans. As a single player experience, this game is polished for its current state and fun.

This game takes time and effort. Me and my Friend have been grinding since the release of the Demo and bought it the next day. The game itself is super relaxing yet stressful in times.

The dev is very responsive in his discord and super helpful and willing to implement QOL changes to the game based of the community.

super fun gameplay mechanics and i would definitively recommend this to anyone who like colony simulation or survival games, even in early access, the content available to explore is rich and sure to keep you occupied for hours. 

However, certain frustrating aspects of this game have had me pulling my hair and screaming at my colonists for a big part of my gameplay and these aspects could easily be fixed. 

First off is the priority system. When given an order, colonists should remember it and it should take priority over other tasks. Colonists who are supposed to eat or sleep will start you order and dismiss it to go do something else completely forgetting your order and making your re-order them multiple times for one single action. maybe also consider adding the option to queue actions. these would only be useful when colonists need to do something urgent that does not fall inside their assigned tasks. when you tell a colonist to flee he should flee. not walk one step and go back into combat. when i tell a sleeping colonist to do something he should do it not go back to bed after walking out of it. 

please consider unifying the overlapping two priority systems. there should not be so many places where priorities can be tweeked as it greatly hinders gameplay and makes troubleshooting really hard when colonists arnt doing what you desire. keep it all in one place please.

mental breakdowns happen too fast. i've lost count of the times i added a single colonist and before i could make the changes every other colonist desired, one would have a breakdown attack the wrong targent and start a whole insect attack on the base at the worst possible moment. in two days of gameplay i have found myself and my co-op partner reloading our save file over 20 times because of un-salvageable situations created by when colonists did something catastrophic and we where not watching for 2 seconds.

Why does my co-op partner get notifications for gang attacks targeting me but not insect attacks ?

This game is so much fun and i cannot wait for the game play experience to be less frustrating and smoother

RE7 is an incredible survival horror game. Of all of the Resident Evil games that I have played, it contains the least action, but is better for it, as it really shines best when exploring its dark, twisted setting. The best section of the game involves going through the large Baker house - a dilapidated estate in Louisiana Bayou. It's a truly inspired setting, and Capcom nailed the Southern Horror vibe incredibly well - it's extremely authentic and believable. The attention to detail is amazing, and it's the most memorable haunted house/house of horrors setting in any media that I've been exposed to. The story is excellent, and very intriguing, as you piece together why Ethan is there, what's really going on, and what happened to the Baker family. They're extremely memorable villains and very menacing as well. Also, even nearly 9 years after release, at the time of writing, the game looks incredible. Up close, some of the character models are showing age, but in the moment-to-moment, the visual fidelity is awesome and the performance is incredible. I also enjoyed the 1st person setting much more than I thought I would - I think it's absolutely necessary for the kind of game they crafted, and it is more immersive than the 3rd person RE games, by necessity, as that's really what you're getting here - a very engaging and immersive horror experience.

after almost 140h pretty much, since i also played it on console, i can honestly recommend re7 with my whole chest; it’s one of those games that somehow manages to be creepy as hell but still kinda.. soothing? like you’re walking around this disgusting mold-infested nightmare house, but your brain’s just locked into that “ok let me solve this entire building like it’s one giant nerd puzzle” mode. the pacing hits that perfect spot too: chaos one minute, then you’re standing there staring at a weird shadow puzzle feeling like einstein because you rotated a plastic bird correctly. the whole game turns into this satisfying loop of “survive, explore, uh oh, puzzle time,” and it scratches that exact itch of horror mixed with logic.
idk, it’s just one of those games where even when you’re stressed, you’re vibing,  like a cozy panic. and if you’re a puzzle/atmosphere nerd like me, it’s honestly peak

I think this game has a pretty middling story, a pretty terrible protagonist, and it sort of falls off in the second half. There are no puzzles which go beyond ‘find three different colored things to open the thing door,’ and there is almost nothing in this game which does not exist outside of decades old, well established horror tropes.

Despite all of that, this game is STILL A BANGER. Yeah my wife is a bitch and has crazy spaghetti hair, I don’t even give a damn its still a banger. Yeah the second half is much worse than the first half, you know what other game has an even worse second half? DARK SOULS, and that game? Yeah chat, you guessed it, BANGER.

Ethan Winters is a dipshit and I cannot excuse his actions but the rest of the cast are really good. Jack Baker is so scary and his actor put in 110% effort, getting chased by him can wildy swing between pee-my-pants terrifying and pee-my-pants funny. Him laughing and giggling while stalking you, and going “I seeee youuuuuu!” when he spots you, what an incredible character and enemy design. (Ethan ruins it, of course, whenever he opens his mouth but Jack is still my goat.)

Past Jack, it is not quite as good, but still enjoyable. Big ups to Margy, I killed that damn bug bitch but she seemed nice. Lucas is a shithead who pussed out after I got through all his coward ass traps but thats okay I forgive him. I actually found the decision between my wife (i think her name was Mia, idk) and Zoe to be difficult. Let me lay it out for you.

Mia Pros:
My Wife
Kissed me
Known her for many years

Mia Cons: 
Weird Spaghetti hair
Lied to me about being secret umbrella agent (cringe)
Cut my hand off (wtf babe)


Zoe Pros:
Funny
Normal human hair (huge)
Helps me out the whole time
Sense of humour (funny 2)

Zoe Cons:
From Louisiana (weird accent)
Not as funny as Jack (but nobody is, so not big deal)

In the end, I picked my wife because the other one dies anyway and my choice doesn’t matter, but it was a real moral conundrum for a moment there.
Back to that funny thing, I think RE7 balances horror and levity really well, offsetting tense moments with spots of relief or humor, and then doubling down on the anxiety. This game is crazy spooky, and has some of the best audio design ever. The first few hours I had to take a break every 15 minutes because you are just hearing weird shit all of the time, and can’t tell exactly how far away it is; just some of the best atmosphere building in any game ever. 

The music is great, the characters are really well performed (fuck you ethan) and the house is very big and very cool. I think I am going to remember this house for years to come, each and every inch of it has been etched into my mind.

So in the end, yeah, you can poke a bunch of holes in it, and critique it to shreds if you want, but instead of being a big nerd and analysing everything, I will say that I really enjoyed my experience of playing this game, and I won’t forget it for many years.

There's a lot to say about this game. Firstly, its not like any other Resident Evil game, it's so far from the familiarity of heavy action-packed gameplay and instead focusses solely on horror, horror and horror. Biohazard 7 truly broke the mould (no pun intended) of what everyone knew the franchise was about. Aesthetically, gameplay-wise, narratively, everything about this has been carefully crafted to be it's own independent story without too much reference to the other games. This is perfect, it's a breath of fresh air and grounds the player in the world that they're in through the eyes of Ethan Winters. We're not just playing as Ethan Winters, we feel like we are Ethan Winters weaving our way through a great story with just the right amount of exposition, tension, action, and emotion.

There are hardcore fans of the Resident Evil franchise who have been there since the beginning and express their discomfort with the new direction this game took. It's so different that it doesn't actually feel like a Resident Evil title, but instead an actual horror game like Silent Hill, Still Wakes the Deep, Find Yourself, etc etc. Whether you like the game or not depends. Do you want another heavily action packed resident evil with boulder-punching Chris Redfield with an ocean of bullets, or do you want something fresh, subtle, with amazing narrative and story?

Personally, I think this is by far the best Resident Evil title ever. Though, that's mostly because the game rejuvenated the franchise and attracted new fans which contributed to the popularity of the remakes and new titles after that. That and the fact that the game is just perfect. It's a beautiful gem. If I had to give first place to any other Resident Evil game, it would be Resident Evil 4 remake, then RE8 Village and then RE2 remake.

This game is amazing and everyone should try it whether you like horror, are a resident evil fan or neither. The game is just that good.
The game that revived the franchise back to it's horror roots.

I've been a long time Resident Evil fan and have played basically all of them except for some of the more obscure ones. With that in mind, I honestly think that 7 was a fine addition to the franchise and made for a unique and enjoyable experience. Scuffed Chris Redfield notwithstanding of course. I just recently played through this game again and enjoyed it just as much as I initially did. When the game was first announced, I was admittedly skeptical that the game's formula wouldn't translate well to a first person perspective, but I was pleasantly surprised that it worked well. Of course, it doesn't play like your average Call of Battlefield CE FPS so don't expect slide canceling and drop shotting. What you'll get is a good first person horror experience that is a fun ride in a unique setting. I give this game 7 Chris Redfield Boulder Punches out of 7.

Resident Evil 7 completely blew me away. Coming from playing the older RE games and being amazed at their action and scale, stepping into RE7 felt like entering a whole new era of Resident Evil — and I LOVED every second of it.

The story is insane in the best way possible. The mystery of the Baker family, the creepy atmosphere, the plot twists, and finding out the truth behind Eveline… bro, I was hooked the entire time. Every reveal just made me go “NO WAY, so SHE was behind all this!?”

The gameplay is tight and genuinely scary. The first-person perspective hits different — it puts you right in Ethan’s shoes. Exploring the Baker house felt like being inside a horror movie. The tension, the footsteps, the doors slowly opening… damn. Peak horror.

I also loved how the characters operate in this game. Jack chasing you down the hallway like he owns the place, Marguerite with her creepy insect powers, Lucas being a psycho genius… and Ethan? That dude is HIM. The man takes more damage than any human should and still keeps going just to save Mia. Respect.

And bro — the guns feel AMAZING. The shotgun slaps, the pistol feels crisp, and every upgrade hits hard. When you finally get fully geared? You feel like a badass walking through hell to end everything.

Overall, Resident Evil 7 reminded me why this franchise is GOATED. It’s terrifying, emotional, intense, and unforgettable. If you love horror, story, and pure Resident Evil vibes, this is a masterpiece.

10/10 — Eveline tried to control me but she can’t control my love for this game.

THIS GAME SUCKS!

Alright now that I have your attention. I'd rate the game a 5/10 maybe lower for a few reasons. The game not pausing while in menus adds to the tension but it doesn't really work with RE, I hate the blocking mechanic and never was able to get it down and the game just feels dated in some areas. I am a fan of the compliment sandwich system though so I'll say some things I like to begin and end.

[SPOILERS AHEAD]

The story is AMAZING and honestly was the only thing that got me through the later 3/4ths of the game. You really feel for the victims of this story unlike other RE games where you just shoot them with no remorse it's the only RE game that delved into the humanity of what is actually happening. The puzzles too were great! They managed to do so much with so little space and it was a perfect master class YET AGAIN on how to do perfect survival horror level design.

Everything after the main house sucks and I would never replay any of it. Jack is the KING of this game and his section is the only fun one. His boss fights are amazing and make you go "OH WHAT THE F-" more than once while fighting him plus there are multiple ways to beat him. It's no secret that all the first zones in RE games get more love (The RPD, Downtown Raccoon City, The Village in RE4, and Castle Dimitrescu) but this game has it the worst by far.

Marguerite's section and boss fight suck, the bugs are annoying to fight, the puzzles and level design in her section suck
I'd never play Lucas's section again, it was predictable at best and horrific at worst.
THE BOAT BLOWS ASS. Straight poop like there is nothing to save this zone it goes on for way to long. "Oh hey! Lets make the player play through THE WHOLE SHIP in this VHS tape... THEN MAKE THEM DO IT AGAIN!" Like there is no point it just kills an hour of your time.
The salt mines is just a ammo dumb and F you if you don't have enough
I was this close to quitting on all of these sections. The amount of times I'd go "bet this annoying thing is about to happen" then it happened was horrible.

The DLC's are horrible, Bedroom and Daughters are amazing all the others suck. 21 is "fine" if you aren't going for the achievements. Ethan Must Die and Jack's 55th Birthday are just there to pad out time and Nightmare is just a hoard shooter. Not A Hero and End Of Zoe are both pretty good but leave a lot of plot holes and clearly needed more time in the oven to be perfect, I really think either could have been as good if not better than the whole game but lacked behind sadly. You really wan't me to believe LUCAS was the mastermind of the whole thing and was in connections with a international terrorist organization? Yeah right! Eve was just chill with being sold again? Or was he somehow strong enough to overcome the mind control? They don't explain any of this. Jack comes back in End Of Zoe which is crazy, you can tell it's him too before the big reveal because they used the same animations.

GOD FORBID you try and 100% this game like I did. There is the standard challenge of like "Read All Files" or "Break All The Mr. Everywhere Dolls" but HOLY this was the worst. I have 100% RE2, RE3, RE4, and RE8 and out of all of them this was the worst. The others were fun all the way through but this sucked. So many are challenges in the DLCs and others are just annoying to pad out time, locking an achievement behind "Ethan Must Die" I wanna force whoever came up with that to sit down and play that until they get it because there is NO WAY they have it.

Eve is horribly written. I don't feel bad for her, I don't care about her, I don't understand her. She is meant to be like the Bakers where you feel bad for her by the end of the story but she just sucks. She comes across as an annoying spoiled princess and that isn't what she is meant to be. She is meant to be a traumatized kid who doesn't understand the world, she is scared and just wants a loving family. She instead comes across like "Father I want a pony NOW!". She is just a posh prick that lacks anything interesting and I actually think she is the most annoying character in every single RE game I have played AND I WENT THROUGH HELL WITH ORIGINAL ASHLEY. She is just annoying and I can't take her seriously at all, it is a shame she is the main villain in the story (But wait actually it's Lucas as a DLC shows off like wtf?) because she lacks anything interesting with her. She is just a brat and I hate it.

The horror is on point though! A lot of the time I was too annoyed or frustrated to be scared but if you enjoy the game I can see it being the scariest RE game. You are just some average guy! Not a cop, not a STARS special agent or FBI. You are just Ethan Winters, and that is horrifying. You feel so powerless even after you get the good guns and that is something the game does very well.

I would never play it again fully. Maybe play the Baker house again then just stop there but the later half of the game is horrible and I lost love for it way before that. Granted, the one I played before it was RE4 so anything that came after the literal BEST GAME the whole franchise has to offer was gonna suffer but this was just an outdated experience

Guard doesn't seem to work when I need it to, I get grabbed at at stupid distances, and shooting the enemy to stagger them for a second doesn't really work as well as you think it would.
