[h1]Immersive and terrifying horror game, dragged down by clunky mechanics[/h1]

[h2]Interesting story and setting[/h2]
The Louisiana Bayou is a cool setting and yields a ton of potential, especially in terms level design and character building. The crazy redneck-inspired antagonist family bears a strong resemblance to the Sawyer family from Texas Chainsaw Massacre. The opening scenes are crazy-well made and on par with real horror films. Sadly, the intriguing, cinematic, horror craziness last only for the prologue and ends after the gameplay starts.

[h2]Clunky fps-gameplay ruins the experience[/h2]
I was intrigued by the first-person take on the Resident Evil 7, especially because I was never drawn to earlier RE games, due to their 3rd person gameplay. The first person perspective works wonders in bringing alive the tight hallways and creaky rooms of the old Bayou-house, but ultimately ruin the whole thing when it comes to combat. The fps-combat feels like if a game developer decided to implement first person gameplay, while actively trying to make it as clunky and unfunny as possible:
[list]
[*]The field of view is like 80deg at max.
[*]You cannot truly ADS with guns - meaning that you'll miss like 50% of the shots due to RNG, even if you play fps games and know how to aim
[*]The black goo-monsters are infuriating. Fighting the first few of them in the basement is fine. But after you complete the basement sequence, they'll start appearing all around the house. Their HP is clearly RNG-based, meaning that sometimes you'll down one with 3 headshots, but some of them consume all of your ammo. The monsters have twitchy head animations, and thus you'll miss most of your shots unless you use the shotgun.
[*]The bosses are tanky as hell and consume like 95% of your ammo. 
[*]The bossfights are designed with janky 3rd-person style mechanics where you have to aim for magic weak-spots if you want to make any actual progress. Shooting bosses in the head - like in other shooters - doesn't have a special effect.
[*]You don't have a replenishing source of ammunition, or a any good melee weapons - meaning that if you're not careful enough, you can actually run out of ammo and meds, soft-locking yourself out of bossfights, and forcing you to load previous saves from hours ago.
[/list]

I played through the game up to the point where you fight Jack in the goo-monster form, inside the swamp house. Having to redo 10-minute bossfights due to annoying mechanics is a nightmare. We're not playing a souls-like here so wtf? It completely breaks the immersion and ruins the mood when you try to enjoy the scary horror plot.

I would change my mind on the game, if the 1st person combat was actually fluid and responsive, otherwise I'd be happier with more traditional RE 3rd person gameplay. This just sucks.
the boss battles in this game make no sence, there is 0 hints as where to go, 0 pointers how to defeat a boss. this game blows

This is middle of the road RE.  Not as good as 2 or 4, but better than 5 and 6.  The over reliance on jump scares gets old and means this game has almost no replayability.  You could replay it on higher difficulty, but the set pieces are no where near as fun as the ones in RE4.  It's worth a play through, especially with VR, but only if you're already beat the better RE games.

Also, single player game with Denuvo.  Shame on you Capcom.  I know you eventually removed it, but that's only because Denuvo was caught dropping the frame rate of RE8 to 12fps so you had to remove it.

Horrible lazy story writing. A teleporting, invincible bad guy not allowing the player to explore isn't "fun" or "resident evil atmosphere" to me, its just lazy and annoying.

This is not Resident Evil. This does not even resemble Resident Evil. The tone is wrong, the feel is wrong, the design is wrong. This game is a generic first person action horror, with no personality of its own to set it apart from any other horror games or horror movies from which it liberally borrows and mashes up ideas.

Resident Evil 7 was the single most unpleasant experience I have had with this series and I own and have played and beaten Resident Evil Gaiden. I enjoy and still play RE Survivor on occasion and that game is objectively terrible but it is Resident Evil in tone, feel, and design.

The protagonist, Ethan Winters is a faceless, milktoast, nothing-burger. The player is given no reason to care about him or sympathize with him for even a second. Steve Burnside from Code: Veronica is a better character than Ethan. Joseph Frost from RE1 is a better character and left more of an impression than Ethan and Joseph dies in the opening cutscene of RE1.

The primary enemies, the molded, are lazy pallet swapped mashups of previous and better enemies from the series, namely the leach men in RE0, the regenerators in RE4, and the ooze in RE Revelations. The variety of molded is also minimal, they come covered in either black or white mold and skinny or fat, very lazy design. One variant does walk on all fours and jump but that just makes them a black licker without the tongue.

The Bakers are neither interesting nor developed enough to warrant any emotional response other than annoyance and boredom. Jack Baker is a stalker enemy but speaks far too much to be intimidating. Margarite Baker is so forgettable, I had to double check her name for this review as I could only remember her as the "insect woman". Lucas Baker is probably the weakest villain in the series and would fit nicely into the villain role in the later Saw films which are also terrible. Imagine Chop Top from Texas Chainsaw Massacre 2 with Jigsaw's engineeeing knowledge and that sums up Lucas pretty well. These particular enemies also swear at you like a 12 year old trying to shock their parents, apparently that is what makes modern media mature and edgy.

The remaining characters Zoe Baker and Mia Winters also have nothing to offer besides an ultimately unsatisfying choice. No matter which choice you make, you as the player lose because you played this game. One character is an innocent bystander deserving of salvation but choosing her nets the bad ending. The other is bio-terrorist but by saving her you net the "good" ending. Pretty stupid for a series about characters trying to stop bio-terrorist.

The story, is never good, but it only continues to decline in quality and entertainment after leaving the Baker estate.  The two final areas, the ship and the caves, are so generic and unmemorable that I struggle to recall anything about them other than the feeling that they would never end.

The final boss and surprise (not so suprise) main villain is unremarkable. All the boss fights are interchangeable due to the nature of the mold, they all look the same, black mold with a weak spot. Remeniscent of the Uroboros monsters from RE5.

The final cherry on top is a cameo from an imposter Chris Redfield, who also gets his own DLC. His character model must have been heavily criticized by the fans because the devs of RE8 put the real Chris in that game. This should be enough to tell any fan of the series how much Capcom thought of the fans that they could throw a completely random character in and call him Chris Redfield to loosely connect what should otherwise be a game in a new IP.

Full disclosure, I purchased this game but I did not play the game myself. I watched and commented as my friend put 20 hours into this game for YouTube recording purposes but I will never play or watch this game again. RE8 being a direct sequel to this is responsible for my decision to never purchase or play RE8 even for recording purposes. I have no desire to return to or support any new entries in this franchise until it returns to being Resident Evil. 

The remakes have been great but they are a distinctly different flavor than classic RE. Regardless, Capcom has been dropping the ball when it comes to new stories in this series since RE4, which is a great action game but a terrible Resident Evil game.

This is the first time I've actually been softlocked in a Resident Evil game, and it's due to an inventory/key item glitch.

I'm pretty sure it glitched because I tried to pick up one of two key items (blue keycard), but my inventory was full. On the way back to the storage box, I decided to get the other key item (red keycard) since it was closer, intending to go back for the other one later. The second key item triggered progression in the story, and now I can't interact with the original key item.

Some of the other Resident Evil games have some quirks and bugs, but this is the only one I've experienced in my playthroughs that resulted in a permanently broken save.

Other than that, games scary and has a spooky atmosphere but the first person makes it lose some character compared to other RE games.

There are two types of design philosophies I absolutely despise in games, corridor shooter that require a substantial amount of backtracking to progress( with mandatory puzzles), and shooters that throw a ton of enemies at you with very little resources at your disposal.

Tack on bad pathing, tedious level design, and a story that seems interesting on the surface, but is about as deep as a puddle, and you get resident evil 7. That is not to mention the absolutely atrocious inventory systems as well, or insanely limited resources. 

The worst thing about all of this, is that the game is a slog to playthrough. There is some cool ambience that is served up, but other then that- I'm not compelled to finish the rest of the game. Seven hours was enough for me to want to uninstall this game.

Final rating: 2/10- buy on sale or just watch the cutscenes on youtube.

Risk of Rain 2 doesn’t feel satisfying to play: it becomes repetitive, build development is uninteresting, and progression feels slow. There’s no real sense of danger or urgency.

Some thoughts: the teleport event seems pointless—its only function is to move you to another biome, but there’s no meaningful reset or shift in pacing. Boss fights are significantly harder than regular encounters, yet the reward is the same single item, so defeating a boss doesn’t feel genuinely rewarding.

Opinion: as a roguelike, the game has potential, but it needs substantial rebalancing and a deeper rethink of how builds and progression develop.

I've had a blast with this game. When it wants to work (keep that sentiment in mind), messing around with it is incredibly fun, and it can be fascinating to see how broken you can get. So why is this a "not recommended" review?

The answer's quite simple: Gearbox and Take-Two have their grubby mitts on this game. Between their predatory EULAs and other scummy business practices, not to mention how they've handled the game itself since taking over, Hopoo's legacy and the hard, honest work of those who have worked on Alloyed Collective have effectively been spat on repeatedly. They want control over everything in the IP, and that includes information on those who play it. You're more than welcome to keep going on it if you trust Gearbox and Take-Two with the stuff on your computer and trust them with every fibre of your being (although why you would want to do that is beyond me). Because, per their EULA, if what they cause via those methods ruins something, you can't hold them liable.

Probably the biggest red flag is that multiplayer itself is completely dysfunctional half of the time. And by "dysfunctional", I mean "it will straight up not load at all, no game for you". Considering that multiplayer is a pretty major pull for a roguelike such as this one, that's just such a big no-no. And as a result of our [i]dear publishers[/i], I don't know - or care - if those problems will be fixed.

Risk Of Rain 2, I love you. I love the way you play and I would have loved to sift through everything Alloyed Collective offers. But I think it's officially time to file for a divorce and head to roguelikes that will actually respect the person playing it.

Look at my playtime. I clearly like this game.

So why the negative review?

After a long break, I try to launch the game again and am met with a new EULA. The very first thing at the top of the EULA? "Mandatory Arbitration." Literally "You agree that even if our coding errors destroy your entire computer, you waive your right to take us to court, and agree to let us BS you about how we owe you nothing."

No company worth supporting has mandatory arbitration clauses. If they HAVE such a clause, it's because they EXPECT to NEED it. So why would they need it? Maybe they want to sneak in spyware which is illegal in your country? Maybe they want to use your computer to mine bitcoin for themselves in the background as you play? Who knows? Whatever the case, it is NOT good. Avoid at all costs.

I'm annoyed at this game.  I don't think it's even remotely on the level of Hades 1, and there is not one quality of life or any improvement I could name about the game that sets the bar higher than the previous title.

  I think Hades 2 punishes the player directly or indirectly for too many things, has too much bullet hell mechanics, too much indiscriminite crap happening on screen making it impossible to predict (especially when considering your own boon effects visually proc-ing), too many mediocre min-maxed boons, mediocre pets, mediocre weapons, mediocre story progression, mediocre music except for a couple of tunes that shine (Olympus Aflame, Siren battles etc).  The game feels to me as if the developers watched too many speed runs of their previous game, and forgot that the vanilla game doesn't need to be in an arms race with insane speed runners who have nothing else to do.

Why not let the player take more boons in the first area on the way to Olympus similar to the rat maze?  Then restrict the rooms later via heat level?  Why am I staring at 8 rooms and only able to choose 6?  I honestly want to install a mod manager for the game because getting the combination you want is less likely to happen across time than the heat death of the entire cosmos.  The game could probably be balanced IMO easily by simply adding like 2-3 chambers/encounters per region.

Why are the chaos trials so fun, yet the builds from those trials are utterly and completely unbuildable?  Yet another unintentional punishment to the player "here is something you can never do nor achieve! enjoy!"  If the odds of a deck of 52 cards being shuffled is basically guaranteed to be unique - then the odds of a single Hades 2 game is probably unique with more than twice or thrice as many combinations.  I challenge someone to figure out the math on it.  How the heck did they even playtest it then, is also my question.  Clearly they didn't in some cases (Hermes boon that affects percentages gets nerfed on Sea Star if you level up Sea Star later for example).

  I'm having a difficult time enjoying any of it, and just fizzling out on heat level 6 Olympus runs because the heat level bosses are just stupid.  I never felt this way about Hades 1 heat level bosses, it was always epic and exciting getting amped for the plus level boss fights.  Now it's like "what random 2-frame timing projectile bullshit are they going to throw at me now".  Too much projectile hell in a world where you basically never get Athena's dash.  It's nearly impossible to get a decent intentional build, and even when I do ( for example just did a run where I got a Zeus + Hera duo boon granting me +12 on all my zeus boons) but then of course I have like 1 death defiance left because the poison battle with Medea and Polyphemus is absolute and pure bullshit, and then the fight with whats-her-bucket after that will finish you off.

It feels like this game never left beta, and I'm just not excited to play it anymore, or even finish the story.  It's extremely frustrating.  Melinoe is possibly one of the most boring characters written in the history of games, she isn't exactly unpleasant at least.  She seems to be the kind of girl girls would aspire to see themselves as, fair enough.  But just bland as pouring baking flour in your oatmeal.  The only carrot is the story of Melinoe's family dragging me along, and it's so few and far between that this story develops, it makes Persephone's presence in the previous game seem like she practically lived in Tartarus.
Constantly crashes. At this point, I give up. It would be fun, but it's unplayable.

After finishing the full release, I have to say I’m disappointed. I supported this in early access but after all this time the game just doesn’t pull me in like the first one did. The tone, writing, and presentation constantly break immersion instead of building it.

The story and dialogue never clicked for me. In Hades 1, conversations felt clever and fitting for mythic figures. Here, it’s casual and repetitive, and the characters rarely grow or respond meaningfully to your progress. The plot never gave me the same drive or emotional hook that made Zagreus’ journey compelling.

The characters feel weaker, and Melinoë never really develops, even after dozens of victories. The cast lacks the charm and spark of the first game, and the serious tone never lands because there’s no wit or emotional payoff.

The redesigns of many characters feel wrong, they clearly weren’t meant to immerse you in the world or tell the story, but to do something else entirely. That takes me out of the game more than anything else.

Gameplay is solid at its core, but the magic of the first game isn’t there. Weapons feel too similar, combat is slower, and builds rarely feel impactful. Progression is bloated with too many materials and grindy systems that make runs feel like chores. On top of that, screen clutter from attacks and effects often makes fights frustrating because you can’t see what’s happening.

Overall, the game lost the personality, charm, and tight design that made Hades 1 special. Supporting it early felt exciting, but the final result just didn’t deliver, and if this is the direction Supergiant sticks with, I won’t be backing their next project.

[h1]Overhyped Disappointment[/h1] 
The developers were once known for experimenting with different genres. It’s a shame those experiments seem to have ended, and instead we got a game that could have easily been just a DLC (and in that case, there would’ve been no complaints).

The first Hades was a breakthrough title that showed for the first time that roguelikes can have high-quality narrative and storytelling — all wrapped in Supergiant Games’ signature art direction. For many people, the original Hades became the showcase of the action-roguelike genre and the entry point into it (myself included). Despite its click-click-dash combat, the game delivered a fresh and exciting experience.
What experience does Hades II offer? With such tedious combat and build-crafting, it can easily push players away from the genre entirely: “If the overhyped Hades II is this boring, then other roguelikes must be even worse.”

At first, I wanted to describe all the issues, but once I started writing, I realized I’d spend an enormous amount of time. It’s not worth it. There are already many great negative reviews with detailed examples and explanations. So here’s a short summary of the game’s problems:
[list]
[*]The combat became broader, but not deeper. Just like before — it’s simply click-click-dash.
[*]Battle balance is broken. Normal difficulty is extremely easy, while higher difficulty is absurd and tedious.
[*]The balance of boons and build-crafting is questionable. The dominant strategy is to pick the highest damage percentages for your basic or special attack and spam it. There are far too many useless boons.
[*]The Arcana system is dark-meta that effectively gets removed at high difficulty.
[*]Resource grind and the grind animations show no respect for the player’s time.
[/list]
What I simply disliked:
[list]
[*]The visual style
[*]The story feels childish, the characters are weak, and the developer-intended ending doesn’t match the dark and brutal tone of Greek mythology
[/list]
If you haven’t played the first Hades, go play it. And if you have, you’re better off trying Curse of the Dead Gods instead.

[h3]Good gameplay. Mediocre story.[/h3]

After the success of Hades, the idea of having Chronos, the titan of time, felt like the perfect villain for the style of game that had been created. A time wielding antagonist in a loop structured game seems like a match made in heaven. The problem is implementing it.

The game design and visuals are as good as the first game. It rewards you as you learn it. I love three of the new characters: Nemesis, Medea, and Scylla. Nemesis is so cool that sometimes I wonder if she would have been a better protagonist. Medea is another really cool character with a distinctive somber persona. Scylla and the sirens, what a remarkable boss. She is as memorable as Thesius. A charismatic foe that you love to hate. The best songs of the game come from her confrontation.

Some minor complaints and suggestions before the big one. The reagents and greeneries should be used for more enchantments and relationship progression. In the current state of the game, the majority of them are barely used, just keep filling up space, and are just a waste of time to collect once used. Supergiant could add incantations to the relationship system of the game instead of heavily relying on nectar and ambrosia. Melinoe could do strange and funny incantations she thinks might help her acquaintances, but which could backfire. She isn't as cheeky as Zagreus, but her naivete could be used to add some funny moments to the game. She could give some rare reagents and greeneries to Hecate, Circe, Medea, and maybe Arachne. She could give rare reagents to Icarus and Hephaestus. Give Persephone some greeneries. Her mother would love to receive flowers from her daughter. Mix things up. Not just give the same thing to everybody.

Most relationships in Hades 2 have a dissatisfying development and conclusion. The alliance with the Olympian gods plays exactly like the first game so they didn't feel anything special. A suggestion here would be Melinoe learn how to infuse nectars and ambrosias through incantations to please the gods. Sort of like the ectoplasmic draught she makes for Icarus. Different gods requiring different incantations. Regarding the relations with the other NPCs, there is a clear difference between Hades and Hades 2. Zagreus helps all those who help him throughout the game. It is extremely gratifying to interact with them. Melinoe in contrast just seems to meet them and become an acquaintance to most of them. Even if you advance all relationships in the game, she is just someone these people know and have to interact occasionally. There is no emotional benefit to befriending most characters. It is just something to unlock more dialogue. It is purely transactional. In the first Hades, it is so rewarding to help Achilles, your mentor and guy who has been encouraging you and being positive throughout the whole game. Dusa, Nyx, Sysiphus, Patroclus, Eurydice, Orpheus, Megaera, etc. It feels great meeting, talking, befriending, and helping them. There is nothing like that in Hades 2. Talking to the NPCs advances the story, but in the end there is barely any emotional attachment to most of them. Melinoe may meet lots of people, but she doesn't befriend or help most of them. Even the ones she helps end up in lackluster conclusion. Even her romance options end up being dull.

I did not like to face Cerberus as a boss. I love him in the first game. He is a source of comfort. I love when you first reach the final gate and instead of fighting him, you discover that you just need to give him a treat. You only see him in combat for a brief moment in the advanced final boss fight, which is hilarious (bad boy, bad boy!). In Hades 2, after having "soothed" Cerberus, I didn't even want to listen what Homer had to say. You turned a character that I loved in the first game into a character that I loathe having to face every single time I go to the Underworld. It makes no sense that he keeps getting corrupted even after you have freed Hades and Persephone.

If Chronos can imprison powerful characters like Zagreus, Persephone, and Hecate in those time bubbles; why doesn't he do that to Milenoe? This is a plot hole to me. In my head, I kept thinking how cool it would have been if Hecate had planned to make Milenoe's true identity to Chronos a secret because her main advantage would be that since she is directly related to him, his powers of time would not be reliable against her. Everyone who is directly related to Chronos would have this advantage. Only in later encounters he would deduce who she really is. I imagined him freezing her. After one or two seconds she frees herself, he shouts "impossible!", and the song "In the Blood" starts to play as the final fight progresses. But if I need to make mental gymnastics to justify your story, then there is definitely something wrong.

Now the big complaint. The first time I reached each of the endings of the first Hades it felt like bliss. When I reached the first ending of Hades 2, it just made the game worse and worse. It felt like some Kung Pow Enter the Fist type of joke, but done seriously.

Milenoe: I have diligently trained my entire life to kill the man who took my family away from me. I will never forgive him. Not in a million years. Never.
Zagreus: I implore you to reconsider.
Milenoe: Hmm... (in a high pitched voice) Okay. Hey grandpa, you are forgiven.

Chronos: For millennia, I painfully reconstituted myself after having been slain by my own children. Now it is my children's turn to suffer through my rightful revenge!
Zagreus: I implore you to reconsider.
Chronos: Hmm... (in a high pitched voice) Okay. Hey family, sorry.

Two tales of revenge. One from the protagonist and one from the antagonist. They both end in an awkward family reunion. That is bullshit. Shoving a happy ending when it isn't earned just left me with a huge feeling of disappointment. Every time I met with the reformed Chronos, I rolled my eyes. The post ending justification of having to battle other timelines is such a lazy excuse. The writer wrote himself into a corner and came up with this lousy trick. Suddenly we have a multiverse to fight for eternity. Give me a break.

If I had to describe this game in one word, it would be unsatisfying. After all those hours invested in this story, you are left with a pitifully weak ending. Then play more to reach the true ending, and it is another huge let down. The meeting with the Fates is extremely underwhelming. Just like waking up Hypnos. Then you get Hecate's reveal which is a convoluted time travel mess. It made me think what was the point of it all. What a waste of my time. I have occasionally reinstalled the first Hades a couple of times to beat it once again since it is so much fun. If I had to describe the first game in one word, it would be rewarding. After uninstalling Hades 2, I will probably never play it again. I paid full price in early access only because I bought the first game in a discount and loved it so much I promised I would pay full price for the next game.

If you are planning to buy this game, most likely you have played the first Hades. If you don't care much about the story and are only interested in the game mechanics or the speed running aspect, go for it. It is as good as the predecessor. If you care about the story, I would advise to only buy this game on a very big discount. While the game is fun, the story is extremely unsatisfying.

Same formula as the first, but nearly as tight. They added more systems, but a lot of it is frustrating rather than intriguing. Super builds aren't nearly as common which adds to the frustration. All-in-all a more poorly paced game that has issues with the story and the presentation.
It sucks cuz its on steam
I truly enjoy this game but EVERY TIME I launch it forces me to verify the game files.  I cant recommend it until they fix this.

(Hades2 is the "The New Colossus" to Hades1's "The New Order")

TLDR: Game's great, but feels subpar to SuperGiant's ridiculously high standards, so Hades1 - for coherent storytelling and consistency, Hades2 - for more diverse gameplay.

.. to elaborate:
- True & Epilogue Ending both are mediocre at best (the patch only made it a smidge better)
- just time-travel in general messing up the whole premise and post-game justifications
- some NPC arcs falling flat (Chronos, Hypnos)
- subplots going nowhere or lacking a satisfying resolution. Hades1 Sisyphus stayed for Boldy, Hades2 NPCs stay because of the "NPC in a rogue-like" reason - they can have it better, but none take the opportunity or, in some cases, even move (Tartatus couple).

.. the rest are nitpicks - outlandish style choices (suited Chaos; Dionysus's attire; the Oceanus boss - albeit entertaining but still too whimsical), tame weapon aspects (save for a few), flat God portraits (poses, not animations), boring +5% upgrades (Moon tree), ubiquitous status curses with similar effects.

Mechanically Hades2 is super fun, the surface climb is awesome, the music\songs are beautiful, some characters do leave an impression, not to mention the overall level of polish and attention to details - this is still SuperGiant!
.. but I enjoyed Hades1 more..
They sold you the same game twice. Not twice better than the first game.

The core of what made Hades a great game is there, but the game has a frustrating habit of suddenly dumping damage on you with cheap shots. In one end game area I died to a falling object with no tell. One boss has a pattern memorization attack that basically wipes or halves one life (if you were pumping max health) if you make a single error. If it had front loaded more of it's cheap stuff early I would have honestly refunded it.

it quickly become not fun. Amount of grind is quite astonishing. Filler dialogs while you gather story-required resources are so bad. A more tight progression would make a miracle to the game. Some character art has laughing anatomy. It's a big miss from art direction standpoint. Surface final boss is a chore to say at least.

I can't recommend a game where there's a studly-imagined Odysseus and they won't let you peg him.

... pretty not like Hades, is that a good thing? Apparently, because a lot of the game feels like someone said "we have to do something different, because Hades was so amazing but we don't want to do the same thing again because...." fade to silence.

So I guess the review in case someone actually reads this is that this mess is really irritating in a lot of ways.  The boss fights are pretty boring, are full of patched in after-thought mechanics, a-la the classic clone battle mechanic, the bosses are nowhere near as entertaining character-wise, the minions are kinda weird and kinda annoying, think Hades annoying minion mechanics x10, the maps I managed to play before becoming totally disgusted with the game are all reskinned versions of the originals with different names (and pasted in hazards that are not well flagged)... generally the whole thing feels underbuilt, like something solid has been stretched out and colorized through some kind of chemical process.

[b]The final insult for me was being perma-slowed in a forced cut-scene that reskins you as your character's child-self to relay some kind of very important who-knows-wtf about ?, hence, if follows of course, that you get a perma-slow and half-dash effect because it makes the bizarro segment authentic because of shorter legs? lol. Also, while slowed this way, you have to search around a very large area for someone who is hiding. Think 4x the size of a basic fight room. Oh aaand add a bunch of child-speak voice lines as accompaniment, because everyone loves that cringe, or well at least everyone apparently said they loved it when it got crammed into the game at probably great expense.[/b]


holy ****. This is unskippable, shows up directly after a run, and generally ****s up just trying to play the game which is already a pita with all the systems, characters and fun footnotes you'll be expected to interact with just on your way to the next run.

Pretty obnoxious. Oh well.. Hades was pretty obnoxious in the same ways, but there was a lot to love there. Here, not so much, not at all. How could anyone let something go so wrong, and not even for a good reason like an old fashion cash-out. wth... this should win the award for most inexplicably terrible sequel.

I'm a "not recommend" for people like me.

[h1]Young Adult Story for Girls[/h1]

I bought this thinking more Hades. Turns out Hades was the guy one, Hades 2 is the girl one. You should know this going in, because playing Hades 2 as a guy is probably what playing Doom Eternal as a girl feels like. "Ugh, this isn't for me" will be your thought through all of the dialogue and story beats.

[b]Young Adult[/b]: The premise is "time killed my parents, so now I have to kill time in order to bring them back." Obviously failure to kill time and acceptance of reality is the outcome, because teenagers are impressed by the lesson that people die of old age and resentment of that makes no sense.

[b]For Girls[/b]: Your character is a teenage girl going through a very teenage girl arc. She's born into privilege (surrounded by mentors and admirers, royal lineage), so she has all of the tools she needs to be successful. She's even turned those tools into talent. But ugh, she'll never be good enough in her own eyes. She begins solving every problem with "but I'm not good enough to try and solve this problem!"

She needs (and gets) constant reassurances and you-got-this from every role model in her life. Even when someone scolds her, it's just positive reinforcement couched in a scolding tone. "Melinoe cease your self deprecation at once. I'll have none of this self doubt, especially not from you of all people! I know you can beat me, and I feel deep down you know it too! Now get up and try again!"

So her quest is learning to accept the fact that she IS GOoD enough, dammit!

This is not something we go through as guys. But my understanding is  "stop doubting yourself and try" is a very common lesson learned in ladyland.

[h1]Gameplay Doesn't Hit that Button that Hades Did[/h1]

It plays similarly enough. 

Issues for me are TONS of upgrade systems that require futzing with menus all day. 

I'm 5 weapons deep and none of them feels as fun as any of the weapons in Hades did. "Slow and clunky" is the theme, even for "fast" weapons. And each time I try a special or a charge attack, my feeling is "oh, that's it?"

Every character wants to talk constantly. So you finish a run, then you get those "talk to me" exclamation points above everyone's head. And because of my story points above, going through them all to make sure I unlock more gameplay is a chore.

There is a boss called Scylla. A group of Sirens in a rock band. Fun on paper. In practice, their music is corny teenage edgelord pop, so it grates on my nerves that I'm hearing it halfway through every run.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Some folks are gonna LOVE this game. F18-34 mostly, I'm willing to bet. 

To Supergiant's credit, they finally seem to have cracked the "how do we make an action game for girls" nut that the industry has been slamming against the table for the past 15 years. So that's cool.

Can't stand how this is even more meta-progression focused and decides to split the fucking game into 2 paths (lol and multiple Gods are locked behind this too.. wth) instead of adding actual room and encounter variety which this game lacks in even more than the 1st game as well. Enemy design is safe and lacking. Everything just feels safe as hell. Nothing wowed me even close to the last 2 areas and boss encounters of the 1st game.

The fact that the rat miniboss in Oceanus is something you can encounter past the 1st time you see it too.. wow, peak fun. Peak game design having to read an instantly dashing tiny ass rat you can barely see on your screen while you're bombarded from all sides. Who the hell designed this?

Game is good overall, but I'd prefer to be critical considering how overblown this game's praise is.

How is it possible? I Mean... How?

On the other hand, this one still have a good combat, but it's very hit and miss, glacial pacing, terrible story, boring characters, ok music (except for the Sirens, they are great) e abysmal endings (especially the epilogue)...

Add the total lack of respect for greek mythology acurracy and you have Hades 2... Such a shame...
Just play the first one and move on.

A bit of a different experience from the original Hades, some things are better some aren't. Story wise it has its ups and downs. Melinoe is everything that Zagreus isn't (which is very good honestly, doesn't make it better or worse, though). What we fell in love in the original is there, but also the Steven universation... The old story of old dude can do all terrible things and get a pass. There are better ways to solve a conflict, talk no jutsu is one of the worse.

It doesnt click as the first one, Hades 1 is perfect and this one tries to be similar but different at the same time.

The characters are less charismatic copies of the first game. For example, Nemesis and Oddyseus feel like aliexpress versions of Meg and Achilles. The new gods are bland, and the returning ones come off like actors worn down after six seasons of playing the same part.

Personally  I didn't enjoy any of the weapons and I'm not having fun with the magic system. Any weapon in Hades 1 is more fun than the Witch Staff.

Also, I'm color blinded and I didn't have problem seeing things in Hades 1 but after 60 minutes playing this one my eyes were exhausted.

After completing it and getting to the epilogue I'm realizing only after the fact that... It's just not as good in terms of writing as Hades 2. It's nonsensical and unfulfilling in a lot places, with either unearned or hanging plot threads and characters all over the place.

This is one of those times I wish I could give a neutral recommendation, but forced to pick yes or no? It's no. Make no mistake, what's here is an improvement gameplay-wise on Hades, but Hades 1 was a complete package and that's why it was good: Writing and mechanics actually interlocked in such a great way to keep you playing well past the ending. That isn't present here. They really dropped the ball with the development of the narrative overall here, it's all weird and disjointed when you stop to think about it, all the way from simple bonds you have with characters, to how things 'resolve'. And that just isn't good enough when you're only standing on your mechanics, and being compared to a much better complete experience like Hades 1.

The short review is: play the first game, it's awesome. This one's a lame copy. 

The long one is: I really wanted to love this game. The first one was one of the best games I've ever played and I've played a lot. However, I simply can't. And for many reasons: 

1. One of the finest characteristics of the first game was how balanced it was. Each weapon had some advantages, same for the gods. And none was truly broken. You had to do your best. Now... Well, now there are many broken combos. And you don't even need them. Just get a Selene damaging boon, improve it, get loads of life and nothing else matters. You can one-shot each phase of the final boss with it. And with enough life you don't really need to bother too much with his attacks. No strategy or ability required. This game is way easier than the first without being more interesting.
2. This game pretends to have more options, but they are not really options. For instance, would you rather have three extra lives or deal more damage to enemies with two curses? Most of the options you have are either super powerful or mostly useless. For instance, one of the challenges of the game is to manage you mana consumption. However you can choose to start with a powerful mana regen, which makes mana management moot.
3. Far too many resources, most of which are used once or twice, then become irrelevant. The game itself knows it and at some point gives you a magic that makes you not even have to gather them. 
4. The conversations are boring. There are far too many characters and you have to give far too many gifts to each of them, and your reward is too listen to same sentence with different words. Besides, almost everyone is super nice ever since the beginning. There's no drama and no evolution to the characters. The gods even apologize when you spurn them.
5. Most of the characters are very tedious. The headmistress is a fortune cookie sentence generator. Odysseus only alerts you to things that you already know. (By the gods! The skeleton has better advice.) Very few characters have something interesting to say.
6. The love interests are lame. Two weak, apologetic men. (One of them actually apologizes to you for having only you as a lover while you have a lot of people.) One woman hates you and does everything she can to make your life worse. (Really? That's the one the main character is going after!?) Only the other woman has a nice story and doesn't seem a lame lover.
7. The antagonist could be easily swapped by Doc. Evil, given how cliche he is. And the ending (both of the main story and the epilogue) are super boring. 

The only saving grace was Scylla. The idea of a boss that sings different songs throughout her level is awesome. And her songs are much more interesting than the bgm of the rest of the game.

All in all, this was not a good sequence to the first. Having played Silksong recently, the difference in quality is glaring. Whereas in Silksong the creators clearly learned from the first game and made an even better one, in this game no lessons were learned. In fact, there were many downgrades that I simply cannot understand. 

For instance, when checking a god's boon list, in the first game you could see simultaneously both the requirements and the details of the boon. Now you can see only one or the other. Who thought this would be better? On the first, after you finished the main quest, the ending of a run was a lighthearted joke on the protagonist. Now we have only a boring generic ending. Is the protagonist so soft skinned that she can't take a joke?

My take on this game is that this game was not thoroughly thought before its implementation and that early access made it worse instead of better. The loudest people usually ask for a less challenging game and for more OP characters, which can be fun for a little while but make for a much less enjoyable game.

For instance, the last weapon to be created requires no brain to play. Just spam super specials and that's it. Super boring. I did the 32 darkness challenge with it at the beginning of the game without breaking a sweat. This should not happen. In the end, the hardest challenge is to play the super random challenge, where you may end with the lamest weapon and worse enemy boosts. Not fun at all.

Please do yourself a favor and play Hades 1 instead.

I loved Hades 1 and was so, so excited for this game. And I really enjoyed it for 60 hours! And then i reached the ending and ate the greatest dissatisfying nothingburger 0 character development of all time. The game and characters had so much potential and none of that is ever addressed. Melinoe isn't particularly likeable and she never gets character development throughout the entire game, she isn't even a satisfying protagonist which sours the otherwise great gameplay. The art style change was just disappointing, considering how Hades 1 had an incredibly unique, dynamic style

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG
review_text:
Rust is less a video game and more an ontological crucible—a ruthless simulation of human fragility in which players are unceremoniously thrust, naked and bewildered, into a violently indifferent world. Armed initially with nothing but a rock, one becomes acutely aware that this primitive tool is not merely a means of gathering resources, but a symbol of humanity’s eternal struggle against entropy. The island itself operates as a living ecosystem of paranoia, where each footstep behind you triggers a sudden philosophical inquiry into mortality.

What truly distinguishes Rust is its uniquely volatile social dynamic. Alliances form and dissolve with the same instability as subatomic particles, and the concept of trust becomes a rare and precious hallucination. The player must navigate a landscape saturated with Machiavellian scheming, economic desperation, and a level of unpredictable human behavior that borders on the anthropological. A single encounter with another player can unravel hours of effort, transforming personal progress into an existential tragedy worthy of Greek theatre.

The emotional turbulence Rust generates is unparalleled. Triumph feels mythic—your first fortified base stands not merely as a structure, but as a monument to defiance against an uncaring universe. Conversely, being raided at 3 a.m. by a clan of sleep-deprived marauders is a humbling reminder of the cosmos’s disdain for your ambitions. This perpetual oscillation between empowerment and devastation makes Rust an experience not of simple entertainment, but of psychological endurance.

In conclusion, Rust is a hyper-chaotic meditation on survival, cruelty, and the volatile nature of human interaction. It is exhausting, awe-inspiring, and occasionally soul-crushing, but it is unquestionably one of the most brutally honest reflections of human behavior ever disguised as a game.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG
review_text:
Best game ever

Rust is a survival game that excels at one thing above all else: punishing its players. From the moment you spawn on the beach with nothing but a rock and a dream, the game makes it very clear that it owes you absolutely nothing—and it delivers on that promise relentlessly.

The learning curve is steep and often brutal. Crafting, building, raiding, monument puzzles, electricity, recoil control—Rust provides little instruction and expects you to figure things out the hard way. For some, that’s part of the charm. For others, it’s an exhausting uphill battle with no payoff in sight.

Rust’s community is another hurdle. The proximity and voice chat systems, while innovative, often serve as gateways to some of the most toxic interactions in online gaming. Trash talk, harassment, and trolling are commonplace, and unless you disable communication entirely, you’re likely to experience the worst of it.

The game is also a massive time sink. Bases decay unless maintained, raids can happen while you sleep, and servers wipe regularly, erasing your progress and requiring you to start over. To stay competitive, many players feel pressured to commit long, continuous sessions—something not everyone has the time or desire for.

Even if you can stomach the gameplay loop, technical performance might still stand in your way. Rust demands a powerful PC, and even then, it’s prone to frame dips, long loading times, and occasional instability.

Finally, playing solo is a challenge bordering on masochistic. Rust heavily favors groups, and lone players often find themselves outnumbered, outgunned, and outmatched.

In short: Rust is a game that rewards perseverance but punishes everything else. If you’re looking for a harsh, unforgiving survival experience and don’t mind the toxicity or time commitment, Rust can be incredible. But for many players, the difficulty, community, and grind make it an easy pass.

review_text:
I absolutely love the concept of this game, but recent updates by the developers don't make sense and are lackluster, I believe this game is being mismanaged.

**jungle update**
  - doesn't make sense gameplay-wise, tier 0 biome right next to spawn beach yet has wildly unfair animal AI compared to other biomes
  - doesn't offer any monuments other than ziggarat, it looks cool, but offers almost nothing for the amount of risk you have to go through.
**meta shift**
  - slows down progression (people complained that it's too fast) by adding blueprint fragments to various puzzles
  - kind of works on low pop, a lot of players from my server complain that it's not fun to obtain
  - you will be prim-locked forever as a solo / small team on high pop.
  - fragments serve no purpose afterwards if you already have the corresponding workbench
  - imo they tackled the wrong thing, they should've done something about unlocks, not workbenches
**pivot or die**
  - made tech tree costs stupidly low (why? didn't you just slow down progression?)
  - removed workbench taxes by default (this is something that i believe should've been experimented with, reward players for finding items in-world with noticeable cost reductions, rather than completely locking them out of workbenches and then suddenly making lucky players with workbenches be able to progress at mach 4)
**naval update**
  - not out, but so far from staging branch seems like it'll have the same issue like the jungle biome where there's not enough value for the amount of effort and risk you have to go through to reach and stay afloat in the deep sea

it just seems like they're changing stuff just for the sake of change and that they've ran out of ideas. although i've never played during this era, i believe that rust's content updates had more vision under Garry's leadership. every update served a purpose whereas a lot of newer updates under Alistair's leadership don't add anything interesting or even actively harm the game. there's also been a lot more focus on monetization to the point where I feel like I'm playing a F2P game, P2W items exist, they allow you to do things normal players can't do, there is literally a hazmat that changes stats for money. servers owners also lose a lot of control over their own servers with new EULA changes, you cannot even the odds between players by giving P2W items in any way (loot tables, ability to craft, etc) as a server owner, you cannot restrict players with P2W items from using them for any reason at all either, it's not a good look and just sucks for people who dislike having to spend money on microtransactions to compete on a game that's they've already paid for.

optimization is also another issue, it uses an absurd amount of VRAM (6GB for eighth resolution, which is the lowest graphics preset) for a game that doesn't look as good as others which consume less memory, this could be a unity limitation for all i know but this is absurd and it was never this bad when i played a year ago. it also uses a ton of memory in general and 16GBs is not something you should be playing with. recent updates have also added a lot of buggy code and constant client errors which aren't seemingly being addressed.

i also want to express my concerns about Linux support, as it would be really nice if you allowed EAC to work under Proton, it's a single checkbox that you can tick in the EOS dashboard and shipping linux EAC binaries. I know it's weaker but would it be that bad considering that most servers already moderate suspicious players? It won't stop me from playing as I've created a non-EAC server alongside a friend that's marginally successful, but it would be a nice gesture from Facepunch.

you've created an awesome game that I personally enjoy, there's nothing like it anywhere else in the entire game's industry but it has so many flaws that I cannot recommend it to new-comers in this state.
SUPERHOT is the most innovative shooter I’ve played in years!

While I typically avoid FPS games, SUPERHOT caught my eye because of its presentation. It's a bullet time game where time only moves when you do, and even with this huge advantage you're constantly having to think on your feet in close ranged combat.

A part of why this works so well is that the game is a puzzle as much as it is a FPS. Every level places you in a difficult situation that they need to figure out with moment to moment reactions. You also die very easily, so it's about trial and error until a working strategy prevails.

I feel that this initially had the potential to be one of the best games I've played, even for something outside of my typical preferred genres. However, the way the story presents itself is a bit flawed, as it's far too intrusive to the actual gameplay from the getgo. I know some people will argue that's the point, but I don't want to ever replay the game exactly because of this. I feel there are better ways that the story could have been executed without sacrificing too much of the gameplay itself. If the message is supposed to be that the gameplay is addictive, then let me experience that!

I still like SUPERHOT, the gameplay itself is intuitive. A minimalist style and mechanics to focus purely on the bullet time aspect makes for a memorable, albeit not perfect, experience. I'd suggest just getting this on sale due to the shorter playtime, although the franchise as a whole is probably not worth checking out unless if you [i]really[/i] find the core gameplay to look interesting.

I like this game ALOT. It’s very fun and addicting, with tons of challenges and quick action that keeps you on your toes. I played the VR version (13 hours), and I loved that game.


Although this game is flawless with no complaints, I must say that in my opinion the concept of SuperHot: where time moves when you move. is better executed in VR. I had so much more fun in the VR version because SuperHot’s gameplay is smoother and better done in VR than in the original.

Also, with how short these games are, I don’t find real value in the $25 price tag for each of them. The VR version is by far worth its price, while the original feels lacking because its Gameplay and Difficulty is just stale in comparison.

Now, I do want to make this clear: SuperHot is not bad. It is wonderful and a joy to play through, and I can see some people justifying the $25 price tag. I just think that when you compare it to SuperHot VR, its price isn’t worth it to me personally.

I bought this for about $8, and I’m happy with it, but I would not pay the full $25 price. If you can buy this game on sale, then I’d say it’s worth your time and money. However, I believe that SuperHot VR is the definitive and better version to play.

[h1]Cool as hell[/h1]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3602437149
[i]There will be a TL;DR at the end.[/i]
 
~
 
There I was, in a stairwell I assumed would be my end.
Two men with guns were coming up from below, and someone is right next to me about to punch my lights out.
In the blink of an eye I grab a nearby fire extinguisher and throw it at the nearest man, then follow up with a flurry of blows that sends him to the red-guy shadow realm.
Picking up a hammer, I throw it at the first gunman, mankind him fall back and drop his gun.
Leaping out, his buddy shoots at me - but I twitch faster than a speeding bullet, like something out of the matrix.
I punch the first gunman as he tries to pick up his gun - his buddy from behind BLOWS HIS HEAD OFF trying to shoot [b]ME[/b]
In a flash, I grab the gun as it tumbles through the air, turning it around and putting a round into the head of the second assailant.
Three more red guys spawn in - guns drawn.
I throw my pistol at mach 5, hitting one and rupturing his internal organs. Guy behind him readies a shot - I don’t think so.
I TRANSPORT MY CONSCIOUSNESS into that guy’s body, leaving the meat puppet I was originally controlling to fall over in a state of fatal neural shock and overheat.
In the new body I toss the butt of the rifle at my closest enemy, grab that guy’s shotgun, blow away the final guy.

How could anyone not think this game is awesome.

I’ve played this game for ~8 hours on my XBOX and loved it - popping it open on [i]Steam[/i] let me fall in love with the game all over again. With a total of 26 hours playing [b]SUPERHOT[/b] at time of writing, I can easily recommend.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3602436808
To temper expectations against what everyone else is hyping the experience up for - the only thing you do is shoot red guys. Nothing more.
There are a few little minigames, the story is interesting, and the style is both creative and unique. The title is overall charming.

There isn’t a globe trotting adventure, tons of different mechanics, dynamic dialogue trees, loads of rewards or cosmetics, etc.

But if the core gameplay loop looks like something you’d like, it will repay your curiosity in dividends. Even though red dude’s heads explode and they shatter into glass, the game is generally clean enough to play around teens - it’s good fun and a lot of adventure - very well made, and you are given tons of secrets and challenges to test that noodle of yours after you’re done with the main helping this experience has to offer.

The game is short, sweet, and basically a super tricked out tech demo or proof-of-concept slice.

~

I’ve only played SUPERHOT for about an hour, but even that short time was enough for me to say this game is AMAZING. I picked it up on sale without expecting much, even though I had heard some good things. But honestly, it completely blew me away.

The game feels so fresh and unique. The graphics are super clean, and the fact that it came out in 2016 is mind-blowing. The maps kind of remind me of TABS, and the whole experience makes you feel like you’ve been dropped into another world. I was literally sitting on the edge of my seat the whole time, waiting for something wild to happen.

The “SUPER... HOT” voice is so cool and really sticks with you. The way time moves only when you move makes everything feel intense and tactical, like you’re actually dodging bullets in slow motion. The only thing that bugs me is how accurate the bots get when you’re not slowing time. It almost feels like they have aimbot.

Even with that, I’d still say to NOT get this game. I’ve heard it’s short and it gets WAY too repetitive. The lore is boring as hell and I have no free will. "They" keep telling me to leave.. so I did and I never played it again. It is a fun and unique play, but it costs way too much. $30.00 CAD for me.

Mechanically a good game ruined by tedious processes. 

The levels are the fun part. The text based "story" is not. Who even cares about the story? It's the same stuff over and over and over and over again. Oh no you're not in control, oh wait yes you are, just kidding no you aren't. Go visit yourself and see your own body in the real world, wait your trapped, hurt yourself, obey disobey, obey, disobey, rinse repeat. OHHH METANARRATIVE, HOW COMPELLING, HOW DARING. Annoying is more like it. 

Incredibly annoying and ruins all the pacing the game builds upon during the action levels. Imagine watching an action packed movie, and after every fight, there's a 2 minute long uninterruptable ad that you have to interact with in order to progress. 

The flame fizzles as soon as the story garbage begins.
Neat I guess but way overpriced for a handful of neat levels and a plot the devs admitted was completely worthless.

While the gameplay is cool I quickly got frustrated with each reset I initiated. We got couple of stuff at our disposal, depending on the level, be it weapons or objects and later on an ability to switch bodies, so there are couple of ways we can clear the level. 
Game quickly became a puzzle instead of a shooter. With each reset, I knew more possibilities of approaching threats but it wasn't for a better. Five tries here, switching approach, another two tries there, switch, different tactic, here I couldn't make it, there I was not quick enough. That's not for me to have an multiverse gameplay in my world, maybe its my brain that Im capable of seeing all the possibilities and none at the same time so Im stuck 5 times in one confrontation before I switch to different threat or progress further. I feel like that gameplay was melting my brain and on top of that, the lore, the progression of said simulation became irritating. So, in the end, I got a decent mix of frustrating triggers. Im only glad I got it while it was -70% so Im not so bitter about it. I honestly have to pause the game to say the story is probably the most obnoxious thing I've ever experienced. 
The gameplay is superhot, great fun. But the story interjecting constantly between levels completely ruins the flow of the game. It should honestly be patched to be removed and have the game just seamlessly go from level to level.

This game has a pretty cool concept but that's about it. in my opinion this game is simply way too overhyped. The story is shorter than 90 minutes, 60 if you are hurrying, 30 if you barely make a mistake and 15m 52s 107ms if you are the world record holder. 

First of all, the story is just trash, constantly pretending like you are helpless and a slave to the Virus, when in reality literally nothing changes. I can't write what I think? That's been there from the beginning! I can't exit the game? Yes I can, just press the windows button or any of the fifteen shortcuts, that close the game. You are also not really forced to obey, ratehr being "You have to" and then not actually doing anything. Making me bored is not forcing me.

But lets look at the shooter part instead: It is pretty okay but over all it's short once you figure out how to play, most levels are pretty easy but the game gives you the illusion of difficulty by spawning enemies behind you with no way of knowing unless you died to them before and even if, you probably don't know it was them since there is no way to know what killed you. They also walk like they are completely drunk, making aiming a nightmare sometimes. The weapons are pretty boring, I like the Gun the most, since it is just simple and fitting for such a game, you can shoot, you can throw, once it's out, no more shooting for you. Punching is also pretty fun but completely ruins the point of the bat, the corwbar and the katana which are all (more or less) the same. The spread weapons are pretty trash, why would i need a spread weapon in a game where i have all the time in the world to move and am often punished for getting close? There is also a weapon that if you shoot, shoots 4 times and fast, again, why do i need that? It feels so much more unprecise if there are more bullets, just make it fire one bullet. Lastly the throwing items are pretty fun, although enemies only get stunned from them unless you hurl like 10 at them.
Lastly, you have the ability to "take control of them" which is just a lie and actually means: "You teleport to the point where the enemy was standing and kill him but have no weapon now". It sounds pretty fun but it's stale quickly since instead of landing a cool shot in slow Motion or managing to get to the guy and punching him to pieces, you just pressed a button and it feels like no impact at all. A better Version would have been to control the red guy for a little bit, using his weapons and fighting the other guys before switching back to yourself instead of how they handled it.

The game is also far too short for being this price, even discounted I don't really find it worth it. If you played through the story, there are challenges which are pretty much playing the story again but with a specific weapon.

You can also rewatch your gameplay after a level, which would be pretty cool, if it wouldn't look so goofy at full speed, was shrunken down, had the worlds most ugliest effect over it and the robotic voice that is capable of less words than Groot from Guardians of the Galaxy: "Super Hot".

I actually have no problem with the grafics, I think it fits pretty well. The maps could have really used more veriety, the windows for example are pretty cool, having something in the map that is interactable.

If you still like the slow Motion shooting and want the game just for that, Time Shooter 2 on crazy games is probably your best option since instead of handing over your life savings, you can play the slightly worse version for free. On top of that, you don't need to suffer through this half-assed story.

If you couldn't tell, I kind of don't like the game but that is just my opinion, if you want to make your own, don't forget that you can refund games if you didn't play them for more than 2 hours and didn't own them for more than 2 weeks.

Cool concept but way too short of a game for what it is asking. The main mode can be beaten in an hour or so. Once you get beyond the time slowing down mechanic it's just a simple shooter with a few melee weapons.
The story mode is short and sweet, but I have little desire to complete all the endgame challenges. The main mechanic—time only moves as you do—gets old after spending 2 hours in the story mode.

This is a great and highly innovate fps, but it has some problematic design choices that weigh it down.

These problems mostly come in the delivery of information. Mind swap charged, full screen flash. Story beat, full screen flash. Run out of ammo, full screen flash. Anytime the game wants to tell you something, it gives you a flash-bang effect. It gave me a headache pretty quickly and I had to turn down the brightness of my monitor or look away whenever it got aggressive.

I get how the flashes tie into the story, but that doesn't make them magically not obnoxious. It also doesn't help that the story is charitably described as a low quality copy pasta. 2 hours isn't enough time to develop much, so at least keep the story elements from degrading the feeling of the game. 

The challenges and endless mode get this flash-bang effect the worst, which is a shame since that's where you will experiment the most and discover how deep the combat can be.

"Time moves only when you move"
This is a great concept that would have been much better if implemented in a game that has other things going for it. But as it stands, it's the only game mechanic, and there isn't much of a story either. You shoot some red guys then the game is over.

At the end of each level, they spam you with a loud voice repeating the game title. Perhaps to make sure you remember it. It's very annoying.

The game knows not to overstay its welcome, but the gameplay grows old faster still.
(It took me 2 hours to beat, then I left it open to get trading cards)

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]

[b]TL;DR:[/b] I wouldn't describe this game as a shooter but rather a puzzle game - which is something I can appreciate but unfortunately the game fails incredibly to feel rewarding due to the missing demand of sophisticated solutions. The level design and enemy placement is so trivial that it gets fairly hard to fail.


[h1]Pros:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Fantastic idea for a puzzle game
[*] Challenges and Endless mode do provide challenges - unfortunately in a fairly repetitive manner
[*] Modest visuals
[/list]

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
[list]
[*] Insanely annoying noises as well as voices
[*] Disgusting visuals and transitions between levels or within the Options
[*] The entire game is basically an infinite flash bang and you most likely have to select a low brightness mode on your monitor
[*] Gameplay loop is very repetitive and boring
[*] Fails to be a proper puzzle game (see TL;DR above)
[*] It is rather hard to read the movement of your enemies. Their entire body can scream they are about to change directions by 90° and proceed to not to while at the same time other enemies run towards you in full sprint, just to stop in an instant and run backwards without some kind of inertia. To be fair you can do the same. But once this mechanic is combined with the extremely slow bullet speed in comparison to movements it actually is one of the few shooter where I do struggle to hit headshots. Enemies may do a step or not. They may change directions or not. So instead of a potential fantastic puzzle game you get a very tedious enemy check. "Did I hit enemy 1? Did I hit enemy 2? Did I hit enemy 3? ..." over and over again.
[*] Story is fairly bland and barely existent
[*] Performance is meh ~140fps but you also don't really need more
[/list]

It’s okay — it’s actually great for, let’s say, modern Yu-Gi-Oh.

The game itself is probably much better than previous titles. Updates are frequent, new cards arrive about five months after they’re released in the TCG, duels are found almost instantly, and there are often events with changed limits or forbidden cards.

But for me, the game would be much better if you could switch the game mode to formats like Goat, Edison, etc., and find opponents who play the same format as you. Of course, you can create custom games and play that way with your friends — which I do — but why should I only play with my friends when I could play against you?

Overall, the game is good. I’ve made all the decks I own in real life, and it’s a great option to experiment with different strategies and to learn new decks much faster.

The most accessible way to play Yu-Gi-Oh! online. Cards trail behind the TCG/OCG by about 6 months. Gems for cards are earned at a decent rate. Perhaps the least gacha gacha game on the market. Unlike Duel Links, cards can be crafted/dismantled for dust, similar to Hearthstone at about a 3:1 ratio of dismantle to craft. This means even unplayable duds of the same rarity contribute towards cards you actually want. No need to scrape the bottom of the packs looking for must haves like Duel Links. Events are held roughly twice a month for some variety and include loaner decks to experience the latest decks, albeit not their meta versions. Ban list is wildly different to the TCG, for better and for worse.  While it doesn't make paper play obsolete, it is a fine alternative if you are just looking to play Yu-Gi-Oh!
A game between good and bad at times fun for awhile. Repeat.
Best way to play modern Yu-gi-Oh!

Yu-Gi-Oh! Master Duel delivers a compelling introduction to the long running card battling franchise by presenting a polished and accessible platform for both newcomers and veterans. The game captures the appeal of strategic duelling while retaining the depth that has defined the series. Its online focus allows for quick matchmaking and varied opponents, helping the experience remain consistently engaging.
Gameplay stands out as the strongest element, offering intricate duels that reward planning and adaptability. A wide card pool ensures that players can experiment with many strategies, from fast paced combos to slower control styles. The tutorial and guidance systems ease newer players into complex mechanics, making competitive play more approachable.
Visuals are polished and vibrant, adding flair to every duel without overwhelming the screen. Summon animations highlight key cards with cinematic touches that enhance the sense of progression during matches. The interface is clean and readable, contributing to a smooth and refined experience.
Overall, Yu Gi Oh! Master Duel succeeds in delivering a dynamic and engaging card game that respects its legacy while welcoming a new generation of players. Its blend of strategic depth, polished presentation and accessible features makes it a strong entry in the digital card game landscape. Despite its focus on competitive play, it still provides enough structure and charm to appeal broadly.
Yu-Gi-Oh! Master Duel gets a 7/10.

I recently got into the Yu-Gi-Oh for the first time and was overall pleasantly surprised, but Master Duel has some really bad stuff.

First of all, if a game has this many "must have" generic staples, they should be easy to get, and not be f****** URs, are you kidding me? And UR drops are so rare that by the time I time I collect enough dust for the playset of all of the must-play handtraps I already lost interest. Unlike in Hearthstone, each rarity uses separate dust, which means you need to actually pull URs to craft URs.

Around 25% of your deck is either generic handtraps everyone plays or counters to these handtraps, so it's not even like these expensive cards you're crafting are resulting in building cooler decks. They also don't give you more fun play experience either. It's like a nuclear race: both sides are forced to stockpile their decks with the most powerful weapons to keep up with the other side, even though the end result sucks for both of them.

On the plus side, the visuals and OST are fantastic. Solo mode is a good way to introduce archetypes, and the special tournaments are fun too - and often give rental decks, which bypasses the awful UR grind. If KONAMI uses experience from these they might improve ranked. Alternatively they could ban Maxx "C", that works too.

Pros: 
- Yu-Gi-Oh card simulation seems smooth. 
- Music is good.
- Highlights relevant card text for various effects. 
- Some event duels create new metas outside the traditional ranked. 

Cons: 
- Story mode content is basically a nice looking power point.
- In App account management between devices is a dumpster fire. (Do not play on any device before linking up your account. There is no simple log out button.) 
- Once event duels end, there is no meaningful way in game to engage with casual play. 
- Game locks packs of various archetypes, and you can only purchase these various types of packs by generating a card from that 'set' or using gems (earnable, but still a paid currency.) to hopefully pull an SR from the set. Which then allows you to spend gems on the set you are actually aiming for. 

It's a Yu-Gi-Oh! TCG simulator. As an official product that generates revenue, I would say it doesn't meet expectations. If you like Yu-Gi-Oh! - you will enjoy Yu-Gi-Oh! in the app. That's as far as it goes.
