Wait, I never left a review on this? Okay guess I get to absolutely rant.
[h1]I love Yugioh, but it does have flaws.[/h1]
My problem with Yugioh is actually the problem that it's basically the card game version of a fighting game. In my previous group, I was in the middle. The person above me would basically always win easily and I felt bad. The person below me would always lose to me even when I'm running the absolute funniest Amazement Traptrix deck you've ever seen, and like next level it'd be too easy to beat and they'd feel EXTREMELY bad. Is the solution just to play worse? I accidentally bullied my friends out of playing the game with me by playing the game it's very sad.

[u]This game has that problem to the extreme.[/u]

What's something you know about Yugioh?
It's that it's a best of 3 format, right? You see who goes first and then after the win people get a chance to use the side deck and pick for themselves if they go first or not. That means even if your deck does a flash in the pan instant win on game one, there's a chance you just straight up lose in the next two rounds because your opponent outplayed you with their backup cards or now that they know what you're actually doing, hand-trapping the correct cards. Or, your opponent doesn't draw any hand traps and only gets their starters and bricks and you win for free anyway [i]let's save that for another time...[/i]
But Master Duel is not that. Master Duel is a best of one. You go on the latter, you lose the coin flip, give up honestly it's over requeue to make it faster. Maybe if you had hand traps? Oh no sorry the best decks now resist hand traps anyway so like yeah just stop trying. There's one hand trap they can't resist but uh, we'll get to that at the very end.

You might wonder why I had so little playtime. I basically ruined the game for myself.
If you somehow didn't notice despite the fact you reading this are probably someone who actually spent a lot more time in the game, anything you want to play is all URs. Everything is URs. In the past you would have most of your main combo be SRs, some URs are the one-off boss monsters in the extra or something like that, and then MOST of your URs are the hand traps you run in every deck. That's nice, you only need to get the [i]really expensive[/i] high rarity cards that you'll just put into every profile to make them at the bare level playable in this landscape.
[u]I played ghostricks and doll monsters. I spent all of my currency on those two decks and I only got the full deck for one of them, but not even the hand traps since I didn't know they existed because when I played it was my first time with Yugioh ever.[/u]
You HAVE to know in advance the good cards in Yugioh normally, kinda sucks but whatever I guess. Uh so I did permanent account damage to myself for pulling fully on a pack that I thought was cool and then never got the really really really good auto-include cards because nothing and nobody ever told me they were even a thing. The tutorial certainly didn't explain to me, "Make sure to craft some hand traps before heading out!"
Ghostrick also isn't a good deck. So what would it take if I, today, for some reason wanted to get right back into the game and play the new meta?

34 URs.

[h1]Excuse me, what?[/h1]
In order to keep the sun in the sky shining or something, Konami has decided now that every single new archetype that comes out now is all URs. All of them, every single one, with the SRs being leftover cards from the past still relevant today, like idk 3 rares? If even? And then the only common card, one copy, in the entire profile is the archetypal trap card. I don't think I need to explain why that's extremely bad. I'll give my personal example of how bad that is in a second but let me sideline with something about balance here since I did say the whole "every match is a coinflip" and you might be wondering why.

[h2]So yes, the current meta is Maliss[/h2]
They are extremely expensive and blah blah. What really upsets me is the fact they are the strongest. Master Duel most often gets their content drops last, after TCG and OCG. OCG gets pack reveals and their cards first, meaning there's room for issues and stuff with the random cards and stuff people get excited for yeah that's fine. TCG usually gets the same cards with some TCG exclusives months later, with content from the OCG redefining what happens in these packs allowing it to be more fair and fun for everyone. Sometimes, let's not forget the Bonfire incident. But in general that's multiple months to prepare for the next release basically using OCG as a testing ground.

Master Duel had so long to wait for Maliss. They had all the time in the world to see the deck was outperforming the competition and making people sad or mad and such. With all this extra time, they could prepare for the release by maybe like straight up holding off some of the cards from the deck until later? Like straight up not even print Dormouse (not a real suggestion but an example) so that the deck can exist but is in such an underpowered state that it will not ruin everything that exists here. It's a digital game, they control all fictional copies of cards and their availability. They could even have cards limited or semi-limited on release if they really wanted to. People would feel weird about it but they could've done anything.
So then can someone please explain to me why they still decided to release Maliss, full power, and it has dominated the meta of this game for I believe over four months now???? Are you actually kidding me? Is it so hard to just not have done that? Does releasing it in full power actually print that much money? It probably does because as I explained, decks are way too expensive to make now. Speaking of:

If I burn my entire collection, I most likely won't even get halfway there. Okay how about a less powerful deck like Diabellestar? Mix it with White Forest and Azamina, the full lore strategy, sounds pretty fun!
If I was crazy enough to not wanna do the default good cards you always include, I just wanted the playable cards for the actual deck of Diabell, it would STILL BE [b]28[/b] ULTRA RARE CARDS.
Like, if I destroyed literally every single card I've ever pulled from packs, I wouldn't even have enough just to make the bare essentials like Ash Blossom, Crossout, Called By, Fuwalos or

[h1]Maxx 'C'[/h1]
Big shock, I hate the card. I think it makes the game objectively worse.
"OCG has it and they're fine!" Best of 3 format. Do not. They don't even like the card themselves either! If you've ever bothered asking them, most OCG players actually despise it probably MORE than us because unlike TCG players, they actually do have to deal with it!
They at the very least have a chance to survive it, with a best of 3 format that makes it sometimes possible [i]not[/i] to draw it. They really have so much going against them already but they can at least play the game over there.
Not over here! If you get Maxx 'C'ed, you have only the one round of this one game match to beat your opponent. Better pack it up, this isn't a coin flip on just who goes first anymore, it's an additional coin flip on who resolved Maxx 'C'. You finally got to go first, but your opponent baited your Called By with Fuwalos and now gets to Maxx 'C' you? Tough shit, game is over. You can probably play like 3 cards and realize your opponent got better pot of greed into ash + imperm + nibiru + called by for their turn and you auto lose. Congrats. Oh so your opponent got to do basically full combo even through your hand traps and now its your turn, but they Maxx 'C' you off the top? It's over. Break their board and let them pick up their entire deck, sure.
9/10 times Maxx 'C' resolves, the game is already decided.

Tuleb tõdeda, et kuigi Sea Of Thieves pretendeerib kõrgtasemelisele mereavastuse ja piraatluse simulaakrumile, on selle tegelik struktuur valdavas ulatuses ühekülgne ning kannatab korduva sisulise hõreduse käes. Mängijale lubatakse müstilist ja ohtuderohket merd, ent liiga sageli leiab end üksluisest ringkäigust.

Progressioonisüsteem kaldub liialt kosmeetilistesse nipsasjadesse, mille funktsionaalne väärtus jääb minimaalseteks. Sügavama sisulise arengu asemel näib mängija pingutust kroonivat üksnes esteetiline tühisus, mis mõjub alavääristavalt ja juhib tähelepanu kõrvale teose võimalikust strateegilisest potentsiaalist.

Kõige eelneva valguses leian paratamatult, et Sea of Thieves, kuigi visuaalselt lummav ja atmosfäärilt potentsiaalikas, ei saavuta kunstilist ega tehnilist küpsust, mida selle mastaap väärinuks. Mäng ei seisa väärikana omaenda ambitsioonide kõrgusel ning vajab sisulist, mitte pelgalt kosmeetilist revideerimist.

I could not get the game to respect my settings and not use hands free calling for my wireless Headset. 
For those who don't know this results in horrible Audio quality since Bluethooth is not capable of handling high quality In and output at the same time. Just imaginge putting your phone in a tin can and put the volume to max. Then you know how this sounds. This is not an issue in any other game I own. Every game respects not using the Headset mic how its set up in windows.

Deactivation all other devices besides my USB mic and Headphones did not work. 
Changing gamebar and xbox settings to use the Headphones for just output and the usb mic for input did not work. 
Deactiviating Hands Free mode via windows resulted in no audio at all. 

The game always forced the hdeadphones to be used in hands free mode resulting in horrible audio quality for the whole system. 

After trying everything i could find online about fixing it and nothing working i just gave up and refunded without playing a single second.  I wasted over an hour researching and messing with settings without success. 

Sad that a mircrosoft related company can not get their product to work properly with their own operating system.

In all honesty I love this game, I started playing this back in season 4. However, this game has been recently plagued by some pretty annoying issues. I was never one for pvp, anytime the devs try to make serious changes to pvp the loud minority of player wine until the meta is reestablished. The current issue with pvp in sea of thieves is not that it is hard but that it is boring, the tactics are flushed out and all battle basically devolve into get on their ship and drop the anchor. The second big issue is the player base in general, every time I play the game i either am fighting someone screaming racial slurs, a literal child, or someone with the pvp skins who have clearly played more hours then me. Now I know what your thinking just get gud, play more hours and pvp, well here's the thing I don't want to and apparently considering the dwindling player count no one else does either. Even if I did I pretty much run into cheaters every time I play. Alternatively rare has included a team sever mode, which is great but due to the how much your loot drops are nerfed combined with no multipliers that mode isn't very fulfiling. This caused the player spike when the mode was released to be very short lived. Not to mention the most recent tall tales sucked. 

To summarize:
Cheaters, sweats, and murder hobos ruined pvp
hour glass is full of cheaters
PVP is to linear and always plays the same
A team server that is less restrictive would actually sustain the player spike
PVP players will argue that the game got worse when the solo mode was added, they are lying it is a disingenuous argument that suits their desire to fight someone who doesn't want to. There were large player spikes when the mode was added and the main complaint was it was to restrictive, the less restrictive form nerfed loot drops and did not allow for meaningful progression. 
Would I recommend this game, nope, games player count is on the decline and unlike in season 4 solo slooping no longer feels doable.

Sekiro isn’t just a great game—it’s a triumph of design, storytelling, and craftsmanship. FromSoftware took the soul of their signature difficulty and forged it into something faster, tighter, and more exhilarating than anything they’d made before. The result? A game that doesn’t just challenge you—it transforms you.

From the moment you pick up the sword, Sekiro becomes a dance. Every clash, every deflection, every perfectly timed parry feels like a spark of lightning in your hands. Unlike other action games, Sekiro doesn’t let you hide behind shields or overpowered builds. It demands mastery, discipline, and patience. And when you finally get it, the game opens up in the most rewarding way possible. Few gaming moments compare to breaking an enemy’s posture and landing that final, devastating deathblow—it’s pure satisfaction.

The world of Ashina is equally stunning. From misty temple forests to burning castles and mythical mountains, every area feels alive and purposeful. The vertical movement, grappling hook traversal, and stealth options give the world a sense of depth that makes exploration genuinely thrilling. You don’t just walk from place to place—you swoop, climb, stalk, and strike.

Sekiro’s story, though quieter than most, hits with surprising emotional weight. Wolf’s journey is simple on the surface—save your young lord—but the bonds, betrayals, and moral choices woven into the narrative give every moment gravity. It’s a tale about loyalty, honor, and the weight of legacy, told with elegance and restraint.

Bosses are where Sekiro truly becomes legendary. Each one is a test of everything you’ve learned: Genichiro tightening your fundamentals, the Guardian Ape shocking you with unexpected chaos, Isshin pushing you to your absolute limits. They’re not just fights—they’re iconic encounters that stay with you long after the credits roll.

Sekiro is not an easy game, but it is a fair one. It respects the player. It teaches without words. And when you finally overcome the impossible, it rewards you with a sense of triumph few games can match.

It’s not just one of FromSoftware’s best—it’s one of the greatest action games ever made. A masterpiece of precision, passion, and unforgettable moments.

It is a solid  game with awesome graphics as you would expect from FromSoft. However, it is a console game they overlaid PC keyboard play ability on too. I'm a PC Gamer and don't have a game console. The game's sword parry, deflection, and dodge mechanics require being far too good with heavy penalties for dying and very little resources for healing. You may have to plan on restarting with a new game several times unless you are a natural speedster. Also, if you die, you have to do the entire area over. You don't get to pick where your save points are.

Hard to recommend this.

E.g.
- The game is designed in a way to make it very difficult to learn. You have to get good at parrying, and weirdly it offers you very little opportunity to really do that. 
- Far too much BS, and far too many situations encouraging cheese.
- OP consumables that trivialise fights, but extremely rare to find so tough shit if you didn't kill the boss the time you used snap seeds.
- Punishes the dying and learning cycle with dragonrot mechanic.

I did get to a point where I enjoyed the game, but FromSoft really did make it as difficult as they could to get to that point. I'd recommend Lies of P or Khazan over it any day.

Yeah its a decent game but not worth the money it costs... I would only say buy if on sale, the mechanics can be so clunky sometimes and the bosses are just flat out wayyyyyy stronger than the character like its so bs. I am usually very good at souls like games but I just cant with this game I feel like my characters power is = to a toddler. Another point is that when u die ( which happens a lot) you usually lose like half ur stuff which sucks and theres not nearly enough checkpoints. A very tedious game like this need manual checkpointing. Many things could be better but oh well.
This game is NOT for weenies. And I am a stupid loser, and an unlovable weenie freak. I'll never beat this game and as a man this hurts my "gamer" soul.

The combat system is neat. Its enjoyable for a bit but gets really repetitive and drawn out on some encounters.

A lot of bosses have really cheap tricks that they throw at you that feels like it breaks the flow of the combat and I don't find the cheapness fair or interesting. Most of the bosses and mini bosses can kill you in just one or two hits, which makes learning them a painful chore, but of course you need to get about 50 in so that their posture bar doesn't deplete so fast in order to kill them. 

Player dropoff is almost 50% by the first major boss. For the rest, a lot of players resort to cheese tactics to beat a lot of the encounters, which I think goes against the intent of the game. I get being tough, but I find this game doesn't always play by its own rules. 

Despite picking it up a few separate times to give it a fresh approach, each time I find I just hate it.

Usually challenging games make it fun to develop the skills needed to play it. Fromsoft games seem to take the opposite approach: make the player miserable until they can rise above the challenge, and punish the player for needing to learn. Sekiro is no different. I haven't encountered a boss in a couple of hours because I'm stuck exploring this vast area with lots of dangerous enemies and no checkpoints. Sneak past them? Sure, maybe a couple. But when I need to enter a cavern guarded by 5 enemies, or when the way forward is guarded by monks with spears that do half my health bar with one hit, it's just not fun. This game doesn't make me want to get better at it, it makes me want to quit. The realization that dragonrot also punishes you for dying by denying you the ability to do side quests? Yeah, I'm done with this.

Great game so far but I have issues with launching the game a lot of the times. For example, if I connect my controller AFTER launching the game, the game will be screen-locked and I'd be forced to restart my PC because I can't tab out or even close the game. Sometimes, the only thing I can do is Alt+F4 and restart the game when this bug occurs.

Oftentimes, the game will get stuck on a black screen and I'd get a message prompt saying that the application isn't responding which also forces me to restart my PC in order to play. Another bug is sometimes when I'm in game, I can't tab out from the screen or even use any keyboard buttons such as Print Screen to take screenshots.

While I am enjoying the game and find myself constantly thinking about wanting to play it on the weekends, I can't recommend it in its current state unless you're okay with possibly being forced to put up with all these bugs.

For people who are fans of very hard games, this might be it for you. But be warned I've played Silksong and Dark Souls and liked them just fine.

For me there's just too many frustrating issues with this game.

___GAMEPLAY____

First off, there's very little choice in how you engage with the combat or the world. It's one of the most linear games I've played in a long while. 

How the game GENERALLY work is as follows, you, the player, will enter an area, where there's a set number of enemies, you can't really attack multiple enemies at once, since they'll just gang up on you immediately, so 1-on-1 is definitely preferred, occasionally you can deal a couple of the weaker enemies at the same time, but generally you definitely want to sneak around and stealth kill.

The stealth is half baked and feels on rails, sometimes enemies can spot you a mile away and run ALL the way to you, other times you can shank a friend of theirs 5 meters to their right and they'd be none the wiser. It really depends on if you stealth kill the enemies in the correct sequence. This can be a very lengthy process and you're gonna do this A LOT in each area.

The combat is too much waiting and either parry/jump/dodge (except dodge is super nerfed in this game) depending on the attack animation. You have very little agency in controlling the battles you are almost only reacting and never acting, it's like one long randomized QTE you have to endure. This is to the point where the miniboss battles I did endure to beat was not enjoyable or fun but just a chore. 

Miniboss? you ask, why yes, there's two kinds of hard enemies, afaik, minibosses and then regular bosses, the regular bosses will give you a small boost to your attack stat (btw, there's no allocation of rpg stats in this game, so forget about "builds") now minibosses are probably gonna take up most of your time, they're basically very difficult enemies with a series of attack patterns that you need to learn 100% or else you'll just die. Mostly you need to learn to deflect when the correct animation plays (which is the vast, VAST majority of combat) to the point it feels like you're playing a rhythm game.

Now a lot of the combat is supposed to be about reading the animation and reacting accordingly, but do you know what's constantly blocking the camera from clearly seeing the enemy that you're up close to? that's right the player character itself. Then there's the camera who will spazz out when you're in tight corners. and sometimes just not lock on to the enemy RIGHT NEXT to you, and in an easier game I could forgive that, totally, but not when the punishment for death is as high as it is. 

Whenever you die, and you will die, a lot, you lose half your money and a lump portion of xp, which can't be retrieved, it's just gone. Then there's the dragonrot where if you die enough times, which you will, npcs will stop helping you, so you have to spend extra money to fix it in order to progress a story line.

____STORY AND LORE____

Then there's the story and lore, I do think there's something interesting about this world and how so many of it's inhabitants are obsessed with immortality, especially the undead monks, were really cool.

But I don't care about the main character and his lord (a twelve year old boy with magic resurrection blood), really none of the characters are of any interest to me, except maybe the Carver and the undead training dummy, they're kindda funny. 

____Overall____
And that's really the issues I have overall with the game, I'm not interested in getting better in a game, that I have so little stake in. I don't care about the characters or what's gonna happen next to them, the world itself is kindda cool, but not enough to warrant the ungodly amount of hours I'd have to invest in order to "git gud".

I have had more fun dueling the Razor in Slay The Princess than any of the bosses in this wanna-be-tough-guy game.

I will still get to Sword Saint just so the fanboys can't scream "gIT GuD!!!1!1!!!!" at me for not liking the game.

Good parts: i commend them for releasing a game that isn't a soulsborne. All enemies are new which surprised me and i don't expect originality coming from fromsoft. The game does feel good to play when it all works, and it looks like there is a cool idea beneath the bad stuff.

Bad stuff: 60 fps locked in current year. If a mod can easily bypass this, then this can be added by devs. For me this is enough of a dealbreaker on its own. The option menu is abysmal, and although performance is not as atrocious as Elden Ring, it's unacceptable for a game that looks as this one does.

Posture system is a neat idea but in reality it doesn't. Your own posture barely matters, most enemies can't punish a posture break and it takes less than 2 seconds to recover by just holding block. On bosses it matters but not as much as damage. You can kill a boss by depleting the posture, but for posture to not deplete fast, you need to deal damage first. So it ends up feeling like posture damage doesn't matter for a good chunk of the fight, and then damage doesn't matter. I get the idea but it's badly executed.

Farming is waaaay too encouraged. If you have a ton of experience you are encouraged to farm till your next level or you risk too much if you die. Gold pouches seem like a system that only feels bad. You don't feel smart for paying the 10% tax to save your gold, losing it feels bad, using the pouches feels bad. It's not like gold is super necessary, it's just there to make you feel bad about dying. More than a soulslike. XP tree is bloated with things just to encourage farming. Shinobi tool upgrades require a ton of materials that are rare drops on specific mobs. There are literally consumables to help you farm. Why not like, remove this entirely from the game? It adds nothing and makes everything feel worse. You even have to farm your revives, so you'll be attempting a boss, you don't have your 2/3 revives, you need to go out, kill some trash to farm your revives, to go back to the boss and lose the xp and gold you gathered while farming.

Which gets us to the next point. The trial and error is replaced by a easier game where you are punished a lot for failing. Consumables are super op, tools are op, revives are op, you get too much healing. You can pretty much bulldoze your way through the game as intended; or you can try to learn bosses, try to defeat them cleanly and meanwhile feel that the game is angry at the way you want to enjoy playing it. At least dragon rot was partially removed from the game, holy shit, what a dumb mechanic, it's like these people forget all the mistakes they already made, insane that it didn't get completely removed.

Quests and story as incomprehensible as ever, but if you like following a guide to get the endings power to you. Exploration is a bit messed up with places getting up to 3 different states and loot shifting around, but that's not a biggy.

Bosses are pretty good for the most part, really low amount of bullshit, even if you are trying to properly learn them. Barring a couple of bosses that go against the main design of the game and are just tanks you have to hit 300 times and you are discouraged from parrying. It's like they have a dumb ideas for bosses quota and they need to hit it.

So yeah, i know these games gather the most undesirable people whose only form of self validation is being able to beat a kinda hard game and they can't have a different opinion pop up on the steam reviews. So kindly, fuck off.
yeah i think fromsoft missed the mark on this one. its just not fun.

I'm going to go against the grain here - In my opinion, this is the worst game from FromSoft. The need to mod the game so I can play at more than 60 fps on PC is ridiculous. I love the Souls genre, but this just didn't hit the spot for me.

Who knew Fromsoftware could come up with a death mechanic more egregiously awful and time wasting than what they did in the Souls games? Amazing! Combine that with brain-dead simplistic stealth and overly punishing one hit enemies and you have a casserole of garbage. It is literally the least punishing stealth game ever, combined with EXTREME punishment for getting hit by bosses. The game systems also encourage grinding in numerous different ways. Grinding is bad game design, period. 

If you have played any 3D stealth game in your life, the stealth gameplay will be trivial. And incredibly boring. If you alert an enemy, walk away for 30 seconds and the enemy will forget all about you. WTF?! Is this a PS1 game? Over half of this "hard" game would be literally trivial gameplay for a 10 year old. 

The other bits are literally rote memorization bosses that kill you in 2 to 3 hits. So you will likely die and have to traverse back to try again. It is pure tedium, which is the actual design mechanic Miyazaki has perfected; disguising tedium as gameplay. Additionally, the main strategy in this game is spam the parry button. Apparently it works on 80-90% of bosses. BORING!!! It is an insultingly easy stealth game wrapped around an insultingly punishing, but boring, action game. Who pretends to enjoy awful gameplay like this? Add in the Fromsoft classics of obvious dropped inputs and one of the worst cameras of any 3D game made past 2002 and this becomes a truly dreadful game.

TLDR: This game is trash. Miyazaki is one of the most overpraised creators in the history of the world. In 30 years, people are going to try and play these praised games and wonder just how high (or dumb) you had to be in order to pretend to enjoy this crap. 30 years before this shit-stain you had Super Mario 3, and Sid Meyer's Pirates, and Sim City. Games that are inherently enjoyable. This game inherently sucks. It also has objective technical issues like the capped 60 FPS from a 2019(!) game and the dropped inputs and Mario 64 level-of-awful camera, that you should not be able to argue about. Yet Fromsoft fanbois WILL argue about these obvious and blatant technical incompetencies. If you don't believe me, just Google "Sekiro camera issues" and see people step up to simp for Miyazaki and pretend that every game he has ever made is totally perfect. You people act as if you are in a cult. It is straight up creepy. 

Edit after review is up for one hour: Just look at the typical FromSoft fanboi loser commenting on my review of a six year old game. This is the behavior of someone who likes this garbage. Some straight up socially retarded obsessive compulsive behavior. These people cannot STAND IT when someone has a different opinion than them. It is incredibly pathetic behavior, and oh so predictable.
Sick of fromsoftware games. Not buying anything else from them ever again.

A lot of people really like this game but I was not really a fan. It feels like From gutted the RPG experience in a bid to have better action than ever before, but because of how parry-focused this game is, the action actually feels like a dumbed down rhythm game. The exploration and level design is also a lot more confusing and frustrating in this game because of the verticality given to the player. In the Souls games, you pretty much could just follow every path to its end and you would be pretty unlikely to miss that much. In this game, you need to keep your eye out for random tree branches to grapple to which could appear above or below where you're standing on a cliff face hundreds of feet away, or walls to climb that sometimes aren't very clearly signposted, which can lead to you getting lost even just trying to complete the main story. 

That being said, the combat definitely still has the potential to be quite satisfying. The final boss of the standard route is one of the most exhilarating fights From has ever made, so there's definitely fun to be had. But be aware that your experience with this game might vary, especially depending on your expectations. You are not guaranteed to love the game just because you loved Dark Souls or Elden Ring. 

Wish I could give this game something in between recommended/not recommended, but most of my experience with Sekiro was negative so it gets a "not recommended" from me. That doesn't mean there's no chance you'll enjoy it, or that if you had fun playing the game your feelings are somehow invalid. Just understand that this game is not for everyone, and know that not being for everyone can be a good thing.

Despite what people may have told you, the game is not a rhythm game, and certainly doesn't just "click" at some point. These are claims are from folks who wish to hold there skill above you. When looking for advice, tips or technique about the game the most common responses in forums are "i just did it" or "just do it without {spirit emblems, attack power, prayer beads, consumables, any skills, etc etc}" or "you can just do {be perfect} and win", or "it wasn't a problem for me". This being the standard community response when people are asking for help when struggling shows you everything you need to know about the game.

I wish people would just say:
"It was hard, and i'm glad i did it so i can say i did."
Which is great, i feel the same way,

It's hard all the way through, it doesn't get easier, you can't go out and try other things and come back stronger, you won't magically get better.

The lineup at the end with Owl(85 attempts), Owl2(143), and the final boss(157) are nutty hard, in remarkably un-fun ways, lightning w/e is the dumbest gimmick in the game. The game always finds a new way to do something rude. The example i roll my eyes at the hardest is the merchant you can buy ako's sugar and divine confetti going away when you get the world to the final state to fight the last 3 bosses... glad him and his buddy are gone just before the fights i'd want those the most for /s

If you're coming to this from DS/ER don't waste your time unless you're the type of player who likes to play with 10 Vigor or Soul Level 1. Sekiro makes the choice for you what weapon you'll use and how hard the game will be, you don't get any control over that, unless you want intentionally not gain attack power or prayer beads or ring a bell and make everything worse lol.

Positive Notes:
The combat and movement is the tightest of any FromSoft game, following a named character and feeling like part of the story is great, visually the game is wonderful... gory and beautiful. FightinCowboy, Tyrannicon, Ogles and a few other exemplary people on the subreddit and YouTube do some heavy heavy lifting, the tiny minority of people on these forums being offering real advice and sharing practical experience I am in great debt to, i couldn't have done it without y'all.

tl;dr game could be 50% easier and still be amazing, as it stands it's laughable that a game that 55% of the player base never beats Genchiro (the first real boss) was even in the conversation for game of the year.

Let's start with the reason for this review being negative: I don't believe this game deserves this high of a score in Steam's community rating system. Personally, yes, I do reccomend this game, but the issues with new player expierience are too glaring for this game to be Overwhelmingly Positive. 

I won't be focusing on the positives too much here, there's plenty of other reviews about that. And they're right, mind you, the combat systems *is* that good, the world *is* that cool. 

So what are my issues with the new player expierience? Two things, mainly: consumables and penalties. Your Shinobi Prosthetics use a consumable resource that you have to farm if you run out while learning a boss. There are enemies that are extremely hard to fight without a specific item. Ran out while learning? Welp, go farm. 
Another thing - Dragonrot. That's a union between consumables and penalties. And I know Dragonrot doesn't actually matter, that you have to intentionally try to make it a real problem because there are enough items to cure it, but that doesn't change the fact that it feels awful. 
Just like the next thing - loss of exp and money on death. Like, why? I died, I don't need extra penalties to know I've failed. The only thing this system incentivizes is roaching out whenever you feel like you might die for real. And what do you do after that? Run to the bonfire. Which s the same result as death. It also hinders exploration because if you see anything that resembles a boss arena and you're currently holding a lot of exp or gold you just can't enter it. So you have to go farm enough exp or gold to buy what you want, and only then can you progress. Not cool imo. 

And so all of that amounts to game punishing you for learning. Which seems real weird considering that also seems to be the main way of playing it. It also doesn't help that you are the weakest at the start of the game, both in terms of resources and personal skill. You lack many useful upgrades, your healing is very limited, your health and attack power are low. 

A few side things: 
- stealth is quite a big part of the game, so it's a bit weird how the enemies are dumb as fucking bricks. Their vision and hearing are terrible, unless the game says "nu uh" on a few occasions and gives them supersight and hearing. There's one ninja that has cheats and will lock onto you the moment you enter his zone or kill the dog that alerts him. The only way to kill him with stealth is to drop from 100 meters above him. Ranged enemies have generally better eyesight, so I guess that make sense but still feels weird compared to their dull melee kin. Oh, did I mention they have ZERO information spread? If you throw a shuriken at an enemy talking to another enemy the one you hit will lock onto you, but the other one will be just midly concerned. There can be situations where an eneme is chasing you while all the other ones in the are are just going about their business. 
- the game's paths feel forced at times. The ever-useful grapple can only connect to points the developers put by hand. So sometimes there's 50 of them all around, but then suddenly when it'd be really useful and help you skip something bam, not a single point, even if it feels like it should be there by game's logic. I don't recall the exact circumstances but I've encountered a rocky wall a child could climb but since it wasn't designed so it was impossible for my nimble shinobi to go up it. The point is that the clash between a nimble shinobi and a character that has to follow a set path oftentimes exposes the game for what it is. 
- the deatblow animations, while extremely cool, seem like a bit of an overkill for bosses' first healthbar. I put a hole in a normal guy's throat and he just shrugs it off the first time around. It's more of a nitpick but it does feel funny/weird. 


Like I said, in the end I enjoyed this game. I got 100%, did a charmless run, beat all 4 gauntlets. I reccomend it but I just want people to know that it's not just "git gud" that stops new players.

I cannot reccomend this to anyone. It's an NES standard game. Enemy damage and health/posture is boosted to artificially increase the game time and the entire thing is centered around pattern recognition, which is so not fun. The input reading just adds salt to the wounds.

Sekiro is a great game that suffers from the syndrome known as being apart of the Soulsborne Legacy. That is to say, everything that Sekiro does right feels like an evolution of the Darksouls formula, but fails to let go of aspects that makes it miserable. The game play is excellent- when you already know exactly what to do. The map is well designed - when you know exactly where to go. The game is fun to play - after you've already mastered it. If that sounds nice too you, get it, but I can't recommend a game like that in good faith.

Pros (which there are a lot of)
- Fast and Interesting evolution of Souls-Borne combat
- Excellent Boss-gated Leveling system
- Amazing atmosphere 
- Interesting Bosses

Cons
- Weird tacked on Souls-mechanics that detract from the Experience (Abhorrent camera, Weird hitboxes, Souls-esk Stumbling and Uncharacteristic clumsiness, occasionally inconsistent rules)
- Lack of proper tutorialization/introduction to mechanics (Lightning attacks, Shielded Enemies, Archaic actions required for certain areas of progression.)
- Very forgettable story with mediocre characters
- Beginner unfriendly, not encouraged to experiment (Very low heath at game start, Potential to be soft-locked out of using an XP mechanic due to death mechanic, Items made to ease difficulty implemented frustratingly poorly.)

I'd say this game is a time sink, where if you spend the time, you WILL enjoy it, but after 40-some hours, I know for me this is not something I'd recommend to others, nor is something I'd complete without a guide in hand, cheesing every boss I had the mispleasure of facing for the first time.

Not well designed and incredibly overrated. The good things include the visuals, the story, and the one on one combat is amazing. However, they do their very best to avoid that. In summary, you have to wade through hours of slop until reaching a handful of amazing bosses, which just isn't worth it. There are too many good games out there to waste 30 hours on this. I would suggest Nine sols as a similar game that just was miles better for me. Sekiro has potential to be amazing if it leaned into one on one combat and reworked a couple of the areas, but it feels like it does its best to avoid this, so overall not worth the time or money.

Insanely overrated game. Boring, tedious, and repetitive. It boggles the mind to think that quick-time-events are unanimously hated in the gaming community (and rightfully so), but this game is universally praised as a masterpiece. Essentially, every fight is a punishing, lopsided QTE simulator that requires quick reflexes and enemy attack pattern memorization. Block/parry most attacks, dodge/jump when it's something like a charge, sweep, grapple, etc. Succeed and you get a brief window to chip away at the enemy, maybe 3-4% of their health. Fail and you get hit for 50-75% of your own health. 

It's Guitar Hero, but with ninjas. F*ck off.

A well calculated game...

NBA 2K20 continues the franchise’s tradition of delivering a highly realistic basketball simulation, with stellar visuals, tight gameplay, and robust content. However, it’s not without its flaws.

Pros:
Gameplay Mechanics: Smooth and responsive controls make dribbling, passing, and shooting feel intuitive. AI improvements enhance realism in both offense and defense.
Graphics and Presentation: Stunning visuals and lifelike player animations capture the essence of the NBA, while dynamic commentary keeps the experience immersive.
MyCareer Mode: A compelling storyline with celebrity involvement adds depth, alongside satisfying customization options for your player.
Variety of Modes: From MyTeam to MyLeague, there’s plenty of content to keep players engaged, whether you prefer competitive online play or managing a franchise.

Cons:
Microtransactions: Heavy reliance on in-game purchases in modes like MyTeam and MyCareer detracts from the enjoyment, especially for casual players.
Repetitiveness: Despite small updates, gameplay can feel overly familiar for long-time fans.
Server Issues: Online connectivity remains inconsistent, which can be frustrating for multiplayer enthusiasts.

Verdict:
NBA 2K20 shines in gameplay and presentation but stumbles with aggressive monetization and recurring technical hiccups. It’s an excellent choice for basketball fans who can overlook its shortcomings. Rating: 7.5/10.

[h3] I asked the community which NBA game on steam to play. [/h3]

[h1] Gameplay: [/h1]

I can't compare with other NBA 2k's because I haven't played since Allen Iverson's 03.
But I enjoy playing this one, the game is smooth and stable, the difficulty is easily adaptable to your level.
Progression through the game is fast, and the gameplay can be adapted according to ability.
Dribbling is much more complex than I remember, where I used to dribble all over the place with the SG.
Gameplay can be adapted to make the game very arcade-like, big dunk, stealing, fast pass, alley oops and I love it.
The MyCareer mode is very bad, we need a very low level to progress, better than Jordan but ridiculous all the same.
I probably don't understand the concept of this mode, even though it's one I'm very fond of in any other sports.
The ambiance is very immersive, though, and you really feel like an NBA player.
The other “online” modes are inactive, and the game can be considered dead if you don't play against the AI.


[h3] The game is dead, but I still enjoy the occasional match, so I can only recommend it if you don't want to play online.  [/h3]

NBA 2K20 has received overwhelmingly negative reviews, becoming the 5th lowest-rated game on Steam.
Bugs and Technical Issues
There are numerous bugs and technical problems that hamper the gaming experience. There are tons of graphical performance issues, with some users noting that the game looks less crisp and polished compared to its console counterparts. Performance problems and lag have also been mentioned, affecting gameplay smoothness and responsiveness.
One of the most prevalent complaints is the rampant cheating in online modes. Only the PC version is plagued by hackers, significantly diminishing the enjoyment of multiplayer gameplay. The lack of effective anti-cheating measures has led to a toxic online environment, with many users exploiting the game's vulnerabilities.
2K Games has been criticized for their insufficient efforts to combat cheating. The absence of robust anti-cheat systems has allowed hackers to run rampant, particularly in online modes. This issue has persisted across multiple iterations of the game, leading to frustration among legitimate players seeking fair competition.
The combination of bugs, cheaters, and lack of anti-cheat measures has severely impacted the overall gaming experience. While some players find enjoyment in single-player modes like MyCareer and MyLeague, the online component of NBA 2K20 on PC is frustrating and unbalanced due to the prevalence of cheaters.
In conclusion, NBA 2K20 for PC has been marred by technical issues, rampant cheating, and inadequate developer response to these problems. While the game may offer some enjoyment in its offline modes, the online experience falls short of expectations due to the lack of effective anti-cheating measures and the resulting toxic environment.

I hate NBA 2K20 with an intensity that’s hard to put into words - it’s truly insane! This game is complete trash, filled with clunky mechanics, frustrating shooting glitches, and zero innovation. It doesn’t even work half the time, making it more of a chore than a game. The MyCareer mode is painfully shallow, and the constant push for microtransactions feels exploitative. The company is extremely greedy, more interested in squeezing every last dollar out of fans than delivering a quality experience.

Honestly, I can’t imagine even basketball legends like Shaquille O'Neal would call this game anything but trash - he’d probably take a sledgehammer to a copy, smash it to pieces, and then set it aflame! And let’s be real, I wouldn’t be surprised if LeBron James took the DVD and pissed on it! All NBA players would be embarrassed to be associated with this mess.

The company keeps releasing the same game year after year, milking fans dry while delivering nothing new. No one should buy this game! I’d rather burn money, set my house aflame, or destroy all my clothes than endure this mess again. I’d happily shatter every window in my home and watch it be torn down instead of playing this game for another minute.

Letting myself be bitten by a snake sounds more appealing than facing the clunky gameplay and endless glitches. I’d rather stub my toe repeatedly, fail all my exams, or have all my life’s hard work be destroyed than deal with this disaster. I’d even willingly get my leg amputated or spend a week in a jail cell rather than suffer through NBA 2K20. Honestly, I’d rather be eaten by lions than put up with this game!

I’d gladly take a sledgehammer to my TV, dig a hole in my backyard, or scrub my floors with a toothbrush just to escape this non-functional mess. Cleaning out a filthy garage, organizing my sock drawer, or listening to elevator music for hours sounds like a welcome distraction. The thought of watching paint dry or listening to a lecture on tax law feels like a treat compared to this. I’d rather clean my gutters, deal with a flat tire, or spend an entire weekend cleaning the attic than endure NBA 2K20.

It’s an insult to basketball fans everywhere, and it deserves to be buried and forgotten! Do yourself a favor and steer clear of this game - it’s nothing more than a cash grab wrapped in flashy graphics!

Please read this before buying! It's not that it's a terrible game. It's easy to pick up and engaging, but the more you master it and become familiar with it, the more you realize how much it relies on RNG. Everything is chance to the point of every loss feeling less like a strategic error and more like you did not get lucky enough on the cards drawn.

Compare this to Balatro. Balatro is perfectly balanced, and once you gain skill in Balatro, beating the base difficulties feels pretty easy. You unlock new decks and new chips which enhance the difficulty, and it can become as difficult as you want. 

In Slay the Spire, you have no choice. It'd be like Balatro starting you off with one of the highest difficulties and saying good luck. This is lazy game design; add gradations in difficulty and let people have satisfying runs where they feel OP before it ends and they unlock a higher difficulty. You're literally climbing the same levels each time in this and it feels like Sisyphus pushing the boulder up the hill only for it to fall back down over and over again. Not satisfying at all, losses feel unfair and painful versus informative, not enough unlocks to incentivize repeated plays, and the art is so basic. Balatro's art is interesting and each Joker is unique, but in Slay the Spire the enemies are way too bland for a game for game in the fantasy genre. You fight literal slime, furry creatures, and basic hooded robbers. Many times you spawn with a shop a level ahead of you that you can't afford to purchase from, simply because of RNG. With lazy game design, art design, and unsatisfying replayability, I'm surprised the reviews are overwhelmingly positive. Just because a game can hook you for a few hours doesn't mean it's fun or worth your time and money. Read the other negative reviews; they are right to emphasize how RNG-based this is, not in a fun Balatro way, but in a frustratingly inconsistent way. Leave this one and go play Balatro, this unfun game has gotten enough purchases already

Alright, I'm writing a review for this game because I enjoyed the card game IRL.

This version of the game is *not* soemthing I encourage people to play under the genre of roguelike deckbuilders. In its current state, it is near-unplayable.

The game requires you to be a statistics focused person, or basically a card-game deckbuilder pre-planner. Why am I using all these nonsensical words? It is because of how much RNG there is to play this game.

All the enemies are generated randomly. Okay, no biggie, you expect that in a card battler.
All the rewards are generated randomly(including things like gold). Okay, no biggie, this is rogue-like.
All the bosses are generated randomly. Okay...no biggie, this is still rogue-like.
All of the rewards at a merchant are generated randomly. Okay...it's still rogue-like...righT?
Your starting buffs at the game are generated randomly. Isn't that the point of rogue-like?
Your character's card deck is created randomly. Zachary_XYZ_Fusion, what is your point!? Isn't the point of Roguelike games to have replayability by randomizing certain variables?
Yes, yes, I'm getting somewhere.
You're iimited to 3 energy per turn, which means on average you can only play three cards in your hand. 
Your hand is randomized, of course, unless you have deck control, which is of course random rewards(not every character gets this).
You're card-locked via ascensions, which means you must progress, complete a boss, then fail to gain "exp" to unlock other cards for better runs.
You're also unable to increase your starting rewards unless a previous run beats a boss, so abandoning runs for a better run is punished in a rogue-like game. You know, where if you're starting aspects are shit, you just reroll right? No, you can't reroll. It is fixed rewards according to teh bosses you beat, with all this combination in between randomized.
You're also still dealing with devastating debuffs the enemy can inflict on you. In a game with flat numbers, as you see in their combat right, you think, okay weaken takes all my damage by 1 like the card game? No, it's by percentage. so 25% damage increase, 50% damage increase, and so on. That's ontop of the RNG.

Of course, it is. The point I'm making is that you are hardcoded to fail most runs. Everything you do is randomized ASIE from your starting relic(which is basically just character ability). Every single character has enemies that hard-counter their decks, regardless of their structures, especially if they outnumber you. In addition, you cannot play this game without playing that characters meta.

I have so far been unable to enjoy an ironclad strength build because every enemy I fight deals 7-12 damage an attack(usual max HP is 70 on him), and I have to spend it to block and still have to deal with my HP dropping. To be clear, after each section you clear, your HP DOES NOT regenerate unless you have a relic that allows you too, and you can only REST at ONE location(very spare rest sites on the map).

In addition, it says I have ten hours right? Or something like that? That was ten hours of me just clicking buttons with nothing interesting going on. Animations DO NOT change, and all the card text and image becomes repetitive exactly after 8 hours.

It is a time waster, with an unfair amount of progression required. I could go into the math in this review but I'm already insanely frustrated with the amount of CARD-GAME PROBABILITY you are REQUIRED to understand to have fun with this game. big X


This is NOT a game I recommend to ANYONE. This is a FAIL TO PLAY game, not a PLAY TO SUCCEED game. There is such a thing as too much randomized generation of certain things. This is one of those types of games.

Spend your time and money, for 25$ on any old games from before 2015 or something, or go save up for witcher 3. Or play the card-game IRL, or play...anything but this?

Solid game for 60 hours. Gets boring after that. Prolly a fine game if you pick it up on sale but would never recommend buying at full price. It is in competition with BG3 for the most over glazed games of all time.
I dont get how this is overwhelmingly positive. Super rng heavy beginning and pretty obnoxious mostly. Monster Train is better
Even with a bunch of stacking synergies and combo effects you rarely win act 3 if ever. random minions doing 60 damage and there are FIVE of them plus the mini bosses.

There are so many cards and variables and interactions; it would be interesting if each turn in combat weren't just simple math ad infinitum. You lose a run because you spin a wheel and land on the less satisfactory space. You win a run because you draw your power cards on turn one. And then, afterwards, you stare at the victory screen, all your items having already been unlocked, and close the game, doomed to forget this run like countless others. It's unfulfilling because you barely have to think.

I come back to this game after a couple of years to check if anything has been added, and what I've found? It seems to me that a lot has been changed, and all for the worst: the game was already difficult, now It's insane. You won't win any run, even at level 0, unless you absolutely always make the best (and only) choice at disposal: get a "wrong" card, and you'll be screwed; meet the wrong enemy, and you're done. I'm not even sure if most of the runs are winnable. The game is not a deck builder anymore, it has become a puzzle game for people that enjoy the grind of trying all the possible combinations for a run until you get the optimal. Usual deck builder strategies do not apply here, you just need to know EXACTLY what is the only viable choice in every situation. And I'm not exaggerating: if you just add a card that won't synergize perfectly with the cards and artifacts you'll get in the future, in the third act you'll loose because of that card. If you don't add one because you're not sure if it will synergize later, you're screwed. If you don't do enough combat encounters, you will not find the cards that are indispensable; if you don't take enough events you won't be able to remove enough cards and you will loose. Unless totally everything is perfect (and I mean everything: speaking of the ironclad, you need a lean deck, at least 4 energy, a way to weaken stronger enemies, a way to hit enemy groups, a very strong attack to kill bigger enemies, a way to obtain enormous amount of shield and of course a way to be able to use all of your tools at the right moment) you will loose even at level 0.
To summarize:  a deck builder that plays more like a puzzle game: unless you're a fan of the genre, it's not fun to play, just frustrating.

You know how when you play a game for a long time and don't notice the time go by, it means that you're having a lot of fun? 
This is a very rare example of the opposite effect, you don't notice the amount of time spent but you end up in resentment and wishing you could get it back.

- The difficulty scaling of this game is absolutely ridiculous. I've played for over 50 hours and done dozens of runs with all characters, unlocked everything, and yet my win rate is around 20%, probably less. I've never gone above Ascension level 1, and there's 20 fucking difficulty levels. I can't even imagine what it's like at its hardest.
Are you supposed to spend the majority of your time playing the game HOPING you get the perfect combo going, and if you don't, wallow in frustration over the past hour or so that you just wasted in the attempt? It's unfair as fuck.
- It's simply far too reliant on RNG. RNG of the cards you get, RNG of the relics you get, RNG of the cards you draw, RNG of the enemies actions. RNG of the map layout and which enemies you fight. If it's not enough that runs can be ruined by just a couple of random effects, making mistakes when playing the cards feels that much more punishing. 
- The concept of Crowd Control does not exist in this game?!?! No character has any ability to freeze, stun, banish, nothing.
- I'm not kidding about the difficulty, if you don't have VERY good RNG in your run, you're not even reaching the final boss which is again, ridiculous.
- Graphics are laughably basic and downright ugly to the point where you'd think a kid could have drawn most of the art in this game. There's barely any animation anywhere.
- Coming from other/older card games like Hearthstone, the visual and sound effects of the cards themselves are really light and underwhelming. Every single application of block sounds the same, every single "strike" card sounds the same, across all characters..
- There's only 4 characters which is too low, and because of the very bad balance, you quickly discover the "build variety" is a lie since nothing but a very select few OP combos will get you the win.
- After the first 15 or so hours the progression completely stops. You learn nothing new, you unlock nothing new, you've seen all the enemies in the game, and that's when you start the downward spiral of "I could have finished if my RNG was a little bit better", and eventually end up realizing the truth of this hideous RNG reliance far too late, like I did.
- Losing in this game feels like shit. And you will do that a lot.
- Single-player only.
- Achievement hunting is atrocious. You're not getting half of these achievements without the blessings of Allah, Jesus and Buddha COMBINED.

Praise be the following, however:
- The music in this game is so fucking good, it's easily the most memorable and best thing about it hands down, greatly helped to push through some of the frustration.
- Unlike Hearthstone & all the other major card games out there, there is no such thing as "running out of cards", you simply reshuffle your discard pile and start drawing again. The idea is fantastic and allows for some matches to last far longer and do much crazier stuff in them than you would otherwise.
- The thematic feel of each of the 4 distinct characters is very well done.

Even within the card battler roguelike genre, I've played far, far better games that are either less frustrating in challenge by default and/or can be experienced in co-op which mitigates the RNG factor, such that if 1 player has bad deck/card draw, another player can help carry the run to some degree with their better RNG. 
Like Hellcard or Battle Bands.

It seems there's only 3 levels to clear, which will take you around 90~120mins, and you just do that over and over again, while not really getting much stronger per run aside from the new cards you unlock on level up (which only happens once every 2~3 attempts, and then you have to find those cards in a run. Your starting deck doesn't change, so it's hard to feel good about starting a new run when you never get any stronger.
Story and characters are non-existent, so the game has to stand entirely on it's gameplay and while It's fun enough if you take it for what it is (a single player card game) and don't compare it to more fleshed out card games like MTG, again, I'd say I wouldn't pay full price for it. I certainly don't understand the glazing that it gets.

This game is fun at first, when you aren't trying to do what is essentially the new game plus versions where it gets harder after every success.

The game's major issue can be summed up pretty easily.

1. It is punishingly hard, it's probably the hardest card game that is on steam and even people with thousands of hours in this game can't beat it on even 10/20 difficulty reliably.

2. Every climb starts with the same kit, and that kit is TERRIBLE. Because the kit is terrible you are super screwed after the first half of the first floor if you didn't get lucky with the card drops.

3. There are bosses that just hard counter specific card combinations and if you didn't already know that you're just going to lose once you get to that boss.

4. The game is overwhelmingly based on RNG. What cards drop are random, how bad the monsters are is random, what kind of boon you get to start with is random, what items drop from bosses are also random.

Some of these items are great, some of them are outright trash, and some of the enemies you can run into are so stupidly strong they can take you from full hp to dead in a single encounter.

If you're fine with restarting over and over and over again and maybe having 1 in 5 runs be actually viable to even get past the first floor of the three then go ahead and play this game but as it currently stands you may as well just go sit down at a slot machine because that's basically all this game is.

The only reason I can see for so many people liking this game is the fact that I seriously doubt anyone actually tries to clear the harder modes. If you just played it for like 10 hours, beat the first mode, and quit it would probably feel like any other deck builder but the fact is that level goes from 0 to 20 and it gets punishingly hard at like 5.

To give you an idea, only about 14% of people playing this game have reached the part where you actually beat it (which is on 3 out of 20 levels) and the number of people who have beaten tier 20 is about 7% of the people playing int. Only about 16% of the players have even gotten to 10.

Fantastic game. It's a one of a kind storytelling experience alongside Automata in my opinion. 

The pros:
The story is great, the world, characters and even some quests are good. The music is the best part of the game for me, the Nier series really knows how to accentuate story moments using fantastic songs and get raw emotions out of you without the need for any lyrics.

I really like how Yoko Taro changes gameplay elements in the middle of the playthrough, like now you're in a hack and slash and the next moment you're basically playing a visual novel, or the camera changes to an isometric view in some levels, cool stuff.

I love how the subsequent routes recontextualize past events in the story, this is my favorite storytelling quirk so I may be biased toward it lmao.

Now for the cons: 
I would say this is a remaster of the 2010 game with some added content, not a full remake, which means the quests, combat and upgrading weapons can be rough. I've seen a trend with older jrpgs having a lot of meaningless grinding and repetitive quests. There are a lot of fetch quests that make you go from place to place without the means of fast travel which can get annoying really fast, which is a shame since there are some side quests with great stories behind them. 

The combat is not bad but I wouldn't really call it satisfying for me, it's reminiscent of Automata but unpolished at the same time. The grind to upgrade your weapons is too much so I didn't really do that, but the weapon stories that update as you upgrade them could be worth it if you like little lore pieces.

The ways to get all endings can be hit or miss, playing the game multiple times can seem like a waste of time sometimes. Though the last ending which is original to this upgraded version of the game is really worth it in my opinion.

Also I wasn't a fan of the Kaine fanservice outfit, I don't think it's an issue for the vast majority of players but it seemed really out of place and meaningless, but to each their own.

Overall, it's a great experience, also release the Nier Replicant ver.1.22 ost on spotify already, it's been 4 years.

NieR Replicant ver.1.22474487139 is an action RPG that builds on the cult classic NieR. The updated version improves visual fidelity and gameplay flow while keeping the original structure. The world design presents a bleak tone that pushes the player to question the value of progress. Strong art direction supports this.

Combat uses light and heavy attacks mixed with magic abilities. Animation timing feels responsive. Enemy variety grows at a steady pace. Boss encounters stand out through scale and pattern recognition. The combat system is not complex but remains engaging across the runtime.

The narrative focuses on a journey to save a loved one. It presents moral ambiguity without pointing to a single correct answer. Dialogue reveals layered character motivations. Themes involve identity and the cost of survival. Emotional impact builds as the story advances.

Multiple endings encourage repetition. New routes add narrative context rather than simple alternates. Later runs change perspective and reframe earlier events. This structure rewards patient players who want deeper lore. It also increases the total playtime without feeling padded.

The soundtrack is notable. Vocal tracks rise during key story beats. Ambient music maintains tension in quieter moments. Sound design fits both exploration and combat. Audio feedback supports player awareness in fights.

Visual upgrades include refined textures and improved lighting. Character models feel more detailed. Environments show stronger depth. Performance remains stable on modern hardware. Load times are short.

NieR Replicant ver.1.22474487139 succeeds as a refreshed version of a niche title. It preserves the unusual tone and narrative risk while modernizing weak points of the original. It appeals to players who value story driven structure more than mechanical complexity.

As other's have said the story is great, and seeing it through to its conclusion is definitely what drove me through all the endings that game has to offer. The characters are fun and endearing, the soundtrack is fantastic and the game looks pretty and runs well.

All that being said, I cannot recommend this game. In order to experience all this game has to offer in terms of story you must:
Marking as Spoilers just in case.
[spoiler]
1. Complete the game to receive ending A. This took me a little over 16 hours but can be done faster if you're into that.
2. You now restart the game at the halfway point and must complete it again to receive ending B. 0 change in game play, it is literally the same game again from the half way point. You get extra cut scenes that give you a different perspective, however it is the exact same game you just played.
3. You start from the half way point again and must collect the rest of the weapons you didn't get in the other playthroughs in order to gain access to ending C and D. Again, it is the exact same game you have just played TWICE now you get a couple extra cut scenes, on top of the extra cut scenes you got after ending A. (by the way, some of these cannot be easily skipped. you need to mash your buttons to skip the dialogue, but if there is no dialogue happening on screen you need to just wait and watch a cut scene again)
4. Ending C and D occur based on a choice you make at the very end of the game. If you're wise and make a second save you can experience both without having to replay half of the game again, you do still however have to replay the ending section.
5. Choosing ending D will give you access to the new content added for this remake, but you must replay the first hour or two of the game with 0 differences before you can actually access that content. you actually get to play as a different character with an entirely new move set... but the content only lasts for about an hour or so and then its over. Want to replay it? Gottah do Ending D again and replay the beginning of the game AGAIN. [/spoiler]

Spoiler free version: half of my play time was replaying the game to achieve the other endings. There were 0 gameplay changes in that replay time, exact same content, with a few extra cut scenes sprinkled on top. Not worth the $90 Aud price tag.
The story itself is great, however, the endless side quests and grinds for items, running from A to B constantly is extremely tiring.

I played NieR Replicant for about 15 hours, and honestly, I found the experience disappointing.

A large chunk of my playtime was spent running back and forth on the same roads just to reach different villages or cities, which quickly became repetitive. Enemy variety felt low, and the boss fights didn’t really stand out — they were more underwhelming than exciting.

The story was interesting on the surface, but it never really dug deep or elaborated enough to keep me fully engaged. Compared to the first NieR game, this felt like a step backwards. For me, it ended up being more of a waste of time than a memorable experience.

This game is a junky mess.
I'll rate this game as a 2021 game (meaning I expect it to meet 2021 game standards), not a 2010 one.

The story is acceptable enough that it kept me playing and forced me to play and get the ABCDE endings.

And the story is the only positive thing about this game; everything else is mediocre/horrible.

- Gameplay - junky, slow. Everything you do in the game should be done faster: every dialogue, interaction, collecting anything, just everything.
- Combat - junky, tedious, repetitive. Sometimes I just ran past enemies because I didn't feel like fighting them.
- Side-Quests - absolutely horrible, boring, snooze-fest. Most of them are fetch-quests that add nothing to the game.
- Fast Travel System - should be much better, not this crap with boats where you have four places to travel and usually it's faster to get somewhere else by just running there
- Bosses - most of them were tragic, boring, and too long. Lots of gimmick bosses, multiple phases. The culmination of the bosses' tragedy was a boar that had to be killed 15 times (I counted) in many places to progress.
- The structure of this game is poor. The gameplay should be structured so that you play once and discover everything in that single playthrough, instead of everything being divided up so that in route A you get almost nothing, in route B you get a few more cutscenes, and in route C you get a few more dialogue lines. And you play for hours just to get one more line of dialogue. All of this should be in one playthrough, not forcing the player to repeat everything multiple times to get the "context" of what we've done.

I will start by saying the shorter version, is it good? Yes, is it worth 60 euros? absolutely not, i'm giving it a do not recommend only because there isn't a "meh" button on steam, but if you find this game on a heavy discount (20 euro or lower) i would say do pick it up as it's an interesting game in its own way.

Now for the long version, why thumbs down instead of thumbs up despite being meh and still recommending it when discounted? well a few factors.
First of all it's the gameplay; aside boss battles, it's like eating unsalted gluten free crackers. An infinite amount of fetch quests and "Go here go there" on a map that doesn't see fast travel after midgame.
Second issue is how the game hides some important mechanics or upgrades behind meaningless and voidlike subquests, i bet many people don't even know there is a mount in the game that is hidden behind a stupid sidequest at the start of the game THAT COULD BECOME AN UNCOMPLETABLE QUEST EVEN ON A "NEW GAME+", simply because most likely they didn't even bother doing it from how boring they are.
Third, and worst of all in my opinion, is that you don't get to see around 50% of the game until you beat it and PLAY IT AGAIN. With this i mean full on cutscenes, character stories and interactions between characters and between enemies that are simply not shown during the ENTIRE FIRST PLAYTHROUGH. When i did my first run i had literally zero attachment to ANY of the characters, and the various big reveals at the end felt like nothing due to the game literally showing NOTHING, you can play it again and get the full experience sure but now you already know how it ends and it literally spoils the whole story, missing emotions that otherwise would've been present the first run, so it doesn't matter how many times you play it, it'll still feel like total emptiness. 

I genuinely feel like i have been robbed of an amazing game if only Yoko Taru didn't have a kink with leaving things in the dark.

Despite the huge flaws though the game isn't all bad, the music is a banger, the bossfights are a banger and there are some gameplay mechanics that are unique, but those are few and far between. Graphics wise it's okay for a remaster/remake and the character models are super cool, but that's about it for the positives.

As for the conclusions, if you're unsure between getting automata or replicant, just get automata, buy replicant only if you want a minor elucidation on past events and only if you see it on a heavy discount.

I really wanted to enjoy NieR Replicant, but the PC version is plagued with technical issues that make it hard to justify the price, or the time investment.

🛠️ [b]Technical Problems Galore[/b] From inconsistent frame pacing to poor mouse and keyboard support, the game feels like a barebones port. Crashes, stuttering, and resolution scaling issues are common, and even basic features like borderless window mode are missing or broken. It’s baffling that the game was released in this state.

🚫 [b]Developer Neglect[/b] What’s most frustrating is the lack of meaningful updates or communication from the developers. These issues have been widely reported since launch, yet there’s been little to no effort to patch or optimize the game for PC players. It feels abandoned.

💸 [b]Refunded and Relieved[/b] I ended up getting a refund, and honestly, I wouldn’t recommend anyone spend more than 10€ on this unless the technical problems are fixed. As it stands, it’s not worth the hassle.

🎮 [b]Final Verdict[/b] If you’re curious about the story, maybe watch a playthrough or pick it up on console. But for PC? Save your money and your patience.

NieR:Replicant feels like a weird stage play of a video game. The parts are there, the characters emote, there is things that make it look like a game and there is a story. But everything is just weirdly off, and not in a very interesting way. Top that with a crazy 60€ price tag for an okay port of a really old game.

The whole first act feels like an eerie hommage to Zelda, complete with the animation when the Prince receives the item, almost like a jab at the generic fantasy RPG village beginnings. The neverending back-and-forth for insanely dull main and side quests feels like some kind of subversive critique of bland gameplay. 
Characters join your party, you do one thing together and suddenly there is a huge dramatic scene where emotions overflow and the characters swear eternal allegiance to each other in the name of their unbreakable friendship. As if the script writer just tossed the whole intermittent part between beginning and end of the act out the window, which seems like some kind of parody of video game plots. The game's story beats and character reactions outside of the side quests seem so exaggerated to the point where you suspect this is leading up to some kind of plot relevant twist.
However, after hours of running back and forth on the same maps, killing the same few enemies by mashing buttons, and hearing the same generic dialogue from side NPCs I gave up trying to figure out if there is some grand point to be made and whether or not those things actually lead up to something.

There is nothing to get invested in to make me want to see it through to the end, because all you are given is the game telling you that the characters have deep connections with each other, but you never really see any of this. Side quests are aggravatingly generic in the variety of "Kill X wolves until you get their drop Y times", "Bring the item to NPC Z" or "Deliver this item but you cannot dodge or get hit or you have to try again". If you force yourself through these torturously laborious side quests you are rewarded with world building insights among the lines of "Thank you!". No interesting bits about the world or characters, no interesting philosophical conundrums like in Automata. Just a forgettable sentence of a forgettable NPC in a generic world.

There is some decent writing in there somewhere. The text wall segment in the forest was really well written and some of the dialogues are very pleasing to listen to, aided by the very strong voice acting.

But ultimately the game is so insanely flat and sterile and just feels like it's wasting your time with every bit of gameplay that stands in the way of the next bit of story that may or may not be interesting that I cannot be bothered. And I definitely don't want to slog through it multiple times for multiple endings. I'll just look up a story summary online.
Might as well get the console version.

I do not get it. I couldn't finish it and had to put it down. 

The voice of the book is so grating. Constant exhalation, way more than necessary. Switched to Japanese and then had trouble reading the tiny subtitles in the middle of combat. 

The constant backtracking is mind numbing. You spend more time running from A to B then doing anything. 

The side quests are the absolute worst form of MMO garbage. This is totally unacceptable. Half of them require you to either grind a bunch bullshit, or just buy arbitrary quantities of things. 

Story moments frequently lock you out of interacting with NPC's critical to services and side quests. 

Music is great but there is only like 4 songs. 

Combat sucks. No gap closer, wonky camera when locked on, getting stuck in a 5 second combo facing the wrong direction, basically all magic except dark blast is pointless and a waste of time, and every trash mob has a steel foundry worth of armor you need to bash off before doing damage. 

Characters are unlikable. Main character might be the best, fashion sense aside. The story of the endlessly sick sister that everyone wants to have her just lay in bed "resting" until she dies drives me up the wall. Bitches days are numbered, let her have fun. Emil is cloying and melodramatic. Kaine is some kind of futa fetish fantasy constantly talking shit. 

The desert mask people are supposed to be cute? They are annoying, the desert I have to constantly cross to get to them is annoying. 

The forest text dungeon was waaaaaay too long. I just skipped through all of that crap. 

After heading back to the starting area for the bajillionth time I just couldn't take it anymore. This game sucks.
