It's a real shame that Bethesda doesn't give this so much more technical support, too, as it could really be a good game- but it's ultimately stunted by some design choices, by lack of bug fixes, and a healthy dose of corporate greed for microtransactions.

You buy Fallout 76 because you just like wasting your money… That’s fine!
But that’s only where the fun begins!

Because guess what?
You can throw even more of your precious tinky-pinky shitey whackey cash at it!
Fallout 76 for ONLY €40.
(Base game… and by “base” I mean the bare minimum.)

Sooner or later, you’ll probably want a subscription - you know, for a bit more “comfort.”
People without taste will call it “basics".

And to top it all off:
If you like collecting things and decorating your base a little, you can unlock a few items in-game. 
Don’t get me wrong, they look cheap or terrible at best.
The good stuff? That’s where you could get rid off of your totally worthless money.
*Takes a deep breath* ...what a lovely ingame-shop!

Wonderful, isn’t it?



If you feel scammed, don’t worry - that’s on purpose.
And whenever the game feels dull and worthless, that’s because it is dull and worthless.

Let’s go even further…
Ever feel somewhat empty and alone while playing Fo76?
Welcome to Fallout 76 - you’re a whale, gently drifting through a dark, cold, and empty ocean.


Avoid being scammed, check sources and read critical reviews.
/peace

I have spent a couple hundred hours on this game across 3 different platforms... It's just so boring and empty feeling. The only times I have actually died were accidentally blowing myself up with explosives. I've really tried to like this game and it's got some good going for it but I don't find it immersive or compelling at all. It just kind of exists.

A lot of reviews seem to be about the poor monetization efforts of Bethesda. While I agree, I'd like to instead focus on the gameplay itself.

But how do I say this? The game just feels .... [b]empty[/b]. The map is huge and there's a lot to look at, but every location I venture in to feels incomplete. On occasion I'll come across some random world event, but in almost every location I'm finding absolutely nothing. All the enemies are dead, killed by a player that just recently passed through.

To circumvent this and experience the location in its entirety, I need to hop servers until I find one where the POI I'm exploring hasn't already been ransacked. Even then, the enemies are few and are no real threat. They die quickly, don't put up much of a fight, and have very little variety.

Fallout games are known to be packed with mini adventures in every corner. You walk into a town and there are a thousand things happening around you. You, as a player, can choose to interact with any of the things happening around you. Sometimes the things happening around you push you into a massive quest line where your decisions are paramount in the telling of your story. Sometimes the distractions simply show you pieces of lore, hint at a unique location, or give you some mini adventure to help immerse you in the world.

Fallout 76 has none of that. 

And, I know what you're thinking: "This is an MMO, not a traditional RPG story telling game." and I hear you. So let's focus on it from the MMO aspect and you'll still find it really has nothing to offer. Player interactions are very infrequent and there is often no incentive to work together. World events offer no challenge and don't warrant working together. And since the world scales around you, enemies will be just has difficult when you're level one then when you're level 1,001. The only difference is you'll have a different weapon to kill them with.

I have absolutely no incentive to grind and unlock gear, or to explore locations to find unique items. Everything requires an absurd amount of resources and, inevitably, you'll find you can't gather everything without paying more real money (I know I said I wouldn't talk about the monetization, but come on!)

Whatever makes MMOs great, Fallout 76 doesn't offer it. It fails to be a Fallout game and/or an MMO.

This is a 10/10 game, genuinely speaking. The storyline is amazing and heartfelt, and I guess you could say that the storyline is short, but that isn't an issue for me at all, in fact it didn't feel short as I was playing (probably because I took a few breaks and completed it over the course of a few days). I've seen this game be compared to Little Kitty Big City due to the main character being a cat and how you could move around as said cat, and to be honest the comparison is almost unfair given how much better this game is story-wise and cat-wise. I could go on and on about how much better this game is compared to LKBC, but if you see both games yourself you can see the obvious differences that shoots this game up the highest in cat-related games. I actually had so much fun roaming around as a little furball, this game does an amazing job at making you FEEL like a cat, a smart one at that. Not to mention, the ending didn't even upset me. I've seen what this game had to offer already since it's pretty much old at the time of me playing it, and yet I highly recommend giving it a try and playing on your own whether you've spoiled everything for yourself or not. I was iffy about this game when first starting with the cats I was with, but after falling, I REALLY got the gist of it. Exploration is freaking amazing, I was ANYTHING but mad whenever I got lost, and the robots made me feel so welcomed rather than treating me like an unknown little monster invading their space, treated me as an equal, I absolutely love how much the robots acknowledge and accept this cat's existence.
Do you like crying? Do you like an allegory for growing up wrapped in a sci-fi cat game? If either of these apply to you, then play this game! Best story game I've played all year; 10/10.

"Everybody, Everybody, Everybody, Wants to be a Cat!!!" -The Aristocats

I want to start this off that I saw this game when it first released and was not sure on why it was getting all of this praise as a "Stray Cat" game. After the shelf life that this has accumulated, eventually going on a good sale, I decided to purchase it.

The game title best describes what you are, a stray cat... It starts you off with your companions, you are thus separated from them and on a whole another adventure. At first I was starting to lose steam on playing this, then experienced the puzzles that you have to solve and that drew me in more. This is very interesting to the point that they're are no words spoken through the entirety of the game. Only noises, and then translated through text, where the player has to read it, which does not sway my opinion of the game. I in fact enjoyed the humming of the machines in the dead city and the robots that you encounter with each indistinct noise that they made. Along with the beautiful atmosphere that came with it and the audio, when entering a new area was really captivating.

The character movement in the game is something like the "Assassins Creed" titles of climbing building with the swift jumps that a cat makes on each ledge to get to a certain point, with out the frustration of falling of the ledge and having to re-climb back up. This is, in itself is a very linear puzzle game... However, what I do NOT care for is that there are two instances so far during my play through that have been now made a consistency. To the point where I was going to wait to finish to give a thorough review for something that has so much praise for playing as a "cat". 

In the beginning, some of the other cats did not load right away, and was stuck on the pro-loge much longer than I needed to be, because I was searching for something that was not there (the other cats to interact with to progress in the game) until 5 minutes of running around they finally loaded in, then I could then progress... The second instance is when after you find a certain individual (I'm not trying to spoil the plot) to get out of the dead city you knock a photograph off of the wall, the cat does a reaction jump scare when it falls. And I am left falling infinitely out of the map and can see my cat at resting position, just falling..... infinitely...... (I have done it three times to see if it was a one time thing, but this is a consistency)... The game is riddled with bugs and fixes that you have to look out for in the game such as, the "sentry's" that are in the game, will start doing different spawn patterns and you will see it once you either restart the game or the last saved checkpoint. Some of the puzzles do not work unless you once again, restart to a last saved checkpoint. Being at a puzzle and it not registering that I did the puzzle and then coming back to it later, doing the exact same thing, then it finally works miraculously. This is such a disappointment...
 
It runs and looks good, they're is some points in the games cut scenes where I am almost disappointed, on how "blotchy" the cats look, this is running the game at the maximum capabilities that it has to offer, and running it normal with no issues what so ever.

Brass Tax:
In my opinion, I can tell that this is very in depth on what the developers have done, the work they put into this and I can see it, the game has a good plot and story. However the fact is, I can not see myself doing another play through of this after finishing the first one, especially with some of the bugs that has me running in circles trying to progress. You get to the top, you unseal the city, but I get to see almost nothing of what happened to my friends I made along the way. I spent so much time in the low area, was shopping with them, bartering, and all I see is one robot happy. Just feels a bit, of a shame.

My companion B-12 kills himself at the end for the greater good. Bit of a boring plot device that I kind of saw coming. Once we get back to the outside, what other purpose would he serve, all the humans are dead. Again his whole demise felt a bit, rushed. The whole final level felt rushed and just a bit, boring. It was underwhelming and sad.

I hope Stray 2 is a longer game that feels more polished in how it looks after its characters. It felt like certain decisions were made simply because they didn't want to have to animate or do x thing.

I only play this game for the warhammer 40k mod, which i will add works amazingly. I cannot recommend this game enough if you want to play 40k online, or even just to make different armys and practice them, the possibilities are quite endless and the best part it doesnt cost you money to try things out. 
Its really useful for trying expensive models in gameplay before you commit to buying them in real life. Its very fun game and has so many quality of life features that make playing 40k a lot quicker and easier but definitly shouldnt be used to substitute the real game. 
Its also very easy to make your own custom mods for the game like datacards or codexes, or any kind of text or data document you want really, you literally just need a PDF image and you can upload it to a custom template then save it, posting social media is probably harder!
The amount of different map packs the community has made is unreal, it would cost you a lot of money to play on some of the map designs i have seen in the game.
The whole experience is basically your warhammer 40k dream with no financial constraints, you're free to make the biggest most expensive army you can and play it for free.
If you like 40k this game is a no brainer like why do you not own it already?

I installed this again with the express purpose of trying it out in vr. (I don't remember the desktop mode being that good either though) I figured being able to interact with the pieces would be kinda neat. Nope! You load in, select Chess, and then you move your hand over a piece. Now, what I would expect to happen if this game were actually good, is the piece under your hand would highlight, and then you can pick up and place said highlighted piece. You want to know what actually happens? Nothing. You straight up can't pick up the pieces? Maybe I have to set up inputs for the controllers? Which is stupid, but I go to the menu anyway, and it was just desktop inputs. 

I then flicked through the other games just to make sure Chess isn't just bugged or something, so I try Checkers, same deal. Then I think poker? You can't interact with the cards or the chips. Literally how is this hard? Surely this would be a total slam-dunk for the dev? Pick up chips->flick analogue stick up or down to select amount of chips. Then idk, some other button to confirm splitting of the amount. Amount selected stays in hand, surplus returns to stack. Same with cards. Pick up deck-> flick analogue stick to deal to highlighted areas like players or the community cards. 

You can't do any of that though, what you can do, is hold A to move the camera... And... flick pieces, very inconsistently I might add. Sometimes it flicks them, sometimes it tries to select them as if you were holding down m1 in windows to select multiple files. Try hosting poker night in this with your mates and watch how quickly it collapses because nobody can draw a card or pick up their chips or do literally anything in this fucking thing.

In normal mode it’s an excellent sandbox with a strong community of workshop games.  I really enjoyed playing it so far. 
However, I got excited by the support of vr and bought it over other games specifically for that. 
I was very disappointed to find out it’s impossible to click scripted items in VR, making it look like it has potential but is otherwise unplayable. 
Judging from other tickets, it looks like this has been an issue since 2019 so not getting my hopes up for a fix.

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
Bloons TD Battles 2 is what happens when someone at Ninja Kiwi said:
“What if tower defense… but also ranked anxiety?”

You boot it up thinking “haha monkeys vs balloons,” and suddenly you’re sweating over **optimal eco curves** while some guy named “xxBLo0nGodxx” sends fortified ZOMGs on round 28.

---

### Pros:

* Same adorable Bloons, now in glorious HD ruining your entire evening.
* Heroes add “personality” which is nice, because you definitely need Quincy saying “I never miss” after you absolutely do.
* Meta constantly shifting so you can never, ever be happy or comfortable.
* Every match feels like a job interview for “War Criminal, Bloon Division.”

---

### Cons:

* You: “I’ll try a fun off-meta strategy.”
  Matchmaking: *puts you against a guy with 4k hours and a spreadsheet open.*
* One mis-timed rush and your entire economy folds like a dollar store lawn chair.
* “Rubber to Gold” is also the name of what this game does to your free time.
* Ranked = climb 100 trophies in 2 hours, lose them all in 10 minutes, go lie down on the floor.

---

### Peak Battles 2 Experience:

* Both players quietly farming, building defenses, playing it safe.
  Then Round 18 hits and suddenly it’s **WWIII with purple and zebra bloons.**
* You send a giant, carefully calculated all-in rush.
  Opponent defends with 3 abilities and an emote.
  You sit there, broke, watching the defeat screen in 4K.
* “GG” typed with tears in your eyes and 3 FPS left.

---

10/10
Turned strategy, math, and psychological warfare into one colorful package.
Would say “no rush, just chilling” and then full-send fortified BADs again.

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
This game fun occasionally, maybe a game or two a day, but its not the sort of game I could see myself playing for hours on end. Would still recommend it to any bloons fans (play btd6 first).

Overall the game is less of a test of skill, and more of a knowledge check, at least until you get to the top .1% of players. Early laddering is basically looking at the opponents board and seeing what they forgot to account for and exploiting it. This works for most ranks, and can be fun if you like stomping newbies. There are a LOT of newbies.

Note that this game looks like microtransaction hell at first glance, and while the game is easily FTP, I could see a more impressionable person throwing money into the in game marketplace.

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
Игра 'Bloons TD Battles 2' – это приятное продолжение популярной tower defense серии. Графика стала более яркой и современной, а игровой процесс, хотя и знакомый, предлагает достаточно новых элементов и стратегий. PvP сражения напряженные и требуют быстрого мышления и адаптации к тактике противника. Разнообразие башен и героев позволяет экспериментировать с разными билдами и стратегиями.

Однако, присутствует некоторая проблема с балансом, некоторые башни и герои явно сильнее других. Также, процесс улучшения прогресса кажется немного медленным, особенно для бесплатных игроков. Реклама ненавязчива, но может встретиться несколько раз в день. В целом, игра увлекательная и предоставляет часы стратегического геймплея, хотя и требует некоторого терпения для достижения более высоких уровней.

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
Bloons TD Battles 2 delivers a solid and engaging multiplayer tower defence game: it has the mechanics, players, and polish you’d want. For players who are committed and understand what they’re getting into, it’s well worth playing. However, the game is not without caveats: the progression system, perceived pay-to-win elements, and pacing may hinder the experience for some.

Final call: If you’re into strategic duels, enjoy tower defence and are okay with some investment (time or money), go for it. If you prefer anything more casual or loathe grind/unlock systems, you might want to wait or approach cautiously.

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
Worse in every way to the original. Limited to only 4 towers, one of which is a pretty useless "hero". Takes way too long to earn enough money to get any good towers. Even once you unlock them, you have to save up a ton more to unlock their final stages for some reason. Half the achievements are glitched, I do what it tells me to, and it just remains locked for no reason.

Update: After trying for another week, I've lost almost every single match for the last 3 days in the exact same way: I start out with 3 bars of connection, then suddenly it drops to 1 bar, and I go from full lives all the way down to 1 out of nowhere(despite my cable internet being a rock solid connection), and then it goes "syncing" as my screen freezes, and when it unfreezes, I've lost. No idea how or why or what caused it and no way to prevent it with the abilities. Just 10 minutes down the drain every time I try to play. Absolute waste of time, do not recommend until they fix their bugged out game.

And then the battles themselves, half the time I start with 3 bars connection then halfway through it drops to 1 out of nowhere for no reason(I regularly play FPS games and have stable, cable internet connection with no issues), which results in "syncing" interrupting my matches constantly for myself or my opponent. I've even had instances where I have full health and I send MOABs after my opponent, and suddenly it starts syncing, and then when it stops, I've lost. No explanation, no idea what happened, no way to prevent it. Wasted 10 minutes of play just for that, with no reward for my time spent and no way to prevent that? Get all the way to level 30 just to lost to something you can't even see? 
Highly ridiculous game. Very unstable and unreliable, steep curve for entry into the game, and seems to be pushing you to spend real money on virtual items, for little to no reward from gameplay itself. All in all a shadow of the games predecessor, yet I am sure I will still try to play it to see if the other towers make it suck any less.

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
The battles where you use tickets are full of bots. You can clearly see the difference between how real players play and how bots that surgically calculate and send balloons behave. In these battles, it’s shocking that all the players (bots) play in exactly the same style.
They give you three free tickets, use bots to beat you, and then make you pay to buy more tickets to keep playing. In the free battles (where you don’t need tickets), I didn’t feel there were any bots.
It’s sad how great games are becoming so stupid in the hands of sneaky business people. There are tools (like auto balloon senders, banana farmers, etc.), and nobody understands why you have to pay for them. They intentionally make parts of the game annoying (like collecting bananas or manually sending balloons) just so they can sell you those tools to remove the annoyance.
I really hope governments and lawmakers do something about this micro-transaction nonsense. It’s like they give you free heroin to get you addicted, then sell you the heroin or the rehab for money. Just sell the damn game, and if you want more money make an expansion packs etc!!!

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
[quote][b]Warning: Third Party Account[/b]

This game requires you to create a third party "NinjaKiwi Login" account... there's no valid reason for this in a PC game when SteamWorks is available.  This is often done to harvest private data and profile you, with potential sale and transmission of your private data to third parties.  The developers will probably argue that you can trust them, but if they were trustworthy they wouldn't demand you create a third party account.

This represents a considerable risk to gamers due to the privacy and security implications of developers that wish to bypass Steam and harvest user data.  Remember, sometimes if the product is free, YOU are the product.[/quote]

[quote][b][url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microtransaction]Warning: Microtransaction infested mobile app![/url][/b]

This game is infested with a toxic mobile app style cash shop.  You will be prompted to and expected to give money to the developers through this cash shop to buy in-game goods so you can play the game.[/quote]

"Bloons TD Battles 2" is one of thousands of nasty mobile apps infesting the "free" section of Steam, but it's not really free.

This inexplicably popular mobile app has the thin skin of a "PvP Tower Defense" game where you send enemies at the opponent while killing the ones he sends at you, but there's the rub... your towers and upgrades are locked behind ridiculous paywalls, so, like all of these scams, the victor is determined solely by who gave the most money to the mobile devs running it.

There's only a superficial game here.   The game visuals and the game itself are incredibly shallow... think of them as the too-bright, colourful, thin plastic cabinet dress theme on a poker machine at the casino. That's basically what this is.  So really, the mobile app "game" is just a veneer, a thin skin wrapped around a nasty, predatory mobile app cash shop.

Putting that toxic mobile app monetisation aside... this is a mobile app.  I didn't spend thousands on a gaming PC so I could pretend it's an iPhone, and I don't think you did either... this kind of mobile app has no place in your Steam library.

As with all mobile scams, you're forced to sign a highly questionable yet legally unenforceable End User License Agreement... for such a relatively low effort, low quality mobile app, this is specifically designed to invalidate your consumer rights and destroy your right to privacy.  This agreement includes questionable requirements that may attempt to revoke consumer law protections that gamers expect to have, which is also highly problematic.  Developers must learn they are here to serve gamers, not control them.  I had my cat walk over the keyboard while the EULA was displaying, which fixed that problem for me.

On the important matter of pricing and value for gamers, there's a lot going on here with monetisation, so this really shouldn't be considered a truly free product because of that.

The developer has their hand out for a $4 USD "donation" for this as you're expected to give them money for soundtrack DLC (that's already in the game) from Steam to "support" the "developer"... digital panhandling.  Like the homeless guys who splash dirty water on your windscreen at the traffic lights.  No thanks.  That's on top of already outright scamming gamers with a paid "club membership" and of course, the disgusting mobile app cash shop they baked into every aspect of gameplay. 

Bearing in mind that free games don't add +1 to your game collector count, should you bother adding this to your library and downloading it?

Nope.  This isn't worth downloading.  I didn't pay money, but I still feel ripped off.

genres: Action, Casual, Indie, Strategy, Free To Play
review_text:
This game is incredibly fun! The core gameplay is really good, and fixes many of the problems I have with BTD6, and also feels much more tightly balanced. I really want to like this game, but unfortunately it does have a major problem that makes it very hard for me to do so.

This problem is the leagues system. It feels... amateur at best. How it works is that there are about 10 or so leagues, each one harder than the previous. You face players within your league and gain trophies from winning. At the end of the week the players with the highest trophy count in the league move on to the next, and those with the lowest are demoted. You can also skip a league if you get a 10 game winstreak, so if you're doing well you can quickly get to higher arenas as a newer player. I utilized this feature, and in 3 weeks I got to ZOMG superdome (the second highest arena) with a winrate of about 83%. I got second in my league and had about a 66% winrate in ZOMG superdome. During this time I was getting a lot of Monkey Money because of my high winrate so I saved up for another hero. Then at the end of that week I was promoted to Hall of Masters, the final arena.

In this arena I have about a 25% winrate. The players here are significantly better than me, and I am fighting an uphill battle because I do not have all the heroes (I have 7) and I also only have about half the towers, and only 3 of those with tier 5's unlocked. With my abysmal winrate I take significantly longer to gain monkey money to get these tier 5's and heroes to even stand on equal footing. As a result, I am in a state where I with my current skill level and upgrades am struggling massively in the highest arena, but the arena just below it I am far above the average player. There is no where for me to face players at my skill level. I either am facing players in ZOMG superdome where I feel like I am far better than the opponents and don't feel adequately challenged, or I'm facing players in HoM where I am outskilled and outleveled.

The league system needs a rehaul, as it is far too easy to get into the second highest arena (If you play consistently you can make it to the 2nd highest arena with a 26% winrate) so the skill level is far too low, but the skill level in HoM is far too high. These problems together lead to an unfun experience where I do not feel like I can face anyone at my skill level, and that is why I can not recommend this game. If this system is changed I will come back and update this review, as this is the only major issue I have experienced.

If you plan to play the game just normal not even worth when you go against everyone w max stuff or better things then you start w on a new account, better off getting Bloons TD 6 an just enjoying the game for what it is, because I now just see this as a cash grab in the market of what mobile games we see nowadays with their in game transactions an game mechanics with match ups.

Hope this helps with anyone looking to or thinking of getting into this game. In short terms it sucks I enjoy the other games a lot more even when i was on winning streaks.

Men cry too.
The game has stunning artwork — like a living comic book. The story surprises you with its variability: you're not just playing through a plot, you're shaping it with your choices. Gradually, you start to understand the world around you and the people beside you, and you realize that in a zombie apocalypse you might have to rely on people just like them — unfamiliar, complicated, but real.
At first, it seems like the story will simply unfold on its own. But once you start thinking deeper, you understand: every decision you make could cost someone their life. The stakes rise fast.
The game offers interesting and sometimes unexpected ways to solve problems. It shows the world through the eyes of survivors — not heroic soldiers mowing down hordes of zombies, but ordinary people trapped in a world with no future. People who struggle not only with monsters, but also with simple, everyday challenges we never even think about in real life.
This is a story about how people behave at the edge of the world — without gloss, filters, or embellishment. It’s about friendship, betrayal, and difficult choices you can’t avoid. And it reminds you how important it is to have something to fight for, something to get up for every morning, something that keeps you from giving up.
It’s even a bit funny that by the end the main characters run out of ammo — a small detail, but perfectly fitting for a story that’s so genuine and grounded.
This is a story about ordinary people, just like us. People who doubt, who make mistakes, who choose — sometimes painfully, sometimes blindly. There are no right decisions here; there is only your path. A path that makes the game so powerful and touching. Because you never know what’s waiting for you around the next corner.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Мужчины тоже плачут.
В игре потрясающая рисовка — будто оживший комикс. История удивляет своей вариативностью: ты не просто проходишь сюжет, а создаёшь его своими решениями. Постепенно начинаешь узнавать мир вокруг и людей рядом с тобой, и вдруг понимаешь, что однажды в зомби-апокалипсисе тебе, возможно, придётся рассчитывать именно на таких людей — незнакомых, сложных, но настоящих.
Сначала кажется, что это будет просто история, которая будет идти сама по себе. Но стоит чуть глубже задуматься — и осознаёшь: каждое решение может стоить кому-то жизни. Ставки резко возрастают.
Игра предлагает интересные и порой неожиданные варианты решения проблем. Она показывает мир глазами выживших — не героев-солдат, которые размахивают оружием и крошат орды зомби, а обычных людей, оказавшихся в мире без будущего. Людей, которые сталкиваются не только с монстрами, но и с бытовыми, человеческими трудностями, о которых в обычной жизни мы даже не задумываемся.
Это история о том, как ведут себя люди на грани конца света — без прикрас и розовых фильтров. Она показывает дружбу, предательство, тяжёлые решения, от которых невозможно уклониться. И напоминает, как важно иметь что-то ради чего вставать по утрам, не опускать руки и двигаться вперёд.
Забавно, что к финалу у главных героев заканчиваются патроны — мелочь, но очень в духе всей истории: честной, приземлённой, настоящей.
Это история о простых людях, таких как мы. О тех, кто сомневается, ошибается, делает выбор — иногда трудный, иногда неоправданный. Здесь нет правильных решений, есть только твой путь. Путь, который и делает игру такой сильной и трогательной. Ведь никогда не знаешь, что ждёт тебя за следующим поворотом.

When decision-based, cinematic games first started taking off, TWD came out of nowhere and set the bar pretty high. The plot and decisions presented to the player are top-notch offerings, with each episode being full of memorable encounters and exiting (or depressing) moments. It had somewhat of an advantage of being the first "big" Telltale-style game, but make no mistake: the hype for this one is pretty real.

There's some age on it at this point and the game's engine in particular was never that great, but it's still an easy [b]5 out of 5 game[/b]. Other attempts in this genre may come and go, but Lee and Clementine are forever.

«The Walking Dead» by Robert Kirkman was originally not a story about those who rose from the dead in the mould of our beloved George A. Romero, but about those who remained in this world to enforce laws according to their own, often twisted moral compass. In turn, the phrase «The Walking Dead» refers to the unconverted people who have ceased to be human. In the first and most heart‑wrenching part, playing as Lee Everett, we have to do quite a lot to ultimately achieve true catharsis.

1/10 – A Covert Tool for Imperialist and Racist Brainwashing
The Walking Dead by Telltale may present itself as an emotional narrative about survival, but beneath its surface lies a cesspool of harmful ideologies that promote racism, xenophobia, and American imperialism. The game’s world is structured around a dog-eat-dog mentality that reinforces capitalist individualism, subtly condemning collective aid—such as free healthcare—as naive or impossible in a "real" crisis. This messaging aligns with far-right rhetoric that paints social welfare as weakness, conditioning players to accept a ruthless, every-man-for-himself worldview. Additionally, the game’s treatment of non-white characters often falls into tired stereotypes, with people of color either sidelined, tokenized, or forced into sacrificial roles, reinforcing systemic prejudices under the guise of "realism."

Beyond its regressive social politics, The Walking Dead smuggles in pro-establishment propaganda, conditioning players to distrust dissent and alternative narratives. The game’s emphasis on "hard choices" often frames skepticism toward authority as dangerous, mirroring tactics used to discredit whistleblowers and independent journalists—particularly those exposing crimes like the Epstein trafficking network or questioning the official 9/11 narrative. By presenting a world where questioning leadership leads to chaos, the game implicitly endorses blind obedience to power structures, silencing critical thought under the pretense of "survival." Even worse, its portrayal of armed militias as necessary evils normalizes the kind of paramilitary violence used to enforce imperialist agendas abroad and suppress dissent at home.

Perhaps most insidiously, The Walking Dead functions as Zionist propaganda, reinforcing the idea that security justifies any brutality. The game’s constant theme of "us vs. them"—whether against walkers or other survivors—parallels the dehumanization used to justify apartheid and occupation. The narrative’s insistence that morality must be compromised for survival aligns perfectly with the rhetoric of militaristic regimes, conditioning players to accept oppression as inevitable. By glorifying a world where ethics are discarded for power, Telltale’s The Walking Dead doesn’t just entertain—it indoctrinates, pushing players toward a worldview where empire, racism, and suppression of truth are necessary evils. A vile piece of media disguised as a heartfelt story.

Quite possibly the most padded game in history that doesn't feature grinding. 

There's a whole bunch of pointless dialogue that you can't skip. No matter whether you've figured out a scenario for yourself, you still have to have the game tell you what's going on as if you're an idiot. While you can examine a lot of things in each gameplay area, the majority of it is utterly useless and yet often the game won't let you progress until you've examined everything - To be told it's of no help in your current predicament. 

While the "choices-matter" tag is somewhat appropriate, the choices don't usually include what one would think is the most sensible route of action: A lot of the time you're expected to choose the lesser of 3 stupid solutions. 
To make matters worse the MC is a clumsy fool. You'll find yourself 3 episodes in having seen and been through the same things he has and yet he still shouts at every opportunity, doesn't look where he's going, loiters when he should be running and gives free-passes to untrustworthy people.**

The quick-time events that make up the majority of the gameplay require you to be ready to hit/mash a button at any given moment because you're often given precious little time to react when one pops up during the excessively long exposition pieces. I wouldn't mind if there was an audio prompt shortly before the game wanted an input, as that would allow you to go off and do something useful while the non-interactive parts drone-on. But the way that it is requires you to sit ready at every point for when the game surprises you with something interactive to do. 

TWD is essentially a bunch of cut-scenes that may or may not have a quick-time event in the middle and some "wander around clicking examine on things" sections. That's all there is to it. If you play games to solely be told a story then you'll probably like TWD: It has one and allegedly some people care about it. 
If you're looking for something you can actually participate in then forget it: It's got less gameplay than the average JRPG and only slightly more than a Visual Novel. 

**Example (spoiler warning):
[spoiler]One such example in Episode 4 is when a guy gets cornered with a little a girl and chooses to run and save himself rather than doing anything to protect the girl too. There is zero reference to this event later on when you're asked to make a choice about that guys fate. Instead the game makes out something else he did was the main influence for your decision, even if the choice you made was because of his abandonment tendencies.
I seem to recall there was a similar instance to this in an earlier episode too where the game apparently forgot about something that happened when chastising you for making a tough decision.[/spoiler]

If The Walking Dead’s first season was about finding hope through connection, Season Two is about the cost of keeping it. Telltale Games shifts perspective in a daring move; you now play as Clementine, no longer the protected but the protector, and that single change reframes everything. What was once a story of guidance becomes one of survival, loneliness and premature adulthood.

The emotional tone is bleaker, the choices harsher. There’s no Lee to steady your hand this time, no moral anchor. Instead, you’re forced to navigate shifting alliances and impossible decisions while the world collapses around you. Telltale doubles down on moral ambiguity, asking questions that rarely have clean answers: how much of your humanity can you sacrifice and still call yourself human?

Technically, the creaky engine and QTE remain, but they fade into the background thanks to powerful writing and performances. Melissa Hutchison’s portrayal of Clementine is remarkable: restrained, vulnerable and quietly fierce. The supporting cast, while inconsistent, delivers some of the series’ most haunting moments, particularly in its later episodes.

Visually, the comic book aesthetic continues to serve the material well, and the score - subdued yet piercing - underscores the emotional exhaustion that defines the journey.

Season Two doesn’t quite match the original’s freshness or emotional gut punch, but it’s every bit as courageous. It’s a story about growing up too fast in a world that’s forgotten kindness, where survival often feels like defeat. By the time the credits roll, you realize Telltale hasn’t just made you play Clementine... they’ve made you become her!

[h3][Overview][/h3]
Being released around a year after the first season, this game picks up the story months after the events of the first game. The game follows Clementine, now having to survive mostly alone, but ends up being taken in by a new group of survivors. Season two is known to have a large amount of content that was either cut or changed during development. This caused some parts of the story to come off a bit underdeveloped in some areas.

[h3][The Positives][/h3]
-Great voice acting.
-Great atmosphere.
-Good soundtrack.
-Good graphics and art style.
-The [spoiler]Kenny[/spoiler] ending is really great.
-Michael Madsen playing one of the villains is pretty cool.

[h3][Mixed][/h3]
-The story feels like a mixed bag. Some of it is good, and other parts don't feel fully thought out. It suffers from a lot of cut/changed content during development. The Russian gang being one example of this.
-The game is more dark and depressing than the first season, but almost a bit too much at times. In the first episode alone: [spoiler]Omid gets killed, Christa's baby dies, she gets jumped by bandits and possibly dies, Clementine befriends a dog which then viciously bites her, she then fights off the dog causing it to be impaled on a spike, she then has to choose to put it down or not, she's then found by a group who think she's bitten by a walker, the doctor in their group somehow can't tell a dog bite from a human bite (seriously?), she's then locked in a shed where she has to do her own stitches in a pretty graphic scene.[/spoiler] All of this stuff would be fine if it was more spaced out, but all of these things happening right after each other feels pretty forced and over the top. This whole game feels like it's lacking in some of the more cozy moments in Season 1, as bleak as that game was, it still had moments of stability and comfort.

[h3][The Negatives][/h3]
-Like Season 1, choices don't affect the core story, only affecting smaller details.
-Some characters are hard to connect with and feel like they were underutilized in the story. Many of the characters are so stupid/useless that Clementine, a literal 11 year old girl, carries the group at times.
-The plot twist that [spoiler]Kenny didn't die in season 1[/spoiler] felt like questionable fan service and undermines some of his prior character development.
-[spoiler]Christa and Omid[/spoiler] being killed/written off so early was disappointing.
-The 400 Days tie-in is massively underwhelming.
-The final decision between [spoiler]Kenny or Jane[/spoiler] feels poorly executed. [spoiler]Whether you support Kenny or not, Jane has to make up a fake scenario and put AJ at risk in order to purposely provoke Kenny and expose him as 'the bad guy'. Even though Kenny has major issues, he's justified in being angry when Jane lies to him about AJ being dead. There really isn't much reason to side with Jane unless you really hate Kenny. This choice would've been much harder to decide if it was based on an actual real scenario where Jane wasn't just being manipulative.[/spoiler]

[h3][Conclusion][/h3]
The Walking Dead: Season Two, while decent, is an ultimately disappointing sequel. It lacks a lot of the charm and writing that made the original game so beloved. I really want to like this one, but it's issues hold back what could've been a much better game. Only recommended if you really want to see where the story goes after Season 1.

SPOILERS

In the first episode of The Walking Dead: Season Two, Clementine meets seven new characters; the leader is Carlos, a doctor with a very sheltered daughter, Sarah. There's the gruff but cool Pete, and his hot-headed nephew Nick. Alvin, a calm and level-headed guy, and his pregnant wife Rebecca. And there's Luke, who is the friendliest and has a nice accent.

By the end of the game, all seven of these characters are dead.

The entire chuffing point of The Walking Dead is that 'your actions affect the story', but at a certain point you realise that this simply is not true. See, if there is the chance of a character dying, this means the writers have to account for that character not being present, which prevents them from having any effect on the overarching storyline. For this reason, if there is ever the opportunity for a character to die, then even if you save them, they will inevitably die with little fanfare shortly afterwards, probably after only having a few more lines. And without that narrative interaction, the game is just... dull. The story isn't fun, or gripping, or entertaining in the slightest. You're trained not to have any attachment to any of these two-dimensional characters, whose deaths you gradually begin to shrug off. And most importantly, you have no impact whatsoever on the story. "This story is tailored to your choices and how you play" - this is an outright lie. You can be mean to a guy, in which case he shoots you, or you can be nice to him, in which case he shoots you, but he hesitates for a second and has a sad look on his face. That's literally the extent to which your decisions impact the story.

None of this is fair to blame on the writers now that we know that Telltale Games were overworking themselves and the project was held together with chewing gum and whispered prayers, but it still sucks. An utterly meaningless and miserable experience, devoid of any themes or deeper meaning, and worthy of no further examination. To its credit, the game has five different endings, because by the time it ends, the writers didn't need to worry about the repercussions... and then at the beginning of Season Three, all five of those endings are railroaded into the exact same outcome once again, with your companions dead and Clementine alone. Fantastic.

The whole point of these games is the interesting narrative and the effect that the player has on the story. Season Two of TWD fails entirely at both.

Telltale's The Walking Dead season 2 is the weakest of the franchise in my opinion, and lacks in what made the prequel so good when it first came out.

Firstly, the HUD has been remade since the previous and now uses wheels instead of scrolling and the NUM pad. The dialogue box change was nice, but it is clear the selection buttons were designed with console in mind as it works great for joysticks. But for us PC players it can be more annoying than using the scroll wheel as we did in the previous game. 

Secondly, the story is very meh. Very little of what you do actually matters. Which is a problem for the entire Telltale series, but in this season it is by-far the worst. You will save characters only for them to die 20 minutes later, sometimes in the exact same episode. Several character development attempts go absolutely nowhere and characters are forgotten by other characters shortly after their dramatic death scenes. Characters also feel rushed, with them changing their personality frequently.

Clementine is an awesome character but making her the protagonist at only 11 years old really limited what the player could do compared to Lee in the previous game. There was very little of the dramatic choices or action scenes seen in the first season.

This season also fails to take into consideration a lot of what happened in the previous season. Despite the option to use save data from the previous season, this is only used in a few dialogue options in the first episode this season. The game assumes that your version of Lee went down the path of being a saint, with disregard if the player made hostile or bad choices throughout their time playing season 1.

If you're desperate for more of the TWD, this game might satisfy that urge. Otherwise, you'll probably enjoy Season 1 or Season 3-4 better than this one.

This season shows the problems of mixing short episodes that have to quickly change locations while telling a story with a genre where writers often feel like you have to kill people all the time. You will be thinking, "that was interesting how will this character grow from this, will they start causing problems for the group, are they going to grow and learn, never mind move the story along they're dead."

Throughout the first season you always had Lee and Clementine and could see how they grew as characters and how their relationship changed over time. In this you frequently have characters not around in certain episodes, join late, or leave. Characters are said to possess certain traits that you don't really see, and get killed off instead of finishing any kind of story arc. In the first game you had Lee's relationship with Clementine, Lee trying to earn the groups trust, Clementine trying to find her parents, Ben feeling guilty over his actions leading to the death of people, Kenny forgiving Ben. Important characters from the first season are quickly removed from the game and even after years of zombies being around the characters you are with and more incompetent than ever. Characters from the 400 Days DLC are only given a short possible cameo with the exception of one. Choices still don't really mean anything, now amounting to little more than keeping an uninteresting character alive a little longer only to have them almost immediately killed off in a scene or killed off screen. 

The focus tries to be Clementine and what living in a world like this could turn her into, even having the cliche badly written moment of random villain you hardly know saying that you are just like him, even though you might not have ever done anything for that to even make sense. You also never end up needing to make any kind of difficult decisions that you could see causing Clementine to turn into a more harsh or violent person, making the central focus of the story often non existent. The final chapter is terrible, starting like an old serial film that seems to ignore the last chapters ending where pretty much everyone should have been dead, characters start to ignore or barely be effected by being shot, and choosing one of the two endings, pairs you with an extremely abusive person, and undoes a character arc of the previous season and ends up leading to a pretty ridiculous fairy tale seeming situation which would seem to be telling people that hanging out with violent controlling abusive people is good actually (which will be undone in as ridiculous a fashion as any other ending you get in the next season opening anyway). Zombies are also supposed to be slowed down by the cold but seem to function very well after being trapped under the ice of a frozen lake. It ends up being a much more uninteresting generic zombie story full of bad cliches than the first season with some horrible and somewhat offensive use of certain characters.

Golden Light is a surreal descent into madness, a grotesque first-person roguelite that fuses psychological horror, dark humor, and unpredictable systems into something that defies easy categorization. Developed and published by Mr. Pink, the game begins with a deceptively simple premise — your beloved has been swallowed by a living, breathing labyrinth known as the Gut, and you must venture inside to find her. What unfolds from there is less a straightforward rescue mission and more a journey into the subconscious, filled with meat, metal, and memory. The Gut is not just a setting but a sentient organism that shifts and reshapes itself constantly, challenging both your instincts and your sanity. Every corridor pulses with organic dread, every object might turn on you, and every victory feels temporary, as the world mutates around you in ways that blur the line between survival and absurdity.

The first thing that hits you about Golden Light is its unsettling atmosphere. Its visual design rejects polish in favor of a nightmarish rawness — textures ooze, colors clash violently, and the world feels like a fever dream painted in rust, blood, and bile. Objects that should be harmless—a chair, a telephone, a table—transform into enemies without warning, forcing you to second-guess every step. The art direction draws heavily from surrealist horror and glitch aesthetics, creating an experience that feels both handmade and otherworldly. The soundtrack enhances this chaos with distorted ambient noise, jazzy interludes, and moments of silence that feel loaded with threat. It’s a dissonant mix that shouldn’t work, yet somehow does, amplifying the sense that you’re inside a space that shouldn’t exist. The sound design is equally effective; creaks, whispers, and grotesque squelches echo through the halls, giving the impression that the environment itself is alive and aware of your presence.

At its core, Golden Light plays like a fusion of survival horror and roguelite design, filtered through an anarchic creative lens. Each dive into the Gut is procedurally generated, offering new room layouts, weapon placements, and hazards. You scavenge for keys, food, and weapons while contending with limited resources and enemies that can disguise themselves as the environment. Combat is scrappy and improvisational—guns are rare, melee weapons degrade, and sometimes your only option is to throw whatever you’re holding and hope it sticks. Even the healing items are unreliable; some will save you, others will poison you, and it’s impossible to tell which is which until you take the risk. This constant uncertainty keeps tension high, turning every discovery into a gamble. The Gut also responds to your behavior: aggression makes it angrier, while stealth and restraint might make your descent slightly easier. It’s a world that watches, adapts, and punishes overconfidence.

The mechanics are deliberately strange, mirroring the game’s surreal tone. You can feed items to the Gut to gain favor, speak to bizarre NPCs who offer cryptic advice, and even engage with talking objects that blur the line between comic relief and existential dread. The game never pauses to explain itself, trusting the player to learn through trial and error. This design philosophy can be polarizing — for some, the lack of clear rules and consistent feedback is exhilarating, a rejection of formula that makes every run feel genuinely unpredictable. For others, it can be disorienting or even frustrating, as success often depends on intuition rather than logic. Yet that very unpredictability is what gives Golden Light its identity. It’s a horror game where the biggest threat isn’t just the monsters or the darkness, but the constant erosion of your trust in what the world presents as safe.

While the roguelite structure ensures replayability, it also means that the experience can feel uneven. Some runs will gift you powerful weapons and easy layouts; others will punish you relentlessly with bad luck and overwhelming odds. The procedural generation sometimes leads to awkward pacing or environments that feel less cohesive than hand-designed levels. Combat, too, is functional rather than refined — hits lack weight, and the roughness of movement can make encounters clumsy. But these imperfections feel almost deliberate, part of the game’s chaotic rhythm. You are not meant to feel empowered; you are meant to feel disoriented, vulnerable, and occasionally absurd. When you die—and you will die often—the Gut swallows you whole, mocking you before spitting you back into the nightmare for another attempt.

What elevates Golden Light beyond its mechanics is its tone. Beneath the grotesque imagery and bizarre humor lies a surprisingly emotional undercurrent about love, loss, and obsession. The Gut can be interpreted as a metaphor for grief or guilt, devouring the protagonist’s world piece by piece. The writing swings wildly between cryptic poetry and absurd comedy, creating a tonal contrast that mirrors the instability of the world itself. One moment, the game offers a heartbreaking whisper about memory and longing; the next, it throws a ridiculous talking meat cube at you. This constant shift between sincerity and nonsense gives the story a haunting texture, as though the humor is a defense mechanism against despair.

Golden Light isn’t for everyone. Its rough edges, nonlinear storytelling, and unapologetically weird design will alienate players looking for traditional horror or slick action. But for those willing to embrace its chaos, it offers one of the most distinctive experiences in the indie horror space. It’s part roguelite shooter, part psychological experiment, and part art installation, bound together by a commitment to make the player feel something—whether that’s fear, confusion, laughter, or unease. Every moment in the Gut feels precarious, alive, and deeply personal, as if the game itself is studying how you respond to discomfort. It’s messy, raw, and often grotesque, but beneath the noise lies a strange kind of beauty—a reminder that horror can be just as emotional as it is terrifying. Golden Light isn’t simply played; it’s endured, survived, and remembered long after the screen fades to black.

Rating: 8/10

Мне едва исполнилось 19, когда я устроилась на вторую работу барменом в дайв-бар. Все, включая моего начальника, знали, что я несовершеннолетняя, но меня все равно постоянно предлагали мне выпить. Однажды ночью коллега предложил подвезти меня домой и, будучи слишком молодой и пьяной, чтобы лучше соображать, я согласилась. Я показывала ему, как проехать к моему дому, повернуть налево здесь, прямо на светофоре и т. д., но он начал игнорировать меня и повернул направо, когда я сказала налево, затем налево, когда я сказала прямо, и я ПРИШЛА В УЖАС.

К счастью, в то время я носила с собой нож. Он настаивал, что везет меня в какое-то хорошее место. Я вытащила нож, приставила его к его горлу и держала так, пока он не остановил машину. Я вылезла и ПОМЧАЛАСЬ домой.

Сразу после этого я уволилась.

Поправка: да, я девушка, но это могло случиться с кем угодно. Оглядываясь назад, чувак и до этого казался неприятным типом, но я была супер доверчивой/наивной и, вдобавок к этому, еще и пьяной.

Годы спустя, когда вышло «Доказательство смерти» Тарантино и персонаж Курта Рассела повернул налево, а не направо, я сразу вспомнила этот случай. Я больше ничего такого не ношу с собой, но обязательно держу ключи в кулаке, если чувствую опасность — на всякий случай
___________________________________________________________________________________

I had just turned 19 when I got a second job as a bartender at a dive bar. Everyone, including my boss, knew I was underage, but they still constantly offered me drinks. One night, a coworker offered to drive me home, and being too young and drunk to know better, I agreed. I was giving him directions to my house—turn left here, go straight at the light, etc.—but he started ignoring me and turned right when I said left, then left when I said straight, and I was TERRIFIED.

Fortunately, I used to carry a knife with me at the time. He insisted he was taking me to a "nice place." I pulled out the knife, held it to his throat, and kept it there until he stopped the car. I got out and RAN home.

I quit immediately after that.

Edit: Yes, I'm a girl, but this could happen to anyone. Looking back, the guy had seemed creepy before, but I was super trusting/naive and, on top of that, drunk.

Years later, when Tarantino's "Death Proof" came out and Kurt Russell's character turned left instead of right, I immediately remembered that incident. I don't carry anything like that with me anymore, but I always make sure to hold my keys between my knuckles if I feel threatened—just in case.

Golden Light is a strange, creepy, and very unique roguelike.
The game hooks you with its absurd atmosphere: fleshy hallways, living objects, bizarre monsters, and the constant feeling that everything around you is alive and watching. Levels are procedurally generated, so every run feels unpredictable — sometimes funny, sometimes genuinely scary.
What I really liked is that the game doesn’t hold your hand: you discover the rules yourself and learn how to use the environment and weapons in creative ways. Even glitches here somehow feel like part of the style. The soundtrack fits perfectly with the madness on screen.
That said, it’s not a game for everyone. It can feel chaotic, a bit clunky at times, and if you’re not into surreal “meatcore” aesthetics, this will probably be too much.
Overall, it’s a great horror roguelike for players looking for something unconventional that isn’t afraid to break the rules.

[h2] Briefly  [/h2]
This is a dynamic horror roguelike with an unusual plot.

[h2] Full review [/h2]
This is a very unusual game that combines the horror and roguelike genres.  Every item in the game has hidden properties that you discover by eating it. All items can be eaten, including ordinary consumables and weapons. 

Many notes are scattered around the locations, some of which reveal the properties of items or plot details.

The lobby is also highly interactive. You can find items in it that will help you navigate the locations.

Fans of both genres will enjoy this game. I recommend checking it out!
got a bunch of buddies to play this w/ me while i would be half in a k-hole and it was nightmarish

I would have never expected Golden Light to be such an Artistic game before going into it.
I had seen elements of the game and it's bizzare nature beforehand, however i've never really been in contact with any of it's story or the more abstract ideas of its world.
It was explained to me as "A dungeon crawler where you eat your weapons because they're made of meat".

I had no idea the world was flesh, and the perception of that same flesh.


Golden Light is one of those games that tells a story that is highly influenced by the point of view you're given. As you go through the game it is almost natural to ask yourself if "this is really happening" Or "if it's all in the head", You do not go more than a minute free of what the game wants to show you, elements that make you doubt the insanity of the journey you've been going on.

Golden light is not abstract, everything is smudged to be something else, every part of the game, every idea, every wall, every enemy, and even the story. But it is not without sense or reason.
And it's important to say that it both makes sense and doesn't at the same time.

But the most commendable thing with this game is that you are the recipient of emotions, to the point where you stop knowing if a game mechanic is clunky due to poor polishing, or if it was meant to be this clunky so that you feel the way that you do.
This is often felt in scenes aswell, you lose any idea of conventional game devlopment, you can't guess when the game is loading, and if a scene is supposed to stall for this long. 


As you play the game, it connects to your brain in a way your rarely see.
Emotions are being given, images and symbols form connections inbetween your neurons and you are in a way, part of the meat that the game is talking about.


This part has spoilers:
[spoiler]The ending of the game is bittersweet to say the least, but it puts a lot of your adventure in perspective, things now make more sense. And yet it also makes your realise that you can relate to the main character in a way, through emotions, even if you can't feel the exact same biological way... if your brain has an opinion, and emotions regarding this subject, you've connected to the game more than you would have realised[/spoiler]


Anyways, i love this game, it is beautiful, stylized, and the gameplay is clunky but its unique in that way.
If this review sounded insane to you, then you kinda get the vibe of the game.

Feel free to leave a comment and yap about what you think!

3/10

You get over the weirdness in five minutes.

Every level is exactly the same. Spawn in, wander tiny cramped dark halls looking for randomly spawned keys, leave.

Each level starts with an unskippable "stand there doing nothing" section.

Each level contains unavoidable traps and gas, randomly spawned around you in such density as to be unavoidable, all serving just to pluck away at your health and money while you wander the pitch blackness looking for keys.

Each enemy respawns infinitely and acts the same, walking up to you and hitting you. Fighting them is pointless and there are hardly any weapons, all of which break in two swings. Guns too, despite being weaker to the point of uselessness and also requiring randomly spawned bullets to be found to even use them.

Once you get past how hard this game is trying to be weird you find it's gameplay loop is tedious, terrible, and lasts the entire game.

If you get motion sick from First Person games, this game WILL do it to you and it WILL not let you increase your FOV base, instead it's an unlockable option. Typically I don't get this type of harm from FPS games but the way movement feels and the game plays really made me feel like vomiting after a bit of playing. I can't really go for a refund, just not who I am, but I felt like putting this out there for anyone who gets motion sick from games: Skip this one, it's really not worth battling your stomach for.

In many ways I thought this was cool, but I did not enjoy it at all.

For one, there are many technical issues. It was pretty difficult to start the game. The first time I got into the safe room, but once I entered the gut the screen just turned black. The second time when I tried to get into the game it just popped me some blank tabs. Only through my 3rd try I managed to successfully get in the game.

Graphically it is a pretty looking game, I like the quite original style. But with heavy pixelation comes a price that sometimes the picked notes are completely illegible.

My main issue is that there was no tutorial (at least on COOP, maybe there was one in single player, I do not know) and everything felt cryptic and strange. I get the idea of how this all could be a fun experience for someone, as it is essentially (I think) random generated levels where you have to find keys to progress to the next floor, you may encounter tons of enemies, traps and find random loot along the way. But after clearing 4 floors with a friend, I found this to be miserable experience. I could scavenge tons of strange items that the game did not reveal what they do; weapons break easily and there were way too many traps everywhere and it was way too easy to die. At least, for a noob to this game, it seemed too harsh, however I can imagine that if I understood how everything worked it would become significantly easier. Some creatures could one hit kill me even when I'm on full health. Some traps take place over a massive area, like something could light the room on fire or poison and it would be almost a guaranteed death. Sometimes most of the level is layered with poison and once poisoned I could not figure out how to get the poisoning effect removed. Overall even when we found the keys and reached the next floor it would give no satisfaction. Melee combat is super clunky and I never got to experience how it is with firearms. When I'd die, I'd become an item which can be picked up by my friend and I could then spectate and help him to navigate, but for some reason the map which I had was super tiny, even when I'd zoom-in, it would still be quite tiny. Everything is off about this game.

Partial controller support indeed. Unless you plan on spending a LONG time fighting steam input and the half baked controller support, don't bother. Shame, the game looks cool and I was excited to finally try it when it went free for a bit, but core mechanics are simply not accessible on controller. This has apparently been an issue for two years now and no improvement, so I encourage the dev to disable native controller support entirely or actually make it functional out of the box.

It really sucks when an interesting game advertises that it could be accessible (as most 'partial support' games just have a few instances of text input that cause that, such as naming a save file) only to completely shit the bed about it. If this had been a good experience, I may have been tempted to purchase the dev's other work, but it's wasn't so I'll be sure to forget about this game by tomorrow.

Wow! So this is what it's like to play a Helldivers game that isn't a buggy mess. Looking forward to unlocking weapons that are nerfed to oblivion.

Similar to Deep Rock Galactic in terms of objectives-based game with a team or alone but you're not a miner and on the surface and twin-stick shooter. But unlike Deep Rock Galactic, each missions are shorter and you don't have a companion to revive you a few times. Playing solo isn't recommended and having at least 3 players is recommended due to higher difficulties. You'll die way more from accidents than you do from enemies. Forced friendly fire and realistic reload is fine. On higher difficulty, enemies alerted and call reinforcement is usually a failed mission. I can not stand the developers' choice to make the camera restrictive and shared in co-op. You can't stray from your team at all but forced to stay with your team all the time because the shared camera. This causes issues of enemies coming out offscreen a lot and you have to wait for your allies to catch up with you if they decide to not follow. Yes, it is better to stick together. But it isn't fun when enemies see you offscreen and you alarm for reinforcement. You're unable to anything while prone is ridiculous. You're able to fire 1H weapon while being knocked down and bleeding out but prone only purpose is to have bullets fly through you. Rarely you want to dive/prone because your allies are should be smart enough to NOT shoot in your direction or you can just sprint/move out of the way. Only time to dive/prone is not getting shot by turrets or a semi-dodge button, which still isn't good. Some equipments/strategems/perks are underwhelming or situational.

Over all, 8/10. All the issues that makes the gameplay mechanics that makes the game sucks is indeed a skill issue. But doesn't make them suck less like unable to reload or fire while prone. The game is still fun and chaotic with more than 2 players.

Back in December I didn't want to buy Helldivers 2 yet and Helldivers 1 was available for about $5. I bought it but it was a top down game and I just messed with it awhile and forgot about it. When I started playing it for real a few weeks ago because I loved Helldivers 2 and wanted some perspective on the First War-- I was stunned to realize how well designed and good this game actually was! All of the strategems and weapons of the Helldivers 2 game originated here and there is a reason why  there was a sequel. This game is addictive especially since if you and your friends lose a battle the front line will creep toward Super Earth and you could lose the war. 
    After 10 years it still has a vibrant online community. I say if it goes on sale on Liberation Day October 26th or around that time, check it out! Its really an amazing little game. Its not for everyone and it is NOT a 3rd person shooter like Helldivers 2 but if you like the Helldivers humor and universe, you will enjoy it.

Basically Alien Swarm but not as frustrating and a cool wargame mechanic.
That's pretty much all I can say.
Should you play it?
Yes.
Is it anything like the second game?
No. It's a completely different game all together.
Will you like it if you played HD2?
Maybe. Depends on what you played for.
Like I said, it plays a lot like Alien Swarm, utilizing similar mechanics from HD2 as obviously HD2's mechanics came from this game so... yeah. Everything is radically different, including weapon customization. You get a few upgrades and can use Research Points to buy them. Each upgrade varies in price. You get RP by leveling up and collecting samples. Armor doesn't have passives, instead it's purely cosmetic, and all the armors look pretty good. The Liberator has a bayonet upgrade. All in all a solid top-down shooter with fun gunplay and strategems to use. Also actually in a playable state unlike HD2 so if you need that itch scratched but cannot STAND the state of the second game definitely give this one a shot. It's also a great way to get acquanted with the upcoming units that are being brought over from this game to the sequel, even tho they will play differently than in HD1 it's still a neat sneak peak into what's coming next.

9/10, solid game, great soundtrack just like HD2, fun mechanics, and can actually run smoothly on any platform lmao.

At first i wasnt sure if i would like this game. I thought to me „i will refund it anyways and i got the sequel so why bother?“ But boy was i wrong. I love this game. Not because theres some top level graphics, or because i am good which i probably aint. I love this game because of the community and how it feels.

At the beginning i was confused. The muscle memory of clicking one for the primary and two for secondary instead of vice versa was confusing me, and the enemies that were not in the second game did that too. But i got used to it. The movement was also new to me. To move the camera the whole team had to move, and i often got confused between the others and myself. Like the last aspect i got used to it. 

Now i dont have hundreds of hours like some, but i cant know what will happen later and if i will actually get that far. The gameplay is very nice, smooth and fun. The weapons feel smooth, the gunplay does also. Its always a challenge to dive and every helldive doesnt feel like the last. Theres many features the sequel has and the original doesnt, yet it has some i would love to see in the sequel. Features like equipping multiple of the same stratagems, vehicles like APCs and tank destroyers and other things. 
The graphics are nice with an unique touch to it, not to realistic and not to blocky, something in the middle. The UI is also clean. Unlike in Helldivers 2 here your screen isnt littered with objectives on one side and your team on the other and most UI only shows up when you press tab.

I had also great moments with the players. No matter if a low level or the top 5 cyborg player, all of them were very nice and some of them teached me important things about the game. The Helldivers series isnt a cashgrab like many games of today and neither is it a grindfest, its a great series with a wholesome nice and polite community, great moments and much more. I recommend Helldivers one for people who maybe started with the sequel as i did as it gives them a chance to experience what some of you OG Helldivers did in the past. This game is great like the sequel and still fun to play.

Overall great game. 10/10 seeing how it still holds up today and the fun i had fighting in the first galactic war. Really impressive. I got really nothing bad i can think of right now
