As always, Arrowhead makes a game that comes close to greatness but falls short by it's many, many, many, bugs (no pun intended). This game is riddled with problems that most players overlook: frequent crash to desktop incidents (just like Magicka), disconnecting from servers (and losing all your progress), invisible hit boxes that prematurely cause weapons to explode. Arrowhead needs to learn to spend more time with their games in a QA process.

I bought this as a "party game" for multiple family or friends to enjoy together but it's nothing but frustration. Aside from the poor software programming that went into this, the game design itself seemed more interested in creating an experience that aims to frustrate more than encourage fun. The illuminates can shoot players from about three screens away, walls randomly appear boxing in players, spawns can happen anywhere, right where you're standing, resulting in an instant-kill, or maybe right on top of a tower you're supposed to defend. Hellpods that bring in other players actually target living players (by programmatical design). The entire game is based around a community contribution experience so you can have the misfortune of ONLY being allowed to fight illuminates (usually the case, since almost nobody enjoys those missions); watch what happens once the Cyborgs and Bugs have been defeated: the player count effectively drops to zero until the galaxy resets.

It's really too bad, like I said in my opening line: Arrowhead makes games on the verge of greatness but can't seem to escape a handful of design decisions that ruin the overall experience. Somebody in the design room literally sat back and said to themselves "What would be the most challenging thing we could throw at players, whether fair or not?" without asking the question whether the challenges enhanced or took away from the overall player experience. I play to have fun. But this game is all frustration.
This review was removed by the ministry of truth under suspicion of Treason.

While not the worst twinstick shooter ever made, Helldivers 1 does [i]not[/i] hold up well to modern standards. The atmosphere (especially voice acting) is underwhelming, the combat is clunkier than its successor, and the game as a whole lacks the polish that is present in its successor.

The atmosphere, in particular, is worth singling out above all other flaws present in HD1; while the core gameplay is passable, the atmosphere simply [i]is not there[/i] compared to HD2. Comparing the intro cinematics between the two games is enough to summarize the difference, especially as that difference in quality persists long after the intro ends.

Only try this if you can live with a much more underwhelming atmosphere and gameplay is the only trait you're looking for.

The game makes one really questionable design decision that made me hate it.

A friend and I bought the game with the intention of playing together. We just so happened to start playing at the end of a global campaign or whatever they call it. What that means is that after we finished the tutorial and could join each other, there was only one enemy force we could fight: the machines, which I think are considered the hardest enemy type for beginners. The other two enemy forces had been totally eliminated already in the global campaign. So we attempted one level 1 mission and failed it, but were eager to dive back in and try again, but at this point the campaign entered some kind of "Final Battle" mode where every player in the world had something like 24 hours to cumulatively win enough missions to gain a total victory over the final remaining enemy force. But this also locked us into only being able to play these final battle missions, which start at level 3.

Being total noobs at the game with no experience and no upgrades, it was way too hard for us to take on these harder difficulty missions before we had a chance to learn the ropes and upgrade our gear on some of the lower difficulty missions first. No problem, we thought, we'll wait a day for the players to win and the campaign will get reset back to the beginning with easier difficulty missions and all varieties of enemy forces. But what actually happened was there were not enough players doing the missions to win within the 24 hours, but there were enough to keep entering the "final battle" state. So in essence, the 24 hour timer kept resetting. Day after day. We checked every day for a couple of weeks but it was always stuck in that "final battle" state of the global campaign.

After doing some research, I found a way to bypass the global campaign by disabling cloud saves and essentially running the game disconnected from the global campaign and we managed to play together that way. But it was a time-intensive, hacky workaround that involved making backup copies of the early campaign save file, playing one mission, at which point the game would connect to the servers and see the universe was at the final battle, so then I'd have to quit the game and restore the backed up campaign file again, start the game up, invite my friend to join me and do one mission before starting the process over again.

By the time the global campaign actually reset back to the beginning my friend had dropped off playing because there was too much friction to enjoy it while it was stuck at the end of the campaign. I was still interested in playing and had been making some decent progress solo using my "disconnected" workaround, but when I went to rejoin the early stages of the global campaign I also re-enabled cloud saves so I could easily play on my PC or my Steam Deck. Instead of keeping the character I'd spent 14 hours playing with, the cloud save overwrote all progress I had made in the past month and reset my character to where it was when I had disabled cloud saves. My character was essentially back to being a total noob, having completed the tutorial and failed a few missions. No upgrades, no unlocks. All gone and reset to zero. That totally destroyed any motivation I had to keep playing.

I think if we had happened to buy the game when the global campaign was at an earlier state and had been able to work our way up to competently completing level 3+ missions before being locked in to that difficulty, we probably would have had a lot of fun and spent dozens of hours playing the game. But because of the design decision to force everyone into a global campaign with no way of experiencing other enemy types or character level-appropriate mission difficulties, we had a very disappointing first impression and every effort to have fun with it was met with a lot of friction and resistance.

The fun parts that are in the game and should be there for every player were locked and there was nothing we could do to unlock them. It was beyond our control. It felt a lot like a group project where the other people you depend on don't do their part and so you get a failing grade. That one design decision probably changed this from a game I would have loved and spent dozens of hours playing to one I put in way more time trying to bypass this silly restriction before finally giving up and losing interest in wasting more time on it.

To our American friends, If you see this message, please consider acquiring this ridiculous game company. Love from EOS. This should have been a historic moment in gaming — players from all over the world united for a last stand, a glorious comeback. But Arrow turned its back on everyone who believed in them. All our efforts were in vain. We poured countless hours into this, and all of it was for nothing.

review_text:
Tower Unite is a brilliantly laid back game. With several minigames from the casual and fun Minigolf, to the arcade horde shooter of zombie massacre.

This game has plenty for people to see and do, with a player base which may be small yet is highly active and devoted to this game, you should see the workshop content this game has!

However, the best thing about this game has to be the development team who are active in the game and listen to player feedback as well as hosting plenty of events throughout the year to keep players interested, if you want a laid back party game you can enjoy, I highly suggest you give Tower Unite a go!

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
This is a social game and is an AMAZING value for the money. I bought it long ago when most of the games and cosmetics that are here now were not, and it was still worth it back then.

For $20 (or less) this has it all: mini-golf with a dozen or more courses, ball racing, go kart racing, minigames in the Plaza, a casino, bowling, trivia, an arcade with dozens of games to earn tickets and redeem for prizes, a shooting gallery, a roller coaster, fishing spots with various bait and tackle, tons of fish, condos you can decorate and buy items for (and invite others to hang out in!), movie theaters (and you can watch YouTube movies/videos with friends there OR your condo!)...it's an absolutely incredible value for the money and tons of fun. And NO MICROTRANSACTIONS!! Everything you buy in the game, you EARN in the game, by playing games in the arcade or the main games.

10/10, if you like even 10% of what's there.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
Started playing Tower Unite way back in 2013, when I didn't even have the Counter Strike games yet. I was looking at a big pink chessboard and I still loved everything it had to offer. MacDGuy was even available to chat to on Skype.  Great times. 

When the game became standalone, I held off for years - because I felt I wouldn't enjoy it as much anymore. But once I got it; boy, was I wrong. I love everything about this game and it's a shame that it doesn't get played as much as it did back on GMod. 

I would love to see this game skyrocket in the future!

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
Tower Unite is everything I loved about the old GMOD community experience, modernized and expanded into its own vibrant world. As someone with several hours in GMOD, I truly appreciate the culture this game has built on and evolved. It captures that same sense of creativity, fun, and community but with its own unique personality.

The variety of mini-games is a blast, and there’s always something new to jump into. Whether you’re competing, exploring, or just hanging out, there’s a strong social aspect that brings players together in a way few games manage these days.

I enjoy all the activities Tower Unite offers, and it’s clear the game has plenty of room to grow. The dedicated dev team is constantly improving things and seems genuinely passionate about the project. It’s refreshing to see developers so involved and committed.

Overall, Tower Unite is an awesome experience with tons of potential. I’m excited to keep playing and can’t wait to see where the devs take it next.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
I love this game. I was a long time player of GMod Tower, Tower Unite's predecessor, and when I first heard about this game, I was worried. I backed the Indiegogo campaign, and as soon as I got access, I was playing. I've been off and on again, as other games catch my interest, but I've kept an eye on Tower, and often return.

Honestly, it has issues at times, but I feel that most of the issues are peanuts in comparison to the lack of content in other social games. Many social games feel like glorified chat rooms, and if Tower Unite was a chat room, it'd be a BBS in December of 1993. I've bought this game for multiple people, who have all enjoyed it, including my sister (who otherwise just plays Sims 4 and Minecraft), my fiance, and my best friend (who otherwise plays Age of Empires 2 and Counter-Strike: Source).

Despite it's flaws, the game has something for everyone, and even at the slowest of times, you can find people online to hang out with. I love this game, and as long as it's online, I'll be playing it.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
For those who like immersive, personalized experiences, this is a great game. For those who like party games, this is also a great game. You can do a variety of different things such as bowling, a kart racer, arcade games and billiards, etc. Participating in these activities rewards you with various currencies that you can spend on items that you can place in any "condo" that you own, such as a nightclub, movie theater, apartment, etc. There's also workshop support so that you can replace your player avatar with other characters, or even get objects to place in your condo.

There's various different seasonal events during different times of the year, but even if you miss an event the rewards are still available if you go to the right shopkeepers in the plaza. However, if you want to take part in the holiday themed event activities, you will have to play during the correct time of year. Whether you are playing during a holiday event or not however, this is a much more fun experience if you bring friends along for the fun.

Condo customization is rather extensive. You can not only place various items around to do some interior decorating, but you can also toy around with the textures and such to really make these spaces your own. Some of the items you can place are even interactive, such as musical instruments or a pool table or even a TV. You can invite some friends over to become a music band together, or watch videos on the TV, or even emulate your favorite retro games provided you dump the files onto your PC.

There's also a great many other things to discover in this game, such as the pets you can "purchase" with your in-game reward money. My only real nitpick is that you can create private sessions to play in your condo alone or with friends, but you can't do the same for the plaza. It can be annoying dealing with other people sometimes, and it would be nice to be able to set up private sessions to go bowling or play in the arcade or etc. Either way though, that is ultimately just a nitpick and it doesn't stop the game overall from being a blast to play.

Overall, as far as immersive time wasters go this is quite decent. A great choice whether you just want to kill some time or need something to play at a party.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
Tower Unite is one of those games that's perfect for a friend group who struggles to decide on what to play. It may not be something I reach for every day, but it's something I'm always confident I'll come back to.

There's plenty of fun, curated experiences and activities that the developers provide alongside a plethora of self-expression and ways to create your own fun: Custom player models, a level editor for various activities, and even a robust player housing system.

Just when my friends and I think we've seen it all, we find some guy who turned his condo into an entire 80s vaporwave sci-fi retro-futuristic city to explore.

I would highly recommend it for often-ambivalent friend groups, people who are looking for a chill social experience, or people with a strong creative spark who enjoy expressing themselves in the games they play.

review_text: There is a lot of nostalgia tied with this game, for sure. I will always love when this was just Gmod Tower, and even with it becoming its own thing, which I will say was a grand thing for it to be able to do, for sure, I will also admit that it did sort of, in a way, make it that much harder to get into it in its own right. I do feel like I've gotten a good time out of it, for sure, but I can also see how some people might not think that way about it with how it is now. I will say that, even with the last time I touched it being a good while ago, I have gotten a good time out of it, and I hope that if anyone else gets it, they have a grand ol' time with it as well.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text: This game is soulless. The magic of "Gmod Tower" is gone and dead; nonetheless, a soulless shell persists on its grave. And that game is Tower Unite. Throughout the years, the game has been slowly dying and losing interest to those who had hoped it would be a golden frontier for Gmod Tower. But sadly, they failed to deliver. With the slow updates and repetitive gameplay, most players succumbed to boredom and deleted the game right after. The updates don't include a lot of material for players to work with. Being forced to be stuck with a limited gameplay loop of: A. A very small player base that plays mini-games, which may consist of 3 to 5 players, or, if unlucky, none of the mini-games have any active player base. B. Oversimplified mini-games. Because of how simple the game is, it becomes boring very fast due to its very repetitive nature. Of course, I can go for hours talking about the flaws and issues with the game. But that wouldn't solve anything, nor be necessary. I'm overall disappointed with how this game turned out. Sure, there's gambling and great detail with all these games and how they look and function. It doesn't feel rewarding after a certain point. It feels bland. Of course, this is my opinion and feeling about the game, and others feel different, but overall, this is what I've noticed.

review_text: unfortunately even after 1.0 release this game is so laggy, both in terms of performance and networking, that the experience of even something as basic as walking around in the lobby is deeply unpleasant, let alone playing a minigame. i really wish i could recommend this game but it's so hard to look past the fact that, despite some interesting and fun aspects, the core gameplay experience is still disorientingly laggy and unstable despite years of updates. if i wasn't always rubber banding around the lobby and experiencing big frame hitches just walking around, i'd probably give the game more consideration, but unfortunately the game feels *very* janky and uncomfortable to play.

review_text:
It's a good game. There's a lot to do. And this review would normally be positive, but:

It is incredibly buggy. Alone in half a week of playing again, there have not just been simple overlookable bugs but outright game-breaking ones, including full hard crashes.
And in addition to that, the servers themselves also have massive lagspikes spanning 15 seconds, if not longer.

This was sort of excusable in early access, but the game has been released since then.
From a gamedev perspective there have also been really odd choices regarding UI/UX among other things.

I want to reiterate that it is a ton of fun with all the things you can do, but i cannot recommend it currently due to the above issues at the asked price at all.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
Gmod Tower dono, early supporter of Tower Unite. I check in every now and then to see what has changed over the years, which isn't much. It's still a half baked laggy hive of furries and predators. 

It's so weirdly immature and highschool clique-esque (devs included) I feel I'm risking a ban by even leaving a negative review, but at this point I don't care. It appears to be a dead game to everyone except for people who have literally no other outlet for social interactions in their life. It is somehow more of an echo chamber than people on VRchat staring at a mirror. 

RIP to what this game could have been. I will mostly miss the arcade.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
This review is about the ability to play/host this game privately with a couple of friends rather than the game mechanics itself. See to other reviews if you don’t care about this.

Short version:
You cannot host a private plaza dedicated server like you used to, neither can you have a private session with your friends anymore. (You can however set your private condo to friends-only if you host from the game client from what I’ve understood)

Longer version:
As someone who used to play this game every day (not on this account) many years ago I was so excited to pick this up again seeing how much it had evolved over time only to find they’ve removed the ability to host a private plaza and have essentially forced most of the interactions into the public sphere. Their reasoning for doing this makes sense but it sounds more like an excuse rather than a justified reason because they could have made it so people who wishes to host a private game were simply forbidden from using these private characters and any asset on public servers. I understand this requires more work but having come from the time this game allowed this made it really disheartening to discover after my excitement. ☹

Maybe someday the developers will again grace us introverts with the ability to host our fully private version away from the public hoi polloi of business. Until then I cannot recommend this game for people like me.

Thanks for reading!

review_text:
I don't recommend this game due to the amount of snowflakes, and quite frankly weirdos that play it. The moderators / devs will mute, kick, ban you for literally having an opinion that does not match their weird ideology. The game is filled with NSFW condos with porn (inc. minors) which do not get banned and are openly promoted, with most players supporting these and getting very aggressive if you voice that you're against it, but are not punished as the devs support this, also allowing p*dos to play the game. But don't you worry! you could tell someone to shut up and a select group of NSFW obsessed players will @moderators and get you punished immediately! but if you're called names and harassed by creepy old men who prey on the young women in this game, thats fine, moderators / devs don't care about that!

The devs also are happy to ban certain players from speaking in game, messaging, hosting condos, etc which basically stops them from playing the game as it was advertised and meant to be played, which i am pretty sure is illegal but pop off i guess?

The only positive thing about this game for me is building in condos, which is the only thing i do on this game, anything else could get you banned in 5 seconds. New minigames have not been added to the game in a long time, and recent ones are quite frankly boring within one day, and for a game that is no longer considered early access you'd expect a lot more in it!

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

EDIT: I've seen a common theme, which I forgot to add to this review, and have continued to see this theme in the comments below of how the community needs to report the things that happen in this game and that we "cannot expect mods to be able to moderate the whole community". My response to this is, why can't we expect that? It's their job, right?, I don't see myself getting paid to go around reporting all the things wrong with this game, every other game manages to moderate their game themselves. Of course its ok for community to help report some issues, but, ultimately, its up to the moderators to do their jobs.

The moderators in this game are not clear on what is / isn't allowed in the game, and more often than not appear 'trigger happy' to punish players for very little things, such as my "censored by moderators" text message which according to devs deserved a timeout, while, at the same time thats happening, theres NSFW condos that are not being moderated with underaged content, its all well and good saying its not allowed in ToS, but its still happening?


----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

[h1]EDIT 2:[/h1]

Thanks for the reply, MacDGuy. 

You did respond to parts of what I raised in this review, but you also dodged the core issues I raised.

In relation to the Discord incident. You say the rules are “clearly written,” yet nowhere in those rules does it state that mentioning or advertising a banned user’s condo is against the rules. That was the exact reason my image was removed.
If this is a rule, please point to where it’s written.

Wheezher claimed the image was removed because the banned user had been removed from the game for creating an unsafe environment. Two problems with that:
The rules still don’t say anything about “no promoting a user after they’re banned.",
The user in question isn’t even banned; they are still active on the game.

I then re-posted the same image, this time censoring the advertisement and replacing it with “[censored by moderators].”
This was also not against the rules; it was satire. Staff simply didn’t like being playfully mocked and issued a 1 day time-out.

After my review went up, that 1-day suddenly became a 7-day ban.
Wheezher claimed it was “unrelated” due to a prior infraction, the fact that the ban duration wasn't updated until hours later highlights there's a lack of effective moderation tools, and the timing makes it look retaliatory for the negative review.

Why was the image actually removed, and why was the Discord time-out applied?
These questions remain unanswered, and your reply reads like a deflection.

If you are fine with allowing NSFW content on this game, you shouldn't need to rely on player reports; you should be able to moderate them by yourselves. This is the reason why no other game allows it.

Since my review has been up, I've received several strongly worded and aggressive comments in response. For new players or anyone considering this game, this is exactly what I raised in my review, and it really doesn't help to disprove that the community can create a hostile environment over the most trivial things. This is the same in the official Tower Unite Discord - if you voice an opinion that differs from others, you receive the exact same treatment. The moderation team seems to show a lot of bias when it comes to allowing/punishing this behaviour

This will be my final edit for this review, as I feel I have clearly stated my thoughts above. Thanks!

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
I think people have already pointed out plenty of issues with this game. 

I will not repeat those again and instead tell you about my own, personal gripes with Tower Unite.

I enjoy building in games. It is very fun and relaxing to me. I have been working on my condo (Your own personal home which you can decorate) piece by piece in the ~ 300 hours I played.

[u]However, the game actively fights you at every turn if you want to build. [/u]

I have had to deal with: 

-The game instantly closing itself when editing Condo IO objects.

-Condo IO objects not having any matching connection types (Imagine trying to change some lamp setting through an IO object and all you get is being asked if you'd like it turn invisible or visible instead of on or off.)

-Extreme host lag. If more than 8 people play on my condo, my game becomes a slide show.

-Removal of the undo button??

-Some items being precolored. This means that, if you place a table and want to color match it to a white wall and change its color in the wheel to white? Guess what! The base color of the table is brown and therefore can only be ugly tones of brown, making the colorwheel useless on these items.

-EXTREME inconsistency in artstyle and direction. Imagine trying to build a forest. You buy an assortment of trees. You go to place them and notice one tree is photo-realistic, one tree looks like plastic and another looks like it's from a cartoon style game. This will make your condo look like clown vomit within seconds. It is awful.

-Super limited textures for alterable items. Why only give me half the textures that this game even has?

-Constant glare. Some things in this game always look like plastic. Rocks have the look of painted styrofoam and damn near every wood texture shines like it's been waxed and polished. The worst offenders of this are metal items. These textures are straight up broken. Half of all items in the game that have any bits of metal on them at all appear as black voids unless you crank the lighting to painful degrees and then you get like mario 64 type metal blob looking things.

-Inconsistent pricing. You want wall bushes? 50 units. You want normal bush? 300. Some items cost so stupidly much that furnishing more elaborate places becomes a pain. Now I know you can farm money relatively easily in this game, but if you are like me and have played this in Gmod already, you are probably sick of these games. I am sick of Virus. I'm sick of Zombie Massacre and I'm so so sick of minigolf and the others. Making me play hundreds of hours of outdated minigames or sit down for 100 consecutive rounds of bingo so i can furnish my library with the chairs I like sucks. 

I could go on and on and on. My friends cant even play with me anymore because their modern day PCs shut down when trying to join my condo because of how badly this game runs. And what's the point of a social game where being social is the worst part? I wanna be social by building something cool and having people explore that. This game, however, forces me through many hundreds of hours of grind and hinders me with its inconsistent style and poor, small selection of items to do that. Instead I am meant to be social by playing the same Zombie Massacre map 50 times in a row so I can have enough cash to build. And why build if the game is so poorly optimised that fulfilling my artistic vision means crashing my and other's game upon trying to join? 


In the end...
It's just not fun. I really don't get it. A lot of the decisions this dev team has made puzzle me and insead of constantly adding more bloat to the game in the form of weird features like cooking (who asked for this???)  they should focus on fixing the code and tidying up their artstyles.

I don't get the hype behind it. It's so fast and twitchy, it annoys me. The gameplay's just not for me, I guess, I'm just surprised it is so universally praised.

Also GTFO outta here with your "Souls" bosses.

For a shooter that is supposed to be all about the SSStyle most enemies sure don´t react in any meaningful way to the majority of your shots. This means that the "player expression" is more of a facade than anything else as it pushes you to vary up your weapons for variety's sake and little else. The ranking is mostly superfluous aside from it helping with your hp regeneration, but even then the stylish part itself is not that engaging, at least in DMC, when you style on something you get to combo and lock down said enemies in the air as a result of your skills, but without significant stagger it loses much of its appeal.

Arena and boss design is similarly vapid due to this rigidity. With so little crowd control aside from the techniques to maximize dps, most enemy rooms turn into clusterfucks of projectiles where you spam the blood regen to tank the shots, and the bosses are mostly simplistic pattern memorization fights, where not even parries stops their onslaught, which makes such manoeuvres feel flaccid despite offering a lot of benefits in regenerating your health and dealing damage.

While not totally devoid of cool ideas as seen by the coin ricochets and some cool weapons, it is a game that has ridden more on its hype rather than the substance of its mechanics. The mark of amateurish design is to be seen everywhere, like how, for example, the game has secret collectables for you to pick up, but also simultaneously punishes you in your ranking for taking too long to explore the level. It is this lack of attention to detail and messy design that makes Ultrakill a gimmick rather than a true stepping stone for boomer shooters.

genres: Adventure, Casual, Massively Multiplayer, Simulation, Sports, Free To Play, Early Access
review_text:
VRChat is a platform of many extremes, and that is something that has to be accepted when playing, especially in public lobbies. I've personally had some of the most enjoyable times, enlightening conversations, and the closest connections I could've ever imagined. I've also seen some of the most vial, gross and downright reprehensible content spread here. It's a polarizing tugging of both ends of the spectrum. Vile language and frequent inappropriate content are frequent in public lobbies due to the lack of moderation. A good strategy is to get some close friends or a tightknit community to hang out with in private lobbies, and avoid public lobbies aside from most games. You should be fine then, but be prepared if something else should arise. The block button is a wonderful feature, and you should not be afraid to use it if someone is being offensive or reprehensible.

If you're a parent looking at reviews to get a gauge on if this game is okay for your kids, wait until they turn 18 for their own sake.
If you're a child thinking you're mature enough, you are not. Wait until your 18 for your own safety, and thank me later.
If you're over 18, You're an adult. Go in with an open mind, and you'll be surprised at some of the pleasant folk that wander some of the quieter corners of the community.

genres: Adventure, Casual, Massively Multiplayer, Simulation, Sports, Free To Play, Early Access
review_text:
VRChat is marketed as a **social VR platform where you make friends, explore worlds, and express yourself with custom avatars.**
In reality it’s:

> A multiverse where a hyper-real anime girl, a 2-polygon Shrek, and a 9-foot robot are all arguing in front of a mirror at 3 a.m.

You *can* use a VR headset… or just play in Desktop and experience 10% of the immersion and 200% of the social anxiety.

---

### Pros

* Thousands of community-made worlds: nightclubs, horror maps, movie theaters, flight sims, hangout rooms, McDonald’s roleplay, therapy couches, and a guy’s extremely detailed apartment for some reason.
* Fully custom avatars: anime, furry, robot, fridge, eldritch abomination, literal brick – if Unity can import it, someone is already using it as their personality.
* Lip sync, eye tracking, full-body tracking – you haven’t lived until you’ve seen someone in full mocap doing cursed Fortnite dances in a medieval tavern.
* VR *not* required, which is great if you want to stare at a mirror with strangers without putting on a headset.
* Social sandbox: people host talk shows, concerts, church, D&D sessions, group therapy, and also the weirdest parties you’ll never tell your parents about.

---

### Cons

* “Free to play” but not free from social chaos. Public lobbies range from wholesome to “I need to log off forever” in under 30 seconds.
* Performance: your PC is fine until someone loads in with a 400k-poly avatar with realtime reflections and 8K textures. Then it’s a slideshow.
* You join for “a quick look,” you leave 5 hours later after emotionally bonding with a British raccoon model named “Dave.”
* Safety filters, trust ranks, and content controls exist, but like any big social space, you still have to use the mute & block buttons like a gunslinger.
* If you get into avatar/world creation, say goodbye to your free time. It’s just you, Unity, and 47 compiler errors at 4 a.m.

---

### Peak VRChat Moments

* Joining a “chill hangout” world and walking straight into a full-blown courtroom roleplay in progress.
* Going to a horror map and bravely leading the group… until the first jumpscare, at which point you become background decoration.
* Accidentally wandering into a deep, heartfelt conversation about life with three people you will never see again, all dressed like cursed cereal mascots.
* Spending two hours in a mirror world doing nothing but talking, posing, and occasionally questioning how this became your main game.

---

**10/10**
Not really a game – more like an unmoderated multiverse convention where everyone brought their own body.
Would log in “just to check something,” wake up six hours later in a karaoke bar world singing off-key with a dozen anime robots again.

review_text: I can't say for playing with strangers, but i always have fun playing this with my friends and partners, and i love that there's always new worlds to explore, there's so many different worlds that even playing by myself is fun and how i often play, i have no experience with uploading worlds, but i've had decent luck uploading avatars using vroid, blender, unity, and vrchat's offical helper add-on/ app (i can't remember what it's called but it's on their website) though i definitely recommend watching some youtube videos for guides and extra help, all in all, i think vrchat is fun, i know many people have bad experiences playing online with strangers, unfortunately, in a lot of cases, you have to do your own moderating and make sure you block, and if necessary, report, people that are causing issues or harassing you or others, vrchat is a huge platform with countless players and the moderators can only keep up so well if people aren't actually using the in game reporting system

genres: Adventure, Casual, Massively Multiplayer, Simulation, Sports, Free To Play, Early Access
review_text:
VRChat is a social platform for everyone, provided "everyone" is a subset of people who own a full-body tracking suit and have decided their spirit animal is a neon-blue fox. The ratio is approximately 80% fluff to 20% existential crisis. 

If you stand still for too long, you will be adopted by a pack of digitally enhanced canine avatars. 

It's less a game and more an accidental, full-scale ecosystem designed to test the limits of your PC's shader capacity and your own tolerance for ear-splitting squeals.

If you are looking for a reminder that society is actively degrading and that technology merely provides us with new, more efficient ways to be miserable together, VRChat is perfect. It is a necessary, awful, and deeply honest reflection of who we are when there are no consequences.

review_text:
A good concept, but.... I ended up giving up. You have nothing to do there unless you're already with your private friends. People are asocial, it just doesn't make me wanting to return there.

Struggling to develop my review as all of my experiences have been bad there since the first time I tried, so I guess I will just give pros and cons.

[h3]Pros[/h3]
 • Be what you want as long as you have your model to import.
 • If you don't have your own model, many are available to get in game.
 • Playable on PC and VR.
 • Various worlds with many purposes, such as games, exploration, or a simple home to relax in.
 • Customization is almost limitless, but...

[h3]Cons[/h3]
 • ... extremely complexe to create and to setup, especially compared to competitors
 • Community is very closed. Don't join hoping meeting people. Join with your own friends.
 • SteamLink terribly unstable depending on setups.
 • Subscription options too much highlighted. It almost jumps to your eyes on the menu, and happens to appear on loading screens.

[h3]Subjective points[/h3]
 • None comes in mind, feels like experience is black or white (but mostly black)

[h3]Final note[/h3]
Since it's free, you can always give it a try and potentially spend time with your friends in there, but that's it.

Back in 2022 Vampire Survivors did not invent its genre but it did give it a major boost in popularity, now there are numerous Survivor-likes everywhere.
But back thern  its content was pretty damn anemic.

A big part of the major content that has been introduced since then can be found in the DLCs, but there were also plenty of updates to the base game.

The result of this is that there is at least something to do in this game unlike many lesser titles.
There is a sizable number of unlocks, a clear progression path of what to do and unlock next, many different stages with some unique gimmicks and plenty of hidden secrets.

If you go for full completion you will be busy for a while and even if you arent then the variety can be entertaining for a while.

That said, this is still the game that survivor-likes come from and therefor does not innovate upon the genre.
For the most part it really is just the same eternal loop of pickung up a few weapons and upgrading them until the entire screen explodes and the game becomes hard to look at.
You can do this with many different characters and weapons now but the result and gameplay will always be the same.

But there is a reason this genre got popular and its 5 bucks without a sale, just give it a try, you will at least get a few hours out of it.

This game feels like a side mode to a bigger game. there was games like this (side modes) as an afterthought to just mess around with. after you beat the main campaign. the gamkic  of this game is playing the same stages over and over...until you unlock new stuff. if there was a story that goes along with it, then ok. but there's not, heck even arcade games had a little story in them. and you keep moving forwarded. you feel like the game is progressing in the plot. i wasn't feeling it after 4 mins of playing. but i gave it a 2 hour and 30 min try. the characters are just way too slow. i played a clone of this game before..i loved it. it played way faster and i prefer the gameplay of that one. but i'm not feeling this one. different things for different people. there's no filters or graphic options too. so i can't make the game look prettier. i wish the game was faster, gave out rewards quicker (the progress felt so slow), and not having to unlock dlc characters (i already paid for) behind a so many tasks. imagine if a fighting game did this? people would be so mad, heck, any other game. we're welling to pay for dlc characters because we want them now. not paying for them and having to do an ungodly amount of task to unlock them. replaying the same stages in different ways to unlock them.

Poncle, I love your game, I bought it for 3 of my friends and we have all your DLC.

While we all understand the new online mode is exactly what it is; NEW. There are many a problem we face. 

Opening chests during late games will cause all of us in the game to be hung up and nobody can open the chest forcing one or all of us to ALTF4 and reboot the game.

This has been an ongoing thing for the past 4 days as I post this comment so it's not a one time thing to complain about.

Three times just on the night I am sending this, our game has frozen during online play and while all our Survivors could move. we could not interact with floor drops, pause or see the other players move at all, all while being immune to damage and dealing none to the enemies.

Once again, I love your game and understand that the function is NEW so I can't bitch too much, I just want to inform you and others reading that this is a problem we are facing at the moment.

Thank you very much for readin

I have no idea what I'm supposed to do to progress. Knowing who to use or what stage to complete for the next unlock you need to continue in the game itself is completely unclear.

You can unlock stages well before you have the upgrades to beat them. Exclamation points draw you to stages that have seemingly no objective left to complete.

And worst of all, every match either feels too easy or is frustratingly impossible. You can either walk the map with impunity, as if there were no mobs spawning around you, or you're being hopelessly overwhelmed and were doomed from the start, regardless of choice and skill.

I'm sorry. I really, really tried to like Vampire Survivors, but I can't. The early game isn't engaging in the slightest.
I really can't understand how this "dopamine simulator" is supposed to be hooking me when I've spent the past hour watching my character attack the air for me at a snail's pace.

Yes, I tried getting the upgrades. I upgraded Might, like, four times, just as the guides told me. But *I* still get mowed down because my Fire Wand decided to shoot at some borderline invincible zombie instead of the crowd of bats, or my five knives just don't do enough damage. I thought I was the one supposed to be doing the mowing!

When I *do* get kills, all the XP ends up pooling within a cluster of enemies that I have to spend what, in this game, feels like a purgatory sentence just to herd everyone away from the loot.
And when I finally get there, I can only pick up a good 30% of the orbs before the horde catches up with me and forces me to run away again. This whole time, I'm flailing two whips around while the bad guys pool everywhere except where my hitboxes are.

I also don't get how casino noises make this game a "gambling simulator," as I've seen some say. In the hour I played, I didn't notice any RNG come up once.
Fire Wand doesn't count.

You guys have fun, but I don't care what the trailers and end game builds look like. I'm not going to make myself wade through another grinding chore when I can just get my $3.something back and buy my TF2 Medic another obnoxious hat, or something.

[B]I find Vampire Survivors to be an offline equivalent to a live service in that it's incredibly addictive for the right people and there’s so much content & secrets that you’ll always have something to chase. The developers continue to add content (free & paid DLC) so those that enjoy the title will have even more to play with time if this practice continues.[/b]

I would begrudgingly recommend Vampire Survivor's to roguelike fans with the disclaimer that the game is slow & tactile (in regards to movement as the game attacks for you) before evolving whilst degrading into an addicting & stimulating AFK power fantasy built around discovering & merging specific items together.

[I]A few notes before elaboration as to why I did not recommend Vampire Survivors.[/I]

[list]
[*]Combat plays itself, you move around avoiding the AI while positioning yourself so that your weapons can hit them.

[*]The meat of the game comes from weapon fusions & the power fantasy of killing hordes without being hit, something that is rarely possible at the start.

[*]Runs are always restricted to 30 minutes with few exceptions or until you unlock an endless gamemode.

[*]Menu & UI elements have to be unlocked via gameplay including a progression guide (Unlocks), a bestiary (it lacks clear information of enemy weaknesses), Permanent upgrades (health, luck, speed etc.), Arcanas (Modifiers), Gamemodes (Hyper (Sped up gameplay), Endless, Inverted (Flipped map)) & more.

[*]There are a lot of items, characters & secrets that require dedicated playtime to unlock & earn new weapons. This can make progression feel like a slog as you're required to play unfun characters.
In regards to fusing weapons, unless you have external sources helping, numerous runs boil down to 15 minutes of trial & error.

[*]The UI fails to provide clear & necessary information during runs including how weapons/stats interact with upgrades, their names, strength, effects and more importantly for late game, how they interact with other weapons(fusion). Not to mention that during mid-late game runs the UI & enemies are blown out by the weapon effects, so they become hidden amongst the effects.

[*]Despite the large item/weapon list, character choice rarely matter & builds homogenise after a few hours of play, even more so if you use the optional egg buff mechanic (but that's up to player choice).

[*]As you gain more weapons & passives in a run, the actual gameplay devolves into standing AFK while Area of Effect strikes wipe the board and there's very little movement/gameplay involved unless you select specific characters you may not enjoy.

[*]p.s. You can skip case openings by pressing ESC on your keyboard but it won’t skip for super lucky crates. (This is more of a PSA if you play the game).
[/List]

[H2] Elaboration [/H2]
[H3]Progression & Information Clarity[/H3]
Game/Progression direction drops off a cliff at some point and while there is an Unlock tab in the menu & this is your guide on what you're supposed to do besides survive in a level, they are vague which is fine but after at a certain point it's too vague to be reasonable without third party assistance. This mostly occurs around the time you reach Capella Magna for the first time as a result of certain characters being ineligible for “story” progress or being able to trigger the unlock requirements for further progression; those being Mortaccio, Cavallo, Ramba, O’Sole & Ambrojoe.
 
[H3]Characters[/H3]
The large roster of characters despite having stat variance play the same and are essentially hosts to their starting weapon, your selection of character will depend on the weapon more than the character. Certain characters are better than the rest as a result, Pugnala & her dual welding pistols, the priest & his bible, Cleric & the holy water have staple weapons that provide Area of Effect and strength starting you closer to endgame while characters like Krochi & his axe or the starting characters are mono target strikers that have you praying for AoE weapons at level up.

The mid-late game characters are more interesting by having additional properties alongside their weapons like Cavallo’s scaling projectiles or they have risky pay offs like Giovanna’s self-harming Cats that scale based on item consumption (none of which is explained in game).

External assistance (wiki’s, guides etc.) are near mandatory for mid-late progression and the starting map is more difficult than the later maps.
 
[H3]Weapons[/H3]
Weapon unlocks, they are fun to stumble upon during your multiple runs but if you're trying to figure out a combination without using third party sources it can take numerous 10+ minute runs. I understand "Fail to learn" is the name of the game but unlike enemy pathing & understanding how different weapons are helpful in the early game, the evolution system is just a nuisance.

Weapon combinations which is the meat of the power fantasy require an asinine amount of fails runs to work out given the amount of items & weapons in the game. The game auto attacks for you so gameplay comes down to tactical positioning & movement but after unlocking new items & purchasing account upgrades, movement becomes irrelevant as after the 10-20 minute mark gameplay to devolves into undecipherable full visual effects, afking & screen wipes; all of which obscure the UI, enemies & map.
 
The early game Weapons, passives & account upgrades are gained through failed & successful runs with respective characters, which is fine given Vampire Survivor’s is a roguelike but the early characters & their associated weapons suck to play with in more than just player strength as the starting character weapons aren’t sustainable and the reliance on a specific weapon (garlic) is near mandatory until later options are unlocked. Basically you’ll spend around 20 minutes with a character you don’t like to unlock their weapon which is required to get a sustainable version of itself or another.
 
[H3]Secrets[/H3]
Uncovering secrets and completing quests aka “Unlocks” can either be reasonable or asinine. Best case scenario you unlock the progression or UI items on each map as you progress like the unlock screen, map, bestiary, grimoire (weapon fusion guide) etc. that reveal unlocks, items, characters & a few secrets on the map.

Worst case scenario you miss them or you unlock & use a character (that’s not explained in game) that is ineligible for “story” events, so you follow the poorly explained unlock screen, complete levels, survive the full 30 minute level duration multiple times, obtaining weapons & items and fuse them together only to find out you have to use another character to progress & unlock new game modes, items, characters & more.

with little to no hints on how to achieve them without external assistance or prolonged playtime linked to specific items that unlock basic UI elements.

After the latest update, the max item slots in couch coop were reduced from 4 to 2 per player. This completely breaks the balance and progression for duo play. How are we even supposed to reach the Grim Reaper (30-minute mark) with only 2 upgrades? Some weapons (like Peachone and Ebony Wings) are already useless early on without evolving, and now evolution is basically impossible because you can’t hold both needed weapons. (Maybe with Exdash but do I need cheatcodes to progress?)

I started playing this game with another person, and we wanted to unlock everything only by playing duos. We put around 10 hours in - having fun, progressing steadily - then suddenly there’s an update, and this massive change hits without any mention in the patch notes. No explanation, no reasoning. Our progress didn’t just slow down - it pretty much died.

I’m not interested in using cheat codes or having one player sit out just so the other can unlock things. Why even make coop mode if you’re going to cripple it like this?

I saw people saying online that you can “unlock Party Mode” from the West Wood map by gambling with someone \ but what even is West Wood? Where do you unlock it? Can I even reach that point playing duo with only 2 item slots each? Also a bit separate matter but the Wiki is zero help with anything regarding couch coop.

To make it worse, the game now crashes around the 25-minute mark since this same update. What even changed in the base game if the update was only supposed to add online coop? 

All in all, this update feels rushed, untested, and uncommunicated. Vampire Survivors used to be a so fun in couch coop but now it's just unplayable.

The new online update sucks. You can't help each other unlock stuff; you are essentially just a helper in battle. If you want to unlock a weapon or character, you essentially have to do it twice for both of you, but on couch co-op it works like it's supposed to. When I did that, I could unlock multiple things at once and only needed to do it one time.

I'm voting Vampire Survivors down not because it's inherently bad (it's okay), but because it locks your PAID DLC behind having to work to unlock them in-game. 

In other words, you pay real money to get the DLC and characters, and to access your paid content, you have to "work for it" or you don't get it. 

I could understand that if this were free DLC, but most of the DLC requires you to purchase it. Making people spend money and then spend their free time just so they can then play what they bought is completely unacceptable. 

Now I know some people are going to think, "It's easy to unlock! Just spend several hours at it." These are same knuckle-dragging dudebros who'll consider this review "funny" and/or give me a "jester" award. 

First off, I don't want to spend my free time "working" at something that's supposed to be entertainment. If I work, I get paid. I don't pay to work. 

Second, this is a game that's been marketed as a quick "jump in, play, jump out" title. That means I shouldn't have to dedicate a lot of time to do anything. 

Third and most importantly, they're missing the point. If I pay for something, I expect it handed over immediately, end of story.

I think it's official -- I like this more than Slay the Spire. There's a little more depth in terms of clear synergy strategies, and that becomes fun to think about. I also like the clarity of knowing what kinds of boss challenges are ahead to inform a deck build.

Shiny Shoe delivers again. If you enjoyed Monster Train or any other roguelike deckbuilders, you are going to enjoy this one too. The soundtrack in particular is quite an improvement! 

Apart from that, most of the initial problems (e.g. old clans not having room and equipment cards) have been adressed and the game is actively improved by free updates. Looking forward to any DLCs!

However, if you are looking for real difficult challanges comparable to StS A20 Heartruns or similar, you will be dissapointed. The game lacks a bit for the real brainians that like to spend hours on a run. With some experience, most runs will feel solved after the first couple of rings. There are some "cursed seeds" that challenge you more, but you have to join some discord groups to find them.

Similar to Slay the Spire, the gameplay is well constructed and fun, with different reasons you might replay it time and again if you enjoy the card battles.

That said, once I beat both this and Slay the Spire multiple times with different starter decks/mechanics, there really isn't much left in the way of new things to do. The lack of any really interesting story also makes it feel a tad hollow. Get on a deep sale for a decent distraction.

[b]Score: 8/10[/b]
[list]
	[*][b]Art Style:[/b] The art direction is solid and cohesive, with detailed card designs and distinctive unit visuals. While the overall aesthetic might not appeal to everyone, it fits the game’s theme effectively and maintains visual clarity even during the most hectic battles.
	[*][b]Music:[/b] The soundtrack is quite good. There are memorable and entertaining themes that enhance the experience, even if they don’t all stand out individually for extended listening.
	[*][b]Story:[/b] Very basic story. The narrative serves as a light framing device rather than a deep or meaningful journey.
	[*][b]Gameplay:[/b] Strong variety of characters (clans) and deck-building options. The core idea is original and fun. That said, some combinations aren’t very well balanced, which can affect fairness and replayability.
[/list]

Just got Monster Train on sale in 2025 and immediately hooked the Steam Deck up to the giant TV to hyper-size and slightly blur the graphics. I don't think this has quite the complexity or difficulty of Slay the Spire, but there are enough unlockables and new clans to play as that it kept me playing for quite a while.

If you haven't played this yet and are looking for a deck-builder that's quick to pick up and hard to put down, this is a good option.

Being a roguelite deckbuilder, it is very similar to Slay the Spire in gameplay. But unlike StS where several less than perfect choices can easily ruin your run, Monster Train focuses on forging yourself into an unstoppable powerhouse.

The interesting concept of mixing two clans creates multitudes of unique synergies. Game-breaking combinations exist in droves and it is up to you to experiment and discover them.

This game is not as tightly balanced than StS, with many runs highly dependent on luck. There is always randomness to games like this, but it sometimes feels nigh impossible to optimize your choices to find a way to win. Nonetheless, for a casual player like me, successfully amassing exodia in my deck and steamrolling all foes is still exhilarating as ever.

Monster Train is a very, very good game. It's inferior in most aspects to Slay the Spire, although not in all. Design wise it's heavily leaning toward combinations - less cards per ensemble, but out of the box ability to combine two ensemble that is not just a quasi-gimmick like the prismatic shard in Slay the Spire but actually designed for that. Similarly the playing board has extra dimensions - floors, numbers of entities on both sides - while the card play itself is more limited (although still very much existent and deep). Art is nothing remarquable although it's reasonably pleasant. Music is catchy. While I prefer StS on all of those aspects, it's a matter of taste. What is not though is the fact that the UI is way less polished/well thought than Slay the Spire, by far my biggest issue with the game. It's nothing disastrous but coming from StS, oof. Issues include inability to see the whole board at once (for no reasons other than aresthetic at the -severe- expense of clarity and responsiveness - a major crime shared by Inkulinati, who thinks those constant zoom in zoom out are any good? Jesus.), discard UI that has the wrong trajectory for card pick making discarding the wrong one the default results if you don't circle around things, an enthousiasm for playing card you released 34 thousands mile away from away from a floor after deciding you didn't want to play it on that floor (which it absolutely will nonetheless). In general they were many other things that could have been done but weren't so that the information was less bloated. Lots of numbers without bars, lack of hierarchy in the tool tips... make it very easy to miss informations and give up on learning by the game rule, instead just trying stuff. Which is... doable but StS precisely shown that you could be *actually playing* the game from the first minute, having all the information you need to make decisions. 

It does share a cons with StS which is no undo/restart the fight but it's vastly more problematic because of the above, the facts that a lot of the time you have to play shit to simply get the rule the tool tip wasn't 100% clear about etc. Nothing bad in itself but it's a bit dumb to have to quit to the main menu en re enter the game to restart it. 
While this all may sound negative let me reiterate this is down the line a brilliant game though. It's *extremely* catchy, packed with interesting mechanics and a solid execution of those. The cost in money is nothing here, it's more about how willing you are to put your finger in the cogs and get eaten by the game. Although from what I understand the endgame isn't eternal like StS, but it sure is hundreds of hours of great fun. Unquestionably worth buying.

Monster Train 2 abandons a lot of what I loved about the first game, and what's left is... fine. There's nothing really new here, but you'll get more Monster Train out of it.

It's probably not the main thing most people cared about, but the previous game had genuinely good writing, interesting and varied character designs, the interesting worldbuilding, factions with internal diversity that still maintained thematic coherence, and carefully varied mechanics that allowed for a wide variety of solutions to every game problem, allowing you to feel clever when you pulled off a particularly niche or non-obvious build. This game offers none of that - it does have more spectacle, it has bigger numbers, everyone's power level is through the roof, but the vibe, to me, the bits that tie it all together, is just... gone.  The writing quality is through the floor, the careful and surprisingly deep worldbuilding of the previous game replaced with "lolrandom" humour, and a lot of it is just completely undercooked or not well thought out. The power scaling and powers make everything *extremely* swingy, as well.

This is even reflected in less obvious elements like the UI (which is often missing important information - it doesn't even say what the faction leaders do anymore, and information about their lore is well hidden) and the artwork in general (which looks like it was done by several different artists who didn't collaborate much).

Let's compare factions, for a second, by looking at the wealth-based factions. In the old game, it was the Melting Remnant, a section of hell that believed that the melting away of wax released the soul, and was split into two factions, the pious and orderly class of devotees and priests who tended to their flames, and the uncouth street toughs who lived for material wealth, represented by a burning priest wielding two maces and empowering others with his leadership and an eternally young street urchin willing to fight and die as many times as it could to win. They even had their own section of the map you passed through on your journey.

The Monster Train 2 equivalent is the Pyreborn, a faction of dragons, with two leaders - the greedy skinny dragon and his wife the greedy fat dragon who makes fun of him for being poor despite being obsessed with money (in cutscenes)and who are both actively disinterested in the cause for which they fight.

It's a fine game, but unless you've played the first one into the dirt, it offers nothing that isn't done better previously.

What started out as a fun game ended up as a game where I lose 9 out of 10 times due to the game increasing the difficulty curve after each win. You need to scale super hard which in turn requires you to be lucky enough to get the correct combo cards offered in each pack. That coupled with unbalanced clans and heroes decreases fun and replayability, especially because wins feel like they were only possible because you got lucky.

Each time you win, the games makes it a little bit "harder" for you to win, however every addition is so minor even after those add up you can counteract them pretty easily as well.

For example when starting a run at higher "Difficulty" a lot of trash cards get added to your deck, the simplest way it to mark the unwanted cards with freeze, or simply remove them, there are such solutions for most things in the game like this, knowing what abilites the Bosses have before facing them makes this more strategic but also yet again easier.

In the moment of writing slay the spire has 97/100 and this has 96/100, in that one percent there is a lot of quality. Monster train plays (and looks) like a generic mobile game. Monster train is one of the easier card games and is probably great if you have little or no experience with this kind of game but it will offer a veteran player nothing but dull disappointment.

I find myself unenthused by the design philosophies of Monster Train. I've played 4 runs, all with different faction combinations; won 3 with minimal resistance, always playing on the maximum difficulty the game would allow.

All runs seem to revolve around creating a "perpetual motion machine" with your deck, I.E. a set of cards you can rapid fire with little thought while watching numbers balloon to absurd and broken heights, and then as each stage draws to a close, hope the numbers have increased sufficiently to survive the end boss. If they haven't, there's next to nothing you can do anyway, but that rarely even comes close to happening.

Maybe I've been spoiled by the Culdcept series, but the variety of cards and the breadth of possible strategies seems severely lacking, and while there's some enjoyment to be had picking and choosing options for the deck, actually playing it is pretty dull. Each run goes for about 4 hours, and I feel it should have been 1/4 that much. The game expects you to do A LOT of grinding. It "unlocks" new features with a glass dropper, and the new features do little to spark interest anyway.

That somber, melancholic world theme clashes really heavily with the cartoonish/goofy/mobile shovelware art style of the game, and just the thought of having to listen to that song again makes me not want to play.

It's not a bad game, just not one to my liking. It's got too many mechanics, which at first may seem like a good thing, but it ends up being overwhelming. The other thing that put me off it is that balance is all over the place; things scale too much too fast and the deck-building aspect of the game ends up being unimportant. Only in the first few battles you'll have to think strategically how to use your resources to defeat the enemy but it really won't matter much since numbers are low and they'll barely do any damage to your Pyre (the thing you have to protect which one-shots any low-level monster that gets near it), while by the middle of the run the enemies can knock you fast if you don't have the right cards to stop them. In a run you'll have 20-30 cards in your deck but your actual build will be just one or two overpowered monsters that you keep using the same buffs on one over and over or triggering the same effect over and over.

Then there's the artifacts, which are also unbalanced af, some give you a minor situational buff, or help with certain cards which you may or not get more that one or two of, and there's others that pretty much win the run for you, like the one that instantly summons four of your monsters on the first turn regardless of cost or size - I already got that artifact twice in ten or so runs and it makes it virtually impossible to lose. I haven't even unlocked all the factions but I expect them to play similar or introduce more mechanics that end up not mattering or being completely broken.

I feel about this game the same way I feel about Balatro, another overwhelmingly positive rated game that lost it's appeal after a few hours when I realized it's all about doing the same thing over and over again, getting op powerups and watching the numbers get bigger and bigger, eschewing any need for strategy or careful planning. People love that shit.

It is short the endgame is stupid.

The RNG is balanced in the beginning but by the end the tolerances are just too narrow for the sheer amount of variance.

Good effort, bad results.

It's not like this is a bad game by any means, the game is quite polished and has a very interesting concept.
So why do I not recommend it?

That's because the gameplay feels kinda off in a lot of places, making the overall experience feel quite unsatisfying. To give a quick overview of how a run goes without getting into details: You select a primary and allied clan to play with, determining your starting cards, and then the game is a loop of choosing 1 of 2 paths to use all shops, events, etc... on that path, fight a group of enemies in an encounter and repeat until you beat the final boss. An encounter sees wave after wave of enemies start on the bottom floor and make their way up the train to attack your core.

1. Upgrades are too impactful. As an example, one of the weakest upgrades for spells is "+10 spellpower", if you apply this to a damaging spell, it causes that spell to do 10 extra damage. The "problem" is that your starting damaging spells will likely be something like "deal 2 damage", so this "weak" upgrade straight up makes that spell 6 times as powerful. These big and easy powerspikes result in making getting stronger feel pretty unsatisfying. Other games in the roguelike genre, typically have upgrades be more gradual, like slay the spire for example, where you can upgrade a 5-damage strike into an 8-damage strike+.

2. Enemies jump in strength too quickly. This goes hand-in-hand with the 1st point, because the problem isn't that enemies outscale you, the problem is that they need to get big jumps in strength in order to keep up with your uprades, but this does very quickly invalidate your non-upgraded cards. overall it contributes to this unsatisfying feel the game has. Also, within a wave itself enemies differ wildly, one enemy will have 95 health, and the enemy right behind them will have 4, the idea is that the lower health enemies are easy to kill, but hard to reach, so it does make sense from a balancing pov, yet it still contributes to this unsatisfying feeling I've been talking about.

3. Enemies move too quickly. Each round, every ally and enemy on each floor will attack once, and then the enemies move up to the next floor, if they reach the 4th floor, they'll start damaging your core. So your goal is to build a defense that's able to kill each wave of enemies before they reach the top. My problem however, is that combat feels way too short, each ally will only get 1 attack round on each enemy wave, and vice versa, this again isn't a problem from a balancing perspective, but it ends up feeling unsatisfying.
Luckily, the final boss of each encounter does stay on their current floor until all your troops or they are defeated. Getting to test your defenses in a fight to the death is definitely the highlight of each encounter, but it also makes me wish that the rest of the encounter (which takes up the majority of your time), was more like it.

I don't think the game has actual balancing issues, yet every time I win a run, it felt unsatisfyingly easy, and every time I lost a run, it just felt unavoidable.

[h1]It has less agency during fights than StS[/h1]

Once you play a unit on a certain floor, that's it, you can't play the unit again this fight (except if you upgrade that card with a special rune) and you can't move the unit to other floors (except with spells). The only other choices you get regarding that unit is whether you play other units in front or behind and whether you play spells on it. 

After all the units have been played, you're cycling through the cheap spells, waiting for the better spells to draw. 

[h1]Waiting out bossfights is wasting the your time[/h1]

When all waves are cleared and the boss enters the first floor, units will repeatedly take turns hitting each other, until either your units are dead or the boss is dead. There is nothing you can do, besides watch. This is so stupidly boring, that the game teaches you to use the fast forward button during the tutorial. There's no point in watching, since you can't influence it in any way. 

These two designpoints render everything else the game does well, irrelevant.
Music is good, boss gimmicks are neat, challenges are good, menu animations are quick, gameplay mechanics are reasonably readable. 

But I don't recommend it.

AMAZING Game, maybe 7 or 8/10 for new players, but definitely a 10/10 if you spend the time to really learn the game.
No game I have ever played goes as in depth for so many different systems and mechanics that all intersect beautifully. The movement is top-notch, the melee combat smooth and satisfying, the gunplay is very fun and responsive, the wide array of different Warframes to play as are individually unique and in-depth, and the upgrades systems for each are also very in-depth and compliment eachother well. The story and lore of Warframe, while it may seem very minimal in the earlier hours of the game, is a major part of my personal enjoyment of the game.
The biggest downside of the game, however, is the earliest hours of the game. The game itself does not do a very good job at teaching new players how the upgrades and damage systems work, and will require a LOT of time either researching on the Wiki, or being taught by veteran players. That being said, Digital Extremes have been including ways to streamline the path of the new player with their recent updates to the game such as adding a new quest that teaches new players about how to mod their weapons to deal specific damage types.
Warframe also has the most positive and new-player friendly community I have ever been a part of. Veterans of the game (myself included) are very eager and happy to teach new players how to do everything that the game itself struggles to teach. But also be aware, there is a toxic side of the community, while it is small, they have become a little louder since people from the Destiny 2 community are migrating to the Warframe community.

Warframe — Rise of the Tenno Across the Stars

Warframe throws you into a breathtaking galaxy teeming with conflict, mystery, and opportunity. Every mission, from stealthy infiltrations to high-octane battles, challenges players to master movement, timing, and strategy while navigating ever-changing environments.

Combat is exhilarating and precise. Each Warframe offers a distinct playstyle, and chaining abilities, acrobatics, and weapon combos turns even standard encounters into thrilling spectacles. Elite missions and boss fights push players to think creatively and execute flawlessly, rewarding skill and adaptability.

Exploration is expansive and engaging. Open-world hubs, hidden corridors, and procedurally generated events encourage curiosity and experimentation. Frequent updates, limited-time events, and new missions ensure the experience remains fresh for both newcomers and veterans alike.

Progression is rich and satisfying. Upgrading weapons, unlocking Warframes, and customizing builds provides meaningful growth. Cooperative multiplayer adds depth, allowing squads to combine powers and strategies for devastating effect, while solo players can also tackle challenges with careful planning and mastery.

Visually, Warframe captivates with detailed sci-fi landscapes, fluid animations, and spectacular particle effects. The soundtrack and immersive sound design enhance the intensity of every mission, making exploration and combat feel cinematic and alive.

Final verdict:
Warframe is a thrilling, ever-evolving adventure that blends speed, strategy, and skillful combat. With endless customization, deep progression, and dynamic multiplayer, it offers a galaxy of challenges for any player willing to master its systems.

"A fast, fluid, and endlessly exciting journey through a galaxy of combat and discovery."

If you like grind this is the game for you.
You can pay real money to buy mods/frames/weapons from the market but you can grind for them relatively easily. The game is PVE so if you still consider it p2w then thats that.
The gameplay is fun, the shooting feels good and weapons feel unique and impactful. 
You feel the progress for every upgrade you make.
Since this is a grind game, you need to grind to progress which may render progress static if you dont grind daily.
Stages are repetitive but the game offers a variety of game modes you can choose from. 
The game is volatile against internet instability and will isolate you in missions that require a team to finish but you can not really blame the game for that.
Crafting stuff in this game has a timer than can go from few minutes to 3 days max. Obviously you can skip the timer using the currency you buy with real money or by selling stuff in the market. Its bad that the game needs to make money that way and through cosmetics but at least there are a lot of things you can do while waiting for your things to be crafted.
The game has limited slots for everything, so if you think you are going to collect all frames thinks again because you will need to buy slots every now and then with currency you get using real money or by selling stuff in the market. However, slots are relatively cheap and as a f2p you will get a lot by selling stuff on the market. 
Unfortunately, the market is saturated with paying players that everything is relatively cheap, thats good if you want to buy but terrible if you are a f2p and thats the only way you can get currency. 
You can get cosmetics with currency or you can use currency to buy useful things for your build or slots. So cosmetics are the luxury of paying players even though f2p can still use currency in large amounts to buy cosmetics.
So in a nutshell, this game is f2p friendly, it offers shortcuts for people who pay but you can still get everything through grinding.
If you don't like grinding, this game will feel like its locking progress behind mundane chores since what you will be caring about are the rewards.
