Great Battle Royale game with high tension.

When the Battle Royale genre came to market, I played a couple of them. After PUBG, which I found fun for a while, but eventually bored me, Apex Legends hit the scene and it was an amazing experience.

In Apex Legends, you start in a team (with friends or random people) and choose a character and class. Each class has its own starting layout and proficiencies and, depending on the play style, can really make the difference between winning or losing.

An epic cutscene plays in which you are dropped from a plane, and while descending, you can choose where on the map to land. On your drop, you can also see the spread out other players, so you can determine somewhat how close they are going to be. After landing, you can explore a giant map in search of new weapons, enemies and gear.

Every so often, the playable area gets smaller and running into other players will be more likely by the minute. The tension is great and with each passing second, the chance for victory or annihilation gets closer. In the end, the combat arena is not bigger than a living room in a house and the combat en tension rises to a whole new level. It is them or you.

Apex Legends looks great. The huge map, the forests, the water, character models and color pallet, it is beautiful to look at. For me, the way the game looks, really enhanced my experience and made me choose this game over other Battle Royale games in the genre.

In terms of sound, the game is also outstanding. The glorious battle music at the start, the ambient, threatening tracks when exploring the map, it is just great.

The overall atmosphere of the game feels like a whole crowd of fans and supporters is watching. It has some sort of “Super Bowl vibe” if that makes sense. Sure, players who have been eliminated can watch you struggle (or die) but most move on to another game, which makes sense. Still, Apex Legends has this appeal.

I really liked the overall setting of the game. The action, the constant alertness of your surroundings, finding cool stuff, the adrenaline rush combat when you turn around a corner and the enemy is standing there, and one time, I even won the match with my team and I felt like a God.

The game is, of course, most fun to play with friends and the coordination and teamwork is just great. You are playing a video game, but it feels like you are in the army.

My only personal problem with Battle Royale games like this, is that you find a lot of cool stuff, get one-shotted in the head, and the game is over. This has nothing to do with the game, it is just how it is played, but I always get a little bumped out over building up something cool and strong, and then lose it all in a second.

Overall, I think Apex Legends is a great game and I would recommend it to everyone.

Path of Exile is nothing short of a masterpiece in the action RPG genre, offering players an unparalleled experience that combines depth, complexity, and engagement. The game excels with its vast character customization options, particularly through the intricate passive skill tree and the unique skill gem system, allowing players to create truly personalized builds that cater to their playstyle. The dark, immersive world of Wraeclast is rich with lore and filled with challenging enemies and epic loot, making exploration feel rewarding and exhilarating. The frequent updates and expansions demonstrate the developers' commitment to constantly evolving the game, introducing new mechanics, leagues, and content that keep the community excited and engaged. Additionally, the game’s free-to-play model is executed flawlessly, offering a fair experience without pay-to-win elements, making it accessible for everyone. Overall, Path of Exile stands as a benchmark for what an online RPG can achieve, combining deep mechanics, a thriving community, and an expansive world into a consistently rewarding adventure that sets a high standard in the genre.

The only downside of PoE is the barrier of entry for new players. Being such a complex game, with years of deep complex, and meaningful systems accumulated, the game can be quite intimidating for new players. But I can guarantee that if you like the genre and keep playing past the initial learning curve, you will not be disappointed. The character progression and build creation potential are honestly almost endless, and this paired with a solid campaign and an AMAZING (and almost a bit addictive) endgame array of options, makes this my all-time favourite game to play continuously.

I’ve now played POE 2 for over 90 hours, and I’m completely disappointed. The only aspects that make the game remotely interesting are the graphics and the skill tree. The regular mobs on the maps are generally no challenge at all. Bosses simply spam countless AOE attacks and throw trash mobs at you. There’s no noteworthy mechanic or significant challenge behind the boss fights. They just deal massive damage and have an endless health pool. When it’s supposed to be “especially difficult,” the boss room is artificially shrunk until you’re forced to fight an AOE-spamming boss in a tiny square, or they use damage types against which it’s nearly impossible to have sufficient **** 1 is far more entertaining and enjoyable to play. In this case, it feels like they tried to create a Dark Souls **** my opinion, POE 2 doesn’t deserve any attention, and the price for early access to a free-to-play game is outrageous, especially since you’re not really getting anything special for it. Sure, let the test players pay for the privilege of being test **** sum up POE 2 in bullet points:Boring mapsAbsurdly stupid boss fightsZero innovationExtremely long farming due to almost no useful gear dropsMindless grindAcceptable graphics but poor performanceThe game isn’t worth a single cent! If you’re considering buying it, I can only advise against it. Wait until it’s free to play.

It's an insult (especially in the age of Overwatch 2) to call this game a clone, especially if you're aware of the development cycle and timeline of both games. But I do feel that I have to mention that first, due to the image the game has and how much that oversimplification has harmed the game's reputation.

This game honestly feels infinitely more balanced than OW foundationally. OW forces you to play certain team comps, on certain maps, with each character usually having a single viable playstyle with little room to budge. Paladins offers tons of playstyles for each character through options like talents, in-game store abilities (think MOBAs, not actual cash stores), and even a loadout system using deckbuilding to sway your characters skills to your playstyle, optimizing exactly how you play.

Overwatch is such a frustrating experience because of how thin its meta is and how you're forced into certain playstyles and comps. If you don't follow them, you're going to get steamrolled. If you play support or tank and don't have reliable teammates, you're going to get steamrolled since you can't manage enough to defend yourself. Paladins gives you the option to play your role and hold your own when you need.

This game is not an Overwatch clone, it is better. You have options, you're not limited in how you can play characters, and while you probably aren't going to win without solid teamwork, you can at least have more freedom to sway the game in your direction and keep yourself alive by fighting back.

*Destiny 2* is a sequel that expands and refines the experience of the original game, taking players on an epic journey across the galaxy to save humanity. The main story is more cinematic and accessible, with a plot that sees the Guardians facing Dominus Ghaul and the Red Legion, an army threatening to destroy Earth and the Light of the Traveler. The campaign is well-structured, offering a clearer narrative arc than the original, with engaging cutscenes and memorable moments that enhance players' understanding of the *Destiny* **** gameplay in *Destiny 2* retains the series' signature fluidity and responsiveness, with precise shooting mechanics and unique abilities for each class. The three main classes—Titan, Hunter, and Warlock—return, each with new subclasses that bring variety and strategic options to combat. PvE content has expanded significantly, with missions, new explorable planets, and activities like Adventures and Lost Sectors that add depth to exploration. Raids remain a highlight of the endgame experience, featuring complex mechanics that demand strong player **** the PvP front, *Destiny 2* offers a wide range of modes, with a 4v4 structure that creates a tighter, more competitive pace. However, the initial progression system faced criticism for a lack of rewards and incentives, which Bungie has improved over time with updates and new expansions.Visually, *Destiny 2* is stunning, with breathtaking environments and rich artistic detail. Each planet has a unique and distinctive aesthetic, and the attention to visual details further elevates immersion. The soundtrack, featuring epic orchestral compositions, adds emotional depth to the game’s key **** essence, *Destiny 2* provides a visually and narratively richer experience, blending polished gameplay with expansive content, making it a standout continuation of the *Destiny* saga.

хороший бесплатный шутер, да разрабы поступили стандартно, игра бесплатная есть донат и платные DLC. но это игру не портит, ведь донат даёт только красивый транспорт или корабль на который большинству игроков плевать. DLC тоже не дают какого-то особого преимущества над другим игроками только премиум валюта, дополнительные битвы локации и собственно дополнительная сюжетная линия которая не так и важна для прохождения основной. так что можно смело скачивать. и да тут есть сюжет в отличии от других подобных многопользовательских шутеров. к сожалению отключить мультиплеер нельзя но никто не будет вам мешать сюжет вы проходите один и только один, игру я ещё не прошел но оставить отзыв обязан хоть и поиграл относительно мало. но этого опыта достаточно чтобы понять стоит играть в эту игру дальше или нет. лично я рекомендую!что могу отметить из хорошего и плохого?хорошее:*мультиплеер не бесит(тупые игроки не могут помешать вам проходить сюжет и квесты)*за хорошую оптимизацию контроллера для ШУТЕРА отдельный респект такое встречаю не часто*no pay to win тоже плюс, хотя по поводу DLC тут можно поспорить*русская озвучка*нет тупой системы лутинга, ты не умрёшь из-за того что у тебя слишком слабое снаряжениеи плохое:*когда текстура одежды багается когда вы садитесь на спэрроу не вся но большинство.но не смотря на всё это игра хорошая. стоит попробовать!

Destiny 2 is a game in a rather rough shape followin (date 12/11/2023) heavy layoffs and the posticipation of the final expansion (which lorewhise was meant to be like marvel's endgame in a place where its infinity war didnt deliver well).
playing this game on its fullest requires roughly an ammount of 180 euros if you want the full fleshed out experience, in a place where doing endgame activities requires a group of people (3 in total for dungeons, 6 for raids), thats rather hard to find in a community that on one side calls the experts elitists with massive egos and one the other views helping new players out a rather big waste of time.
Is destiny 2 worth playing? yes (on pc expecially) despite the downsides a new player has a lot to work with, improving, finding a team/clan and testing themselves on normal and hard versions of interesting raids and (for the more masochist) testing themselves in trials on a pvp ruled by meta ability spam of certain characters, exotics and damn smgs with qa rather **** balancing. (it aint worth it trust me). On a run for normal and adept loot with specific rolls.

Storywhise you have to put a lot of hope on how the story of the final shape expansion delivers, hoping that the season "battle pass" ceazes to exist with the following episodes that will be later introduces. the previous ones were mostly mediocre (apart from the witch queen).
Play this game (which possesses beautiful qualities) only if you ae aware of the risks...

Do not buy Edge of Fate. This is one of the most blatant examples of anti-consumer design I’ve seen in Destiny 2. Bungie removed over half of the activities from the previous season, replaced them with shallow, recycled content, and have been asking players to grind the exact same things on repeat as if that’s “new content.” It got old really quick and that isn’t game design—it’s a cash grab. The focus isn’t on creating a rich, engaging experience for players anymore, it’s on squeezing every cent out of the community. Bungie has shown they don’t value their players’ time, only their wallets.With Sony’s acquisition, there’s hope for change—but right now, Destiny 2 is running on a rinse-and-repeat formula that insults loyal players who’ve supported the game for years. Don’t reward this behavior. Spend your money elsewhere until Bungie shows real respect for its community.

Desgraciadamente, no puedo decir que Destiny 2 valga la pena para jugadores nuevos como yo. La razón principal es que es imposible ponerse al día, no solo por la parte mecánica (he metido muchas horas a Warframe, entiendo que para que un jugador nuevo entre a un juego así y se ponga al día va a necesitar invertir tiempo) sino porque han quitado tanto contenido que literalmente es imposible que nos importe lo que está pasando. Un ejemplo, nos dicen que Cayde-6 está muerto y todo el mundo está tremendamente triste, y entiendo que sea un personaje importante del 1 y el 2, pero como han quitado todo su contenido del juego lo único que podemos hacer es jugar la misión en la que se muere, que falla en tener ningún impacto emocional porque no conocemos al personaje. Y así con todo. Sabía que el vault existía, pero pensaba que habían metido en él cosas laterales, sidequests y demás, pero como han metido campañas enteras, lo que encuentras es un desastre a nivel narrativo que es muy difícil seguir, saber en qué orden hacer, etc. Una de las peores experiencias que he tenido como jugador nuevo en un juego.Y eso que, la parte de combate, las clases, las habilidades, las armas y demás, todo eso es divertido. Bueno, menos las secciones de plataformeo, que son un coñazo ortopédico y parece que les gustan mucho. Pero todo lo demás realmente es muy bueno, y los trozos que te dejan ver de la historia parece un mundo interesante, con buen worldbuilding e ideas chulas. Pero todo eso se pierde bajo la frustración de que la mayor parte de lo que puedes hacer con la parte gratuita del juego es en buena medida irrelevante, carente de razones reales para hacerlo porque no hay ni historia ni nada en muchas de las zonas, etc.Gráficamente el juego está muy bien, el sonido también lo está, y yo la verdad es que me he encontrado muy pocos bugs en las horas que le he metido. Con lo cual a nivel técnico cumple muy **** una lástima que sea este desastre injugable el resultado final, realmente me estaba gustando y estaba bastante decidido a comprarme las expansiones y eso hasta descubrir que en realidad aún con ellas me iba a perder multitud de contenido, historia y demás. Quizás cuando salga Destiny 3 valga la pena entrar, pero como jugador nuevo, la experiencia de entrar al 2 ahora es completamente terrible. Deberían aprender de cómo lo ha gestionado Warframe, que lleva mucho más tiempo de desarrollo, y aún así no priva a ningún jugador de experimentar toda la historia y sus cosas, y gratis además. Así que, en resumen, un 4 que cae aquí, probablmente habría sido una experiencia muy guay cogerlo hace unos años, pero hoy por hoy no.

Despite a rough launch that led to a divebomb of negative reviews just about that, there's plenty of other things that really make you hate it.  
THE FINAL SHAPE LACKS REAL CHARACTER.   The villain is just annoying to see or even hear any wierd ramblings from.  The amazingly beautiful visuals and gunplay are so contrasting to story and overpowered ability spam.   The final shape is a mediocre offbeat soap opera.  The final shape is lucky that no other game is trying a first person live service looter shooter.    

Honestly Zavala, Ikora, and ghost are relatively annoying.  Did you realize that the story mentions some great apocalypse, then the FINAL SHAPE FEELS NOTHING LIKE THAT.  The missions are tedious and have several "gotcha" moments.  A lot of time I feel like I'm just waiting for some dialogue or something to just play out.

The best parts of Destiny's past have been the speaker, Cayde, Savathûn, and Ghaul.  All of the world and feeling of complete power that Savathûn had in the Witch Queen is just gone since then.

The "end game" still boils down to making the same dozen exotics work.  The grind to get perfect gear and eggballs is aweful. The most recent "events" are all based on FOMO and are horrible to play.   I hardly know anyone who could put in the hundreds of hours to complete the 25 lost sectors or 50 runs of onslaught.  The dev team has completely lost touch with their player base.  

Who wants 2 hour long actitives like the recent raid.  It's great for streamers and aweful for friendship.  People get bored repeating fights in a room with wave after wave of stuff spawning in.  The main way to die is to not memorize where things spawn in for their gotcha kills.  

It's going to be the same thing as usual.  Bungie literally gives Destiny expansions and all current FOMO items to all their streamers to keep them streaming it.  This is public knowledge.  In contrast, I keep running into people with 30-100 clears of dungeons and raids without the exotics or main loot.   It's absolutely repetitive to the point that you hate it and has only double downed on that.

If you feel like it's worth a playthrough of the story and not getting the main items of value that it's probably worth getting it for you.  If you are lonely and have nothing going on in life, it's a great opportunity to stay that way and that may be for you.   The final shape really didn't capture a gaming experience and is really hoping that you buy it for nostalgia of what once was a game.
An enormously wasted opportunity from a game that had the potential to be one of the best of all time but once again got hamstrung by greed
a mega piece of junk. created with money-grabbing and fast food junk type of gameplay in mind.
This game is bad. There is absolutely nothing else to say about this sorry ****. This game is just bad.

I did not like Destiny 2. Although my reasons are entirely personal, I just could not get into it. I never liked service model games to start with, and Destiny 2 is no exception.

From the start, I could not care less about the main story of the game. There is a whole universe of lore, story, events, memorable characters etc., but for some reason, I could not give a flying ****. I created my character, finished the tutorial and already felt pointless and bored. Normally I would “educate” the reader of my reviews with a quick recap of the story or main goal, but in this case, I just cared too less.

I played some missions and quests but nothing felt like it mattered. I go to the location, kill stuff, complete the mission, earn my rewards and felt hollow inside afterwards. The thought of repeating this process until I grew to a certain level pained me, and when reaching level ten or so, I was done.

Graphicly, I think Destiny 2 is boring. It is blend, stale and flat. The worst environment with these graphics is the Central Hub location. Weapons and animations look well and polished enough, but the color pallet is just boring.

Sound wise, I think this is one of the worst I have played. Sound effects and music is so generic and dull, and distant enemies do almost not make any sound or grunts at all.

The controls and menus were horrendous and really hard to figure out and understand for me, and the sleek, SQL database design of it did not appeal to me.

Loot was absolutely pointless in my opinion. You get the same weapon or armor twenty million times, but with a different rarity or color. The stats meant nothing to me and I had no freaking clue wat was good and wat was bad. The numbers showed me that an item was way better than the previous one, but when equipping it, I did not notice any difference.

Destiny 2 has a certain “theme/skin/feel” that is the same as games like Anthem or Starfield (in hindsight). It is hard to explain, but revolves about the look of the inventory screens, stat screens, quest markers, etc. It is purely based on the menus and inventory management. For me, that was a problem, because Anthem was one of the worst games I ever played in terms of boredom.

The feeling of a freemium game in which you complete generic missions over and over and over again is just not for me. I constantly got the feeling that I could achieve nothing, unless I pulled out my wallet, although this is technically not the case.

Because the game is “Freemium”, you constantly get confronted with “deals”, “special offers”, “new store items”, and “best values” from the in game store. In the menu’s, at the start screen, at every interactable screen, it just felt like playing a online webstore in a browser. I understand it, because of its model, but I just don’t like microtransactions in games in general and, in hindsight, it is just better for me not to play this kind of games at all.

In conclusion, my own personal experience with Destiny 2 was very miserable. I hated every second of it and was bored out of my mind the second I even started the tutorial.

J'ai eu une mauvaise expérience avec Helldivers 2, mais ils sont majoritairement dûs à l'affreux portage PC qui a de nombreux problèmes très irritants. Le jeu en lui-même est fun entre amis, mais je ne me verrais jamais jouer seul, c'est simplement, car il est très répétitif dans le fond, mais spectaculaire dans la forme. Jouer avec des amis nous fait oublier que c'est la même chose en boucle due au chaos environnant et des moments drôles. Malheureusement, le portage PC apporte des problèmes qui m'ont fait mettre le jeu de côté pendant 1 an. Je n'ai pas une bonne connexion et si le jeu ne détecte plus votre connexion pendant un court instant, il vous déconnectera instantanément voir même ferra crash le jeu. Et si on combine ça avec le fait que les touches clavier sont réinitialisées à chaque lancement, ça devient rapidement insupportable. Cependant, ces problèmes ont été résolus depuis donc je ne peut que le recommander si vous comptez jouer avec des amis.

I have played many shooters. There is an appealing fear factor with RS2. A complete novice can get the drop on you, no matter how experienced you, are as a player. The weapons have real-world recoil and sound. You feel the tracers whiz past your head. My only disagreement with other reviews is that, the Commander is not the most important role. SQUAD LEADER is the most important, as you are on the front, in the trenches with your men, capturing points and painting targets for the Commander...while under fire. Also responsible for digging tunnels for spawning purposes. Without the SQUAD LEADERS, the Commanders have no drops. In my opinion, this is one of the hottest shooters to date. Even with its age, you still have no problem finding a 64/64 brimming with death and destruction. I luv it!

The trend in war based shooters of late is to literally take a blast from the past. Battlefield 1 looked at WW1 and Call of Duty returned to its WWII roots for the most recent game in the series. As such when Rising Storm 2: Vietnam was announced, it seemed like a good progression and one that holds a lot of potential for gamers. The previous game in the series focused on the Pacific Rim conflicts and focused on the conflict with Japan.
This time out the focus is Vietnam and players can opt to fight for either the Vietnamese or U.S. forces and they will also be able to select a class and loadout unique to each side before entering the fray.
The matches I took part in showed off the large and detailed maps which provided plenty of options to flank and enemy or attack from cover. Fields, towns, temples, and more were all an option and I had intense battles in a multi-level building, trenches, fields, and in a town. The weapons were varied but I opted mainly for an M-16 or AK-47 depending on which side I was assigned to. I did have a great opportunity early in the match to ride on a Helicopter and took my position manning one of the machine guns, which allowed us to strafe enemy targets as we traveled.
Our focus was a mix of taking and securing an objective and of course eliminating as many enemies as I could. Using a mix of grenades and rifle shots I was able to dispatch a few enemies but you could tell that there were some seasoned players online who used to the map to their advantage and were masters at striking without being seen.
I also experienced some people who were more than happy to call in a Napalm strike without any concern to the number of friendly troops in the target area. Naturally as you progress you will rank up and have more options for your character and loadouts.
The graphics of the game were solid but did seem a bit dated compared to other shooters. But this does a great job of giving a rough and battle-worn look to the game and not trying to make a blasted and remote area looked like an over-polished presentation.
If you are a fan of team-based online shooters and want some great action in the Vietnam setting; then Rising Storm 2: Vietnam just might be the game for you.
3.5 stars out of 5

Куча багов. еще с убийством и попаданием в врага проблемы. Вышел на челика 5 пуль попал с каллаша, а он выживает и убивает тебя (интересно как). Преготовтесь к тому что вы будете жить меньше минуты т.к постоянные артобстрелы, гранаты, и просто челы из какой нибудь жопы вас убьют. Игру могу посоветовать только любителям вьетнама и реализма (мазохисты). И лучше дождитесь скидок, я ее за 270 рублей взял. Фулл Прайс  она не стоит это точно

Prodeus is an old school classic FPS which takes inspiration from both the Doom and Quake series. It is a pretty good game and a satisfying shooter though is not perfect by a long shot in my opinion. What is best about it is the shooting and the sound design especially when it comes to gunfire sound effects. The level design through a decent amount of missions it provides is almost superb at its best to almost quite **** at its worst. The guns are pretty amazing overall and they are extremely fun to use with some being even better than others. Visually is alright even with the retro thingy that is going for but still I wouldn't exactly say it's anything spectacular. what keeps it down for the most part in my eyes it's a lack of viriety in general whether it's the enemies, the environments, the textures etc. there is not much of any of that really. What annoyed me personally is the respawn system after death which is something similar to bioshock, I could explain why but I will just say that it just doesn't work for me. And the final thing which is not exactly a problem but maybe is worth mentioning is that the game is pretty short, it can get 10 hours give or take to do most things in the game.

Short review: I have three main issues. I noticed after 10 hours of playing that I had never died from an enemy, the difficulty is in finding the ores and the exploration/platforming more than the enemies themselves unlike in Doom where both are difficult. Secondly, I find that finding these ores is incredibly difficult, to the point where I often need to look online for their locations. Even getting the map doesn't help much, as it lacks clarity and is convoluted. The issue is that the store is an integral part of the game, and not getting ores holds you back gameplay-wise. Finally its a little bit repetitive, but I guess this is an inherent/vestigial trait of this sort of old school FPS-style game. Nevertheless, the game is still fun, and the sound design, style, and sfx are great and helps set Prodeus apart from the rest. Shooting feels great too. Finally I like the amount of content there is, and the community maps is a great feature that adds a creative aspect and more replay-ability. It's a simple, fun game to briefly play daily. 76/100.
Doomy Goodness. Really good level design and weapons that truly feels like a part of the series they are trying to emulate.

This might be my favorite boomer shooter of all time! And believe me, I played them all :) I grew up on Doom, Quake etc. But Prodeus is SO MUCH MORE. The levels are cleverly designed and full of secrets. The weapons: there's 16 of them, and most of them are cool, clever (again) and really satisfying to shoot.
The game is great, but the missions are a bit annoying and there is no sound of footsteps

SUPERHOT stands out as an independent game offering a unique shooting experience. The game's distinctive feature is the manipulation of time, where time only progresses when the player moves. This grants the player the ability to slow down time when enemies are shooting or launching attacks.Graphics and Design:Graphically, SUPERHOT adopts a minimalist style. Enemies and the environment are highlighted with red accents on a white background. This design choice enhances the player's focus and strategic thinking.Gameplay:The game allows players to progress through challenging levels filled with formidable enemies. However, thanks to the time-slowing mechanic, players can carefully plan each move and foresee dangerous situations. This provides a different and thought-provoking experience compared to traditional first-person shooter games.Story:SUPERHOT's story transports players into a mysterious virtual reality world. As players attempt to complete a game within this world, they uncover secrets embedded within the game. The story keeps players engaged in an immersive narrative.Shortcomings:Some players might find the short story mode less satisfying, but this is compensated by additional content that enhances the game's replayability.Conclusion:SUPERHOT is a standout game with its unconventional gameplay, impressive design, and challenging levels. The time manipulation mechanic encourages tactical thinking, providing players with a unique shooting experience. If you're looking for a different FPS experience, SUPERHOT is definitely a game worth considering.
Amazing Game                                                                                       .

(Reseña sacada de mi cuenta de Steam: APolChrome) Después de completar la campaña de SuperHot, puedo afirmar que no esperaba encontrarme con un videojuego tan bueno. Un juego simple pero complejo al mismo tiempo. Un juego que me ha sorprendido narrativamente. Un juego que tiene mucho contenido al terminarlo. Un shooter único en su especie vaya. Voy a empezar hablando del gameplay.SuperHot es un shooter que cuando no nos movemos, el tiempo transcurre muchísimo más lento (casi se para), permitiéndonos hacer auténticas virguerías con los enemigos (unos personajes rojos). Ya está. No tiene muchísimas mecánicas, no te atosiga con armas. No. Tú te inventas la forma de pasar los niveles. La cantidad de interacciones es única y es una gozada ver la repetición de un nivel en el que has hecho alguna fantasmada. Aunque el tiempo se pare bastante, se siente muy frenético y nos da una sensación de adrenalina muy **** variedad de armas que hay me ha sorprendido. Tanto que puedes usar hasta objetos del entorno (cosa que se hace muy divertida de ver) para lanzárselos a los enemigos. La mecánica que más me ha gustado ha sido la del HotSwitch. Consiste en que podemos cambiarnos el cuerpo con enemigos para transformarnos en ellos. Parece raro, pero a la hora de la verdad resulta increíble usarla. Ahora bien, esto se usa a partir de la segunda mitad, por lo que me parece que no se aprovecha todo lo que podría, pero el tiempo que se aprovecha, es un 10.Audiovisualmente, me ha gustado. Es un juego muy simple en este apartado, pero ser simple lo hace tan bien que acaba siendo muy bonito. Un estilo artístico muy limpio y unos sonidos muy buenos hacen de este juego una sorpresa en este aspecto.Y la historia me ha encantado. No porque tenga un guión elaboradísimo, sino por las sorpresas que da por el camino. La manera en la que la enfocan y cómo se va torciendo el juego me han fascinado, a parte de que tiene un transcurso muy natural y poco forzado. Aviso que os va a encantar.Resumiendo, SuperHot me ha gustado muchísimo. Es un juego único que creo que todos deberían darle una oportunidad al menos, porque no dejará indiferente a nadie. Un shooter como ninguno en una experiencia como ninguna. Recomendadísimo

Another pay to win card game in the same vein as Hearthstone and Gwent.  If you like Hearthstone but would rather play a card game set in the League of Legends universe then this game is worth checking out.  Be forewarned though, just as with Hearthstone, you'll either have to spend a lot of money up front or spend a copious amount of time playing the game over the coming months to be able to build a competitive deck.  Matchmaking is abysmal and deck balance doesn't exist.

The game seems generous at first with rewards, but you quickly learn that the rewards aren't the powerful cards you really need to compete.  And if you decide you do want to spend money, then I hope you have plenty of cash to burn because it will cost quite a bit to build a competitive deck or two with how the shop is structured.

Card balance and mana costs need a lot of tuning, which is surprising since I would have assumed they would have gotten this more balanced before going live.  Some champions are absolutely broken, Tryndemere springs to mind.  He's insanely powerful and once he's on the field it's a guaranteed win.  Doesn't require any set up or intricate card combinations to pull off, just play him and you win 95% of the time.   That's not well balanced, and that's just one example.

Stay away from this game unless you plan on spending a lot of money, or don't plan on having a competitive deck for several months, because it will take at least that long to build with the reward system currently in place.

Riot also employs Bots in ranked play.

I haven't seen anything like it in years. It's an extraordinary game, a masterpiece in every aspect: design, art, dialogue, gameplay, graphics, characters, etc. Game of the year, without a doubt. It's the best example of how much can be achieved with very little. Studios lack the talent and time to create these works of art. I think it's the game of the decade.

Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 transcends the medium and delivers on every single front. Games time and time again try and fail as they expand in scope - this isn't a diss on any production, but it's more so the reality of development. There is so much to do right, leaving many avenues to invariably mess up on. 

Expedition 33 manages to nail every single thing it attempts to deliver on. Its storytelling is masterful: a shockingly emotionally profound journey woven in the backdrop of grief, love, and family. The soundtrack is just... wow. Visuals are stunning, gameplay is addictive and well polished (a singular inconsequential bug during my entire playthrough). 

Truly a generational experience. I implore anyone, irrespective of whatever games are their typical go-tos, to dive headfirst into it. And this is the studio's first game?? Bravo

Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is a stunning masterpiece. Its painterly aesthetic feels alive, with animations that flow like brushstrokes in motion. The voice acting is exceptional, giving every moment emotional weight. But the real highlight is the innovative combat system—fluid, strategic, and refreshingly original. A rare blend of beauty and brilliance.

Like Chained Echoes, Sea of Stars is a beautifully crafted throwback to the 90s RPG era, complete with all the quality of life improvements that we’d expect in the 2020s. No more random battles, painful level grinding and scattered save points; and as for the old-school ways of turn-based combat, it’s been given some clever twists, including a puzzle-lock system that gives you a chance to stop your opponent’s attack with the right spells.

Where Chained Echoes goes for a very elaborate and epic story full of plot twists, though, Sea of Stars goes for a more intimate and cozy tale of friendship and loyalty between three childhood friends who have a clear enemy to defeat. And whereas Chained Echoes had some fairly sprawling level environments, Sea of Stars has a more compact approach to dungeons, with tight puzzles to solve and pretty varied themes.

I would say overall I preferred Sea of Stars for its moment-to-moment gameplay and Chained Echoes for its story. Both have pacing issues and neither quite manages to reach classic status; still, I enjoyed both a lot and hope their developers will put out even better follow-ups.

Having found myself stuck deep in 1000+ hours with this game, I believed I could say that it is a great game.  

Overall, this game isn't just about warfare; it has within it intrigues, strategies, and some unpredictable plot twists just like in real life! You wouldn't be surprised to find out about why medieval people love to marry their kin and offspring off to some powerful duke or king. Even though it is sufficient enough to play it with the base game, I highly recommend the extension like "Roads to Power" and "Tours and Tournaments," as it would add more varieties and more engaging content to the game.  

The game mechanic is quite good with a great UI; you can play as historical characters such as Kaiser Heinrich V of the HRE or King William the Conqueror (Duke of Normandy) or even the Mongols Borijin dynasty, and if you're up for something new, you can create your own character and rule the land you choose!  

For the mechanics, first let's begin with cultures. Cultures, of course, determine what we are like; If we are Mongols, then we are good at riding horses, and you can challenge your ruler for the throne or vice versa. While some cultures are more advanced, each culture shows different strengths and weaknesses. Next, the religions: there are also many religions unknown to me in this game, so I'd like to mainly talk about Christianity and what's unique about it; The pope will likely declare a crusade around 12th century, and you can either pledge to support it financially or militarily or both; the worst case scenario would be not to support it, as you'll lose piety and prestige. While participating could lead to a gain in prowess, prestige, and gold, you may have to take the risk of losing your knights or heirs in the battle. You can also create your own religion if you'd like to.  

Now, it's the characters time. So, if you choose some of the historical characters within the recommendation, then you will surely have a great stated character. The stats of a character comprise of prestige, diplomacy, intrigue, learning, stewardship, martial, and prowess: I guess the names already give hints of what they do. The higher the stat, the better your character will be at each task; high diplomacy means you can soothe other rulers and may be easier to make friends with them, etc. There is also an education mechanic where you can raise your child to have a certain personality upon their growth period (0-16 years). Choosing guardian can be a hard task, as you must choose according to the baby's traits such as the "Charming" should be studying diplomacy, and the guardian should have a great number of diplomacy stats, etc.  

To conclude, I do urge you to try this game out. It's got everything you'd expect. As an Asian, I don't think you should buy it full price, as lately, this game has been out on lots of discounts, so I do highly recommend you wait until the next promotional period.  

The rating would be 8.5/10.

6/10 + 1 because of the perfectly executed couch coop.
Short: The game with great combat system, but generic setting and the plot that you don't really care about. I loved levelling up, and hated music and visual style.
Longer: What "Divinity: Original Sin" does very well is the combat system. Levelling up is slow and you rarely gain any new skill - and this was a great decision. After a while you perfectly understand every action you may take, its pros and cons. I played the whole game with my wife in a couch coop way and it was a great way to experience this game.
However, I was expecting more from an RPG when it comes to plot and atmosphere. When playing it, I felt like I was playing a hack&slash game with turn-based combat. The atmosphere is dull, generic and the dialogs are poorly written. We either skipped through them or was bored by them. The silly tone both in visuals and in dialogues was more annoying than entertaining.
We also hated the music that was so much anti-climatic. Especially that you have to listen to it over and over again during many many fights.
The quests were designed in clever way, presenting many ways of solving them, using the game elemental interactions. But beware the riddles. I usually love riddles in the games, but most of them in this game, are based on finding a correct object that you don't know that you are looking for.
Overall, it is a good game, but based on reviews I was expecting more. I was constantly comparing it to Pillars of Eternity, which I liked much more. If you want a good gameplay mechanics I encourage you to play "Divinity: Original Sin". But if you are looking for a good RPG, keep away from it.

One of the advantages of wait to buy this game is that now (2019) when bought it, I get two different experiences. I get the classic version and a enchanted version.
It may not seem significant, but it is. They are two distinct experiences of the same fantastic game.

I have not finished the game yet, because it is an immense and challenging game, but honestly I think I will not going to finish it for now, at least on this classic version of the game. Little more than 20 hours of playtrough in the classic version I think I have a good feeling of what the classic version have to offer and going to do the same with the enchanted...

But back to the game, it is simply incredible. Visually, mechanically. A pure role playing game experience, where the roots of the genre were transposed to the maximum.
Fighting for me is the most interesting and challenging element and it is necessary to use the head and the elements that surround us against the enemy.

It is a game of elements where fire, earth, water and air annihilate each other in a perfect circle. Its a game where an "area of effect spell" reaches not only the enemy but the ally in that area. And it's so perfectly done every single way, every moment on every fight.

Those small details are also huge and make this game unique. For me it is a masterpiece of the genre, that I strongly recommend.

Every star stone is kinda a secret in the game, you don't get them that easily. So I'm 90 hours in to the game and now I need to shovel-through the whole 5 areas again in search for these bloody stones. Devs, REALLY!!?? WTF. It's just fckn ridiculous...

Captain Jack dropped us off at a beach instead off at the harbor of Cyseal as the town was besieged by orcs, mostly from the sea. The town, with its sizable harbor, apparently lacked a navy of sorts, which left it at the mercy of the orcish incursions. Well, not quite, for it did have an army called the legion, which would also have failed to defeat the orcs if it hadn't been for some magical crossbows the local hedge wizard had put together.

We didn't really mind to disembark as Jack seemed a bit too much like a pirate with his eyepatch, wooden leg and speech spiced with harrs and yarrs. In fact we were certain he was one as he knew the situation in Cyseal all too well.Since pirates prey on local shipping by hiding out in coastal waters, it stands to reason that they are perfectly aware of the comings and goings of ships and people in that harbor and the associated opportunities and dangers. Anyway, he was crash enough to tell us about the plight of the town only when we were about to reach it and proposed ditching us on a beach as if he was offering us a way out. We suspected that the only other option would have been walking the plank.

We were source hunters. Source was a thing that sourcerers used to power whatever needs powering. Actually we forgot the last part as we were stuck thinking about sourcerers/sorcerers thing. Somewhere a guy behind a screen in a universe far away thought this brilliant or hilarious and he was even able to convince some other guys in other rooms of that fact. It is indie and therefore it is excusable we were informed.

Somewhat further inland we ran into a dead guy. The note on his corpse informed us that some statues convinced him that he could fly. Apparently he took some time to write this down, either before or during his leap of faith. We suspected foul play as it was far more likely that he was killed and then the perpetrator took time to cover this up by planting this note on him.  It is that level of (N)CIS writing we are talking about. We found out later that nothing of the sort happened; he actually did write the note(!).  But at that point we actually didn't really care one way or another as we were not the law in those parts, in fact we soon found out.. nobody was.

After an encounter with a poetic shell(the only highlight) and some undead summoned by some guy which we dealt with by summoning stuff of our own, we encountered two drunk soldiers, then ran into a group of orcs headed by a mysterious man, which would have made mincemeat of us if  three sober soldiers had not taken care of them for us.

Finally we reached the town Cyseal which was noteworthy because of three things. The first were the dozens, nay hundreds, of barrels, chests, caskets, baskets filled with random content running from nothing to incredible powerful, if you happen to require stats improvements for two stats that are diametrically opposed. The second thing were quests that started someplace, continued at another place, without being clear how to go for one place to the other, and then earned you a trifle experience if you finished them. The last was that exiting the town on the other side too soon resulted in instant death as you need at least one or two levels and be equipped with some good stuff to beat even the three undead lurking on the outskirts. And once we did have that we found out that our gear deteriorated at such a rapid pace that we had to repair our gear every second battle.

Furthermore we ran into an imp called ZixZax who was the historian of all events in time, which was really funny, if we had been eight perhaps, a morai who had migrated out of the Greek legends(or a norn out of the Norse mythology) and dozens of more stuff stolen from history, mythology and stories that hailmark this game as superior uninspired as it comes to storytelling, which would not even be so bad if it just had added something original to it, like a twist instead of a silly play of words.
At this point we gave up and went to read a book or watch a movie or redo tombraider.

Original Sin is a LRPG. A looting role play game which is the wet dream for anyone who wants a nickname that spells micromanagement. You get to loot and loot some more and do that save-before-opening-the-random-chest-and-reload-if-it-doesn't-give-you-anything-worthwhile thing. The loot only marginally improves you scores as does the leveling. The whole thing is aimed at having you spend most of you time on deciding things like: should I use this dexterity +1 and strength +1 / + 10 % poison resistant sword or this speed +1 and intelligence +1 club with double durability? Only to find out  weapons either break two battles later or have become worthless after you progress one or two levels. But if you do not micromanage: prepare to die. A lot.

Apparently.. this is what what the people who kickstarted this game wanted.
Have fun guys!

Tried game for one hour. The combat is insipid, slow, and thoughtless. Combat is turn based. If this game played like Dungeon Siege, it would have been awesome, but, it does not. The good graphics does not save this game. As a hero, you feel pretty weak and the characters are fragile compared to the enemies. The combat is painfully slow, it takes 10-15 minutes to fight 3 -6 skeletons! Your spells and abilities seem only to pinch the enemies and the enemies heal 2 turns worth of your attacks in one turn. The enemies are also very spread out so you are walking around a lot with nothing to look at except the map. This game absolutely is a chore to play, and is not fun. Don't listen to the hype, this game ****.

Хорошая игра для любителей серии по Гарри Поттеру. Сюжет средний, саид квесты главных персонажей нормальные. А вот доп квесты вообще интереса не вызывали, за исключения одного квеста. Боёвка раскрывается только на позднем этапе, когда все заклинания уже выучены. Музыка хорошая. Мировая карта однообразная, её вообще не интересно изучать. Вивари и выручай комнату интересно изучать и делать всякие постройки и разводить всяких животных, жаль что их так мало.

Diese Spiel gibt einen tollen einblick in den Schulaltag der Schüler*innen von Hogwarts, es ist äuserst schon gestaltet und hat viel kleine deteils und anspillungen auf die Welt von Harry Potter. Allerdings ist es sehr Nervig am nachdem man den Endboss besiegt hat weitere 6 Level zu Farmen um die letzte Mission freizuschalten, das klingt zwar nach nicht viel ist aber totstem sehr nervig vorallen da man nach der letzten Hauptmission trotzdem noch weiter spielen- und somit das spiel auf 100% bringen kann. Das wäre sogar gut und nicht schlecht wenn man nicht nach dem Endboss noch mindestens 10 Stunden Leveln müste. Das ist vörallem nervig wenn man nach dem Endboss das spiel einfach nur noch beennden möchte, das geht sogar so weit das zumindestens ich am ende unr noch genärft da sahs und einfach nur dieses level ereichen wollte und das sollte ja auch nicht sinn der sache sein. Empfehlen würde ich es Trotstem da mir die Zeit vor und werdend des Endbosses äuserst gut gefallen haben.

I've never been a Harry Potter fan, never read the books or watched the movies or paid much attention to it. It just never interested me. I prefer  GOT. But I did watch gameplay of this game and it interested me as I could create and play as my own **** world is so amazing, unique, wondrous and creative. Interesting to explore at **** Castle is the most interesting to explore. Everywhere else seems like a repetitive boring after thought and wasn't necessary and would of preferred if they put more focus and effort into making NPC's more interesting in dialogue, interactions and choices.Combat is done well even though it lacks enemy **** story is sort of ok.I do like exploring and trying to solve and complete things, but the puzzles and objectives are a bit too repetitive and rather dull. And there is too much of going back and forth as everything is gated behind skills that you get gradually. It took a long time trying to find all 95 Merlin trials and complete all challenges. I got all Revelio pages but it's so boring trying to find and complete the collection, so don't think I'll bother as it feels like a torturous waste of time.I don't like how you can only sell gear, you can't sell potions or materials. Even when you get your own shop. But even so I had so much money left even after buying all seeds, potion recipes and all the items you could for your room.Beast breeding is a bit disappointing the offspring doesn't grow up. All you can do is sell them to the beast shop. So no breeding different mounts or anything fun like that.I feel the game needs much better content. The conversations and narrative are boring, bland and weak. The game encourages you to converse with the professors  but what they say isn't interesting at all. I didn't find the characters interesting at all either. And it feels like the professors talk to you like you are a moron. It seems like this games speech is more catered towards young children than adults. It doesn't feel like a good open world game. It's an alright game. The game play doesn't feel very meaningful. I only kept playing as I am a bit OC about trying to complete a game and I will keep playing an alright game as long as I don't absolutely hate it.I didn't have any technical issues and only minor stuttering in some areas besides the  over bright lighting in treasure vaults making it impossible to see during the day which is an issue caused by a previous patch. This game is a bit too simplistic and seems it's made more for children.I like the castle, Hogwarts is enthralling and it's creatures. Riding around on a broom is fun and love when you finally get a beautiful hippogriff. Summoner's court was fun and it would of be nice if we could play it as much as we like. Everything else is sort of ok to rather meh and the most pointless and boring is most conversations as whatever you decide doesn't affect anything.I'd rate it 7/10. As needs better narrative, characters and deeper more diverse compelling gameplay.

25hours - Really good game but the performance is really bad, specially the big bosses. I had to lower the graphics settings to the lowest just for the final boss to be playable, and even still there were stutters on EVERY move the boss made. The world, combat and story are 9/10s.

It is a beauty, it seems that you are playing in a diorama the art is simply beautiful, each story makes you feel that you connect with each character and each ending is convincing and leaves a good taste in your mouth and invites you when you finish it to continue exploring its world, a must buy.

Just wonderful, little gem that I recommend to anyone! it is very reminiscent of the Final Fantasy of the 90s, excellent for those who have not lived through those times and excellent for those who are nostalgic for that type of work, I think it should not be missed.

Octopath Traveler II tells us that we don't need to be a superstar in order to bring hope to people. If you can make even just one person smile, you've accomplished something incredible and they will be a ray of happiness to you in return.

It conveys the idea that anyone can lose their way if they let their own pain taint their actions, and that it can be difficult to get out of that state of mind without a helping hand. Being patient with such a person in a time of need may blossom into a lifelong bond. Saving someone from their inner turmoils and giving them a chance to get back on their feet is a worthwhile endeavor.

It urges us to seek our own path, for we can never be truly free when adhering to someone else's expectations unwillingly. Sometimes, if your words fall on deaf ears, the only option left is to remove that person from your life.

It encourages us to be good to people, with no ulterior motive, and not to be insecure when challenged by misguided individuals who perform irrefutably malevolent deeds. If you let yourself be swayed by someone who acts with hatred, resentment or jealousy in their heart, you can quickly become just as lost as they are. It also reminds of the importance of patient critical thinking over immediate emotional response.

It even manages to tackle the topic of technological advancement and the need for wealth redistribution as new things get invented that improve the efficiency of production. After all, if knowledge exists to be shared with all, dough shouldn't just be hoarded either.

It is a tale about enjoying the simple pleasures of life, and spreading warmth and happiness around us.

~ ~ ~

This game is more than everything I had hoped for in a sequel to the first game. Much of the praise I had for that game also applies here, so I won't repeat all of the things Octopath Traveler II took from the first game that didn't need to be fixed, but let's dive into the ways in which it improves upon the original.

Improvements to the skills make it so there are much more ways to break enemies, and classes have been rebalanced in a way that feels like they all complement each other even better than before. The new Latent Power and EX Skills also make each character have a stronger identity in combat, and there is now a way to equip the same sub-class onto more than one character if you want to.

This series continues to have best-in-class music. As catchy as it is epic, as comforting as it is melancholic. Most of it is new, but a couple of melodies from the first game made a return in remixed fashion, striking a chord of nostalgia within me while strengthening the continuity of the series. It gave me the sentiment that these eight new travelers were experiencing emotions that the characters from the first game had also felt on their journey, despite having completely different stories. This is just one example of Team Asano's masterful understanding of emotion. Emotions are not unique; if it's a real emotion, then anyone can relate to it, because we are all human. Hearing those melodies again made me feel those intended emotions twice as strongly, as I thought of my past adventures in the continent of Orsterra as well as my current ones in Solistia.

Something I love about this series is how much the story feels like it ties into the gameplay and vice versa, and they went above and beyond this time to give us some jaw-dropping moments with the path actions at the end of each story. They somehow even managed to weave in the new day/night cycle mechanic into the plot.

The world is even more fun to explore due to the addition of boats and the way the map is less predictable to navigate. I think there are also more bosses to defeat, or at least they are spread out better. I still recommend equipping the Evasive Maneuvers scholar skill to reduce the encounter rate, making it just right as you explore. The chapters are also less formulaic this time around, making it so you don't know for sure what to expect from a given chapter. The post-game is much expanded as well, with some fully voiced side-quests that let you see what happened to some important characters in the story. Speaking of, the Japanese voice acting performances are absolutely fantastic and full of life.

The new cross paths really help tie everything together. And when I say everything ties together in the end, I mean it. Also, in the first game, a lot of the camaraderie between your party members came from your own imagination and roleplay. I'm glad that aspect is still present throughout the game, but there's a lot more jerky around the bone this time around, if you will. The final segment of the game made everyone feel even closer than I imagined my party in the first game to be, boosting the affection I have for these characters even more.

As the end approached, I didn't want to say goodbye. I'm grateful for this warm feeling... thank you for traveling with me.

A significant improvement to the original and a perfect example that stunning graphics aren't all that a video game needs (although the stylization of this game will love a timeless vibe). if you aren't a fan a traditional JPRGs, than they may not be the game for you. However, if you grew up on Final Fantasy games before they reach their double digits there is a wonderful adventure to find here. Although its emulates it's older JRPG predecessors too much sometimes (this script needs and editor) the strong gameplay and soundtrack of the Octopath series continues to shine. I have my gripes with the game, such as the story to gameplay ratio at times, however this is still a 10/10 for me. As a long time JRPG fan from the 80s & 90s, I look forward to Asano's next creations as a creator who doesn't make perfect products, but makes products perfect for my niche.
Jogo bom pra caralho. Me ajudou a copar com situações semelhantes na vida real. A beleza desse jogo é absurda. Existem momentos que você simplesmente para e pensa: "Puta que pariu".
Ein sehr schönes, aber sehr kurzes Spiel mit nur maximal 3h Spielzeit, wenn man es das erste Mal durchspielt. Artistisch sehr gelungen und die Message kommt auch sehr gut durch.

Diante de tanta beleza e sentimento, não tem como reconhecer o grande mérito por trás de toda a direção artística e musical. Me tirou em mais de uma vez calafrios, porém, poderia ser algo muito maior. Senti como se fosse uma demo de um futuro projeto, e isso me deixou um pouco decepcionado, algo muito parecido com o que é o jogo: Sky Children of the Light.
Excelente juego de plataformas. Muy intuitivo. Los puzzles no son imposibles aunque si te llevan un tiempo.  La banda sonorame parece impresionante.

N'étant pas fan de la série des Yakuza, je suis allé vers ce dernier volet sans avis favorable. Le jeu s'avère très prenant et très riche dans les possibilités que l'on a de s'occuper (une floppée de mini jeux en tout genre, allant même jusqu'à intégrer un jeu de kart et de gestion d'entreprise ). Les personnages et l'histoire sont plutôt prenant bien que parfois les scènes trainent en longueur (le gnan-gnan japonais dans toute sa splendeur). Les combats sont plutôt faciles et répétitifs, sauf les derniers boss qui donnent enfin du fil à retordre. Le jeu reste une très bonne expérience, rien que pour la balade dans ce japon citadin et contemporain.

Wegen GameTwo habe ich mir mein erstes Yakuza Game geholt und es war absolut witzig und hatte eine herausragende Story, enorm viel Humor, aber auch sehr ernst und emotional. Man kann hier eine echt klasse gemachte Spielwelt, super Szenen und nicht vorhersehbare & schockierende Storywendungen erleben!Kasuga ist mir als etwas auf dem Schlauch stehender und extrem gutmütiger Ex-Yakuza einfach enorm ans Herz gewachsen und ich freue mich deswegen schon sehr auf Infinite Wealth und hoffe auch viele weitere Like a Dragon Teile!Die Teammitglieder sind auch klasse und es wird viel auf sie eingegangen, sie haben ihre eigenen persönlichen Momente in der Story und abseits davon eine Art Charakterstory freispielbar, die nochmal etwas vertiefter ins Persönliche **** Gameplay ist dynamischer als andere Games dieser Art, nach einigen hundert Kämpfen dann aber iwann doch zu viel, ich konnte auch Mabutchi nicht besiegen, obwohl ich immer alle Nebenquests und Heldenaufträge gemacht habe, bevor ich den nächste Storyschritt angegangen bin. Das Level-Grinden sehe ich als einzige Schwachstelle des Spiels!

Gioco che merita parecchio,ottima storia anche se sembra troppo diluita soprattutto alcuni dialoghi secondari, ottimo il **** principale cosi come quelli secondari, ci sono tantissime attività secondario che non annoiano (tranne la gestione dell'azienda) il combattimento a turni potrebbe infastidire i vecchi fan della serie Yakuza, gioco divertentissimo pieno di battute e scene surreali

Gioco che merita

I had reservations about Yakuza no longer being a story-based brawler, but this is honestly one of the best Japanese role-playing games I've played in years. There's a fun job system, reminiscent of the ones you'd find in the older Dragon Quest games. Tongue-in-cheek callbacks to other popular JRPGs are everywhere, from direct references to Dragon Quest to more subtle nods like the "New Age Hippie" that was one of the sillier enemies in Earthbound.

The story is just about what you'd expect from Yakuza; the main plot is a somewhat more serious crime drama, while the subplots are every bit as zany as the ones in Kazuma Kiryu's adventures in the previous games. One of the best modern RPGs I've had the pleasure of playing.

I remember when this game came out and all world play it. I remember many streamers play it and others continued to play it a long time after its released. By seen it on streams I never got why it was so popular. Some things in the game mighty confuse you when you see it such: The hack system game play or the air gameplay with the robot. 
The time past and I play games like "Final Fantasy online" which was the best mmorpg I ever tried and the time for "Nier Automata" has come for me even a bit late. 
The game is probably the most beautiful game I have ever played and one of the most emotional. Literally the game reach the perfection on any part such: gameplay, story, soundtrack, artwork, characters, boss fighting. All touch the perfection for me and in every city I discovering it was a real expierence for me. All it was so beautiful and the game has something to put you inside. How you move the char and you feel it. Is like you really you are inside in this place and feel all these things around you.
I never expected to play and saw such a game and taste such perfection.This game has many things to offer and is one of the few games out there that is for everyone. Every person can play it and admire it as it deserves. I wish I can put higher ratings for such a masterpiece
NieR's story is a masterpiece when you get to the true ending

Personally, my expectation from an RPG game is definitely having combo mechanics in combat. In my opinion, this was one of the biggest shortcomings of Nier. When we look at other RPG games like Devil May Cry or Final Fantasy, we see that they do this very well. We experience combat at its peak with dozens of combo mechanics. Nier, on the other hand, only offers us 2 different attack options and doesn't really showcase the combo differences between weapons. For example, I didn't see much animation difference between swords. I don't know. Nier disappointed me in this regard, although the combat animations are quite nice. The second issue is the insufficient variety of enemies. I don't call the same robot with some metal scraps added on top and its level increased a different type of enemy. Another issue is the environment design; I really didn't expect it to be this weak. If you want to understand what I mean, just look at the Abandoned City map. That's all I have to say. This game, which has the potential to be much better and to enter the top 10 of the greatest RPG games, has been left in the lurch. It's sad that it is so little known even with 2B's influence. When I ask anyone around me, I hear that the only reason they play this game is 2B. It actually explains a lot...

Not your Casual Masterpiece.
This game is mind breaking, multiple endings,amazing philosophy, great combat mechanics and to top it all an eargasm of a music.
This game is not just a games its a masterpiece of an art.

Don't Starve is a survival video game developed by Klei Entertainment. The game follows a scientist named Wilson who finds himself in a dark, dreary parallel world known as the Constant and must survive as long as possible. To this end, the player must keep Wilson alive, fed, and mentally stable as he avoids a variety of surreal and supernatural enemies that will try to kill and devour him. The game's Adventure mode adds depth to the sparse plot and pits Wilson against the game's supposed antagonist, Maxwell.
The art design is AWESOME. It's a lot of fun with its survival mechanics and variety of characters.

Assume the role of Wilson, an intrepid Gentleman Scientist who has been trapped by a demon and transported to a mysterious wilderness world. Wilson must learn to utilize his environment and its inhabi

Completé el 78% del juego en un total de 30 horas y 58 minutos sin mirar guías ni nada. Estuvo muy divertido. Lo que más me gustó del juego fue el movimiento por el mapa, es bastante fluido al igual que su combate.

no geral o jogo é bom mas tem partes meio chatas como o diário do caçador e fazer 100% no modo alma de aço mas no geral ele é bom
fora a historia maravilhosa arte legal mas não afeta (os gráficos a historia é no máximo um ponto forte) e sua dificuldade é balanceada ou media até com uma exploração magnífica essa é a minha review

Hollow Knight es un 10/10 absoluto. Un metroidvania con una jugabilidad precisa y desafiante, una banda sonora que se queda grabada en la memoria y una atmósfera inolvidable, reforzada por un diseño artístico fenomenal. Team Cherry creó una obra maestra que no solo redefinió el género Metroidvania, sino que también se consolidó como un referente indiscutible, ganándose un lugar entre los mejores videojuegos de todos los tiempos.

Una reseña no es suficiente para describir lo que este juego ha hecho por los metroidvania, belleza de juego por donde lo mires, el movimiento esta pensado al minimo detalle, como una escultura griega, ningún otro juego se le compara a lo que hizo team cherry el momento en el que se les cruzo por la mente crear semejante juego y no, no es glazing, bueno un poco si la verdad
Une expérience globalement satisfaisante. J’ai passé un bon moment du début à la fin.

A truly unique indie RPG with good music, interesting combat and a story that will keep you guessing with its creepy, funny and interesting moments. Avoid story spoilers at all costs!

If you like RPG maker games, Classic NES/SNES JRPGS, and games that take you to fantastical locations go play OMORI!

Enchanting world. Beautiful music and artistic direction that fit the themes. This game would be a 10 IF the combat gameplay were better. Sure it makes sense thematically and it's clever in the way that abilities are used to give insight in the characters, but in practice it ends up being tedious. I still had some challenging and fun fights though!

Feelings! If feelings and heartache is what you look for, Omori is the game to play. Amazingly well done, many layers of meaning and extra stuff to find.
The gameplay is nice enough: turnbased like. Altough, evidently, the battle system is not the core aspect of the game.. it is preety good, you have reasons to change your buils, select which skills to equip and make up your strategy.. it is not meant to be challenging, but is not naive either! I like it for this.
The world is really nice and the design s AMAZING..only downside, and that is a great downside.. is that the main quests are really dispersive and often you wish that there were more main quests but shorter (because you end up losing interest). But that is the only negative aspect of the game. That being said, play the game to feel it not to rush it, experience it and it will talk to you
Absolute masterpiece, made me cry, i don't any words other than "masterpiece" to describe this piece of art
The story is phenomenal. This game made me think about what I really want in life. its tear-jerking and eye-opening experience

The game is truly amazing, there is some slight flaws about the blinking mechanic when using the camera, but just here and there if you follow the guide on how to set it up correctly.
The story is incredible for a game like this, truly eye opening and emotional.
100% recomend to anyone who is reading the reviews to just buy the game and play it without knowing anything about the story.

There aren’t words to describe how beautifully crafted this game is. Everything from the storyline, to the animation, to the background music is perfect. The story is heart wrenching from the very beginning, and the twist is absolutely ****. Though there’s only about an hour to ninety minutes of play time, it’s well worth downloading. Would definitely recommend to anyone, although caution to anyone who cry’s easily, I spent literally the whole time crying. If I had to think of one issue I had with the game it would be the eye tracking, sometimes it was a little too sensitive and would sense a blink when I moved my mouth or hand, overall i’d like to underline that I really did love this game
A game that makes you say 'I can speedrun' The mechanics are very clever. The game draws you in more and more.

Neon White is quite possibly the single most replayable game of all time. The movement is absolutely fantastic, the skips and new strategies you can take to improve your time is addicting. I genuinely cannot recommend this game enough to anybody.

Life Is Strange es un juego de estilo novela grafica, quizá algo mas evolucionada. A nivel de historia es muy bueno, casi impresionante con escenas para el recuerdo. El arte y la musica no se quedan atrás, bastante buenos. Cuando lo jugué en su año de lanzamiento recuerdo que me impacto bastante y ahora que lo revisito me parece simplemente fenomenal, con esos aires de innovación (aunque ya no tanto) que hacen comprender por que es tan valorado en la comunidad. Una maravilla en el cual su punto fuerte es la historia. El punto menos fuerte seria su jugabilidad, que se siente muy pesada para el desplazamiento, aun cuando la versión remastered según es mas rápido el desplazamiento, a mi se me hace demasiado lento, mas de lo que el juego requiere.

Every moment of this game made me feel good and comfortable. Every time I played it, I tried to play one episode per day so I could fully enjoy it and make it last longer.

This game is really underrated. I thought the story was amazing and because of the interactions I focused even more then I would whilst watching TV which made it even better. I really loved all the characters and found them all interesting. The game can be slow at times but even during them moments I never lost interest because the story still was moving forward at a good pace.

A couple of things that I didn't like was that the game was way to easy. I know it focusing on Story telling but still would have been nice if on the odd occasion something challenged you like QTEs (Quick time events) or some harder puzzles. A couple missions were kind of detective sort of thing but they were mostly self explanatory.
Another thing that was frustrating but not really an issue with the actual gameplay. For some reason when I 1st installed the game it kept crashing after completing chapter 1 and loading chapter 2. I tried verifying files (Xbox App) and that didn't fix the issue. When I reinstalled it was fine thou. Mite have been a corrupt file or something. It was saying something about a UE4 siren but no error code.
Another thing to note was that throughout the hole game I was getting random screen tearing during cutscenes. I tried messing about with video settings but nothing solved the problem. Apparently it is just an issue with the game. Its annoying thou cos the game has been out half a year and this should be fixed.

Overall the game is amazing and I really enjoyed it. If you enjoy slow pace story games then you should give it a go!
Muito bom isso aí simplesmente sensacional bom do começo ao fim, tem uma Partes parada mas outra q por serem bem carregada emocionalmente prendem sua atenção de uma forma sem igual

I liked most of the characters from True Colors from the start. Even if one or the other cliché was served here, I found the characters written interesting and I enjoyed following their stories.
The main story itself is neither particularly innovative nor offers many surprises. Still, I liked the way the story was told and it makes you think about it even after you've finished. It changes from sad to happy situations without exaggerating them.

Unfortunately, there are hardly any decision-making options and if there are any, they have little effect, but that didn't bother me personally.

As usual in Life is Strange, you spend most of your time walking around, talking to other people and listening to monologues about things. The last one could have been shortened to a more bearable level for my taste. At least it gives you a bit more context sometimes.

If you don't like games like this, which focus very much on the story and offer hardly any gameplay, you won't be happy with True Colors. Otherwise, I can highly recommend the game because it was a wonderful gaming experience for me, which deals with difficult topics in an unobtrusive way and still leaves you with hope and a good feeling.
